Ramban on Exodus

Introduction

‘V’EILEH SHEMOTH’ (AND THESE ARE THE NAMES OF…)<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew names for the books of the Bible are generally taken from the first words in the Hebrew text. Thus the name <i>“V’eileh Shemoth”</i> for this second book of the Torah, or just <i>“Shemoth,”</i> as it is now known. In the Talmud it is known as <i>Chomesh Sheini</i>, the “Second Fifth” of the five books of the Torah (Sotah 36 b). The English name Exodus stems from the Septuagint, the first Greek translation of the Bible, and is based on the fact that the first fifteen chapters deal with the exodus from Egypt.</i> In the Book of Genesis, which is the book of Creation, the Torah completed the account of how the world was brought forth from nothingness and how everything was created, as well as an account of all the events which befell the patriarchs, who are a sort of creation to their seed.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary on the Book of Genesis, Ramban develops this theme at great length. See Index to Vol. I, p. 618, Patriarchs.</i> All the events that happened to them were symbolic occurrences, indicating and foretelling all that was destined to come upon their seed. After having completed the account of creation, the Torah begins another book concerning the subject that had been alluded to in those symbolic events [recorded in the Book of Genesis].
The Book of V’eileh Shemoth was set apart for the story of the first exile,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Four exiles were decreed. The first one was in Egypt. See Index to Vol. I, p. 613, Exile.</i> which had been clearly decreed,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13.</i> and the redemption therefrom. This is why He reverted and began [this second book of the Torah] with the names of those persons who went down to Egypt, and mentioned their total number,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 5 here: <i>And all the souls … were seventy souls</i>.</i> although this had already been written.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:8-27.</i> It is because their descent thereto constituted the beginning of the exile, which began from that moment on.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The exile thus did not begin with the actual enslavement of the Israelites by the Egyptians; rather it started with their very descent into Egypt. Hence here at the beginning of the book of the exile, the Torah uses the same verse found in the Book of Genesis where the actual account of the descent is given, in order to indicate that the exile began at that point. See also Ramban on Genesis 46:2 (Vol. I, p. 553), where he alludes to this thought. Ramban makes further reference to it here in Verse 1.</i>
Now the exile was not completed<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is now aiming to explain why the second book of the Torah, which as explained above is the book of the first exile and the redemption therefrom, does not close with the actual exodus or with the Revelation on Sinai, but instead proceeds with the account of the building of the Tabernacle. Ramban’s answer is most illuminating and inspiring.</i> until the day they returned to their place<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Hosea 5:15.</i> and were restored to the status of their fathers. When they left Egypt, even though they came forth from the house of bondage, they were still considered exiles because they were <i>in a land that is not theirs</i>,.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13.</i> entangled in the desert.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 14:3.</i> When they came to Mount Sinai and made the Tabernacle, and the Holy One, blessed be He, caused His Divine Presence to dwell again amongst them, they returned to the status of their fathers when <i>the ‘sod eloka’ (counsel of G-d) was upon their tents</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 29:4, and Ramban’s commentary thereon, (in my Kithvei Haramban: Vol. I, p. 90), where he interprets the verse as follows: “Job is saying that <i>sod eloka</i> — the counsel of G-d - was known in his tent, as if He foretold all future events. Thus Job and all who were with him were guarded from mishaps and troubles. It may be that <i>sod eloka</i> is a reference to the angels of the Supreme One and the host of the heavens that dwelled upon his tent to guard him from all evil, etc.” Ramban is thus intimating here that the complete redemption of the Israelites from their first exile was not achieved until they were restored to the same position held by the patriarchs. Whereas the Divine Presence rested upon the tents of the patriarchs — see Shabbath 55b, where Rashi clearly states that before the building of the Tabernacle, the Divine Presence was to be found upon the tents of the righteous — so Israel regained its original status only when the Divine Glory came to rest upon the Tabernacle at the time of its completion. See end of Book of Exodus. It is for this reason that the second book of the Torah — devoted as it is to the first exile and the redemption therefrom — continues with the account of the building of the Tabernacle.</i> and “they were those who constituted the Chariot of the Holy One.”<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 47:8. See Vol. I, p. 224.</i> Then they were considered redeemed. It was for this reason that this second book of the Torah is concluded with the consummation of the building of the Tabernacle, and the glory of the Eternal filling it<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:35.</i> always.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 9:16: <i>So it was always: the cloud covered it…</i></i>





Chapter 1



Verse 1

AND THESE ARE THE NAMES OF …. The meaning [of the connective <i>vav — v’eileh</i>, (‘and’ these are) — when it would have sufficed to say, “These are the names of …,”] is that Scripture desires to reckon the subject of the exile from the time they went down to Egypt. It was then that they were <i>the first of the exiles to go into exile</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 6:7.</i> as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 7 above.</i> It is for this reason that He returns to the beginning of the subject [stated in the Book of Genesis], which is the verse, <i>And all his seed he</i> [Jacob] <i>brought with him into Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:7.</i> There it is written afterward, <i>And these are the names of the children of Israel, who came into Egypt</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> This is the very same verse that He repeats here. Even though they are two separate books, the narrative is connected with subjects which follow one another successively. Here, once He mentioned the children of Jacob, He adopted a concise approach to his children’s children and all of his seed [and did not mention them by name as He had done in the Book of Genesis]. Rather, He alluded to them only generally, just as He had said there, <i>All the souls of the house of Jacob, that came into Egypt, were threescore and ten</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27. In the same way He said here in Verse 5: <i>And all the souls that came out of the loins of Jacob were seventy souls</i>.</i><br>A similar case is found in the Book of Chronicles and the Book of Ezra. The Book of Chronicles finishes with the verse: <i>Now in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the Eternal by the mouth of Jeremiah might be accomplished, the Eternal stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, that he made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom, and put it also in writing, saying: Thus saith Cyrus king of Persia, etc</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 36:22-23.</i> The author repeated the very language of these two verses at the beginning of the Book of Ezra in order to connect the narrative. However, since they were indeed two books, he completed the first book, [i.e., the Book of Chronicles], with the events that transpired before the building of the Second Sanctuary, and he devoted the second book, [i.e., the Book of Ezra], to the events that happened from the time of the building [of that Sanctuary].<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s thesis apparently is that Ezra himself completely authored the two books, Chronicles and Ezra. See, however, Baba Bathra 15a, where it is stated, “Ezra wrote his book and the genealogy of Chronicles up to himself.” This would seem to indicate that only the first chapters of the Book of Chronicles, which deal with the genealogical tables, were written by Ezra, but not the other parts of the book. The key to the understanding of Ramban’s words must lie therefore in grasping his intent, i.e., that Ezra connected the Book of Chronicles with his own book by using the restoration-edict of Cyrus as the linking material, with the object of bringing out the continuity of the events during the two Sanctuaries.</i> The same thing occurs in these two books, Bereshith and V’eileh Shemoth.
Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that because He mentioned at the end of Bereshith [50:23] that Joseph <i>saw children of the third generation</i> to his children, this is why He mentioned [here in the second book] that his brethren likewise were at first few and then were fruitful and multiplied. But this is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban did not explain the reason for his rejection of Ibn Ezra’s interpretation. I found this in Isaac Abarbanel’s (1437-1508) Commentary on the Torah, where he offers the following explanation for Ramban’s rejection: “The reason for it is that in the Book of Genesis, the Torah has already mentioned each one of the twelve tribes, their children, and their children’s children, who went down into Egypt. And this is far more than the mere names of the tribes He mentioned here. Besides, it would have sufficed to say here, <i>And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly</i>, thus informing us of their great increase, and not just mentioning the names of the tribes. Moreover, in my opinion, if Ibn Ezra’s interpretation be correct, it would not have been necessary here to include Joseph as it did in Verse 5, since he had been mentioned already at the beginning of this topic, [i.e., at the end of the Book of Genesis]. Moreover, the division of the chapters refutes Ibn Ezra’s opinion.”</i><br>Rashi wrote: “Although Scripture had already enumerated them whilst they were living, it again enumerates them by name, following their death, in order to show how they were beloved by G-d. They are compared to the stars which G-d also brings out by number and brings in by number,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi: “Which G-d also brings out and brings in by number and name.”</i> as it is said, <i>He bringeth out their host by number, He calleth them all by name</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:26. “It is for this reason that He mentions the names of the tribes always and repeats them, all for the sake of showing how dear they are to G-d” (Bachya).</i> These are words of homiletic exposition,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:3.</i> and insofar as they indicate the love of G-d for the tribes — how the Holy One, blessed be He, loves them and repeats their names always — they are words of truth. But the matters of the connection of the verses and how they are joined by the <i>vav</i> — [<i>v’eileh shemoth — (‘And’ these are the names of…)</i>] — is as I have explained.

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

COME, LET US DEAL WISELY WITH HIM. Pharaoh and his wise counsellors<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 19:11.</i> did not see fit to slay them by the sword, for it would have been a gross treachery to smite without reason a people that had come into the land by command of a former king. The people of the country also would not give the king consent to commit such perfidy since he took counsel with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">As it says in Verse 9: <i>And he said unto his people…</i></i> and all the more so since the children of Israel were a numerous and mighty people and would wage a great war against them. Rather, Pharaoh said he would do it wisely so that the Israelites would not feel that it was done in enmity against them.<br>It is for this reason that he placed a levy upon them, as it was customary that strangers in a country contribute a levy to the king, as it is mentioned in the case of King Solomon.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 2:16-17.</i> Afterwards he secretly commanded the midwives to kill the male children upon the birthstool<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> so that even the mothers should not know it. Following that, <i>he charged all his people, Every son that is born, ye</i> — yourselves — <i>shall cast into the river</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> Essentially, Pharaoh did not want to charge his executioners to slay them by the decree of the king or to cast them into the river. Rather, he said to the people that whoever would find a Jewish child should throw him into the river. Should the child’s father complain to the king or to the master of the city, they would tell him to bring witnesses and then they will exact vengeance [for the crime]. Now once the king’s restriction was removed,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “And when the king’s strap was untied.” In other words, when the government’s restraint against murder was removed, the Egyptians, etc. Ramban thus traces through the verses the gradual disintegration of the Israelites’ right to life in ancient Egypt.</i> the Egyptians would search the houses, entering them at night, and indifferent [to the cries of the parents], would remove the children therefrom. It is therefore said, <i>And when she could no longer hide him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 2:3.</i><br>It appears that this [decree to drown the Israelite children] lasted but a short time, for when Aaron was born [three years before Moses],<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:7.</i> the decree was not yet in existence,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">This would explain why his mother did not have to seek a way to preserve his life.</i> and when [shortly after] Moses was born, it appears that the decree was revoked. Perhaps it was through Pharaoh’s daughter, who, in her compassion for the child Moses, said to her father that he should not act in that way. It may be that when it became known that this decree was enacted by the king, he revoked it, or again it may be that it was revoked on account of the astrologers, as is the opinion of the Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">“When Moses was thrown into the waters, the astrologers said to Pharaoh, ‘Their deliverer has already been cast into the waters.’ Immediately, they voided the decree” (Shemoth Rabbah 1:29). See also Rashi to Verse 22 here.</i> since it was all done dexterously by them in order that the crime not be known. This is the meaning of the complaint made to Moses our teacher [by the officers of the children of Israel], <i>Ye have made our savor to be abhorred in the eyes of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of his servants, to put a sword in their hand to slay us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 5:21.</i> meaning, “Now they will increase their hatred of us and find justification for saying that we rebel against the government, and they will then openly slay us by the sword without the necessity of doing it slyly.”
AND HE WILL GO UP ‘MIN’ (OUT OF) THE LAND. “I.e., ‘against our will.’ Our Rabbis explained that they spoke like a person who is pronouncing a curse against himself but assigns the curse to others. Thus it is as if Scripture wrote, ‘And <i>we</i> shall have to go up out of the land, and they will possess it.’” These are the words of Rashi. But if the explanation is as the Rabbi has it, [i.e., that the Israelites will go up to wage war against the Egyptians], Scripture would have said, “And he will go up <i>al</i> (against) the land,” [instead of saying <i>min ha’aretz</i> (<i>out</i> of the land)]. Such is the correct expression concerning warriors: <i>Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up ‘al’ (against) all the fortified cities of Judah, and took them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban here combined two verses: II Kings 24:1 and 18:13.</i><i>; Rezin the king of Aram… went up to Jerusalem to war ‘aleha’ (against it)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 7:1.</i> Perhaps [Rashi will explain it by] saying that the meaning is that “he will come up against us from the land wherein he dwells,” meaning the land of Goshen.<br>It is possible to explain that Pharaoh is saying that “if wars will occur, the Israelites may join forces with our enemies <i>to take the spoil, and to take the prey</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:6.</i> They will get themselves up out of this land to the land of Canaan with all our belongings, and we will not be able to wreak our vengeance on them nor to war against them.” This is similar to the verses: <i>that brought us up out of the land of Egypt;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:1.</i> <i>that brought up and that led the seed of the house of Israel out of the north country, and from all the countries whither I had driven them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:8.</i> Similarly, the verse, <i>And they shall appoint themselves one head, and shall go up out of the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 2:2.</i> means they shall appoint over themselves a captain and they shall go up to their land out of the country in which they had been exiled.

Verse 11

SAREI MISIM’ (OFFICERS OF THE TRIBUTE) TO AFFLICT THEM. Pharaoh imposed a tribute upon the Israelite people to take men from them for the king’s projects. He appointed Egyptian officers over the tribute to take men at will in turns to serve for a month or more in the royal building-projects and the rest of the days [they remained] at home. These officers commanded the Israelites to build cities for Pharaoh, and the people built storage-cities for Pharaoh through this levy. When the Egyptians saw that this forced labor did not harm the Israelites, they were in dread for their own lives<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> on account of them. They decreed that all Egyptians force the Israelites to serve them,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> so that any Egyptian who needed work done had the authority to take from them men to do his work. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i><br>They furthermore decreed against them that they do hard work <i>in mortar and in brick</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14. Ramban now proceeds to show how <i>all</i> the Israelites — not only those forced into labor for the king’s building-projects — were afflicted. It is necessary to recall the full text: <i>And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigor. And they made their lives bitter with hard service, in mortar and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field; in all their service, wherein they made them serve with rigor</i> (Verses 13-14). Ramban understands the term “Egyptians” here as referring to the whole population. Further in the text, Ramban will suggest another interpretation.</i> Whereas at first the officers would give them the bricks and the men of the forced labor would erect the buildings, they now conscripted the entire Israelite people into the work, commanding them to bring the earth, make the mortar with their hands and feet while only the straw was given to them from the king’s house, and give the bricks to the men of the forced labor engaged in the construction of the buildings. Every other manner of hard service in the field for Pharaoh and the Egyptians — such as excavations and the removal of dung — were all imposed upon them. In addition, they subjugated them, pressing them not to rest while beating and cursing them. This is the sense of the expression, <i>in all their service, wherein they made them serve with rigor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14. Ramban now proceeds to show how <i>all</i> the Israelites — not only those forced into labor for the king’s building-projects — were afflicted. It is necessary to recall the full text: <i>And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigor. And they made their lives bitter with hard service, in mortar and in brick, and in all manner of service in the field; in all their service, wherein they made them serve with rigor</i> (Verses 13-14). Ramban understands the term “Egyptians” here as referring to the whole population. Further in the text, Ramban will suggest another interpretation.</i><br>The king supported them with <i>sparing bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:20.</i> as is customary for those who work in his service. This is the purport of those lusting persons<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:4.</i> who said, <i>We remember the fish, which we were wont to eat in Egypt for nought; the cucumbers</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> Fish are very abundant in Egypt, and by command of the king, the Israelites would obtain them from those who caught them. They would also take cucumbers and melons from the vegetable-gardens,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> no one putting them to shame, for such was the king’s command.<br>But our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, Bachodesh, end of Chapter 5.</i> “The Israelites were servants to kings, but not servants to servants.” If so, the verse, <i>And the Egyptians made the children of Israel to serve with rigor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> alludes to Pharaoh’s officers of the tribute, [mentioned above in Verse 11].

Chapter 2



Verse 1

AND THERE WENT A MAN OF THE HOUSE OF LEVI. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 12a.</i> that he went after the advice of his daughter.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Amram and Jochebed, Moses’ parents, had been married previously. The children of that union were Miriam and Aaron. “When Pharaoh decreed that the male children of the Hebrews be killed, Amram separated from his wife, and his example was followed by all of the Israelites. Miriam then told her father that his decree is worse than that of the king. ‘Pharaoh decreed only against the male children, while you include the girls as well. It is doubtful if the decree of wicked Pharaoh will persist, while you are a righteous man and your enactment will surely be upheld by G-d.’ Upon recognizing the justice of her plea, Amram remarried his wife, and the men who had previously followed his example also remarried” (Sotah 12 b). It is this episode which the verse suggests by saying, <i>And there went a man</i>, i.e., “went” after the advice of his daughter and remarried his divorced wife. See also further on in the text for a reference to a prophecy Miriam made at that time.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the Israelites dwelled in many cities, and this woman Jochebed lived in another city. [This would explain the term “went” in the above verse, i.e., he <i>went</i> to another city for his wife.] But what need is there for Scripture to mention this?<br>In my opinion Scripture uses the term “went” because this man paid no heed to Pharaoh’s decree and took to himself a woman to beget children. Such is Scripture’s way of speaking of anyone who prompts himself to do something new. Thus: <i>And Reuben went and lay with Bilhah;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:22.</i> <i>So he went and took Gomer the daughter of Diblaim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 1:3. Since she was a harlot, it required self-prompting on his part to perform the novel act of marrying her.</i> <i>Come, and let us sell him to the Ishmaelites;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:27.</i> <i>Come, and let us smite him with the tongue;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 18:18.</i> <i>Come now, and let us reason together</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:18.</i> Similarly this man Amram alerted himself and married a daughter of Levi.<br>The reason Scripture does not mention the name of the man nor the name of the woman he married is to avoid tracing their genealogy and mentioning who their fathers and their fathers’ fathers were up to Levi. At this point, Scripture desires to shorten the subject until the birth of the redeemer takes place, and after that, in the second <i>seder</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., in <i>Seder Va’eira</i>. (<i>A seder</i> is the weekly portion of the Torah read in the synagogue at the Sabbath morning services.) Specifically, Moses’ genealogy is found in <i>Seder Va’eira</i>, Chapter 6, Verses 16-20.</i> He traced the genealogy even of other tribes<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Reuben and Simeon. (<i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 14-15).</i> on account of Moses.<br>In line with the simple meaning of Scripture, i.e., that this was a first marriage [and not a remarriage as stated above], there is no significance in its being mentioned earlier or later in the chapter. This marriage took place before Pharaoh’s decree [that all male Hebrew children be killed], and she gave birth to Miriam and Aaron. After that, Pharaoh decreed, <i>Every son that is born, ye shall cast into the river</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:22.</i> and then she gave birth to this goodly son Moses. Scripture did not mention the birth of Miriam and Aaron inasmuch as there was nothing new about them. However, in the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 12a.</i> this was a remarriage, since Amram separated from his wife in consequence of Pharaoh’s decree and then took her back on account of his daughter’s prophecy.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Miriam prophesied, “My mother is destined to bear a son who will deliver Israel” (Sotah 13 a).</i> He made her a wedding and placed her in the litter, while Miriam and Aaron danced about them in their joy<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">So clearly stated in Sotah 12a.</i> because through this marriage, Israel would be redeemed [from Egypt]. Even though Aaron was young<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">He could have been no more than two years old since he was but three years older than Moses, and Moses was born after the second marriage.</i> [at that time], G-d put gladness in his heart for this occasion, or possibly his sister Miriam taught him.

Verse 2

AND WHEN SHE SAW HIM THAT HE WAS GOODLY SHE HID HIM. It is a known fact that all mothers love their children, goodly or ungoodly, and all of them would hide them [from harm] with all their might. There is thus no need for Scripture to explain <i>that he was goodly</i>. But the meaning of this goodliness is that she saw in him some unique quality which, in her opinion, foreshadowed that a miracle would happen to him and he would be saved. Therefore she applied herself and thought of ways to save him. When she saw that she could hide him no longer, she thought of saving him by another device. She made him an ark of bulrushes [and put him among the reeds at the side of the river], and his sister placed herself at a distance<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> — so that the Egyptians would not recognize her — <i>to know what would be done to him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> All this is support for the words of our Rabbis who expounded,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 12a.</i> “<i>That he was goodly</i>, namely, that the whole house became filled with light,” and for what the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Miriam prophesied, “My mother is destined to bear a son who will deliver Israel” (Sotah 13 a).</i> i.e., that Miriam prophesied, “Mother is destined to bear a son who will deliver Israel.”

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

TO BATHE ‘AL’ (BY) THE RIVER. “Transpose [the order of the words in] the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The order of the Hebrew words is: <i>And the daughter of Pharaoh came down to bathe by the river</i>. Rashi explains it to mean: “And the daughter of Pharaoh went down by the river to bathe in it.”</i> and then explain it: the daughter of Pharaoh went down by the river to bathe in it.” Thus the language of Rabbeinu Shlomo [Rashi]. If so, <i>al haye’or (by</i> or <i>upon the river)</i> is like <i>el haye’or</i> (to the river). Similarly, <i>And Elkanah went to Ramah ‘al beitho’ (upon his house)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:11.</i> [is like <i>el beitho</i> (to his house)]; <i>Thus shall ye say every one ‘al rei’eihu’ (upon his neighbor) and every one to his brother</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:35.</i> [is like <i>el rei’eihu</i> (to his neighbor)].<br>It is possible that there were steps upon the bank of the river and that she went down from the royal palace to bathe upon the first step by the river, but did not enter into the river’s stream. [In this case, the expression <i>al haye’or</i> would be completely understandable, as it would mean that she came down to bathe <i>“upon</i> the step near <i>the river”</i>], <i>and</i> then <i>she saw the ark among the reeds</i> far from her and she sent her handmaid to fetch it. It may be that to bathe <i>‘al haye’or’</i> is like “to bathe <i>baye’or</i> (in the river).” Similarly, <i>And thou shalt put them ‘al’ one basket</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:3.</i> [is like <i>b’sal echad</i> (‘into’ one basket)].

Verse 6

AND BEHOLD IT WAS A WEEPING LAD. “His voice sounded like that of a grown lad.”<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This interpretation is based on the change of reference to Moses within the same verse: <i>And she opened it, and saw it, even ‘hayeled’ (the child), and behold it was a weeping ‘na’ar’ (a young lad)</i>. Hence, in accordance with Rabbi Yehudah’s opinion in Sotah 12 b, Rashi construed that he was a child with the voice of a young lad.</i> Thus the language of Rabbeinu Shlomo. Now the Rabbis have already rejected this opinion, saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opinion of Rabbi Nechemya (<i>ibid.</i>).</i> “If so, you have made Moses our teacher appear as having a blemish [and being unfit for Levitical service in the Tabernacle].”<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Part of the Levitical services in the Tabernacle — and later in the Sanctuary in Jerusalem — consisted of the chanting of the services. A Levite who had no sweetness of voice was disqualified for this service. (See Maimonides’ The Commandments, Vol. I, pp. 32-3, Soncino.) Now if as an infant, Moses, who was a Levite, already had a voice like that of a young lad, as he grew older his voice must have thickened. After the building of the Tabernacle when he was past eighty, his voice naturally could no longer be a singer’s voice, as it would have been greatly out of proportion to his age.</i> Besides, what reason is there for Scripture to mention his unnatural voice?<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that his limbs were developed as that of a young lad. Perhaps Scripture mentioned this in order to denote the child’s beauty. It was due to his exquisite beautiful appearance that she [the princess] had compassion for him since she recognized that he had been recently born and yet his limbs were well-developed like those of a lad.<br>A more correct interpretation is that his was a strong and unrelenting cry like that of a lad, and therefore she had compassion for him. A homiletic exposition has it:<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:28.</i> “<i>A weeping lad</i>. He was a child whose behavior was that of a lad [who is not prone to crying]. At that moment, the angel Gabriel came and struck him so that he would cry and she would be compassionate towards him.”<br>In my opinion there is no need for all this. From the day of his birth, a child is called <i>na’ar</i> (lad) [in Scripture], as it is said, <i>What shall we do ‘lana’ar’ (to the lad) that shall be born?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 13:8.</i> Similarly, <i>And David besought G-d for ‘hana’ar’ (the lad)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 12:16. The subject there is a child, not a grown lad.</i> Conversely, Scripture calls a grown lad <i>yeled</i> (child), as it is said in the case of Ishmael.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And she cast ‘hayeled’ (the child)</i> (Genesis 21:16). At that time, Ishmael was seventeen years old. (See Ramban, Vol. I, p. 270, and Note 329, <i>ibid.</i>). Yet he is called <i>yeled</i>.</i> Similarly, <i>‘v’hana’ar na’ar’ (and the lad was young)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 1:24. That Samuel was but a child at that time is explained by Ramban in the text, and yet Scripture refers to him as a <i>na’ar</i>.</i> meaning that he [Samuel] was a young child of twenty-four months. As soon as she [his mother, Hannah] had weaned him, she brought him up to Shiloh, as it is written, <i>And she gave her son suck until she weaned him. And when she had weaned him, she took him up with her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 23-24.</i>
AND SHE SAID, THIS IS ONE OF THE HEBREWS’ CHILDREN. [She came to this conclusion because] contemplating what happened, she said [that his mother had done it] in order to save him or that she had placed him there so that she might not look upon the death of her child, and why should an Egyptian do that? Some Rabbis say<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion, found in Sotah 12 a and in Shemoth Rabbah 1:29, is ascribed to Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina.</i> that [she knew he was a Hebrew because] she saw that he was circumcised. If so, [we must assume that] she removed his clothes and examined him. But there is no need for this.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent seems to be that since Pharaoh’s decree to cast the male children into the river applied only to Hebrew children — as the simple meaning of Scripture indicates — there was no need for the princess to seek to establish his identity. There is, however, a Midrashic tradition mentioned in Rashi (above, 1:22) that for one day the aforesaid decree applied to all children. The astrologers had said to the king, “Today the deliverer of the Hebrews has been born, and we do not know whether he is born of an Egyptian father or of an Israelite.” Therefore the decree on that day applied to all children. In accordance with that opinion, it is logical to assume that she examined the child, and only then did she come to the conclusion that he was a Hebrew. This is the basis of the opinion of Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Chanina (see preceding Note), i.e., that she knew he was a Hebrew because she saw that he was circumcised.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

AND WHEN MOSES WAS GROWN UP HE WENT OUT UNTO HIS BRETHREN. This is to be understood that he grew to manhood. It has already been said, <i>And the child grew</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> which means that it was no longer necessary to wean him, and then the mother<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 8-9: <i>And the maiden went and called the mother of the child</i>, etc.</i> <i>brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> for he was to stand in the presence of kings.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 22:29.</i> After that, he grew to manhood in maturity of mind.
AND HE WENT OUT UNTO HIS BRETHREN. This indicates that they told him he was a Jew,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">See Esther 3:4.</i> and he desired to see them because they were his brethren. Now he looked on their burdens and toils and could not bear [the sight of his people enslaved]. This was why he killed the Egyptian who was smiting the oppressed Hebrew.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

WILT THOU SPEAK TO KILL ME? “From here we learn that Moses had killed the Egyptian by merely pronouncing the Tetragrammaton.”<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton (<i>Shem Hamphorash</i> or <i>Shem Hamyuchad</i>) is the Proper Name of G-d. It consists of four Hebrew letters, the utterance of which is now forbidden. It is translated here as the Eternal. By pronouncing this Name, Moses needed no weapon to accomplish his purpose of bringing about the deserved death of the Egyptian.</i> Thus the language of Rashi, and it is also a Midrash of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:35.</i><br>But I wonder. If so, who told <i>the wicked one</i><sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">“The wicked one” — so called by the Torah in Verse 13: <i>and he</i> [Moses] <i>said to the wicked one, ‘Why do you smite thy fellow?’</i></i> that Moses killed him? Perhaps Moses placed his hands upon the Egyptian and cursed him in the Name of G-d,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">See II Kings 2:24.</i> [and the Hebrew who was now quarrelling with Moses saw him doing that]. This would explain the term <i>vayach (‘and he smote’ the Egyptian)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">A similar use of the term is found in the case of the Assyrian army that was smitten outside Jerusalem by the angel of G-d. It says there, <i>And it came to pass that night, that the angel of the Eternal went forth ‘vayach’ (and smote) in the camp of the Assyrians</i> (II Kings 19:35). Now just as in that case <i>vayach</i> does not signify a physical act of striking by hand but rather the inflicting of defeat by supernatural power, so also here in the case of Moses. (Bachya.)</i> It may be that because the Egyptian had fallen dead before him [after he had pronounced the Tetragrammaton over him], Moses feared that they may report him and so he buried the Egyptian in the sand. The Hebrew who saw him doing that reckoned that Moses had caused [the Egyptian’s death somehow, even though he did not know that he had killed him by pronouncing the Tetragrammaton]. Perhaps he thought Moses had killed him by the sword, as he saw only the burial.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, scholars say<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra in his commentary here, and R’dak in his Book of Roots, under the root <i>amar</i>.</i> that the expression, <i>wilt thou ‘omer’ (speak)</i>, means “think,” since we find <i>amirah</i> (speaking) referring to the thought of the heart. <i>I said in my heart;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:1.</i> <i>I say, that an untimely birth is better than he</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:3. It is obvious that Ramban’s intent in selecting these two verses from the Book of Ecclesiastes is to show that the term <i>amirah</i> (saying) as such is equivalent to <i>amirah b’leiv</i> (speaking in one’s heart). Hence the Book of Ecclesiastes uses them interchangeably.</i> But here there is no need for this, for [the intent of the Hebrew’s words to Moses] is as follows: <i>“Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?</i> Is it because thou dost desire to kill me <i>as thou didst kill the Egyptian</i> that thou reprovest me and sayest, <i>‘Why smitest thou thy fellow?’”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, Ramban is saying that the expression <i>atah omer (thou sayest)</i> alludes to that which Moses had said in Verse 13: <i>Why smitest thou thy fellow?</i> The Hebrew thus said to Moses: “Is it because you desire to kill me as you killed the Egyptian that you reproved me by saying, ‘Why do you smite your fellow?’”</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

NOW THE PRIEST OF MIDIAN HAD SEVEN DAUGHTERS. Scripture does not mention him by name for he is not known [to the reader], but rather epithetically mentions that he was the honored one in his priesthood. This was Jethro, for after he became related to Moses it is written, <i>And Moses went and returned to Jether his father-in-law</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 4:18.</i> and there it is written, <i>And Jethro said to Moses: Go in peace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 4:18.</i> [This proves that Jether and Jethro are the same person], just as Eliyah and Eliyahu,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Eliyah (II Kings 1:3), Eliyahu (I Kings 17:1).</i> Yirmiyah and Yirmiyahu.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Yirmiyah (Jeremiah 27:1), Yirmiyahu (<i>ibid.</i>, 1:1).</i> After he became a proselyte to Judaism, he was called Hobab, as it is written, <i>from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 4:11.</i> for it is the way of all who become converts to Judaism that they be called another name in Israel. And he [Jethro or Hobab] was the son of Reuel, for it is written, <i>And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:29.</i> The verse here stating, <i>And they came to Reuel their father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> means “their father’s father,” just as [Jacob had said], <i>O G-d of my father Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:10.</i> [and Abraham was his father’s father], and [when speaking of Belshazzar, king of Babylon, Scripture says], <i>Nebuchadnezzar his father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 5:2.</i> [while he was his father’s father].<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Evil-merodach, king of Babylon, ruled after Nebuchadnezzar (see II Kings 25:27), and he was followed by Belshazzar (see Megillah 11a). Nebuchadnezzar was thus Belshazzar’s grandfather, and yet Scripture (Daniel 5:2) speaks of him as his father.</i> Similarly: <i>Know ye Laban the son of Nahor?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 29:5. But Laban was really the son of Bethuel, for he was the brother of Rebekah (<i>ibid.</i>, 24:29), and of Rebekah it is written that her father was Bethuel (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 15). Bethuel’s father was Nahor (<i>ibid.</i>, 22:20-22). Yet Jacob asked, <i>Know ye Laban the son of Nahor?</i> It is because a grandfather is called “father.”</i> <i>And Mephibosheth the son of Saul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 19:25. Mephibosheth was the son of Jonathan (<i>ibid.</i>, 4:4), who was the son of Saul.</i> There are many other such verses.<br>[Jethro’s daughters came and told Reuel their grandfather of how Moses came to their aid — as is related in Verses 18-19 — and did not tell Jethro] because the priest was not found in the house since he was preoccupied with the ministry in his temple, and so they came to the grandfather. It is possible that the verse, <i>And Moses was content to dwell with the man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> refers to the priest mentioned above [in Verse 16 — namely, Jethro]<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">The intent of Ramban’s words is as follows: According to the above-mentioned interpretation that Jethro was not to be found in his home and that consequently his daughters told Reuel, his father, what had happened (as stated in Verses 18-20), it should follow that the expression, <i>And Moses was content to dwell with ‘the man’</i> (Verse 21) refers to Reuel, and it was Reuel who gave Moses Zipporah his granddaughter as a wife. But, continues Ramban, it is possible that “the man” in Verse 21 refers back to “the priest” in Verse 16, and so it was Jethro who gave Moses his daughter in marriage.</i> — for it was he who gave Moses Zipporah his daughter.
AND THEY CAME AND DREW WATER. Every day, the practice was that the shepherds drew water, filled the troughs and watered their flocks first, and then these women watered their flocks. It happened that on this day, the women preceded the men <i>and they came and drew water</i>, thinking to water their flocks before the shepherds came. But then <i>came the shepherds and drove them away</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> from the troughs, insisting on watering their own flocks first as they had always done. Moses’ anger was aroused because of this injustice, and he saved them, for since they had filled the troughs, the water belonged to them. Moreover, he drew water for them<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> as the troughs did not suffice for all their flocks. This is the purport of the question, <i>How is it that ye are come so soon today?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> [which Reuel their grandfather asked them]. And they answered, <i>An Egyptian delivered us out of the hand of the shepherds</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> meaning that “they had always driven us away when we came to the troughs first.”

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND IT CAME TO PASS IN THE COURSE OF THOSE MANY DAYS. Scripture uses the expression “in those days” or “on that day” only when alluding to a brief current event, but of a past event it says, <i>and it came to pass afterward</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">As in Judges 16:4.</i> In that case then, it should have said here, “and it came to pass afterward that the king of Egypt died.” It is for this reason that our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:40.</i> that because they were days of suffering [for Israel], Scripture calls them “many” although alluding to a brief current event.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, Scripture is really referring here to a specific current event, namely, the death of the king, and yet it uses the term “many” — <i>and it came to pass in the course of those ‘many’ days</i> — instead of saying “in those days.” To a suffering people — as Israel was at that time — even a brief period appeared as a long one.</i> So also have the Rabbis said<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:32.</i> in connection with the above-mentioned verse, <i>And it came to pass in those days when Moses was grown up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 11.</i> that his growth was unnatural, meaning, sudden and fast.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is thus confirming what he stated above, i.e., that the Scriptural expression <i>in those days</i> alludes to a brief current event. Hence when it says in the case of Moses’ growth, <i>and it was in those days and Moses was grown up</i>, the Rabbis interpreted it to mean that his growth was brief and sudden.</i> Under all circumstances, the period [covered in the verses], <i>and the king of Egypt died</i>, and the children of Israel cried out <i>and their cry came up unto G-d</i>, was [altogether] a brief period of time.<br>However, we might also explain that <i>in the course of those many days</i> refers to the days of suffering and hard labor which were exceedingly many, as the exile became very prolonged. It was this [long period of suffering and hard labor] which caused them to cry out, <i>and their cry came up unto G-d</i>. Similarly, the verse, <i>And it came to pass after many days, the word of the Eternal came to Elijah, in the third year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 18:1.</i> means that there were many days [of famine] and afterwards this event, [related there in the Book of Kings], occurred.<br>In my opinion, the purport of this verse, [<i>And it came to pass in the course of those many days</i>], is to allude to those days when Moses was a fugitive from Pharaoh. Indeed he was but a youth when he fled, as the verse said, <i>And when Moses was grown up he went out unto his brethren</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 11.</i> suggesting that immediately when he grew up and became self-conscious and they told him that he was a Jew, he longed to see the burdens, toils and oppressions of his brethren. On that [first] day on which he went out, he smote the Egyptian, and on the second day, they denounced him [to the authorities] and he fled. He was thus at that time approximately twelve years of age, as our Sages have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:1.</i> and at any rate not twenty,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:32.</i> and when he stood before Pharaoh he was eighty years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:7.</i> In that case, he was a fugitive from Pharaoh for about sixty years, [and it is with reference to those sixty years that Scripture speaks of <i>those ‘many’ days</i>].<br>It is likely that at the end of that period, Moses came to Midian and married Zipporah, since when this word [of G-d that he return to Egypt] came to him, he had begotten of her only his firstborn son Gershom<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> [while Eliezer, his second son, was born during his journey to Egypt].<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi further, 4:24. This proves that Moses’ arrival and marriage in Midian were towards the end of his sixty-year absence from Egypt.</i><br>Scripture however mentions nothing of [the entire period of] his flight excepting, <i>And he dwelt in the land of Midian, and he sat down by a well</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> since nothing happened to him in those other days which Scripture found necessary to relate. And it is logical. He who flees from the reach of a government does not tarry in a settled place or its environs. Instead, he flees from place to place in remote regions. Thus he stayed away for a long time, hiding himself and feigning to be a stranger, going about <i>from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:13.</i> and at the end of that time he came to Midian and stayed there. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And he dwelt in the land of Midian</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> It would have been fitting for Scripture to say, “and he went to the land of Midian,” but instead it implies that he did not dwell in any city until the end [of the period], when he came to the land of Midian and there he dwelt.<br>Now due to the fact that Scripture mentions his flight from Pharaoh and his dwelling in Midian, and it immediately relates that he was made to return to Egypt by command of the Holy One, blessed be He, it alludes to this entire period by saying, <i>And it came to pass in the course of those many days</i>, meaning [those days] when Moses fled from before Pharaoh and during part of which time he stayed in Midian. At the end [of that period], the king of Egypt died, and the Divine Revelation concerning it came to Moses and he was returned to Egypt and redeemed the children of Israel. It is for this reason that Scripture does not say, “and it came to pass <i>after</i> many days,” for the purport of that would have been that [the death of the king of Egypt] occurred long after Moses dwelt in Midian. But that is not so, for the expression <i>those many days</i> refers to all that is related above.
AND THE KING OF EGYPT DIED, AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SIGHED BY REASON OF THE BONDAGE. “He was stricken with leprosy [and hence may be considered as dead], and he was wont to slaughter Israelitic babes and bathe in their blood.” Thus the words of Rashi. This is a Midrash of the Sages.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 1:41.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, [it is to be explained that] the custom of all subjects of a wicked tyrant is to hope for and look forward to the day of his death. But when the Israelites saw that the king died, they wailed bitterly lest <i>a godless man may come to reign</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Job 34:30.</i> who will be more wicked than the preceding king. They said, <i>Our bones are dried up, and our hope is lost</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 37:11.</i> and thus they chose death rather than life.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 8:3.</i> This is the sense of the word <i>na’akatham (their groaning)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> for they groaned <i>with the groanings of a mortally-wounded man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 30:24.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25

AND G-D SAW THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained this as meaning that G-d saw the violence which the Egyptians overtly did to them, <i>and G-d knew</i> what was done to them secretly. And Rashi explained: “<i>And G-d knew</i>. He directed His heart to them and did not hide His eye from them.” This is correct in line with the plain meaning of Scripture. At first He hid His face from them and they were devoured,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 31:17.</i> but now G-d heard their groaning and He saw them, meaning that He no longer hid His face from them; He knew their pains and all that was done to them, as well as all that they required.<br>Now Scripture gives a lengthy account of the many reasons for their redemption: <i>And G-d heard their groaning, and G-d remembered His covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> <i>And G-d saw the children of Israel, and G-d knew; For I know their pains</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 3:7.</i> This is because even though the time [of bondage] decreed upon them was completed, they were not worthy of redemption, as was explained by the prophet Ezekiel;<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:6-10.</i> it was only on account of the cry<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And we cried unto the Eternal, the G-d of our fathers, and the Eternal heard our voice</i> (Deuteronomy 26:7). See also Numbers 20:16.</i> that He in His mercies accepted their prayer.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], there is in this verse one of the great mysteries of the Torah, suggesting that their afflictions came up to the light of His countenance, which brought them [their afflictions] near the Knowledge [of G-d], just as is implied in the verse, <i>In midst of the ‘shanim’ (years) make it known; in wrath remember compassion</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 3:2. Shem Tov ibn Gaon, (a Spanish Cabalist of the pupils of Rashba — printed in Ma’or V’shamesh, Livorno, 1839), explains that Ramban’s intent in mentioning this verse is that the word <i>shanim</i> (years) should be understood as <i>sh’nayim</i> (two), a reference to the two Divine attributes, justice and mercy. When they unite, Israel is remembered for help and redemption. This is explicitly referred to in the second half of the verse: <i>in wrath remember compassion</i>.</i> It is for this reason that Scripture gives this lengthy account — [<i>And G-d saw the children of Israel, and G-d knew</i>] — after already having mentioned, <i>And G-d heard… and G-d remembered</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> This verse, [<i>And G-d saw…</i>,] has been explained in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Also called Sefer Habahir. Ramban’s reference is found there in paragraph 76 (Margoliot ed.). See Vol. I, p. 24, Note 42. Ramban was the first author to quote from this classic of Jewish mystic thought in an open and extensive manner. See the learned work of Israel Weinstock, B’maglei Haniglah V’hanistar (Mosad Harav Kook, Jerusalem) on various aspects of this book.</i> From there you will understand the verse.

Chapter 3



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND THE ANGEL OF THE ETERNAL APPEARED UNTO HIM IN A FLAME OF FIRE. Because Scripture originally states, <i>And the angel of the Eternal appeared</i>, and then it goes on to say, <i>And when the Eternal saw that he turned aside to see, G-d called unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that <i>elohim</i> mentioned here [in the second verse] is the angel mentioned [in the first], as in the verse, <i>For I have seen ‘elohim’ face to face</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:31. The reference there is to an angel. See Ramban on Verses 26 and 30, there.</i> The expression, <i>I am the G-d of thy father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> is a case of the deputy speaking in the name of Him Who sent him.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 260, for a similar instance.</i> But this is not correct. Moses the greatest in prophecy, would not have hidden his face from an angel [as is related in Verse 6].<br>Our Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 97:4. The complete quote mentioned here by Ramban is found in Shemoth Rabbah 2:8.</i> “<i>Angel</i>. This refers to the angel Michael. Wherever Rabbi Yosei Ha’aruch<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Rabbi Yosei the tall one.” He was an outstanding pupil of Rabbeinu Hakadosh, or Rabbi Judah the Prince, redactor of the Mishnah.</i> was seen, people would say, ‘There is Rabbeinu Hakadosh.’ Similarly, wherever the angel Michael appears, there is also present the Glory of the Divine Presence.” The Rabbis intended to say that at first, the angel Michael appeared to Moses, and there was also the Glory of the Divine Presence, but Moses did not see the Glory, as he had not duly prepared his mind for prophecy. When he duly prepared his heart for it <i>and he turned aside to see</i>, then the vision of the Divine Presence revealed itself to him, <i>and G-d called unto him out of the midst of the bush</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i>
AND, BEHOLD, THE BUSH ‘BO’EIR’ (BURNED) WITH FIRE. [The word <i>bo’eir</i>] has the same meaning as <i>doleik</i> (burning),<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to solve this difficulty: In the verse before us it says, <i>and, behold, the bush ‘bo’eir’</i>, and in Verse 3 it says that Moses asked, <i>why the bush is not ‘yiv’ar’?</i> Ramban explains that in the first case, <i>bo’eir</i> has the same meaning as <i>doleik</i> (burning), while <i>yiv’ar</i> means “consumed.”</i> i.e., [the bush] was in the midst of a burning fire, and it is like the verse, <i>and the fathers ‘m’va’arim’ the fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 7:18.</i> meaning, “kindling” and burning the wood with fire. But the expression, <i>why the bush is not ‘yiv’ar’?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> means, “why is it not consumed and wasted?” Similarly, <i>As flax that was ‘ba’aru’ with fire</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 15:14.</i> means “consumed.” And so is the opinion of Onkelos, who translated the first [<i>bo’eir</i>] as <i>bo’eir</i> (burning), and the second one [<i>yiv’ar</i>] as <i>mitokad</i>, [the Aramaic word for “consumed”]. It may be that <i>yiv’ar</i> has the same meaning as in the verses, <i>‘Uvi’arta’ (So shalt thou put away) the evil from the midst of thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:7.</i> <i>Then a man useth it ‘l’va’eir’ (for fodder)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:15. The expression “for fodder” suggests destruction and annihilation. See R’dak, (mentioned in my Hebrew commentary, p. 288), who so interprets this verse. Here then the sense of the verse would be: “why does the fire not <i>remove</i> or <i>eat up</i> the bush altogether?”</i> Such is the style of the Sacred Language to use [one term in the same instance with two different meanings], as in the verse: <i>They rode on thirty ‘ayarim’ (ass colts) and they had thirty ‘ayarim’ (cities)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 10:4. Thus the word <i>ayarim</i> has two separate meanings in the same verse. In the instance before us here, the Hebrew root <i>bo’eir</i> is used with two separate meanings: burning, and consuming or removing.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

APPROACH NOT HITHER. Moses had not yet reached the highest degree of prophecy, for at Mount Sinai <i>he drew near unto the thick darkness where G-d was</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:18.</i> This also accounts for the hiding of his face [in this instance], for he had not yet reached that high [degree of prophecy of] which it was said of Moses, <i>and the similitude of the Eternal doth he behold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:8.</i>
FOR THE PLACE WHEREON THOU STANDEST IS HOLY GROUND. Even though Moses was far from the bush, the angel warned him [not to approach], for the whole mountain became sanctified when the Divine Presence came down upon the mountain—top, just as it did at the time of the Giving of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:20.</i> Now Moses was on the mountain for he had ascended thereto, as it is said, <i>and he came to the mountain of G-d, unto Horeb</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> and the bush was on the top of the mountain.<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Accordingly we must understand that before the burning of the bush began, Moses had already gone up on the mountain but not to its top. It was later when he desired to approach the top of the mountain to see <i>this great sight, why the bush is not burnt</i>, that he was warned not “to approach.” Had he not been on the mountain at all, the warning should have been not “to come up.”</i> Thus the entire site became holy and therefore the wearing of sandals was forbidden. A similar case is found in Joshua.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 5:15.</i> Likewise, the priests ministered in the Sanctuary only while barefoot.

Verse 6

I AM THE G-D OF THY FATHER. In accordance with the plain meaning of Scripture, this is equivalent to saying, “the G-d of thy fathers.” However, He mentions the singular instead of the plural, for the intent is “the G-d of each one of your ancestors,” since people refer to all ancestors as fathers. Similarly: <i>the G-d of thy father;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:5. These words were spoken by the prophet Isaiah to King Hezekiah. Now since David was not Hezekiah’s father, it proves that people call an ancestor “father.”</i> <i>this is my G-d, and I will glorify Him; my father’s G-d, and I will exalt Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 15:2.</i> meaning “the G-d of my fathers.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said [that the word “father” in the phrase], <i>the G-d of my father</i>, refers to Abraham since he was the first who began to call upon the name of the Eternal.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 12:8. See Ramban there, Vol. I, p. 172.</i> After that, He mentioned Abraham by name and then joined the rest of the patriarchs to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The verse before us reads: <i>I am the G-d of thy father, the G-d of Abraham, the G-d of Isaac, and the G-d of Jacob</i>.</i> In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:1.</i> [“father” in the phrase] <i>The G-d of thy father</i>, means Amram. This is just as if He had said, “I am thy G-d,” [i.e., Moses’ G-d], but He desired to associate His Name with that of a righteous man who had already died - [namely, Amram] - rather than with that of one yet alive, [i.e., Moses].<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">The reason for it is stated by Rashi in Genesis 28:13: “Because it is said, <i>Behold He putteth no trust even in His holy ones</i>” (Job 15:15). As long as a person lives, the evil inclination in him is still present.</i> After that, [He mentioned] <i>the G-d of Abraham, the G-d of Isaac, and the G-d of Jacob</i>, meaning that He is the G-d of all Israel.<br>The reason for His mentioning “the G-d of” with each one [of the patriarchs] instead of saying “the G-d of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob” is that He referred to His Name and His memorial,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">See further, Verse 15.</i> [thus alluding to the special attributes by which He was associated with each of the patriarchs],<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">“It is with reference to them [the separate attributes associated with the patriarchs] that Moses mentioned, <i>the great G-d, the mighty, and the feared</i> (Deuteronomy 10:17). ‘The great’ alludes to Abraham, as it is said, <i>and of great kindness</i> (Psalms 145:8); ‘the mighty’ to <i>the Fear of Isaac</i> (Genesis 31:42); and ‘the feared’ to Jacob, as it is said, <i>For with Thee there is forgiveness, that Thou mayest be feared</i>” (Psalms 130:4). (Ricanti in his work here on the Torah).</i> blessed and magnified be He. I will explain yet more on this point in the chapter.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Further in Verse 15.</i>

Verse 7

AND THE ETERNAL SAID. Scripture mentions Him in the attribute of mercy since it is in connection with His compassion for the people [in bondage], even though the entire chapter mentions Him by the name of <i>Elokim</i> (G-d), [a name signifying the attribute of justice].

Verse 8

AND I AM COME DOWN TO DELIVER THEM. That is, “for I have revealed Myself in fire on this mountain.” This has the same meaning as in the verses: <i>And the Eternal came down upon Mount Sinai;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:20.</i> <i>Because the Eternal descended upon it in fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> It may be that [the expression <i>come down</i> has the same meaning here] as in the verse, <i>I will go down now, and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry of it, which is come unto Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:21. See Ramban there (Vol. I, p. 245) where he explains that the meaning is, “I will go down from the attribute of mercy to the attribute of justice.” Here the meaning would be: “and I am come down from attribute to attribute.”</i> I have already explained its secret there.
UNTO A GOOD AND LARGE LAND, UNTO A LAND FLOWING WITH MILK AND HONEY; UNTO THE PLACE OF THE CANAANITE, AND THE HITTITE, AND THE AMORITE, AND THE PERIZZITE, AND THE HIVITE, AND THE JEBUSITE. He mentions here six nations and omits the seventh.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">The Girgashite, mentioned among the seven nations that Israel was to inherit (Deuteronomy 7:1).</i> Perhaps this was because his land was not <i>flowing with milk and honey</i> as were these [lands of the six nations mentioned]. Similarly, He mentions these six only in the verse, <i>For Mine angel shall go before thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:23. <i>And bring thee in unto the Amorite, and the Hittite, and the Perizzite, and the Canaanite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite</i>.</i> It may be because He alluded here [to a future event], i.e., that they will conquer these six nations first, for it is these six nations who assembled to fight Joshua,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">So clearly stated in Joshua 9:1-2.</i> and G-d gave them into his hand. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shebiith VI, 1.</i> that the Girgashite arose and emigrated of his own accord. This is why he is not mentioned together with those destined for destruction, as it is said concerning them, <i>and I will cut them off</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:23. <i>And bring thee in unto the Amorite, and the Hittite, and the Perizzite, and the Canaanite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite</i>.</i> I will discuss this matter further,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:25.</i> with the help of G-d.<br>The sense of the expression, <i>a land flowing with milk and honey</i>, is that He first praised the land as <i>a good land</i>, meaning that its climate is good and beautiful for people and that all that is good is found in it, <i>and</i> as <i>a large</i> land, meaning that it will afford all Israel to be established <i>in a broad place</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 31:9.</i> It may be that <i>r’chavah</i> (large) means spaciousness, referring to [the extensive lands of] the lowland, the valley and the plain, large and small, and is not confined mostly to mountains and valleys. He then began to praise the land as being a land for cattle, having good pasture and good water which cause the cattle to have abundant milk, for healthy and good cattle with abundant milk are to be found only where the climate is good, with plenty of vegetation and good water. But since these are found only in the marsh-lands,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew: <i>ba’achu</i>. See Ramban, Genesis 41:2 (Vol. I, p. 495) for his explanation of that term.</i> while on the height of the mountains fruits are not very fat and good, He further states that this land is so fat that its fruits [all over] are fat and sweet, even to the extent that it all flows with the honey that comes from them. Thus He has praised the land for all its <i>goodness of the Eternal, for the corn, and for the wine, and for the oil, and for the young of the flock and of the herd</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:11.</i> This is the meaning of the verse, <i>It is the beauty of all lands</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:6.</i><br>The reason that He said, <i>unto the ‘place’ of the Canaanite</i>, and not “unto the ‘land’ of the Canaanite” as He said in all other places,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., see further, 13:5.</i> is to allude to the fact that they will inherit [the Canaanite, etc.], and will destroy them and settle in their places, and not dwell among them as their fathers had done.

Verse 9

AND NOW, BEHOLD, THE CRY OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL IS COME UNTO ME. Even though He has already said, <i>and I have heard their cry</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> He says again that it has <i>come unto Me</i>, thus stating that “their cry has come to the Throne of My Glory, and I will no longer pardon<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">According to another reading: “permit Pharaoh to enslave.”</i> Pharaoh, for the Egyptians are oppressing them exceedingly.” It is similar in sense to the expression, <i>a rage which hath reached up unto heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 28:9.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], <i>the cry of the children of Israel</i> is a reference to <i>Knesseth Yisrael</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">“The Congregation of Israel.” Here understood in a Cabalistic sense, an allusion to the attribute of justice.</i> similar to the verse, <i>according to the cry of it which is come unto Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:21.</i> I have alluded to it there.
The meaning of the verse, <i>moreover I have seen the oppression</i>, is that He will punish Pharaoh and his people because by oppressing Israel so exceedingly, they perpetrated more than had been decreed against them, as I have explained in <i>Seder Lech Lecha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 15:13 (Vol. I, pp. 203-8).</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

AND HE SAID: BECAUSE I WILL BE WITH THEE; AND THIS SHALL BE THE TOKEN UNTO THEE, THAT I HAVE SENT THEE: WHEN THOU HAST BROUGHT FORTH THE PEOPLE OUT OF EGYPT, YE SHALL SERVE G-D UPON THIS MOUNTAIN. Explanations of this verse are numerous. The correct interpretation in line with the simple meaning of Scripture is that the Holy One, blessed be He, had said two things to Moses. [First], He would come down <i>to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> This might mean that He will deliver them out of their hands while they will remain in the land of Goshen itself or in some place nearby. Therefore, He further promised <i>to bring them up out of that</i> entire <i>land to the place of the Canaanite</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i><br>But Moses was fearful of both [promises], saying, “<i>Who am I, that I should go unto Pharaoh?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> I am but a humble person, a keeper of the flock, and he is a great king. If I will tell him to let the people go altogether, he will kill me.” This is similar in meaning to that which Samuel said. <i>And if Saul hear it, he will kill me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 16:2.</i> And Moses said further, “<i>Who am I … that I should bring forth the children of Israel out of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> as Thou didst tell me to bring them up to the land of Canaan. <i>Surely this great nation is a wise and understanding people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:6.</i> and they will not hold me in sufficient esteem to go after me to the land of nations greater and mightier than they,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 38.</i> as Thou hadst said, <i>to bring them up … unto a good and large land … unto the place of the Canaanite</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> The delivery from the hand of Pharaoh — whether he will listen and lighten his yoke from upon them and thus deliver them [from bondage], or <i>drive them out of his land</i> against their will<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:1. See also Rashi there.</i> — is not dependent on them. Besides, they themselves will listen to any one on this matter — for what man is there who would not want to go out from unparalleled cruel bondage — but they will not give heed to go up to the land of Canaan.” Such indeed was the case. The war against those nations [in the land of Canaan] was hard on them from beginning to end, and they feared it while still in Egypt and later when they were in the desert. This then was the fear of Moses our teacher, of Pharaoh, and his apprehension of the children of Israel.<br>And the Eternal answered him on both matters. He said to him: “Do not fear Pharaoh for <i>I will be with thee</i> to save thee. <i>And this shall be the token unto thee</i> for the people <i>that I have sent thee</i> to them, for <i>when thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve G-d upon this mountain</i>. From then on, they will take upon themselves the worship of G-d and walk in His commandments,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">See II Chronicles 17:4.</i> <i>and they will also believe in thee forever</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:9.</i> and they will run after thee<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">See Song of Songs 1:4.</i> wherever thou shalt command them [to go]. Now I have revealed Myself to thee on this mountain <i>in a flame of fire</i>, for so it will be in front of all the people when they will serve Me on this mountain.”<br>Thus in that which he saw, there was a sign for Moses that he should not fear Pharaoh since G-d assured him his deliverance.
