For Israel it was to be a sign that they should not fear the nations upon their coming to Mount Sinai, for to go out from Egypt — with Pharaoh’s consent — to a nearby place <i>a three days’ journey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18. See also Ramban further, 19:1.</i> they would surely give heed and do so whether willingly or unwillingly.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tur’s rendition of Ramban: “they will surely listen and not ask for a sign.”</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], <i>‘V’zeh’ (And this) shall be the token unto thee</i>, is like the verse, <i>‘Zeh li’ (I have now been) twenty years in thy house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:41. Literally: “<i>this</i> to me is twenty years.” Rabbeinu Bachya ben Asher here intimates that Ramban’s intent is to be understood in the light of the verse, <i>‘Zeh’ (This) is my G-d, and I will glorify Him</i> (further, 15:2). See my Hebrew commentary here on Ramban, p. 290.</i> thus alluding to the verses, <i>Because I will be with thee</i>, and behold <i>there is a sign unto thee</i>, the sign of the covenant that “I will be with thee always,” just as it is intimated in the verse, <i>As for Me, behold, My covenant is with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:4.</i> “It is I who send you that you should serve G-d upon this mountain, and then I too will go up in the midst of this people <i>into the place which I have prepared</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:20.</i>

Verse 13

AND THEY SHALL SAY UNTO ME: WHAT IS HIS NAME? WHAT SHALL I SAY UNTO THEM? This verse calls aloud for an explanation. It is incomprehensible that Moses should say, <i>And they shall say unto me: What is His name?</i> meaning that this will be a sign to them to believe in him. The asking for His Name and Moses’ telling it to them are no sign to anyone who did not believe in Moses to begin with. If Israel knew that Name, Moses likewise knew it, and thus his knowledge thereof was equivalent to theirs and it would be no sign or wonder at all. If they had not heard of it previously, what proof would that be that they should believe in his words altogether? And now even after He informed him of the Great Name, Moses still said, <i>But, behold, they will not believe me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:1.</i> and then He gave him the various signs!<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 2-9.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Moses asked which of G-d’s Names he should mention to Israel, for the Name of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> (G-d Almighty) does not signify the performance of miraculous signs; only the Great Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton], indicates that. But this interpretation does not appear correct to me. Moses had not yet been told that He would make great and wondrous signs and portents at the going forth from Egypt. Rather, he was told that He would save them from the hand of the Egyptians and bring them up to the land of Canaan, and for that — to strike at the heart of Pharaoh, as well as to be victorious over the seven nations — the name <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> suffices. Sarah was taken out from Pharaoh’s house <i>with great plagues</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 12:17.</i> and Abraham alone subdued the great kings<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:14-15.</i> — all with the help of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>, the Divine Name known to the patriarchs,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:3.</i> and so likewise He would do to their descendants. Moreover, Jacob had said, <i>And ‘Elokim’ (G-d) will be with you, and bring you back unto the land of your fathers</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 48:21.</i>, and Joseph also said, <i>‘Elokim’ (G-d) will surely remember you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 50:25.</i> Thus the remembrance is by <i>Elokim!</i><br>In my opinion, Moses even at that time was already the father of wisdom, great in achievement of the heights of prophecy, and inherent in his question was the request that He inform him Who is sending him, that is to say, by what Divine attribute is he sent to the Israelites, just as Isaiah said, <i>And now the Eternal G-d hath sent me, and His spirit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 48:16.</i> Thus Moses said: “They will ask me concerning my mission whether it is with the attribute of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> which stood by the patriarchs, or with the high attribute of mercy with which You will do signs and wonders which will be new phenomena in creation.” [Moses was obliged to ask] this question because He had said to him, <i>I am the G-d of thy father, the G-d of Abraham</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> and He did not elucidate to him at all any of His sacred Names. Moses then heard that He assured him of the Revelation on Mount Sinai and the Giving of the Torah, and he knew that the Torah would not be given with the Name of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> mentioned in connection with the patriarchs, but would be given with the Great Name with which the world came into existence. Therefore he asked, <i>What shall I say unto them?</i><br>Our Rabbis have alluded to this interpretation. Thus they said:<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:6.</i> <i>“And Moses said unto G-d, Behold, when I come unto the children of Israel.”</i> Rabbi Shimon related in the name of Rabbi Simon that Moses said: ‘I am destined to become the agent between Thee and them when Thou wilt give them the Torah and say unto them, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i>.’<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:2. “And if I am worthy to become Thy agent at the Giving of the Torah, I request to be informed now of Thy Great Name” (Eitz Yoseph to Shemoth Rabbah). This conclusion is here implied and is so clearly stated at the end of the Midrash here quoted.</i><br>“<i>And I shall say unto them: The G-d of your fathers hath sent me unto you</i>. At that moment, Moses desired to be elucidated concerning his activities, for he feared lest the children of Israel ask him, <i>What is His name? What shall I say unto them?</i> At that moment Moses desired that the Holy One, blessed be He, inform him of the Great Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton].” This was the purport of Moses’ question.
And G-d answered him, “‘I WILL BE THAT WHICH I WILL BE.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> I will be with you<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">“You.” In our version of Rashi: “them.”</i> in this sorrow, and I will be with you<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">“You.” In our version of Rashi: “them.”</i> in other sorrows.’<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">“In other sorrows.” In our version of Rashi: “In the subjection [they will suffer at the hands] of the other kingdoms.”</i> Thereupon Moses said to Him, ‘Master of the universe! Sufficient is the evil in its time, [and why should I mention to them other sorrows in store for them in the future].’ G-d replied to him: ‘You have spoken correctly. <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel:</i> I WILL BE <i>hath sent me unto you</i>.’” Thus the language of Rashi quoting the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 9b.</i> Their intent in this Agadah is as follows: Moses had said before Him, blessed be He. <i>And they shall say unto me: What is His name?</i>, meaning that G-d should tell him the Name which wholly teaches His existence and His providence. The Holy One, blessed be He, answered him: “Why should they ask for My Name? They need no other proof, for I will be with them <i>in all their affliction</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:9.</i> They shall call, and I will answer them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 91:14.</i> This is the great proof that there is a G-d in Israel near to us <i>whenever we call upon Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:7.</i> and <i>verily there is a G-d that judgeth in the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 58:12.</i> This is a correct interpretation of this Agadah (homily).<br>In a similar way it is said in a Midrash Agadah:<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer V’hizhir. See Torah Shleimah by Rabbi M. Kasher, paragraph 188.</i> “And what is the meaning of I WILL BE THAT WHICH I WILL BE? ‘As you are with Me, so I am with you. If they open their hands and give charity, I also will open My hand, as it is said, <i>The Eternal will open unto thee His good treasure the heaven to give the rain of thy land in its season</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:12.</i> And if they do not open their hands, what is written there? <i>Behold, He withholdeth the waters, and they dry up</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:15.</i><br>In a similar vein the Rabbis expounded:<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:6.</i> “Rabbi Yitzchak said that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: ‘I am He Who has been, Who is now, and Who will be in the future.’ This is why <i>Eh’yeh</i> is written here three times.” The explanation of Rabbi Yitzchak’s opinion is that since with respect to the Creator, past and future times are conceived completely in terms of the present — for there is no host succeeding host with regards to Him, and nothing of His time has passed — hence all times with reference to Him are called by one name, signifying a Being Whose existence is absolute.<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Or “a Being Who is necessarily existent.” “G-d alone is that Being, for His existence is absolute — existence and essence are perfectly identical. He is not a substance to which existence is joined as an accident, as an additional element. His existence is always absolute, and has never been a new element or an accident in Him” (Moreh Nebuchim, I, 57, Friedlander’s translation).</i><br>Now Onkelos translated the first two names, [i.e. <i>‘Eh’yeh Asher Eh’yeh’</i>], as “I will be with him that I will be,”<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning thereof is further elucidated by Ramban. In our version of Onkelos, these two Divine Names are also not translated and instead are retained in their original Hebrew form.</i> but he did not translate the third name <i>Eh’yeh</i> expressed in the verse, <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel: ‘Eh’yeh’ hath sent me unto you</i>. It appears that Onkelos’ opinion is that <i>the glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> of which He informed Moses was this four-letter Name of which He commanded him, <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel: ‘Eh’yeh’ hath sent me unto you</i>. But He first informed him of the purport thereof, for Moses’ request had been to know the ways of G-d through His Name, just as he was once again to request [later on]: <i>Let me know Thy ways, that I may know Thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:13.</i> And just as He answered him then, <i>And I will proclaim the name of the Eternal before thee, and I will be gracious unto whom I will be gracious</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> — meaning that with <i>this glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> which He will proclaim before him, He will be gracious and will show mercy, and no man can fathom the profundity of His ways — in the same vein He said to him now: “I will be with him that I will be,” meaning, “with My Name that you will tell them, namely, <i>Eh’yeh</i>, with that Name I am gracious and show mercy to man.”<br>And the Gaon Rav Saadia wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">In his Arabic translation of, and commentary on, the Torah. So clearly mentioned by Rabbi Abraham the son of Rambam in his commentary (Wiesenberg ed., London, 1958, p. 226). See Index in my Kithvei Haramban, Vol. II, p. 564, under <i>lashon</i>, for Ramban’s extensive use of Arabic. In view then of the fact that Ibn Ezra does not mention this interpretation of Rav Saadia Gaon in his commentary, nor is it found in Saadia’s philosophic work Emunoth Vehadei’oth, it may be assumed that Ramban saw it in the original Arabic.</i> that its explanation is as follows: “[He is the Being] Whose existence has never ceased and will never cease, for He is the first and the last.” The opinion of the Gaon is not far from the opinion of Rabbi Yitzchak, [i.e., that the name <i>Eh’yeh</i> indicates eternity, as explained above].<br>And the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has said in the Moreh Nebuchim (Guide of the Perplexed)<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Part I, Chapter 63. In Friedlander’s translation: p. 239.</i> that the meaning of <i>Eh’yeh Asher Eh’yeh</i> is: “He is the existing Being which is the existing Being, that is to say, Whose existence is absolute. The proof which Moses was to give to the elders of Israel consisted in demonstrating that there is a Being of absolute existence, that has never been and never will be without existence.”<br>Now according to these Sages,<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, Rabbi Yitzchak, Rav Saadia Gaon, and Rambam in his Moreh Nebuchim, all mentioned above.</i> it is necessary to explain that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses that he should tell them this Name and teach them its import. That is to say, Moses was to inform them of this Name and show the rational proofs by which His eternal being or existence would be firmly established among their wise men. The mere mention of the Divine Name — be it whatever it may —is no proof in itself to eradicate the doctrine of the eternity [of matter] from among them, or the calculated heresy of denying the existence [of the Supreme Being] altogether. But this is not the sense of the verse! Rather, [it clearly implies] that the very mention of the Name to them will be the proof, sign and token on the matter they will have asked of Moses.<br>In my opinion, the elders of Israel never doubted the existence of the Creator, as the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] said — Heaven forbid! But this Name does contain the answer to [Moses’ question of G-d], as we have explained it to you.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Namely, that Moses asked by what Divine attribute is his mission to them, whether with the attribute of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> which stood by the patriarchs, or with the high attribute of mercy with which signs and wonders, new phenomena in creation, will be done to speed their redemption — all as explained above.</i> He informed Moses that he is being sent to them with the attribute of justice, which is within the attribute of mercy, [suggesting that the miracles which will be done on behalf of their deliverance from the bondage will at the same time be acts of judgment against the Egyptians. This is the sense of <i>Eh’yeh Asher Eh’yeh:</i> “<i>I will be</i> in judgment <i>that which I will be</i> in mercy].” And then G-d said to Moses, <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel: ‘Eh’yeh’ sent me unto you</i>, thus teaching the unity [of the two attributes, which explains why the Divine Name is not mentioned here twice]. It is for this reason that G-d commanded Moses yet further, <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel: The Eternal… hath sent me unto you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15. The Divine Name mentioned here is the Tetragrammaton.</i> for this Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton], indicates the attribute of mercy, and thus they will know <i>that He hath caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:12.</i> and He will make new signs and wonders in the world. Thus G-d explained to Moses that the Name <i>Eh’yeh</i> which He commanded him to tell the children of Israel corresponds to this Great Name [the Tetragrammaton] and that they are alike in language, [as both signify eternal existence], and in letters, for the two final letters of the first Name [<i>Eh’yeh</i>] constitute the first ones in the Tetragrammaton. And may the Holy One, blessed be He, show us wonders in His Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">See a similar ending in Vol. I, p. 553. Ramban evidently uses the expression in order to indicate that he has merely touched on only the surface of the mysteries here indicated in the text, and one must constantly pray to be shown new wonders that lie hidden in the Torah.</i>

Verse 14



Verse 15

AND THIS IS MY MEMORIAL UNTO ALL GENERATIONS. This refers back to <i>the G-d of Abraham, the G-d of Isaac, and the G-d of Jacob</i>, for the covenant [of G-d] with the patriarchs will never be forgotten, and throughout all generations whenever the children of Israel will mention [in prayer], “the G-d of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob,” <i>G-d shall hear and answer them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 55:20. The verse here thus states: <i>“Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel</i>. Whenever you mention Me in prayer say thus: <i>‘G-d of Abraham, G-d of Isaac…’ This is My memorial unto all generations.”</i></i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], <i>this is My name forever</i> refers to <i>the G-d of Abraham, the G-d of Isaac. And this is My memorial</i> refers to the expression, <i>and the G-d of Jacob</i>. This is the reason He added here the letter <i>vav — [v’zeh zichri (‘And’ this is My memorial)]</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">It is to indicate that this is the preponderant Name in the memorial (Bachya).</i> This is the sense of the expression, <i>zichri l’dor dor</i>, [with the words <i>l’dor dor</i> written] defectively, [i.e., without a <i>vav</i> between the <i>dalet</i> and the <i>resh</i>]. The person learned in the mysteries of the Torah will understand.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND THEY SHALL HEARKEN TO THY VOICE. “I.e., of their own accord. As soon as you will mention to them this expression, [namely, the double use of the word <i>pakod — pakod pakad’ti (I have surely remembered)</i>, mentioned in Verse 16], they will immediately hearken to your voice for they have long had this sign as a tradition from Jacob and Joseph, that by use of this expression they will be delivered [from Egypt]. Jacob said to them, <i>and G-d will surely remember you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 50:24, that it is Joseph who is speaking. But it is clearly implied there that Joseph is quoting a tradition given to him by his father. Hence Rashi here mentions it in the name of Jacob. Ramban will further stress the fact that it was Joseph who stated it twice.</i> and Joseph said to them, <i>G-d will surely remember you</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> Thus the language of Rashi. Perhaps Rashi will explain that Joseph used this expression twice<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 233 above.</i> in order to affirm that it was a tradition he received from his father.<br>And in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah, the Rabbis said:<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:11.</i> “[As soon as you will say to them <i>pakod pakad’ti</i>], they will immediately hearken to your voice. Why? It is because they have a tradition of the words [wherein G-d will announce the approaching redemption], so that the redeemer who will come and mention to them this double <i>p’kidah</i> [remembrance] is the true redeemer.” Thus the language of the Rabbis on this Agadah.<br>Now you may ask: Why should they listen to Moses? Perhaps he heard this tradition as well as they did. In reply it may be said that thus they received the tradition from Joseph, who heard it from their father the prophet: <i>the first person</i> who will come and announce the message with this expression [<i>pakod pakad’ti</i>] will be the one who will deliver them [from Egypt], it being revealed and known before the Holy One, blessed be He, that no man will come and deceive them. This He promised them.<br>But in another place in the Midrash I found:<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:1.</i> “Said Rabbi Chama the son of Rabbi Chanina: ‘When Moses was in his twelfth year, he was torn up from his father’s house. Why? Had he grown up in his father’s house, the children of Israel would not have believed in him when he came and told them these things.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is: <i>hama’asim</i> (the deeds). If this is the correct reading, it is obviously a reference not only to the words of the message, but also to all of the signs he did before the people. (See further, 4:1-9 and 30). However, from the concluding language of this Midrash quoted here further — <i>kol had’varim</i> (‘all’ the words) — it is clear that the sense here is also “words,” and reference is to the wording of the message of redemption: <i>pakod pakad’ti</i>.</i> They would have said that his father handed him over these words, as Joseph had handed them over to Levi, and Levi to Kohath, and Kohath to Amram. This was why he was torn up from his father’s house, and when he came and told Israel all the words, they therefore believed him, as it is said, <i>And the people believed</i>.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 4:31.</i> The intent of the Rabbis’ words that Joseph handed it over to Levi [and as to why Jacob did not reveal it directly to Levi] is that Jacob revealed the secret to Joseph because of his love for him.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:3. And see Ramban there, Vol. I, pp. 451-2.</i> With this very same language Joseph made all his brothers swear, and he revealed it to Levi.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">On the basis of Genesis 50:25, Ramban’s intent may be explained as follows: Joseph made all his brothers swear to bring his bones up from Egypt at the time of the redemption, and to Levi he revealed the secret of <i>pakod pakad’ti</i>, that with these words the true messenger will announce the approaching redemption.</i> He told them that he gave this [as a secret to Levi] on account of the tradition he received from his father [not to reveal it], and he commanded that the matter remain a secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">Hence when Moses came and said the words <i>pakod pakad’ti</i>, the elders of Israel who now knew of the tradition confirmed him as the true redeemer, for they knew that he could not have heard these words from his father as he was torn up from his father’s home when only twelve years old.</i>

Verse 19

V’LO B’YAD CHAZAKAH’ (AND NOT BY A MIGHTY HAND). “So long as I do not let him feel My mighty hand he will not let you go.” Thus the words of Rashi.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">The sense of the verse according to Rashi is thus: “except by a mighty hand.” It is so translated in the J.P.S. translation. Ramban will suggest its meaning to be: “and not even by a mighty hand.”</i><br>The correct interpretation in my opinion is: <i>“The king of Egypt will not give you leave to go</i> by plea, <i>and not</i> [even] <i>by a mighty hand</i>, until I will put forth My hand <i>with all My wonders which I will do in his midst,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> <i>by a mighty hand, and by an outstretched arm, and by great terrors, and by signs and by wonders</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:35. In the verse there, the phrase “by trials and by wonders” is listed first.</i> <i>And after that he will let you go.”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> Indeed, all these manifestations came upon him before he gave them leave to go.

Chapter 4



Verse 1

AND MOSES ANSWERED AND SAID: BUT, BEHOLD, THEY WILL NOT BELIEVE ME, NOR HEARKEN UNTO MY VOICE. “At that moment, Moses spoke improperly. The Holy One, blessed be He, had told him, <i>And they shall hearken to thy voice</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:18.</i> and he said, <i>But, behold, they will not believe me</i>. Immediately, the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him according to his opinion,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Since it was Moses’ opinion that the people would not believe him, he was therefore in need of certain wonders which he was to do before them to convince them of the truth of his mission. Accordingly, G-d now gave him the wonders he was to do. The implication of the Midrash is thus clear: If Moses had not said that the people would not believe him, there would have been no need for him to do these wonders before them.</i> and gave him signs commensurate with his words.” Thus the language of V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:15.</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, that G-d related to Moses that the elders will believe him, but He did not mention that the people will believe. Perhaps they may hearken to his voice but would not believe him wholeheartedly. But this does not appear to be correct. Rather, it is possible to say that <i>v’sham’u l’kolecha (and they shall hearken to thy voice)</i> does not constitute a promise but a command: “And they must hearken to your voice” — for it is to their advantage to listen — <i>and thou shalt come, thou and the elders of Israel, unto the king of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:18.</i> A similar case is found in the verse, <i>When the Egyptians shall hear — for Thou broughtest up this people in Thy might from among them — they will say to the inhabitants of this land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:13-14.</i> meaning it is fitting that the Egyptians should say so. Similarly, the verse, <i>In this thou shalt know that I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:17.</i> means it is fitting that it be so, but not that it so happened. In a similar vein is the verse in this chapter, <i>and they will believe the voice of the latter sign</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> [which means it is fitting that they believe the latter sign], and many similar cases.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the expression <i>v’sham’u l’kolecha</i> means that “they will listen to you to come with you to the king and say to him, <i>The G-d of the Hebrews hath happened to meet us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:3.</i> for what will they lose by it?” Thus G-d informed Moses that the king of Egypt would not give them leave to go, and this was why Moses said, <i>But, behold, they will not believe me</i>, for after seeing that Pharaoh did not give them permission to go, they would no longer believe him at all, <i>for they will say:</i> “<i>The Eternal hath not appeared unto thee</i>. If you were G-d’s messenger, Pharaoh would not have rebelled against His word.” It may be that they will say that “G-d has not appeared to you by the Great Name with the attribute of mercy, to do for us signs and wonders as you have said, for you are not greater than the patriarchs.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">To whom He appeared as <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>. See Ramban above, 3:13, for a full explanation of this matter.</i> This was why Pharaoh did not hearken, for if Pharaoh had believed your words, we would have gone out from Egypt under all circumstances, and it is not our iniquities that have separated between us and the G-d of mercies.”<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 59:2.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND HE SAID: CAST IT ON THE GROUND. AND HE CAST IT ON THE GROUND. I do not understand why G-d performed the signs before Moses. Moses believed that it is the Holy One, blessed be He, Who speaks with him, and it would have been fitting for Him to say, “The staff that is in your hand you shall cast on the ground before them, and it shall become a serpent,” and the same also with respect to the second sign, [i.e., his hand becoming leprous], just as He said at the third sign, <i>and thou shalt take of the water of the river, and pour it upon the dry land</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 9. In other words, the third sign of the water turning to blood was not performed now, but only when Moses came before the people. The question thus arises: Why did He perform the first two signs — the staff turning into a serpent, and Moses’ hand becoming leprous — before Moses now?</i> It is for this reason that the words of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:16.</i> can be relied upon, namely, that the first sign, [i.e., the staff turning into a serpent], was a hint to Moses that he had slandered the Israelites [when he said that they would not believe him],<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 3:5, that the serpent was the first creature to slander when it said to Eve, <i>For G-d doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, ye shall be as G-d, knowing good and evil</i>. Thus it suggested to her that it was not because it may bring about her death that G-d forbade it, but out of a sense of jealousy. As Rashi puts it: “Every artisan detests his fellow-artisans.”</i> and the second sign was for the purpose of punishing him.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 12:1-10 that the punishment for slander is leprosy.</i> And this is the sense of the expression, <i>and Moses fled from before it</i> [the serpent]. He feared lest he would be punished and the serpent would bite him, since every person naturally avoids danger, even though Moses knew that if it was indeed G-d’s desire [to punish him], there was no one that could deliver him out of His hand.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">See Daniel 8:4.</i><br>Perhaps even though He informed Moses of the Great Name with which the world was created and everything came into existence,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 3:13.</i> He wished to show him that with this Name signs and wonders would be done, changing the natural order of things, so that the matter would be firmly established in Moses’ heart and that he should in truth know that with the Great Name he will perform new things in the world. The first two signs were sufficient for Moses, and therefore the third miracle of the water [turning into blood] was not done here. Instead, G-d commanded him to do the third sign in the sight of the people.

Verse 4



Verse 5

THAT THEY MAY BELIEVE THAT THE ETERNAL … HATH APPEARED TO THEE. The interpretation of this verse is that “they may believe when you do the sign before them.” Scripture, however, speaks briefly about this for it is self-understood that G-d showed Moses wonders with the intent that he perform them before the people in order that they believe him.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

V’HAYU’ (AND IT SHALL BE) THAT THE WATER WHICH THOU TAKEST OUT OF THE RIVER ‘V’HAYU’ (SHALL BECOME) BLOOD UPON THE DRY LAND. “The word <i>v’hayu</i> is mentioned here twice.<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">The literal translation of the Hebrew text is: “And it shall be that the water which thou takest out of the river, and it will be blood upon the dry land.”</i> It appears to me that if He had said, ‘<i>V’hayu</i> (And it shall be) that the water which thou takest out of the river be blood upon the dry land,’ I might understand it to mean that it would be turned into blood in his hand, and that also when it reached the ground it would remain in the same state. But now, [as the verse actually reads], the final <i>v’hayu</i> teaches us that it would not become blood until it reaches the dry land.”<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">The significance of this point is explained by L’vush Ha’orah (see Preface in Vol. I, p. IX, Note 12): If the water had turned into blood while still in Moses’ hand, skeptics could say that it was done through some secret art. But running or flowing water turning into blood upon reaching the ground was undeniably a miracle.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But the purport of this verse is not as the Rabbi [Rashi] has it, and there is no need for his Midrash, for the masters of language<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Found in R’dak’s Sefer Hamichlal. The repetition of a verb occurs after a lengthy intervening phrase.</i> have found in many places that it is the normal style of Scripture to repeat words for the purpose of emphasis and significance, or because of some lengthy phrase intervening between them. Such a case is the verse: <i>And if a Levite come from any of thy gates out of all Israel, where he sojourneth, and come with all the desire of his soul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 18:6.</i> Here Scripture repeats [the verb] “come” because of the lengthy expression between [the parts of the verse]. Similarly: <i>And the king of Egypt spoke to the Hebrew midwives, of whom the name of the one was Shiphrah, and the name of the other Puah; and he said: When ye act as midwives</i>, etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:15-16. Here the verb “said” is repeated because of the identification of the midwives stated in the verse.</i> <i>And G-d spoke unto Israel in the visions of the night, and He said: Jacob, Jacob</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:2.</i> There are many instances of such verses.

Verse 10

AND MOSES SAID UNTO THE ETERNAL: O LORD, I AM NOT A MAN OF WORDS, NEITHER YESTERDAY NOR RECENTLY NOR SINCE THOU HAST SPOKEN UNTO THY SERVANT; FOR I AM SLOW OF SPEECH AND OF A SLOW TONGUE. “This teaches us that for an entire period of seven days, the Holy One, blessed be He, sat<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">“Sat.” This word is not found in our text of Rashi.</i> and urged Moses to undertake the mission. [The expressions], ‘yesterday,’ ‘recently,’ and ‘since Thou hast spoken,’ imply three days, and the three-fold word <i>gam</i> — [here translated ‘neither’ or ‘nor,’ but literally meaning ‘also’] — points to a similar extension of time. Thus you have six days [that have passed], and it was now the seventh day [when Moses still refused to go on his mission].” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the purport of the verse is as follows: [Moses said,] “For I am slow of speech from heretofore and from time past, for I have been slow of speech from my youth on and all the more now that I am old, <i>and also</i> now <i>since Thou hast spoken unto Thy servant</i>, for Thou hast not removed the defect in my speech when Thou didst command me to go to Pharaoh to speak in Thy name. How then can I go before him?” Now Moses out of his great desire not to go [on the mission] did not pray before G-d, blessed be He, that He remove his defective speech from him, but he argued: “Since You have not removed my slowness of speech from me from the time You spoke to me to undertake this mission, do not command me to go, for it is inconceivable that the Master of everything should send a man <i>of uncircumcised lips</i><sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:12.</i> to a king of the nations.” And since Moses did not pray [for the removal of his defect], the Holy One, blessed be He, did not desire to heal him. Instead, He said to him, <i>I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt speak</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> meaning that “you will be able to correctly express the words which I will put in your mouth.”<br>And in V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 3:20.</i> the Rabbis said: “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: ‘Do not mind it that you are not a man of words. Have I not made the mouth of all that speak, and him that I desire I made dumb? And have I not made the deaf and the blind, and opened their eyes to see and ears to hear? Now had I wanted that you be a man of words, you would have been so. But it is my desire that you continue to be so, and when you will speak [to Pharaoh] your utterance will be correct, for <i>I will be with thy mouth</i>.’<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> This is the sense of the verse, <i>Now therefore go, and I will be with thy mouth</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i><br>According to this Midrash, it appears to me that the reason He did not desire to remove his defective speech from him was because a miraculous event,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">That such is the intent of Ramban — and not that Moses did not desire to have the defect removed — may be seen from the language of the Tur, who states: “Some scholars say He did not heal him because Moses’ defective speech came through a miracle.”</i> as told by our Rabbis, happened to Moses when he was still before Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban evidently refers to Shemoth Rabbah 1:31, wherein it is related that when Moses was still an infant and Pharaoh played with him on his lap, Moses took the crown from the king’s head and placed it on his own. Terrified at what had happened, the magicians advised that he be slain. But Jethro, who was one of the counsellors of the king, advised that he be tested as follows: Two dishes were to be placed before him, one containing pieces of gold and the other live coal. If he would stretch out his hand for the gold, it would be known that his taking the crown was done consciously, and therefore he was to be slain. But it he would grasp the live coal, he was innocent. When the test was made, Moses began stretching his hand toward the gold, but the angel Gabriel made him take the live coal. Thereupon Moses put his hand with the coal into his mouth, which burnt part of his tongue. As a result, he became slow of speech and of a slow tongue for all his life.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that G-d said to Moses, “<i>Who hath made man’s mouth? or Who maketh a man dumb? … Is it not I the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> Who does all this? I could heal you. <i>But now</i> since you did not want to be healed, nor have you prayed to me about it, <i>go and I will be with thy mouth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> and I will cause you success in My mission.” It is also possible that there is a hint in the verse, <i>And the anger of the Eternal was kindled against Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> that He did not want to heal him, and that He sent him against his will.

Verse 11

WHO HATH MADE MAN’S MOUTH? This is a reference to man’s power of speech because it resides in the mouth. Similarly: <i>Safa echad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 11:1.</i> [literally: “one lip”] (<i>one language</i>); <i>that speak ‘s’fath’ Canaan</i><sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 19:18.</i> [literally: “the lip of”] (<i>the language of Canaan</i>).
OR WHO MAKETH A MAN DUMB? Scholars have explained<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">The difficulty presents itself: Since the absence of a property is nothing positive and dumbness is the lack of the property of speech, how can one speak of “the making” of dumbness when it is nonexistent? See Rambam’s Moreh Nebuchim, III, 10, where the author discusses this problem. The answer, quoted here by Ramban, that it refers back to “the man,” suggesting, “Who can create a man without the capacity of speech?” is mentioned there by Rambam.</i> that this refers back to man, meaning: “Who maketh a man that is dumb?” That is to say, “Who has created a man without the capacity of speaking?” “The making” thus refers to the making of man, but as regards the absence of the power of speech, you cannot speak in terms of “making,” for it is non-existence, the lack of the power of speech. Perhaps because man has a speaking soul,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Genesis 2:7 (Vol. I, pp. 66-69) on the great significance of this point.</i> and, for people who lack this capacity, it is due to some obstruction in the veins of the tongue, it is then possible to say, “Who made the dumbness?” [since the making of the obstruction required an act]. Now the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] said in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Moreh Nebuchim, III, 10.</i> that it may be said of him who removes a certain property that he produced the absence of that property, for they say of him who puts out the light that he has produced darkness. In accordance with this view, Rambam explains the verse, <i>I form the light and create darkness, I make peace and create evil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 45:7.</i> [for darkness and evil are non-existent things].

Verse 12



Verse 13

SEND, I PRAY THEE, BY THE HAND OF HIM WHOM THOU WILT SEND. “This means by the hand of him whom You are accustomed to send, and that is Aaron. Another explanation is: by the hand of some other person whom Thou wilt be pleased to send, for in the end I will not bring them into the Land, nor am I destined to be their deliverer in the future. Thou hast many messengers.” Thus the language of Rashi. And Onkelos said: “by the hand of him who is fit to be sent.” This means: “Send by the hand of him who speaks eloquently, who will be fit and proper for an honorable mission such as this. Do not send by the hand of one who is slow of speech and of a slow tongue and be with his mouth when he speaks before Pharaoh, since it is not a matter of respect and honor that Your messenger be one <i>of uncircumcised lips</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:12.</i> and none of the people will heed him when he speaks before the king, since this will appear to them as a defect.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Moses said, “<i>Send, I pray Thee, by the hand</i> of anyone <i>whom Thou wilt send</i>, for there is not a person in the world who is not more fit for the mission than I.” The reason for all this obduracy of Moses was his great meekness, <i>above all the men that were upon the face of the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:3.</i> as he could not see himself assuming importance and speaking to the king and [taking] glory in saying, “The Eternal sent me,” nor [to speak] to Israel to bring them out from Egypt and be king<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:5.</i> over them.

Verse 14

I KNOW THAT HE [Aaron] CAN SPEAK WELL. That is to say, “It is revealed before Me that, out of his love for you, Aaron will willingly speak on your behalf even if I were not to command him. <i>And also, behold, he cometh forth</i> of his own bidding <i>to meet thee, and when he seeth thee he will be glad in his heart</i>, and he will not be jealous over your distinction in this honorable mission.” The reason that it was necessary that G-d tell Aaron, <i>Go into the wilderness to meet Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Further. Verse 27.</i> was in order to inform him of the road by which Moses was coming. It is possible that Aaron heard of Moses’ departure from Midian, and on his own accord he went out to meet him. Afterwards, when he was already on the way, it was said to him, “Go into the wilderness to meet him, for there you will find him.”

Verse 15

AND I WILL BE WITH THY MOUTH. I.e., “to teach you that which you are to speak to Pharaoh.” G-d now told Moses that Aaron will speak on his behalf only to the people, as it is said, <i>And he shall be thy spokesman unto the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> but Moses himself was to speak to Pharaoh. It is possible that this was out of respect to the king. But in the end, Moses came back and said, <i>Behold, I am of uncircumcised lips, and how shall Pharaoh hearken unto me?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:30.</i> G-d then permitted him that he should not speak even to Pharaoh. This [consent] was a distinction to Moses, and therefore He said there, <i>See, I have set thee in G-d’s stead to Pharaoh</i>, and <i>Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:1</i> And the intent of the expression [here in the verse], <i>and I will be with his</i> [Aaron’s] <i>mouth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., why was this promise necessary since Aaron was not defective of speech?</i> is that his words will find favor with everyone that will hear them.

Verse 16



Verse 17

AND THOU SHALT TAKE IN THY HAND THIS ROD, WHEREWITH THOU SHALT DO THE SIGNS. Concerning the rod, only one sign — that it turn into a serpent — has thus far been mentioned. But the [plural] expression “the signs” means “the signs which I will tell you.”<br>It appears to me that when G-d said to Moses, <i>With all My wonders which I will do in his midst</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:20.</i> He informed him of all the wonders in detail, but Scripture speaks briefly, and this is the intent of the expression here, <i>wherewith thou shalt do the signs</i>.

Verse 18



Verse 19

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES IN MIDIAN: GO, RETURN UNTO EGYPT, etc. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said, “There is no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 18 it says that Moses bid farewell to Jethro because he was ready to return to Egypt. Why then was it necessary now that G-d command him to return there? For this reason, Ibn Ezra renders Verse 19 as meaning: “now the Eternal <i>had</i> said.”</i> and the explanation thereof is, ‘now the Eternal had said.’ There are many similar cases.”<br>But Ibn Ezra’s interpretation here is not correct. The first Divine communication, [i.e., that Moses return to Egypt], was not in Midian but at Mount Sinai.<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:10. <i>Come now therefore, and I will send thee unto Pharaoh</i>.</i> In Midian He spoke to him only at this time, [as mentioned in the present verse]. However, when Moses accepted the mission by word of G-d to go to Egypt and he returned to Midian to obtain permission from his father-in-law, it was his intention to go alone and disguised. It is for this reason that Moses said to Jethro, <i>Let me go, I pray thee, and return unto my brethren that are in Egypt, and see whether they be yet alive</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> That is to say, “I will see my brethren whether they be yet alive and I will return,” for it was to be in the nature of a visit by one who is anxious to see his brethren. But then the Eternal said to him in Midian, <i>Go, return unto Egypt</i>, that is to say, “Arise, go out of this land and return to the land of Egypt and have no fear there, for all those who sought to harm you have died, and stay there with the people until you will bring them forth from there.” Therefore Moses took his wife and children since it was the right way to bring them with him, insamuch as the children of Israel would have greater reliance on him because of it. [They would say]: “A free man in Midian who lives peacefully in his home with his children and with his wife, a son-in-law of the priest of the land, would not have brought them to be with slaves and make their lives bitter with hard service if his heart were not steadfast. He is trusting that they will soon go out from Egypt and that he will go up with them to the land of Canaan, and that it will then not be necessary for him to return to Midian to take his wife and his children from there.”

Verse 20

AND MOSES TOOK HIS WIFE AND HIS SONS. The intent thereof is like that of the verse, <i>And the sons of Pallu: Eliab</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 26:8. It states “sons” in the plural, but mentions only one son. A similar case is here, as Ramban explains.</i> At that time, he had only Gershom, as Scripture mentions,<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:22.</i> and his wife became pregnant with Eliezer on the way [to Egypt] or in Egypt, if she went there.<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further in this verse.</i><br>It is possible that before the Divine communication came to him <i>on the mountain of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Above 3:1.</i> only Gershom had been born. Zipporah however was already pregnant [with Eliezer], and when he returned to Jether his father-in-law,<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> she gave birth, but <i>because the King’s business required haste</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 21:9. Ramban evidently understands here the word “king” as referring to G-d.</i> he did not circumcise him, nor did he give him a name. On the way when his mother circumcised him,<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> she did not give him a name, as Moses was met at that time by the angel.<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24. And see Rashi: “and the angel sought, etc.”</i> It was after he came to Egypt and saw that he was saved from all those who sought his life that he then called him Eliezer, <i>for the G-d of my father was my help, and delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:4.</i> Our Rabbis have also stated<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:8.</i> that the child that was circumcised [by Zipporah, as mentioned here in Verse 25], was Eliezer.
AND HE RETURNED TO THE LAND OF EGYPT. I.e., with those mentioned [at the beginning of the verse, namely, his wife and his sons]. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the expression, <i>and he returned to the land of Egypt</i>, means that Moses alone returned. When he was met by G-d,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24. Ibn Ezra refers to the language of the verse: <i>and the Eternal met him</i>. See above, Note 298.</i> Eliezer was circumcised, and when he was healed, Zipporah together with her children returned to her father.<br>This [explanation of Ibn Ezra] is possible, for due to the fact that Eliezer was circumcised, Moses could not take him on the road until the child would become strong. At the same time, he did not want to delay the mission of the Holy One, blessed be He, and therefore he left them in the lodging-place and commanded Zipporah to return to her father’s home when the child will become healed. This is the purport of the expression, <i>after he had sent her away</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:2.</i> It is also probable that they all went to Egypt, and after they stayed there for some time, she longed for her father and so Moses sent her with the children. This then would be the sense of the word <i>shilucheha (after ‘he had sent her away’)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:2.</i> since Jethro feared that perhaps it was Moses’ intent to divorce her.<br>And in V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 4:4.</i> [the Rabbis have said]: <i>“And Moses went and returned to Jether his father-in-law</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> Where did he go? He went to take his wife and sons. Jethro said to him, ‘Where do you take them?’ Moses replied, ‘To Egypt.’ Jethro said to him, ‘Now that those who are in Egypt wish to leave it, do you desire to lead them there?’ Moses replied, ‘Very soon [those held in bondage] are destined to go forth from there and stand at Mount Sinai and hear the words of the Almighty, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d Who brought thee out of the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:2.</i> Should my children not hear it together with them?’ Jethro said to Moses, <i>‘Go in peace.’”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> In accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis [in the above Midrash], it is proper that we explain that after Moses and Jethro agreed on Moses’ returning to Egypt, the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded him thereon, thus confirming the word of His servant,<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 44:26.</i> and he returned to Egypt with his sons and his wife, as I have explained.

Verse 21

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: ‘WHEN THOU GOEST BACK INTO EGYPT SEE ALL THE WONDERS,’ etc. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that this was said to Moses when he was yet in Midian. G-d informed him that He would harden Pharaoh’s heart and he would not let the people go because of all the wonders which he would see until the last wonder. Ibn Ezra’s intent is thus to explain this verse as saying: “<i>See</i> that for <i>all the wonders which I have put in thy hand</i> and which you will do <i>before Pharaoh</i>, for all of these he will not let them go until you will tell him that I will slay his son, his firstborn. Then he will let them go.”<br>This explanation is not correct for what sense is there for the expression, <i>when thou goest back into Egypt, see</i>, etc.? Rather, the purport thereof is as follows: When leaving Midian, Moses took the rod of G-d in his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> <i>to mark the way with his footsteps</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 85:14.</i> G-d forewarned him and said to him, “When you go on the way, <i>mark well and behold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 44:5.</i> that all the wonders which I have put in your hand you should do before Pharaoh; do not forget to do anything before him. <i>And I will harden his heart</i>, but do not despair from doing them because of his obstinacy, and you will yet warn him again on the last plague which will cause him to let them go.” The purport of the expression, <i>I have put in thy hand</i>, is that “in your hand I have put them; you are to do them, and not someone else.” He had already informed him that He would perform many signs and wonders in Pharaoh’s midst, as He said, <i>with all My wonders which I will do in his midst</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:20.</i> All this was an encouragement to Moses, for since he was forced to go on the mission, G-d warned him before the action, and commanded him again at the time of the action before each and every wonder.<br>It is possible that the expression [concerning the smiting of his firstborn], <i>and thou shalt say unto Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> is but to inform Moses now that in the end He will so command him to say it to Pharaoh. Thus the purport of His words is as follows: “<i>I will harden his heart and he will not let the people go</i> in spite of all the wonders, <i>and thou shalt say</i> to him on that day, <i>‘Behold I will slay thy son, thy firstborn,’</i> and then he will let them go.” We do not find that He informed Moses of the death of their firstborn except at this time, and thus [we must say] that not all of the Divine communication [here given to Moses was relayed to Pharaoh] now.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">The intent of Ramban is as follows: In Chapter 11, Verse 1, it is said concerning the final plague: <i>And the Eternal said unto Moses: Yet one plague more will I bring upon Pharaoh, and upon Egypt; afterwards he will let you go hence</i>. But nothing was mentioned to Moses about what that plague was. Ramban suggests that Verses 22-23 here concerning the final plague were said to Moses now with the understanding that later, before the tenth plague, he was to relay the warning to Pharaoh, but not that he said it to Pharaoh as soon as he came to see him. Hence it was not necessary for Scripture to say in Chapter 11, Verse 1, what that “one plague more” was.</i><br>It is possible to explain [the matter as follows]: “<i>See all</i> these three<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">The staff turning into a serpent, Moses’ hand becoming leprous, and the waters turning into blood (Verses 3-9).</i> <i>wonders which I have put in thy hand</i> to do before the Israelites, <i>do them</i> also <i>before Pharaoh</i> so that Pharaoh should know that the elders of the people who request of him to let them go say so according to the commandment of G-d, and he should not come with a pretext against them.” And so did Moses do [these three wonders<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">The staff turning into a serpent, Moses’ hand becoming leprous, and the waters turning into blood (Verses 3-9).</i> before Pharaoh], even though it is not so written. The verse [further on] which states, <i>When Pharaoh shall speak unto you, saying: ‘Show a wonder for you,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:9.</i> [which might indicate that the wonder of the staff turning into a serpent was done by a special command, and not because of the Divine communication here, as explained above], means that Pharaoh will want a sign for himself. G-d thus commanded Moses to throw the rod and it shall become a <i>tanin</i>, not a <i>nachash</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus distinguishes between the <i>nachash</i> mentioned here in Verse 3, and <i>tanin</i> mentioned further in 7:9. Rashi however explains there that <i>tanin</i> means <i>nachash</i>. In the J.P.S. translation, both terms are translated as “serpents.” In other translations, <i>nachash</i> is translated as “snake,” and <i>tanin</i> as “reptile.” Some such distinction between the terms is to be made according to Ramban.</i> as mentioned the first time. Thus He wanted to show Pharaoh that Aaron’s rod would swallow up their rods, instructing him that He would vanquish them and that they would be destroyed forever by Him.<br>In the Midrash V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:6.</i> I have seen mentioned: “[<i>And the Eternal said to Moses: ‘When thou goest into Egypt, see all the wonders,’</i> etc.] To which wonders does He refer? If you say that it is to [the staff turning into] a serpent, [his hand becoming] leprous, and [the waters turning into] blood, the Holy One, blessed be He, told Moses to do these only before Israel! Moreover, we find nowhere that Moses did these signs before Pharaoh. But what then is the meaning of <i>all the wonders which I have put in thy hand?</i> This refers to the rod upon which were written the initials of the ten plagues: <i>‘D’tzach Adash B’achab.’</i> ”<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">They are: <i>Dam</i> (blood), <i>Tz’phardei’a</i> (frogs), <i>Kinim</i> (lice), <i>Arob</i> (beasts), <i>Dever</i> (murrain), <i>Sh’chin</i> (boils), <i>Barad</i> (hail), <i>Arbeh</i> (locusts), <i>Choshech</i> (darkness), <i>Makath-b’choroth</i> (slaying of the firstborn).</i> According to this Midrash, the explanation of the verse will be: “<i>See</i> and contemplate the writing on the rod <i>which I have put in thy hand</i>, for all wonders thereon you will perform before Pharaoh.”

Verse 27

AND HE MET HIM IN THE MOUNTAIN OF G-D. Thus you learn that Mount Sinai is between Midian and Egypt.
AND HE KISSED HIM. Aaron kissed Moses, for Moses the humble one treated his older brother with respect. For this reason, it does not say that they kissed each other.

Verse 28

AND MOSES TOLD AARON ALL THE WORDS OF THE ETERNAL WHEREWITH HE HATH SENT HIM. This means that he told all the words which were spoken between him and the Holy One, blessed be He, and all the objections he had raised against undertaking the mission, and that he was sent against his own will. This is the intent of the word <i>kol (‘all’ the words of the Eternal)</i>. In Midrash Chazit<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Another name for the Midrash Rabbah on the Song of Songs. The quote is found there, 4:12. See Vol. I, p. 292, Note 73, for the reason of the name Chazit or Chazita.</i> [we find it stated]: “And the Rabbis say that Moses revealed to Aaron the Tetragrammaton [which had been revealed to him].” The intent of their explanation is that Moses told Aaron the Divine Names mentioned above<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 3:13.</i> by which He sent him, and the Name that is derived [from them],<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary for elucidation of this Cabalistic subject.</i> and the explanation that is inherent in them.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary for elucidation of this Cabalistic subject.</i>

Chapter 5



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

LEST HE FALL UPON US WITH PESTILENCE. “Moses and Aaron wanted to say [to Pharaoh], ‘Lest He fall upon thee,’ but they showed respect to royalty.” Thus the language of Rashi. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: “‘<i>Lest He fall upon us;</i> that is, including us Israelites, also you Pharaoh and all Egypt.’ Therefore when the Egyptians saw the slaying of the firstborn, they said, <i>‘We are all dead men,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:33.</i> for the words of Moses now became clear to them when he said, <i>Lest he fall upon us with pestilence</i>, and therefore they drove them to go to sacrifice [to G-d].”<br>This explanation of Ibn Ezra is not correct, for Moses and Aaron were not commanded to say that Israel too would share in the punishment of pestilence or sword if they would not sacrifice [to G-d],<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Only the Egyptians were to suffer that punishment if they failed to permit the Israelites to go to worship the Eternal.</i> and Moses and Aaron would by no means change anything in the mission of G-d.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], this is the secret of the offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Genesis 4:3 (Vol. I, p. 88, and Note 423).</i> as they constitute a redemption from punishment, for <i>before Him goeth the pestilence</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 3:5. This explains the verse here: <i>Let us go…and sacrifice… lest He fall upon us with pestilence</i>. Ramban then proceeds to explain the end of the verse: <i>or with the sword</i>.</i><br><i>Or with the sword</i>, this means the harsh [attribute of justice]. Moses said this because the Holy One, blessed be He, had commanded them, saying, <i>And you shall say unto him: ‘The Eternal, the G-d of the Hebrews hath met with us. And now let us go … that we may sacrifice to the Eternal our G-d.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> and they said to Pharaoh, <i>Thus saith the Eternal, the G-d of Israel: ‘Let My people go.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> Now Pharaoh was indeed a very wise man. He knew [of the existence of] G-d and acknowledged Him, as he — or his predecessor<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">This is a reference to the difference of opinion among the Rabbis of the Talmud (Sotah 11 a) regarding the verse, <i>Now there arose a new king over Egypt, who knew not Joseph</i> (above, 1:8). One Rabbi said that he was really a new king; the other said that it was the same king but he decreed new edicts, and comported himself as though he did not know him.</i> — said to Joseph: <i>Forasmuch as G-d had shown thee all this;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 41:39.</i> <i>a man in whom the spirit of G-d is</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 38.</i> But Pharaoh did not know the Proper Name of G-d, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton],<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 84.</i> and accordingly, he answered, <i>I know not the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> Therefore they replied and said to him, as they were commanded, <i>The G-d of the Hebrews hath met with us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 3 before us.</i> mentioning to him only <i>the G-d of the Hebrews</i>, which is equivalent to <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>. They said, <i>He hath met with us</i>, relating to Pharaoh the exact language of the message they were commanded to bring him, and they explained to him that in this meeting which they would have [with G-d], it would be necessary for them to sacrifice before Him, lest the meeting be <i>with pestilence, or with the sword</i>. In a similar vein did Scripture set forth in connection with Balaam, as it is said, <i>And G-d met Balaam, and he said unto Him: I have prepared the seven altars, and I have offered up a bullock and a ram on every altar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 23:4.</i>

Verse 4

WHEREFORE DO YE, MOSES AND AARON…? Pharaoh asked them for their names, and he mentioned them by name in a manner indicating respect.
TAPHRI’U’ THE PEOPLE FROM THEIR WORK. Onkelos translated: <i>t’vatlu</i> (you cause them to idle from their work). Similarly: <i>‘porei’a’ (refuseth) instruction</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 13:18. Now Rashi explained <i>taphri’u</i> as meaning: “taking them away.” Ramban therefore calls attention to Onkelos, who interpreted it as meaning “idle,” “making to nought all their work.”</i> <i>‘vatiphr’u’ (and ye have set at nought) all my counsel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:25.</i>
GET YOU TO YOUR BURDENS. If we follow the simple interpretation of Scripture, reference here is to the work for the king,<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s interpretation, mentioned further on in the text, is: “Go to your work which you have to do at home, etc.” Now although Ramban will later agree with this explanation of Rashi, his point here is that in line with the simple meaning of Scripture, “the burdens” are a reference to the labors imposed upon them as slaves.</i> since Moses and Aaron were part of the [Hebrew] people for at this time they came before him with all the people. But he did not listen to them and commanded them: “Return you all to the work.” Later when Moses and Aaron returned before Pharaoh and he said to them, <i>Show a wonder for you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:9.</i> and they did so, they appeared to him like the magicians, sorcerers, and wise men, and he showed them respect. Still later, when the plagues began coming upon him, he was in dread fear of them.<br>It appears furthermore that not all the children of Israel worked all the time for Pharaoh <i>in mortar and in brick</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:14.</i> for in that case they would have filled the whole land of Egypt with cities. Rather, they worked in levies, and he pressed his yoke upon them by taking many of the Israelites [into his labors].
Now Rashi explained: “<i>Get you to your burdens</i>, i.e., ‘to your work which you have to do in your homes.’ But [it cannot signify ‘go to your labors as slaves,’ for he was speaking to Moses and Aaron, who were of the tribe of Levi, and] the work of Egyptian slavery was not imposed upon the tribe of Levi. You may know that this was so because Moses and Aaron went and came as they pleased.” This is correct. All man’s work whether at home or in the field is so called [<i>sebel</i> (labor)], just as in the verse: <i>over all the ‘sebel’ (labor) of the house of Joseph</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:25.</i> And it is customary among all people to have wise men who teach them their laws. Therefore Pharaoh did not impose slavery upon the tribe of Levi, who were the teachers and the elders of the children of Israel, and it was all caused by G-d.<br>I have seen in V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:2.</i> “Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said that the tribe of Levi was free from servile labor. Pharaoh said to them, ‘It is because you are free [from the forced labor] that you therefore say, <i>Let us go and sacrifice to our G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> <i>Get ye unto your burdens</i> for Israel.’<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, “attend to your work of teaching them their laws, but do not divert them from doing my work with such a plan as going on a journey.”</i> Another interpretation: Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, ‘It is enough for you that you are free! Perhaps you are displeased because you are not doing this forced labor; [if so], <i>get ye unto your burdens</i>.’”<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the verse, <i>Get ye unto your burdens</i>, as meaning the burdens of the entire people, since Pharaoh spoke to them for all Israel.

Verse 22

ADO-NOY’, WHEREFORE HAST THOU DEALT ILL WITH THIS PEOPLE? The Divine Name is here written <i>Aleph Dalet</i>, for through the Proper Name of G-d, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton], which is the attribute of mercy, no evil would befall the people. However, above [in Chapter 4, Verses 10 and 13], Moses twice mentioned the Divine Name written <i>Aleph Dalet</i> — [<i>Bi Ado-noy</i> (O G-d)] — since he was praying that the anger of G-d would not be kindled against him [for refusing to undertake the mission to go to Pharaoh]. Perhaps Moses was afraid to mention the Great Divine Name that was then being revealed to him and speaking to him.
WHEREFORE HAST THOU DEALT ILL WITH THIS PEOPLE? [It should be asked]: After G-d twice informed<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:19 and 4:21.</i> Moses that the king of Egypt would not let them go, why did he complain? Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Moses had thought that from the moment he would speak to Pharaoh in the name of G-d, he would ease the burden from upon the children of Israel, and that G-d would begin to redeem them, but Pharaoh hardened and increased their woes. This is the sense of the expression, <i>Wherefore has Thou dealt ill…?</i> “It is the opposite of what Thou hast told me, i.e., <i>I have surely seen the affliction of My</i> people.<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:7.</i> <i>And I am come down to deliver them</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> But this [explanation of Ibn Ezra] does not appear to me to be correct because [Moses said], <i>Neither hast Thou delivered Thy people at all</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> and “delivery” means only their going forth from exile.<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">How then could Ibn Ezra explain that Moses’ primary complaint was that he had thought G-d would merely ease their burden?</i><br>In my opinion, Moses our teacher thought G-d had told him that Pharaoh would not let them go immediately at his command, nor by sign and wonder until He would perform His many wonders among them. But Moses thought that G-d would bring them upon Pharaoh in uninterrupted succession in a few days. When Pharaoh said, <i>I know not the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> He would immediately command him to execute the sign of the serpent before the king, and [if] the king would still not listen, He would smite him on that very day with the plague of blood, followed by all the rest of the plagues. But when Moses saw that three days passed and the king increased their woes every day and G-d did not rebuke him, nor did He reveal Himself to Moses to inform him what he should do, then Moses thought that [the captivity] is a long one.<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 29:28.</i><br>It is possible that there was a long period of time to this story recounted here by Scripture. When the officers of the children of Israel were beaten,<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> days passed until they spoke to Pharaoh himself, saying to him, <i>Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> It is not every person that has a right to come into the inner chambers of the king’s palace and speak to him face to face, and all the more the officers of those people abhorrent to him. Thus they suffered in their burden and oppression many days, and they would come <i>even before the king’s gate</i><sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 4:2.</i> until their outcry was heard before the king and he commanded that they come before him and speak with him. It is likewise possible that Moses returned to the Eternal and said, <i>Wherefore hast Thou dealt ill…</i>, many days after the officers of the children of Israel met him.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i><br>The Rabbis have said in V’eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:23.</i> “<i>And the taskmasters of the people went out, and their officers, and they spoke to the people, saying, Thus saith Pharaoh: I will not give you straw</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> When this was decreed by Pharaoh, Moses went to Midian and stayed there six months while Aaron remained in Egypt. At that time, Moses took his wife and sons back to Midian.” The Rabbis have furthermore said:<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:24.</i> “<i>And they met Moses and Aaron</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> After six months, the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself to Moses in Midian and said to him, <i>Go, return unto Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:19.</i> Moses then came from Midian, and Aaron from Egypt, when they were met by the officers of Israel as they came forth from Pharaoh.” I have furthermore seen a similar [tradition] in Midrash Chazit:<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 2:22. See Note 317 above.</i> “<i>My beloved is like a gazelle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:9.</i> Just as a gazelle appears [and hides] and reappears, so did the first redeemer, [i.e., Moses], appear to the children of Israel, then he disappeared, and then he appeared to them again. For how long was he away from them? Rabbi Tanchuma said three months. It is this which Scripture says, <i>And they met Moses and Aaron</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> And Rabbi Yehudah Beribi<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">In the Midrash above: “Yehudah B’rabbi.” In the Hebrew text of Ramban: “And Rabbi Yehudah Br’.” But see Hyman’s Toldoth Tannaim V’amoraim that the correct reading is: “Rabbi Yehudah Beribi” or “Yudan Beribi”.</i> said that [he was away from them] for periods of time.” That is to say, the word “meeting” — [<i>and they ‘met’ Moses and Aaron</i>] — indicates periods of time.<br>Thus many days passed between G-d’s speaking to Moses and Moses’ coming to Pharaoh. Therefore when Moses returned to G-d he said, “<i>Wherefore hast Thou dealt ill with this people</i>, hurrying to send me before the time [of redemption] had come? It was not fitting to send me until You wanted to deliver them, but now You have dealt ill with them and You have not delivered them. And if You deal thus with them, they will perish in the affliction that will come upon them.” Therefore G-d answered Moses at this time: “Soon <i>shalt thou see what I will do to Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 6:1.</i> for I will not prolong it for him to the extent that you thought, and his time is near to come, and his days shall not be prolonged.”<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 13:22.</i><br>Va’eira

Chapter 6



Verse 1



Verse 2

AND G-D SPOKE UNTO MOSES. Rashi explains that He spoke to him harshly<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s interpretation is based either on the name <i>Elokim</i> (G-d) mentioned here, which signifies the Divine attribute of justice (Mizrachi), or on the two words <i>Va’yedabeir Elokim</i> (And G-d spoke), whereas the usual expression in the Torah is <i>Va’yedabeir Hashem</i> (And the Eternal spoke) (Gur Aryeh).</i> because he had been critical when he said, <i>Wherefore hast Thou dealt ill with this people?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:22.</i> AND HE SAID UNTO HIM: “I AM THE ETERNAL, Who am faithful to recompense reward to those who walk before Me wholeheartedly.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">“Whole-heartedly.” This word is not found in our printed texts of Rashi. But see Genesis 17:2 and 25:27 where it is found in connection with Abraham and Jacob respectively.
