See also Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>, 26:2, where a similar expression is mentioned in connection with Isaac. All three patriarchs were thus whole-hearted in their worship of G-d.</i> In this sense we find the phrase explained in many places, etc.
God appeared to the Patriarchs as the Prime Mover behind all natural events.  His miracles were apparent to them without recourse to violating the natural order.  In times of famine He redeemed them from death and in war from the sword and provided them with wealth and honor and every good thing.  These things, like all the promises in the Torah of blessing and curse, are not meted out to a man as his due, as a reward for good deeds and punishment for sin.  They constitute miracles (of Divine grace).  Man's own deeds do not automatically give rise to favorable effects or otherwise.  But the reward and punishment alluded to in the Torah in this world are in the nature of miracles, hidden ones which the onlookers regard as the workings of nature.  But in reality they are the providential allocation of reward and punishment.... God said to Moses: I appeared to the Patriarchs as One who assists His chosen ones through the might of my hand (but without violating nature).  By My ineffable name expressing the essence of all existence (Exodus 3:14) I was not known to them to introduce innovations changing the natural course of events.  Therefore tell the Children of Israel that I am the Lord and let them know My great name through which I shall perform for them wonders that they may know that I am the Lord who does these things.

Verse 3

“AND I APPEARED UNTO ABRAHAM, etc., BY THE NAME ‘E-IL SHA-DAI’ (G-D ALMIGHTY). I made many promises to him,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“Him”: Abraham. In our texts of Rashi: “Them,” which refers to all three patriarchs, and so it is mentioned further on.</i> and in all cases I said to him, <i>I am G-d Almighty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:4 (to Abraham), 35:11 (to Jacob).</i> BUT BY MY NAME, THE ETERNAL, WAS I NOT KNOWN UNTO THEM.” It was not written here, [“But My Name, the Eternal], I did not make known to them.” Rather, it is written, [<i>But by My Name, the Eternal</i>], <i>was I not known unto them</i>, meaning: “I was not recognized by them in My attribute of keeping faith, by reason of which My Name is called Eternal, which denotes that I am certain to fulfill the words [of My promise]. Indeed I made promises to the patriarchs<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">“Him”: Abraham. In our texts of Rashi: “Them,” which refers to all three patriarchs, and so it is mentioned further on.</i> but did not fulfill them [during their lifetime].”<br>All these are the words of Rashi. His intent is to explain that the fulfillment of His promise [to the patriarchs] had not taken place. Even though the time for the fulfillment had not arrived [in their lifetime, and consequently the absence of such fulfillment was no indication of a lack of His “keeping faith” since the time had not arrived], yet He was not known to the patriarchs in the fulfillment of His promise.<br>But with all this interpretation, Rashi has not properly explained the language of the text.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew text reads: <i>ush’mi Hashem lo nodati lahem</i> (literally: <i>and My Name the Eternal I was not made known to them</i>). Ramban’s point is that according to Rashi’s interpretation, the verse should have read either (a) <i>lo hodati</i> (I did not make known), or (b) <i>ush’mi Hashem lo noda lahem</i> (and My Name the Eternal was not known to them).</i> [According to his interpretation], it should be said, <i>lo hodati</i> [“and My Name, the Eternal, ‘I did not make known’ to them,” instead of <i>lo nodati</i> (<i>I was not made known</i>), as the text reads]. Or it should have said, “and My Name, the Eternal, <i>lo noda</i> (was not known) to them.” Perhaps according to Rashi’s opinion, the sense of the verse is: “and My Name is the Eternal, <i>v’lo</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban adds here the letter <i>vav</i> to the word <i>lo — v’lo</i> — thus making it independent of the expression <i>ush’mi Hashem</i>. Accordingly, there are two separate thoughts expressed: “and My Name is the Eternal,” which denotes that “I am certain to substantiate My promise,” and “I was not made known to them by that Name since I made promises to them but did not fulfill them.”</i> <i>nodati lahem</i>,” meaning that “I was not made known to them by that Name.”
And the learned Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the letter <i>beth</i> of the words <i>b’E-il Sha-dai</i> (by the Name G-d Almighty) connected [with the ensuing words <i>ush’mi Hashem</i>, making it <i>ubish’mi Hashem</i>], which has the following meaning: “And I appeared unto Abraham, etc., by the Name <i>E-il Sha-dai</i> (G-d Almighty), but <i>by</i> My Name the Eternal I was not made known unto them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Thus according to Ibn Ezra, the sense of the verse is as if it were written: “And I appeared into Abraham…<i>b’E-il Sha-dai ubish’mi</i> — [instead of <i>ush’mi</i>] — <i>Hashem lo nodati lahem</i> (and by My Name the Eternal I was not made known to them).”</i><br>The purport of the verse is that He appeared to the patriarchs by this Name [<i>E-il Sha-dai</i>], which indicates that He is the victor [and prevailer]<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 215-6 and 556-7, for further discussion of this theme. See also end of <i>Seder Bo</i> in this volume.</i> over the hosts of heaven, doing great miracles for them except that no change from the natural order of the world was noticeable, [as was the case with the miracles performed through Moses our teacher]. In famine, He redeemed them from death, <i>and in war from the power of the sword</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Job 5:20.</i> and He gave them riches and honor and all the goodness, just like all the assurances mentioned in the Torah [in the section dealing] with the blessings and curses.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:3-46 and Deuteronomy 28:1-69.</i><br>It is not [in nature] that man should be rewarded for performance of a commandment or punished for committing a transgression but by a miracle. If man were left to his nature or his fortune, his deeds would neither add to him nor diminish from him. Rather, reward and punishment in this world, as mentioned in the entire scope of the Torah, are all miracles, but they are hidden. They appear to the onlooker as being part of the natural order of things, but in truth they come upon man as punishment and reward [for his deeds]. It is for this reason that the Torah speaks at great length of the assurances concerning this world, and does not explain the assurances of the soul in “the World of Souls.”<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This is the world to which the soul goes following the death of the body. At the resurrection, body and soul will be reunited. That world, according to Ramban, is <i>Olam Haba</i> (the Coming World). Ramban thus distinguishes between <i>Olam Han’shamoth</i> (the World of Souls) and <i>Olam Haba</i>. The <i>Olam Han’shamoth</i> is concomitant with this world, and <i>Olam Haba</i> is the world of the future.</i> These [assurances mentioned in the Torah as recompense for the observance or transgression of the Divine Commandments] are wonders which go contrary to nature,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">“For it is not by nature that the heavens become as iron because we have sowed our fields in the Sabbatical year, etc.” (Ramban, Vol. I, p. 557.)</i> while the existence of the soul [after the death of the body] and its cleaving unto G-d are the proper way inherent in its nature that she <i>returneth unto G-d Who gave it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:7.</i> I will yet explain it further<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:11.</i> if G-d accomplishes it for me.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 57:3.</i><br>Thus G-d said to Moses: “I have appeared to the patriarchs with the might of My arm with which I prevail over the constellations and help those whom I have chosen, but with My Name <i>Yod Hei</i> with which all existence came into being I was not made known to them, that is, to create new things for them by the open change of nature. And <i>Wherefore say unto the children of Israel: I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> and inform them once again of the Great Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton], for by that Name I will deal wondrously with them,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">See Joel 2:26.</i> and they will know that <i>I am the Eternal, that maketh all things</i>. ”<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 44:24.</i><br>All the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra on this matter were thus correct except that he was as one who prophesies but does not know it.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The source of this expression, “he prophesied but did not know what he prophesied,” is in Sotah 12b. Ramban uses the expression here to intimate that Ibn Ezra did indeed allude to the correct interpretation of the verse, namely, that the letter <i>beth</i> in <i>b’E-il Sha-dai</i> is connected also to <i>ush’mi Hashem</i>, making it <i>ubish’mi Hashem</i>, as explained above (see Note 8). But, suggests Ramban, there is still a question to be raised on Ibn Ezra’s explanation, as explained further in the text.</i> Even according to his interpretation, the verse should have said, “And I made Myself <i>known</i> to Abraham, etc., by the name of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>, but by My Name <i>Hashem</i>, [which describes My true essence], I did not make Myself known to them,” or it should have said, “but by the Name <i>Hashem</i> I did not <i>appear</i> to them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, why does the Torah use two separate terms: <i>va’eira</i> (<i>and I appeared</i>) and <i>nodati</i> (<i>made Me known</i>)? One term — “appear” or “made Me known” — should have sufficed in both cases.</i> However, Ibn Ezra can answer this by saying that because the prophecy of the patriarchs came to them <i>in the visions of the night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:2. See also Ramban, <i>ibid.</i>, 15:1 (Vol. I, p. 193).</i> He said here, <i>Va’eira</i> (<i>And I appeared</i>) to them, and because that of Moses was <i>face to face</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:10.</i> He said here, “<i>I made Me not known to them</i> [the patriarchs] as I made Myself known to you [Moses].” <br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], the verse can be explained in consonance with its plain meaning and intent.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is suggesting that whereas in other places the mystic teachings of the Cabala do not reflect the plain meaning of Scripture, here “the way of the Truth” is in harmony with the plain meaning and import of the text.</i> He is saying: “I the Eternal appeared to the patriarchs through the speculum of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>,” just as is the sense of the verse, <i>In a vision do I make Myself known to him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:6.</i> “But Myself, I the Eternal did not make Myself known to them, as they did not contemplate [Me] through a lucid speculum so that they should know me,” just as is the sense of the verse, <i>And there hath not arisen a prophet since in Israel like unto Moses, whom the Eternal knew face to face</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:10.</i> The patriarchs did know the Proper Name of the Eternal, but it was not known to them through prophecy. Therefore when Abraham spoke with G-d, he mentioned the Proper Name together with the Name <i>Aleph Dalet</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:2. See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i>, 17:1 (Vol. I, p. 216).</i> or <i>Aleph Dalet</i> alone.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:30.</i> The purport thereof is that the revelation of the Divine Presence and His communication with them came to them through an ameliorated attribute of justice,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 543.</i> and with that attribute was His conduct towards them. But with Moses, His conduct and His recognition to him were by the attribute of mercy, which is indicated by His Great Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton — the Eternal], just as is denoted in the verse, <i>He caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:12.</i> and it is written, <i>So didst Thou lead Thy people, to make Thyself a glorious name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> Therefore Moses does not henceforth mention the name <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>, for the Torah was given with His great Name, as it is said, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:2.</i> This is the sense of the verse, <i>Our of heaven He made thee to hear His voice, that He might instruct thee; and upon earth He made thee to see His great fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> I have already alluded to the explanation of the word <i>hashamayim</i> (the heaven).<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">In Genesis 1:8 (Vol. I, p. 37).</i> May the Holy One, blessed be He, open our eyes and show us wonders in His Torah.

Verse 4

AND I HAVE ALSO ESTABLISHED MY COVENANT WITH THEM … AND MOREOVER I HAVE HEARD THE GROANING OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 4-5.</i> The meaning thereof is as follows: “I have appeared to the patriarchs <i>by the Name ‘E-il Sha-dai’ and I have also established</i> this covenant [by this Divine Name] before Me, <i>and moreover</i> with My Great Name <i>I have</i> now <i>heard the groaning of the children of Israel, and I have remembered My covenant</i> which I have established for them with Me.” The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.<br>Now as regards what our Rabbis have expounded:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 6:4, and mentioned by Rashi in Verse 9 with variants.</i> i.e., that [the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses], “Alas for those that are gone, [namely, the patriarchs], and are no more to be found! Many a time did I reveal Myself to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob by the Name <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>, and I did not inform them that My Name is the Eternal as I have said it to you, and yet none of them cast aspersions upon My dealings with them, etc. Moreover, none of them asked Me what My Name is, as you asked. Right at the beginning of My mission, you said to Me, ‘What is Your Name?’<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:13.</i> And at the end you said, <i>For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Thy name, he hath dealt ill with this people</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:23.</i> It is in connection with this [complaint] that G-d said to Moses, <i>And I have also established My covenant with them</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4. That is to say, “Not only did I promise them the Land but I also established My covenant with them on that, and yet they did not find fault with Me” (<i>ibid.</i>, Shemoth Rabbah).</i> The purport of this Midrash likewise fits in with the text.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi on Verse 9 where he explains that this Midrash does not fit in with the text for several reasons. Ramban proceeds to show that it can be fitted in with the verses.</i> The Rabbis, of blessed memory, found it difficult to understand why G-d mentioned the prophecy of the patriarchs altogether, diminishing their accomplishment in prophecy and saying that He appeared to them only by the Name of <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>. What purpose did that serve? He could have said, “I am the Eternal, and wherefore say unto the children of Israel: ‘I am the Eternal, and I will bring you [from under the burdens of the Egyptians], and you shall know that I am the Eternal Who brought you out.’” Therefore the Rabbis explained that the message constituted a rebuke to Moses, telling him: “Behold, the patriarchs, whose accomplishment in prophecy was not as high as yours inasmuch as they contemplated Deity only through the Name <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>, believed in Me, <i>And I have also established My covenant with them</i>, and I have heard the groaning of their children for their sake. Surely you who have known Me by the Great Name and whom I have given My assurance [by that Name], you should have trusted in [My] mercies and assured Israel in My Name that I will do signs and wonders for them.” This interpretation too is correct and fitting.

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND I WILL BRING YOU OUT FROM UNDER THE BURDENS OF THE EGYPTIANS. He assured them that He will take them out from the land of the Egyptians and that they will no longer suffer from their heavy burden.
AND I WILL DELIVER YOU FROM THEIR BONDAGE. The Egyptians will no longer rule over them at all, nor will they subject them to be <i>a servant under tribute</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:15.</i> wherever they live.
AND I WILL REDEEM YOU. He will bring such judgments upon them until the Egyptians will say: “Here You have the Israelites as a redemption for our lives.” The meaning of the word <i>g’ulah</i> (redemption) is close to the subject of <i>mecher</i> (sale), [thus implying that “I will buy you from the Egyptians”]. And the meaning of the expression, <i>with an outstretched arm</i>, is that His arm will be extended over them until He takes them out from Egypt.

Verse 7

AND I WILL TAKE YOU TO ME FOR A PEOPLE. That is, when you will come to Mount Sinai and you will accept the Torah. There, [at Mount Sinai], it was said, <i>Then ye shall be Mine own treasure</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:5.</i>
AND YE SHALL KNOW THAT I AM THE ETERNAL YOUR G-D WHO BROUGHT YOU OUT FROM UNDER THE BURDENS OF THE EGYPTIANS. The purport thereof, said Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, is that it was in the combined mighty power of the higher constellations that the children of Israel should yet stay in the exile. But this is not of the theme of the chapter. Rather He says: “When I will redeem you with an outstretched arm visible to all nations, you shall know that it is I the Eternal Who performs new signs and wonders in the world, and that I am your G-d and for your sake I had so acted, for you are <i>the portions of the Eternal</i>. ”<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:9.</i>

Verse 8

AND I WILL BRING YOU IN UNTO THE LAND CONCERNING WHICH I LIFTED UP MY HAND. “I have lifted it up to swear by My throne.” Thus the language of Rashi. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that it is an idiom [denoting the exercise of power], just like a man who lifts his hand to the heavens and swears, such as: <i>For I lift up My hand to heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 40.</i> [to take an oath of vengeance]; <i>And he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven, and swore</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:7.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], <i>I lifted up My hand</i> means that “I have raised the strength of My arm to Myself that I will give them the Land.” Similarly, <i>For I lift up My hand to heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 40.</i> means that “I will lift up the great hand to the heavens since it abounds in eternal life.”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">According to Meir Abusaula (see Preface, Vol. I, p. XII, Note 21) the thought suggested here is that His Name will forever be in Israel’s midst, and thus He assured them eternal life.</i> But the verse, <i>And he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:7.</i> has no relevance here, for that was said concerning the angel <i>clothed in linen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:6.</i> who swore <i>by Him that liveth for ever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:7.</i>

Verse 9

BUT THEY HEARKENED NOT UNTO MOSES FOR IMPATIENCE OF SPIRIT, AND FOR CRUEL BONDAGE. It was not because they did not believe in G-d and in His prophet [that they hearkened not]. Rather, they paid no attention to his words because of impatience of spirit, as a person whose soul is grieved on account of his misery and who does not want to live another moment in his suffering even though he knows that he will be relieved later. The “impatience of spirit” was their fear that Pharaoh would put them to death, as their officers said to Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:21.</i> and the “cruel bondage” was the pressure, for the taskmasters pressed upon them and hurried them [in their daily task],<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> which gave them no chance to hear anything and consider it.

Verse 10

AND THE ETERNAL SPOKE UNTO MOSES ‘LEIMOR’ (SAYING). The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in his Book of Roots, under the root <i>amar</i> (saying).</i> said that throughout the entire Torah, the word <i>leimor</i> means “saying to Israel,” the purport thereof being that G-d said to Moses, “Say these, My words, to Israel.” Here the word <i>leimor</i> means “saying to Pharaoh.” But the verse stating [Laban’s words to Jacob], <i>The G-d of your father spoke unto me yesternight ‘leimor’</i> (<i>saying</i>): <i>Take heed to thyself that thou speak not to Jacob either good or bad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:29.</i> does not fit in correctly with this explanation [since Laban was not commanded to relate these words to Jacob]. Similarly, there are many cases in Scripture where the term “saying” is repeated, [and it is not correct to say that it means “saying it to others”]. Thus: <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses, saying: Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:1-2.</i> <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses, saying: Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:37-8.</i> <i>And they</i> [Moses and Aaron] <i>spoke unto all the congregation of the children of Israel, saying;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:7. Here the word “saying” could not mean “saying it to others,” since Moses and Aaron were already speaking directly to the people.</i> <i>And the children of Israel spoke unto Moses, saying: Behold we perish;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:27.</i> <i>And I spoke unto you at that time, saying</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:9.</i> There are many other such verses. Likewise in this <i>seder</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The portion of the Torah assigned for reading on a particular Sabbath. See Vol. I, p. 15.</i> we find: <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses and unto Aaron, saying: When Pharaoh will speak unto you, saying</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:8-9.</i> and the word “saying” cannot correctly mean “saying it to others.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that in all places the word <i>leimor</i> indicates the clarification of a subject. The verse, <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses, saying</i>, means really explicitly, free from doubt or uncertainty. This is why this expression always appears in the Torah, for of Moses’ prophecy it was said, <i>Mouth to mouth do I speak with him, even manifestly, and not in dark speeches</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:8.</i> And Laban also said to Jacob: “<i>Yesternight G-d spoke unto me, saying</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:29.</i> clearly that I should not harm you; except for that, I would have done you evil.” Similarly, the verse, <i>And the children of Israel spoke unto Moses, saying: Behold, we perish</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:27.</i> means that they said so explicitly to Moses and Aaron, shouting to them brazenly. [In Hebrew], the infinitive is used for clarification of a subject. Occasionally, it comes before the verb,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Such as <i>sachor s’charticha (I have surely hired thee)</i>, in Genesis 30:16. Here the infinitive <i>sachor</i> is written before the verb <i>s’charticha</i>.</i> and sometimes it comes after the verb, such as: ‘<i>omrim amor</i>’ (<i>they surely say</i>) <i>unto them that despise Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 23:17. Here the infinitive <i>amor</i> is written after the verb <i>omrim</i>.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

BEHOLD, THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL HAVE NOT HEARKENED UNTO ME because You have done nothing [for Israel] so that my words should be acceptable to them. AND HOW THEN SHALL PHARAOH HEAR ME? AND besides, I AM OF UNCIRCUMCISED LIPS, and I am not fit to speak before a great king.<br>It is possible to explain that Moses thought that due to his deficiency — for he was of uncircumcised lips — the children of Israel would not hearken to him, <i>for he could not frame</i> [words] <i>to speak</i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 12:6.</i> kindly to them, words of good cheer and comfort, and all the more how could he speak to Pharaoh?<br>Now the reason that Moses again broached this argument [of his speech-impediment, when he had already mentioned it above in Chapter 4, Verse 10], is that G-d did not originally command him that he was to speak before Pharaoh. He merely said, <i>And thou shalt come, thou and the elders of Israel, unto the king of Egypt, and ye shall say unto him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:18.</i> In that case it was possible that the elders should speak [before Pharaoh] and Moses would remain silent. Then Moses said that he was ashamed even to speak to the people, saying, <i>I am not a man of words</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:10.</i> Whereupon the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, <i>And he</i> [Aaron] <i>shall be thy spokesman unto the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> And so indeed Moses and Aaron did when they first came to the people, as it is said, <i>And Aaron spoke all the words which the Eternal had spoken unto Moses, and did the signs in the sight of the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> But now Moses himself was commanded, <i>Wherefore say unto the children of Israel: I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> and he did speak to them as He commanded him, but they did not hearken to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> Now when He again commanded Moses to speak to Pharaoh,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> Moses said, “How can I speak to him, I who am of uncircumcised lips.” Then the Holy One, blessed be He, associated Aaron with him, and gave both of them <i>a charge unto the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> that they should say to them whatever He will command them, <i>and unto Pharaoh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> to bring them forth out of his land. Now Rashi commented: “[<i>And He gave them a charge unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh, king of Egypt</i>]. That is to say, He gave them a command with regard to the children of Israel and His mission on which He had sent them to Pharaoh.” But there is no need for this.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi, the command of His mission to Pharaoh was the one with regard to Israel. But according to Ramban, there was also a command with regard to Israel, as explained in the text.</i>

Verse 13

AND HE GAVE THEM A CHARGE UNTO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. Rashi wrote: “The purport of this command is explained in the second section,<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 29-30.</i> after the order of genealogy. [It properly belongs here], but because Scripture mentioned Moses and Aaron here, it interrupted the subject-matter [with the narrative of their genealogy], informing us how each was born and with whom they are connected by descent. <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses in the land of Egypt, saying: I am the Eternal; speak thou unto Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I speak unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> This is the selfsame command which is mentioned here [in Verse 11]: <i>Go in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt</i>. However, because Scripture broke off the subject-matter in order to record their genealogy, it reverts to it [further in Verse 29] and begins it anew. <i>And Moses said before the Eternal: Behold, I am of uncircumcised lips, and how shall Pharaoh hearken unto me?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> This is the selfsame statement Moses made here [in Verse 12]: <i>Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me</i>, etc. However, because Scripture broke off the subject-matter [for the abovementioned reason], it repeats it there [further in Verse 30]. Such indeed is a proper method, just as a person who says, ‘Let us return to the previous subject.’” And so also is the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<br>But I do not agree with this.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The reason is obviously that Rashi’s and Ibn Ezra’s interpretation necessitates the conclusion that one set of verses — either 10-12 or 29-30 — is redundant.</i> Rather, [it is my opinion] that when G-d commanded Moses to speak to the children of Israel — as it is said, <i>Wherefore say unto the children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> — he did so and they hearkened not unto him.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> Then He commanded him to go before Pharaoh and bid him to let them go out of his land,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> and Moses answered: <i>Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> Then the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded both Moses and Aaron to speak to the people and to Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This is in Verse 13 before us.</i> Moses thus thought that both of them — [he and Aaron] — are to take equal part in all the signs they are to do; both of them are to come to the children of Israel and to Pharaoh. But indeed [Moses reckoned that] it is sufficient that only one should speak, for such is the customary way of all pairs of emissaries, that one speaks and the other is silent. This was consented to, and G-d then said to him: “<i>I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> Who revealed Myself to you only to speak in My Great Name. <i>Speak thou unto Pharaoh king of Egypt all that I speak unto thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> for it is to you that all communications are given, not to Aaron [primarily] and to you. It is you that I made the emissary to Pharaoh.” Then Moses answered once again: <i>Behold, I am of uncircumcised lips</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> And G-d said to him: “<i>See, I have set thee in G-d’s stead to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 7:1.</i> You will go before Pharaoh with Aaron, and there [in Pharaoh’s presence] you will command Aaron while Pharaoh will not hear your words, and Aaron as your emissary will make your words heard.” This is just as G-d commands a prophet and the prophet makes His words audible and chastises [the people] with them. This was a great achievement for Moses,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Moses had thought that his speech impediment would be a handicap. It now turned out to be to his honor, for on account of it he was to state to Aaron every Divine message as it reached him, and Aaron was to address it to Pharaoh, just as G-d commands a prophet and the prophet addresses the message to the people.</i> which he merited by his humility since he was ashamed to speak because of his speech — impediment. And so Scripture says, <i>Moreover the man Moses was very great in the land of Egypt, in the sight of Pharaoh’s servants, and in the sight of the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 11:3.</i> It was measure for measure. He had been afraid lest he be despised in their eyes [on account of his defective speech, but Scripture testifies to the Egyptians’ admiration of his greatness].<br>Now Rashi commented: “<i>Thou shalt speak</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:2.</i> each and every message once, just as you heard it from My mouth, <i>and your brother Aaron</i> shall express it in eloquent language and explain it in Pharaoh’s hearing.” This is not correct at all.

Verse 14

THESE ARE THE HEADS OF THEIR FATHERS’ HOUSES: THE SONS OF REUBEN…. Scripture did not wish to begin with the statement, <i>And these are the names of the sons of Levi according to their generations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> so that it should not appear that henceforth in honor of Moses, Levi is first in genealogy. Instead, [Scripture therefore] mentioned Levi’s elder brothers, [i.e., Reuben and Simeon], and that Levi is counted third.<br>Now Scripture mentioned the sons of Levi <i>according to their generations</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> because in the case of Reuben and Simeon, it mentioned only those who went down to Egypt with them, but in the case of Levi it mentioned his children, the number of years of his life, the birth of the fathers of the prophets — [namely, Kohath the grandfather, and Amram the father of Moses and Aaron] — and the number of years of their lives,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 18 and 20.</i> all in honor of the prophets. Besides, they themselves — [Kohath and Amram] — were the pious ones of the Most High, worthy to be spoken of as the fathers of the world.

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

AND AARON TOOK HIMSELF ELISHEBA, THE DAUGHTER OF AMMINADAB, THE SISTER OF NACHSHON TO WIFE. Just as Scripture mentioned the mother of the prophets, [namely, Jochebed],<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> in their honor, saying that she was the daughter of Levi, a righteous man, and alluding to the fact that a miracle occurred to her,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban to Genesis 46:15 (Vol. I, pp. 554-9).</i> it also mentioned the mother of priesthood, i.e., that she was related to the seed of royalty, being the sister of the great prince [Nachshon of the tribe of Judah].<br>Scripture mentioned the mother of Phinehas,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25: <i>And Eleazar, Aaron’s son took him one of the daughters of Putiel to wife, and she bore him Phinehas</i>.</i> for he too was a priest, a reward which he earned himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 25:6-13. Originally when Aaron and his four sons - Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar — were anointed as priests, this prerogative extended only to them and their offspring born after the anointment. Phinehas the son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron who was alive at the time of the anointment was thus not included. Priesthood was later bestowed upon him as a reward for being zealous for G-d.</i> Now if this name Putiel — [Phinehas’ maternal grandfather] — is a proper name, it is not clear why Scripture [suddenly] mentions the name of a person whose identity we do not know. It is for this reason that our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 43 a, and mentioned here by Rashi.</i> that Phinehas was of the family of Joseph, who conquered his passion,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 39:7-12. The Hebrew word <i>pitpeit</i> (conquered) is suggested by the name Putiel.</i> and of the family of Jethro, who fattened<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Piteim</i> (fattened) is also suggested by the name Putiel. Phinehas was thus descended on his mother’s side not only from Joseph but from Jethro also.</i> calves for idolatrous sacrifice, and he is mentioned for praise [here together with Aaron and his sons], who for their righteousness were worthy to be endowed with everlasting priesthood.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, we will say [that the mothers of Moses and Aaron, of Aaron’s sons, and of Phinehas are mentioned here because] in the case of kings, it is the customary way of Scripture to mention the names of their mothers: <i>And his mother’s name was Maacah the daughter of Abishalom;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 15:10. Mentioned in the case of Asa, king of Judah.</i> <i>And his mother’s name was Azubah the daughter of Shilhi;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 20:31. She was the mother of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah.</i> and so in all cases. It may be that [Scripture does not relate more about Putiel because] he was an honorable and known person in his generation, and it [sufficed just to] mention him in praise.<br>Scripture says, <i>of the daughters of Putiel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25: <i>And Eleazar, Aaron’s son took him one of the daughters of Putiel to wife, and she bore him Phinehas</i>.</i> and not “the daughter of Putiel,” because Putiel had many daughters and Eleazar chose one of them. It may be that she was not his daughter but his daughter’s daughter who related herself to him on account of his distinction, and therefore Scripture did not mention her name.

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE DAY WHEN THE ETERNAL SPOKE UNTO MOSES IN THE LAND OF EGYPT. It is possible to explain that the verse refers to the one above.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and Ibn Ezra explain that Verse 28 here is connected with the following Verses 29-30: <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses, saying</i>…. Ramban finds this difficult to accept since the plain meaning would seem to indicate that Verses 29-30 constitute an independent section not connected with the preceding verse. Therefore he interprets Verse 28 as being connected with the preceding verse, as explained in the text.</i> Scripture is thus stating: “And it came to pass that <i>it was they</i> — [Moses and Aaron] — <i>who spoke to Pharaoh, king of Egypt</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> at the time <i>when the Eternal spoke unto Moses in the land of Egypt</i>.” For since Scripture said, <i>These are that Aaron and Moses, to whom the Eternal said: Bring out the children of Israel from the land of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> it might have appeared that the communication came to both of them equally. Therefore it now explains [in Verse 28] that the communication came to Moses, and the command to bring them forth from Egypt was to both of them. This is why Scripture closed the chapter [of the genealogy of Moses and Aaron with this subject].

Chapter 7



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

AND I WILL HARDEN PHARAOH’S HEART. The Rabbis said in Midrash Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 5:6.</i> “G-d revealed to Moses that He was destined to harden Pharaoh’s heart in order to bring judgment upon him for he caused them to work in cruel bondage.” It is also stated there [in Midrash Rabbah]:<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:4.</i> “<i>For I have hardened his heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:1.</i> Rabbi Yochanan said, ‘This provides a pretext for the heretics to say that G-d did not allow Pharaoh to repent.’ Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said, ‘The mouths of the heretics be closed! Only, <i>if it concerneth the scorners, He scorneth them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 3:34.</i> When He warns one on three occasions and he does not turn from his ways, He closes the door of repentance on him in order to punish him for his sin. Such was the case with wicked Pharaoh. After the Holy One, blessed be He, sent him five times<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">“In the case of the first five plagues, it is not stated, ‘The Eternal hardened Pharaoh’s heart,’ but ‘Pharaoh’s heart was hardened’” (Rashi). That is, it was hardened by his own stubborness.</i> [the request to let His people go] and he paid no attention to His words, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him: You have stiffened your neck and hardened your heart; I will double your defilement.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “I will add defilement to your defilement.”</i><br>The Rabbis [in the above Midrash] have thus discussed the question which all ask:<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">See Ibn Ezra here, and Rambam in his Shemonah Perakim, Chapter 8, and in his Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Teshubah 6:3, where this problem is discussed.</i> “If G-d hardened his heart, what then was Pharaoh’s sin?” For this there are two explanations, and both of them are true. One is that Pharaoh in his wickedness had unjustifiably perpetrated such great evils against Israel that justice required that the ways of repentance be withheld from him, as is so indicated in many places in the Torah and in the Writings.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">See Rambam in Mishneh Torah, <i>ibid.</i>, where he quotes from the Prophets and Writings to substantiate this point.</i> He was judged according to his wickedness which he had originally committed of his own will. The second explanation is that half of the plagues came upon him because of his transgressions, for in connection with them it is only said: <i>And Pharaoh’s heart was hardened;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 13 and 22, and 8:15.</i> <i>And Pharaoh hardened his heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:28 and 9:7.</i> Thus Pharaoh refused to let the children of Israel go for the glory of G-d. But when the plagues began bearing down upon him and he became weary to suffer them, his heart softened and he bethought himself to send them out on account of the onslaught of the plagues, not in order to do the will of his Creator. Then <i>G-d hardened his spirit and made his heart obstinate</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:30.</i> so that His name may be declared [throughout all the earth].<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 9:16.</i> Similar in meaning is the verse, <i>Thus will I magnify Myself, and sanctify Myself, and I will make Myself known in the eyes of many nations, and they shall know that I am the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 38:23.</i> And that which He said before the plagues, <i>And I will harden his heart, and he will not let the people go</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:21.</i> was merely His warning to Moses of that which He was destined to do to Pharaoh in the last [five] plagues, it being similar to that which He said, <i>And I know that the king of Egypt will not give you leave to go</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:18.</i> This then is the meaning of the verse [before us], <i>And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and multiply My signs</i>. That is to say, “I will harden his heart so <i>that My wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 11:9.</i> since in the last five plagues, as well as at the drowning in the sea, it is said, <i>And the Eternal hardened the heart of Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:8.</i> for <i>the king’s heart is in the hand of the Eternal; He turneth it whithersoever He will</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 21:1.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

AND THEY ALSO, THE MAGICIANS OF EGYPT, DID IN LIKE MANNER ‘B’LAHATEIHEM’ (WITH THEIR SECRET ARTS). Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 67b.</i> that these are deeds of sorcerers who perform their arts through angels of destruction,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">A term found in Kiddushin 72 a, and designating a supernatural being holding destructive power.</i> the word <i>b’lahateihem</i> being derived from the expressions: <i>eish loheit</i> (<i>flaming fire</i>);<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:4.</i> <i>the flame ‘t’laheit’</i> (<i>burned up</i>) <i>the wicked</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 106:18.</i> The purport [of the saying of the Sages] is that these deeds of sorcery are done by means of “the flaming ones,” angels of a fire that burns in man, and he does not know that the fire burns in him and pays no attention to it. It is similar in sense to the expression, “And the Eternal opened the eyes of the young man of Elisha, and behold there were horses of fire and chariots of fire.”<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The verse, II Kings 6:17, reads: <i>And the Eternal opened the eyes of the young man, and he saw, and behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire round about Elisha</i>.</i> Perhaps these are identical with the angels that dwell in the atmosphere of the spheres of the [four] elements,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The four elements — fire, air, earth and water — are the basic components of all created things that are beneath the firmament, which is below the lunar sphere. See Rambam, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 3:11 and 4:1.</i> which are called <i>sarim</i> (lords).<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 310, that it is possible there is another reading here. Instead of <i>sarim</i> (lords), the word should be <i>sheidim</i> (demons). The first reading seems to be more correct here.</i> I will explain this theme again [in the Book of Leviticus 17:7] with the help of the Rock.<br>But the word <i>b’lateihem</i>, [mentioned further in 8:3 — <i>And the magicians did in like manner ‘b’lateihem’</i>] — is explained [by the Rabbis] as meaning <i>sheidim</i> (demons) — the word being derived from the Hebrew word <i>lat</i> (secret): <i>Speak with David ‘balat’</i> (<i>secretly</i>) — since the demons come quietly inasmuch as they are ethereal bodies whose presence is not felt. This is why Scripture states [in Verse 11 before us] that Pharaoh called <i>for the wise men and the sorcerers</i>, for the wise men who knew [the art of] incanting and assembling the demons were the leaders and elders of the Egyptians.<br>The term <i>chartumei mitzrayim</i> (the magicians of Egypt) includes both of them, [i.e., the wise men and the sorcerers]. We do not know the root of the word <i>chartumei</i>. Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra says that it is either an Egyptian or Chaldean word since we find it only mentioned in their accounts.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Here, and in the Book of Daniel 2:2, and other places there.</i> The more likely explanation is that of Rashi, who said<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s interpretation is found in Genesis 41:8.</i> that it is an Aramaic compound-word: <i>char tami</i> (those who excite themselves by means of the bones [of the dead]). It is known that the greater part of this craft is one with the bones of dead persons or the bones of animals, just as they mentioned in the case of the <i>yid’oni</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:31. “The <i>yid’oni</i> takes the bone of a bird [or a beast] called <i>yido’a</i>, puts it into his mouth, burns incense, recites certain prayers, performs a certain ritual until he is in a condition akin to fainting, and falls into a trance in which he predicts the future” (Maimonides,”The Commandments,” Vol. II, p. 10).</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND, BEHOLD, HITHERTO THOU HAST NOT HEARKENED. Because this was one of the [ten] plagues and henceforth He will begin to smite him, He therefore said to him that it was his wickedness which was responsible for the bringing of the punishment upon him since he hearkened not to the command of his Creator. Now at this time, [i.e., when the warning about the first plague was given to him], Pharaoh did not declare to Moses and Aaron that he will neither hearken to G-d’s words nor let the people go. It was only at the first time [when they came before him] that he said, <i>I know not the Eternal, and moreover I will not let Israel go</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:2.</i> At present, he did not rebuke them; he only heard their words and remained silent, for since they performed the wonder of the serpent before him and Aaron’s rod swallowed up their rods,<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> he was already afraid of the plagues, except that during the first plagues he attempted that the magicians do likewise, that is, by means of deeds of sorcery. Thus he was afraid, and yet he hardened his heart. This is the sense of the expression, <i>And Pharaoh’s heart was hardened</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AND HE LIFTED UP THE ROD, AND SMOTE THE WATERS THAT WERE IN THE RIVER IN THE SIGHT OF PHARAOH. That is to say, Aaron lifted up the rod and stretched out his hand over the land of Egypt in all directions,<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is to state that the lifting up of the rod, mentioned here in Verse 20, is identical with “stretch out thy hand,” mentioned in G-d’s command in Verse 19. Ibn Ezra, as stated further in the text, differs with this opinion.</i> and afterwards <i>he smote the waters that were in the river, in the sight of Pharaoh</i>. In Pharaoh’s sight, <i>all the waters that were in the river turned to blood, and the blood was</i> furthermore <i>throughout all the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21. Ramban thus explains that the waters that were in the river turned to blood by reason of the smiting of the rod, while the waters in all other places turned into blood by reason of Aaron’s stretching forth his hand in all directions (Bachya).</i> And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Scripture mentioned the smiting of the river but found it unnecessary to mention the stretching out of the hand [in all directions] over the entire land of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Thus according to Ibn Ezra, Scripture merely shortened its account here and did not mention the stretching out of Aaron’s hand, but not, as Ramban has it, that the stretching out of the hand is already included in the act of the smiting of the waters of the river.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

NEITHER DID HE SET HIS HEART TO THIS ALSO. I.e., to the wonder of the rod turning into a serpent,<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 10.</i> nor to that of the waters turning into blood. [Thus the language of Rashi.] A more correct interpretation would appear to be that <i>to this also</i> means “to this also which was indeed a plague,” [as distinguished from the wonder of the rod turning into a serpent, which was not a plague at all], and he should have feared lest the power of G-d be upon him from now on.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above in Verse 16, where he explains that beginning with the wonder of the rod, Pharaoh already began fearing the coming of the plagues. It is this then which Scripture says here: In spite of his fear which he already had then even before the plagues came, “also” now that the first plague did come and he should have feared the coming of other plagues, yet he did not set his heart to it.</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25

<i>And seven days were fulfilled after that the Eternal had smitten the river</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> This is connected with the verse above, and the purport thereof is as follows: And with this<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">The verse states, <i>‘Vayimalei’</i> (<i>And it was fulfilled</i>) <i>seven days</i>, using a singular verb when the verb actually required is a plural: <i>vayimal’u</i> (and they were fulfilled). Rashi explained it by adding the word <i>minyan</i> (number) in the singular, explaining it thus: “and <i>the number</i> of seven days was fulfilled.” Ramban suggests that the verse is connected to the preceding one and is to be understood with the additional word of <i>bazeh</i> (with this), thus rendering the sense of the verse: “and with this activity — i.e., with the Egyptians’ digging, etc., as stated in the above Verse 24 — was filled (or completed) seven days.”</i> — namely, the Egyptians’ digging round about the river <i>for they could not drink of the water of the river</i>, [as stated in Verse 24] — with this was filled the seven days after the river had been smitten.

Chapter 8



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

L’MATHAI’ (AGAINST WHAT TIME) SHALL I ENTREAT FOR THEE? Rashi commented: “If the text said <i>mathai</i> (when) — [not <i>l’mathai</i>] — <i>shall I entreat</i>, it would signify ‘when shall I pray?’ But now that it said <i>l’mathai</i>, it means ‘Today I will pray for you that the frogs be destroyed by the time which you will set for me. Say then by what day you wish that they shall be destroyed.’”<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the removal of the plagues took place at the time of Moses’ prayer, as it is written, <i>And Moses cried unto the Eternal</i>, etc., <i>and the Eternal did according to the word of Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 8-9.</i> and it is not written “and the Eternal did so tomorrow.” The letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>l’mathai</i> is no proof that Moses prayed immediately, for the word <i>l’mathai</i> is equivalent to <i>mathai</i>, there being many verses where the <i>lamed</i> occurs [just for elegance of language], thus: <i>‘l’min’</i> (<i>from</i>) <i>the day that thou didst go forth out of the land of Egypt;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:7. The <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>l’min</i> is superfluous.</i> <i>until ‘l’minchath’</i> (<i>the offering</i>) <i>of the evening;<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 9:4. There the <i>lamed</i> in <i>l’minchath</i> is a superfluous style.</i> the wing of the one cherub was five ‘l’amoth’</i> (<i>cubits</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 3:11. Here the <i>lamed</i> in <i>l’amoth</i> is superfluous.</i> There are many other such cases.
THAT THE FROGS BE DESTROYED. This is an allusion to their death, just as the expressions: <i>that soul shall be cut off;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:19.</i> <i>and I will cut off from Ahab every man-child</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 21:21.</i><br>The intent of Moses’ repeating the promise to Pharaoh, <i>And the frogs shall depart</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> was to state that as soon as he will have prayed, the frogs will all be removed, and that Pharaoh should not fear that when these frogs die, others will come up from the river. Rather, the plague will be completely removed even though some of them will remain in the river.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> All this was to inform Pharaoh that the plague came from G-d for the sake of Israel alone.

Verse 6

AND HE SAID, FOR TOMORROW. It is a known fact that it is man’s nature to pray that his misfortune be removed from him at once. [The question then arises: Why did Pharaoh say that the frogs were to be removed tomorrow?] In the name of the Gaon Rav Shmuel ben Chophni,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The father-in-law of Rav Hai Gaon, the last of the Gaonim. See Vol. I, p. 97, Note 477. Rav Shmuel, who was the Gaon of the Academy of Sura, wrote extensively in Arabic on Biblical exegesis as well as on Halachic themes. Only fragments of his work are now extant. He is quoted by Ibn Ezra (as in this case) and R’dak. In Biblical commentary, his method generally was that of the rationalist.</i> they have explained that Pharaoh thought that perhaps some heavenly constellation brought the frogs upon Egypt, and that Moses [by his knowledge of astrology] knows the time when they will disappear, and therefore Moses had said to him, <i>Have thou this glory over me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> thinking that Pharaoh will now tell him to destroy them immediately. Therefore Pharaoh extended the time until the morrow.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that because Moses had said, <i>Against what time shall I entreat for thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> Pharaoh thought that Moses was desirous for time, and so he fixed the shortest time limit, <i>And he said, For tomorrow</i>. Moses answered him, “<i>According to thy word</i>, let it be so, for since you did not ask that they be removed immediately, they shall not be removed until tomorrow.”

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

AND THE MAGICIANS DID SO WITH THEIR SECRET ARTS TO BRING FORTH GNATS. The purport of the expression, <i>and the magicians did so</i>, [when it immediately says afterwards, <i>but they could not</i>], is that they hit the dust of the earth and incanted the demons and performed their secret arts, as they used to do at other times, in order <i>to bring forth the gnats, but they could not</i>. It is possible that the expression, <i>and the magicians did so</i>, teaches that they did indeed do the correct things which do bring forth the gnats, but they were not successful this time, [for G-d thwarted their plans]. The learned magicians knew what they could do and they had tried to do so at other times [and succeeded. Hence they tried to do it now, but they failed “because it was now the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, to remove that power from them henceforth],”<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">From Ramban’s sermon on <i>Torath Hashem T’mimah</i>. See my Kithvei Haramban, I, p. 146.</i>

Verse 15

AND THE MAGICIANS SAID UNTO PHARAOH: THIS IS THE FINGER OF G-D. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that because the magicians had done as Aaron did with the serpent and also with the plagues of blood and the frogs and now they could not do so, they therefore said to Pharaoh: “This plague of gnats has not come through Aaron for the sake of Israel. Rather it is a plague of G-d due to the particular [evil] stars under which the land of Egypt found itself at the time.” Pharaoh did not deny the existence of the Creator<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above in <i>Seder Shemoth</i> 5:3.</i> but only the Divine Name which Moses mentioned to him. This is similar in sense to the verse, <i>It was not His hand that smote us; it was a chance that happened to us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 6:9.</i> Therefore Pharaoh’s heart was hardened. And Ibn Ezra brought proof for his explanation from the fact that Scripture does not state that the magicians said, “This is the finger of the Eternal,” which would have been a reference to the G-d of Israel, just as Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron, <i>Entreat the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> Another proof [which Ibn Ezra brought for his explanation] is that in the case of the smiting of the river, Moses had forewarned Pharaoh,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Above 7:17-18. And so also was there a forewarning in the case of the frogs (<i>ibid.</i>, Verses 27-29).</i> but he mentioned nothing to him about the plague of gnats. [Therefore the magicians felt justified in saying that it was not a plague for the sake of Israel but merely due to the evil stars.]<br>Ibn Ezra’s interpretation does not appear to me to be correct. “A chance” is not called “the finger of G-d.” Only a plague which comes directly from Him as a form of punishment is called <i>the hand of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 5:9.</i> and <i>the finger of G-d</i>, just as it is written in the verse which [Ibn Ezra] mentioned: <i>It was not His hand that smote us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 6:9.</i> And it is furthermore written: <i>And Israel saw the great hand;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 14:31.</i> <i>And the hand of the Eternal shall be against you</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:15 and <i>ibid.</i>, 5:11.</i> <i>the hand of G-d was very heavy there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:15 and <i>ibid.</i>, 5:11.</i> Moreover, in the next plague of swarms, as well as in the following ones, Pharaoh no longer called upon the magicians to stand before Moses to do the same things, even though there had been a forewarning of their coming!<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">How then could Ibn Ezra say that because Moses had not forewarned Pharaoh of the coming of the gnats, the magicians said that the plague came through the evil stars and not from the Eternal? In the following plagues when Pharaoh was forewarned of their coming, why did he not call upon the magicians to do likewise? The answer must be, as Ramban explains, that in the case of the plague of the gnats, the magicians already admitted that it was from the Eternal and therefore they could not do likewise. There was thus no need for Pharaoh to call upon them in the following plagues of which he was forewarned, since those were surely from the Eternal, the G-d of Israel, before Whom the magicians were helpless.</i><br>But the subject, in accordance with the simple explanation of Scripture, is as follows: When the magicians saw that they could not bring forth the gnats, they admitted Aaron’s deed to be through an act of G-d, and this is why Pharaoh no longer called upon them from that time on. They [the magicians] said, <i>This is ‘the finger’ of G-d</i>, and not “the hand” of G-d [as is the customary way of the Scriptures to refer to plagues, as e.g., <i>It was not His ‘hand’ that smote us</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 6:9.</i> in order to minimize the plague, that is to say, it is but a small plague from Him [which we can easily endure].<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">In his Discourse “The Law of the Eternal is Perfect,” Ramban adds: “Nevertheless the magicians [thereby] admitted [that it was an act of G-d], and thus they became apprised of the fact that Moses’ deed was effectuated by the Lord of the universe.”</i> They did not, however, say to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of ‘the Eternal,’” [but instead they said, <i>“This is the finger of ‘G-d’”</i>]. Pharaoh and his servants would not mention the Proper Divine Name except when speaking to Moses because he mentioned that Name to them. [In addressing Pharaoh, however, the magicians would not use that Name since that would be an open recognition on their part of His existence and power. Therefore they said to Pharaoh, <i>“ This is the finger of ' G-d, ’”</i> although their intent was to say, “This is the finger of ‘the Eternal.’ “] That the magicians could not bring forth the gnats was [not because they really could not do it, but it] was by reason of the fact that G-d so caused it to happen to them. He confounded their counsel in accordance with His Will, for everything is His and it is within His power to do all.<br>It appears to me further that in the first two plagues — in the one of blood, where the water naturally<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Since water and blood are both liquids, the change of the one into the other may be spoken of as in “the nature” of things inasmuch as both are classified under the element of water. See above, Note 117, on the four elements.</i> changed into blood, and in the one of the frogs, which consisted of bringing them up from the river — since they did not involve the creation of some new phenomenon out of nothing or some act of new formation,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew text reads: <i>bri’ah o yetzirah</i>. See Vol. I, p. 23, that only the term <i>bara</i> (or <i>bri’ah</i>) signifies “bringing forth something from nothing.”</i> the magicians could do [as Aaron did]. Scripture does not say, “and the frogs came into existence,” but only, <i>and the frogs came up;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> they assembled and came up. In the plague of gnats, however, there was an act of creation, for it is not in the nature of dust to turn into gnats. Therefore He said, <i>that it may become gnats</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12. The word “become” suggests a new act of creation.</i> The verse, <i>And the magicians did so with their secret arts to bring forth gnats</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> is similar in intent to: <i>Let the earth bring forth the living creature</i>, etc., <i>and it was so</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:24. In other words, the expression here, “to bring forth the gnats,” means a new act of creation, just as in the Book of Genesis.</i> But only the Creator, praised and magnified be He, can perform such a [new] act of creation. The verse, <i>And the magicians did so…but they could not</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> means they incanted the demons to do their command, but they were powerless.<br>Confirming me in my opinion concerning the frogs, [i.e., that there was no new act of creation there], is the following text [of the Talmud]:<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 67b.</i> ‘Rabbi Akiba said that there was only one frog<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">As Verse 2 has it: <i>‘Vata’al hatz’phardei’a’</i> (<i>and the frog came up</i>), in the singular.</i> which swarmed and filled the whole land of Egypt. Rabbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">“Eliezer.” In our text of the Gemara, “Eleazar,” and so also further in Ramban.</i> ben Azaryah said to him: ‘Akiba, what have you to do with Agadah (homily)? Turn from these matters and go instead to [delve in the difficulties of] Negaim<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Negaim (Leprosies) is the name of a treatise in the Mishnah dealing with the laws of leprosy. It is considered a very difficult subject.</i> and Oholoth.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Oholoth (Tents) is one of the most difficult treatises of the Mishnah. It deals with the laws regarding the uncleanness of a corpse as affecting a house and its vessels, as well as human beings.</i> It was only one frog croaking to all other frogs, and so they gathered.’” Rabbi Eleazar ben Azaryah could not accept the opinion [of Rabbi Akiba] that the magicians should have been able to bestow a new nature upon the frog, i.e., that one frog should give birth to so many, which is contrary to its nature, but rather they gathered them in order to bring them up. In the opinion then of Rabbi Akiba, the verse <i>And the river shall swarm with frogs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:28.</i> means that the river should swarm with them more than its due. But according to Rabbi Eleazar ben Azaryah, the sense of that verse is like, <i>‘shirtzu’ in the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 9:7. Said to Noah and his sons.</i> which connotes movement, as I have explained in <i>Seder Bereshith</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:20 (Vol. I, pp. 47-48).</i> and here its meaning is that the frogs gather and move about in the river and from there go up upon Egypt.<br>Now with regard to the gnats, our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 67 b, and mentioned by Rashi here in Verse 14.</i> that the demon [through whose power this was to be done by the magicians] is powerless in the case of a creature that is smaller than a lentil.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">“Lentil.” In our text of the Gemara, as well as in Rashi here: “a barley-corn.” At any rate, it was completely unnecessary for Scripture to inform us that the magicians could not bring forth gnats, as these are creatures smaller in size than a barley-corn. The expression, <i>but they could not</i>, must hence mean as explained in the text. Such is Ramban’s intent as explained by Rabbeinu Bachya. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 313.</i> The expression, <i>but they could not</i>, must therefore mean that they could not assemble gnats from their [breeding] places and bring them.<br>In Midrash Rabbah, the Rabbis have further said:<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 10:7.</i> “Perceiving that they cannot bring forth the gnats, the magicians at once recognized that [Aaron’s deed] was an act of G-d and not an act of the demons. From that moment on, therefore, they were no longer anxious to liken themselves to Moses by bringing forth the plagues.”<br>Now with regard to Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s statement that Moses did not inform them of the coming of the plague of gnats, it appears to me that Aaron struck [the dust of the earth] with the rod <i>in the sight of Pharaoh</i>, just as he did in the case of the soot of the furnace.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 9:8. In other words, just as in the case of boils it is said that it was done in the sight of the king, so also in the case of gnats, where the verse reads, <i>And Aaron stretched out his hand with his rod and smote the dust of the earth</i> (Verse 13), it was done in the sight of the king.</i> However, there was no forewarning here, since the Holy One, blessed be He, warned Pharaoh only of those plagues which entailed the death of people. In the case of the frogs, [there was also death involved], as it is written: <i>And</i> [He sent among them] <i>frogs, which destroyed them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:45.</i> which is an allusion to death or to the kind of destruction mentioned by our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 10:4.</i> i.e., that the frogs made them impotent. Similarly, [He warned him of] the locusts, [which destroyed the crops], because it would cause the Egyptians to die of hunger, for they ate up <i>the residue of that which escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:5.</i> All this reflects His mercies towards man, just as it is said, <i>Nevertheless, if thou warn the wicked of his way to turn from it, and he turn not from his way; he shall die in his iniquity, but thou hast delivered thy soul</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 33:9.</i> Therefore, He did not warn Pharaoh of the plagues of gnats, boils, and darkness, [as these did not entail the loss of human lives]. He warned him<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 9:3-4.</i> only of the pestilence of cattle because it involved death which should have taken effect also on man, as He told him afterward, <i>For now I might have stretched out My hand and I might have smitten thee and thy people with pestilence. But in very deed for this cause have I raised thee up</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 15-16.</i> Therefore He informed him of what was to happen.

Verse 16

In the case of certain plagues, [i.e., blood, swarms, and hail], G-d said to Moses, <i>Rise up early in the morning … lo he cometh forth to the water</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">The three verses are mentioned by Ramban more fully later in the text. Here he mentions the text in a general way although it is based on Verse 16 here.</i> In line with the plain meaning of Scripture,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi commented (above, 7:15): “<i>Lo, he goeth forth unto the water</i> to ease himself. Pharaoh claimed to be a god and asserted that [because of his divine powers], he did not need to ease himself. Therefore he would rise early and go forth to the Nile to ease himself in secret.” This interpretation of Rashi which is based upon a Midrash (Tanchuma Va’eira, 14) is alluded to by Ramban’s words that his own explanation is “in line with the plain meaning of Scripture,” thus implying that there is a Midrashic or homiletic interpretation of the verse, namely, that of Rashi mentioned above.</i> this was the time when the kings were wont to go forth in the morning to enjoy themselves in the waters, and the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Moses to go there. The reason for it is that since the plague of blood was the first one [of the plagues], He wanted Moses to do it in the sight of the king and without fear of him. This is the sense of the expression, <i>and thou shalt place thyself towards him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:15, in the case of the first plague.</i> Similarly, in the plague of swarms it is said, <i>Rise up early in the morning, and stand before Pharaoh; lo, he cometh forth to the water</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Here in Verse 16.</i> and also in the case of hail it is said, <i>Rise up early in the morning and stand before Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 9:13.</i> which likewise took place when the king went forth to the water. He wanted these two plagues to be wrought [at that particular time] because since swarms and hail brought death and punishment upon the people, the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted the warning to be given in the sight of all people. When the king went forth to the water, a multitude of people followed him, and when Moses will then forewarn him in their sight, perhaps they might plead with their master to return from his evil way. In case they do not do so, they will deserve punishment. But in the case of the other plagues, the warning given to the king alone was sufficient, and therefore in connection with them it is said, <i>Go in unto Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:26 (in the plague of frogs); further, 9:1 (pestilence), and 10:1 (locusts).</i> meaning that Moses was to go into the palace. In the case of gnats and boils, it does not say [that Moses was to go into the palace] because Aaron had to strike the dust of the earth [to bring on the plague of the gnats], and in the king’s palace there is no dust, as it has <i>a pavement of green and white marble</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:6.</i> In the case of boils, Moses had to throw the soot of the furnace heavenward.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 9:10.</i> Thus [we must say that] these two plagues, [i.e., gnats and boils], were done in the sight of Pharaoh when he was <i>in the court of the garden of the king’s palace</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:5.</i> or some similar place.

Verse 17



Verse 18

AND I WILL SET APART IN THAT DAY THE LAND OF GOSHEN. Due to the fact that the first plagues were not migratory in nature, it was no wonder that they were confined to the land of Egypt and were not to be in the land of Goshen, [Israel’s habitation].<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 47:15.</i> But this [plague of swarms] was a migratory plague.
