Thus when the wild beasts came up <i>from the lions’ dens, from the mountains of the leopards</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:8.</i> and brought ruin upon the whole land of Egypt, it was natural that they also come into the land of Goshen, which contained some of the best of the land of Egypt.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 47:6, where the land of Goshen is referred to as <i>the best of the land</i> of Egypt.</i> Therefore it was necessary for Him to say, <i>And I will set apart in that day the land of Goshen</i>, so that it would be completely saved [from the wild beasts] because <i>My people dwell in it</i>, as the majority of its inhabitants were Israelites.<br><i>And I will put ‘p’duth’</i> (<i>a division</i>) <i>between My people and thy people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> The intent thereof is that even in the land of Egypt, if the beasts will find a certain Jew, they will not harm him. Instead they will devour the Egyptians, as it is written: <i>He sent among them swarms of beasts, which devoured them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:45.</i> This is the sense of the word <i>‘p’duth’ between My people and thy people</i>, which is similar to the verse, <i>I have given Egypt as thy ransom, Ethiopia and Seba for thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 43:3.</i>
I AM THE ETERNAL IN THE MIDST OF THE EARTH. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it as being a figure of speech, emblematic of the nature of kings to establish their seat of government in the center of the kingdom in order to be near to the remote comers thereof. This explanation makes no sense. Rather, its intent is to state that He rules and supervises <i>in the midst of the earth</i>, and not, as some think, that <i>thick clouds are a covering to Him, that He seeth not; and He walketh in the circuit of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Job 22:14.</i> It is possible that the sense of the expression is similar to the verse, <i>For My name is in him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:21.</i> and the secret thereof is sublime and recondite.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 314, that the allusion here is to the Cabalistic term of “the upper earth.” See Ramban to Genesis 1:5 (Vol. I, pp. 35-38).</i>

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

AND MOSES SAID: BEHOLD, I GO OUT FROM THEE, AND I WILL ENTREAT THE ETERNAL THAT THE SWARMS WILL DEPART FROM PHARAOH, FROM HIS SERVANTS, AND FROM HIS PEOPLE, TOMORROW.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">The question here arises: Why did Moses say that he will pray that the removal of the plague be tomorrow, when Pharaoh had just said to him, <i>Entreat for me</i> (Verse 24)? Ramban proceeds to answer this question.</i> Just as Pharaoh, during the plague of the frogs, had asked that it be removed tomorrow,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 6.</i> so did Moses want to do it in this case as well; he would pray that the swarms [of beasts] shall depart tomorrow. And then G-d <i>removed the swarms</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> and they vanished completely, unlike the case of the frogs, [where Scripture states that they died].<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 9.</i> This was for the reason, as stated by our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 10:6.</i> that the Holy One, blessed be He, desired to afflict them with plagues from which they would derive no benefit.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">If the beasts had died in the land of Egypt, the Egyptians would have made use of their skins. Hence they just disappeared. This of course was not the case with the frogs.</i> Now Moses guarded himself when he spoke to Pharaoh, saying <i>to destroy the frogs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 5.</i> which alludes merely to their death, as I have explained there,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 5.</i> [while here in the case of swarms, he said <i>that the swarms will depart</i>].

Chapter 9



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

BEHOLD, THE HAND OF THE ETERNAL IS UPON THY CATTLE WHICH ARE IN THE FIELD. Scripture speaks of the ordinary custom that most cattle are in the field, but the plague was also upon the cattle in the houses, just as it is said, <i>And all the cattle of Egypt died</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> It is possible that because <i>every shepherd is an abomination unto the Egyptians</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:34.</i> the Egyptians removed the cattle from the cities except for the use of horses for riding and asses for loading. Thus the cattle were located far from Egypt, grazing in the fields bordering upon Goshen, and in those pastures the cattle of the Egyptians and of the Israelites would intermingle. Therefore it was necessary that it be said, <i>And the Eternal shall make a division between the cattle of Israel and the cattle of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> It may be that the division was necessary because since the pestilence was caused by the change of air, it should naturally spread over the whole district, [affecting the cattle of the Israelites as well], but G-d dealt wondrously with them.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">See Joel 2:26.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AND IT SHALL BECOME SMALL DUST OVER ALL THE LAND OF EGYPT. According to the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 11:6.</i> [the small quantity of] soot [in the hands of Moses] became the dust which settled over the whole land of Egypt, and that dust, coming <i>upon man and upon beast</i>, caused them to break forth with boils and blains <i>throughout all the land of Egypt</i>, since it was a burning hot dust. Perhaps the wind caused the dust to enter the homes as well, and there was thus no escape from it. This is a correct [conjecture]. Many times during a drought, the fall of the dew is accompanied by a sort of dust, and it is furthermore written, <i>The Eternal will make the rain of thy land powder and dust</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:24.</i><br>It is also possible to say, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture, that the purport of the expression, <i>And it shall become small dust</i>, is that the dust which will be produced in that place from the soot will bring the boils <i>over all the land of Egypt</i>, as He infected the air to do so, it being a decree of the Supreme One.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">According to this interpretation, the miracle entailed was thus greater than the one in consonance with the first interpretation, which had the dust throughout the land of Egypt causing the boils and the blains. According to the second interpretation, the soot of the furnace became dust only over the place where the miracle was wrought, which in turn caused the whole atmosphere over Egypt to effect the boils.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND THE MAGICIANS COULD NOT STAND BEFORE MOSES. <i>They were ashamed, and confounded, and covered their heads</i><sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 14:3.</i> since they were full of boils and could not rescue themselves. Therefore they made no appearance in the royal palace, nor did they appear before Moses in the streets. And so they were imprisoned in their homes.

Verse 12

AND THE ETERNAL HARDENED THE HEART OF PHARAOH. It is possible that during the first plagues, the magicians hardened Pharaoh’s heart in order to pride themselves in their wisdom. But now that they did not come before him and there was none to help him and none to uphold him<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 63:5.</i> in his folly except his iniquities that ensnared him,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 5:22.</i> [it was G-d Who hardened his heart]. It is possible that Scripture is alluding to that which our Rabbis have explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 11:7.</i> i.e., that during the first plagues, the hardening of Pharaoh’s heart was his own doing,<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">And not, as stated before, that it was caused by the magicians, who were proud of their arts.</i> and now it was [rightfully] caused by G-d, as I have explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:3.</i> This is the true explanation.

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

In view of the fact that Scripture states, <i>A very grievous hail, such as hath not been in Egypt since the day it was founded</i>, and repeats it again, <i>Very grievous, such as had not been in all the land of Egypt since it became a nation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 18 and 24.</i> there is an allusion that there are other places in the world where such hail did come down, such as is mentioned in the verse, <i>And the Eternal cast down great stones from heaven upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 10:11.</i> or as is mentioned in connection with [the destruction of] Sodom, <i>brimstone, and salt, and fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:22.</i> But in the land of Egypt, where there is no rain or hail, this was a great wonder.<br>I have not understood what is said in Midrash Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 12:2. In our Midrash, there is a different version of this text. See also my Hebrew commentary, p. 316.</i> “The verse does not say, ‘as hath not been in Egypt like it,’ but instead it says, ‘as hath not been like it in Egypt,’ which means there has neither been like it in the world nor in Egypt.”<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">This Midrash is in clear contradiction to that which Ramban stated above, i.e., that such hail has come down in other places. Therefore Ramban preceded the Midrash by saying that he does not understand it. Since Ramban’s opinion is based upon the verses mentioned above, he cannot revoke his opinion as being incorrect.</i> And the expression, <i>since the day it was founded</i>, is equivalent to saying: “Your fathers and your grandfathers have never seen the like of it.” But it is not possible to say that it suggests that the like of it occurred before the world was founded or before the inception of nations. Perhaps because this hail came as a punishment upon the inhabitants of Egypt and was not in the natural order, [the verse] is saying that nothing like it has ever occurred because of the sins of the fathers, for before the inception of Egypt as a nation, surely there was no [reason for] such hail to come.
BEHOLD, TOMORROW ABOUT THIS TIME I WILL CAUSE IT TO RAIN A VERY GRIEVOUS HAIL, etc. 19. NOW THEREFORE SEND, HASTEN IN THY CATTLE. All this is G-d’s word to Moses, and it is self-understood that Moses came and told Pharaoh all the words of G-d that He sent him to speak, and there was no need to prolong the account [of Moses’ going to Pharaoh and so telling him]. Scripture only states, <i>He that feared the word of the Eternal among the servants of Pharaoh made his servants and his cattle flee into the houses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> from which it is clear that Moses had told them [G-d’s words]. This advice was on account of G-d’s being merciful to them, since the plague of hail was sent only against the produce of the earth and not against man, <i>therefore doth He instruct sinners in the way</i><sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 25:8.</i> to save them from the plague.

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

ONLY IN THE LAND OF GOSHEN, WHERE THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WERE, WAS THERE NO HAIL. Because Moses had stretched forth his hand toward heaven and brought down the hail,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> it should have followed that it came down also upon the land of Goshen, as the air thereof and that of Egypt are the same. Therefore Scripture explained that the air over the land of Goshen was saved [from the hail] because the children of Israel were there.

Verse 27

I HAVE SINNED THIS TIME. The explanation thereof is: “This time I will acknowledge the Eternal,<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 8:15, that throughout, Pharaoh did not acknowledge the Eternal, the G-d of Israel. Ramban points out that this was the first time Pharaoh did acknowledge Him. Ramban transposes the words, <i>chatathi hapa’am Hashem hatzadik</i>, and explains them as follows: “<i>This time</i> I acknowledge <i>the Eternal</i>, for <i>I have sinned</i> against Him, etc.”</i> for I have sinned against Him, and He is the righteous One, <i>and I and my people are wicked</i>, for we have rebelled against His word from then until now.”

Verse 28



Verse 29

AS SOON AS I AM GONE OUT OF THE CITY, I WILL SPREAD FORTH MY HANDS UNTO THE ETERNAL. In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is possible to say that [on other occasions] Moses prayed in his house, [which was within the city]. However, this time He saw fit that his hands be spread heavenward so that the thunders and the hail cease immediately, and that was impossible to be done in the city [because it was replete with idols]. Hence he said, <i>As soon as I am gone out of the city</i>. And so it is said further on, <i>And Moses went out of the city from Pharaoh, and spread forth his hands</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33.</i> But at first, [i.e., during the plague of swarms], Moses said to Pharaoh, <i>Behold, I go out from thee, and I will entreat the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 8:25.</i> [for as soon as he left the palace he went to his house in the city and prayed].<br>But our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta Introduction, and quoted further on (12:1) by Rashi.</i> that Moses “did not pray within the city because it was full of idols, and all the more He did not converse with him except outside the city.” If so, we must say that since Pharaoh now pleaded with Moses that he remove the hail immediately,<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> Moses found it necessary to explain to him that he must go out of the city first and after that he will spread forth his hands to the Eternal, and He will remove it on account of his prayer. This is the true explanation.

Verse 30

I KNOW THAT ‘TEREM’ (NOT YET)<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This translation accords with the interpretation of Rashi. Ibn Ezra’s explanation as well as that of Ramban will differ, as explained further.</i> WILL YE FEAR THE ETERNAL G-D. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra correctly criticized Rashi [for explaining that wherever the word <i>terem</i> occurs in Scripture, it signifies “not yet” and does not mean “before”]. It is the opposite: it does not mean “no,” but rather it means “before.” And Ibn Ezra explained that the verse here is missing one word, [namely, <i>zeh</i> (this), making it read]: <i>terem zeh tir’un</i>. That is to say, “Before I will spread forth my hands and the thunders and hail will cease, ye do fear G-d, for after the removal of the plague you will return and rebel against Him.”<br>It is furthermore correct to explain<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban now proceeds to explain in a manner where it is not necessary to posit the absence of a word in the text of the verse. It thus has an advantage over that of Ibn Ezra.</i> that Moses is also alluding to the first occasions, saying: “I know from your [former actions] that before [I pray on your behalf] you fear G-d, and in the end, [after I pray], you rebel against Him. Before the plagues are removed from you, you fear G-d as you did in the plague of frogs and of swarms, and then you returned <i>and ye rebelled against the commandment of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:47.</i> and so will you continue to be forever.” It was for this reason that when Pharaoh recanted [his promise to let the people go], Moses no longer warned him of that but instead knowingly prayed on his behalf during the plague of the locust,<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:18.</i> in order that he continue to sin.

Verse 31

AND THE FLAX AND THE BARLEY WERE SMITTEN, etc. Scripture narrates what happened, but I do not know why these two verses were entered in this place before the subject of Moses’ prayer and the removal of the hail was completed. In the name of Rav Saadia Gaon,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned by Ibn Ezra here. One of the greatest Jewish personalities of all times, Rav Saadia (892 or 882-942) was Gaon of the Academy of Sura. He wrote extensively on every aspect of Jewish learning: Bible, Talmud, grammar, philology, philosophy, polemics against the Karaites, etc. His work, Ha’emunoth Vehadei’oth, the first of its kind in the field of Jewish religious philosophy, exercised a great influence on Jewish thought. He translated the Scriptures into Arabic and wrote extensive commentaries in Arabic on the books of the Bible, which influenced the later commentators. Ramban’s knowledge of his commentaries, as indicated here, seems to have been mainly through a secondary source. See, however, Note 224 in <i>Seder Shemoth</i> that there is some proof indicating that Ramban may have seen the Gaon’s commentary in the original Arabic.</i> the commentators have said that these [two verses are also part of] Moses’ words to Pharaoh. He said to him: “Before you had feared G-d and said, <i>The Eternal is the righteous One</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> the flax and the barley were already smitten and these can no longer be saved. <i>But the wheat and the spelt were not smitten</i> yet, and henceforth you will no longer suffer damage.”<br>I find no sense in this explanation. <i>The hail smote every herb of the field</i><sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> and broke every tree,<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> and the wheat and the spelt were saved only because they had not sprouted at all or because they were so tender that they were not destroyed completely by the hail since they could sprout again. That being the case, even if the hail had continued for days more to come down upon them, there would not be a loss. There was thus no need for Moses to inform Pharaoh of what he lost and what he did not lose, for when the hail will be removed, he will himself see!<br>In my opinion, these are Moses’ words to Pharaoh. Moses said to him: “I know that before the plagues are removed, you fear G-d, and afterward you repeat your folly.<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 26:11.</i> Now the flax and the barley were smitten while the wheat and the spelt which are your livelihood were not smitten in this plague, but it is within G-d’s power to destroy them if you return and sin again before Him.” Thus Moses alluded to them that which G-d said later [of the locust], <i>And they shall eat the residue of that which escaped</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 10:5.</i><br>Bo

Chapter 10



Verse 1

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: GO IN UNTO PHARAOH; FOR I HAVE HARDENED HIS HEART AND THE HEART OF HIS SERVANTS. The Holy One, blessed be He, informed Moses that it is He Who has hardened their hearts in spite of their fear of Him during the hail and their confession of sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Although Scripture above (9:27) mentions only Pharaoh confessing his sin, it is apparent from Verse 30 there that the king’s servants also made this confession, since Moses said to all of them, <i>But as for thee and thy servants, I know that ye will not yet fear the Eternal G-d</i>. This is a clear indication that the servants too had joined the king in admitting their guilt. Ramban is thus correct in writing here in the plural: “<i>their</i> confession of sin.”</i> And He explained to him: “The reason I hardened their hearts is that I might set in their midst these signs that I wish to do among them so that the Egyptians will know My power, but not in order that I can punish them more on account of this hardening of heart, and also that you and all Israel should recount during the coming generations the power of My deeds, <i>and you shall know that I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> and whatsoever I please, I do in heaven and in earth.”<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 135:6.</i>

Verse 2

HITH’ALALTI.’ “<i>I have mocked</i> him, for it is I Who hardened his heart and exacted punishments of him.” This is similar in intent to the verse: <i>He that sits in heaven smiles, the Eternal mocks them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:4.</i><br>The Holy One, blessed be He, now informed Moses of the plague of locusts, [although this is not stated here in Scripture], and that he should tell it to Pharaoh, for what sense was there that he be commanded, <i>Go in unto Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> and not say something to him, the plague being mentioned only in the words of Moses to Pharaoh,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 4-6.</i> as Scripture spoke succinctly of this. So also was the case above with the plague of hail, where Scripture told of the words of the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses, <i>Stand before Pharaoh, and say unto him</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:13.</i> but did not at all mention that Moses said so to Pharaoh, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> The reason for it is that Scripture does not want to elaborate on it in two places, [i.e., when G-d said it to Moses, and when Moses relayed it to Pharaoh], and so it shortens the narrative sometimes at one point and other times at another.<br>In Eileh Shemoth Rabbah,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 13:5.</i> I have seen it stated: “<i>And that thou mayest tell in the ears of thy son</i>. The Holy One, blessed be He, informed Moses what plague He is about to bring upon them, and Moses wrote it down with a hint: <i>And that thou mayest tell in the ears of thy son, and of thy son’s son</i>, which is an allusion to the plague of locusts, just as it is said [of the locusts in the days of the prophet Joel], <i>Tell ye your children of it, and let your children tell their children</i>, etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 1:3. This was said by the prophet during the terrible plague of locusts and drought. See Ramban further, Verse 14. The Midrash thus confirms Ramban’s explanation that within G-d’s command to Moses, as stated in the Torah, there was also included the oral communication concerning the locusts. The Midrash however added that the plague is alluded to in the expression, <i>And that thou mayest tell</i>, etc., which is a reference to the locusts.</i>

Verse 3

AND MOSES AND AARON CAME IN UNTO PHARAOH. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented: “We know that Moses never came to Pharaoh without being accompanied by Aaron, who was the interpreter.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:2.</i> Scripture here makes a point of mentioning Moses and Aaron in order [to make clear] that Pharaoh’s command that both of them be brought again before him<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 8.</i> and his final act of driving them out<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> — something he had not done previously — [applied to the two brothers alike].”

Verse 4

BEHOLD, TOMORROW WILL I BRING LOCUSTS. Commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra (Verse 5) in the name of another commentator.</i> have said that there was a long interval between the plague of hail and that of locusts, as is suggested by the expression, <i>and</i> [the locusts] <i>shall eat every tree which groweth for you out of the field</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In the present verse. Since we have been told that the hail broke every tree of the field (above, 9:25), a long interval must have passed to allow the trees to grow back.</i> In my opinion, the interval between these plagues was not a long one but rather was very brief. It is known that the judgment of the Egyptians did not last more than a year, this being so established through our knowledge of the years of Moses our Teacher,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Moses was eighty years old when he stood before Pharaoh (above, 7:7). Add the forty years of the desert, and you have the one hundred and twenty years he lived (Deuteronomy 34:7). Thus, the elapsed time of all the ten punishments decreed for Egypt could not possibly have been more than a year.</i> just as we have been taught in Tractate Eduyoth:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Eduyoth 2:10.</i> “The judgment of the Egyptians in Egypt endured twelve months.” And so it is indicated by Scripture when saying, <i>and they shall eat the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> And it is further written, <i>even all that the hail had left</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 12.</i> thus indicating that it was in that very same year. If so, [we must say that] the hail came down that year during the month of Adar, not before, <i>for the barley was in the ears</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:31.</i> [and therefore smitten by the hail], but the wheat had not grown up<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32.</i> and therefore its tender sprouts could not be completely destroyed by the hail, as they would grow back again. Then too the vine had not yet budded, and the trees were not in flower. It is for this reason that Scripture states, <i>and</i> [the hail] <i>broke every tree of the field</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:25.</i> meaning that it broke the branches and boughs. Then, in one month’s time, in the month of Nisan, the wheat and the spelt grew, these being <i>the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> and the trees began to blossom and the flowers appeared. This then is the purport of the word <i>hatzomei’ach</i> (which groweth),<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> since the locusts came and ate their blossoms and thus destroyed everything since they did not leave them a blossom or flower. And in this very month, the children of Israel were redeemed [from Egypt]. The verse which states [that the locusts consumed] <i>all the fruit of the tree</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> [which would indicate that there were fruits already on the tree and, therefore, that a long interval must have passed between the plagues of hail and locusts], is to be understood as referring to the flower which produces the fruits, similar to the expression, <i>every herb on the tree</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> [which cannot be understood literally, since herbs do not grow on trees. Consequently, it must be understood as Rashi has it: “any green leaf on the tree.” Here too then, “the fruit of the tree” is not to be taken literally, but should be understood as “the flower of the tree”].

Verse 5



Verse 6

AND HE TURNED AND WENT OUT FROM PHARAOH. Due to the fact that the Egyptians were in a state of trepidation during the plague of hail, Moses thought that now too they would fear lest they die from famine if they lose <i>the residue of that which is escaped</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> which remained to them. Therefore he went out without the king’s permission before they accepted or rejected his request, so that they might take counsel on the matter. This was indeed correct, for so the servants did and said to Pharaoh, <i>Knowest thou not yet that Egypt is destroyed?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> In the words of our Rabbis:<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 13:5.</i> “Moses saw the servants turning to each other, believing in his words, so he went out from there in order that they may take counsel to do repentance.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that Moses did so every time he came to Pharaoh’s palace; he warned him and went out. Scripture found it necessary to mention it only here because of the sequel: <i>And Moses and Aaron were brought again unto Pharaoh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

BUT WHO ARE THEY THAT SHALL GO? Pharaoh desired that their leaders, elders, and officers<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 29:9.</i> should go, <i>men that are pointed out by name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:17.</i> Moses answered him that also the sons and daughters will go, “<i>for we must hold a feast unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> and it is mandatory upon us all to take part in the feast.” Pharaoh’s anger was then kindled on account of the sons and daughters, and he said that under no circumstances will he send the little ones, for they take no part in the offerings. Instead he would send all the adult males because of the feast which Moses mentioned, while the little ones and the women will remain [in Egypt].

Verse 9



Verse 10

SEE YE THAT EVIL IS BEFORE YOUR FACE. “The intent of the verse is as the Targum [Onkelos] explained it.” Thus the language of Rashi. Now how commendable it would have been if Rashi had written out [the text of Onkelos he referred to], since there are variant texts of this Targum! In some texts, it is written: “See, the evil you are about to do is set against you.”<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">This is not the text found in our version of Targum Onkelos. Ramban will later mention two other variants of Onkelos’ text here. See Note 34 for the text found in our version of the Targum.</i> According to this text, it appears that Onkelos intended to explain: “the evil you are contemplating to do is set before you, bearing witness against you that it is your desire to escape altogether.” This is similar to the verse, <i>And set two men, base fellows, before him</i> [Naboth], <i>and let them bear witness against him, saying</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 21:10.</i> It is also similar to [the expressions]: <i>And they sat down to eat bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:25.</i> which the Targum translates <i>v’istacharu</i> (and they sat down), [the same as the term <i>istacharat</i> that appears to be in the Targum here]; <i>Arise, I pray thee, sit</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:19.</i> which the Targum translates <i>istachar</i> (sit).<br>And there are versions of [Targum Onkelos] in which it is written: “will turn against yourself.”<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">This text appears in our version of Targum Onkelos.</i> The purport thereof is thus: “Behold, this evil you are about to do is destined to turn against you, for it will pass upon you.” This is similar to the expression, <i>So shall no inheritance of the children of Israel pass from tribe to tribe</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 36:7.</i> which the Targum translates: <i>lo tistachar</i> (not pass), [similar to the Targum here, <i>l’istachro</i>]. This explanation finds authority in the Midrash of the Sages, who said in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 13:5.</i> “[Pharaoh said]: ‘It is the custom of young men and the elders to offer sacrifice, but is it the custom of children and the little ones to do so? He who says so intends only to escape. See that which you want to do, namely to escape, will turn against you, that you will not go forth from here,’” a kind of measure for measure.<br>And I have found yet another version in the Targum: “your countenance does not bear witness to the absence of this evil,” meaning that “your countenance does not bear witness to the removal of the evil in your hearts. On the contrary, the show of your countenance bears witness against you.”<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, [the intent of the verse is to be understood as follows]: “Know that evil is before you, ready and imminent to come upon you from me, for I will requite you evil when I see that you want to escape.”

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14

NEITHER AFTER THEM SHALL BE SUCH [LOCUSTS]. Scripture informs us by way of prophecy that after them, there would never be such [locusts]. Now Rashi commented: “[The plague of locusts] which occurred during the days of Joel, of which it is said, <i>There hath not been ever the like</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:2.</i> teaches us that it was greater<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">“Greater.” In our text of Rashi: “more grievous.”</i> than that in the days of Moses. The one that happened in the days of Joel was caused by many species together: locust, caterpillar, canker-worm, palmer-worm.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 1:4.</i> But the one which occurred in the days of Moses consisted only of one species, the like of which there never was and never will be.”<br>I have found difficulty in understanding the explanation of the Rabbi [Rashi]. It is written [of the plague which happened in the days of Moses], <i>He also gave their produce unto the caterpillar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:46.</i> and it is also written, <i>He spoke, and the locust came, and the canker-worm without number</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 105:34. Thus it is clear that in the plague which occurred in the days of Moses, there were also many species of locusts involved, unlike Rashi’s explanation above.</i> Perhaps the Rabbi [Rashi] will answer by saying that in the days of Moses, locust proper was greater than that in the days of Joel, but all other species of locusts in the days of Joel were greater than those in the days of Moses. But these are useless arguments.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">It is illogical to say that the Torah here attached such importance to the plague just because one of the species involved was greater than that in the days of Joel, although in the number of species, the plague of locusts which occurred in the days of the prophet was unparalleled. (Mizrachi in explanation of Ramban’s intent.)</i> Instead, [we must say that the expression], <i>in all the borders of Egypt</i>, is connected with the end of the verse: <i>before them there were no such locusts as they, neither after them shall be such</i> there [in Egypt, but in other places there may be].<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">There is thus no contradiction to the prophet Joel’s words. That plague of locusts did not occur in the land of Egypt.</i> It is possible that because the land of Egypt is exceedingly moistened by the river, locusts are not abundant there, for these naturally come in years of drought, as is mentioned by the prophet Joel.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><i>For the water brooks are dried up</i> (Joel 1:20).</i><br>Now Rabbeinu Chananel<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">A Rabbi of Kairwan, North Africa, who flourished in the first half of the eleventh century, just when the Gaonic period in Babylon was about to come to a close. Rabbeinu Chananel’s commentaries on the Talmud are among the most important works in Rabbinic literature. He also wrote a commentary on the Torah, which has been lost in the course of time, except for important extracts from it which are found mostly in the commentary of Bachya ben Asher. Some extracts are found in the works of Ramban and in the Sermons of Yehoshua ibn Shuib, a pupil of Rashba. An edition of mine of these collected explanations of Rabbeinu Chananel has recently appeared through the Mosad Harav Kook, Jerusalem, and they indicate a wide spectrum of interests on the part of the author in Biblical themes.</i> has written in his commentary on the Torah: “From the time that Moses our teacher prayed [for the removal of the locusts] till now, the locusts have not caused damage to the entire land of Egypt, and if an attack of them does occur in the Land of Israel and they proceed to enter within the border of Egypt, they do not devour the produce of the land. People say that this is known by all. Come and see! In the case of frogs, Moses said, <i>Only in the river they will remain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 8:5.</i> and therefore the <i>altamtzach</i> — [the Arabic word for frogs] — have remained in the river till now. However, in the case of the locusts it is written, <i>There remained not one locust in all the border of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 19.</i> It is of a phenomenon of this kind that Scripture says, <i>Speak ye of all His marvellous works</i>. ”<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:2.</i> Thus the language of the Rabbi.<br>In my opinion, the plain meaning of the verse, [<i>neither after them shall be such</i>], is that because the plague of locusts is known to come in all generations, and moreover since this one [in the days of Moses] came in a natural way, it having been the east wind that brought the locusts,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> [and there was thus reason to believe that such a plague would again come upon Egypt in a natural way], Scripture therefore states that such locusts were the greatest that ever occurred in the natural order of things. Neither before them were there such locusts as they, nor after them shall be such. Through the magnitude of the plague, the Egyptians thus knew that it was a special act of G-d, since the like never happened before. [The plague] that occurred in the days of Joel was likewise a special act of G-d, [and hence Scripture also describes it by saying, <i>There hath never been the like</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:2.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

NOW THEREFORE FORGIVE, I PRAY THEE, MY SIN. This is an expression of respect to Moses [on the part of Pharaoh] since Moses was <i>in G-d’s stead to Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:1.</i> <i>and very great in the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 11:3.</i> [Hence Pharaoh addressed this appeal to Moses alone, as the singular verb <i>sa</i> (forgive) indicates, for the king knew of the extraordinary position of Moses, as explained.] <i>And entreat ye the Eternal your G-d</i>. He addressed this appeal to both Moses and Aaron. He respectfully spoke thus every time [that he asked for prayer on his behalf]<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 8:4 (in the case of frogs), 8:24 (swarms of beasts), and 9:38 (hail). In each case, Pharaoh said <i>ha’tiru</i> (pray ye) in the plural.</i> although Pharaoh knew that Moses alone was the one who prayed, for so he told him: <i>Against what time shall I entreat for thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Above</i>, 8:5.</i> <i>And I will entreat the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> <i>I will spread forth my hands to the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:29.</i> Moses did not say it in the plural, [i.e., “we shall entreat”], so that he should not utter a falsehood, [but Pharaoh nevertheless addressed himself to both as an expression of respect].

Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

THEY SAW NOT ONE ANOTHER, NEITHER ROSE ANY FROM HIS PLACE. The meaning thereof is that this darkness was not a mere absence of sunlight where the sun set and it was like night. Rather, it was <i>a thick darkness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> That is to say, it was a very thick cloud that came down from heaven. It is for this reason that He said, “<i>Stretch out thy hand toward heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> to bring down from there a great darkness which would descend upon them<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 15:12.</i> and which would extinguish every light, just as in all deep caverns and in all extremely dark places where light cannot last [as it is swallowed up in the density of the thick darkness].” Similarly, people who pass through the Mountains of Darkness<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The name is found in the Talmud (Tamid 32a) in connection with Alexander the Great, who told the Sages of the south: “I wish to go to the country of Africa,” whereupon they answered him, “you cannot go, for the Mountains of Darkness intercede.” It would seem then that these were mountains somewhere in the heart of Africa, a dim knowledge of which reached the outer world. Considering the fact that the heart of central Africa was not penetrated by European explorers till the end of the nineteenth century, it is no wonder that not much was known in Medieval Europe about this region.</i> find that no candle or fire can continue to burn at all. It is for this reason that <i>they saw not one another, neither rose any from his place</i>, for otherwise they would have used the light of fire. This is the intent of the verse, <i>He sent darkness, and it became dark</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:28.</i> It was not the usual absence of daylight above but an extraordinary darkness as well. It is possible that it was such a very thick cloud that there was something tangible in it, as our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 14:1.</i> and as indeed it happens on the Atlantic Ocean, as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra testified.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">“It often happens on the Atlantic Ocean that it is impossible to distinguish day from night, and this sometimes lasts for five days. I have personally experienced it many times” (Ibn Ezra). A native of Spain, Ibn Ezra was born in the city of Tudela in the year 1093. In search of knowledge, he journeyed throughout the European countries and the Near East, where he made the acquaintance of the greatest luminaries of his time. Sometime after 1150, he visited London, where in the course of his journey he most likely experienced the density of fog he describes.</i>

Verse 24

ONLY LET YOUR FLOCKS AND YOUR HERDS BE STAYED. Since the Israelites <i>were keepers of cattle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 46:32.</i> and all their wealth and belongings consisted of cattle, Pharaoh thought that they would not leave all their possessions and flee from the country. Even if they were to flee, he would be left with their great wealth, as they were very rich in cattle.

Verse 25

THOU MUST ALSO GIVE INTO OUR HAND SACRIFICES AND BURNT-OFFERINGS. Moses did not make this a condition, neither did Pharaoh. Rather, these are words to impress Pharaoh. In effect Moses was saying to him that G-d’s power will be so heavy upon him and his people that even sacrifices and burnt — offerings <i>and all that he hath will he give for his life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Job 2:4.</i> Indeed, when Pharaoh said to Moses and Aaron [at the time that he gave the people permission to go], <i>And bless me also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:32.</i> he would willingly have given all his cattle in atonement for his sin [of rebelling against G-d’s command till then]. Moses however had no intention to do so, for <i>the sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 21:27.</i> as <i>it pleased the Eternal to crush him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 53:10.</i> not to forgive him but instead to punish him and to overthrow him with all his host in the midst of the sea.<br>Now our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta d’Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai, on the Verse further, 12:32.</i> that Pharaoh’s expression [to Moses and Aaron], <i>Take both your flocks and your herds, as ye have said</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:32.</i> refers to their saying to him, <i>Thou must also give into our hand sacrifices and burnt-offerings</i>. Perhaps the Rabbis intended to say that Pharaoh hinted to Moses and Aaron that he is ready to give them whatever they say, but not at all that they took anything from him. It may be that he supplied them with sacrifices and burnt-offerings for their use so that the Israelites would fulfill their own obligation [in the observance of G-d’s feast]. But this also is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Since permission for their own cattle for sacrifices was specifically made a condition by Moses [here in Verse 26 — <i>Our cattle shall also go with us… for thereof must we take to serve the Eternal our G-d</i>] — it could not be correct to say that they later took sacrifices for themselves from Pharaoh. We must therefore conclude that Pharaoh only hinted to them that he was ready to give them whatever they demand, but actually they took no animals from him for sacrifice.</i>

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND MOSES SAID: THOU HAST SPOKEN WELL; I WILL NOT SEE THY FACE AGAIN ANY MORE. That is, “I will not see you again after I leave you.” After the plague of the firstborn, Moses did not see Pharaoh. The meaning of the verse, <i>And he called for Moses and Aaron</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:31.</i> is [not that he called them to come to see him, but instead] that he himself went to the entrance of their home and shouted in the darkness, <i>Rise up, get you forth from among my people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:31.</i> Perhaps he sent the message to them by Egyptians, of whom it is said, <i>And the Egyptians were urgent upon the people to send them out of the land in haste</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 33.</i><br>It is possible that the verse, <i>I will not see thy face again any more</i>, means “in your palace,” namely, “I will not come to you any more.” And so the Rabbis have said in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 14:4.</i> “You have spoken well in saying, <i>See my face no more</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> I will not come to you again; you will come to me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">According to this Midrash then, Moses did see Pharaoh later, but the king came to him. According to the first explanation, however, after he left the palace this time, Moses no longer saw Pharaoh at all.</i>

Chapter 11



Verse 1

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: YET ONE PLAGUE MORE WILL I BRING UPON PHARAOH. “This [prophecy] was spoken to him while he was still standing before Pharaoh, for after he left him he did not see his face again.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Our Rabbis have similarly said:<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 18:1.</i> “G-d sprung upon Moses. He, as it were, entered Pharaoh’s palace, [which was replete with abominations], for the sake of Moses — who had said, <i>I will see thy face again no more</i> —<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:29.</i> so that Moses might not be branded a liar. Now you find no other occasion on which the Holy One, blessed be He, spoke to Moses in the royal palace except this moment. Whence may we deduce this? From the verse, <i>As soon as I am gone out of the city, I will spread forth my hands unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:29. And see Ramban there.</i> But now the Holy One, blessed be He, sprang upon Moses and said to him, <i>Yet one plague more</i>, etc.”<br>Now here too<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 10:2.</i> there is a shortening of narrative. G-d said to Moses, <i>Yet one plague more will I bring upon Pharaoh</i>, and He informed him of the nature of that plague, saying to him, <i>At midnight I will go out into the midst of Egypt</i>, as well as the whole communication stated in this section, [further in Verses 5-8, as Moses’ address to Pharaoh in the Name of G-d]. But Scripture did not want to lengthen the account by first narrating what G-d said to Moses, it being sufficient to state what Moses said to Pharaoh, i.e., <i>Thus saith the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> just as I have explained in the case of the locusts.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 10:2.</i> There are many such sections in the Torah. In this <i>Seder</i> (section of the Torah), in the segment, <i>Sanctify unto Me all the firstborn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 13:2.</i> Scripture shortens the subject which the Holy One, blessed be He, communicated to Moses, and it prolongs the account of Moses’ words to the people, i.e., <i>Remember this day</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> and so on to the end of that entire segment.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., to the end of Verse 16 there.</i> They really are G-d’s words to Moses, which he said to Israel in the very language with which he was commanded.

Verse 2

SPEAK NOW IN THE EARS OF THE PEOPLE. I.e., after you depart from Pharaoh.

Verse 3

AND THE ETERNAL GAVE THE PEOPLE FAVOR IN THE SIGHT OF THE EGYPTIANS. The purport thereof is that the Egyptians did not hate them because of the plagues. Instead, they conceived affection for them, and the Israelites found favor in their eyes, the Egyptians acknowledging, “we are the wicked ones. There is violence in our hands, and you merit that G-d be gracious to you.”
MOREOVER, THE MAN MOSES, who brought the plagues upon them, WAS VERY GREAT IN THE ENTIRE LAND OF EGYPT, IN THE SIGHT OF PHARAOH’S SERVANTS — his opponents — AND IN THE SIGHT OF THE PEOPLE, Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Unlike Ibn Ezra, who explains <i>in the sight of the people</i> as referring to the Egyptians. Ramban will refer to this explanation further on.</i> After [the officers of the children of Israel] had said to Moses and Aaron, <i>The Eternal look upon you, and judge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:21.</i> after <i>they hearkened not unto Moses for impatience of spirit</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:9.</i> he now became very great in their sight when they saw <i>that he was established to be a prophet of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 3:20.</i> And some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra.</i> say that the expression, <i>in the sight of the people</i>, means the Egyptians.<br>The reason Scripture does not state [that Moses was very great] “in the sight of Pharaoh and in the sight of his servants,” [but instead mentions only Pharaoh’s servants], is that G-d made Pharaoh’s heart obstinate towards Moses because he [Pharaoh] had twice spoken to him improperly,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:10 (<i>So be the Eternal with you, as I will let you go</i>), and <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 28 (<i>Get thee from me</i>).</i> and He desired that Pharaoh come to Moses and bow down to him as one comes before his enemy, all this being a sign of the power and achievement of Moses.<br>Now it is impossible to explain the expression, <i>And the Eternal gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians</i>, as referring to the favor they found in the eyes of the Egyptians at the time of the borrowing, [mentioned further, 12:36]. In that case, the verse there relates that G-d later fulfilled the promise He made here.<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">The explanation refuted now by Ramban is that of Ibn Ezra [in Verse 3 before us].</i> If the verse here were establishing the Divine promise, [i.e., that the people will find favor in the sight of the Egyptians and that they will let them have what they asked], the verse here should not have said, <i>And the Eternal gave;</i> it should have said, “And I will give the people favor.” [Hence we must conclude that the intent of the verse here is to be explained as above, i.e., that the Egyptians bore no grudge against the Israelites because of the plagues.] It is further on at the time of the actual event that Scripture says, <i>And the Eternal gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they let them have what they asked</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:36.</i>

Verse 4

AND MOSES SAID: THUS SAITH THE ETERNAL: ABOUT MIDNIGHT WILL I GO OUT INTO THE MIDST OF EGYPT. Moses said this to Pharaoh and to his servants, as he mentioned at the end of his words, <i>And all these thy servants shall come down unto me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> Now he did not explain on what night this plague will take place, since this Divine communication to Moses and the transmission thereof to Pharaoh happened before the first of Nisan,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In view of the fact that Ramban wrote above (10:4) that the plague of the locusts occurred in the month of Nisan, it is difficult to understand his statement here that the Divine communication to Moses and the transmission thereof to Pharaoh concerning the plague of the firstborn happened <i>before</i> the first of Nisan. In my opinion, this is to be explained on the basis of that which Ramban wrote in <i>Seder Shemoth</i> (4:21), that at the very first time that Moses came before Pharaoh, he warned him of the <i>last plague</i> which will force him to let the people go. In that case, the Divine communication to Moses and the transmission of it to Pharaoh did indeed take place before the first of Nisan. The verse here, <i>yet one plague more will I bring upon Pharaoh</i>, must then be understood in the sense that G-d told Moses that the time had come for the final plague of which He had told him in the beginning and which Moses had related to Pharaoh. See also my Hebrew commentary, p. 323, for further discussion of this problem.</i> and when he said <i>about midnight</i>, he did not yet know on which night it would be. Thus Moses did not inform them of the specific night on which this plague would take place, but instead he said in kindled anger, “<i>I will see thy face again no more</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:29.</i> It is you who will call upon me at about midnight to go out from your country, and your servants will bow down to me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> In the second section He elucidated to Israel, <i>And I will go through the land of Egypt in that night</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:12.</i> and in the third section Scripture states, <i>And it came to pass at midnight</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> i.e., the night mentioned when they were eating the paschal lamb.

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: PHARAOH WILL NOT HEARKEN UNTO YOU. It was to be expected that Pharaoh and his servants should dread the plague of the firstborn and be in consternation thereof moreso than for anything that had happened to them — indeed they had previously seen all the words of Moses fulfilled. G-d therefore informed Moses that it is He Who is hardening his [Pharaoh’s] heart, so that His wonders would be multiplied through the plague of the firstborn in both man and beast and the judgments He will execute against their gods.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 12:12.</i><br>Rashi commented: “<i>So that My wonders may be multiplied</i>. This refers to the slaying of the firstborn, the division of the Red Sea, and the overthrowing of the Egyptians in it.” This explanation is not possible, because of the verse after that which states, <i>And the Eternal hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not let the children of Israel go out of his land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10. This indicates that the expression, <i>that My wonders may be multiplied</i>, which was mentioned in Verse 9, refers only to those wonders which took place <i>before</i> the exodus, as Verse 10 clearly indicates that on account of the hardening of Pharaoh’s heart he did not let the people go. It thus cannot refer to the division of the Red Sea and the overthrowing of the Egyptians in it, as these wonders happened <i>after</i> the exodus (Mizrachi).</i>

Verse 10

AND MOSES AND AARON DID ALL THESE WONDERS. These are the wonders mentioned above. Scripture states this now because it completes [the narrative of] all the deeds they did [before Pharaoh], including the decree of the plague of the firstborn of which they already informed Pharaoh, for in the actual slaying of the firstborn, Moses and Aaron had no part.

Chapter 12



Verse 1



Verse 2

THIS MONTH SHALL BE UNTO YOU THE BEGINNING OF MONTHS. This is the first commandment which the Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Israel through Moses. Therefore it says here [that the Eternal spoke unto Moses and Aaron] <i>in the land of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> for the rest of the commandments of the Torah were given to him on Mount Sinai. It may be that the intent of the expression, <i>in the land of Egypt</i>, is to exclude the city of Egypt, just as our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, Introduction.</i> “<i>In the land of Egypt</i>. This means outside the city.”<br>Now Scripture should have first said, <i>Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel, saying:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> <i>This month shall be unto you the beginning of months</i>, and so on to the end of the chapter. [Why then is the verse, <i>Speak ye</i>, etc., mentioned after the verse, <i>This month</i>, etc.?] It is because Moses and Aaron — [as mentioned in Verse 1: <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt, saying: This month</i>, etc.] — are in the place of Israel. Saying it to them is equivalent to saying it to Israel in all their generations. In the following verse, however, He repeats by saying, <i>Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel</i>, in order to command them something which is not binding for all time, namely, the buying of the paschal offering in Egypt on the tenth day of Nisan.<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">In subsequent generations, the paschal offering may be purchased at any time (Pesachim 96a). Ramban’s thought is thus clear. With the commandment, <i>This month shall be unto you</i>, etc., applying as it does for all time, it is sufficient for Scripture to mention only Moses and Aaron in connection with it, since they are in place of Israel for all times. But since the command mentioned in Verse 3, <i>In the tenth day of this month they shall take to them every man a lamb</i>, applied only to the paschal offering in Egypt, He therefore preceded it again by saying, <i>Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel</i>, the Israel of that time.</i><br>According to the Midrashic interpretation,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 25b. The process involved witnesses who saw the appearance of the new moon. After their testimony was heard and examined, the chief of the Court then said, “It is hallowed!” and all the people answered him, “It is hallowed! It is hallowed!” This established that day as being the first of the month, and the occurrence of all festivals of that month were accordingly determined. With the Great Court or Sanhedrin no longer functioning in the Land of Israel, the first of the month is established only by calculating when the new moon appears. For a more detailed discussion of this important topic, see my translation of “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 159-163.</i> <i>lachem</i> (unto you) [in the verse, <i>This month shall be unto you</i>], means that “the Sanctification of the New Moon”<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 25b. The process involved witnesses who saw the appearance of the new moon. After their testimony was heard and examined, the chief of the Court then said, “It is hallowed!” and all the people answered him, “It is hallowed! It is hallowed!” This established that day as being the first of the month, and the occurrence of all festivals of that month were accordingly determined. With the Great Court or Sanhedrin no longer functioning in the Land of Israel, the first of the month is established only by calculating when the new moon appears. For a more detailed discussion of this important topic, see my translation of “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 159-163.</i> is to be performed only by a Court of experts [as Moses and Aaron were]. And this is the reason it does not say at the beginning [of Verse 2], <i>Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel</i>, since “the Sanctification of the New Moon” can be performed only by Moses and Aaron and their like.<br>Now the purport of the expression, <i>This month shall be unto you the beginning of months</i>, is that Israel is to count this as the first of the months, and from it they are to count all months — second, third, etc., until a year of twelve months is completed — in order that there be through this enumeration a remembrance of the great miracle, [i.e., the exodus from Egypt, which occurred in the first month]. Whenever we will mention the months, the miracle will be remembered.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Thus everytime a person says, for example, “the third month,” he implies that it is the third in the order of the months which begins with Nisan, when the exodus occurred.</i> It is for this reason that the months have no individual names in the Torah. Instead, Scripture says: <i>In the third month;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:1.</i> <i>And it came to pass in the second year, in the second month … that the cloud was taken up from over the Tabernacle of the Testimony;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:11.</i> <i>And in the seventh month, on the first day of the month</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:1.</i> and so in all cases. Just as in counting the weekdays we always remember the Sabbath-day since the weekdays have no specific name of their own, but instead are called “one day in the Sabbath,” “the second day in the Sabbath,” as I will explain,<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:8.</i> so we remember the exodus from Egypt in our counting “the first month,” “the second month,” “the third month,” etc., to our redemption.<br>This order of the counting of the months is not in regard to the years, for the beginning of our years is from Tishri, [the seventh month], as it is written, <i>And the feast of ingathering at the turn of the year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:22. Now the feast of ingathering is in the seventh month (Leviticus 23:39) and yet Scripture calls it here <i>at the turn of the year</i>, which means the beginning of the new year. Thus we learn that Tishri is the beginning of the year, although in the order of the counting of the months it is the seventh month.</i> and it is further written, <i>And the feast of ingathering, at the end of the year</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:16.</i> If so, when we call the month of Nisan the first of the months and Tishri the seventh, the meaning thereof is “the first [month] to the redemption” and “the seventh month” thereto. This then is the intent of the expression, <i>it shall be the first month to you</i>, meaning that it is not the first in regard to the year but it is the first “to you,” i.e., that it be called “the first” for the purpose of remembering our redemption.<br>Our Rabbis have already mentioned this matter when saying,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Rosh Hashanah I, 2.</i> “The names of the months came up with us from Babylon,” since at first we had no names for the months. The reason for this [adoption of the names of the months when our ancestors returned from Babylon to build the Second Temple], was that at first their reckoning was a memorial to the exodus from Egypt, but when we came up from Babylon, and the words of Scripture were fulfilled — <i>And it shall no more be said: As the Eternal liveth, that brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, but: As the Eternal liveth that brought up and that led the children of Israel from the land of the north</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 16:14-15. The expression <i>and that led</i> is found <i>ibid.</i>, 23:8.</i> — from then on we began to call the months by the names they were called in the land of Babylon. We are thus reminded that there we stayed [during our exile] and from there, blessed G-d brought us up [to our Land].<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">From Ramban’s “Sermon on Rosh Hashanah,” where he discussed the same topic (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. I, p. 215), it is crystal clear that the author’s intent here was not that the memorial of the redemption from Babylon will thrust aside the memorial of the redemption from Egypt. Rather, the one of Babylon will be added to that of Egypt, so that the names of the months will be reminiscent of the two redemptions together. See Note 114 further, for example. Joseph Albo’s position in his book Ikkarim (Roots), III, 16, that Ramban’s intent here was that after the return from the Babylonian exile, the first memorial was to give way altogether to the second, is thus not correct. For further discussion of this problem see the note in my Hebrew commentary Vol. II, p. 520.</i> These names — Nisan, Iyar, and the others — are Persian names and are to be found only in the books of the prophets of the Babylonian era<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">See Zechariah 1:7, etc.; Ezra 6:15; Nehemiah 1:1.</i> and in the Scroll of Esther.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 3:7, etc.</i> It is for this reason that Scripture says, <i>In the first month, which is the month of Nisan</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> Thus both memorials are mentioned simultaneously: <i>the first month</i> to our redemption from Egypt, <i>which is the month of Nisan</i>, a name which is reminiscent of our Babylonian exile from which we have also been redeemed.</i> just as it says, <i>they cast ‘pur,’ that is, the lot</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> In this case too Scripture explains the Persian word <i>pur</i> as meaning lot, just as it explained the name Nisan as being “the first month.”</i> To this day, people of Persia and Media use these names of the months — Nisan, Tishri, and the others — as we do. Thus through the names of the months we remember our second redemption even as we had done until then with regard to the first one.

Verse 3

THEY SHALL TAKE TO THEM EVERY MAN A LAMB, ACCORDING TO THEIR FATHERS’ HOUSES. The reason for this commandment is that the constellation of Aries (the Ram) is at the height of its power in the month of Nisan, it being the sign of the zodiac which ascends the heavens.<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">There are twelve signs or constellations in the zodiac, an imaginary belt encircling the heavens, revolving around the sun. Each month, another constellation begins the procession of the signs in their course around the heavens. The Ram is the first sign of the zodiac in the month of Nisan.</i> Therefore He commanded us to slaughter the sheep and to eat it in order to inform us that it was not by the power of that constellation that we went out from Egypt, but by decree of the Supreme One. And according to the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">In translating the words of Moses to Pharaoh, <i>Lo, if we sacrifice the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes</i>, etc., (above, 8:22), Onkelos translated: “if we sacrifice that which the Egyptians worship.” In his Moreh Nebuchim (III, 46), Rambam also writes: “Scripture tells us, according to the version of Onkelos, that the Egyptians worshipped Aries, etc.”</i> that the Egyptians worshipped it as a deity, He has all the more informed us through this that He subdued their gods and their powers at the height of their ascendancy. And thus the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 16:2.</i> “<i>Take you lambs and slaughter</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 21.</i> the gods of Egypt.”

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

BEIN HA’ARBAYIM’ (AT EVENTIDE). “The period beginning at the sixth hour and onward, [counted from the beginning of the day, which in Torah-law is always divided into twelve hours], is called <i>bein ha’arbayim</i> (at eventide), because the sun inclines in the direction of its setting there to become darkened. It appears to me that the expression <i>bein ha’arbayim</i> denotes those hours which are between the beginning of the darkening of the day and the final darkening at night. The darkening of the day is at the beginning of the seventh hour of the day, from the time <i>the shadows of the evening are stretched out</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 6:4.</i> and the darkening of the night is at the beginning of the night. The word <i>erev</i> (night) is an expression of gloom and darkness, just as in the verse, <i>All joy is ‘arbah’</i> (<i>darkened</i>).”<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:11.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra refuted [this explanation of Rashi] by pointing to the verse which says, <i>And when Aaron lighteth the lamps ‘bein ha’arbayim’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 30:8.</i> [‘There is no doubt that he lights the lamps at sundown”], as it is written there, <i>Aaron and his sons shall set it in order from evening to morning</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:21.</i> [Thus it proves that <i>bein ha’arbayim</i> does not begin with the seventh hour of the day as Rashi would have it, but at sundown near night.] Besides, the verse regarding the paschal offering itself states: <i>There thou shalt sacrifice the Passover-offering at even, at the going down of the sun, at the time thou camest forth out of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:6.</i> and “the going down of the sun” occurs at sunset. [How then could Rashi explain <i>bein ha’arbayim</i> mentioned here as commencing at the seventh hour of the day?]<br>But this is no refutation of the Rabbi’s [Rashi’s] explanation. Our Rabbis have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 9a.</i> that the meaning of the verse is as follows: “<i>At even</i>, you slaughter [the Passover-offering]; <i>at the going down of the sun</i>, you eat it; <i>at the time thou camest forth out of Egypt</i>, [i.e., in the morning of the fifteenth day of Nisan, it becomes <i>nothar</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Literally, “left over.” Portions of sacrifices left over after the prescribed time within which they are to be eaten must be burnt. See “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 103-4. Now since the Passover-offering is to be eaten only on the night of the fifteenth day, whatever is left by the morning of that day is to be burnt. The actual burning, however, takes place on the morning of the sixteenth day, since it is not permissible to burn <i>nothar</i> on a Festival day.</i> and you burn it.” The Rabbi [Rashi] has already so commented [in his commentary to Deuteronomy 16:6].<br>The correct interpretation on this matter appears to me to be that the night is called <i>erev</i>, as it is said, <i>‘ba’erev’ ye shall eat unleavened bread</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> and this is at night, as it clearly states, <i>And they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> Similarly, <i>And there was ‘erev’ and there was morning</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:5.</i> means the beginning of night when the stars do come forth. The same applies to the verse, <i>In the twilight, ‘ba’erev’ of the day, in the blackness of night and the darkness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 7:9.</i> [where the word <i>ba’erev</i>, coming after “the twilight,” must signify the night]. Now the end of the day is also called <i>erev</i>, as the verses indicate: <i>And the two angels came to Sodom ‘ba’erev,’ and Lot sat in the gate of Sodom;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:1. In view of the fact that Lot surely did not sit in the gate at night, <i>ba’erev</i> must mean at the end of the day.</i> <i>And it came to pass ‘ba’erev’ that the quails came up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 16:13.</i> and the quails did not come at night.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12: <i>At eventide ye shall eat flesh</i>. This clearly indicates that the quails came before the night. The word <i>ba’erev</i> in the verse, <i>And it came to pass ‘ba’erev’ that the quails came up</i>, must therefore mean at the end of the day.</i> There are many other such cases.<br>It is further written: <i>‘Erev,’ and morning, and at noonday, I will sigh and moan</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 55:18.</i> Now these three periods include the whole day [of twenty-four hours. Therefore, if we interpret <i>erev</i> as meaning actual night, the hours from noonday to night will be missing here. We must] thus conclude that [the period] immediately after noonday is called <i>erev</i>, [which lasts from the latter part of the day till morning. Thus the verse encompasses the whole day of twenty-four hours].<br>Morning is so called from sunrise and thence onward as long as the sun remains in the east. This period lasts four hours, just as the Rabbis testified<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">In Tractate Eduyoth 6:1. This testimony is attributed to Rabbi Yehudah ben Baba.</i> that the morning Daily Whole-offering [for the entire congregation of Israel] may be offered in the [first] four hours of the day [but not later].<br>After morning, the time is called <i>tzohorayim</i> (noonday), just as it is said, <i>from morning until ‘tzohorayim’</i> (<i>noon</i>).<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 18:26.</i> It consists of two hours: the fifth and the sixth hours of the day. The word <i>tzohorayim</i> is of the root ‘<i>tzohar</i>’ (<i>A light</i>) <i>shalt thou make to the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 6:16.</i> and implies brightness. It is written in the plural [<i>tzohorayim</i>] because it is the two [brightest parts of the day] which, so to speak, make two <i>tzohorayim</i>. It may be that it is written in the plural because light is then disseminated on all sides. In the morning the light is centered in the east, and towards evening it is in the west, but in the middle of the day when it is high in the sky, it gives light on all sides.<br>When <i>tzohorayim</i> (noonday) passes and the sun departs from shining upon two sides, the time of the day is called <i>arbayim</i> — [from the root <i>erev</i> (darkness)] - because the sun has darkened from [its state of shining on] those two sides. This period [of <i>arbayim</i>] lasts as long as the sun shines in the sky [and is permissible for the slaughtering of the Passover-offering].
