How then is it possible that Abraham was one hundred years old at the birth of Isaac (Genesis 21:5) if he was seventy-five years old when he left Haran, and the covenant took place long after his departure from Haran?</i> We must therefore explain the case satisfactorily in accordance with what we have been taught in the Seder Olam:<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Order of the World.” This is an historical chronicle of events from the time of creation to the destruction of the Second Temple. It was authored by Rabbi Yosei ben Chalafta, a disciple of Rabbi Akiba. The text quoted here is found in Chapter 1.</i> “Our father Abraham was seventy years old when G-d spoke to him at the ‘covenant between the parts,’ as it is said, <i>And it came to pass at the end of four hundred and thirty years … that all the hosts of the Eternal went out from the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 41 here. “And you cannot find four hundred and thirty years unless the “covenant between the parts” took place thirty years before the birth of Isaac” (Yaakov Emden, in his commentary on the Seder Olam).</i> Then he returned to Haran and stayed there five years, as it is said, <i>And Abram was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 12:4.</i> The sense of the verse then is to state that when Abraham finally left Haran, his native land, never to return again to his father’s house, he was seventy-five years old.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">And the “covenant between the parts” accordingly took place five years before his final departure from Haran, since from the time of the covenant to the birth of Isaac, as Rashi stated, thirty years had passed.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is my opinion that G-d said to Abraham, “<i>Know of a surety that</i> before I give you this land, <i>thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs</i> for a long time — <i>four hundred years</i>.” He did not care to mention the additional thirty years<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus introduced a new explanation to help solve the problem, which was as follows: Since in Genesis 15:13, the length of the exile was foretold to be four hundred years, how is it that Scripture mentions here in Verse 40 an additional thirty years? Rashi answered that the four-hundred year period represents the time from Isaac’s birth till the exodus, and the additional thirty years represent the preceding years that elapsed between “the covenant between the parts” and the birth of Isaac. Accordingly, we were forced to say that the covenant took place five years before Abraham’s final departure from Haran. Ramban suggests that the intent of the verse in Genesis 15:13 is also four hundred and thirty years, for although the additional thirty years are not clearly written in the verse, they are nevertheless alluded to, as is explained further on. In his commentary on the following verse, Ramban will revert to this theme for further elucidation.</i> to him [i.e., Abraham], because He told him further on, <i>And in the fourth generation they shall come back hither</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> thereby informing him that they will not come back immediately at the end of four hundred years until the fourth generation when the sin of the Amorite will be full.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> Thus He alluded to these thirty years, for the Israelites’ staying in the desert for forty years was not on account of the sin of the Amorite not yet being full, [since the four hundred and thirty years were completed at the time of the exodus; their stay in the desert was on account of their own misdeeds].<br>Accordingly, the purport of the verse [before us] is as follows: Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in Egypt was until four hundred and thirty years, since they lived there in order to fulfill the period of time set [for Abraham’s seed] to live in a land that is not theirs. Thus Scripture informed us that now when they went forth from Egypt, the exile decreed upon them was completed. He brought them forth from servitude to [complete] freedom, and it was not that He took them out from Egypt and they were yet to be strangers in a land not their own. Now because He has already mentioned this matter and informed us thereof [in the section of the “covenant between the parts”], there was no need to prolong it [here], for this verse [here] is intended only to inform us of the thirty years that were added to [the four hundred years mentioned specifically to Abraham]. This is why He says it briefly, i.e., that in Egypt were completed the four hundred years mentioned to their father Abraham and known to them, and an additional thirty years. Then He reverts and says, <i>And it came to pass at the end of four hundred and thirty years</i><sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 41.</i> of their exile, <i>they went out from the land of Egypt</i> to perpetual freedom.<br>A similar case is the verse, <i>And the days in which we came from Kadesh — barnea, until we were come over the brook Zered were thirty and eight years</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 2:14.</i> This is to complete the reckoning. The journey from Kadesh–barnea to the brook Zered did not take thirty-eight years. Instead, they abode in Kadesh many years,<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:46.</i> and then they journeyed from there and turned back by the way to the Red Sea,<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:1.</i> and in the thirty-eighth year they went over the brook Zered. The purport of the verse is thus: <i>and the days in which we came from Kadesh-barnea, until we were come over the brook Zered were</i> until <i>thirty and eight years</i> had passed. Similarly: <i>Happy is he that waiteth, and cometh to the thousand three hundred and five and thirty days</i><sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 12:12.</i> means [happy is he who waits and reaches] the end of those days, not the days themselves.

Verse 41



Verse 42

IT WAS A NIGHT OF WATCHING UNTO THE ETERNAL FOR BRINGING THEM OUT FROM THE LAND OF EGYPT. The verse is stating that from the time He decreed the exile upon them, He observed the matter that He bring them out on that night once the end had come, for <i>I will hasten it in its time</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:22.</i> It may be that the verse, <i>It was a night of watching unto the Eternal</i>, means that He was watching and looking forward to the night when He would bring them out from the land of Egypt, for the Holy One, blessed be He, looked forward to the time when they would merit to be brought out therefrom.<br>Now if we are to say [as Rashi did, quoted in the commentary on Verse 40], that the [period referred to in] the verse, <i>that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13. <i>And they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them four hundred years</i>.</i> begins from the time that Abraham had seed, and that the reckoning [of the four hundred and thirty years] begins from the birth of Isaac, you will find that they stayed in Egypt two hundred and forty years, according to the explanation we mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Thus: Isaac was sixty years old when Jacob and Esau were born (Genesis 25:26). When he stood before Pharaoh, Jacob was one hundred and thirty years old (<i>ibid.</i>, 47:9). We thus have one hundred and ninety years since the birth of Isaac. Deduct them from the sum of four hundred and thirty, and you have two hundred and forty years remaining for the stay in Egypt.</i> But this too in my opinion is not correct according to the plain meaning of Scripture, since all the days of Abraham cannot be counted as exile with respect to his seed.<br>The correct interpretation is that He was saying to Abraham “<i>that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs … four hundred years</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13. <i>And they shall serve them, and they shall afflict them four hundred years</i>.</i> from this day on.”<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., from the time of the “covenant between the parts.” According to Ramban, who is now following the simple meaning of Scripture, this covenant took place after Abram had left Haran when he was seventy-five years old or thereabout. Thus at the time of the covenant, Abraham was about eighty years old, and not seventy, as we reasoned before according to Rashi. (See beginning of Verse 40.)</i> The purport thereof was to tell him: “your children will not immediately inherit this land which I give them, but instead they will be strangers like you were, in a land not theirs [for a period of] four hundred years and more. They will not return here till the fourth generation<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> when four hundred and thirty years will be completed.” But if so, then their stay in Egypt lasted about two hundred and twenty years or thereabouts.<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ramban’s interpretation, Abraham was about eighty years old at the time of the covenant. (See Note above). It was twenty years from then until Isaac’s birth, since Scripture states that Abraham was one hundred years old when Isaac was born. Isaac was sixty years old when Jacob was born, and when Jacob stood before Pharaoh, he was one hundred and thirty. Thus we have two hundred and ten years. Deduct them from four hundred and thirty, and you are left with two hundred and twenty, which is the length of time they stayed in Egypt.</i> Now if the numerical value of the word <i>‘r’du’</i> (<i>get you down</i>) <i>thither</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 42:2. These were Jacob’s words to his sons upon sending them to buy food in Egypt. He did not use the word <i>l’chu</i> (go you), but <i>r’du (get you down)</i>, because the numerical value of the word <i>r’du</i> is two hundred and ten. There was thus an allusion here to the time the Israelites would stay in Egypt.</i> [which is two hundred and ten], be an established tradition in Israel, it is possible that [Jacob, by using the word <i>r’du</i>], alluded to those who arrived in Egypt that after Jacob’s death they would stay there two hundred and ten years. With the seventeen years that Jacob lived in the land of Egypt,<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 47:28.</i> their stay altogether totalled two hundred and twenty-seven years.<br>And I have already mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 15:13 (in Vol. I, <i>Seder Lech Lecha</i>, p. 203).</i> the explanation of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra that the expression, <i>that thy seed shall be a stranger</i>, means “in servitude and affliction until the end of a four-hundred year period commencing from this day of the covenant.” And Ibn Ezra further said that the thirty additional years [mentioned here in Verses 40-41] represent the time that elapsed between Abraham’s departure from his country<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., his native country, Ur of the Chaldees. From there he went with his father to Haran, where they stayed five years, and then Abraham left for the land of Canaan. He was then seventy-five years old. Twenty-five years later when Isaac was born, the thirty year period, commencing from the time he left Ur of the Chaldees, was thus completed (Ibn Ezra).</i> [and the day of the covenant]. Accordingly, the explanation of the verse here is as follows: “<i>Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in Egypt</i> until the end of the period when they and their ancestors were strangers in a land not theirs, <i>was four hundred and thirty years</i>.”<br>I maintain further that the most lucid explanation of all is that we say that the decree of the four-hundred year period, [as mentioned in Genesis 15:13], is to be reckoned from that day [of the “covenant between the parts],” as we have mentioned, and these thirty additional years — [in Verses 40-41 here] — were due to the sin of that generation. If exile and affliction are decreed upon a person for a year or two because of his sin and he will fully continue to add to his transgressions, exile and visitation of seven times<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 26:28.</i> the original magnitude will be his lot; his first punishment is no guarantee against his being punished for the additional sin he committed. Now it had been decreed upon Abraham that his children would be strangers in a land not their own [for a period of] four hundred years, and that they will not return until the fourth generation, <i>for the iniquity of the Amorite is not yet full</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> Abraham was given no assurance [concerning the precise ending of the exile], except in the promise, <i>And afterward they will come out with great substance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:14.</i> and that [“afterward”] could be immediately [after the four-hundred year period] or some subsequent time. Even that promise was given conditionally, as He said, <i>And also that nation, whom they shall serve, will I judge; and afterward shall they come out with great substance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:14.</i> meaning that He will bring them to judgment to determine whether they did to Israel in accordance with their deeds and as was decreed upon them.<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">For fuller explanation of this point, see Vol. I, pp. 204-205.</i> Besides, no assurance is immune to annulment because of subsequent sin unless it is accompanied by an oath. And it is a known fact that the Israelites in Egypt were wicked and exceeding sinners, having also done away with circumcision, as it is written, <i>And they rebelled against Me, and would not hearken unto Me; they did not every man cast away the detestable things of their eyes, neither did they forsake the idols of Egypt; then I said I would pour out My fury upon them in the midst of the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:8.</i> Again it says, <i>And put away the gods which your fathers served beyond the River, and in Egypt, and serve ye the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:14.</i> It was for this reason that He prolonged their exile for thirty years.<br>In fact, it should have been prolonged even more, but on account of their cries and many prayers, [it was shortened to thirty years]. This is the sense of the verses: <i>And the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:23.</i> <i>And G-d heard their groaning</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> <i>And now, behold, the cry of the children of Israel is come unto Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 3:9.</i> And it further states, <i>And we cried unto the Eternal, the G-d of our fathers, and the Eternal heard our voice, and saw our affliction, and our toil, and our oppression</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 26:7.</i> since they did not deserve to be redeemed on account of the end [of the four-hundred year period], but only because He accepted their cry and their groaning on account of the great agony they were in, as I have explained in <i>Seder V’eileh Shemoth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:25.</i> Why should the earlier scholars — [i.e., Rashi and Ibn Ezra] — find it difficult to explain that their exile was prolonged after the end [of the four-hundred year period] by thirty years, when on account of the sin of the spies their stay in the wilderness was later prolonged forty years!<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:34.</i> Those forty years were indeed an affliction to them, as Scripture states, <i>And thou shalt remember all the way which the Eternal thy G-d hath led thee these forty years in the wilderness, that He might afflict thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:2.</i> And it further says, <i>And He afflicted thee, and suffered thee to hunger</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> Thus they were subject [in the wilderness] to complete exile in a land given over to <i>serpents, fiery serpents, and scorpions</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> and the promise, <i>And in the fourth generation they shall come back hither</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> was not fulfilled in them, since during those forty years, that generation surely passed away after the [fifth] generation was already born. Thus the sins caused all delays.<br>It is possible that this [delay of the thirty years] was on account of the children of Ephraim who went out [from the land of Egypt] thirty years before the coming of Moses our teacher, and as our Rabbis have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 92b.</i> They reckoned [the end of the four-hundred year period from the time it was declared to Abraham], and they made no error, <i>but his own iniquities shall ensnare the wicked</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 5:22. In other words, the children of Ephraim were accurate in their reckoning. However, they failed to know that on account of the sins of the generation, thirty years had been added to the length of the bondage.</i> And may the Holy One, blessed be He, forgive us all sin and error.
THIS SAME NIGHT IS A NIGHT OF WATCHING UNTO THE ETERNAL FOR ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL THROUGHOUT THEIR GENERATIONS. The intent of this is “that this night set aside by G-d to bring Israel out of Egypt is <i>unto the Eternal</i>. That is to say, it is to be sanctified to His Name. [It is] <i>a night of watching for all the children of Israel throughout their generations</i>, meaning that they are to observe it by worshipping Him through the eating of the Passover-offering, the remembering of the miracles, and the reciting of praise and thanksgiving to His Name,” just as He said, <i>And thou shalt keep this ordinance</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 13:10. The Hebrew <i>v’shamarta</i> (<i>and thou shalt keep</i>) is of the same root as <i>shimurim</i> (<i>watching</i>) here.</i> And He further said, <i>Observe the month of Aviv, and keep the Passover</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:1. Here too the word <i>shamor</i> (<i>observe</i>) is of the same root as <i>shimurim</i> in the verse before us. It thus proves that <i>leil shimurim</i> (<i>a night of watching</i>) means “a night of observance of the Passover service.”</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the intent of the expression, <i>It was a night of watching unto the Eternal</i>, is that G-d watched the Israelites and did not suffer the destroyer to come into their homes. This is not correct, since Scripture continues to state, <i>It was a night of watching… for bringing them out from the land of Egypt</i>.

Verse 43

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES AND AARON: THIS IS THE ORDINANCE OF THE PASSOVER. “This chapter was related to them on the fourteenth day of Nisan.” Thus the language of Rashi. This is correct, since at the end of this chapter it is written, <i>Thus did all the children of Israel, as the Eternal hath commanded</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 50.</i> attesting concerning them that they and their servants were circumcised, [as this is a prerequisite for eating the Passover-offering].<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 44 and 48.</i> But if so, Scripture should have logically mentioned this chapter before the section, <i>And it came to pass at midnight</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 29.</i> But the reason [<i>the section of the ordinance of the Passover</i> is placed here] is as follows: The chapter of <i>This month shall be unto you the beginning of months</i><sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> was said on the first of the month.<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 6b.</i> Immediately on that day, Moses fulfilled his mission, [as it states], <i>Then Moses called for all the elders of Israel, and said unto them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 21.</i> meaning that he commanded them concerning <i>the ordinance of the Passover</i> [mentioned here], and he assured them that they will be redeemed on the night of the fifteenth day [of Nisan]. They believed, <i>and the people bowed the head and worshipped</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> To this account Scripture adjoined the section, <i>And it came to pass at midnight</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 29.</i> in order to state that He fulfilled the promise He made to them. On finishing this section, Scripture then reverts to the first theme in order to complete the ordinance of the Passover.<br>This chapter adds many commandments [concerning the Passover-offering]: the prohibitions of an alien or an uncircumcised Israelite eating thereof, the prohibitions of removing the flesh thereof from where it is eaten and of breaking any of its bones, and the law of the Passover-offering of a proselyte. These commandments applied immediately and for all generations.<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Unlike certain other laws which applied only to the Passover-offering in Egypt. (See Ramban above, Verse 24 and Note 267).</i> Then Scripture completed the section by saying that the children of Israel did all this; <i>as G-d commanded… so did they</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 50.</i> It uses the expression, <i>all the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 50.</i> in order to explain that there was not one person who transgressed the command of G-d concerning all these matters [mentioned here in the section beginning, <i>This is the ordinance of the Passover</i>], as well as all He commanded regarding the laws of the Passover mentioned in the sections above.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that this chapter dealing with the Passover of the generations, [as distinguished from the Passover of Egypt], was said <i>after</i> the Passover of Egypt, and the verse, <i>Thus did all the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 50.</i> refers to the Passover in the wilderness, which they observed in the second year after the exodus.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 9:1.</i> [Although it should logically precede the Passover in the wilderness, according to Ibn Ezra] it is written here because of the general commandment [on the Passover here], the case being similar [to that of the jar of manna which Aaron was to put up before the Testimony in the Tabernacle, of which Scripture says], <i>And Aaron laid it up before the Testimony, for a charge</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 16:34.</i> [This account should logically follow that of the building of the Tabernacle, but instead it was mentioned in the chapter dealing with the manna in order to complete the subject.]<br>This opinion [of Ibn Ezra here] is a mistake. The commandments in all these chapters deal only with the Passover of Egypt and the Passovers which they were to observe in the Land of Israel, as it is said above, <i>And it shall come to pass, when ye be come to the Land</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 25.</i> The Passover in the wilderness, however, was a commandment only for that particular time.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., only for the second year after the exodus. During all other years in which they were in the wilderness, they did not sacrifice the Passover-offering (see Joshua 5:5), although the other laws of the Passover were of course, observed.</i>
THERE SHALL NO ‘BEN NEICHAR’ (ALIEN) EAT THEREOF. “This means one whose actions are estranged from his Heavenly Father, and applies both to a non-Israelite and an Israelite.”<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">In our Rashi: “an apostate Israelite.”</i> Thus the language of Rashi quoting from the Mechilta.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse before us.</i> The verse of course is needed only for the case of an [apostate] Israelite. And so did Onkelos translate: “<i>There shall no ‘ben neichar’ eat thereof</i>, i.e, any Israelite who has become an apostate,” meaning he has estranged himself from his brethren and from his Heavenly Father through his evil deeds.<br>This is the word <i>neichar</i>, mentioned by the Sages in all places, which means estranged, and the purport thereof is <i>m’shumad</i>, one who is a known [opponent to the Torah]. The usage of the word is similar to the Aramaic expression, <i>‘ve’isht’moda’</i> (<i>And</i>) <i>Joseph</i> (<i>knew</i>) <i>his brethren, but they ‘isht’modei’</i> (<i>knew</i>) <i>him not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 42:8.</i> In the case of the word <i>m’shumad</i>, it is missing the letter <i>ayin</i>, just as it is absorbed in many [Aramaic] words: <i>midam</i> (anything) in place of <i>mida’am; dor kati</i> in place of <i>dor katia</i> (a chopped generation),<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 10b.</i> <i>baki</i> in place of <i>b’kia</i> (expert).<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 5b.</i>

Verse 44



Verse 45

TOSHAV’ (A SOJOURNER) ‘V’SACHIR’ (AND A HIRED SERVANT) SHALL NOT EAT THEREOF. “<i>Toshav</i> is a resident non-Israelite [who has foresworn idolatry, but has not as yet been fully converted to Judaism]. A <i>‘sachir’</i> is a non-Israelite. But why should Scripture mention all these? They are uncircumcised, [and an uncircumcised person may not eat of the Passover-offering]! However, it refers to a circumcised Arabian or a circumcised Gibeonite.”<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">“I might think that since they are circumcised, they are qualified to partake of the Passover-offering. Scripture therefore says, <i>A ‘toshav’ and a ‘sachir’ shall not eat thereof</i>” (Mechilta here).</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>I do not know why the Rabbi [Rashi] wrote down matters which are rejected in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 71a.</i> The Rabbis have objected to this explanation [that the verse refers to a circumcised Arabian or a circumcised Gibeonite], asking: “Are these considered circumcised?! Have we not been taught that he who vows not to have benefit from the uncircumcised is permitted to have benefit from the uncircumcised of Israel, but not from the circumcised of other nations, as it is written, <i>For all the nations are uncircumcised, but all the house of Israel are uncircumcised in the heart?”</i><sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 9:25. Thus it is clear that a circumcised Arabian, etc., is considered uncircumcised, and no special verse is needed to exclude him from eating the Passover-offering, as Rashi interpreted.</i> Instead, the Rabbis [there in the Gemara]<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 71a.</i> explained the verse as referring to a proselyte who was circumcised but who has not yet undergone immersion.<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">For a proselyte to be fully accepted into the Jewish fold, he must undergo both circumcision, and immersion in a body of water valid for that purpose. The verse before us thus teaches that the proselyte who underwent the rite of circumcision alone is still forbidden to eat the Passover-offering, notwithstanding the fact that he is already circumcised and has begun his entry into the faith.</i>

Verse 46



Verse 47



Verse 48



Verse 49



Verse 50



Verse 51

AND IT CAME TO PASS THE SELFSAME DAY THE ETERNAL DID BRING THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT. Since Scripture said above, <i>It was a night of watching unto the Eternal for bringing them out of the land of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 42.</i> it reverted and explained that they did not go out at all of the land then, but that Pharaoh gave them permission [at night] to go out, and thus they became free men. Instead, it was in the glare of full daylight that they went out from all the borders of Egypt with all <i>their hosts</i> — the hosts of women and <i>the mixed multitude</i><sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 38.</i> that attached themselves to them.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the purport of the verse as follows: “<i>And it came to pass the selfsame day</i> that <i>the Eternal did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt</i> that He spoke to Moses, saying, <i>Sanctify unto Me</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 13:2. Thus according to Ibn Ezra, the verse before us is to be joined to the following chapter.</i>

Chapter 13



Verse 1



Verse 2

SANCTIFY UNTO ME. This means that they are to consecrate the firstborn at once so that the commandment be applicable in the wilderness. This chapter adds many commandments: that they remember the day [when they left Egypt] and that the month was Aviv,<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 3-4.</i> and that they keep <i>this ordinance in its season</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> This is an allusion to the intercalation [of an extra month] in the lunar year,<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">A lunar year — i.e., twelve lunar months — totals 354 days, 8 hours, 48 minutes and 36 seconds, as opposed to the solar year, which consists of 365 days, 6 hours and 48 seconds (Mishneh Torah, Z’manim, Hilchoth Kiddush Hachodesh, 9:2). There is a difference of nearly eleven days, and in order to exclude the possibility of the Passover being shifted from the spring, it is therefore necessary to interpolate an additional month about once every three years.</i> since we are to observe the Passover only in the month of Aviv, [which is the spring]. On the subject of leavened bread, this chapter adds: <i>Neither shall there be leaven seen with thee, in all thy borders</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> At the conclusion, it adds the commandment of the frontlets.<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND IT SHALL BE WHEN THE ETERNAL SHALL BRING THEE INTO THE LAND OF THE CANAANITE, AND THE HITTITE, AND THE AMORITE, AND THE HIVITE, AND THE JEBUSITE. “Although it enumerates here only five peoples, all of the seven nations<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">The five nations mentioned here and the Perizzite and the Girgashite. See Ramban above, 3:8.</i> are implied. They are all included in [the generic term] Canaanite although there was one of the races which had no name other than that of Canaanite.”<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Thus under the name Canaanite, one may understand either that particularly so-called nation or any of the other six nations who, besides bearing the generic name Canaanite, were also known as Hivites, etc. In the verse before us, <i>the Canaanite</i> thus refers to the particular nation and to the two other nations, i.e., the Perizzite and the Girgashite, which are not specifically mentioned here, since they are included in the generic name Canaanite.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>It is true that they are all included in [the generic term] Canaanite, for they were all his sons.<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:15-16.</i> Therefore when Scripture says, <i>And it shall be when the Eternal shall bring thee into the land of the Canaanite</i>, it alludes to all of the seven nations, and thus everywhere does Scripture make use of the term, “the land of Canaan.” But here, [according to Rashi’s interpretation], there is no reason why Scripture should mention most of them and yet leave some of them included in the term Canaanite!<br>In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">In the Sifre mentioned further on in the text.</i> the land of these five nations mentioned here was <i>a land flowing with milk and honey</i>, but not so the land of the remaining two nations [omitted here]. Therefore He gladdened them only with this land [of the five nations]. Thus the Rabbis taught in the Sifre with respect to first-fruits:<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre, <i>Ki Thavo</i>, 300.</i> “<i>And He hath given us this land, a land flowing with milk and honey</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 26:9.</i> Just as <i>the land flowing with milk and honey</i> mentioned elsewhere, [i.e., in the verse before us], refers to the land of the five nations, so also the <i>land flowing with milk and honey</i> mentioned here [in the case of the first-fruits] means the land of the five nations. Rabbi Yosei says that first-fruits are not brought from beyond the Jordan since it is not a land flowing with milk and honey.” Thus the land of the two nations, [the Perizzite and the Girgashite], were excluded from the law of first-fruits because theirs is not a land flowing with milk and honey, and for the same reason, Rabbi Yosei also excluded the land beyond the Jordan, which belonged to the Amorite.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 32:33.</i> And the Amorite mentioned here [among the five nations whose land was flowing with milk and honey], is the Amorite who lived in the Land of Israel proper. A text similar [to the one in the Sifre] is found in the Mechilta on this chapter.<br>It is further taught in the Sifre:<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre, <i>Shoftim</i>, 164.</i> “<i>And they</i>, [i.e., all the tribe of Levi], <i>shall have no inheritance</i><sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 18:2.</i> — this refers to the inheritance of the five nations; <i>Among their brethren</i> — this refers to the inheritance of the two nations.” The Rabbis [of the Sifre] thus separated these five nations as different, because theirs was the main land which He promised them, for that was the land flowing with milk and honey. And Rashi, in the section of <i>Shoftim V’shotrim</i>, experienced difficulty in explaining this Beraitha.<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Upon quoting the text of the Sifre — though with a different version — Rashi comments there: “I do not, however, know for certain what the Sifre means.” Rashi then proceeds to suggest his interpretation, and then mentions still another version of the text of the Sifre in question. The intent of Ramban’s words here that Rashi experienced difficulty in explaining this text in Deuteronomy 18:2 is thus clear. (See Note 209 above on the meaning of the word Beraitha.)</i><br>Now according to this opinion [that only the land of the five nations mentioned here was flowing with milk and honey], Scripture stated above, [<i>And I am come down to deliver them… and to bring them up</i>] <i>unto a good and large Land, unto a Land flowing with milk and honey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:8.</i> [and then proceeds to mention the five nations listed here as well as the Perizzite]. However, it does not add the Perizzite there on account of its land flowing with milk and honey, but because it was part of the <i>good and large Land</i>.<br>These are the six nations mentioned everywhere,<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 23:23 and 34:11.</i> for the Girgashite, [the seventh nation], emigrated of his own accord, and is not mentioned in the Torah except in the verse: <i>And He shall cast out many nations before thee, the Hittite, and the Girgashite, and the Amorite, and the Canaanite, and the Perizzite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite, seven nations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:1.</i> This is why He said <i>many nations</i>, [i.e., because all seven are mentioned]. And it is also written: <i>But thou shalt surely destroy them: the Hittite, and the Amorite, the Canaanite, and the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:17.</i> but He did not mention the Girgashite, thus alluding to the fact that he would not war against the Israelites but instead would emigrate of his own accord.

Verse 6

AND IN THE SEVENTH DAY SHALL BE A FEAST TO THE ETERNAL. This means that they are to bring their Festival-offering on the seventh day [of Passover] and are not to delay it any longer, for after that, one can no longer make amends for it. However, as far as the Festival-offering<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Upon going up to the Sanctuary on the three Festivals of Pesach, Shevuoth, and Succoth, one is obligated to bring a Festival peace-offering. (See “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 60-61). That Festival-offering should be brought on the first day of the festival and not later than on the seventh day of Passover or on <i>Shmini Atzereth</i>, which is the eighth day of Succoth. The Festival of Shevuoth, though only one day, has a similar seven-day extension period (Chagigah 9 a).</i> is concerned, amends can be made for the first day of the festival all seven days. Both [the first and seventh] days of Passover are alike with respect to the law of <i>a holy convocation</i>, as He said above, <i>And in the first day there shall be to you a holy convocation, and in the seventh day a holy convocation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:16.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8

IT IS BECAUSE OF THAT THE ETERNAL DID FOR ME. This is equivalent to saying, “It is because of that <i>which</i> the Eternal did for me when I came forth out of Egypt.” A similar case is the verse: <i>And thou shalt show them the way they are to go in</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:20.</i> [which means “<i>wherein</i> they are to go”]. There are many such cases. The father is thus stating [to his son]: “It is because of that which G-d did for me when I came forth out of Egypt that I observe this service.” It is similar to that which is stated further on: <i>Therefore I sacrifice to the Eternal all that openeth the womb</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i><br>The intent of the word <i>zeh</i> (that) [in the verse, <i>It is because of ‘that’</i>], is: “tell him ‘that’ which you yourself see, i.e., what G-d did for you when you came forth out of Egypt.” And our Rabbis have explained<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse before us.</i> that the word <i>zeh</i> (that) alludes to the unleavened bread and bitter herbs that are laid before him.<br>It is possible that the purport of the verse, <i>And thou shalt tell thy son… It is ‘ba’avur’</i> (<i>because</i>) <i>of that the Eternal did for me when I came forth out of Egypt</i>, is equivalent to the verse’s saying “such and such did G-d do unto me.” The word <i>ba’avur</i> also serves to indicate something within a subject itself, [and it does not only convey the idea: “because” of some other subject]. This is as the case in the verse, <i>‘ba’avur’ the child that was alive thou didst fast and weep</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 12:21.</i> [which means “while” the child was alive], and not “because”. [David did not fast and weep “because” the child was alive; he fasted and wept “while” the child was alive so that it should get well.]<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the purport of the verse is: “<i>Because of that</i> which I do and worship Him by eating the Passover-offering and the unleavened bread, <i>the Eternal did for me</i> wonders until He brought me forth <i>out of Egypt</i>.” But it is not correct. I will yet explain this verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 16, beginning with: “By way of Truth.” See Ramban’s discussion there which helps to explain why he did not find Ibn Ezra’s — and incidentally, also Rashi’s — explanation of the verse satisfactory. In Ramban’s opinion, the delivery from Egypt, besides having the purpose of enabling Israel to fulfill G-d’s commandments — as Rashi and Ibn Ezra so interpret the verse here — also served another very high purpose, as explained there.</i>

Verse 9

AND IT SHALL BE FOR A SIGN UNTO THEE UPON THY HAND, AND FOR A MEMORIAL BETWEEN THINE EYES, THAT THE LAW OF THE ETERNAL MAY BE IN THY MOUTH; FOR WITH A STRONG HAND HATH THE ETERNAL BROUGHT THEE OUT OF EGYPT. To be interpreted [properly, the verse must be transposed]: “And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thy hand and for a memorial between thine eyes, that with a strong hand hath the Eternal brought thee out of Egypt, that the law of the Eternal may be in thy mouth.” The meaning thereof is that you are to inscribe the exodus from Egypt [in the phylacteries] upon your hand and between your eyes, and remember it always in order that G-d’s law be in your mouth, [so that you will] observe His commandments and teachings, for He is your Master <i>Who redeemed thee out of the house of bondage</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:6.</i>

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND IT SHALL BE WHEN THE ETERNAL SHALL BRING THEE INTO THE LAND OF THE CANAANITES. This is stated because the law of that which “openeth the womb” [mentioned in Verse 12], applied only from the time they came to the Land of Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary p. 344 for correctness of this reading as based on Ramban manuscript. It is also borne out by Ramban’s statement further on in this section: “But the commandment… did not apply to the firstborn in the wilderness.”</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse, <i>Sanctify unto Me all the firstborn</i>, [mentioned in Verse 2 above] means all the firstborn living at that time. Since He redeemed them from death when He smote in the land of Egypt, He commanded [in that verse above] that they be sanctified to Him to do the work of G-d, whatever He will command them to do. He did not command them at this time concerning the redemption of the firstborn, but only after He exchanged them for the Levites and He commanded the redemption of the firstborn that were over and above the number of the Levites.<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:44-47.</i> But the commandment [as expressed in the verse, <i>Sanctify unto Me all the firstborn</i>], did not apply to the firstborn in the wilderness. Now, [in the verse before us], He commanded that when they shall come into the Land of Israel, the law should apply to the firstborn of both man and beast<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> and the firstling of an ass,<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> and then He commanded the law of their redemption for the generations.<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i>
AS HE SWORE UNTO THEE AND TO THY FATHERS. The meaning of it is that “He swore to your fathers to give it to you,” just as it is said above, <i>which He swore unto thy fathers to give thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> It may be that G-d’s word by itself is called “an oath,” for thus He said twice:<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">“And the repetition of an expression may be regarded as an oath” (Shebuoth 36 a, and see also Rashi to Genesis 8:21).</i> <i>And I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians, and to bring them up out of that land unto a good land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:8.</i> and again it says, <i>And I will bring you in unto the land concerning which I lifted up My hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:8.</i>

Verse 12

V’HA’AVARTA’ UNTO THE ETERNAL ALL THAT OPENETH THE WOMB. This is an expression of setting apart, i.e., that one is to remove the firstling from the flock and it is to be for the Eternal. Then He reverts and explains that this “setting apart” means that every first male offspring dropped by a beast, and every first offspring of an ass and every firstborn son of a man shall be the Eternal’s. But Rashi commented: “<i>And thou shalt set apart unto the Eternal all that openeth the womb</i>. Scripture is speaking of the firstborn of man.”

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

ULTOTAPHOTH’ BETWEEN THINE EYES. No affinity is known to this word. Linguists,<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Menachem ben Saruk, quoted in Rashi. See also Ibn Ezra.</i> however, associated it with the expressions: <i>‘v’hateiph’</i> (<i>And speak</i>) <i>to the south</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 21:2.</i> <i>And my word ‘titoph’</i> (<i>dropped</i>) <i>upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Job 29:22. Ramban evidently understands it: “and to them I spoke my word,” meaning “they followed my advice without question.”</i> The figurative usage thereof is based on the verse: <i>And the mountains shall drop</i> (<i>‘v’hitiphu’</i>) <i>sweet wine</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 9:13. The figurative sense of the verse is that the mountains “will speak” of sweet wine.</i> Thus the verse is saying that you should make the exodus from Egypt a sign upon your hand, and between your eyes a source for discourse distilling as the dew upon those that hear it.<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 32:2.</i> Our Rabbis, however, have called an object which lies upon the head <i>totaphoth</i>, just as they have said: “[A woman] may not go out [on the Sabbath] with a <i>totepheth</i> or head-bangles.”<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 57a.</i> Rabbi Abahu said: “What is <i>totepheth?</i> It is a forehead-band extending from ear to ear.”<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 57b.</i> Now it is the Rabbis [of the Talmud] who are the [true Hebrew] linguists, as they spoke the language and knew it and it is from them that we should accept [the explanation of the word <i>ultotaphoth</i>].<br>Now Scripture says <i>totaphoth</i> [in the plural] and not <i>totepheth</i> [in the singular] because there are many compartments in the phylacteries,<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">The phylactery of the head is divided into four vertical compartments, each compartment containing a scroll of one of the four Scriptural passages referring to this commandment. The phylactery of the arm contains one interior chamber which contains but one single scroll upon which all four sections of the Law are inscribed together. For fuller discussion of the subject, see “The Commandments,” Vol. I, p. 18-19.</i> just as we have received their form from the holy fathers<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the Sages of the Talmud, who received the true Tradition of the Torah.</i> who saw the prophets and the ancient ones up to Moses our teacher doing so.<br>Now the fundamental reason of this commandment is that we lay the script of the exodus from Egypt upon the hand and upon the head opposite the heart and the brain, which are the pivots of thought. Thus we are to inscribe [on parchment] the Scriptural sections of <i>Kadesh</i> (<i>Sanctify unto Me</i>) [Verses 1-10], and <i>V’haya ki y’viacha</i> (<i>And it shall be when the Eternal shall bring thee</i>) [Verses 11-16], and enclose them in the phylacteries because of this commandment wherein we were charged to make the exodus from Egypt for frontlets between our eyes. [We are also to inscribe and enclose in the phylacteries the sections of] <i>Sh’ma</i> (<i>Hear O Israel</i>) [Deuteronomy 6:4-9] and <i>V’haya im shamo’a</i> (<i>And it shall come to pass, if ye shall hearken</i>) [<i>ibid.</i>, 11:13-21] because we are charged to have the commandments [of the Torah] also for frontlets between our eyes, as it is written: <i>And these words, which I command thee this day, shall be upon thy heart</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:6.</i> <i>and they shall be for frontlets between thine eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> This is why we also inscribe [on parchment] these two sections — [<i>Sh’ma</i> and <i>V’haya im shamo’a</i>] — for frontlets [even though the exodus is not mentioned in them], for they contain the commandments of the Unity of G-d, the memorial of all commandments, the doctrine of retribution, which states that the consequence of disobeying the commandments is punishment and that blessings come in the wake of obedience — and the whole foundation of the faith.<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">“The whole foundation of the faith.” This may refer to the principle of the Unity of G-d which is indeed the root of faith, as Ramban describes it in Deuteronomy 6:4. However, in view of the fact that this principle has already been explicitly mentioned here by Ramban, the reference must be to some other doctrine. It is reasonable to assume that Ramban is here alluding to a point he has explained in many places — “a true principle, clearly indicated in the Torah… that in the entire scope of the Torah there are only miracles, and no nature or custom.” (See Vol. I, pp. 556-7; see also his commentary above, 6:2, and on Leviticus 26:11.) The theme appears also in his introduction to the Commentary on the Book of Job (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. I, pp. 17-19). In his “Sermon on the Perfection of the Torah,” (<i>Ibid.</i>, p. 153) as well as at the end of this <i>Seder</i>, he states clearly that “a person has no part in the Torah of Moses our teacher” unless he believes in this principle. It is thus logical to assume that “the whole foundation of the faith” mentioned here is a reference to the above principle.</i> Now of the phylactery of the arm, Scripture says, <i>And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thy hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 9.</i> which the Rabbis explained<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 36b.</i> as referring to the left arm, which is opposite the heart.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the verse, <i>It is because of ‘zeh’</i> (<i>this</i>) <i>which the Eternal did for</i> me,<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i> is similar to <i>‘zeh’</i> (<i>this</i>) <i>is my G-d, and I will glorify Him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 15:2.</i> The verse here thus states that it was because of His name and His glory that He did for us and brought us forth out of Egypt. <i>And</i> “this” <i>shall be for a sign unto thee</i> on the arm of your strength,<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 89:11.</i> just as it is written, <i>For Thou art the glory of their strength</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> Thus the sign [of the phylactery] is similar to the sign of circumcision<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:11.</i> and the Sabbath.<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:13.</i> And since all [emanations] are one perfect unity, which is alluded to in “the sign” on the arm, our ancestors have received the tradition from Moses, who received it from the mouth of the Almighty, that [all four sections of Scripture inscribed in the phylacteries, as described above], are encased in one compartment. This is something like Scripture says, <i>achothi kalah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:1. Literally, “my sister, the bride,” but here interpreted on the basis of the Hebrew roots which suggest “unity” (<i>achothi</i>, my sister — <i>echad</i>, one) and “totality” (<i>kalah</i>, bride — <i>kol</i>, all), as explained in the text. See also Vol. I, p. 292, where Ramban refers to this theme.</i> because it is united and comprised of the thirty-two paths of wisdom<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Yetzirah 1:1</i> [with which the world was created], and it is further written, <i>His left hand is under my head</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:6.</i><br>Then Scripture says, <i>And it shall be for a memorial between thine eyes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 9.</i> meaning that we are to lay them at the place of remembrance, which is between the eyes, at the beginning of the brain. It is there that remembrance begins by recalling the appearances [of persons and events] after they have passed away from us. These frontlets circle around the whole head with their straps, while the loop rests directly over the base of the brain which guards the memory. And the expression, <i>between your eyes</i>, means that they are to be placed upon the middle of the head, not towards one side. It may be that in the middle of the head, there are the roots of the eyes and from these stems the power of sight. Similarly, the verse, <i>Nor make ye any baldness between your eyes for the dead</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 14:1. See Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>, that the expression <i>between the eyes</i> means on the head adjoining the forehead. See also Rashi to Leviticus 21:5.</i> [means baldness adjoining the forehead. Thus the expression <i>between your eyes</i> mentioned here in the case of the frontlets also refers to the identical place]. It is to explain this point, [i.e., that the phylactery of the head is not to be placed between the eyes, as the literal meaning of the words might indicate, but that it is to be placed upon the middle of the head adjoining the forehead], that He reverts here [in Verse 16 and instead of using the expression, <i>and for ‘a memorial’ between your eyes</i>, as stated in Verse 9], and says <i>‘ultotaphoth’ between your eyes</i>. This is in order to explain that the commandment is not fulfilled by placing the phylactery between the eyes bottomward, but rather it is to be placed high on the head where it is to be there like <i>totaphoth</i>, [and we have seen above that the word <i>totepheth</i> was used by the Rabbis for an object which lies upon the head]. He uses the plural form [<i>totaphoth</i>, and not the singular <i>totepheth</i>], because the compartments in the phylactery of the head are many, as we have received the form by Tradition.<br>And now I shall declare to you a general principle in the reason of many commandments. Beginning with the days of Enosh<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:26. See also Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Akum, 1:1, where he traces the process of intellectual degeneration by which mankind fell into gross idolatry. Ramban primarily follows here the process of deterioration as affecting the three basic principles of faith: the existence of the Creator, His providence over the world, and the truth of prophecy. The chief purpose of the commandments of the Torah is to guard Israel against deviating from these principles.</i> when idol-worship came into existence, opinions in the matter of faith fell into error. Some people denied the root of faith by saying that the world is eternal; <i>they denied the Eternal, and said: It is not He</i><sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 5:12.</i> [Who called forth the world into existence]. Others denied His knowledge of individual matters, <i>and they say, How doth G-d know? and is there knowledge in the Most High?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 73:11.</i> Some admit His knowledge but deny the principle of providence <i>and make men as the fishes of the sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Habakkuk 1:14.</i> [believing] that G-d does not watch over them and that there is no punishment or reward for their deeds, for they say <i>the Eternal hath forsaken the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 8:12.</i> Now when G-d is pleased to bring about a change in the customary and natural order of the world for the sake of a people or an individual, then the voidance of all these [false beliefs] becomes clear to all people, since a wondrous miracle shows that the world has a G-d Who created it, and Who knows and supervises it, and Who has the power to change it. And when that wonder is previously prophesied by a prophet, another principle is further established, namely, that of the truth of prophecy, <i>that G-d doth speak with man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:28.</i> and that <i>He revealeth His counsel unto His servants the prophets</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 3:7.</i> and thereby the whole Torah is confirmed. This is why Scripture says in connection with the wonders [in Egypt]: <i>That thou</i> [Pharaoh] <i>mayest know that I am the Eternal in the midst of the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 8:18.</i> which teaches us the principle of providence, i.e., that G-d has not abandoned the world to chance, as they [the heretics] would have it; <i>That thou mayest know that the earth is the Eternal’s</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:29.</i> which informs us of the principle of creation, for everything is His since He created all out of nothing; <i>That thou mayest know that there is none like Me in all the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> which indicates His might, i.e., that He rules over everything and that there is nothing to withhold Him. The Egyptians either denied or doubted all of these [three] principles, [and the miracles confirmed their truth].<br>Accordingly, it follows that the great signs and wonders constitute <i>faithful witnesses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 8:2.</i> to the truth of the belief in the existence of the Creator and the truth of the whole Torah. And because the Holy One, blessed be He, will not make signs and wonders in every generation for the eyes of some wicked man or heretic, He therefore commanded us that we should always make a memorial or sign of that which we have seen with our eyes, and that we should transmit the matter to our children, and their children to their children, to the generations to come, and He placed great emphasis on it, as is indicated by the fact that one is liable to extinction for eating leavened bread on the Passover, and for abandoning the Passover-offering, [i.e., for not taking part in the slaughtering thereof].<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 9:13.</i> He has further required of us that we inscribe upon our arms and between our eyes all that we have seen in the way of signs and wonders, and to inscribe it yet upon the doorposts of the houses, and that we remember it by recital in the morning and evening — just as the Rabbis have said: “The recital of the benediction <i>True and firm</i>, [which follows the <i>Sh’ma</i> in the morning and which terminates with a blessing to G-d for the redemption from Egypt], is obligatory as a matter of Scriptural law because it is written, <i>That thou mayest remember the day when thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt all the days of thy life</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:3.</i> [He further required] that we make a booth every year<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 23:42.</i> and many other commandments like them which are a memorial to the exodus from Egypt. All these commandments are designed for the purpose that in all generations we should have testimonies to the wonders so that they should not be forgotten and so that the heretic should not be able to open his lips to deny the belief in [the existence of] G-d. He who buys a <i>Mezuzah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “door-post.” It is a scroll of parchment on which are written the two Scriptural portions, Deuteronomy 6:4-9 and 11:13-21, and which is fastened to the right-hand door-post.</i> for one <i>zuz</i> [a silver coin] and affixes it to his doorpost and has the proper intent of heart on its content, has already admitted the creation of the world, the Creator’s knowledge and His providence, and also his belief in prophecy as well as in all fundamental principles of the Torah, besides admitting that the mercy of the Creator is very great upon them that do His will, since He brought us forth from that bondage to freedom and to great honor on account of the merit of our fathers who delighted in the fear of His Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">See Nehemiah 1:11.</i> It is for this reason that the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 2:1.</i> “Be as heedful of a light commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">Here understood in the sense of a commandment, the fulfillment of which does not entail a great expense, just like a <i>Mezuzah</i> that can be bought for one <i>zuz</i> and affixed to the door-post.</i> as of a weighty one,” for they are all exceedingly precious and beloved, for through them a person always expresses thankfulness to his G-d.<br>And the purpose of all the commandments is that we believe in our G-d and be thankful to Him for having created us, for we know of no other reason for the first creation,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">“The first creation.” In his “Sermon on the Perfection of the Torah,” where Ramban discusses the same topic (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. I, p. 152), the text reads: “for we know of no other reason for ‘the creation of man.’” See, however, my Hebrew commentary, in the fifth edition, p. 557, where I suggest that the term “the first creation” may be a reference to the period from Adam to Abraham.</i> and G-d the Most High has no demand on the lower creatures, excepting that man should know and be thankful to G-d for having created him. The purposes of raising our voices in prayer and of the service in synagogues, as well as the merit of public prayer, is precisely this: that people should have a place wherein they assemble and express their thankfulness to G-d for having created them and supported them, and thus proclaim and say before Him, “We are your creatures.”<br>This is the intent of what the Rabbis of blessed memory have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Yalkut Shimoni, Jonah 550. See also Yerushalmi Taanith, II, 1.</i> “<i>And they cried mightily unto G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">Jonah 3:8.</i> From here you learn that prayer must be accompanied by sound. The undaunted one wins over the abashed one.”<br>Through the great open miracles, one comes to admit the hidden miracles which constitute the foundation of the whole Torah, for no one can have a part in the Torah of Moses our teacher unless he believes that all our words and our events, [as dictated in the Torah], are miraculous in scope, there being no natural or customary way of the world in them, whether affecting the public or the individual. Instead, if a person observes the commandments, His reward will bring him success, and if he violates them, His punishment will cause his extinction. It is all by decree of the Most High, as I have already mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 215-216 and 556-558.</i> The hidden miracles done to the public come to be known as is mentioned in the assurances of the Torah on the subject of the blessings and imprecations,<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:3-46; Deuteronomy 28:1-68.</i> as the verse says: <i>And all the nations shall say: Wherefore hath the Eternal done thus unto this land? … Then men shall say: Because they forsook the covenant of the Eternal, the G-d of their fathers</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:23-4.</i> Thus it will become known to all nations that their punishment came from G-d. And of the fulfillment of the commandments it says, <i>And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the Eternal is called upon thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:10.</i> I will yet explain this, with the help of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:11.</i><br>Beshalach

Verse 17

AND G-D LED THEM NOT BY THE WAY OF THE LAND OF THE PHILISTINES BECAUSE<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">“Because.” Thus Rashi and Ibn Ezra render the Hebrew word <i>ki</i>, as will be explained. Ramban will suggest further on in the text that the word <i>ki</i> should be understood here as “although.” The J.P.S. translation follows Ramban’s explanation.</i> IT WAS NEAR. “It would therefore be easy [for the Israelites] to return to Egypt by the same route. There are many Midrashic explanations, [but the above is the plain sense of Scripture].” Thus the language of Rashi. This is also the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, who explained the purport of the verse to be that G-d led them not by the way of the land of the Philistines “because” it was near. They might therefore be filled with regret [when they experience war], and they would immediately return to Egypt.<br>In my opinion, if their explanations were correct, the expression <i>for G-d said</i> would have been mentioned in first place in the verse, in which case the verse would read: “and G-d led them not by the way of the land of the Philistines, for G-d said, Because it is near, lest peradventure the people repent!”<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">But actually the verse reads: <i>and G-d led them not by the way of the land of the Philistines because it was near; for G-d said</i>, etc. In other words, Ramban argues that according to Rashi and Ibn Ezra, the reason for G-d’s choice of the route by the wilderness and not by the land of the Philistines [<i>because it was near</i>], should have followed after the expression <i>for G-d said</i>.</i> But the correct interpretation is that [the expression in question does not state the reason for G-d’s choice but merely] states that <i>G-d led them not by the way of the land of the Philistines</i> although <i>it was near</i> and it would have been advantageous to lead them by that route, for G-d said: <i>Lest peradventure the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt</i>.<br>The reason they would experience war if they went by the way of the land of the Philistines, is that the Philistines would surely not have given them permission to go peacefully through their land, and thus they might return to Egypt. But by the way of the wilderness, they would not see war until they came to the lands of Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:8.</i> which were given to them [i.e. to Israel]. At that time, they were already far from Egypt, [and there was thus no reason to fear that they would be tempted to return to Egypt because of war]. The war of Amalek in Rephidim<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:8-13.</i> was no reason for the Israelites to return to Egypt, since they did not pass through the land of the Amalekites. Rather, Amalek came from his country and warred against them because of his hatred of Israel. Even if they were to take their own course to return to Egypt, it would be to no avail since Amalek would fight them on the way. Besides, they were already far from Egypt because of the circuitous route which they had followed, and they knew of no other route.<br>Now Rashi commented: “<i>When they see war</i>. For instance, the war of the Canaanite and the Amalekite.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">In Numbers 14:45 and so in Rashi here: <i>And the Amalekite and the Canaanite came down</i>.</i> If they had proceeded by the direct route, they would have then turned back. For after He had made them go round by a circuitous way they said, <i>Let us make a captain and go back to Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:4.</i> and how much more so would they have said it had He led them by a straight road!”<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse before us.</i><br>The purport of that which Scripture states, <i>and G-d led them not… But G-d led the people about, by the way of the wilderness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> is that when they journeyed from Succoth,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> a pillar of cloud<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> began to go before them. It did not go by the way of the land of the Philistines but instead went by the way of the wilderness of Etham,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> and the Israelites walked after it. The cloud then rested in Etham and they encamped there, and that was at the edge of the wilderness.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i>

Verse 18

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT UP ARMED OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT. This means that even though G-d led them about by the way of the wilderness, they still feared lest the Philistines who dwelt in the nearby cities come upon them. Therefore they were armed, as are people who go out to war. Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Found in Ibn Ezra.</i> say that Scripture is relating that they went out <i>with a high hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 14:8. “With a high hand carrying their arms and not like slaves who escape from their master” (Ibn Ezra).</i> deeming themselves redeemed from bondage, and they did not leave like slaves escaping [from their master].

Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND THE ETERNAL WENT BEFORE THEM. The Sages have already said,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 51:3. See Vol. I, p. 260.</i> “Wherever the phrase <i>And the Eternal</i> is mentioned, it means He and His Celestial Court.” The Holy One, blessed be He, went before them by day, and His Celestial Court by night.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is not part of the above Midrash. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 348, for a similar interpretation in the Zohar, the mystical commentary on the Torah.</i> If so, the explanation of the verse is that G-d<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “the Name,” i.e., the Great Divine Name known by the attribute of mercy. (Ricanti, interpreting the meaning of Ramban.) See my Hebrew commentary, p. 348.</i> abode in the midst of the cloud, and He went before them by day in a pillar of cloud. By night, His Celestial Court abode in a pillar of fire to give them light. This is similar in meaning to that which the verse says: <i>Inasmuch as Thou Eternal art seen face to face, and Thy cloud standeth over them, and Thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud by day, and in a pillar of fire by night</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:14.</i><br>I have seen in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 19:7.</i> “<i>For ye shall not go out in haste, neither shall ye go by flight; for the Eternal will go before you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:12.</i> In the past, I and My Celestial Court went before you, as it is said, <i>And the Eternal went before them by day</i>, but in the World to Come,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here referring to the Messianic era.</i> I Myself will go before you, as it is said, <i>For the Eternal will go before you, and the G-d of Israel will be your rearward</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:12.</i> The secret of this Midrash is as I have mentioned, i.e., that at the first redemption, the Holy One, blessed be He, was with them by day and His Celestial Court by night, but in the World to Come,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Here referring to the Messianic era.</i> the attribute of His Celestial Court will be elevated in mercy and the Eternal — the Tetragrammaton — will go before them, for the G-d of Israel will then assemble His people, <i>and the night will shine as the day, the darkness even as the light</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 139:12.</i> as everything will then be united in the attribute of mercy.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that Scripture here speaks according to the language of men, since it was the power of G-d and His messenger that went with Israel, [thus, <i>and the Eternal went before them</i> would mean “and the angel of the Eternal went before them”], similar in meaning to the verse, <i>He caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:12.</i> Now it is true that the verse here is similar in meaning to the verse, <i>He caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:12.</i> but it is not as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra understood it.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 6:2, for Ramban’s understanding of the verse in Isaiah, and see also further, 14:19, which states: <i>And the angel of G-d, who went before the camp of Israel, journeyed</i>. It was this verse apparently that forced Ibn Ezra to arrive at his interpretation here. See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i>, for a fuller discussion.</i> And it is further written, <i>So didst Thou lead Thy people to make Thyself a glorious Name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:14.</i> [thus indicating that it was the Holy One, blessed be He, Himself that went before the people, and not, as Ibn Ezra explained, that the reference here is to an angel].

Chapter 14



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4

AND I WILL HARDEN PHARAOH’S HEART, AND HE SHALL PURSUE AFTER THEM. Because Pharaoh feared them at the plague of the firstborn and he asked them <i>and bless me also</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:32.</i> he was not disposed to pursue after the Israelites even if they were to flee, and he would rather have Moses do with them as he pleases. Therefore, it was necessary to state that G-d hardened his heart to pursue after them. Further on, it says once more, <i>And I, behold, I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians, and they shall go in after them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> After the Egyptians saw that the sea had split before the children of Israel and that they walked in the midst of the sea upon dry land, which is the most outstanding wonder of all wonders, how could they be disposed to come in after them to harm them! This was indeed madness on their part. But it was He Who turned their counsel into foolishness<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">See II Samuel 15:31.</i> and strengthened their hearts to enter the sea.

Verse 5

AND IT WAS TOLD THE KING OF EGYPT THAT THE PEOPLE HAD FLED. “He sent guards with them, and as soon as they had reached the three days’ journey that was fixed for them to go and return, and [these guards] saw that they were not returning to Egypt, they went and reported to Pharaoh on the fourth day. On the fifth and sixth days, the Egyptians pursued after them. On the night of the seventh day, they went down into the sea, and on the following morning, the Israelites uttered the Song, and this was the seventh day of Passover. It is for this reason that [during the Synagogue service] on the seventh day of Passover, we read [the Scriptural portion containing] the Song at the Red Sea.” This is the language of Rashi. And so it is also explained in the Mechilta.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on Verse 3. Ramban’s intent is that the Mechilta states the order of events as mentioned by Rashi. The established custom of reading during the Synagogue service on the seventh day of Passover the Scriptural portion containing the Song at the Red Sea is of later origin, as is evidenced by the fact that in the Mishnah (Megillah 30b) and in Tractate Sofrim (17:5) another reading is indicated. The reading is mentioned in the Gemara of Tractate Megillah 31 a, quoting a Beraitha.
