The reason why Rashi at this point mentioned the Synagogue custom for the reading of the Torah on the seventh day of Passover, was to show that it is in keeping with “the event of the day.”</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse here is to be understood in the light of that which G-d said, <i>And Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel: They are entangled in the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> When the children of Israel [indicated that this was] so, and they turned back and encamped before Phi-hahiroth before Baal-zephon,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> this was reported to the king of Egypt. He said <i>that the people were fled</i> and entangled in the desert, and that they were not going towards a definite place to offer sacrifices for G-d. And this is the intent of the verse, <i>and the children of Israel went out with a high hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> This means that they made themselves a flag and a banner for display, and they went out <i>with mirth and with songs, with tabret and with harp</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:27.</i> like people who are redeemed from bondage to freedom, and not like slaves who expect to return to their servitude. All this was told to Pharaoh.

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AND THEY WERE SORE AFRAID; AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL CRIED OUT UNTO THE ETERNAL. 11. AND THEY SAID UNTO MOSES: ‘BECAUSE WERE THERE NO GRAVES IN EGYPT, HAST THOU TAKEN US TO DIE IN THE WILDERNESS’? It does not appear logical that people who are crying out to G-d to help them, should at the same time protest against the deliverance He performed for them, and say that it would have been better if He had not saved them! The correct interpretation therefore is that there were conflicting groups,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in the Mechilta here on Verse 13: “The Israelites at the Red Sea were divided into four groups, etc.” In Rabbeinu Bachya’s rendition of this text of Ramban, it clearly reads: “Therefore we can rely upon the words of our Rabbis who say that these verses represent different groups” (Bachya’s Commentary on the Torah, Vol. II, p. 113, in my edition). Ramban, however, following the plain meaning of Scripture here, does not describe them as four groups but merely as ‘conflicting groups’ without enumeration.</i> and Scripture relates what all of them did. Thus it narrates that one group cried to G-d [for help], and another denied His prophet and did not acknowledge the deliverance done for them. They said it would have been better for them had He not saved them. It is with reference to this group that it is written, <i>They were rebellious at the sea, even at the Red Sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:7.</i> This is why Scripture here repeats in the same verse the term, <i>the children of Israel</i>, [saying: <i>and ‘the children of Israel’ lifted up their eyes</i>…] <i>and ‘the children of Israel’ cried out unto the Eternal</i>. It thus indicates that it was the better ones among the people that cried out to G-d; the remainder rebelled against His word. This is why Scripture says afterward, <i>And the people feared the Eternal; and they believed in the Eternal, and in His servant Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 31.</i> It does not say “and <i>Israel</i> feared the Eternal, and they believed,” but it says instead “the people,” for the term <i>the children of Israel</i> signifies the outstanding ones, while <i>the people</i> is a name for the multitude. Similarly, the verse, <i>And the people murmured</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 15:24.</i> [clearly indicates the usage of the term <i>people</i> in Scripture]. Our Rabbis have also mentioned it:<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Bamidbar Rabbah 20:22.</i> “<i>And the people began to commit harlotry</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 25:1.</i> Wherever it says <i>the people</i>, it is an expression of reproach, and wherever it says <i>Israel</i>, it is one of praise.”<br>Now the people did not say, “you have taken us away to die in war,” but [they said], <i>hast thou taken us away to die in the wilderness</i>, and again they said, <i>that we should die in the wilderness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> This was due to the fact that long before they feared war,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">The Tur renders this passage thus thus: “They said that even if they would not experience any war, they did not want to go out to the desert.”</i> they already did not want to go out to the desert lest they die there from hunger and thirst.<br>It is possible that they said so to Moses upon their going forth from the country while they were still in the land of Egypt, when G-d led them about <i>by the way of the wilderness by the Red Sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:18.</i> Perhaps they said so to Moses at the beginning: “Where shall we go? If by the way of the Philistines, they will war against us, and if by the way of the wilderness, <i>better for us to serve the Egyptians, than that we should die in the wilderness</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i><br>It is also possible to say that the people did believe in G-d and prayed to Him to save them, but a doubt entered their hearts concerning Moses lest he took them out of Egypt in order to rule over them. Although they had seen the signs and wonders he did, they thought that he did them through some manner of wisdom. Perhaps G-d brought the plagues upon the Egyptians on account of their wickedness, [but not necessarily for the purpose of redemption of Israel, and Moses took them out of Egypt just to rule over them], for if G-d had desired their going out, Pharaoh would not have pursued after them.<br>And Onkelos here translated <i>vayitz’aku (and they cried out)</i> as <i>uz’aku</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Elsewhere Onkelos translates it <i>v’tzalu</i> (and they prayed). See Deuteronomy 26:7, <i>vanitz’ak</i>, which Onkelos renders <i>v’tzaleinu</i> (and we prayed). The word <i>uz’aku</i>, on the other hand, means “complaint,” as is explained in the text.</i> thus making its purport to be “complaint,” meaning that they did not pray to G-d but that they complained to Him for having taken them out of Egypt. It is similar in usage to that in the verse, <i>‘vayitz’aku’ unto Pharaoh, saying, Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:15.</i> [which does not mean “and they prayed,” but that they complained.] Similarly, <i>Then there was a great ‘tza’akath’ of the people and of their wives against their brethren the Jews</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 5:1.</i> which means they were complaining against them with a great voice and outcry.<br>In the Mechilta we find;<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse before us.</i> “They seized upon the occupation of their fathers, [i.e., at first they conducted themselves properly in that they prayed to G-d as their fathers had done]. <i>And they said unto Moses:</i> ‘<i>Because were there no graves</i>, etc.?’ After ‘they had added leaven into the dough,’<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban will explain further on that this is a euphemism for the <i>yeitzer hara</i> (the evil inclination). In other words, after doubts had entered their minds and excitement was stirred up, they came to Moses and said to him, etc.</i> they came to Moses and said to him, <i>Is not this the word that we spoke unto thee in Egypt</i>, etc.?”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> The “leaven in the dough” is a reference to the evil inclination. Thus the Sages in the Mechilta intended to say that at first the people prayed to G-d to instill in Pharaoh’s heart the desire to turn back from pursuing them. However, when they saw that he was not turning back but instead was marching and drawing near them, they said, “Our prayers have not been accepted,” and an evil thought entered their hearts to find fault with Moses as they had previously done.

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

FOR WHEREAS YE HAVE SEEN THE EGYPTIANS TODAY, YE SHALL SEE THEM AGAIN NO MORE. In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Succah V, 1. See Maimonides’ “The Commandments,” Vol. II, pp. 44-46, in my translation.</i> this is a negative commandment for all times. If so, Scripture is stating: “<i>Fear ye not, stand still</i> in your places, <i>and see the salvation of the Eternal</i> in that He will save you today from their hands. Concerning the Egyptians you see today, G-d commands you <i>to see them no more</i> of your own free will henceforth and <i>for ever</i>.” It is thus a commandment by the mouth of Moses to Israel, even though it is not mentioned above [that G-d had said so to Moses]. Similarly, the verse, <i>And he</i> [the king] <i>shall not cause the people to return to Egypt, to the end that he should multiply horses; forasmuch as the Eternal hath said unto you: Ye shall henceforth return no more that way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:16.</i> indeed constitutes a commandment, not just a promise.

Verse 14



Verse 15

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: WHEREFORE CRIEST THOU UNTO ME? Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">The difficulty is that there is no mention above of Moses’ praying. Rashi therefore comments that this verse itself — <i>Wherefore criest thou unto Me?</i> — teaches by implication that Moses had been praying. Ibn Ezra’s explanation is first in the text, and Ramban’s interpretation follows it.</i> that Moses corresponds in function to all of Israel who were praying to G-d, as Scripture said, <i>And the children of Israel cried out unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 10. In other words, the name Moses is here equivalent to all Israel. But Ramban questions this explanation of Ibn Ezra: “If so, etc.”</i> But if so, why did G-d say, <i>Wherefore criest thou?</i> When it was indeed proper that they should pray! Perhaps [Ibn Ezra] will say that the sense thereof is: “Why do you let them pray? Speak to them so that they will go forward, for I have already told you, <i>And I will be honored through Pharaoh</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i><br>And our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mechilta on the verse before us.</i> that it was Moses who was crying and praying. This is the correct interpretation [and not, as Ibn Ezra said, that the reference here is to all of Israel]. Moses was at a loss concerning what he was to do. Although G-d had told him, <i>And I will be honored through Pharaoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> he did not know how to conduct himself at that moment when he was at the edge of the sea and the enemy was pursuing and overtaking [them]. He therefore prayed that G-d should instruct him in the manner that he should choose.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 25:12.</i> This then is the meaning of <i>Wherefore criest thou unto Me?</i> meaning: “You should have asked what to do, and there is no need for you to cry, since I have already informed you, <i>And I will be honored through Pharaoh</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> Now Scripture did not relate that Moses was crying out to G-d, because he is included among Israel, [of whom it was already written above in Verse 10: <i>And the children of Israel cried out unto the Eternal</i>].

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND THE ANGEL OF G-D JOURNEYED. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that the <i>angel of G-d</i> is the great prince [Michael],<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">See Daniel 12:1.</i> who went in the cloud. It is to him that Scripture refers when it said, <i>And the Eternal went before them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:21. See there towards the end, where Ramban mentions this explanation of Ibn Ezra, i.e., that the meaning thereof is that the angel of the Eternal went before them.</i> When this angel, <i>who went before the camp of Israel, journeyed and went behind them</i>, the pillar of cloud journeyed with him. <i>And there was the cloud and the darkness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel, <i>but it gave light by night</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> through the pillar of fire to Israel, as it did on other nights, in order to enable them to traverse the sea, for it was at night that they traversed it.<br>In my opinion, that which Scripture says, <i>And the angel of G-d journeyed</i>, occurred at the beginning of the night. <i>The angel of G-d, who went before the camp of Israel</i> alludes to the Celestial Court of the Holy One, blessed be He, which is known as the attribute of justice, [which is called]<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">So clearly rendered by Rabbeinu Bachya (Vol. II, p. 115, in my edition).</i> “angel” in certain places of Scripture. It was he who dwelled in the pillar of fire and went before them by night to give them light. Therefore Scripture here mentions [not the Tetragrammaton, which indicates the attribute of mercy, but] <i>ha’Elokim</i> (G-d), [the name which denotes the attribute of justice]. It is possible that [the word <i>malach</i> (angel)] is not in a construct state [meaning “the angel of”] but instead is in apposition.<br>Now I have seen in the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai:<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The standard Mechilta, a Tannaitic commentary of the Book of Exodus, is that of Rabbi Ishmael. There is another Mechilta, that of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai, to which Ramban refers here. To distinguish it from the other, standard, work, Ramban therefore specifies it by name. For another example, see Vol. I, p. 603. The quotation mentioned here appears in Hoffman’s edition of that work on p. 49. The essence of this particular Midrash is also found here in Rashi.</i> “Rabbi Yonathan the son of Yochai asked Rabbi Shimon the son of Yochai, ‘Why is it that in all places it is written, <i>the angel of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., Genesis 16:7 and above, 3:2.</i> and here it is written, <i>the angel of ‘Elokim’</i> (G-d)?’ Rabbi Shimon answered him, ‘<i>Elokim</i> everywhere denotes “Judge” [literally: judgment], etc.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">“The verse thus teaches us that Israel at that moment was arraigned in judgment, i.e., whether to be saved or to be destroyed with the Egyptians” (Mechilta quoted, and also mentioned in Rashi here).</i> The Rabbis thus alluded to that which we have said.<br>Thus [the angel] now journeyed in the pillar of fire from <i>before the camp of Israel and went behind them, and the pillar of cloud from before them</i> also <i>journeyed and stood behind them</i>. Thus the two pillars were behind the camp of Israel. Scripture then reverts [in Verse 20] to explain that the pillar of cloud <i>came between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel</i>, that is to say, the pillar of cloud did not intervene between the pillar of fire and the camp of Israel, but rather it interposed between the camp of Egypt and the pillar of fire.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the order was as follows: First came the camp of Israel, followed by the pillar of fire. After that was the pillar of cloud, followed by the camp of Egypt. The two pillars thus intervened between the two camps (Bachya).</i> <i>And there was the cloud and the darkness</i> between the two camps, with the pillar of fire giving light to Israel, even though it was behind them, because it was high, [thus illuminating the way for them to pass through the sea, as explained above.] The pillar of cloud did not obstruct the illumination from reaching them as it did to the Egyptians. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>and it gave light by night</i>, since the pillar of fire illuminated the night for them.<br>This was not as on all other nights, when its function was <i>to lead them the way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:21.</i> for on that night it did not go before them, [but instead the pillar of fire remained stationary]. This was so because if the pillar of fire would have gone before Israel as on other nights [when they journeyed], and the pillar of cloud was between the two camps, then the Israelites would have passed through the sea quickly. Consequently, the Egyptians would not have seen them, and they would not have come after them. However, now [that the pillar of fire was stationary] the Israelites walked slowly, and since there was no great distance between the camps, the Egyptians saw the camp of Israel from the midst of the cloud, and they followed them. They saw the fire out of the midst of the cloud,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">“For he who sits in darkness can see light in the distance. But the Israelites did not see the Egyptians, for he who sits in an illuminated place cannot see one who sits in darkness” (Bachya).</i> but they were not able to approach them because of the two pillars which interposed.<br>This is the sense of the verse, <i>And the one</i> [camp] <i>came not near the other all the night</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> <i>And it came to pass in the morning-watch, that the Eternal looked forth upon the host of the Egyptians through the pillar of fire and of cloud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> meaning: He removed the pillar of fire from the camp of Israel, as was customary on all days, and today He put it [in a position] overlooking the camp of Egypt. It was thus between the Egyptians and the pillar of cloud which served Israel by day.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, although the pillar of fire was between Israel and the pillar of cloud during the night, in the morning watch G-d took the pillar of fire and placed it between the camp of Egypt and the pillar of cloud. With the pillar of fire heating the Egyptians, they fell into confusion.</i> <i>And He confounded the camp of Egypt</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> by causing the pillar of fire to bear down upon them with its great heat reaching them, and <i>the flame burned up the wicked</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:18.</i> Now I have already explained in the story of Creation<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:1. See Vol. I, p. 26. There the reason is given why the element of fire is designated as <i>choshech</i> (darkness).</i> that the element of fire is called “darkness,” and <i>the cloud and the darkness</i> [mentioned in Verse 20] accordingly mean the pillar of fire and the pillar of cloud. To all Israel, the pillar of fire had given light because of its high position [as explained above], but now it darkened for the Egyptians, because it came together with the pillar of cloud, which caused it to darken just as the sun when covered by a cloud. Thus He did everything by means of these two pillars. This is the correct interpretation of these verses.

Verse 20



Verse 21

AND MOSES STRETCHED OUT HIS HAND OVER THE SEA; AND THE ETERNAL CAUSED THE SEA TO GO BACK BY A STRONG EAST WIND ALL THE NIGHT. It was His will, may He be blessed, to divide the sea by a strong drying wind, making it appear as <i>if</i> the wind dried the sea, something like that which is written, <i>An east wind shall come, the wind of the Eternal coming up from the wilderness, and his spring shall become dry, and his fountain shall be dried up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 13:15.</i> He thus caused the Egyptians to err and then destroyed them,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 12:23. The verse however reads, <i>masgi (He increases) the nations</i>, etc. Ramban interprets it in the sense of <i>mashgi</i> (He causes to err.) A similar usage of this verse appears in Rashi above, Verse 2. The source of this rendition of the verse is in the Mechilta, <i>ibid.</i></i> for because of this, they thought that perhaps it was the wind which made the sea into dry land, but that it was not the power of G-d that did this for the sake of Israel. Although the wind does not split the sea into sections, they paid no attention even to this and they followed after the Israelites into the sea out of their desire to harm them. This is the intent of the expressions: <i>and I will harden Pharaoh’s heart;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> <i>and they shall go in after them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> He hardened their hearts [so that each one] would say: <i>“I will pursue my enemies and I will overtake them in the sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 18:38. See also further, 15:9.</i> <i>and there is none that can deliver out of my hand</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:39.</i> They did not remember now [what they themselves had said], <i>for the Eternal fighteth for them against the Egyptians</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

AND THE WATERS RETURNED, AND COVERED THE CHARIOTS, AND THE HORSEMEN, ‘L’CHOL’ (TO ALL) THE HOST OF PHARAOH. “[The word <i>l’chol</i> should really have been <i>kol</i> without the letter <i>lamed</i>. However], it is the normal manner of expression of many verses to write a redundant <i>lamed</i>, as for example: <i>‘l’chol the instruments of the Tabernacle;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:19. Literally: <i>‘to all’ the instruments of the Tabernacle</i>, but the meaning is “‘all’ the instruments.”</i> <i>‘l’chol’ the vessels thereof thou shalt make of brass;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4. Literally: <i>‘to all’ the vessels</i>, but the meaning is “‘all’ the vessels thereof.”</i> It is only an elegance in Scriptural style.” Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But it is not so in this place.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban understood Rashi as explaining <i>the chariots and horsemen</i> as being in apposition to <i>all the host</i>. Therefore Rashi had written that the <i>lamed</i> of <i>l’chol</i> is redundant, since the expression <i>all the host</i> is added by way of explanation. But Ramban interprets <i>all the host</i> to mean the people Pharaoh took with him besides the chariots and the horsemen. Therefore the <i>lamed</i> is not an idiomatic form here and is a necessary part of the verse, as is explained further in the text.</i> Instead its meaning is as follows: “And the waters covered the chariots and the horsemen <i>and all the</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>l’chol</i> thus indicates the object, and is as if it were written “<i>v’eth</i> (and the) host of Pharaoh.” See my Hebrew commentary, p. 352.</i> host of Pharaoh that went in after them into the sea.” <i>The host</i> is not identical with <i>the chariots and the horsemen</i>, [as is suggested by Rashi’s explanation], but rather they are his people that Pharaoh took with him,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 6.</i> just as it is said above: <i>all the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, and his horsemen, and his host</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9. Here it is clear that <i>the host</i> is separate from the chariots and horsemen, since it says “and the host.”</i> A similar usage of the letter <i>lamed</i> in connection with the term “covering” is found in these verses: <i>As the waters cover ‘la’yam;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:9. Literally: <i>‘to’ the sea</i>, but the meaning is “the sea.”</i> <i>And thou shalt make a covering ‘la’ohel.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:14. Literally: <i>‘to’ the tent</i>, but it means “and thou shalt make ‘the tent’ a covering of….”</i> The term “covering” also appears [in conjunction] with the word <i>al</i>, e.g., <i>The fat that covereth ‘al’ the inwards</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 4:8. Literally, <i>that covereth ‘upon’ the inwards</i>, but the word <i>al</i> is understood as <i>eth</i>, a word which indicates the direct object.</i> There are many cases like this.

Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31

AND ISRAEL SAW THE GREAT HAND. “I.e., the great power which the hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, had exercised. There are many meanings that are appropriate for the word <i>yad</i> (hand), but all of them signify the actual hand, and the interpreter must adapt the meaning according to the theme of the subject discussed.” Thus the language of Rashi. But Onkelos did not explain <i>the great hand</i> as referring to power, for he translated: “the might of the great hand.” And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that it means “the great blow.” And so it also says, <i>Behold, the hand of the Eternal is upon the cattle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:3.</i> [which means that a great plague will overtake them]; <i>The hand of G-d was very heavy there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 5:11.</i> [which means that a great calamity befell the Philistines].<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], the verse is stating that <i>the great hand</i>, which is the attribute of justice that G-d exercised upon the Egyptians, became revealed to them, since it was there inflicting punishment upon the Egyptians. This is like the verse, <i>And upon earth He made thee to see His great fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> This is the <i>right hand</i> which <i>dashes in pieces the enemy</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 15:6.</i> and it is <i>the arm of the Eternal</i>, concerning which Scripture says, <i>Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:9.</i> <i>Art thou not it that dried up the sea?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10.</i>

Chapter 15



Verse 1

AZ YASHIR MOSHEH'(THEN MOSES WILL SING).<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">It is of course translated as a past tense: “Then Moses sang.” Rashi and Ramban will discuss why the future tense is used here by the Torah.</i> Rashi comments: “[<i>Then</i>], when Moses saw the miracle, the thought came to his heart that he would sing a song,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">According to Rashi, this explains why the future tense — <i>yashir</i> (he will sing) — is used here by the Torah, since the expression denotes Moses’ thought that he should sing. Rashi thus interprets <i>yashir</i> to be a pure future. Ramban will differ with this interpretation.</i> and thus he actually did, [as it is said], <i>and they spoke, saying</i>. Similarly, <i>az yedabeir Yehoshua</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 10:12. Literally: “Then Joshua will speak.”</i> means that when he saw the miracle [mentioned there], his heart prompted him to speak, and thus he actually did, [as it is said], <i>and he said in the sight of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i></i> The same interpretation applies to the Song of the Well, which begins with the words, <i>az yashir Yisrael</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 21:17. Literally: “Then Israel will sing.”</i> and Scripture explains after that, <i>Spring up, O well, sing ye unto it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> This part of the verse shows that the preceding expression, <i>az yashir Yisrael</i>, denotes intent of heart to sing, thus: “<i>Then</i>, when they saw the miracle, their hearts told them that they should sing,” and so they did, as is indicated by the expression <i>sing ye unto it</i>, which is the call to the people to sing.</i> Likewise: <i>az yivneh Shlomoh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:7. Literally: “Then Solomon will build [a high place].”</i> which the Sages of Israel explained it as meaning<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 91b.</i> that he proposed to build but did not build it.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">“Thus we learn that the <i>yod</i> as a prefix of the imperfect verb, [i.e., the future tense of a verb], indicates an intent to do a thing” (Rashi).</i> This explanation serves to clarify the literal meaning of the text.”<br>But what will the Rabbi [Rashi] say concerning these verses: <i>‘Ya’asu’</i> [literally: “They will make”] <i>a calf in Horeb;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:19.</i> <i>How oft ‘yamruhu’</i> [literally: “will they rebel”] <i>against Him in the wilderness, and ‘ya’atzivuhu’</i> [literally: “they will grieve Him”] <i>in the desert!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 78:40.</i> The entire psalm is so written [in the future tense]: <i>yaharog</i> [literally: “He will destroy”] <i>their vines with hail;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 47.</i> <i>y’shalach</i> [literally: “He will send”] <i>among them swarms of flies</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 45.</i> — [when all of these verbs refer to past events]! Similarly: <i>And from whence ‘yavo’u’</i> [literally: “shall they come”] <i>unto thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:14.</i> <i>Of the wounds which the Arameans ‘yakuhu’</i> [literally: “shall smite him”].<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:29.</i> Likewise, <i>Now Moses ‘yikach’</i> [literally: “will take”] <i>the tent</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:7.</i> does not denote a continuous event,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">At this point, Ramban’s intent is directed to another statement in Rashi’s explanation, namely, that where an action is continuously happening, it is proper to use either the future tense or the past tense. Where the action is mentioned once and once only, the future cannot be used. However, Ramban points out, in the verse, <i>Now Moses ‘yikach’ the tent</i>, where the future tense “shall take” is used, the action is not one of continuous happening and still the future tense is used!</i> since he took it only once.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi further, 33:11, towards the end (“The Midrash explains, etc.”), that Moses’ removing his tent to pitch it outside the camp happened only once.</i> Instead, [we must conclude that] it is the way of Scripture to use the future tense in place of the past form, and in many places the reverse is quite usual. The reason for this is that it is a distinctive way of language for a narrator of an event to place himself at a certain point of time which he desires, and he then alludes to the event. At times, he places himself at the moment of the action, and he speaks of it in the present tense as if he is watching it from its very beginning. He would say, “Israel is singing,” as if they were singing right before him, and so also in other cases. However, at times the narrator places himself after the event and says, “This has already been done.” It is all a matter of conveying an event realistically. It is for this reason that this interchangeable use of the tenses occurs in matters of prophecy.
KI GA’OH GA’AH’ (FOR HE IS HIGHLY EXALTED). “[He is exalted] high above songs, and however much I may praise Him, there still remain additional [splendor and praiseworthiness] in Him to be expressed.” Thus the language of Rashi. [The Rabbi] thus interpreted <i>ga’oh ga’ah</i> as an expression of exaltation and supreme power. Perhaps this is so, such usage [of the word <i>ga’oh</i>] being found in the verses: <i>And here shall thy high (‘big’on’) waves be stayed;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:11.</i> <i>For the waters were risen (‘ga’u’);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 47:5.</i> <i>And if it exalt itself (‘v’yigeh’), Thou huntest me as a lion</i><sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Job 10:16.</i> — all of which are expressions of power and ascendancy.<br>But the correct interpretation is the opinion of Onkelos, who rendered it literally an expression of pride. The verse is thus stating that He was ennobled above the horse that proudly goes to battle together with its mighty rider, for He threw both of them into the sea. Similarly, the verse, <i>And in the greatness of Thy ‘g’oncha’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 7.</i> and all other such cases are all expressions of pride, for he who indulges in a feeling of pride elevates himself in importance.

Verse 2

THE ETERNAL IS MY STRENGTH AND SONG. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the word <i>ozi</i> (my strength) is connected with the following word [<i>v’zimrath</i> — and song], thus rendering its sense: “my strength and the song of my strength is the Eternal.”<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">“That is to say, with this Name will I vanquish my enemies, and when I will sing of the victory, my song will be the song of the Eternal, for it is He who is my salvation” (Mishneh l’Ezra in his commentary on Ibn Ezra).</i> <i>This is my G-d ‘v’anveihu':</i> I will make Him a habitation, [from the root <i>naveh</i> (habitation)]. This is <i>my father’s G-d, and I will exalt Him</i>, i.e., by recounting His greatness.<br>Now this is surely the plain meaning of the verse. But [it should be noted that] Moses does not mention here the full Divine Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton, which consists of four letters], but instead mentions only the first two letters. In the entire Torah, it is the manner of Moses our teacher to mention the entire Great Name which He communicated to him, as it is said, <i>This is My Name for ever, and this is My memorial unto all generations</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:15.</i> And the Rabbis have already explained the verse, <i>The hand is upon the throne of Y-ah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:16. Because only the first two letters of the Tetragrammaton are mentioned there, the Rabbis explained: “The Holy One, blessed be He, swore, etc.” The explanation is found in Tanchuma, end of <i>Seder Ki Theitzei</i>, and is quoted by Rashi at the end of this <i>Seder</i>.</i> to mean that “the Holy One, blessed be He, swore that His throne will not be perfect nor will His Name be complete until the seed of Amalek will be entirely blotted out.” [The question then arises: why is the full Divine Name not written here?]<br>By way of the Truth, [that is, the mystic lore of the Cabala], the whole deliverance at the sea came through the angel of G-d — the one of whom it is written, <i>for My Name is in him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:21.</i> — just as it is said, <i>and Israel saw the great hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:31.</i> The “hand” alludes to the attribute of justice, which is the great hand that executes the vengeance. It is by this attribute that the sea was divided, as the prophet explained, <i>Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the Eternal… Art thou not it that dried up the sea, the waters of the great deep?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:9-10.</i> and as I have written above.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:31: “<i>The great hand</i> which is the attribute of justice… became revealed to them.</i> It is for this reason that Moses said that his strength and his song are this Name, [i.e., the first two letters of the Tetragrammaton, which allude to the attribute of justice], <i>For in Y-ah the Eternal is an everlasting Rock</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:4. As translated in Singer’s Daily Prayer Book.</i> And so did [the psalmist] explain: <i>What aileth thee, O thou sea, that thou fleest?… At the presence of the G-d of Jacob</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 114:5-7. <i>The G-d of Jacob</i> alludes here to the attribute of justice.</i> And so the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the verse before us.</i> “When Israel went into the sea, the <i>Shechinah</i> (Divine presence)<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 551.</i> was with them, as it is said, <i>And the angel of G-d journeyed</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:19.</i> And in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah, it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 30:1.</i> “The word <i>oz</i> (strength) [or <i>ozi</i>, “my strength,” as is mentioned in this verse], alludes only to judgment, as it is said, <i>‘v’oz’ (And the strength) of a king is he who loveth justice</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 99:4.</i><br><i>This is My G-d ‘v’anveihu.’</i> “I will elevate [the Great Name, i.e., the Tetragrammaton],<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">So clearly interpreted in Abusaula’s commentary on Ramban. See Vol. I, p. XII, Note 21.</i> to the G-d of the most high <i>naveh</i> (abode), this being the G-d of my fathers, to whom He had appeared as <i>E-il Sha-dai</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 6:2, and also Vol. I, pp. 214-216.</i> And now I shall exalt Him by the complete Name, for henceforth the Name will be <i>ish milchamah</i>, [literally, “man of war,” but here alluding to the attribute of justice]. And <i>His Name</i> will be <i>the Eternal</i>, [meaning that the Name comprises justice with mercy],<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is thus interpreting Verse 3, <i>The Eternal is a man of war, the Eternal is His Name</i>, to mean that Israel will henceforth exalt Him both in His aspect of justice and of mercy. I have followed Abusaula’s interpretation of Ramban’s text.</i> similar in meaning to the verse, <i>Now will I be exalted; now will I lift Myself up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 33:10.</i> It is possible that the word <i>‘zeh’ (this)</i> alludes to the seven emanations in wisdom, this being associated with the verse, <i>‘zeh’ (this) is My Name for ever, ‘v’zeh’ (and this) is My memorial</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:15.</i> And in the Mechilta we read:<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on Verse 2.</i> “<i>My G-d</i>. He dealt with me according to the attribute of mercy, while with my fathers he dealt according to the attribute of justice. And whence do we know that <i>my G-d</i> signifies the attribute of mercy? Because it is said, <i>My G-d, my G-d, why hast Thou forsaken me?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 22:2. “And surely one would not say to the attribute of justice, ‘Why hast thou forsaken me?’” (Rashi further, 34:6).</i> <i>Heal her now, O G-d, I beseech thee?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:13. A supplication of this kind is naturally addressed to G-d in His aspect of mercy.</i> <i>The Eternal is ‘E-il’ (G-d), and He hath given us light</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 118:27.</i> If so, Scripture here says <i>‘zeh E-ili’ (this is my G-d)</i>, meaning that “with me He is <i>E-il</i> [G-d in His aspect of mercy] in this matter, since He was exalted with mercy to be compassionate in His justice.”

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

THY RIGHT HAND, O ETERNAL, GLORIOUS IN POWER, THY RIGHT HAND, O ETERNAL, DASHETH IN PIECES THE ENEMY. Rashi commented: “The literal sense of the text is as follows: ‘Thy right hand that is glorious in power — what does it do? <i>Thy right hand, O Eternal, dasheth in pieces the enemy</i>.’ There are many Scriptural verses that follow this form. <i>For lo Thine enemies, O Eternal, for lo Thine enemies shall perish;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 92:10. The meaning then would be: “<i>For lo Thine enemies, O Eternal</i>, what shall happen to them? <i>For lo Thine enemies shall perish</i>.”</i> <i>Eternal, how long shall the wicked, how long shall the wicked exult?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 94:3.</i> <i>The floods have lifted up, O Eternal, the floods have lifted up their voice</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 93:3.</i> In my opinion, however, this is not correct. Verses repeat words in order to indicate that such will always be the case, without identifying what they refer to until they mention it the second time. Had Scripture said here, “Thy right hand, thy right hand, dasheth in pieces the enemy” it would have been exactly like the other verses Rashi mentions. [But instead it says here, <i>Thy right hand, O Eternal, ‘glorious in power,’ Thy right hand, O Eternal, dasheth…</i> and consequently it is unlike the other verses mentioned.] Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the verse means: “Thy right hand, O Eternal, Thou Who art glorious in power, may Thy right hand dash in pieces the enemy.” In that case, the verse here is similar in form to the verses mentioned [by Rashi].<br>A more correct interpretation would be to explain it thus: “Thy right hand, O Eternal, is glorious in power to humble all proud and lofty; Thy right hand, O Eternal, dashes in pieces the enemy with great power.” It mentions <i>the right hand</i> both in the masculine and feminine forms,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">“<i>Thy right hand… ‘ne’edari’ (glorious)</i>” is in the masculine gender; “<i>Thy right hand… ‘tir’atz’ (dasheth)” is in the feminine.</i></i> just as in the verse, <i>Behold, a hand was put forth unto me; and lo, a roll of a book was therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 2:9. <i>Sh’luchah</i> (put forth) is a feminine form; <i>bo</i> (therein) is a masculine.</i> and is repeated as is customary in prophecies.<br>The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand the way of the Truth in this verse from the first verses<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 14:31.</i> I have explained. And so did the Rabbis say it:<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 24:1.</i> “With the very same hand with which He sank the Egyptians, He delivered Israel,”<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 355, that it is so interpreted by Rabbeinu Bachya ben Asher.</i> for it is “the power” that saves, as it is said, <i>And now, I pray Thee, let the power of the Eternal be great</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:17.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

THE ENEMY SAID. “I.e., to his people, when he [Pharaoh] was persuading them with words: ‘I will pursue them and I will overtake them, and I will divide the spoil with my captains and my servants.’” Thus the language of Rashi. Now I have seen in the Midrash Chazita:<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">I have not found this Midrash in Shir Hashirim Rabbah, (see above in <i>Seder Shemoth</i>, Note 317), but in Koheleth Rabbah 1:31 and also in the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai on the verse here.</i> “Thus did Rabbi Yishmael teach: ‘<i>The enemy said: I will pursue, I will overtake</i>. This should fittingly have been at the beginning of the Song, and why was it not written there? It is because there is no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah.’” Now Onkelos is of that opinion, for he translated, “the enemy had said,” referring to the beginning of his plan to pursue after them.<br>In my opinion, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, this is to be understood in connection with the preceding verses, [all of them together explaining how the destruction of the enemy came about.] First, Scripture said that they sank in the sea and that they went down into the depths.<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> This happened when <i>the waters returned, and covered the chariots, and the horsemen</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:28.</i> After that, Scripture reverts to tell how this came about. <i>With the blast of Thy nostrils</i>, which is a reference to <i>the strong east wind</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> <i>the waters were piled up</i>, and <i>the deeps were congealed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> from the beginning. It was because of this that the enemy thought that he would pursue and overtake them in the sea and divide their spoil, and that his lust would be satisfied upon them. But <i>Thou didst blow</i><sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> upon them <i>with Thy wind</i>, and <i>the sea covered them</i>.<br>Now Moses mentioned this for in this thought of Pharaoh too were discernible the wonderful causation of G-d, Who strengthened the hearts of the Egyptians and turned their counsel into foolishness to come after the Israelites into the sea, as I have explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:21.</i> It is for this reason that following that verse, Moses said, <i>Who is like unto Thee, O Eternal, among the mighty</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> doing great and wondrous things in ways mutually opposed to each other, [such as was done here: with the same hand, He sank the Egyptians and delivered Israel, as mentioned above].

Verse 10

NASHAPHTA’ WITH THY WIND. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that <i>nashaphta</i> is derived from the root <i>nesheph</i> (twilight),<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">“For there are two kinds of <i>nesheph</i> (twilight): the <i>nesheph</i> after sundown, and the <i>nesheph</i> before sunrise” (Ibn Ezra)! Here the <i>nesheph</i> before sunrise is referred to.</i> for it was at twilight that He brought the wind which caused the water to return and drown the pursuers. Rashi explained it “as an expression for ‘blowing,’ similar in usage to the verse, <i>When ‘nashaph’ (He bloweth) upon them, they wither</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:24.</i> Rashi has explained it well.<br>My opinion, furthermore, is that the purport of <i>nashaphta</i>, [written with the letter <i>phei</i>], is like [that written] with a <i>beth: Thou ‘nashavta’ (didst blow) with Thy wind</i>. The usage of the word is similar to: <i>Because the breath of the Eternal ‘nashva’ (bloweth) upon it;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7.</i> <i>‘yasheiv’ (He bloweth) His wind, and the waters flow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:18.</i> These two letters — [the <i>phei</i> or <i>pei</i> and the <i>beth</i>] — are of similar usage, just as in the verses: <i>‘al gapei’ (Upon) the highest places of the city</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 9:3.</i> which is like <i>al gabei; ‘im b’gapo’ (if by himself)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:3.</i> which is like <i>im b’gabo</i>. Similarly: <i>And substance ‘yivzor’ (he shall scatter) among them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 11:24.</i> <i>‘bizar’ (He hath scattered) the peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:31.</i> These are expressions of <i>pizur</i> (scattering), [with the letter <i>beth</i> serving here as <i>phei</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 505-506, for a similar interchange of letters between the <i>gimmel</i> and the <i>kuph</i>.</i> In proper names, these letters also interchange, e.g., Shovach, and Shophach.<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 10:16; I Chronicles 19:16.</i> And our Rabbis say in the Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Peah 6:1.</i> “[If produce is proclaimed] <i>hevkeir</i> (ownerless) for the benefit of the poor [only], it is deemed <i>hevkeir</i> (ownerless).”<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">If a person gives up his ownership of the produce of his field, he is free from the obligation of giving the Tithe. But if he proclaimed it ownerless only for the poor and not for the rich, the School of Shammai say it is deemed ownerless and is therefore Tithe-free. The Mishnah continues that the School of Hillel say that it can be deemed ownerless only if it is proclaimed ownerless equally for the rich. Ramban here is interested only in the language of the Mishnah using a <i>veth (hevkeir)</i> for a <i>phei</i>, and therefore he quotes only the beginning of the Mishnah.</i> [The word <i>hevkeir</i>] is like <i>hephkeir</i> (ownerless). From the expression, <i>The grains ‘avshu’ (shrivel)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 1:17.</i> comes the word <i>ipush</i> (musty). The term <i>ben p’kua</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 69a. Literally: “a child [of an animal] which is ripped open.”</i> [an animal taken alive out of the slaughtered mother’s womb], is used in place of <i>ben b’kua</i>, because the mother was “ripped open” and there was found in it a living offspring of nine months.<br>In my opinion also, <i>‘hichpishani’ in ashes</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:16.</i> is like <i>‘hichbishani’ (He presses me)</i> [or “He made me cower”] in ashes, the usage of the word being similar to: <i>And replenish the earth, ‘v’chivshuha’ (and subdue it);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:28.</i> <i>‘yichbosh’ (He will subdue) our iniquities</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:19.</i> In the language of the Rabbis we also find: “a measure which is <i>k’phushah</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 107b.</i> meaning <i>k’vushah</i>, [a measure into which the contents have been “compressed”, and which therefore contains more than its normal measure].<br>The purport of the verse is thus: “with Your strong and mighty wind, the waters of the sea were piled up, and when You blew the wind with which You control the sea, the sea covered them.” This is the intent of the verse, <i>And the sea returned to its strength when the morning appeared</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:27.</i> for He caused the wind to blow on it as He does at His strength when <i>He ruleth the proud swelling of the sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:10.</i>
TZALALU’ AS LEAD. They went down into “the depths” (<i>m’tzoloth</i>) of the sea as lead. Now Moses mentioned this in the Song twice: <i>They went down into the sea like a stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> and <i>as lead</i>, [mentioned in the verse here], in order to emphasize that this too came upon them from the hand of G-d. There were many persons among the Egyptians who knew how to swim, and they were near dry land, and surely all those who rode on the horses could be expected to be saved since horses are accustomed to swimming in water. Similarly, <i>those that handle the shield</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 46:9. The shield can serve as a board for passing through the surf. See Yebamoth 121 a where Rabbi Akiba relates that once when his boat drowned “I chanced upon a board of the boat and every wave that came upon me I bent my head” and he was thus saved.</i> can save themselves in water, and here not one of them escaped! This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the Eternal overthrew (‘vay’na’er’) the Egyptians in the midst of the sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:27.</i> He lifted them with <i>His rough blast</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 27:8.</i> and He lowered them into the sea. The usage of the word is similar to that in the verses: <i>And the wicked ‘v’yina’aru’ (shall be shaken) out of it;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:13.</i> <i>And the strong shall be ‘lin’oreth’ (as tow)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:31.</i> <i>‘n’oreth’</i> being that which is separated and falls off from the flax when it is being prepared [for spinning].

Verse 11

WHO IS LIKE UNTO THEE, O ETERNAL, ‘BA’EILIM’. “I.e., among the mighty ones, just as in the verses: <i>And ‘eilei’ (the mighty) of the land he took away;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 17:13.</i> <i>‘eyaluthi’ (O Thou my strength), hasten to help me</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 22:20.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>Now it is true that the word <i>eilim</i> is an expression of power and strength, but <i>Who is like unto Thee ‘ba’eilim’</i> is a reference to the angels who are called <i>eilim</i>, the usage of the word being similar to that in the verse, <i>This is ‘E-ili’ (my G-d), and I will glorify Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> and the Holy One, blessed be He, is called <i>E-il Elyon</i> (G-d the Most High)<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 14:18.</i> above all powers. Similarly, <i>And he shall speak strange things against the G-d of ‘eilim’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 11:36.</i> is like the expression, <i>He is G-d of gods</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:17.</i> Also, <i>Ascribe unto the Eternal, O ye ‘b’nei eilim’ (sons of might)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 29:1.</i> is like the expression <i>b’nei ha’elohim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 6:2.</i> since they are at times called <i>eilim</i> or <i>b’nei eilim</i>, and sometimes also <i>ha’elohim</i> or <i>b’nei elohim</i>. Thus: <i>For the Eternal is greater than all ‘ha’elohim;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 18:11.</i> <i>And the ‘b’nei ha’elohim’ came to present themselves before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Job 1:6.</i> Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to R’dak, who mentions this point clearly in his Sefer Hamichlal, and quotes the verses mentioned here. If <i>b’nei</i> is not in the construct state, <i>b’nei eilim</i> will not mean “sons of the mighty ones,” as it would if the word <i>b’nei</i> were in the construct state. Instaed, it means “the sons who are the mighty ones.”</i> say that the word <i>b’nei</i> is not in the construct state, nor are these expressions: <i>b’nei shileishim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 50:23. In the construct state, it would mean “children of the third generation,” i.e., the fourth generation. In the non-construct state, it would mean “children who were the third generation.”</i> <i>‘anshei’ (men) portrayed upon the wall</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 23:14. The point here is that the word <i>anshei</i> (men) is vocalized with a <i>tzeirei</i>, as is the rule in the construct state. See Vol. I, p. 503. Yet it is not in the construct state. So also the word <i>b’nei</i>, although vocalized with a <i>tzeirei</i>, is not in the construct state.</i> And this is the meaning of <i>Who is like Thee, ‘ne’edar’ (majestic) in holiness?</i> since there is no <i>adir</i> (lofty one) like Him in the celestial holy abode. And so we find in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>Who is like unto Thee</i> among those who serve before Thee in heaven, as it is said, <i>For who in the skies can be compared unto the Eternal, who among the sons of might can be likened unto the Eternal, a G-d to be feared in the great council of the holy ones?</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:7-8.</i>
NORA TH’HILOTH’ (FEARFUL IN PRAISES). “He is feared by those who recount His praises lest they enumerate fewer than there really are, [and thus fail to praise Him adequately], just as it is written, <i>To thee silence is praise</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 65:2.</i> Thus Rashi’s language. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra also explained “that all who praise Him are fearful when praising His Name, for <i>Who can make all His praise to be heard?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 106:2.</i> And they are duty-bound to praise His Name, for He alone does wonders.”<br>In my opinion, <i>nora th’hiloth</i> means: “fearful with praises, for He does fearful things and He is praised for them, as when He wreaks vengeance on those who transgress His will and thereby helps those who serve Him. Thus He is [both] feared and highly praised.” And because earthly kings are feared because of their <i>oppression and perverseness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:12.</i> Moses said that G-d is feared through the very things for which He is praised. Similarly, <i>To Thee ‘dumiyah’ is praise</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 65:2.</i> means, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, “that hoping to Thee is praise, for all who hope to Thee obtain their wish, and they praise Thy Name in Zion and there they perform their vows<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 65:2.</i> which they have vowed in the time of their trouble.” The usage [of the word <i>dumiyah</i> as “hope”] is similar to that found in these verses: <i>Only to G-d ‘dumi’ (wait) thou, my soul, for from Him cometh my hope;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 62:6. One who hopes waits in expectation of something to happen.</i> <i>‘vayidom hashemesh’ and the moon stayed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 10:13. It is generally translated: <i>And the sun stood still</i>. Ramban obviously takes it to mean: “and the sun ‘waited,’” a term akin to hoping, for he who hopes waits.</i> Similarly, <i>Only to G-d ‘dumiyah’ my soul</i><sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 62:2.</i> means: “only to G-d doth my soul hope.” Thus it appears to me.<br>In the name of other scholars,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned by R’dak in his Sefer Hashorashim, under the root of <i>damah</i>, in the name of “some commentators.”</i> I have heard that it means: “to Thee, praise becomes silent, for no amount of praise can fathom Thy great and fearful deeds.” The usage is similar to the verse: <i>And at night there is no ‘dumiyah’ (respite) for me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 22:3.</i> Accordingly, the meaning of the expression, <i>O G-d, in Zion</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 65:2. The verse reads: <i>To Thee ‘dumiyah’ praise, O G-d in Zion, and unto Thee the vow is performed</i>. Now Ramban had first presented his own interpretation that the word <i>dumiyah</i> means hope, and the purport of the verse is that hoping to G-d is praise, for all who hope to G-d obtain their favor from Him and then they praise His name in Zion where they come to perform their vows. But according to the explanation of the other scholars, i.e., that <i>dumiyah</i> expresses a sense of silence, the verse means: “praise unto Thee becomes silent, O G-d Who dwells in Zion, for no amount of praise can fathom Thy deeds, and unto Thee the vow is performed.”</i> is “the G-d Who is in Zion.” That is to say, the One Who dwells there. The correct interpretation is as we have said, [i.e., that <i>dumiyah</i> signifies “hope”].

Verse 12

THOU STRETCHEDST OUT THY RIGHT HAND — THE EARTH ‘TIVLA’EIMO’ (SWALLOWED THEM). The meaning is that “after you blew with Your wind and <i>the sea covered them</i>, You stretched out Your right hand and Your arm,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16: <i>By the greatness of Thine arm…</i></i> <i>and the earth swallowed them</i>.” The purport thereof is that after they drowned, the sea cast them out as is the custom of the seas, and so Scripture says, <i>And Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea-shore</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:30.</i> There, [on the sea-shore], their bodies decomposed and they returned to the dust upon the earth as they were,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">See Ecclesiastes 12:7.</i> and thus they were swallowed up and destroyed [by the earth]. The usage of the word <i>tivla’eimo</i> is similar to the expressions: <i>Together round about, ‘vativla’eini’ (Thou dost destroy me);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Job 10:8.</i> <i>The Eternal ‘bila’ (hath swallowed up) unsparingly;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 2:2.</i> <i>And the way of thy paths ‘bileiu,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:12.</i> which means “they destroyed.” Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> that the earth opened her mouth and swallowed them, for they were privileged to be buried by virtue of having said, <i>The Eternal is righteous</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:27.</i> [Thus, according to this Midrash of the Rabbis, the bodies of the Egyptians were not totally destroyed, for they even merited a place for burial.] But the expression of G-d’s “outstretched right hand or arm,” [as stated here. <i>Thou stretchedst out Thy right hand</i>], is used in Scripture only as indicating vengeance and destruction! Perhaps the Rabbis [of the above-mentioned interpretation] will explain the verse as follows: “<i>Thou stretchedst out Thy right hand</i> to slay them in the sea, and <i>the earth swallowed them up</i> after that,” this being the burial which they merited.

Verse 13

THOU IN THY LOVE HAST LED THE PEOPLE THAT THOU HAST REDEEMED; THOU HAST GUIDED THEM IN THY STRENGTH TO THY HOLY HABITATION. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that this is a past tense in place of the future, as is customary in prophecies. In my opinion, Moses is saying: “<i>Thou stretchedst out Thy right hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> upon the enemy, and the earth swallowed them, but <i>Thou in Thy love hast led — in a pillar of cloud, to lead them the way</i><sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:21.</i> — <i>the people that Thou hast redeemed</i>, and <i>Thou hast guided them</i> in the strength of Thy hands <i>to Thy holy habitation</i>,” for it is to that holy habitation that they were going, and so also, <i>And all nations shall flow unto it.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:2.</i> <i>Thy holy habitation</i> is a reference to the Sanctuary [in Jerusalem], as Moses says again, <i>The Sanctuary, O Eternal, which Thy hands have established</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> And so the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>Habitation</i> is but a designation for the Sanctuary, as it is said, <i>Look upon Zion, the city of our solemn gatherings; thine eyes shall see Jerusalem a peaceful habitation</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 33:20.</i>

Verse 14

THE PEOPLES HAVE HEARD, THEY TREMBLE. The purport thereof is: “when the people will hear [of Thy visitation upon the Egyptians], they will tremble from the blow of Thy hands, and pangs will take hold of the inhabitants of Philistia when they will hear [of those deeds].” It is possible that Moses is saying that the peoples have already heard all that G-d has done in the land of Egypt, and that they will always tremble from the disease He has put upon them.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">See further, Verse 26.</i> Thus Moses continues to pray that He should let fall upon them terror and dread<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> so that they should not go out to war against Israel.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that the verse, <i>Horror and dread shall fall upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> refers only to Philistia, [mentioned in Verse 14] and Edom and Moab, [mentioned in Verse 15], but not to the inhabitants of Canaan, [who are also mentioned at the end of Verse 15]. This is because Moses said afterward, [i.e., at the end of Verse 16 before us], <i>till Thy people pass over, O Eternal</i>. It was over them [Philistia, Edom and Moab] that the Israelites passed before they came into the land of Canaan, and these peoples really did not war against them. Even when Edom <i>came out against him with much people, and a strong hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:20.</i> it was only so that the Israelites should not pass over his land, but he did not war against them. But were it not for the terror and dread that fell upon them, they would have wanted to battle against them out of their hatred of them. Now Moses did not mention Ammon, because Ammon and Moab are as one nation. It is possible that the dread of the Israelites fell on the Canaanite too, and he did not war against them until they had passed over [the Jordan], for <i>the Canaanite, the king of Arad, who dwelt in the south</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:1.</i> [and who warred against Israel when they were still in the wilderness], was not a Canaanite by descent, according to the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma, <i>Chukath</i> 18. The explanation there is that this was Amalek, but he purposely changed his speech to the Canaanite language so that Israel might be misled and would pray that G-d should give the Canaanites into their hands. Since Amalek was actually not a Canaanite, their prayers would therefore be ineffectual. This interpretation is quoted by Rashi to Numbers 21:1.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

THE ETERNAL SHALL REIGN FOR EVER AND EVER. Moses is saying that just as He has now shown that He is King and Ruler by having brought deliverance to His servants and destruction upon those that rebel against Him, so may it be His will to do so in all generations forever, that <i>He withdraw not His eyes from the righteous</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Job 36:7.</i> nor hide them [His eyes] from the wicked ones who inflict evil upon others. There are many verses that are to be interpreted in this way, such as: <i>The Eternal will reign for ever, thy G-d, O Zion, unto all generations. Hallelujah;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 146:10.</i> <i>Blessed be the Name of the Eternal from this time forth and for ever;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 113:2.</i> <i>And the Eternal shall be King over all the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 14:9.</i><br>Now Onkelos was apprehensive [of translating this verse literally, which is stated in a future tense], since G-d’s sovereignty is [indeed] to all eternity [and no prayer for its continuance is possible]. Therefore he rendered it in the present tense: “The Kingdom of the Eternal endureth for ever and to all eternity,” just as is expressed in the verse, <i>Thy Kingdom is a Kingdom for all ages</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 145:13.</i> But I have not understood Onkelos’ opinion in this matter, for it is written: <i>May the Glory of the Eternal endure for ever;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 104:31.</i> <i>And let the whole earth be filled with His Glory;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 72:19.</i> “Magnified and sanctified shall be [His great Name]”;<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">From the beginning of the <i>Kaddish</i> prayer. In Ricanti’s work on the Torah in quoting this text from Ramban, he writes clearly: “and in the <i>Kaddish</i> [we say], ‘Magnified, etc.’” It is thus to be noted that the <i>Kaddish</i>-text is quoted by Ramban amidst Scriptural verses as authority for his thesis! The great sanctity of the <i>Kaddish</i> prayer is thus clearly indicated.</i> <i>Yea, let it be established, and let Thy Name be magnified for ever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 17:24.</i> It is possible that the meaning of these [future tenses] is similar to the secret of the benedictions.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">“Magnifying G-d’s Name brings life and blessing to the world, thus assuring that His kingdom will be acknowledged in the world in the future. And so is the purport of the benedictions we make, which begin by referring to ‘the Eternal, our G-d’ and continue to mention ‘King of the universe’” (Ma’or V’shamesh).</i>

Verse 19

FOR THE HORSES OF PHARAOH WENT IN WITH HIS CHARIOTS AND WITH HIS HORSEMEN. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that this verse is also part of the Song, for Moses and the children of Israel were singing and saying: <i>For the horses of Pharaoh went in with his chariots and with his horsemen into the sea, and the Eternal brought back the waters of the sea upon them</i> while the children of Israel were walking <i>on dry land in the midst of the sea</i>, this being a miracle within a miracle.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><i>For</i> when <i>the horses of Pharaoh went in</i>, etc., <i>He brought the waters upon them</i>, and at the same time, <i>the children of Israel walked on dry land</i>.</i><br>But this verse is not written in the style of the Song, nor is it in the style of prophecies! [Therefore, Ibn Ezra’s interpretation is not correct.] Instead, the verse is to be interpreted [as dating the Song]: <i>Then sang Moses — when the horses of Pharaoh went in</i>. Immediately on that day — not the following day or at some later time — [he sang this Song]. It may be that the sense thereof is as follows: <i>Then Moses sang</i>, when <i>the horses of Pharaoh went into the sea and G-d brought back the waters of the sea upon them while the children of Israel were yet walking on dry land in the midst of it</i>. Thus the verse relates that they said the Song while they were walking in the midst of the sea on dry land. Scripture further tells<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 20-21.</i> that it was then that Miriam the prophetess took the timbrel in hand and sang them the first verse of the Song that they, [i.e., the women], should sing after Moses and Israel.

Verse 20

AND MIRIAM THE PROPHETESS, THE SISTER OF AARON. The correct interpretation appears to me to be that because Moses and Miriam were mentioned in the Song and Aaron was not, Scripture wanted to mention him. It therefore said <i>the sister of Aaron</i> as a mark of honor to him, i.e., that he was her older brother and that his sister the prophetess connected her genealogy to him, since he too was a prophet and a holy man of G-d. It is possible that it is the custom of Scripture to trace the genealogy of a family through the oldest brother. Similarly it is written, <i>And the sons of Caleb the brother of Jerahmeel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 2:42.</i> because he was the oldest brother, as it is said: <i>The sons also of Hezron… Jerahmeel, and Ram, and Chelubai</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:9.</i>

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

THERE HE MADE FOR THEM A STATUTE AND AN ORDINANCE, AND THERE HE TRIED THEM. “At Marah He gave them some of the sections of the Torah so that they might engage in the study thereof, [such as]: the Sabbath, the Red Heifer,<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers, Chapter 19. The reason that Rashi singles out these three subjects — the Sabbath, the Red Heifer, and the laws of justice — is generally explained as follows: He mentions the Sabbath because it is referred to in the section on the manna (further, 16:23-30), as the means through which G-d tried Israel. The Red Heifer is the most outstanding example of a <i>chok</i> (a statute), the type of a commandment the reason for which we do not know. The laws of justice are the typical examples of <i>mishpat</i> (ordinance), which is a precept dictated by reason. Accordingly Rashi interpreted the verse before us — <i>a statute</i> etc. — as referring to these three subjects.</i> and the laws of justice. <i>And there He tried them</i>, that is, the people.”<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s intent is to explain the extra word <i>v’sham (‘and there’ He tried them)</i>. It should have said, “There He made for them a statute and an ordinance and tried them,” in which case it would have meant that He tried them with the statute and ordinance, i.e., to see if they would observe them. But since it says, <i>and there He tried them</i>, it must refer to something additional, namely, the preceding event when the people murmured against Moses instead of approaching him to pray that the bitterness of the waters be removed. It is to this event, according to Rashi, that the expression refers: “<i>And there He tried them</i>, that is, the people” (Sifthei Chachamim). Ramban, however, will explain that “the trial” was of another nature, as will be explained in the text.</i> Thus the language of Rashi, and it is the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 56b.</i><br>But I wonder! Why does Scripture not explain these statutes and ordinances here, saying, “And the Eternal spoke to Moses: ‘Command the children of Israel,’” as it says in the chapters mentioned above, <i>Speak ye unto all the congregation of Israel?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:3.</i> Indeed, it does so with regard to all commandments given in the Tent of Meeting, on the plains of Moab,<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:1.</i> and the Passover in the wilderness!<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:1-5.</i> Now Rashi’s expression, “He gave them… sections of the Torah so that they might engage in the study thereof,” indicates that Moses did inform them of these statutes and that he taught these statutes to them, [saying], “In the future, the Holy One, blessed be He, will command you so,” in the same way as Abraham our father learned the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 331-332.</i> The purpose of it was to make them familiar with the commandments and to know if they would accept them <i>with joyfulness and with gladness of heart</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:47.</i> This was “the trial” of which Scripture says, <i>and there He tried them</i>, and he [Moses] informed them that G-d would further command them the precepts of the Torah. This is the intent of the verse, “<i>If thou wilt diligently hearken to the voice of the Eternal thy G-d… and wilt give ear to His commandments</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.
