It is thus obvious that Ramban understands the word <i>vayomer</i> (and he said) as a reference to Moses, and not, as rendered in some translations, “and He said.”</i> which He will command you [in the future].”<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, when the Israelites began coming into <i>the great and dreadful wilderness… thirsty ground where there was no water</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:15.</i> Moses established customs for them concerning how to regulate their lives and affairs <i>until they come to a land inhabited</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 16:35. — “<i>Moses</i> established customs.” It should be noted that Ramban uses the expression <i>sam lahem</i> which could possibly be a reference to G-d, that “<i>He</i> established customs for them.” But in Rabbeinu Bachya’s commentary quoting Ramban he writes clearly: “In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, <i>statute and ordinance</i> are the customs how to regulate their lives in the desert, for Moses was king in Jeshurun, a leader who chastised his people and commanded them how to regulate their lives in the desert” (Bachya, Vol. II, p. 137 in my edition). On the basis of Bachya’s interpretation I have translated here: “<i>Moses</i> established customs.”</i> A custom is called <i>chok</i>, this being associated with the expressions: <i>Feed me with ‘chuki’ (my customary) bread;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 30:8.</i> <i>‘chukoth’ (the customary ways or laws) of heaven and earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 33:25.</i> Custom is also called <i>mishpat</i> (judgment or ordinance) because it is something measured out accurately. A similar usage [of the word <i>mishpat</i>] is found in these verses: <i>So did David, and so hath been ‘mishpato’ (his manner) all the while;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 27:11.</i> <i>After the former ‘mishpat’ (manner) when thou wast his butler;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 40:13.</i> <i>And the palace shall be inhabited upon ‘mishpato’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 30:18.</i> i.e., upon its ascertained dimension.<br>It may mean that Moses instructed them in the ways of the wilderness, namely to be ready to suffer hunger and thirst and to pray to G-d, and not to murmur. He taught them ordinances whereby they should live, to love one another, to follow the counsel of the elders, to be discreet in their tents with respect to women and children, to deal in a peaceful manner with the strangers that come into the camp to sell them various objects. He also imparted moral instructions, i.e., that they should not become like bands of marauders who do all abominable things and have no sense of shame, similar to that which the Torah commanded, <i>When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies, then thou shalt keep thee from every evil thing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 23:10.</i> In the case of Joshua it is also said. <i>So Joshua made a covenant with the people that day, and set them a statute and an ordinance in Shechem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:25.</i> Here too the expression, [<i>a statute and an ordinance</i>], does not refer to the statutes and ordinances of the Torah, but rather to the customs and ways of civilized society, such as “the conditions which Joshua made [upon entering the Land],” which the Rabbis have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 80 b-81 a: “Ten conditions did Joshua stipulate [with Israel when they came into the Land]: that all people have a right to pasture their cattle in forests [without the interference of the owner of the forest] etc.” The customs established by Joshua were thus the norms of a functioning society.</i> and other such similar regulations. And Scripture says, <i>and there he tried them</i>, in order to inform us that he [Moses] led them by such a road on which there was no water, and he brought them to a place where the waters were bitter in order to test them, even as Scripture says, <i>And He afflicted thee, and suffered thee to hunger;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:3.</i> <i>And that He might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i>
VAYOREIHU HASHEM EITZ’ (AND THE ETERNAL SHOWED HIM A TREE). The meaning thereof is that G-d showed Moses a tree and He told him, “Throw this tree into the waters, and they shall become sweet.” Now due to the fact that I have not found the expression of <i>moreh</i>, [from which the word <i>vayoreihu</i> here is derived], except in the sense of instruction — [e.g., the verse], <i>‘vayoreini’ and said to me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 4:4.</i> which means “and he [my father] taught me,” and so all other such expressions — it appears by way of the plain meaning of Scripture that this tree had a natural property to sweeten water, this being its uniqueness, and He taught it to Moses. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> that the tree was [naturally] bitter, but that this was a miracle within a miracle, [i.e., that He healed the bitter waters with something which was bitter], just as the salt which Elisha cast into the waters.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 2:21. “Now even if you put salt into good water, it immediately spoils. Here, Elisha put a thing that spoils [salt] into the waters that had already been spoiled, in order to perform a miracle, [i.e., to heal the waters], therewith” (Mechilta).</i> Now if so,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., if, as this interpretation has it, the sweetening power of that tree was not a natural property thereof, the question again arises, why does Scripture say <i>vayoreihu</i> which indicates instruction? Ramban proceeds to remove this difficulty.</i> the word <i>‘vayoreihu’ (and He instructed him)</i> indicates that the tree was not found in that place, and the Holy One, blessed be He, taught him where it was to be found, or perhaps He made it available to him by a miracle. I found further in the Yelamdeinu:<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma, <i>Beshalach</i> 24. For the name Yelamdeinu, see above in <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 196.</i> “See what is written there: <i>Vayoreihu hashem eitz</i>. It does not say <i>vayar’eihu</i> (and He showed him) but <i>vayoreihu</i>, which means that He taught him His way.” That is to say, He instructed him and taught him the way of the Holy One, blessed be He, i.e., that He sweetens the bitter with the bitter.

Verse 26

IF ‘SHAMO’A TISHMA’ TO THE VOICE OF THE ETERNAL THY G-D. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that “[<i>shamo’a tishma</i> here] means ‘to understand’<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Now ordinarily, <i>shamo’a tishma</i> would mean “surely listen” or “diligently hearken,” but wherever this expression is followed by the letter <i>lamed</i> — as in this case, [<i>shamo’a tishma l’kol</i>] — or a <i>beth</i>, it means ‘understanding.’ This is why Ibn Ezra explained it here to mean “if you will have a full understanding of His commandments.”</i> the purport of that which He has commanded you to do. <i>And thou wilt do that which is right in His eyes</i> — this implies the positive commandments — <i>and wilt give ear to His commandments</i> — this implies the negative commandments.” [Thus the language of Ibn Ezra.] And in the Mechilta, the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>And thou wilt do that which is right in His eyes</i>, this means in business dealings. This teaches us that if a person is honest in his business dealings, and the spirit of his fellow creatures finds pleasure in him, it is accounted to him as though he had fulfilled the entire Torah.”<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">This is based upon the following phrases, <i>and thou wilt give ear to His commandments, and keep all His statutes</i>. The sense thereof is thus: “If you will do that which is right in G-d’s eyes, meaning if you will be honest in your business dealings, it will be accounted to you as though you had given ear, etc.”</i> I will further explain this when I come to the verse <i>‘And thou shalt do that which is upright and good,’</i> if the good G-d will show me goodness.<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban Deuteronomy 6:18.</i>
I WILL PUT NONE OF THE DISEASES UPON THEE, WHICH I HAVE PUT UPON THE EGYPTIANS; FOR I AM THE ETERNAL THAT HEALETH THEE. Rashi wrote: “<i>I will put none of the diseases upon thee</i>, and if I do place them [because you will not hearken to My voice], they will be as though they had not been placed, <i>for I am the Eternal that healeth thee</i>. This is the homiletic exposition. But according to the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse is to be understood in the sense of a person who says, ‘I am the physician who warns you not to eat certain things which might bring a man back to his state of disease.’” Thus far the language of Rashi.<br>But according to the plain meaning of Scripture, <i>rophecha</i> is not an adjective, [or more precisely, a noun-adjective, as Rashi would have it, meaning “Thy physician Who teaches thee how disease should not befall thee.” Instead, the meaning of the verse is “that I am the One Who heals thee.”] Besides, it is not customary that a master should assure his servants that “if you will do all my will and desire, I will not slay you with sore diseases.” None of the Divine assurances of the Torah are expressed in that way! Rather, the verse here constitutes an admonition by which He warned them not to be among those that rebel against Him as the Egyptians had been. By hearkening to His voice, they will be saved from all sickness, since that sickness deservedly comes upon all those who rebel against His will, even as it befell the Egyptians when they did not hearken to Him. This is similar to that which He said that He will put <i>upon thee all the diseases of Egypt which thou wast in dread of, and they shall cleave unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:60.</i> And He further said, <i>For I am the Eternal that healeth thee</i>. This constitutes a promise “that I will remove from you sickness that comes in the natural course of events, even as I healed the waters [at Marah].”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that this sign, [i.e., making the bitter waters sweet], which was the first one done for them in the wilderness, was in contrast to the first plague that came upon the Egyptians. The waters of the [Nile] river were sweet and He changed them to be of evil effect, while these waters of Marah were bitter and He healed them. Thus it was shown that G-d does things which are contrary to each other, and therefore you should fear Him and not rebel against Him so that He should not afflict you as He did [afflict] them. You should love Him for He will bestow goodness upon you, even as He healed the waters for you. [Thus far Ibn Ezra’s comment.]<br>Now on the matter of Scripture making use here of two expressions, saying, “His commandments, His statutes,” and concluding, <i>I will put none of the diseases upon thee, for I am the Eternal</i>, [thus using the third-person and first-person pronouns in the same verse], I have already <i>written you three times</i><sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 22:20, according to Jonathan ben Uziel’s translation. Ramban uses the expression here in a figurative sense, meaning: “I have already elucidated this matter in other places.” See Vol. I, pp. 260-261. See also further, 24:2.</i> on the explanation thereof. [Here] it can be understood from the word <i>‘l’kol’ (to the voice)</i> and the word <i>‘ani’ (I)</i>, which convey the thought that if we shall listen to the voice of our G-d to keep G-d’s commandments and His statutes, the Glorious Name will be our healer. It is on the basis [of the verse] that the Sages instituted [the formula of] benedictions [which contain two different pronouns, thus: “Blessed art <i>Thou</i> O Eternal, our G-d, King of the universe,] Who hast sanctified us with <i>His</i> commandments and hast commanded us.” The benedictions contain an expression of acknowledgment of G-d’s Sovereignty, [saying as we do, “our G-d, King of the universe”], and the commandments have been given to us <i>from everlasting even to everlasting</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 16:36.</i> The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand.<br>And I will enlighten you [on this matter]. All benedictions which contain an expression of His Sovereignty are so formulated that they show respect to the Sovereign of the universe, Who has sanctified us [by His commandments] and Who has done [a certain deed] for us. But where a benediction follows another one, in which case the Sovereignty of G-d is not mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Such is an established rule in the prayers. The opening benediction starts: <i>Baruch atah Hashem Elokeinu melech ha’olam (Blessed art Thou, O Eternal, King of the universe…)</i>, the Sovereignty of G-d thus being acknowledged in the second person, i.e., as the One directly addressed. But the benediction concludes with a reference to that Sovereign in the third person, thus concluding, “Who has sanctified us by <i>His</i> commandments.” The following benedictions do not open with a reference to G-d’s Sovereignty, but instead continue throughout in the second person. For example, in the Grace after the meal, the first benediction begins: “Blessed art <i>Thou</i>, O Eternal our G-d, <i>King of the universe</i>, Who sustains the whole world with <i>His</i> goodness… <i>He giveth</i> food to all flesh….” The second benediction begins: “We thank <i>Thee</i>, O Eternal our G-d, for the goodly and ample land of our desire which <i>Thou</i> gavest….” It should be noted that this rule applies only where a number of benedictions relate to one unit of prayer, such as the Grace after the Meal, or the Morning <i>Sh’ma</i>, the Evening <i>Sh’ma</i>, etc. Where the benedictions consist of short unrelated statements, such as the blessings of thanksgiving with which the Morning Service begins, each benediction contains an expression of G-d as the Sovereign of the universe.</i> it is formulated in the second-person, such as [the benedictions beginning]: “Thou art Mighty,” “Thou art Holy,”<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">These are the second and third benedictions of the <i>Sh’moneh Esreh</i> [literally: the “Eighteen” Blessings — the central prayer around which the regular daily services are built]. They do not begin with a reference to G-d’s Sovereignty, and therefore are formulated in the second person: “<i>Thou</i> art Mighty;” “<i>Thou</i> art Holy.” It should be noted that in the first benediction of the <i>Sh’moneh Esreh</i>, although there is no reference to G-d as the Sovereign of the universe, the expression “G-d of Abraham” is deemed equivalent to “King of the universe,” since Abraham was the first to acknowledge His Sovereignty over the whole universe. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 361.</i> and so all the others. The prayer of <i>Aleinu l’shabei’ach</i> [“It is for us to praise the Lord of all things,” a prayer which begins the three special sections of the New Year Additional Service], was designated in the third-person [even though it is not preceded by a benediction in which G-d’s Sovereignty is mentioned], because we mention therein, “And we bend the knee and bow low and offer thanks before the Supreme King of kings.”<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">When one stands in His very presence, it is not proper to address prayer to Him in the second person. Hence the <i>Aleinu</i> prayer is designated in the third person. (Ricanti). See my Hebrew commentary, p. 361.</i> Understand this.

Verse 27

AND THERE WERE TWELVE SPRINGS OF WATER, AND THREE SCORE AND TEN PALM TREES. It is not such a significant matter that seventy palm trees are found in a certain place. In the lowlands, a thousand and more palm trees can be found in one location, and springs of abundant water <i>are springing forth in valleys and hills</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:7.</i> and Scripture does not mention them at all! [Why then are these springs and palm trees singled out here?]<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that Scripture narrates that they came to a good place which was unlike Marah. In Elim, there were many springs, and the waters were sweet and good, since palm trees cannot thrive in soil where the waters are bitter. It is for this reason that Scripture says here <i>and they encamped there</i>, because on account of it, they stayed there for more days than in the other places they passed through. In the section of <i>Eileh Mas’ei</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:1-49. A detailed listing is given there of all the places through which Israel passed on the way from Egypt to the Promised Land.</i> however, Scripture does not relate anything about Marah, and yet it states, <i>And they journeyed from Marah, and came unto Elim; and in Elim were twelve springs of water, and three score and ten palm trees, and they encamped there</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9. Accordingly Ibn Ezra’s explanation that the springs and palm trees of Elim were mentioned here in order to contrast with Marah, where the waters were bitter, cannot be correct, because there in <i>Eileh Mas’ei</i>, Scripture states nothing about Marah and yet mentions the same about Elim as here.</i> and a description of a place at such length is not found there about any of the places they traversed!<br>Now Rashi wrote: “<i>Twelve springs of water</i>, a number corresponding to the twelve tribes of Israel, were ready for them. <i>And seventy palm trees</i> — these corresponded to the seventy elders.” But I do not know the nature of this preparation, i.e., whether it was done for them by a miracle just for that time. I have however, seen here in the Mechilta: “Rabbi Eleazar of Modaim said: ‘On the very day that the Holy One, blessed be He, created His world, He created twelve springs corresponding to the twelve tribes of Israel, and seventy palm trees corresponding to the seventy elders.’” Scripture thus tells that each tribe encamped beside his spring and the elders sat in their shade praising G-d for them, because He had prepared for them [such a restful place] in a land of drought. Our Rabbis have yet another explanation in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 161. Another name for this Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah is Sefer Habahir (Book of the Bright Light). It is one of the oldest books of the Cabala. See I. Weinstock, B’maglei Haniglah V’hanistar, pp. 15-20, on the origin of the names.</i> on this verse, which is wonderful in our eyes.<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 361-2, for further elucidation on this mystic matter.</i>

Chapter 16



Verse 1

AND THEY TOOK THEIR JOURNEY FROM ELIM, AND ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL CAME UNTO THE WILDERNESS OF SIN. Scripture speaks briefly here, for when they journeyed from Elim, <i>they pitched by the Red Sea, and they journeyed from the Red Sea, and they pitched in the wilderness of Sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:10-11.</i> since this great wilderness extended from Elim to Sinai. Thus, when they travelled from Elim, they camped beside the Red Sea in that wilderness. Then they journeyed from the edge of the sea and entered into the midst of the wilderness, making the stages of Dophkah and Alush,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 12-13. See Ramban further at beginning of <i>Seder Yithro</i> (Note 25) for how this explanation affects a major problem in Torah exegesis as to when Jethro came, i.e., before or after the Giving of the Torah.</i> and then <i>they journeyed from Alush</i>, which is in the wilderness of Sinai, <i>and they pitched in Rephidim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i><br>In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 25:5.</i> the manna began falling in Alush. When the Israelites saw that they were journeying and camping in the wilderness — in Dophkah and Alush — and had not come out of it, they became frightened and began murmuring. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And they murmured… in the wilderness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> for they had not murmured when they came there but only after they were there in the wilderness [for an extended period of time].
THE WILDERNESS OF SIN WHICH IS BETWEEN ELIM AND SINAI. The reason for this [geographic description] is to distinguish between this wilderness of Sin and the other wilderness, Tzin, written with the letter <i>tzade</i>, where the Israelites came in the fortieth year [of their stay in the wilderness] <i>and Miriam died there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:1.</i> This is why Scripture mentions there, <i>And they pitched in the wilderness of Tzin — the same is Kadesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33:36.</i> in order to differentiate it [from the wilderness of Sin mentioned here].

Verse 2

AND THE WHOLE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL MURMURED AGAINST MOSES. Scripture should have first narrated the nature of the complaint just as it did in Marah<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Above 15:23-24, <i>And when they came to Marah, they could not drink of the waters of Marah, for they were bitter…. And the people murmured against Moses</i>.</i> and Rephidim,<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 17:1-2. <i>And they encamped in Rephidim, and there was no water for the people to drink. And the people strove with Moses</i>.</i> and at all other complaints — and stated here first: “and there was no flesh to eat, nor bread for them to the full, and the people were famished for bread.” Now Rashi explained that the reason Scripture specifically mentions [that the date of their arrival in the wilderness of Sin] was <i>on the fifteenth day of the second month</i><sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> is in order “to make this encampment unique. On that day, there came to an end the provision which the Israelites took along with them from Egypt, and they now needed the manna. It thus informs you that they ate sixty-one meals<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">The manna first came down on the sixteenth day of Iyar, the second month (see Verse 4), thirty-one days after the exodus. Since two meals are ordinarily eaten daily (see Verse 8), this period required sixty-two meals. The first meal, however, was taken in Egypt on the night of the fifteenth day of Nisan, thus leaving sixty-one meals, which were furnished by the provisions they brought out of Egypt.</i> of the remains of the dough [which they had baked in Egypt on the day of the exodus].”<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Above 12:39.</i> [Thus far the language of Rashi.] This is a tradition received by our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on Verse 1 here.</i> and the reason that Scripture did not [first] explain the nature of their complaint was that it had not elaborated on this miracle which was done for them secretively, [i.e., that the remains of the dough furnished sixty-one meals]. And it is as I have already written in <i>Seder Vayigash</i> concerning the reason [that Scripture is disposed to be silent on hidden miracles].<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 556-558.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that Scripture records the date <i>on the fifteenth day of the second month</i> in order to explain that a month’s time had already elapsed since their departure from Egypt. In the meantime, they consumed the bread they took out of Egypt as well as their cattle, since they were a great multitude of people. This was the reason for the murmuring.<br>In my opinion, the reason for their complaint is to be found in the Scriptural expression, <i>and they came… unto the wilderness of Sin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> When they came to that wilderness far away from Egypt, they began saying: “What shall we eat? What will this great wilderness into which we have come supply us with?” It may be that at first they had thought that after a few days they would come to the cities round about them. Now that a month had gone by and <i>they found no city of habitation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 107:4.</i> they said, “We will all die in the great wilderness into which we have come.” This then is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and against Aaron in the wilderness</i>, the murmuring being because of the wilderness. And so likewise the people said, <i>for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness, to put to death this whole assembly by famine</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> Thus they mentioned “the wilderness’ and “the assembly,” therein stating that a large assembly such as this will undoubtedly die of hunger in this great wilderness. The Holy One, blessed be He, hearkened unto them, and He now began <i>to prepare a table</i> for them <i>in the wilderness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:19.</i> <i>until they came to a land inhabited</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 35.</i>

Verse 3



Verse 4

BEHOLD, I WILL ‘MAMTIR’ (CAUSE TO RAIN) BREAD FROM HEAVEN FOR YOU. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that because the manna came down like rain from heaven, He said <i>mamtir</i>, [which is derived from the root <i>matar</i> (rain)]. But we find: <i>‘yamteir’ (He will cause to rain) coals, fire and brimstone;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 11:6.</i> <i>And the Eternal ‘himtir’ (caused to rain) upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:24.</i> [Brimstone and fire do not come down like rain, and yet Scripture uses the word <i>matar</i> with reference to them!] Perhaps in these cases they accompanied the rain of which the term “coming down” may properly be used. Onkelos’ opinion is that <i>mamtir</i> just means “cause to bring down,” for he translated: “behold, I will cause to bring down.” [However, it has no connection here with rain, as Ibn Ezra would have it.]<br>It is possible that the word <i>mamtir</i> can be associated with the expression <i>‘kamatarah’ (as a mark) for the arrow</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 3:12.</i> although they are of different roots.<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">For the word <i>matarah</i> (target) is of the root <i>natar</i> (keep), since a target is kept in sight and watched. <i>Mamtir</i> however is of the root <i>matar</i> (rain). Yet, as Ramban concludes, they have a common association, as is explained in the text.</i> Scripture makes use of both terms when speaking of every form of “falling from above.” Thus it is called <i>matarah</i> (target) because they come down like arrows [on a target], and it says, <i>‘vayamteir’ (And He caused to rain) upon them flesh as the dust, and winged fowl as the sand of the seas</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:27.</i> It may be that [Scripture does not use the term <i>mamtir</i> for every form of “falling from above,” but only] for the fowl of heaven. [Therefore, the term, <i>vayamteir</i> in the above — mentioned verse refers only to the winged fowl] because they came down upon them as the rain.
BREAD. Because they made bread out of the manna — as it is written, <i>and they made cakes of it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:8.</i> — [Scripture calls it <i>lechem</i> (bread)], for every form of bread is called <i>lechem</i>, not just those of wheat and barley. It says <i>cause to rain bread</i> [although it did not come down in the form of bread, for the meaning thereof is] that He is causing it to come down for them to make it into bread. Similarly: <i>As for the earth, out of it cometh bread</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Job 28:5.</i> [meaning: “out of it cometh the wheat from which bread is made”]. So also: <i>To bring forth bread out of the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:14.</i> which means that He brings forth the wheat from which people make bread. And some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra, and R’dak in his Sefer Hashorashim, under the root <i>lechem</i>.</i> interpret: <i>Behold, I will cause to rain bread</i>, meaning food. Similarly: <i>‘lechem’ of the offering;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 3:16.</i> <i>For he offereth the ‘lechem’ of thy G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:8.</i> <i>When thou sittest ‘lilchom’ with a ruler</i><sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:1.</i> — all are expressions of food.<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Thus is the opinion of Ibn Ezra and R’dak (see Note 303). But, continues Ramban, the correct interpretation is, etc.</i> The correct interpretation is that <i>lilchom</i><sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 23:1.</i> means “to eat bread,” and <i>‘lechem’ of thy G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:8.</i> is a euphemism, meaning that it is “the food” for G-d even as bread is for man, for we find it said, <i>Man doth not live by bread only</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:3.</i>
THAT I MAY TRY THEM, WHETHER THEY WILL WALK IN MY LAW OR NOT. “I.e., whether they will observe the commandments associated with it, such as [the laws] that they should not leave [a remainder] of it until the morning<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 19.</i> and that they should not go out on the Sabbath to collect it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> Thus the language of Rashi.<br>But this is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s objection seems to be that the word <i>l’ma’an</i> (“that” or “for the sake of”) — <i>‘that’ I may try them</i> — expresses causation in itself, namely, that the manna as such will be their trial, as will be explained, and not the precepts associated with it, as Rashi explained.</i> Rather, the intent [of the trial mentioned here] is as He said, <i>Who fed thee in the wilderness with manna, which thy fathers knew not; that He might afflict thee, and that He might try thee, to do thee good at thy latter end</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:16.</i> [The manna itself] was a trial to them, since they had no food in the wilderness and were without recourse to any sustenance except the manna, which they knew not from before and had never heard of from their fathers. Each day’s quantity came down on its day, and they were eagerly desirous for it. Yet with all this, they hearkened to walk after G-d to a place of no food. And so indeed He said to them again, <i>And thou shalt remember all the way in which the Eternal thy G-d hath led thee these forty years in the wilderness, that He might afflict thee, to try thee, to know what was in thy heart, whether thou wouldest keep His commandments, or no</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> He could have led them by way of <i>the cities that were round about them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:5.</i> Instead, He led them <i>through the wilderness wherein were serpents, fiery serpents, and scorpions</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:15.</i> and each day’s quantity of food would come to them only from heaven in order to try them and to do them good at the end so that they would believe in Him forever. I have already explained the matter of “trial” in the commentary on the verse, <i>And G-d tried Abraham</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:1 (Vol. I, p. 275).</i><br>The Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has written in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">III, 24. Ramban is following Al Charizi’s translation of the Moreh Nebuchim. In Ibn Tibbon’s translation, (as rendered by Friedlander, III, p. 114): “<i>That I may prove them whether they will walk in My law or not;</i> i.e., let every one who desires try and see whether it is useful and sufficient to devote himself to the service of G-d.”</i> [on the verse before us, <i>That I may try them, whether they will walk in My law or not</i>, that it means] that “everyone capable of knowledge should know and determine whether there is usefulness in the service of G-d, and whether there is adequate satisfaction in it or not.” But if so, it would have been proper for Him to say, “that <i>He</i> may try them to know!”<br>Now Scripture mentions here only the matter of manna, which was “the bread” which He caused to rain upon them, [and it does not refer to the flesh which He gave them]. However, from that which Moses told them, <i>This shall be, when the Eternal shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 8.</i> we know that everything was told to him. It is only that when a subject is mentioned twice, Scripture shortens it in the report of the command or the narrative, as I have mentioned to you many times.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 10:2 and 11:1.</i> At times, it omits one — [the command or the narrative] — altogether, such a case being the verse written in this section: <i>This is the thing which the Eternal hath commanded: Let an omerful of it</i> [the manna] <i>be kept throughout your generations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 32.</i> and the command [of G-d to Moses] is not recorded at all. This is also the case in many places. But in the opinion of those scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 303.</i> who say that <i>lechem</i> here means “all food,” it is possible that by saying, <i>Behold, I will cause to rain ‘lechem,’</i> the meaning refers to both the manna and to the quail, i.e., that He would fulfill their request for bread and flesh. Moses explained that the flesh would be [available] to eat in the evening, and the bread would be [available] in the morning to the full, as is the customary way.

Verse 5



Verse 6

AT EVEN, THEN YE SHALL KNOW THAT THE ETERNAL HATH BROUGHT YOU OUT FROM THE LAND OF EGYPT. “And it is not we. [i.e., Moses and Aaron] who have taken you out from there, as you have said, <i>for ye have brought us forth</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3.</i> 7. AND IN THE MORNING, THEN YE SHALL SEE THE GLORY OF THE ETERNAL. This does not refer to G-d’s Glory that appeared in the cloud, [mentioned further in Verse 10], for that occurred [later] in the day when Aaron spoke to them, <i>and they looked toward the wilderness and, behold, the Glory of the Eternal appeared in the cloud</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 10.</i> “But,” commented Rashi, “thus did Moses say to them: <i>At even, then ye shall know</i> that His hand has the power to give you your desire, and He will give you flesh. He will not, however, give it to you with ‘a bright countenance,’ since you were improper in asking for it, [inasmuch as one can exist without meat]. Besides, you asked for it out of a full stomach, [i.e., while still having cattle which you took along with you from Egypt]. But as regards the bread for which you properly asked out of necessity, when it falls in the morning, you will see the Glory of His countenance, as He will bring it down for you in a manner indicative of love, i.e., in the morning, while there is yet time to prepare it.”<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">In the printed Rashi text, it concludes: “and there shall be dew above it and dew below it as though it were packed in a chest.” The quail, on the other hand, came down <i>at even</i> (Verse 13) when there was not much time to prepare it. It was thus given, as the Mechilta — quoted by Ramban — said further on, <i>b’panim chasheichoth</i> (with a ‘dark countenance’), or as Rashi puts it, <i>lo b’panim me’iroth</i> (not with a ‘bright countenance’).</i><br>But it is not correct to interpret the expression, <i>and in the morning, then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i> as applying to the gift of the manna because He gave it to them early in the morning. What <i>Glory of the Eternal</i> is made manifest in this? Moreover, how does it logically connect with the phrase following it, <i>for that He hath heard your murmurings?</i> And this Midrash of our Rabbis, [which Rashi mentions, i.e., that there was a difference in the ways the manna and the quail were given to them], is not like a comment upon the expression, <i>then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>. Instead, the Rabbis said it [as an explanation of the fact] that He apportioned their sustenance twice a day and did not distribute all of it in the morning. Thus the Rabbis said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on Verse 8.</i> “<i>And Moses said: ‘This shall be, when the Eternal shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full.’</i> From here, you learn that He gave them the quail with ‘a dark countenance.’ The manna, however, which they were justified in requesting, He gave them with ‘a bright countenance.’” That is to say, in the morning.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the expression, <i>and in the morning</i>, etc., [beginning in Verse 7], is a continuation of the previous verse. [It constitutes Moses’ answer to] what the Israelites had said, <i>for ye have brought us forth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> from Egypt. Moses replied: “G-d will now show two signs for you so that you may know that it was He Who brought you out from there. One, [the quail] will come in the evening of this day, and the other, [the manna] will come tomorrow in the morning.” And, [continued Ibn Ezra], it would have been proper for Scripture to say: “At even, and in the morning, then ye shall know that the Eternal hath brought you out from the land of Egypt.” The expression <i>in the morning</i> is not connected with <i>then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>, since they saw the Glory [later] on that day [and not in the following morning].<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">To grasp the boldness of Ibn Ezra’s explanation, one must note the following sequence of language in the two verses: (6) <i>And Moses and Aaron said… At even, then ye shall know that the Eternal hath brought you out from the land of Egypt</i>. (7) <i>And in the morning, then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>. According to Ibn Ezra’s interpretation, the expression of Verse 7, <i>and in the morning</i>, is to be understood together with <i>at even</i> (of Verse 6), thus: “at even and in the morning, then ye shall know that the Eternal hath brought you out from the land of Egypt.” The phrase, <i>and in the morning</i>, cannot be connected with <i>then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>, for as narrated in Verses 9-10, the Glory of the Eternal appeared that very same day, and not in the following morning. Ramban will further refute this explanation of Ibn Ezra on the basis of the fact that after all, the verses are not written in the way Ibn Ezra would transpose them. His own exposition will then follow.</i> But this interpretation too does not appear to be correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">See end of above Note.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the wonder inherent in the manna was extremely great, whereas He brought the quail in from the sea by a wind which came from Him.<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:31.</i> The manna, however, was created for them now; [it was] a new creation in heaven, similar to the process of [the original] Creation. This is the intent of what the Rabbis have said with respect to the manna, i.e., that it was created on the sixth day of creation between sundown and nightfall.<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 5:6.</i> This is why Scripture said: “By the sign He will perform for you on the coming night, you will know that He brought you out from the land of Egypt, since He prepared <i>a table in the wilderness</i> for you.<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 78:19.</i> But by the great wonder He will do for you in the morning, you will see the Glory of His kingdom, <i>for what god is there in heaven or on earth that can do according to</i> His <i>works and according to</i> His <i>mighty acts?</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:24.</i> By the great and marvellous things that G-d does, He shows His Glory, similar to that which is written, <i>I will gather all nations, and all tongues, and they shall come, and shall see My Glory</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 66:18.</i> It is further written [there], <i>and they shall declare My Glory</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> and there are many other verses similar to this effect. So also is the opinion of Onkelos who rendered [the verse here]: “and you will <i>see</i> the Glory of G-d.” He did not translate it, “and [the Glory of G-d] will be made manifest.”<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Had Onkelos translated “and the Glory of G-d will be made manifest,” it would have comprised Onkelos’ effort to remove any implication of G-d’s corporeality. But now that he translated, “and you will <i>see</i> the Glory of G-d,” his reference is to the great and wonderful deed G-d will do for them through the manna.</i><br>Know that the subject of the manna involves a great matter.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">“Matter.” In the Ricanti quoting Ramban: “secret.”</i> Our rabbis have alluded to it in Tractate Yoma:<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 75b.</i> “<i>Man did eat bread of ‘abirim’ (the mighty)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:25. A reference to the manna which the Israelites ate in the wilderness. The question arises about the meaning of the word <i>abirim</i>.</i> i.e., bread which the ministering angels eat! These are the words of Rabbi Akiba. Rabbi Yishmael said to him, ‘You have made a mistake. Do the ministering angels indeed eat bread? Has it not been said [by Moses], <i>I did neither eat bread nor drink water?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:9.</i> Rather, <i>the bread of ‘abirim’</i> means bread which was absorbed in the <i>eivarim</i> (limbs).’”<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 76, on the fruits of the Garden of Eden.</i><br>The purport of Rabbi Akiba’s words is that the existence of the ministering angels is sustained by the Divine Glory. And so the Rabbis interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 32:4.</i> “<i>And Thou ‘m’chayeh’ (preservest) them all</i><sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:6.</i> [means] He gives food (<i>‘michyah’</i>) to you all.” It is with reference to this that it is said, <i>And the light is sweet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 11:7.</i> since through the Light, they perceive good discernment. Now the manna was a product of that Higher Light which became tangible by the will of its Creator, blessed be He, and thus [according to Rabbi Akiba], both the people who ate the manna and the ministering angels were sustained by the same substance. But Rabbi Yishmael criticized him, since the existence of the ministering angels is not dependent upon something tangible evolving from the Light. Their existence is by means of the Higher Light itself.<br>It was for this reason, [i.e., the heavenly origin of the manna], that the Israelites found in the manna every flavor they desired. The rational power of the soul causes it to cleave to the higher worlds, thus finding restful life and obtaining His favor.<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 8:35.</i><br>And thus the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on Verse 25: <i>Today ye shall not find it in the field</i>. This teaching is that of Rabbi Eleazar Chisma. Ramban will later refer to it by name.</i> “Today, [i.e., in this world], you will not find it, but you will find it in the World to Come.” This text [of the Mechilta] can support two explanations. We may say that among those [inheriting eternal life] in the World to Come,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban clearly uses the concept of <i>olam haba</i> (the World to Come) as referring to the life after the resurrection. It is the life to be in the far hereafter, as distinguished from the <i>olam haneshamoth</i> (the World of the Souls), which is the life in the hereafter immediately following the demise of the body. In <i>olam haba</i>, body and soul will be reunited, and the manner of how the body will sustain itself is here alluded to by Ramban. See also Note 12 in <i>Seder Va’eira</i>. An exhaustive discussion of this whole subject is found in Ramban’s Torath Ha’adam, (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. 2, pp. 283-311).</i> there will be some who have not achieved that high status of sustaining themselves steadily by the Divine Glory. Their existence will be made possible by something tangible evolving from that Glory, like the status of the generation of the wilderness who attained [the beholding of] the Divine Glory at the Red Sea, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta 15:2.</i> “A maidservant saw at the sea what the prophet Ezekiel<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to Ezekiel, Chapter 1. In our Mechilta it states, “Isaiah and Ezekiel.” See Isaiah 6:1-6. Rashi (above. 15:2) just has: “prophets.”</i> never saw.” From that time onward, their souls were elevated to be able to exist by the product [of the Divine Glory], which was the manna.<br>A more correct interpretation is that in the word <i>today</i> — [Verse 25: <i>‘Today’ ye shall not find it in the field</i>] — Scripture is alluding according to the words of Rabbi Eleazar Chisma,<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 345.</i> that those [inheriting eternal life in] the World to Come<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban clearly uses the concept of <i>olam haba</i> (the World to Come) as referring to the life after the resurrection. It is the life to be in the far hereafter, as distinguished from the <i>olam haneshamoth</i> (the World of the Souls), which is the life in the hereafter immediately following the demise of the body. In <i>olam haba</i>, body and soul will be reunited, and the manner of how the body will sustain itself is here alluded to by Ramban. See also Note 12 in <i>Seder Va’eira</i>. An exhaustive discussion of this whole subject is found in Ramban’s Torath Ha’adam, (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. 2, pp. 283-311).</i> will exist by the substance of the manna which is the Higher Glory, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 17a.</i> “[In the World to Come] there will be neither eating nor drinking. Rather, the righteous [of the World to Come] will sit with their crowns on their heads and enjoy the Divine Glory.” [This means] that those [inheriting] the World to Come will exist by their enjoyment of the Divine Glory, which will cleave to the crowns upon their heads. “The crown” is the attribute so named by Scripture when it says, <i>In that day shall the Eternal of hosts be for a crown of Glory</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 28:5.</i> And it is with reference to it that it is said, <i>Even upon the crown wherewith his mother hath crowned him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:11.</i> Thus [the verses] allude to the manner in which the righteous inheriting the World to Come will be sustained, the hint being to the substance of the manna.<br>Now Scripture says, <i>And He commanded the skies above, and opened the doors of heaven; and He caused manna to rain upon them for food, and gave them of the corn of heaven. Man did eat the bread of the mighty</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:23-25.</i> and it further says, <i>And He gave them in plenty the bread of heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 105:40.</i> From this, it appears that this “corn” is in heaven, and He caused it to come down for them by opening its doors. The intent thereof is, as I have explained, that the [Higher] Light was made tangible [and assumed the form of the manna], for it is of the Higher Light that Scripture speaks in this language, [such as]: <i>the heavens were opened, and I saw visions of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:1.</i> It may be that the manna was already existing in the heavens [in the form in which it came down], just as the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 5:6.</i> that it was created on the sixth day of creation between sundown and nightfall.

Verse 7

AND WHAT ARE WE, THAT YE MURMUR AGAINST US. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it as meaning: “And what power to act is there in our hands? We have only carried out what we have been commanded.” But this is not so. Rather, the sense of the verse here is similar to: <i>What is man, that Thou art mindful of him?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 8:5.</i> <i>Eternal, what is man that Thou takest knowledge of him?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 144:3.</i> <i>For how little is he</i> [man] <i>to be accounted!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:22.</i> And this [verse here] is an expression of humility. “For what are we that you should attribute us with bringing you out from the land of Egypt? Behold we are nothing, and our work is vanity.<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 41:24.</i> And <i>your murmurings are not against us, but against the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> It is He Who has brought you out from the land of Egypt, not we.” And in the Mechilta we find.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “[They said to them]: ‘Are we so distinguished that you arise and murmur against us?’”<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">This bears out Ramban’s interpretation that the expression, <i>and what are we?</i> is one of humility, as explained.</i>

Verse 8

AND MOSES SAID: THIS SHALL BE, WHEN THE ETERNAL SHALL GIVE YOU IN THE EVENING FLESH. Moses is explaining his first statement, [recorded above in Verses 6-7]: <i>When the Eternal shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, then ye shall know that the Eternal hath brought you out from the land of Egypt;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 6.</i> and when <i>He shall give you in the morning bread to the full, then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i>

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

I HAVE HEARD THE MURMURINGS OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. SPEAK UNTO THEM, SAYING: AT DUSK YE SHALL EAT FLESH. This communication [<i>at dusk ye shall eat</i>, etc.], had already been conveyed by Moses to Israel,<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i> but it is repeated here only because of that which He said <i>I have heard the murmurings of the children of Israel</i>. At first, He had said, <i>Behold, I will cause to rain bread from heaven to you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> He would willingly do it for them as an act of kindness or because of their merits. But now He said that [their murmuring] is accounted to them as sin, and yet because of the very nature of the murmuring, He will do such things for them so that they might know thereby <i>that I am the Eternal your G-d</i>. Until now <i>ye do not believe the Eternal your G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:32.</i> this is why you murmur against His prophets.<br>It is possible that at first He did not promise them the manna for all the time that they would be in the wilderness. Thus they thought that perhaps it would be for one day or two, as long as they stayed in that place, and that when they would leave it, they would come to a place of food. But now He said to them, “<i>At dusk ye shall eat flesh</i> always, <i>and in</i> every <i>morning ye shall be filled with bread</i> as long as you will be in the wilderness.” And so also is the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Arakhin 15 b, Tosafoth. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 366.</i> that the quail were with them from that day on, just like the manna. It is logically so, for they expressed discontent about the two things — [flesh and bread]<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3: … <i>when we sat by the flesh-pots, when we did eat bread to the full</i>.</i> — and He hearkened to their murmurings on both matters, <i>and He gave them that which they craved</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:29.</i> What would He give them, and what more,<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 120:3.</i> if He supplied them with meat for only one day or two?<br>The reason that the chapter [of the Torah] speaks at length about the matter of the manna is that everything about it was of a wondrous nature, whereas with reference to the matter of the quail, it just writes briefly, <i>And it came to pass at even, that the quail came up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> because it came in a natural way.<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, Verse 6, beginning with: “The correct interpretation.”</i> [Although the quail were a daily occurrence], the subject of the second [incident of] quail at Kibroth-hata’avah<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:31-34.</i> [is singled out for mention in Scripture] because right now [in the wilderness of Sin], they did not receive of them to the full, just as He always says here, <i>flesh to eat, and bread to the full</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8. And also in Verse 12 here: <i>At dusk ye shall eat flesh, and in the morning ye shall be filled with bread</i>. This clearly indicates that bread they had to the full, but not flesh.</i><br>It is possible that only the adults gathered the quail — or it may be that they were marked by chance for the pious ones — while the young craved and hungered for them, since Scripture does not relate concerning the quail, “and they gathered some more, some less,” as it does concerning the manna.<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> It is for this reason that Scripture says there [in the narrative of the second quail]: <i>And the mixed multitude that was among them fell a lusting</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:4.</i> and it further says, <i>and the children of Israel also wept on their part</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:4.</i> meaning that some of the children of Israel were also weeping for it, but not all. He then gave them in great quantity, as it says, <i>He that gathered least gathered ten heaps</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32.</i> and out of that abundance, they ate for a month’s time<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> and then the quail reverted to their first state.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the whole affair with the quail happened only at intervals, but since the manna was their staple food, they always had it, for their chief murmuring concerned it, as it is written, <i>for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness, to put to death this whole assembly by famine</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

DAK’ (A FINE) ‘MECHUSPAS’ (PEELED THING). In the opinion of Onkelos, [who translated the word <i>mechuspas</i> as meaning “peeled,” the word] is associated with the expressions: <i>‘machsoph’ (streaks making bare) the white;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 30:37.</i> <i>‘chasaph hashem’ (the Eternal hath made bare) His holy arm</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 52:10.</i> The letter <i>sin</i> [in the words <i>machsoph</i> and <i>chasaph</i>] is interchanged for the letter <i>samach</i> [in the word <i>mechuspas</i>], and the second root-letter of the verb [<i>chasaph</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">“The second root-letter of the verb.” Literally: “the <i>ayin</i> of the verb.” Following the theory of Dunash ben Labrat, the great Hebrew grammarian of the tenth century, we call the three letters of the root of any verb by the names of the three letters of the Hebrew <i>‘po’al’</i> (verb) [which is spelled <i>pei, ayin</i> and <i>lamed</i>]. Thus the first letter of <i>any</i> verb is called the <i>pei</i> of the verb, the second is called the <i>ayin</i>, the third is called the <i>lamed</i>. In the verb <i>chasaph</i> before us, the second root-letter is the <i>sin</i> or its interchange, the <i>samach</i>, as explained in the text. In the word <i>mechuspas</i>, the <i>samach</i> appears twice. This then is the meaning of Ramban’s saying, “and the <i>ayin</i> (second letter) of the verb is doubled.”</i> is doubled, [thus making it <i>mechuspas</i>].
DAK’ (FINE) ‘KAK’PHOR’ (AS THE HOAR-FROST). <i>K’phor</i> is the covering [of minute ice-particles] upon the ground in cold weather. It is similar in usage to the expression, <i>He scattered ‘k’phor’ (hoar-frost) like ashes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:16.</i> Now Onkelos rendered [the Hebrew <i>dak kak’phor al ha’aretz</i>] into Aramaic thus: <i>da’adak k’gir kig’lida al ar’a</i>. On this, Rashi wrote [as an interpretation of Onkelos, that the word <i>gir</i> occurs in the expression], “<i>as stones of ‘gir,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 27:9. Translated: “chalkstones.”</i> which is a kind of black color. This is just as we say in connection with the covering of the blood [of a slaughtered wild animal or fowl, which the Torah specified must be done with earth.<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:13.</i> The Rabbis enumerate amongst the kinds of earth that can be used]:<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 88b. See further my Hebrew commentary, p. 367, Note 7.</i> ‘<i>gir</i> (powdered chalk) and arsenic (or orpiment).’ [Onkelos’ Aramaic rendition <i>da’adak k’gir kig’lida al ar’a</i> thus means:] ‘thin [and brittle] like powdered chalk, and lying congealed as frost on the ground.’ And this is the meaning of the Hebrew <i>dak kak’phor:</i> spread out fine and connected like hoar-frost. <i>Dak</i> means that there was a thin incrustation on top. And that which Onkelos translated, <i>k’gir</i> (as powdered chalk), is an addition to the Hebrew text, there being no word corresponding to it in the verse.” [These are the words of Rashi.]<br>But all this is not correct. <i>Gir</i> [is not a kind of black color, as Rashi wrote, but instead it] is a white earth which sticks to stone, and when crushed, it is used as plaster upon walls. It is very white and is better for the plastering of walls than lime, [which does not have the admixture of that white earth]. And so it is written, <i>upon the ‘gira’ (plaster) of the wall of the king’s palace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 5:5.</i> This is why the manna which was white and spread out upon the earth could be associated with that crushed white earth.<br>Onkelos then translated the Hebrew word <i>k’phor</i> in two ways. First, he derived it from the expression, <i>and thou shalt pitch it within and without ‘bakopher’ (with pitch)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 5:14.</i> Hence, he said <i>k’gir</i> (as the white earth) with which [the stones] are fastened and covered. Then he derived it also from the expression, <i>He scattered ‘k’phor’ like ashes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:16.</i> which is the covering of minute ice needles which form in a cold atmosphere, just as he translated [the Hebrew] <i>‘v’kerach’ (and the frost) by night,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:40.</i> “<i>ug’lida</i> (and frost) came down upon me at night.”<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is not necessary to say, as Rashi did, that the Aramaic word <i>k’gir</i> in Onkelos’ translation has no corresponding word in the Hebrew text. According to Ramban, both Aramaic words, <i>k’gir</i> and <i>kig’lida</i> (“as powdered white earth” and “as frost”), are two renditions of the one Hebrew word <i>kak’phor</i>. Such was Onkelos’ style, to give two translations of one Hebrew word.</i> The word can be used in the plural [<i>g’lidin</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 152 a: <i>sacharuni g’lidin</i> (ices have sorrounded me), a metaphoric expression of a person describing that the hairs of his mustache and beard have turned gray (Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>)</i> while the singular is called <i>g’lid</i> (ice), just as we have been taught in the Mishnah in Mikvaoth:<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Mikvaoth 7:1.</i> “These are the things which only serve to fill up the immersion-pool [to its prescribed measure of forty <i>s’ah</i>] and do not render it invalid: snow, hail, hoar-frost, <i>v’hag’lid</i> (and ice).” And so indeed does Onkelos translate many Scriptural texts in two ways. But in carefully-edited texts of Targum Onkelos, it is written, <i>da’adak d’gir</i><sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">And not <i>k’gir</i>, as we have assumed the reading in Onkelos to be until now. The reading of <i>k’gir</i> had forced Ramban to interpret that Onkelos simultaneously used two different translations of the Hebrew word <i>kak’phor</i>, namely, “as powdered white earth” and “as frost,” as explained above. This is clearly a difficult position. But with this present reading in Onkelos — <i>d’gir</i>, which means a heap — the Aramaic text leads to one unified thought: the manna was piled up in heaps as ice upon the earth.</i> <i>kig’lida al ar’a</i>, and the meaning thereof is that the manna was piled up in heaps as ice upon the earth. This is the truth, for if [the word <i>k’gir</i> in the Targum] were of the root <i>gir</i> (powdered white earth or plaster), as we assumed at first], the Aramaic translation should have been: <i>k’gira d’g'lida</i> (as the powdered flakes of the ice), [and not, as we have it, <i>k’gira ‘kig’lida</i>], for such is the style of the Aramaic language.<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, since all readings in the Targum have <i>kig’lida</i> (“as” ice), and not <i>d’g'lida</i> (“of” the ice), it shows that the antecedent word is <i>d’gir</i> (a heap) and not <i>k’gir</i> (as powdered white earth). Thus the thought conveyed by the Targum is that the manna lay powdered in heaps as ice upon the ground.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20

AND IT BRED WORMS, AND IT STANK. “This is a verse that is to be transposed, because [the manna that was left over until the morning] must have first stunk and afterwards become wormy, just as it is said, <i>and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 24.</i> this being the way of all things that become wormy.” Thus Rashi’s language. Now if the manna had become wormy in a natural way, as is the way of all things that become wormy, Rashi’s statement would be correct. But since the manna became wormy in a miraculous way, it is possible that it bred worms first,<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">For had it given off a stench first, they would have sensed it at night, and they would have disposed of it. This was why it became wormy first, and Dathan and Abiram, who left it until the morning, contrary to Moses’ command, did not know it. In the morning it stank and it became known to all, and Moses was angry with them (Tur). The source of this reasoning is found in Shemoth Rabbah, mentioned further on in the text.</i> and there is thus no need for inverting] the verse. Moreover, the verse which states [concerning the manna which they retained for Sabbath morning], <i>and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 24.</i> proves that it was so, [i.e., that the manna left over by Dathan and Abiram bred worms first and then stank]. Had it not become wormy until it first stank, when Scripture says [concerning the manna left for the Sabbath], <i>and it did not stink</i>, it would thereby have already assured us that there was no worm therein. Why then should it repeat afterwards, <i>neither was there any worm therein?</i> If however, as the plain meaning of Scripture indicates, the manna that was left over until the morning by Dathan and Abiram became wormy first [in a supernatural way], it became necessary for Scripture to state that <i>this</i> manna [that was left over for the Sabbath] did not stink, nor did any worm come therein at all. Even things which become wormy in a natural way do not give off a stench unless they are warm and moist, but dry things only become wormy and do not give off an odor at all, just as wormy wood or fruits that become wormy when still growing or [immediately] afterwards. Thus Scripture relates that this manna [which Dathan and Abiram left over on a weekday, also stank [in the morning] by a miracle. And in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah we find that the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 25:14.</i> “Is there anything that first becomes wormy and then gives off a stench? It is only that the Holy One, blessed be He, wanting to expose the deeds [of Dathan and Abiram] to the people, therefore caused [the left-over manna] to give off no stench at night lest they throw it out. Instead, during the entire night, it formed rows upon rows of worms, <i>and</i> at once <i>Moses was wroth with them</i>.”

Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

BAKE THAT WHICH YE WILL BAKE. Rashi explained: “Whatever you wish to bake in the oven or boil in water, bake and boil today — all [that you require] for two days.” If so, the purport of the verse is as follows: “<i>That which you would bake</i> of the two omers you have, <i>bake</i> today, <i>and that which you would boil</i> of the two omers, boil now, <i>and all that remaineth</i> for you after eating to the full today, <i>lay up for you to be kept until the morning</i>.” In the morning [of the Sabbath-day], when the Israelites saw that it did not spoil, they came before Moses, since they did not want to eat the manna of yesterday even though Moses had permitted it to be kept until the morning. Then Moses permitted them to eat it on that Sabbath-day only “because it was for that purpose of which I said to keep it for a charge.” He further informed them of the reason of the commandment, for <i>today ye shall not find it in the field</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> since G-d does it so because <i>it is a holy Sabbath unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23 before us.</i> It is possible that by saying <i>and all that remaineth over</i>, He did not set any measure for that. Rather, they could eat at will on the sixth day, as the remainder would suffice for the Sabbath, because <i>it is the blessing of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:22.</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: “<i>That which you would bake</i> ordinarily — namely, the [daily] omer known to you — <i>bake</i> for your use today; <i>and all that remaineth</i>, namely, the second omer, <i>lay up for you to be kept until the morning</i>. At that time, Moses did not tell them what to do with the second omer. It was on the following morning [the Sabbath], that he told them, <i>eat that today</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> But if so, they ate the manna on the Sabbath raw, without baking it or seething it in pots and making cakes of it as it was their custom to do.<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:8.</i> The first interpretation, [that of Rashi], is more correct, and so is the opinion of Onkelos.<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos translated: “That which you intend baking, etc.” By adding the word <i>athidin</i> (intend), Onkelos intimated his understanding of the verse to be similar to that of Rashi: “that which you intend baking of the two omers, bake today, etc.” This is unlike the explanation of Ibn Ezra, who interpreted the verse as meaning: “that which you would bake ordinarily — [i.e., one omer] — bake today, and the other omer leave over till the morning,” thus resulting in their eating the omer on the Sabbath in an unprepared state.</i>

Chapter 17



Verse 1

AND ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED FROM THE WILDERNESS OF SIN, BY THEIR STAGES, ACCORDING TO THE COMMANDMENT OF THE ETERNAL, AND THEY ENCAMPED IN REPHIDIM. Scripture is stating that they journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, where they were encamped after they had set out from Elim,<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:1.</i> and covered various stages of their journey in accord with G-d’s command. Afterwards, they encamped in Rephidim. Scripture thus relates briefly here that when they first journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, they pitched in Dophkah, and afterwards in Alush, and from Alush they came to Rephidim.<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:12-14.</i> This is the meaning of the expression here, <i>by their stages</i>, since there were many stages by which they came from the wilderness of Sin to Rephidim, and they did not reach it on the first journey. Scripture, however, [omits all these various stages here] because its only concern is to explain their murmuring. At the beginning of their arrival in that wilderness [of Sin], they complained for bread, and now they quarreled [with Moses] over water, [as it is said], <i>and there was no water for the people to drink</i>. When they came to that place and did not find fountains of water, they at once quarreled with Moses. This is the meaning of the expression, <i>Wherefore the people did quarrel with Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> for the murmurings mentioned in places where Scripture says, <i>and they murmured</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Such as above, 16:2.</i> mean complaints, i.e., that they were declaring their grievances about their condition, saying, “What shall we do? What shall we eat, and what shall we drink?” But <i>vayarev</i> (and he quarreled) means that they did actually make quarrel with Moses, coming to him and saying, “Give us water, you and Aaron your brother, for you are responsible, our blood is upon you.” And Moses said to them, “<i>Why quarrel ye with me? Wherefore do ye try the Eternal?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> This quarrel is to test G-d, that is whether He can give you water.<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 78:30.</i> If you will hold your peace and let me alone and instead pray to Him, perhaps He will answer you.” And indeed, it was their intent to try [G-d], as Scripture says, <i>And the name of the place was called Massah</i> (Trying) <i>and Meribah</i> (Quarrel), <i>because of the quarrel of the children of Israel and because they tried the Eternal, saying: Is the Eternal among us, or not?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 7.</i> Then their anger against him relented,<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">See Judges 8:3.</i> and for a day or two, they were supplied by the waters in their vessels. But afterwards, <i>the people thirsted there for water, and the people murmured against Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> something like the complaints they made whenever they wanted something, saying, <i>Wherefore hast thou brought us up out of Egypt?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> When Moses saw that they thirsted for water, he prayed to G-d and recounted before Him his distress when they first quarreled with him.<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that there were two groups: one that quarreled [with Moses because they had no water to drink], and one [that had water which they brought from Alush, the place where they were encamped before coming to Rephidim,<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:14.</i> but] who tested G-d [to see if He would give them water]. The correct interpretation is as I have explained.

Verse 2



Verse 3

TO PUT US AND OUR CHILDREN AND OUR CATTLE TO DEATH WITH THIRST. In their complaint, they mentioned the cattle too, thus telling Moses that they need a lot of water and it is therefore necessary to take counsel on the whole matter. This is why it says at the second time [when the incident at the waters of Meribah is recorded], <i>and water came forth abundantly, and the congregation drank, and their cattle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:11. Now here it is not mentioned but it is self-understood that when the rock was turned into a pool of water, they drank and they watered their flocks (Ramban in Verse 5 further). In the instance of the waters of Meribah at Kadesh, it is mentioned on account of the mishap that resulted from the entire affair, as explained there; see also Ramban here in Verse 5 for another interpretation.</i> And our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “They made their cattle equal in importance to themselves. They said: ‘A man’s beast is as his life. If a man travels on the road and his beast is not with him, he suffers.’”<br>Now the reason they mentioned <i>us and our children</i> and did not say generally: “to put us to death with thirst” or “to put to death this whole assembly,” [an expression] which would have included men, women and the little ones, as they said in other places,<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Such as above, 16:3, <i>to put to death this whole assembly by famine</i>.</i> is that by mentioning the children to him, they emphasized their murmuring against him so that he should make haste in the matter, since the young ones could not suffer thirst at all and they would thus die before the eyes of their parents. This is something like the expression, <i>The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth to the roof of his mouth for thirst</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Lamentations 4:4.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: PASS ON BEFORE THE PEOPLE. This is similar in usage to the following expressions: <i>he</i> [Joseph] <i>caused them to pass into cities</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 47:21.</i> <i>and I will make thee to pass with thine enemies into a land which thou knowest not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 15:14.</i> Thus the meaning thereof here is: “go away from them to another place,” [as will be explained further].
