Perhaps this is similar to the expressions: <i>and he</i> [Ahimaaz] <i>overran the Cushite;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 18:23.</i> <i>and he</i> [Jacob] <i>himself passed over before them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:3.</i> meaning that he [Jacob] went in the forefront of them.<br>The purport of this verse is that the people were in Rephidim, and the rock from which the waters were to come was in Horeb,<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6: <i>Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb</i>.</i> this being Mount Sinai, according to the opinion of the former ones,<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the Rabbis of the Talmud. See Shabbath 89 a: “Mount Sinai bears five names: the wilderness of Zin, Horeb, etc.”</i> or in my opinion, some city near the mountain, as I will yet explain.<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">At the beginning of <i>Seder Yithro</i> (18:1).</i> Moses therefore had to go first before the people, to pass on from Rephidim to Horeb — a distance of one more <i>parsah</i> [a Persian mile] or more — from the camp before them. It was for this reason that G-d said to him, <i>Pass on before the people, and take with thee of the elders of Israel… and go</i>. That is to say, “Go until you will see Me stand before you upon the rock in Horeb.” Now Moses hit the rock, and water came out of it. Scripture however does not relate that the congregation and their cattle drank, as it does in the second incident [at the waters of Meribah],<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:11. This took place in Kadesh. See also above, Note 414.</i> for it is self-understood that they did so. It is clear that the people did not go to Horeb to drink, since they did not arrive in front of Mount Sinai until afterwards in the third month.<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 19:1.</i> Instead, they sent their young men and their cattle there to draw water and bring it to them, as is customary in camps.<br>It appears likely to me that the waters — <i>cold flowing waters</i><sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 18:14.</i> — came out from the rock in Horeb and flowed to Rephidim, and there the people drank them. This is Scripture’s intent in saying, <i>He brought streams out of the rock, and caused waters to run down like rivers</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:16.</i> and it is further written, <i>He opened the rock, and waters gushed out; they ran, a river in the dry places</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 105:41.</i> The verse stating, <i>Behold, He smote the rock, that waters gushed out, and streams overflowed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 78:20.</i> also applies to the rock in Horeb, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture.<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Midrash, however, this verse (Psalms 78:20) was said with reference to Moses’ smiting the rock in Kadesh, or, as they are called, the waters of Meribah (Bamidbar Rabbah 19:8).</i> The second rock in Kadesh,<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:1.</i> [instead of gushing forth water], became cleft with a sort of spring welling forth waters, and therefore Scripture states, <i>That is ‘the well’ whereof the Eternal said unto Moses</i>, etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 21:16.</i> and Israel said in the Song, <i>‘The well,’ which the princes digged</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> for it was like a well that was dug. It is for this reason that Scripture says there, <i>and the congregation drank, and their cattle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:11.</i> which means that there they drank from it at that place immediately, but here [in Horeb], overflowing rivers came from it and they drank of it in their homes at their will. Now although according to the tradition of our Rabbis, it was all Miriam’s Well,<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">“That is to say, the rock which was in Rephidim (Horeb) is the same as the one in Kadesh, this being ‘Miriam’s Well,’ which accompanied the Israelites on all their marches during the forty years’ wandering” (Rabbeinu Bachya, Vol. II, p. 153 in my edition). The tradition is mentioned in Bamidbar Rabbah 20:2. This miracle was wrought for the merits of the prophetess Miriam. Ramban’s intent is thus clear: If it was all Miriam’s Well, how can you explain its different forms of activity, for in Horeb it was like a gushing stream, and in Kadesh it was like a well?</i> it is possible that on the first occasion [in Horeb] and during all their forty years’ wandering, the waters came gushing out from the rock like overflowing rivers. The second time, [in Kadesh], as a punishment for that which took place there, it became [only] like a dug well that was full of fresh water [not a gushing spring].
AND THY ROD, WHEREWITH THOU SMOTEST THE RIVER, TAKE IN THY HAND. This means “[the staff wherewith] you commanded Aaron [to strike the river].”<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 7:19.</i> He mentioned the striking of the river, but He did not say, “and the rod which was turned to a serpent”<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> or “the rod wherewith you did the signs.”<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 4:17.</i> This was in order to call attention to the wonder in it, for at that time, the rod turned the waters into blood, thus removing from them their particular nature, and now the rod brought water into a flinty rock,<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 114:8.</i> thus doing things of contrary effect.

Verse 6

BEHOLD, I WILL STAND BEFORE THEE THERE UPON THE ROCK IN HOREB. Since the wonder with the water in this place was now to become a permanent feature as long as they would be in the wilderness, as our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 436.</i> this was why the Divine Glory was revealed upon it at this place, just as it says concerning the manna, <i>And in the morning, then ye shall see the Glory of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:7.</i> since it remained a continuous wonder.

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

AND MOSES SAID TO JOSHUA. It would appear from here that from the day he came before him, Moses called him Joshua, and so it is also written: <i>And Joshua heard the noise of the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:17.</i> Scripture which states in the case of the spies, <i>And Moses called Hoshea the son of Nun, Joshua</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 13:16.</i> must then be referring to the beginning, [when Joshua first came to minister before him]. The verse informs us that this Hoshea the son of Nun, who was chosen to be among the spies, is the same one that Moses called Joshua. Our Rabbis commented<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 34 b, and quoted by Rashi, <i>ibid.</i></i> [that Moses gave him this name of Yehoshua, which is a compound of <i>Y-ah</i> (G-d) and <i>hoshea</i> (help), because] he in effect prayed for him, “May G-d help thee that thou mayest not follow the [evil] counsel of the spies.” The intent of this comment is to state that because of this event of which Moses knew in advance, i.e., that Joshua was destined to go with the spies, he called him by that name [Yehoshua — Joshua] at the outset. We may also say that at that time [when the spies were chosen], Moses designated that name in front of the assembly, i.e., that his name henceforth be not Hoshea but Joshua.<br>The reason that Moses commanded Joshua to fight with Amalek was so that he [Moses] might pray with the raising of hands on the top of the hill.<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> He went up there so that he might see the Israelites engage in battle and train his sight on them to bring them blessing. They too, upon seeing him with his hands spread heavenward and saying many prayers, would have trust in him, and they would thus be endowed with additional valor and strength.<br>In Pirke d’Rabbi Eliezer,<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">In the middle of Chapter 44.</i> we find additionally: “All Israel went outside of their tents, and they saw Moses kneeling on his knees, and they did likewise. He fell on his face to the earth and they did likewise. He spread his hands heavenward, and they also did so. [From here, you learn the principle that] as the public reader of prayers<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “the deputy of the congregation.”</i> recites, so do all the people respond after him.<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">See Berachoth 49 b: “After the fashion of his benediction, so do the others answer him.” See my Hebrew commentary, p. 371, for further elucidation of this point.</i> And thus the Holy One, blessed be He, caused Amalek and his people to fall by the hand of Joshua.” But if so, [i.e., if Moses’ hands were spread heavenward], the sense of the expression, <i>with the rod of G-d in my hand</i>, must be that when Moses went up to the top of the hill and saw Amalek, he stretched forth his hand with the rod to bring down [upon the Amalekites] strokes of pestilence, <i>the sword and destruction</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">See Esther 9:5.</i> just as it is said in the case of Joshua: <i>Stretch out the javelin that is in thy hand toward Ai, for I will give it into thy hand</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 8:18.</i> From the moment Moses began to pray and his hands were spread heavenward, he held nothing in his hand.<br>Moses our teacher did all this because Amalek was an enduring nation<sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 5:15.</i> and very powerful. The Israelites, on the other hand, were not accustomed to battle and had never seen it, just as Scripture says, <i>lest peradventure the people repent when they see war</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:17.</i> In addition they were <i>faint and weary</i>, as it is written in the Book of Deuteronomy.<sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:18.</i> Therefore, he [Moses] feared them, and it became necessary for all this prayer and supplication.<br>It is possible that Moses feared lest Amalek be victorious with the sword, for he was the nation that inherited the sword by virtue of the blessing of the patriarch [Isaac], who said [to Esau, Amalek’s ancestor], <i>and on thy sword you shall live</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 27:40.</i> The first and final wars against Israel stem from this family, as Amalek is of the descendants of Esau.<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:12.</i> It is from him who stood at the head of the nations [in power]<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 24:20. <i>Amalek was the first of the nations</i>. See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i>, where he interprets it to mean: “Amalek is the ‘mightiest’ of the nations. This was why he dared to come to fight Israel,” it is clear that Ramban’s intent here is similar.</i> that the [first] war came against us. From Esau’s descendants, [namely, Rome],<sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, pp. 445, 568-569.</i> the [present] exile and the last<sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban pointedly uses the word “last” and not “the second” in order to indicate that the Third Sanctuary, for the restitution of which we pray, will never suffer destruction. The second destruction by the hands of the Romans was thus the “last” destruction.</i> destruction of the Sanctuary came upon us, just as our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">Gittin 57b. See also above, Note 458.</i> that today we are in the exile of Edom. When he will be vanquished, and he together with the many nations that are with him will be discomfited, we shall be saved out of it [i.e., the exile] forever, just as [the prophet] said, <i>And saviors shall come up on Mount Zion, to judge the mount of Esau; and the kingdom shall be the Eternal’s</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">Obadiah 1:21.</i> Now whatever Moses and Joshua did with them [the Amalekites] at first, Elijah and Mashiach ben Yoseph<sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">Succah 52b. See Ramban’s Sefer Hag’ulah (Kithvei Haramban, Vol. I, pp. 255-295) for further elucidation of his views of the process by which the final redemption will come to pass. For the purpose of illuminating his language here, suffice it to say that Mashiach ben Yoseph — or as Ramban calls him there, “Mashiach ben Ephraim,” since Ephraim was a son of Joseph — will first accomplish the ingathering of the exiles and fight their wars. Then Mashiach ben David will come.</i> will do with their descendants. This was why Moses strained himself in this matter.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND WHEN HE LET DOWN HIS HAND, AMALEK PREVAILED. By way of the plain meaning of Scripture, when Moses was compelled to lower his hands because of weariness, he saw that Amalek prevailed. He then commanded Aaron and Hur to support them, and thus he would not lower them again. Our Rabbis have said in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 138.</i> “Did Moses cause Amalek to prevail over Israel? It was merely because a person is forbidden to tarry three hours with his hands spread heavenward.”<sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary for a quote from the Cabalistic work of the Tziyoni for an explanation of this doctrine. In his commentary on the Sefer Habahir (p. 61, Note 4), Reuben Margoliot quotes from the Commentary of the Vilna Gaon on Proverbs (25:17) that “one must not pray [any given Service] more than three hours.”</i>

Verse 12

AND HIS HANDS WERE ‘EMUNAH’. This means that they remained steadily uplifted. The usage of the word is similar to the expressions: <i>‘va’amanah’ (And a sure) ordinance concerning the singers, as every day required;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 11:23.</i> <i>And yet for all this we make ‘amanah’ (a sure) covenant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:1.</i> meaning a provision “fixed” by covenant. Similarly, <i>a peg fastened in a place ‘ne’eman’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 22:23.</i> means [sure and] strong.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], Moses lifted his ten fingers to the height of heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">See Proverbs 25:3.</i> in order to allude to the ten emanations and to cleave firmly to Him Who fights for Israel.<sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 3:22, <i>For the Eternal your G-d, He it is that fighteth for you</i>.</i> Here is explained the matter of uplifting of hands during the blessing of the priests, and its secret.<sup class="footnote-marker">470</sup><i class="footnote">By uplifting their ten fingers, which allude to the ten emanations, the priests point to the Most High One Whose beneficence is brought down through them to the world by the priestly benediction (L’vush Ha’orah explaining the Ricanti, who quotes the language of Ramban).</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

WRITE THIS FOR A MEMORIAL IN THE BOOK. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote">This quote from Ibn Ezra is found in his commentary to Numbers 21:14. Part of it is also found here.</i> that “this was a known book, namely, <i>the book of the wars of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 21:14.</i> which contained the history of the wars which G-d fought for those that fear Him, and it is possible that the history began from the time of Abraham.” There is nothing in these words of his but an opportunity [to say something without due consideration].<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">It should be pointed out that in his commentary to the Book of Numbers (<i>ibid</i>), Ramban agrees with Ibn Ezra’s comment, by way of the plain meaning of Scripture. This is because it distinctly says there, <i>the book of the wars of the Eternal</i>. Here, however, it just says <i>in the book</i>. Hence Ramban rejects Ibn Ezra’s interpretation that here too it refers to that book of the wars of the Eternal, which is no longer extant, and he proposes his own interpretation, as explained in the text.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the word, <i>baseifer (in the book)</i>, alludes to the Book of the Law, something like that which is written, <i>Take this Book of the Law</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">474</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:26.</i> He is thus stating: “Write this in the Book of My Law so that the children of Israel should remember what Amalek did, <i>for I will utterly blot out</i> his remembrance, and I will lay My vengeance upon him by the hand of My people Israel.”<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote">See Ezekiel 25:14.</i> This is the commandment we find written in the Book of Deuteronomy: <i>Remember what Amalek did unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:17.</i> He said, <i>and rehearse it in the ears of Joshua</i>, to command him to remind Israel of all the travail that had come upon them because of Amalek, for he [Joshua] knows and is witness.<sup class="footnote-marker">477</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 29:23.</i> G-d is thus hinting that after the conquest of the Land, they would blot out Amalek, for the first commandment upon them was to destroy the seven nations<sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:1-2.</i> and take possession of the Land. This is Scripture’s intent in what is said there: <i>And it shall be when the Eternal thy G-d hath given thee rest from all thine enemies… that thou shalt blot out the remembrance of Amalek</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">479</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:19.</i> Now had it been like this in the days of Joshua the son of Nun, he would have urged them on to blot out Amalek, but in his days, a good deal of the Land remained to be possessed,<sup class="footnote-marker">480</sup><i class="footnote">See Joshua 13:1.</i> and the time for the fulfilling of the commandment did not come until the reign of Saul.<sup class="footnote-marker">481</sup><i class="footnote">See I Samuel, Chapter 15.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16

FOR THE HAND UPON ‘KEIS Y-AH’ (THE THRONE OF THE ETERNAL). “The hand of the Holy One, blessed be He, is raised to swear by His throne that He will maintain [a state of] war and enmity against Amalek forever. Now what is the significance of the word <i>keis</i>, and why does it not say <i>kisei</i> [as usual]? Furthermore, even the Divine Name is divided into half!<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton consists of four letters, while here only the first two letters are mentioned.</i> [The answer is that] the Holy One, blessed be He, swore that the throne will not be perfect and the Name will not be full until He will blot out the name of Amalek the son of Esau.<sup class="footnote-marker">483</sup><i class="footnote">Amalek was a grandson of Esau (Genesis 36:12).</i> And when his name will be blotted out, then will G-d’s Name be full and the throne perfect, as it is said, <i>The foe — they are destroyed; perpetual ruins</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 9:7.</i> [This refers to Esau,<sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">In our Rashi: “Amalek.”</i> of whom it is said, <i>And he kept his wrath for ever</i>.]<sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 1:11.</i> <i>Their very memorial is perished</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 9:7.</i> What is written after that? <i>And the Eternal is enthroned for ever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 9:8.</i> Thus you see [that after Amalek’s memory has perished], G-d’s Name is full. <i>He hath established ‘kis’o’ (His throne) for judgment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 9:8.</i> Thus you see that the throne will be perfect.” Thus far the language of Rashi, and it is a Midrash of the Sages.<sup class="footnote-marker">488</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma, <i>Ki Theitzei</i> 11.</i><br>Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">489</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Ibn Ezra in the name of Rabbi Yeshuah.</i> explain the verse as meaning that “when there will be a ‘hand,’ [i.e., king, as explained further], <i>upon the throne of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">The expression found in this verse before us.</i> <i>the Eternal will have war with Amalek</i>, and so shall it be <i>from generation to generation</i>.” The purport of this is that when there will be a king in Israel sitting upon <i>the throne of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">The expression found in this verse before us.</i> he shall wage war against Amalek, thus alluding to Saul, the first king [of Israel]. And so shall it continue <i>from generation to generation</i>, that every king of Israel shall be duty-bound to fight with them until their name will extinct.<br>The following is also a Midrash of the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">491</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 204.</i> as found in [Tractate Sanhedrin] in the chapter of the High Priest:<sup class="footnote-marker">492</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 20b. See also Maimonides’ “The Commandments,” I, pp. 202-203.</i> “By saying, <i>The hand upon the throne of the Eternal: the Eternal will have war with Amalek from generation to generation</i>, Scripture intimates that the Israelites must first appoint a king over themselves [before they are to annihilate the offspring of Amalek], for <i>the throne of the Eternal</i> refers only to the king, as it is said, <i>Then Solomon sat on the throne of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:23. Ramban thus brought proof to the opinion of those scholars mentioned above, who interpret this verse as containing a hint that the reckoning with Amalek is to be deferred until there will be a king in Israel.</i> In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, this is correct.<br>And by way of the Truth, [that is, the mystic lore of the Cabala, the verse is to be understood as meaning] that <i>the Hand</i>, [i.e., the attribute of justice], which is <i>upon the throne of Y-ah</i>, and which is <i>the war from the Eternal</i>, will continue <i>with Amalek from generation to generation</i>, for the high attribute of justice will pursue his extinction forever from generation to generation. The Midrash of the Sages [mentioned above] concerning “the full Divine Name” and “the perfect throne” allude to this [interpretation by way of the Truth].<br>Now the reason for the punishment of Amalek, i.e., why punitive measures were meted out to him more than to all other nations, is that when all the nations heard [of G-d’s visitation upon the Egyptians], they trembled. Philistia, Edom, and Moab and the inhabitants of Canaan melted away<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:14-15.</i> <i>from before the terror of the Eternal, and from the Glory of His majesty</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">495</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 2:10.</i> whereas Amalek came from afar as if to make himself master over G-d. It is for this reason that it is said concerning him, <i>and he feared not G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">496</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:18.</i> Besides, he was a descendant of Esau and related to us,<sup class="footnote-marker">497</sup><i class="footnote">As a relative he was obligated to show kindness towards us. Instead, he behaved very cruelly: <i>he met thee by the way, and smote the hindmost, all that were enfeebled in thy rear, when thou was faint and weary (ibid.)</i></i> <i>a passer-by who meddles with a quarrel not his own</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">498</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs, 26:17. Amalek had no reason to fear attacks from Israel, as they were not bent on taking his land. Amalek’s interposition was thus “meddling with a quarrel not his own.”</i><br>Yithro

Verse 17



Verse 18



Chapter 18



Verse 1

Our Rabbis have already differed concerning this section.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 116 a, and Mechilta in beginning of this <i>Seder</i>. The difference of opinion is between Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Eleazar of Modi’im, Rabbi Yehoshua maintaining that Jethro arrived before the Giving of the Torah, and Rabbi Eleazar saying that he came after the Torah had been given.</i> Some say that Jethro came to Moses before the Giving of the Torah, as the sequence of the sections of the Torah indicate, and some say that he came after the Giving of the Torah. Now this [latter] opinion [that he came after the Giving of the Torah] is certainly assisted by the verse [here] which states, <i>And Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, came with his sons and his wife unto Moses into the wilderness where he was encamped, at the mount of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> Thus Scripture states that Jethro came to Moses when he was encamped before Mount Sinai, the place in which the Israelites camped for one year,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">They arrived before Mount Sinai on the first day of Sivan (further, 19:1), and they first journeyed from there on the twentieth day of the second month in the second year after the exodus (Numbers 10:11). They thus stayed there for twelve months less ten days.</i> this being the meaning of the expression, <i>where he was encamped</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> Moreover, Moses said to Jethro, <i>and I make them know the statutes of G-d, and His laws</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 16.</i> [thus indicating that the Torah had already been given]. Besides, it says here, <i>And Moses let his father-in-law depart; and he went his way unto his own land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> This had taken place in the second year when they journeyed from Mount Sinai, as it is said in the <i>parashah</i> (section) of <i>Beha’alothcha:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 8:1 — 12:16.</i> <i>And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law: we are journeying</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:29. Hobab is identified as Jethro (Rashi). Now if all this happened before the Giving of the Torah, how could Moses say, <i>We are journeying</i>, etc.?</i> There it is written: <i>And he</i> [Hobab] <i>said unto him</i> [Moses]: <i>I will not go; but I will depart to mine own land and to my kindred</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> this being identical with the departure mentioned here, <i>and he went his way unto his own land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i><br>They<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the commentators. The proof is found in Ibn Ezra here.</i> have further brought proof [that Jethro came after the Torah had been given] from that which Scripture says, <i>The Eternal our G-d spoke unto us in Horeb, saying: Ye have dwelt long enough in this mountain; turn you, and take your journey</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:6-7.</i> There it is said, <i>And I spoke unto you at that time, saying: I am not able to bear you myself alone… So I took the heads of your tribes, wise men</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 9-15.</i> This is the advice that Jethro [gave Moses on the morning after he arrived at the camp, as mentioned here further on in Verse 13]. There — [in Moses’ narration of the account in the Book of Deuteronomy] — it is written, <i>And we journeyed from Horeb</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> for they journeyed immediately [after they appointed judges in accordance with Jethro’s advice. All of this serves to prove that Jethro came to Moses after the Giving of the Torah]. And if this is so, we are in need of a reason for this section being written here before [the account of the Giving of the Torah]!<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that this was because of the affair of Amalek. Having mentioned the evil which Amalek inflicted upon us and how G-d commanded us to requite him accordingly, Scripture [by way of contrast], now mentioned the good which Jethro did for us in order to instruct us that we should show him kindness. When we will come to exterminate Amalek, as is mandatory upon us, we should warn the Kenites, [the descendants of Jethro], who dwelt near Amalek, and not destroy them together with Amalek. This was indeed done by Saul when he so spoke to the Kenites.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 15:6, <i>And Saul said unto the Kenites: Go, depart, get ye down from among the Amalekites, lest I destroy you with them; for ye showed kindness to all the children of Israel, when they came up out of Egypt</i>.</i><br>Yet with all this, I find it difficult to understand this opinion [that Jethro came after the Revelation, for the following reasons]: When Scripture says, <i>Now Jethro…heard of all that G-d had done for Moses, and for Israel His people, how that the Eternal had brought Israel out of Egypt</i>, why does it not say that he heard what G-d had done to Moses and to Israel by giving the Torah, which is among the great wonders that were done for them, as He said: <i>For ask now of the days past, which were before thee, since the day that G-d created man upon the earth, and from the one end of heaven unto the other, whether there had been any such thing as this great thing is, or hath been heard like it? Did ever a people hear the voice of G-d speaking out of the midst of the fire, as thou hast heard, and live?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:32-33.</i> And when Scripture states, <i>And Moses told his father-in-law all that the Eternal had done unto Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, all the travail that had come upon them by the way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 8.</i> on the basis of which Jethro said, <i>Now I know that the Eternal is greater than all gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> why did not Moses tell him about the Revelation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “‘the stand’ (<i>ma’amad</i>) at Mount Sinai,” or “the Revelation on Mount Sinai.” It is based on Deuteronomy 4:10, <i>the day that thou ‘stoodest’ before the Eternal thy G-d in Horeb</i>. The expression <i>ma’amad har sinai</i> appears in Rambam’s Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 8:1.</i> on Sinai? Jethro would thereby know that the Eternal is the true G-d and that His Torah is the truth, there being no other but He, as Moses said, <i>Unto thee it was shown, that thou mightest know that the Eternal He is G-d, there is none else beside Him. Out of Heaven He made thee to hear His voice</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:35-36.</i><br>Perhaps we may say that while he was yet in his country, Jethro immediately heard that G-d had brought Israel out of Egypt, whereupon he left his country and reached Moses where he camped before Mount Sinai following the Giving of the Torah. Scripture, however, does not narrate that Moses related the matter of the Revelation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “‘the stand’ (<i>ma’amad</i>) at Mount Sinai,” or “the Revelation on Mount Sinai.” It is based on Deuteronomy 4:10, <i>the day that thou ‘stoodest’ before the Eternal thy G-d in Horeb</i>. The expression <i>ma’amad har sinai</i> appears in Rambam’s Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 8:1.</i> to him, for it had just happened and they were still at that site, and it is self-understood that he told him about it.<br>The most likely explanation seems to me to be to follow the sequence of the sections of the Torah, i.e., that Jethro came before the Giving of the Torah when the Israelites were yet in Rephidim, just as the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here in Verse 1. On the word “Mechilta,” see <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 205.</i> “Rabbi Yehoshua says, ‘[<i>Now Jethro…heard</i>. What particular event did he hear of that he came?] He heard of the war of Amalek, as mentioned in the preceding passage,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:8.</i> and he came.’” He then journeyed with the Israelites from Rephidim to Mount Sinai. The purport of the verse which states [that Jethro came] <i>unto the wilderness where he was encamped, at the mount of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5. Now this verse clearly states that Jethro came to Moses, not in Rephidim, but to where he was camped before Mount Sinai. But the true meaning of the verse is that Mount Sinai, etc.</i> is that Mount Sinai was on the way from Midian, near that country. Moses went there to feed the flock of Midian,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:1.</i> and in connection with Aaron’s [going forth to meet Moses upon his arrival in Egypt], it is said, <i>And he met him in the mountain of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:27.</i> Thus Jethro left Midian with his daughter and the children and came to Mount Sinai.<br>At that time, Moses was in Rephidim, which is a locale in the wilderness of Sin. Scripture says, <i>And they took their journey from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel came unto the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:1.</i> thus stating that the wilderness of Sin stretches until Mount Sinai and includes the locales of Dophkah, Alush, and Rephidim.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:12-14. See Ramban above, 16:1, where the same explanation is expounded briefly. Here, since it affects a major problem in the background - i.e., whether Jethro’s arrival occurred before or after the Giving of the Torah — Ramban discusses his explanation at greater length.</i> Even though it says, <i>And they journeyed…from the wilderness of Sin…and encamped in Rephidim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:1.</i> [which would seem to indicate that Rephidim was not in the wilderness of Sin], it nevertheless also says, <i>And they journeyed from the wilderness of Sin, and pitched in Dophkah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:12.</i> [and from Dophkah they came to Alush, and from Alush to Rephidim, as stated in the following verses<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 13-14.</i> there]. Alush and Rephidim are all part of the wilderness of Sin itself,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">And yet it says (above, 17:1) that they journeyed <i>from the wilderness of Sin</i> and came to Rephidim! But how could this be, for it says in the Book of Numbers that they journeyed <i>from the wilderness of Sin</i> and came to Dophkah and then to Alush and finally to Rephidim? It must be, Ramban concludes, that the name “wilderness of Sin” applies in general to an entire area, as well as to one particular locale, as explained in the text.</i> as the whole desert there was called “the wilderness of Sin,” and the place before Mount Sinai was [also] called “the wilderness of Sin.” A similar case is the verse, <i>And they returned unto the land of the Philistines</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 21:32. See Ramban there (Vol. I, p. 274) that “the sense of the verse is that they [Abimelech and Phicol] returned to their city which was in the land of the Philistines.” Here too “the wilderness of Sin” includes Dophkah, Alush, and Rephidim. Thus, the sense of the verse, <i>and they encamped in Rephidim</i> (above, 17:1), is that they encamped in Rephidim, which was in the wilderness of Sin.</i><br>Thus, the explanation of the verse here is: <i>And Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, came with his sons and his wife unto Moses unto the wilderness where he was encamped</i>, and he [Jethro] came to <i>the mountain of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> It was to the mountain that he [Jethro] came, and he stopped there, this being similar in meaning to the expression, <i>and he came to the mountain of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:1.</i> [which means that he stopped there]. In a similar sense also is the verse, <i>Ye have sat long enough at this mountain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:6.</i> [which means “you have dwelt long enough at this place”]. From Mount Sinai, Jethro sent [a message] to Moses, [who was in Rephidim], saying, <i>‘I thy father-in-law Jethro am coming unto thee,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> <i>and Moses went out</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> <i>to meet</i> him. In this case, it would not be necessary for us to say, [as Ibn Ezra did], that the expression, <i>And he</i> [Jethro] <i>said to Moses: ‘I thy father-in-law Jethro am coming,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> means that he said so before [he arrived at the mount of G-d, as stated in the preceding verse].<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">But according to Ramban’s interpretation, the verses are in chronological order. First, as stated in Verse 5, Jethro arrived at the mount of G-d, and from there, as stated in Verse 6, he sent Moses — who was in Rephidim — the message: <i>I thy father-in-law Jethro am coming to thee</i>. In order to show respect to him, Moses went out to meet him, as related in Verse 7.</i> Even if Rephidim was not in the wilderness of Sin, it was at any event in the desert, for Israel did not come to an inhabited land during all of the forty years.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:35.</i> Further, Rephidim was near Mount Sinai, as [is evidenced by the fact] that a great multitude of people like them came from Rephidim to the mount of G-d in one day,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">I have not found any source for this statement of Ramban that the journey from Rephidim to Sinai was accomplished in one day.</i> and as has been explained in the matter of the rock from which they drank in Rephidim, as I elucidated the subject there.<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:5.</i> Thus the explanation I have offered here is correct.<br>I have also seen this text in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on Verse 5.</i> “<i>Into the wilderness where he was encamped</i>. Scripture thus expresses surprise at him. Here is a man who dwells in the midst of the glory of the world and yet desires to go out into a desolate wilderness which has nothing to offer.” The Rabbis’ intent was to explain the phrase, <i>unto the wilderness where he was encamped</i>, as referring to [that part of] the wilderness where the mount of G-d was, for the wilderness of Sin extended from Elim<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 16:1.</i> until Mount Sinai. Thus, Scripture here relates that Jethro came to the edge of the wilderness where Moses was camped, this being the desert where the mount of G-d was, i.e., unto Horeb.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 3:1.</i> Scripture mentioned this in praise of Jethro, who left his country and came to the wilderness where Moses was, because he knew that this was the mount of G-d, for on it G-d had appeared to Moses. He [Jethro] had already heard of the entire affair, i.e., that Israel went out from Egypt in order to serve G-d upon this mountain,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> and he came <i>for the Name of the Eternal, the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 6:7.</i> This too is correct.<br>It also appears to me concerning that which the verse states here, <i>And Moses let his father-in-law depart; and he went his way unto his own land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 27.</i> that this took place in the first year [of the exodus] and he betook himself to his own land and returned there. It is possible that he went there to convert his family and then returned to Moses while he was yet at Mount Sinai, since it was near to Midian, as I have mentioned. When they broke camp in Iyar of the second year,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:11.</i> and Moses said to him, <i>We are journeying… come thou with us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> and he answered him, <i>I will not go; but I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> Moses in turn pleaded with him very much and said to him, <i>Leave us not, I pray thee… and thou shalt be to us instead of eyes. And it shall be, if thou go with us, yea, it shall be, that what good soever the Eternal shall do unto us, the same will we do unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 31-32.</i> and he did not answer him at all. It would appear then that he accepted Moses’ plea and did according to his will and did not leave them. However, in the days of Saul, we find Jethro’s descendants with Amalek,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 15:6. See above, Note 13.</i> and [after they departed from the Amalekites], they came and attached themselves again to Israel. [We also find that] the sons of Jonadab the son of Rechab — [i.e., descendants of Jethro] — were in Jerusalem.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah, Chapter 35.</i> Perhaps Jethro or his sons returned to their land after the death of Moses. It is possible also that the Kenite that dwelled with Amalek were of the family of Jethro but not his direct descendants, and Saul showed kindness unto the entire family on account of Jethro, just as Joshua dealt kindly with the [whole] family of Rahab<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 6:23.</i> [because of her]. The opinion of our Rabbis is thus that Jethro did go along with the Israelites [in the wilderness]. Thus they said in the Sifre<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The Sifre is a Tanaaitic Midrash on the Books of Numbers and Deuteronomy. The text quoted is in <i>Beha’alothcha</i>, 81. The Sifre is to be distinguished from the Sifra, which is a work of a similar nature on the Book of Leviticus. The Sifra is also referred to as Torath Kohanim [literally: “the law of the priests”].</i> that [at the time they divided up the land], the Israelites gave him the most fertile part of Jericho, and they [Jethro’s descendants] used it until the Sanctuary was built four hundred and forty years later.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The building of the Temple was begun four hundred and eighty years after the exodus (I Kings 6:1). Subtract the forty years of the stay in the wilderness, and you have four hundred and forty.</i> [It was then given as a substitute to him who gave up the land upon which the Sanctuary was to be built.] Rashi himself wrote this tradition in <i>Seder Beha’alothcha</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:32.</i> Thus it is clear that Jethro returned to Moses, [as we have explained above, after he had returned to his land in the first year of the exodus]. In the Mechilta,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on Verse 27.</i> we also find: “Jethro said to Moses: ‘I am going to my land to convert the people of my country, for I shall bring them under the wings of Heaven.’ I might think that he merely went back and did not return; Scripture therefore says, <i>And the children of the Kenite, Moses’ father-in-law, went up out of the city of palm-trees</i>, etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 1:16.</i>
ALL THAT G-D HAD DONE TO<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads: <i>l’Mosheh ul’Yisrael</i>. Ramban first explains it as meaning “‘to’ Moses and ‘to’ Israel.” Hence he proceeds to mention the wonders that G-d did to Moses, etc. Further on, he will mention the explanation of Ibn Ezra, who interpreted the verse as meaning “‘for’ Moses and ‘for’ Israel.”</i> MOSES, AND TO<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew reads: <i>l’Mosheh ul’Yisrael</i>. Ramban first explains it as meaning “‘to’ Moses and ‘to’ Israel.” Hence he proceeds to mention the wonders that G-d did to Moses, etc. Further on, he will mention the explanation of Ibn Ezra, who interpreted the verse as meaning “‘for’ Moses and ‘for’ Israel.”</i> ISRAEL HIS PEOPLE. The marvels He did for Moses were the kindness and goodness He wrought with him, i.e., that he should always be able to come before Pharaoh and not be afraid of him, and that he should inflict the plagues upon him until they went out from Egypt — he and the people with him — Moses being a king to them.<br>And Rabbi ibn Ezra wrote, “<i>l’Mosheh ul’Yisrael</i> means ‘for Moses and Israel.’ The intent is with regard to the plagues and the drowning of Pharaoh” [which G-d wrought for the sake of Moses and Israel, His people]. And so it appears from the opinion of our Rabbis, who said:<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on this verse.</i> “Moses was equal to Israel, and Israel to Moses.”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Now this statement of the Rabbis can be understood only if the letter <i>lamed</i> in the words <i>l’Mosheh ul’Yisrael</i> means “‘for’ Moses and ‘for’ Israel.” The Rabbis could then comment upon this that all the wonders were done for the sake of Moses alone or Israel alone, for Moses alone is equal in importance to Israel, and Israel alone to Moses. But if they interpreted the verse to mean “to Moses and to Israel,” the above statement is incongruous.</i>
ALL THAT G-D HAD DONE… HOW THAT THE ETERNAL HAD BROUGHT ISRAEL OUT OF EGYPT. The reason [for the use of these two Divine Names] is that Scripture first mentions the Name <i>Elokim</i> (G-d) that Jethro knew from before, and then states <i>that the Eternal had brought Israel out</i>, for that was the Name that now came to be known through Moses and through which the signs were performed [before Pharaoh and Israel]

Verse 2

AFTER HE HAD SENT HER AWAY. Because Scripture had [previously] mentioned, <i>And Moses took his wife and his sons… and he returned to the land of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 4:20.</i> it became necessary to state here that she was in her father’s house, as Moses had sent her there. It is possible that Scripture is stating that Jethro took [Zipporah, Moses’s wife], to return her to him although he had sent her away. Having heard <i>all that G-d had done for Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> he thought that it was now time for her to follow the king wherever he would go.

Verse 3

AND HER TWO SONS; OF WHOM THE NAME OF THE ONE WAS GERSHOM. Even though this is not the place where [the narrative of] their birth is told, Scripture here explains the names of the two sons [of Moses — Gershom and Eliezer —] because there was no opportunity to mention the name of Eliezer at his birth, as I have explained in <i>Seder V’eileh Shemoth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:20. See Ramban there regarding why Eliezer was not named at that time. Gershom’s name, on the other hand, is mentioned in 2:22.</i> Here, Scripture wanted to mention the kindness that the Holy One, blessed be He, had shown to Moses, who was a stranger in a strange land. [When he named his second son], he gave thanks there to G-d for having delivered him from the sword of Pharaoh when he fled from before him,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:15.</i> [and for making him] now king over Israel, and [because] He drowned Pharaoh and his people in the sea.<br>The sense of the expression <i>for he said, I have been a stranger</i>, etc. is connected with Moses, who is mentioned in the first verse, [and not with Jethro, who is mentioned in the second verse]. Similarly, the following verse, <i>And the name of the other was Eliezer: for the G-d of my father was my help</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> is connected with the expression <i>for he said</i>, [found in the verse before us. It thus reads: “<i>And the name of the other was Eliezer;</i> for he said: <i>for the G-d</i>, etc.”] There are many cases like that.

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

AND HE SAID UNTO MOSES: ‘I THY FATHER-IN-LAW JETHRO AM COMING UNTO THEE.’ He sent him the message in a letter in which [the above words] were written. A messenger, [as Rashi would have it], could not say, <i>I thy father-in-law</i>. Instead, he would say, “Behold, Jethro your father-in-law is coming to you.” It is also not possible that Jethro told him so mouth to mouth, for in that case he would have said, “Behold, I have come to you.” Besides, it is not customary in such instances for the speaker to mention his name: “I, such and such a person,” for upon seeing him, he would recognize him. A similar case is the verse: <i>Then Huram the King of Tyre said</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the word “said” can clearly apply to “saying in writing.”</i> <i>in writing, which he sent to Solomon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 2:10.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

BLESSED BE THE ETERNAL, WHO HATH DELIVERED YOU OUT OF THE HAND OF THE EGYPTIANS, AND OUT OF THE HAND OF PHARAOH; WHO HATH DELIVERED THE PEOPLE FROM UNDER THE HAND OF THE EGYPTIANS.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The text presents these difficulties: Why is <i>the hand of the Egyptians</i> mentioned twice? Why does Jethro first address himself directly to the people, saying, <i>Who hath delivered you</i>, etc., and then speaks of them in the third person, saying, <i>Who hath delivered the people</i>, etc.? Ramban first presents his interpretation, followed by that of Ibn Ezra.</i> “He has done a great miracle for you in that Pharaoh and his people did not kill you, for it was on account of you that great plagues came upon them in their land.” This miracle was particularly great as far as Moses was concerned [because he frequently came to Pharaoh, as explained above at the end of Verse 1]. Therefore Jethro mentioned him [specifically] in the second person, together with everybody, saying, <i>Who hath delivered you</i>, meaning “you [Moses], and the people.” And He did another miracle: <i>Who hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians</i>, since they were in Egypt and they went out of there to everlasting freedom.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that Jethro first blessed G-d, <i>Who hath delivered you</i>, meaning Moses and Aaron, through whom the plagues came upon Pharaoh and the Egyptians. Afterwards, he blessed Him for how <i>He hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians</i> in Egypt and at the sea.

Verse 11

FOR IT IS IN THE THING THAT ‘ZADU’ UPON THEM. The meaning of this is that in the matter wherein the Egyptians premeditated<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus explains the word <i>zadu</i> on the basis of <i>zadon</i> (premeditated, conscious sin), as is explained further in the text.</i> [their wickedness] against Israel, <i>I</i> [Jethro] <i>now know that the Eternal is greater than all gods</i>. And the purport thereof is as follows: Due to the fact that G-d had decreed upon Israel, <i>and they shall enslave them, and they should afflict them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13.</i> there would have been no great punishment meted out to the Egyptians. But they acted presumptuously against them, and intended to eradicate them from the world, just as they said, <i>Come, let us deal wisely with them, lest they multiply</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 1:10.</i> Pharaoh commanded the midwives to kill the male children,<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> and he decreed upon [all his people, saying], <i>Every son that is born</i> [unto the Israelites] <i>ye shall cast into the river</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 22.</i> It was due to this that there came upon the Egyptians the kind of punishment which utterly destroyed them. It is this principle which is expressed in His words, <i>And also that nation that made slaves of them will I judge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:14.</i> as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> (Vol. I, pp. 203-205.)</i> Now G-d saw their intentions, and He took vengeance upon them for the wickedness of their hearts. And thus does Scripture say again, <i>And Thou didst show signs and wonders upon Pharaoh… for Thou knowest that they dealt insolently against them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:10.</i> for the punishment was because of the wicked plans they devised to carry out against the Israelites. Thus <i>the Eternal looketh on the heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 16:7.</i> and <i>executeth justice for the oppressed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 146:7.</i> <i>avengeth and is full of wrath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Nahum 1:2.</i> and no one can deter Him.<br>Now Onkelos translated [the above Scriptural expression] thus: “for by that very thing with which the Egyptians thought to judge Israel, they themselves were judged.” By this rendition, Onkelos meant to say that their punishment came because of the drowning of the [Hebrew] children in the river, which was not part of the Divine decree, <i>and they shall enslave them, and they shall afflict them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:13.</i> Therefore, He destroyed them by water.

Verse 12

AND JETHRO, MOSES’ FATHER-IN-LAW, TOOK A BURNT-OFFERING AND SACRIFICES FOR G-D. All this took place before they came to Mount Sinai.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">See above at the beginning of this <i>Seder</i>, where Ramban develops at length his explanation that Jethro, having arrived at the mount of G-d, sent a messenger to Moses in Rephidim, informing him of his arrival. Moses thereupon went out to meet him and brought him to Rephidim, where this feast took place. It was thus before Israel’s arrival at Mount Sinai that all this took place.</i> It is also possible to explain that Scripture arranged the entire narrative of Jethro [in one section] even though this particular event occurred after he had stayed with the Israelites a long time and, in the meantime, became converted through circumcision, immersion, and the sprinkling of the blood of a sacrifice, according to the law.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 9a. When the Sanctuary or Tabernacle was in existence, a proselyte entered into the covenant with G-d by means of circumcision, immersion, and the sprinkling of the blood of a sacrifice. Since the destruction of the Sanctuary, only circumcision and immersion are required. These three things were all present at the Giving of the Torah. Circumcision was performed already in Egypt, as is evidenced by the verse, <i>and no uncircumcised person shall eat thereof</i>, i.e., of the Passover-offering (above, 12:48). Immersion is mentioned further (19:10), and so is the bringing of a sacrifice (24:5). At the time of the Sanctuary, immersion and a sacrifice were required of a female proselyte. Nowadays, immersion alone is the prerequisite to her entrance into the covenant. See Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Isueri Biah, Chapter 13, for further eludication of these principles. See also Ramban further, 19:10.</i>
AND AARON CAME, AND ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL, TO EAT BREAD. That is, with Jethro <i>in the day of his espousals</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:11.</i> [i.e., in the day of his entrance into the covenant with G-d], for he was then as a newly-circumcised child.

Verse 13

AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE MORROW, i.e., on the morrow of the day on which they held the above-mentioned [feast], THAT MOSES SAT TO JUDGE THE PEOPLE. In the Mechilta, the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>On the morrow</i>. That is, on the morrow after the Day of the Atonement.” Now the intent of the Rabbis was not that <i>on the morrow</i> alludes to the Day of Atonement, for Scripture has not mentioned the Day of Atonement at all that it should now refer to it by saying <i>on the morrow</i> thereof. Nor is the term <i>on the morrow</i> to be understood literally, [i.e., the day after the Day of Atonement], for they did not eat on the Day of Atonement, that is, if they observed such a day in the first year before they were commanded concerning it.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">“It is impossible to say that they observed the Fast of the Atonement in that first year, since the people were not commanded therein until Moses came down from Mount Sinai for the third time, which was on the Day of Atonement itself” (Mizrachi).</i> Moreover, it was on the Day of Atonement that the second Tablets of the Law were given. On the following day, Moses came and he spoke to the children of Israel, <i>and he gave them in commandment all that the Eternal had spoken with him in Mount Sinai</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:32.</i> It thus could not have been a day on which he sat to judge the people, when <i>the people stood about</i> him <i>from the morning unto the evening</i>. It is also impossible to say that this was on the morrow of the Day of Atonement of the second year, for after the Israelites journeyed [from Sinai on the twentieth day of Iyar in the second year (Numbers 10:11)], Hobab [i.e., Jethro], said, <i>I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:30. And even according to what Ramban has written above on Verse 1, i.e., that Jethro listened to Moses’ plea to stay with Israel and he did not leave them, it is nevertheless obvious that at that time, he intended to leave them. The narrative contained in this section concerning Jethro’s advice to Moses on the delegation of power in the administration of justice, could thus logically not have taken place on the morrow after the Day of Atonement in the second year, some four and a half months after they journeyed from Mount Sinai (Kur Zahab).</i><br>Rather, the intent of this Beraitha, [i.e., the Mechilta quoted above, “on the morrow after the Day of Atonement”], is that it was some day after the Day of Atonement, since Moses had no free day on which to sit in judgment from the day they came to Mount Sinai until after the Day of Atonement of that first year.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Immediately after the Torah was given on the sixth day of Sivan, Moses ascended the mountain and remained there for forty days. When he descended on the seventeenth of Tammuz and found the people worshipping the golden calf, he broke the Tablets. On the next day, he again ascended the mountain to pray for G-d’s forgiveness, and stayed there forty days, which terminated on the twenty-ninth day of Ab. On the following day, he was told to come up to the mountain to receive the second Tablets. He again spent forty days there. Consequently, this forty-day period terminated on the tenth of Tishri, which is the Day of Atonement. Thus, from the time the Torah was given till after the Day of Atonement in the first year, Moses had no free day on which to sit in judgment, as is described in this section of the Torah. For the sources on the above dates, see Rashi here, and in more detail, further, 33:11, and Deuteronomy 9:18.</i>
Scripture says, <i>a burnt-offering and sacrifices to G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Above Verse 12.</i> because Jethro did not yet know the Eternal. It was Moses who said, <i>all that the Eternal had done unto Pharaoh and to the Egyptians for Israel’s sake… and how the Eternal delivered them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> but Jethro sacrificed to <i>Elokim</i> (G-d). You will not find this concerning any of the sacrifices in <i>Torath Kohanim</i> (the law of the priests) [i.e., the Book of Leviticus], as I will explain with the help of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:9.</i> Similarly, <i>Because the people come unto me to inquire of G-d… and I make them know the statutes of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Further. Verses 15-16.</i> are the words of Moses to his father-in-law, [who did not yet know the Eternal]. It is possible that Moses spoke to him thus, [using the name <i>Elokim</i> and not the Tetragrammaton], because of the verse which states, <i>for the judgment is G-d’s</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:17.</i> just as our Rabbis always mention:<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 73:2.</i> “<i>Elokim</i> (G-d): this is the attribute of justice.”

Verse 14



Verse 15

FOR THE PEOPLE COME UNTO ME TO INQUIRE OF G-D. Moses answered his father-in-law: “They must stand about me a great part of the day, for they come before me for many things. <i>Because the people come unto me to inquire of G-d</i>, that is, to pray for their sick, and to inform them of the whereabouts of what they have lost,” this being “the inquiring of G-d.”<br>And thus the people did with the [later] prophets, just as it is said, <i>In former times in Israel, when a man went to inquire of G-d, thus he said: Come and let us go to the seer</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 9:9. The matter there concerned the finding of Saul’s lost asses. The prophet was Samuel.</i> Similarly, <i>Go meet the man of G-d, and inquire of the Eternal by him, saying: Shall I recover from this sickness?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 8:8. The speaker is Ben-hadad, king of Aram, and he is sending Hazael to the prophet Elisha, who had come to Damascus.</i> meaning that the prophet should pray for his recovery and that he should inform him if his prayer was accepted. This is also the meaning of the verse, <i>and she</i> [Rebekah] <i>went to inquire of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 25:22 (Vol. I, p. 316).</i> as I have explained there.<br>“Moreover,” [Moses continued], “I adjudicate matters between them, <i>when they have a matter, it cometh unto me, and I judge</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> And I also teach them Torah, <i>and I make them know the statutes of G-d and His laws.</i>”<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND G-D BE WITH THEE. “I.e., in this counsel. Jethro said to Moses, ‘Go and consult with the Almighty.’” Thus Rashi’s language. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “‘Listen to me, and G-d will help you to succeed as I have counselled you.’ Further, however, Jethro said, ‘<i>If thou shalt do this thing, and G-d command thee so</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> which means ‘if you will do this thing — i.e., that you will consult with the Almighty — and He will command you to do it, then you will be able to endure.’ And there is no doubt that Moses did so” [i.e., he first consulted with G-d and received His sanction and then proceeded to make this arrangement].
BE THOU FOR THE PEOPLE ‘MUL’ G-D. That is, “‘before’ G-d.” Jethro told Moses, “Be thou their intercessor before G-d, to pray to Him.” This is like the verse, <i>I call by day; I cry in the night before Thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 88:2.</i>
AND BRING THOU THE CAUSES — namely, which they will ask — UNTO G-D. Jethro conceded the first matter that Moses had said, i.e., <i>Because the people come unto me to inquire of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 15.</i> It is possible that in this too there was counselling on his part. Jethro would thus be saying: “<i>Be thou for the people before G-d</i>, to sit in the Tent of Meeting before Him, ready to inquire of Him [on the matters they bring to you]. And this should not be at the place where you sit in judgment [to adjudicate their disputes].”

Verse 20

AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM THE STATUTES AND THE LAWS, AND SHALT SHOW THEM THE WAY WHEREIN THEY MUST WALK. That is, “according to the law and the commandment with which you will strongly admonish them, and you will teach the law and the commandment.” Thus Jethro also conceded to Moses on this matter, of which he had said, <i>and I make them know the statutes of G-d, and His laws</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 16.</i> In this too there was counsel [on the part of Jethro], i.e., that Moses should strongly admonish them and warn them of the commandments and [Divine] punishments [in case of transgression], since he himself would not be involved in the execution of the law. “But in matters of judgment whereof you said, <i>and I judge between a man and his neighbor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 16.</i> designate judges to act with you, <i>for the thing is too heavy for thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> That is, the judging of disputes between them is heavier than all, and it would be good for you and for them to make it easier for you <i>and they shall bear the burden with thee</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22. The purport of Jethro’s counsel to Moses, according to Ramban, was thus: “You are indeed correct in not delegating to others the inquiry of G-d on all matters they desire. So also in the matter of instructing the people in G-d’s laws. But in judging their disputes, add other judges to join with you.”</i> Now it is known that Moses had officers in charge of the people. [It was the duty of these officers] to bring before him the persons against whom claims had been made and to force them to comply with the verdict of the judges. He assigned many of these officers as these judges. This is why Moses said in Deuteronomy, <i>and I made them heads over you, captains of thousands… and officers, tribe by tribe</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:15.</i> There was no need to mention them here since their appointment was not part of Jethro’s counsel.

Verse 21

MEN OF ‘CHAYIL.’ This means men who are capable of leading a great multitude of people. Every assembly and gathering is called <i>chayil</i>, and it does not apply only to soldiers going forth to war. Thus it is said [of the dry bones that Ezekiel resurrected], <i>a great ‘chayil’ (host)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 37:10.</i> Of the locusts it is said, <i>My great ‘chayil’ (army)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:25.</i> Of wealth it is stated, <i>My power and the might of my hand hath gotten this ‘chayil’ (wealth);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 8:17.</i> <i>they carry upon the shoulders of young asses ‘chayaleihem’ (their riches)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:6.</i> Of fruits it is said, <i>the fig-tree and the vine do yield ‘cheilam’ (their strength)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:22.</i> Thus an <i>ish chayil</i> in the administration of justice is one who is wise, alert, and fair; in war, an <i>ish chayil</i> is one who is strong, alert, and who knows the art of arraying forces in battle. A woman also is an <i>eisheth chayil (a woman of valor)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:10.</i> when she is alert and knows how to conduct the management of a home.<br>Jethro thus spoke in general and in particular. [In general], he told Moses to select people with powers of leadership in the administration of justice for this great people. In particular, they should be <i>such as fear G-d, men of truth, hating unjust gain</i>, for it is impossible for them to be “men of <i>chayil</i>” in judgment, without these qualities. It was not necessary for him to mention that they must be wise and understanding, for it is clear that these qualities are included in the term “men of <i>chayil</i>.” Further on, when it says, <i>And Moses chose men of ‘chayil,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> everything is already included — i.e., that they were G-d-fearing, men who hated unjust gain, wise and understanding. Moreover, Scripture says [that Moses chose them] <i>out of all Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> which means [that they were] the preferred of all Israel, being the ones who have all of these qualities. Since Scripture states that he chose them <i>out of all Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> it is already stating that they were chosen in preference to all, for it is known that the better ones in Israel possess all good qualities. Jethro, however, not being familiar with them, found it necessary to explain in detail [that they be G-d-fearing, men of truth, etc.]<br>Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra here. Also, R’dak in Sefer Hashorashim, on the root <i>chayil</i>.</i> explain <i>anshei chayil</i> as men of physical strength and zeal, <i>such as have ability to stand in the king’s palace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 1:4.</i> Similarly, <i>eisheth chayil</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:10.</i> is a woman of strength and industry in the work of the home, as Scripture explains there in that section.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 31:10-31.</i> Likewise, <i>Make them wander to and fro ‘b’cheilcha,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 59:12.</i> which means “by Thy power.” Also, <i>Neither doth it</i>, [i.e., the horse], <i>afford escape by its great ‘cheilo,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33:17.</i> [which means “by its great strength”]. The word [<i>chayil</i>] is associated with the Aramaic, as is evidenced by the [Hebrew] expression, <i>‘yesh l’eil yadi’ (It is in the power of my hand)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:29.</i> which is rendered in the Targum: “there is <i>cheila</i> in my hand.” And further on it says, <i>And Moses chose men of ‘chayil’ out of all Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> which means the preferred ones of the entire nation and all qualities are included, as I have explained.
HATING UNJUST GAIN. “Men who disdain their own money in a law-suit, just as we say:<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 58b.</i> ‘Any judge from whom money is collected by a judgment is not qualified as a judge.’” Thus Rashi’s language. By this, Rashi meant to explain that they disdain all money which they know can be collected from them by law, and return it themselves even though it is truly theirs, such as the case wherein one bought a slave without witnesses,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">And the owner comes to reclaim him. Now even though the slave is rightfully the buyer’s, the latter knows that because he has no witnesses who can attest to the sale, the original owner will regain possession of the slave in a law-suit. The buyer therefore voluntarily returns the slave to the original owner. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 381, as to why Ramban mentioned such a specific case.</i> or a similar example.<br>But the text in the Mechilta is not so, [i.e., as Rashi commented]. Rather, this is the way it is taught there:<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “‘<i>Hating unjust gain</i>. I.e., those who, when sitting in judgment, disdain to accept money.’ These are the words of Rabbi Yehoshua. Rabbi Eleazar of Modi’im says: ‘<i>Hating unjust gain</i>. I. e., those who disdain their own money. If they disdain their own money, how much more will they despise the money of their friends!’” The explanation [of this text of the Mechilta] is that Rabbi Yehoshua interprets the expression <i>hating ‘botza’</i> as meaning “hating bribery,” the usage of the word [<i>betza</i>] being similar to: <i>Every one is greedy for ‘botza’ (gain);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 6:13.</i> <i>Each one ‘l’bitzo’ (to his gain), one and all</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 56:11.</i> Rabbi Eleazar of Modi’im explained that <i>hating ‘botza’</i> means that they despise abundance of money and have no desire to increase their silver and gold, something like the verse, <i>If I rejoiced because my wealth was great, and because my hand had gotten much</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Job 31:25.</i> Money [or profit] is called <i>betza</i> [in Hebrew]: <i>What ‘betza’ (profit) is it if we slay our brother?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:26.</i> <i>Is it any ‘betza’ (profit or advantage) to the Almighty that thou art righteous?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Job 22:3.</i> <i>And thou shalt devote ‘bitz’am (their gain) unto the Eternal, and their substance unto the Lord of the whole earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 4:13.</i><br>Again, I have seen in the Yelamdeinu:<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">See Sifre, <i>Devarim</i> 17. For the name Yelamdeinu, see <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 196.</i> “<i>Hating unjust gain</i> [means] those who disdain their own money, and needless to say, they disdain the money of others. They are the ones who say, ‘Even if this man will burn my stack, even if he will destroy my plants, I will render judgment correctly.’” This is the intent of Rabbi Eleazar of Modi’im, who said that they disdain their own money, meaning that they pay no regard to their property when sitting in judgment, that is, if they will suffer a loss of money on account of it. Moses further admonished them on this, saying, <i>Ye shall not be afraid of the face of any man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:17.</i> [Thus according to the Yelamdeinu], <i>betza</i> means money, as I have explained. Onkelos rendered it: “those who hate to receive money.” But the word “money,” [as Onkelos uses it], does not mean a bribe, [which of course is forbidden in itself]. It means rather that they should never accept money from people as a gift or loan, so that they should show them no favoritism at the time of judgment. It is similar to what the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 105b.</i> “A judge who is in the habit of borrowing things [from his neighbors] is forbidden to act as judge in a law-suit involving them.”<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, <i>men of truth, hating ‘botza’</i>, means those who love the truth and hate “oppression.” When they see oppression and violence, they cannot tolerate them, their whole desire being only to <i>deliver the spoiled out of the hand of the oppressor</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 21:12.</i>

Verse 22

AND LET THEM JUDGE THE PEOPLE AT ALL TIMES. The meaning thereof is that “when there will be many judges available, the oppressed one will go to the judge at any time he desires and he will find him ready [to listen to his grievance]. He cannot come near you [i.e., Moses] at any time because of the great multitude of people before you and on account of your many preoccupations. The result of this is that many of them will rather tolerate the violence committed against them because they have no opportunity to tell it to you.
