They do not want to abandon their work and affairs to wait for a free moment when they will be able to approach you.” This is the sense of the expression, each one <i>shall go to his place in peace</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> At present, because they cannot come near for judgment at all times, they will not rest in peace, since this opens a door for unjust people to commit violence and for oppressors to cause contention. And the meaning of the expression <i>to his place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> is that to whatever place they will come, [they will live in peace] as long as they are in the camp in the wilderness.<br>From the language, <i>And let them judge the people ‘at all times,’</i> our Rabbis have derived the principle<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 34b.</i> that in civil cases, the verdict may be reached even during the night,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">In capital cases, the verdict must be reached during the daytime (<i>ibid.</i>, 32 a). The trial itself, in both capital and non-capital cases, must be held during the daytime (<i>ibid.</i>)</i> since it does not say here, “[and let them judge the people] the whole day.”

Chapter 19



Verse 1

IN THE THIRD MONTH. Scripture should have said, “And they journeyed from Rephidim and they encamped in the wilderness of Sinai, in the third month after their going forth from the land of Egypt,” just as it said above concerning the wilderness of Sin.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:1: <i>And all the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of Sin… and encamped in Rephidim</i>.</i> But [Scripture’s manner of expression here is] due to the fact that their coming into the wilderness of Sinai was an occasion for joy and a festival to them, and that since they left Egypt they had been yearning for it. They knew that they would receive the Torah there, for Moses had told them what was said to him, <i>Ye shall serve G-d upon the mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:12.</i> And to Pharaoh also he said, <i>Let us go, we pray thee, three days’ journey, into the wilderness and sacrifice unto the Eternal our G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:3.</i> For this reason, Scripture begins the section with the statement that <i>in the third month… the same day</i> that the month began,<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here, and mentioned in Rashi.</i> <i>they came</i> there [as they had eagerly anticipated]. Following this opening, Scripture reverts [to the usual style] as in the other journeys: <i>And they journeyed from Rephidim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i><br>Now here too Scripture should have said “and they journeyed from Rephidim <i>and encamped</i> in the wilderness of Sinai.” Instead it writes, <i>and they came to the wilderness of Sinai</i>. This is because Scripture’s intent is to state that as soon as they came to the wilderness of Sinai and saw the mountain in front of them, they encamped in the wilderness and did not wait until they would enter a spot better for encampment. Instead, they camped in the wilderness or in Horeb,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:10.</i> which was a waste land before the mountain. This is the purport of the verse; <i>and they encamped in the wilderness, and there Israel encamped before the mount</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i><br>It is possible that they separated from their midst all <i>the mixed multitude that was among them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:4. See also above, 12:38.</i> and the children of Israel alone camped before the mountain while the mixed multitude was behind them. For the Torah was given to Israel, as He said, <i>Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and tell the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> and this is the meaning of the expression, <i>and there Israel encamped</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> It may be that [the name “Israel”] is mentioned as a mark of honor at the time of their acceptance of the Torah.<br>Now Rashi wrote: “<i>And they journeyed from Rephidim</i>. What need was there for Scripture to state again expressly from where they set forth on the journey? Is it not already stated that they were encamped in Rephidim<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:1: <i>And all the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderness of Sin… and encamped in Rephidim</i>.</i> and it is thus evident that they journeyed from there? It [i.e., the intent of the verse] is to declare that their departure from Rephidim was like their encampment<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">“Encampment.” In our Rashi: “coming.”</i> in the wilderness of Sinai. Just as their encampment<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">“Encampment.” In our Rashi: “coming.”</i> [in the wilderness of Sinai] was with repentance,<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">The repentance is indicated by the word <i>vayichan</i>, which is in the singular, thus indicating that Israel encamped before the mountain as one man and with one mind, “while all other encampments were with murmerings and with dissension” (Rashi, quoting Mechilta).</i> so also was their departure [from Rephidim] with repentance.”<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 17:7, for their sin in Rephidim. The present analogy between their coming into the wilderness of Sinai, which was surely in a spirit of repentance, as explained above, and their departure from Rephidim, thus teaches us that their departure was also with repentance.</i> Thus Rashi’s language. But I have not understood this. It says in connection with all journeys: <i>and they pitched</i> [camp] <i>in Elim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 33:9.</i> <i>And they took their journey from Elim… and they came unto the wilderness of Sin;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:1.</i> <i>And they journeyed from the wilderness of Sin… and encamped in Rephidim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:1.</i> and so the entire section of <i>Mas’ei</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:1-49.</i> is written [with the name of the place whence they set forth on the journey repeated after it had already been mentioned that they had encamped there]. The intent of the repetition by Scripture is that there were no other encampments between them.<br>In the Mechilta, we find the following text<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> [on the same theme that Rashi mentioned, but presented in such a form that the above difficulties are eliminated]: “<i>And they departed from Rephidim and came to the desert of Sinai</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> Has it not already been stated in the section of the Torah dealing with all stages of the journey [from Egypt to the Jordan]: <i>And they journeyed from Rephidim, and pitched in the wilderness of Sinai?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:15.</i> And what need is there for Scripture to state here, <i>and they came to the desert of Sinai?</i> It [i.e., the intent of the verse] is to declare that their departure from Rephidim [was like their encampment in the wilderness of Sinai], etc.” The purport of this text of the Mechilta is to explain why, on account of certain new details mentioned there,<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 9 and 14.</i> Scripture repeated in the section of <i>Eileh Mas’ei</i><sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 33:1-49.</i> all stages of the journey from Elim and Rephidim mentioned here, although this journey [from Rephidim to the wilderness of Sinai] is mentioned in identical language both here and there. It was for this reason that [the Mechilta] was compelled to interpret that [the Scriptural restatement] was on account of the above analogy: [Just as their encampment at Sinai was with repentance, so also etc.].

Verse 2



Verse 3

AND MOSES WENT UP UNTO G-D. From the day they arrived at Mount Sinai, the cloud covered the mountain and the Glory of G-d was there. It is with reference to this that Scripture says, <i>And the Glory of the Eternal abode upon Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it six days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:16.</i> i.e., before the Giving of the Torah. It is for this reason that Scripture says here, <i>And Moses went up unto G-d</i>, meaning that he went up to the edge of the mountain to be ready for Him, but he did not penetrate <i>the thick darkness where G-d was</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:18.</i> <i>And the Eternal called unto him from</i> the top of <i>the mountain, saying: Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob</i>.<br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the expression, <i>and He called unto him</i>, is an antecedent, meaning that He had called him [to come up to the mountain] and he went up to Him. But this does not appear to me to be correct, for the calling [mentioned in Scripture after Moses ascended the mountain] was: <i>Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob</i>. Now Ibn Ezra explains the verse to mean as follows: “<i>And the Eternal called unto him to say</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Ibn Ezra here interprets the word <i>leimor</i>, which is generally taken to mean “saying,” as meaning “to say.” The sense of the verse is thus: And Moses went up to G-d, for He had called him out of the mountain to tell him, “Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, etc.”</i> to him, <i>Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob</i>.” But this is not correct.<br>The meaning of the expression, <i>he went up unto G-d, and the Eternal called unto him</i>, is that Moses went up towards the Glory of G-d, which was abiding on the mountain to declare the Ten Commandments to Israel, and with His Great Name [the Tetragrammaton] He would speak with Moses, as is the meaning of the verse, <i>If there be a prophet among you</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:6. <i>If there be a prophet among you, I the Eternal do make Myself known unto him in a vision… My servant Moses is not so… with him do I speak mouth to mouth, even manifestly, and not in dark speeches</i> (Verses 6-8). See also Ramban in this chapter, further, Verse 20.</i>

Verse 4

AND I BROUGHT YOU UNTO MYSELF. I.e., “to the place of My Glory, namely, this mountain where My Presence abides there with you.” Now Onkelos translated: “and I brought you near to My service.” [To avoid a literal translation], Onkelos adapted an expression of respect towards Him Who is on high.

Verse 5

AND YE WILL KEEP MY COVENANT. I.e., “the covenant which I have made with your fathers to be a G-d unto them and to their seed after them.”<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:7.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it as referring to the covenant which Moses was to make with Israel after the Giving of the Torah, as he said, <i>Behold, the blood of the covenant, which the Eternal hath made with you in agreement with all these words</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:8.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [that is, the mystic lore of the Cabala, the verse is to be understood as meaning] that “you should keep My covenant to cleave unto Me, for if thou shalt indeed hearken unto My voice and do all that I speak,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Ibid.</i>, 23:22.</i> 
<i>then ye shalt be Mine own ‘s’gulah’ (treasure) from among all peoples</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Here in Verse 5.</i> This means that “you will be a treasure ‘in My hand,’” for a king does not hand over a precious object into the hand of another [for permanent possession]. The word <i>s’gulah</i> here is similar in meaning to the expression: <i>‘us’gulath’ (and treasure) such as kings and the provinces have as their own</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 2:8.</i> <br>FOR ALL THE EARTH IS MINE. This is similar in meaning to the verses: <i>Which the Eternal thy G-d hath allotted unto all the peoples… But you hath the Eternal taken</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:19-20.</i> And thus He said, “<i>And I have set you apart from the peoples, that ye should be Mine</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 20:26.</i> [own] treasure.” It may be that the word <i>s’gulah</i> connotes “attachment.” [The sense of the verse would then be: “and you shall be attached to Me from among all peoples], for unto Me is the earth called <i>kol (all)</i>,” as I have explained on the verse, <i>And the Eternal had blessed Abraham ‘bakol’ (in all things)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:1 (Vol. I, pp. 290-292).</i> The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand. Similarly, <i>And ye shall be unto me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> means that “you will be Mine in a special sense, and not as the rest of the peoples.” And so did the Rabbis interpret it in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, <i>ibid.</i></i> “<i>And ye shall be unto Me</i>. As though it were possible to say it, [He is stating], ‘I shall neither appoint nor delegate [any power] to rule over you, but I Myself will rule over you.’ And thus it says, <i>Behold He that keepeth Israel doth neither slumber nor sleep</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 121:4.</i>

Verse 6

A KINGDOM OF PRIESTS. This means that you shall be a kingdom of My servants.
AND A HOLY NATION. I.e., to cleave unto the Holy G-d, just as He said, <i>Ye shall be holy, for I the Eternal your G-d am Holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:2.</i> Thus He has assured them [of life] in this world and in the World to Come.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Beshalach</i>, Note 346.</i>

Verse 7

AND MOSES CAME AND CALLED FOR THE ELDERS OF THE PEOPLE, AND SET BEFORE THEM ALL THESE WORDS. This means that he said to them: “Behold, I have presented before you the words [of G-d]. <i>Choose you this day</i><sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:15.</i> if you will do so.” Therefore, they answered him, <i>All that the Eternal hath spoken we will do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> This is similar in meaning to the verse: <i>See, I have set before thee this day life and good, and death and evil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 30:15.</i> and also: <i>And these are the ordinances which thou shalt set before them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 21:1.</i> meaning that they are to say if they choose to observe them and accept [them] upon themselves. It is for this reason that it says there, <i>And Moses came and told the people all the words of the Eternal, and all the ordinances; and all the people answered with one voice, and said, All the words which the Eternal hath spoken will we do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 24:3.</i> Similarly, <i>And this is the law which Moses set before the children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:44.</i> means that Moses asked the generation that was to come into the Land whether they would accept the Torah upon themselves, for he was about to make a covenant with them in the plains of Moab, just as he had done with their fathers in Horeb.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:69.</i> And the Gaon Rav Saadia<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned here in Ibn Ezra. On Rav Saadia Gaon, see <i>Seder Va’eira</i>, Note 229.</i> said that the expression, <i>and he set before them</i>, is similar in meaning to the expression, <i>put it in their mouth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 31:19.</i> [this being a reference to the Oral Law, which is the commentary to the Written Law]. But the correct interpretation is only as I have explained.<br><i>And all the people answered together</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> This also means that Moses called together the elders of the people, who are their wise men and their judges, for theirs is [the power of] choice. <i>And he set before them all these words</i> in the presence of the whole congregation, since it was with reference to all the people that G-d had commanded, <i>Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and tell the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3.</i> But they did not wait for the counsel and decision [of the elders, but readily], <i>all the people answered together — both small and great</i><sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 23:2.</i> — <i>and said, All that the Eternal hath spoken will we do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> And so it says again, <i>and all the people answered with one voice, and said: All the words which the Eternal hath spoken will we do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:3.</i>

Verse 8

VAYASHEV MOSHEH’ THE WORDS OF THE PEOPLE UNTO THE ETERNAL. This means that Moses returned<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus interprets the word <i>vayashev</i> in the sense of “returning,” and not of “reporting”: “he returned to G-d with the words of the people.” “And there was no need to mention that ‘he went up to the mountain,’ since Scripture speaks here briefly” (Ibn Ezra).</i> before Him to the mountain with the people’s answer. Now everything is revealed to Him, and He did not inquire of him, “What did this people answer you?” It is similar in meaning to the verse: <i>And the Eternal heard the voice of your words, when ye spoke unto me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:25.</i> And when Moses came before Him, the Holy One, blessed be He, said, <i>Lo, I come unto thee in a thick cloud, that the people may hear when I speak with thee, and may also believe thee forever</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> Then Moses said before Him,<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">This is the sense of the conclusion of Verse 9: <i>and Moses told the words of the people unto the Eternal</i>, i.e., the words they had said, “Master of the universe, etc.” On the significance of this interpretation of Ramban, see further, Note 186.</i> “Master of the universe, your children are people of faith, and they accept upon themselves whatever You will speak.”<br>The above usage [of the word <i>vayashev</i> as meaning “returning” or “coming back”] is also found in the verse, <i>‘vayashivu’ unto them word… and they showed them the fruit of the Land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 13:26.</i> which means: “They [i.e., the spies] came back to them with the things which they saw.” [It cannot mean that “they reported” to them], for afterwards Scripture says there, <i>And they told him, and said</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> [Hence, <i>vayashivu</i> in the preceding verse must mean that “they came back” with the things they had seen.]<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Similarly, <i>vayashev Mosheh</i> here means that “Moses came back” with the words of the people to G-d. Actually, however, as Ramban continues to explain, he did not report them, as everything was revealed to Him. This differs with Ibn Ezra’s interpretation, as explained in the following note.</i> There is thus no need for Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s interpretation on this point.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra asks the following question: Since it says in Verse 8, <i>‘vayashev Mosheh’ the words of the people unto the Eternal</i>, why does it say again at the end of Verse 9, <i>and Moses told the words of the people unto the Eternal?</i> To remove this difficulty, Ibn Ezra said that <i>vayageid Mosheh (and Moses told)</i> in Verse 9 means that “Moses had already told the words of the people to G-d.” It is thus clear that Ibn Ezra explained <i>vayashev Mosheh</i> in Verse 8 as meaning that Moses “reported” the words of the people to G-d. Hence, Ibn Ezra’s difficulty and his forced solution. Ramban, however, explains <i>vayashev Mosheh</i> as meaning that Moses returned to G-d to report these words. Actually, there was no need to report them, as explained above. Then G-d said to him, <i>Lo, I come unto thee</i>, etc. (Verse 9), and finally <i>vayageid Mosheh:</i> Moses told these words to G-d, i.e., that His children are men of faith and that they accept upon themselves whatever He will speak. “There is thus no need for Ibn Ezra’s interpretation on this point,” as Ramban succinctly puts it.</i>

Verse 9

IN A THICK CLOUD. This is <i>the thick darkness where G-d was</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:18.</i> and all the people saw it and recognized it as such, as it is said, <i>And the appearance of the Glory of the Eternal was like devouring fire on the top of the mount in the eyes of the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 24:17.</i>
IN ORDER THAT THE PEOPLE MAY HEAR WHEN I SPEAK WITH THEE. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that there were among the Israelites people who doubted the existence of prophecy. And even though it is written, <i>and they believed in the Eternal, and in His servant Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:31.</i> it is said there, <i>and ‘Israel’ saw</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:31.</i> but not “all Israel.” It is this which they said to him [after the Giving of the Torah], <i>This day we have seen that G-d doth speak with man, and he liveth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21.</i> for at first they did not believe so. This is the meaning of the verse here, <i>in order that the people may hear when I speak with thee</i>, the Ten Commandments, <i>and also believe in thee forever</i>, i.e., “that you are My prophet,” for henceforth the matter of prophecy will be confirmed to them. [Thus far the words of Ibn Ezra.]<br>This is not correct. The children of Abraham never doubted prophecy, as they had always believed in it since the time of their forefathers. Scripture already has stated so: <i>And the people believed, and they heard that the Eternal hath remembered the children of Israel;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 4:31.</i> <i>and they believed in the Eternal, and in His servant Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:31.</i> Even though it does not say there, “and all the people [believed]” or “all Israel believed,” neither does it say here “that ‘all the people’ may hear.”<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that G-d said to Moses: “<i>I come to thee in a thick cloud</i>, so that you should draw near <i>to the thick darkness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:18.</i> <i>in order that the people may hear when I speak</i>. They themselves will be prophets when I speak, not [necessitating] that it should be confirmed to them through others,” just as it is said, <i>When the Eternal said unto me: Assemble Me the people, and I will make them hear My words, that they may learn to fear Me all the days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:10.</i><br>“<i>And they may also believe in thee forever</i>, i.e., through all the generations. And if there will arise among them <i>a prophet or dreamer of dreams</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:2.</i> to refute your words, they will deny him at once, for they have already seen with their own eyes and heard with their own ears that you have reached the highest stage in prophecy. Through you, will become clear to them that which is written: <i>If there be a prophet among you, I the Eternal make Myself known unto him in a vision, I do speak with him in a dream. My servant Moses is not so; he is trusted in all My house; with him do I speak mouth to mouth</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:6-8.</i> It is for this reason that He said, “<i>in order that the people may hear when I speak with thee</i>, for they will hear when I speak <i>out of the midst of the fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21. This verse had been used by Ibn Ezra to bring proof that before the Revelation there were some Israelites who still doubted the existence of prophecy. Ramban is now to interpret the true purport of the verse.</i> and they will know that it is I the Eternal Who speaks to you. They will believe in My words and also in you forever.” Similarly, that which the people said, <i>This day we have seen that G-d doth speak with man, and he liveth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21. This verse had been used by Ibn Ezra to bring proof that before the Revelation there were some Israelites who still doubted the existence of prophecy. Ramban is now to interpret the true purport of the verse.</i> was to state: “Now the thing has been confirmed to us with the sight of our own eyes, as was the wish of G-d [that we should all become prophets]. Henceforth, <i>Go thou near</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> for we know that you have reached the great stage in prophecy, <i>and hear all that the Eternal our G-d may say… and we will hear it</i> from you, <i>and do it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> for your prophecy has been confirmed to be above that of all prophets.”<br>Now I have seen the Mechilta where it is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>In order that the people may hear when I speak with thee</i>. This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: ‘Behold, I will call you from the top of the mountain, and you will come up,’ as it is said, <i>and the Eternal called Moses to the top of the mount, and Moses went up</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 20.</i> <i>And they may also believe in thee forever</i>, i.e., ‘in you and also in the prophets who are destined to arise after you.’” The words of the Mechilta incline towards the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mechilta states that “they may believe in you and also ‘in all the prophets,’” it would indicate that prophecy itself was still doubted, as Ibn Ezra wrote.</i>

Verse 10

V’KIDASHTAM’ TODAY AND TOMORROW. Rashi explained: “<i>V’kidashtam</i> means ‘and thou shalt prepare them.’” And so is the opinion of Onkelos. A similar usage is found in the verse: <i>I have commanded ‘lim’kudashai’</i> (“those who are prepared for Me” or “My consecrated ones”),<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 13:3.</i> and also in the following verse: <i>‘hithkadshu’ (prepare yourselves) for tomorrow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:18.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained it as meaning that they should bathe themselves in water. But if so, what is the sense of <i>today and tomorrow</i> when bathing was required only once? The correct interpretation is that they should sanctify themselves by separating from their wives, and from all uncleanness, for he who guards [himself] from being defiled by uncleanness is called <i>‘m’kudash’</i> (consecrated), just as it is said with reference to the priests, <i>There shall none defile himself for the dead;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 21:1.</i> <i>They shall be holy unto their G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> And it is further written, <i>because the priests had not sanctified themselves</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 30:3.</i> that is to say, they had not purified themselves. Similarly, <i>And David answered the priest, and said unto him: To a certainty women have been kept from us about these three days; when I came out, the vessels of the young men were holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 21:6.</i> And it is known that [before the Giving of the Torah the people] bathed themselves in water, this being derived logically from the required washing of garments.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, it is not necessary to explain <i>v’kidashtam</i>, as Ibn Ezra did, as meaning that they shall bathe themselves in water, for that requirement can be derived from the express commandment, <i>and let them wash their garments</i> (here, Verse 10). Hence, <i>v’kidashtam</i> must mean as Ramban explained it. The reasoning for the requirement of bathing or immersion is found here in the Mechilta: “<i>And let them wash their garments</i>. And whence do we know that immersion was also required? I reason as follows: If immersion is required in cases where washing of garments is not required (see Leviticus 15:16), is it not logical that immersion is also required in this case where washing of garments is expressly mentioned?”</i> And so did the Rabbis say in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, <i>ibid.</i></i> “There is no case where washing of garments is required in the Torah without the requirement of immersion [of one’s body].”

Verse 11

THE ETERNAL WILL COME DOWN IN THE SIGHT OF ALL THE PEOPLE. I.e., so that all the people will behold His coming down, meaning that they will see <i>the appearance of the Glory of the Eternal like devouring fire on the top of the mount</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:17.</i> but they will not see G-d, for it is written, <i>for man shall not see Me and live</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33:20.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13

WHEN ‘HAYOVEIL’ (THE RAM’S HORN) SOUNDETH LONG, THEY SHALL COME UP TO THE MOUNT. “The Hebrew word <i>hayoveil</i> denotes a ram’s horn, and the horn used here was that of Isaac’s ram.”<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:13.</i> Thus Rashi’s language. But I have not understood this, for Isaac’s ram was burnt as a whole-offering,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 22:13.</i> and horns and hoofs were completely burnt in whole-offerings.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:9 and 13.</i> Perhaps the Holy One, blessed be He, shaped the ashes of the horn [of Isaac’s ram] and restored it to what it was originally. But in my opinion, this Agadah (homily) contains a secret. Thus they<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Evidently, a reference to the masters of Cabala. The source of this statement, i.e., that the Voice heard on Mount Sinai was that of <i>Pachad Yitzchak</i>, is unknown to me.</i> have said that this Voice [heard on Mount Sinai, as stated in Verse 16], was that of <i>Pachad Yitzchak (the Fear of Isaac)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:42.. See Ramban, <i>ibid.</i> (Vol. I pp. 388-389). And in Bachya’s commentary here (Vol. II, p. 172 of my edition): “This is the <i>Pachad Yitzchak</i> which they perceived at Mount Sinai.”</i> It is for this reason that Scripture says, <i>and all the people that were in the camp trembled</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16. “Just as it says [in Genesis 27:33], in the case of Isaac: <i>And Isaac trembled</i>” (Bachya, <i>ibid.</i>)</i> At this manifestation of <i>G’vurah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “strength.” But here it denotes one of the Ten Emanations, the one which is synonymous with <i>Pachad Yitzchak</i>.</i> they did not grasp the commandment itself but <i>only a voice</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:12. See also Ramban further on Verse 19.</i>

Verse 14

AND MOSES WENT DOWN FROM THE MOUNT UNTO THE PEOPLE, AND SANCTIFIED THE PEOPLE. This verse teaches that the command expressed in the [above] verse, <i>And the Eternal said unto Moses: Go unto the people and sanctify them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 10.</i> was also given to him on the mountain which Moses ascended everytime that he was about to speak to Him. In the Mechilta, the Rabbis have explained:<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “This teaches that Moses did not turn to his personal affairs nor go to his house at all, but he went directly <i>from the mount unto the people</i>.”

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

MOSES SPOKE, AND G-D ANSWERED HIM BY A VOICE. In the Mechilta, the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here. The language is that of Rashi.</i> that this verse refers to the time of the Giving of the Torah, when Moses was proclaiming the commandments to Israel, as Rashi has written.<br>By way of the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse here does not yet speak of this. It is rather [to be explained as follows]: <i>The Glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> came down upon the mountain<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> on the third day, and Moses <i>brought forth the people out of the camp to meet</i> the Glory which appeared to them, <i>and they stood at the nether part of the mount</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> Moses went up near to the head of the mountain, where the Glory was, in a place designated for himself, and he spoke with Israel, teaching them what to do. The Israelites heard the Voice of G-d answering Moses and commanding him, but they did not understand what He said to him. Thus He commanded Moses the precepts mentioned further on in this section: <i>Go down, charge the people;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> <i>Go, get thee down, and thou shalt come up, thou, and Aaron with thee</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> This happened before the Giving of the Torah and also during the time when the Ten Commandments were given, for Moses did not go up to the top of the mount <i>unto the thick darkness where G-d was</i><sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:18.</i> until after the Giving of the Torah. And so he said, “<i>I stood between the Eternal and you at that time, to declare unto you the word of the Eternal; for you were afraid because of the fire, and went not up into the mount, saying</i><sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:5.</i> [that you will not ascend] as I did go up.” Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">I have not been able to identify them. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 387, Note 5.</i> explain that the Israelites were very much afraid of <i>the voice of the horn</i> which <i>waxed louder and louder</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19 before us.</i> and Moses would say to them at first: “Direct your thoughts, for now you will hear the Voice in such a manner,” and immediately <i>G-d answered</i> him <i>by a voice</i>.

Verse 20

AND THE ETERNAL CAME DOWN UPON MOUNT SINAI. If you will succeed in having insight into this section [of the Torah], you will understand that His Great Name, [i.e., the Tetragrammaton], came down upon Mount Sinai, and that He abode thereon in fire and spoke to Moses. The communication to Moses in the entire section was by this Proper Name of the Eternal. However, the ascent [of Moses — as mentioned in Verse 3: <i>And Moses went up unto G-d</i>] — and his bringing forth [the people out of the camp — as mentioned in Verse 17] — were towards the place of the Glory, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3, also in Verse 19.</i> And He warned, <i>lest they break through unto the Eternal to gaze</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> because even <i>the nobles of the children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:11.</i> did not see Him, and all Israel heard the Voice of G-d <i>out of the midst of the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21.</i> It is this which Scripture says, <i>And ‘Elokim’ (G-d) spoke all these words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:1.</i> just as our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta, <i>ibid.</i></i> “<i>Elokim</i> designates the Judge.”<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">“The Judge who is just in meting out punishment and faithful in giving reward” (Mechilta, <i>ibid.</i>)</i> And they have also said [with reference to the first two commandments]:<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Makkoth 24a. See Maimonides’ “The Commandments,” Vol. I, p. 1. The term <i>Hagvurah</i> (the Almighty) is analogous to “the Judge.”</i> “We have heard them from <i>Hagvurah</i> (the Almighty Himself).” In Deuteronomy it is written: <i>These words the Eternal spoke unto all your assembly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:19. And according to the above explanation, it should have said, “<i>Elokim</i> spoke.” That is because, etc.</i> That is because Scripture explains there [in the same verse] that He spoke <i>out of the midst of the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:4.</i> And this is the sense of the verse, <i>The Eternal spoke with you face to face in the mount out of the midst of the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:4.</i> And this is why it is said, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 20:2. “This alludes to the verse [in Deuteronomy 5:4, mentioned above]: <i>Face to face</i>, etc.” (Abusaula). The allusion is to the two Divine Names — the Tetragrammaton and <i>Elokim</i> — mentioned together here in 20:2.</i> Now do not find a difficulty in what the people said to Moses, <i>For who is there of all living flesh, that hath heard the Voice of the living G-d speaking out of the midst of the fire?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:23. This would indicate that they heard <i>Elokim chayim</i> speaking (Abusaula).</i> They did not say “that they heard G-d speaking out of the midst of the fire,” but they said <i>the Voice of G-d</i>, referring to what they perceived. This is why they said, <i>Go thou near, and hear all that the Eternal our G-d may say</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> And so did Moses say to them, <i>Did ever a people hear the Voice of G-d speaking out of the midst of the fire?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:33.</i> The word “speaking” here is referring to “the Voice,” something like the verse, <i>and he heard the Voice speaking unto him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i><br>From this you will understand what the Rabbis have always said in Midrashic homilies, i.e., that the Torah was given in seven voices.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 28:4, “Rabbi Yochanan said: ‘The One Voice was divided into seven voices.’”</i> They are the ones to which David alluded in the psalm: <i>Ascribe unto the Eternal, O ye sons of might</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 29:1. This psalm was considered by the Sages of the Talmud as referring to the Giving of the Torah (Sifre, <i>V’zoth Habrachah</i>, 343). The voice of the Eternal appears seven times in this psalm: <i>The voice of the Eternal is upon the waters</i> (Verse 3); <i>The voice of the Eternal is powerful; the voice of the Eternal is full of majesty</i> (Verse 4); <i>The voice of the Eternal breaketh the cedars</i> (Verse 5); <i>The voice of the Eternal heweth out flames of fire</i> (Verse 7); <i>The voice of the Eternal shaketh the wilderness</i> (Verse 8); <i>The voice of the Eternal maketh the hinds to calve</i> (Verse 9).</i> This is also the number of times [that the Voice] is alluded to in this section of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">1. And there were <i>‘koloth’ and lightnings</i> (Verse 16). Since the word <i>koloth</i> is written defectively without the letter <i>vav</i>, it signifies the singular: “and there was a voice.” 2. <i>And the voice of a horn (ibid.)</i> 3. <i>And the voice of the horn</i> (Verse 19). 4. <i>And G-d answered him by a voice (ibid.)</i> 5. <i>And all the people perceived ‘hakoloth’</i> (Verse 15). Here too the Hebrew <i>hakoloth</i> is written defectively and therefore refers only to one voice: “and all the people perceived the voice.” 6. <i>And the voice of the horn (ibid.)</i> 7. <i>And G-d spoke</i> (20:1). Thus there are seven voices mentioned in this section of the Torah (Abusaula).</i> The verse, <i>And there were ‘koloth’ and lightnings</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 246, number 1.</i> is written defectively and therefore counted as one; likewise, the verse, <i>And all the people perceived ‘hakoloth,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, number 5.</i> is missing the <i>vav</i> which signifies the plural, [and thus refers to only one voice]. Thus there are six [‘voices’ mentioned here in the section], and [in addition] it clearly says, <i>And G-d spoke</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, number 7.</i> In Deuteronomy, Scripture likewise mentions seven ‘voices’ in connection with the Giving of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">1. <i>Ye heard the voice of words</i> (Deuteronomy 4:12). 2. <i>Only a voice (ibid.)</i> 3. <i>A great voice</i> (5:19). 4. <i>The voice out of the midst of the fire</i> (5:20). 5. <i>And we have heard His voice</i> (Verse 21). 6. <i>If we hear the voice of the Eternal our G-d</i> (Verse 22). 7. <i>The voice of the living G-d speaking</i> (Verse 23).</i> In Tractate Berachoth,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 6b.</i> however, the Rabbis have said in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">For the meaning of the word Gemara, see <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 204.</i> that the Torah was given in five ‘voices.’ That is because they counted only the voices which are concealed, while the two — i.e., <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i> and <i>Thou shalt have no other gods before Me</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">So interpreted by Abusaula. See my Hebrew commentary, pp. 387-388.</i> — are explained in Scripture. The purport of this is that Moses our teacher was given the Torah in seven ‘voices,’<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">“This is an allusion to the seven [lower of the Ten] Emanations” (Bachya).</i> and he was the one who heard them and contemplated them. The Israelites, however, heard one voice, as it is said, <i>a great voice, and it went on no more</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:19.</i> and it is said again, <i>Ye heard the voice of words, but ye saw no form; only a voice</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:12.</i> Here also Scripture alluded thereto in saying, <i>And all the people perceived ‘hakoloth,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 246, number 5.</i> with one <i>vav</i> missing, [thus making it singular, ‘the voice’], for all voices appeared as one. By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], this is Scripture’s intent in saying, <i>G-d hath spoken once, twice</i> we <i>have heard this</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 62:12. The verse actually reads: <i>‘I’ have heard this</i>.</i> The sections of the Torah are thus explained, without anything being changed with another.

Verse 21



Verse 22

AND THE PRIESTS ALSO, THAT COME NEAR TO THE ETERNAL. I.e., who offer the sacrifices to <i>the Glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> and who come near to Him with them. [They also must sanctify themselves and not go outside of their designated place.]

Chapter 20



Verse 1



Verse 2

I AM THE ETERNAL THY G-D. This Divine utterance constitutes a positive commandment.<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 388. on the position of the Hilchoth Gedoloth on this point. Ramban thus sides with Rambam, who, in his Sefer Hamitzvoth, counted this as the first commandment. See my translation, “The Commandments,” I, pp. 1-2.</i> He said, <i>I am the Eternal</i>, thus teaching and commanding them that they should know and believe that the Eternal exists and that He is G-d to them. That is to say, there exists an Eternal Being through Whom everything has come into existence by His will<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">The universe is thus a result of design, and not merely of necessity. See Guide of the Perplexed, II, 18.</i> and power, and He is G-d to them, who are obligated to worship Him. He said, <i>Who brought thee out of the land of Egypt</i>, because His taking them out from there was the evidence establishing the existence and will of G-d, for it was with His knowledge and providence that we came out from there. The exodus is also evidence for the creation of the world, for assuming the eternity of the universe, [which precludes a Master of the universe Who is in control of it], it would follow that nothing could be changed from its nature.<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">“If you believe in the eternity of matter, it leads to the conclusion that if G-d should desire to shorten a fly’s wing or lengthen an ant’s foot, He would not be able to do it” (Ramban, in his sermon, “G-d’s Law Is Perfect,” Kithvei Haramban, I, p. 146). The miracles preceding the exodus, in which G-d’s mastery of the powers of nature was demonstrated, thus refuted the doctrine of the eternity of matter and established that of Creation.</i> And it is also evidence for G-d’s infinite power, and His infinite power is an indication of the Unity, as He said, <i>that thou</i> [i.e., Pharaoh] <i>mayest know that there is none like Me in all the earth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 9:14.</i> This is the intent of the expression, <i>Who brought thee out</i>, since they are the ones who know and are witnesses to all these things.
The meaning of <i>out of the house of bondage</i> is that they stayed in Egypt in a house of bondage as captives of Pharaoh.<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">This accords with the interpretation of the Mechilta here: “<i>Out of the house of bondage</i>. They were slaves to kings.” And as Rashi puts it, “from the house of Pharaoh where ye were slaves to him.”</i> He said this to them [in order to indicate] that they are obligated [to accept] <i>this</i> Great, <i>Glorious and Fearful Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> as their G-d, and to worship Him, because He redeemed them from Egyptian bondage. It is similar in meaning to the verse, <i>They are My servants whom I brought forth out of the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:55.</i> I have also already alluded to above<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:20.</i> by way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], to the reason why the two sacred Names — [the Tetragrammaton and <i>Elokim</i>] — are mentioned here.<br>This commandment, in the words of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 13b.</i> is called the obligation “to take upon oneself the yoke of the Kingdom of Heaven,” for these words, [i.e., <i>the Eternal your G-d</i>], which I have mentioned, indicate a King addressing His people. Thus the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on Verse 3 here.</i> “<i>Thou shalt have no other gods before Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> Why is this said?<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Since it says, <i>I am the Eternal thy God</i>, etc., it already means, “I, am not another.” Why then does He state again, <i>Thou shalt not have other gods before Me?</i></i> Because it says, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i>. This can be illustrated by a parable: A king invaded a country, and his attendants said to him, ‘Issue decrees to us.’<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">“Us.” In the Mechilta: “them,” i.e., the people.</i> He, however, refused, saying: ‘No! When you have accepted my sovereignty, I will issue decrees to you, for if you do not accept my sovereignty, how will you carry out my decrees?’ Similarly, G-d said to Israel: ‘<i>I am the Eternal thy G-d, thou shalt have no other gods</i>. I am He Whose sovereignty you have accepted in Egypt.’ And when they said to Him: ‘Yes,’ [He continued]: ‘Now, just as you have accepted My sovereignty, so you must also accept My decrees.’” That is to say, “Since you have accepted upon yourselves and have admitted that I am the Eternal, and that I am your G-d from the [time that you were yet in the] land of Egypt, then accept all My commandments.”<br>Now all the [Ten] Commandments are expressed in the singular — <i>the Eternal thy G-d, Who brought ‘thee’ out</i> — and not, as He began to say, [before the Giving of the Torah]: <i>‘Ye’ have seen;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:4.</i> <i>if ‘ye’ will hearken</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> This is because His intent is to warn that each individual is subject to punishment for [transgression of] the commandments, since He addresses Himself to each one individually, commanding him that he should not think that He will judge according to the majority and that the individual will be saved with them. This intent was explained to the people by Moses at the end of the Torah, in the section of <i>Atem Nitzavim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:17-19. See Ramban there on Verse 17.</i>

Verse 3

THOU SHALT HAVE NO OTHER GODS BEFORE MY FACE. Rashi wrote: “<i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i>. Why is this said?<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">Since it says, <i>I am the Eternal thy God</i>, etc., it already means, “I, am not another.” Why then does He state again, <i>Thou shalt not have other gods before Me?</i></i> It is because it says, <i>Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> From this I would only know that it is forbidden to make an idol. Whence do I know that one may not keep an idol that has already been made? Scripture therefore says, <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i>.” This is indeed a Beraitha<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 209.</i> taught in the Mechilta.<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> But if this is so, this verse would constitute a negative commandment in itself, being a prohibition against a person who retains an idol on his premises. [The violation thereof] does not make one liable to the death-penalty by the court. So [the question arises]: Why did He state the prohibition against keeping an idol, which makes one liable to whipping, before [He stated] the prohibition against bowing down to idols or worshipping them,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 5.</i> which makes one liable to extinction [if done intentionally but with no witnesses present], or death by the court [if there were witnesses]?<br>In my opinion, the final decision of the Law is not in accordance with this Beraitha,<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 209.</i> for it represents the opinion of a single Sage [against the opinion of the majority]. Thus we find it taught in the Sifra:<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, beginning of <i>Seder Kedoshim</i> (Leviticus, Chapter 19). On “Sifra,” See above, Note 52.</i> “<i>Nor make ye to yourselves molten gods</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:4.</i> I might think that others may make it for you. Scripture therefore says, <i>Nor… to yourselves</i>. From this I know only that [others may not make it] for you, but I might think that you may make it for others. Scripture therefore says, <i>Nor make ye</i>: not for you by others, and not by you for others. It is from here that the Rabbis have derived the principle that he who makes an idol for himself, transgresses two negative commandments: <i>Nor make ye</i>, and <i>Nor… to yourselves</i>. Rabbi Yosei says, ‘He transgresses three negative commandments: <i>Nor make ye, Nor… to yourselves</i>, and also <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i>.’” Thus you see that Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is that of one against a majority, for it is he who says that the verse <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i> constitutes a prohibition against retaining an idol [in one’s house]. However, according to the opinion of the first Sage, [which is that of the majority of the Rabbis], it is not so.<br>The correct interpretation even according to the literal meaning of Scripture is that the usage of the language of the verse here is similar to the expressions: <i>and the Eternal shall be my G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 28:21.</i> <i>to be your G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 11:45.</i> The verse here thus states that excepting the Eternal only, we are not to have others as gods, neither from all the angels above nor from all the host of heaven who are called <i>elohim</i>. This is something like that which is said, <i>he that sacrificeth ‘la’elohim’ (unto the gods) save unto the Eternal only, shall be utterly destroyed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:19.</i> It is thus a prohibition against believing in any of these beings, accepting them as gods, or saying to them, “thou art my god.”<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 140:7 and Sanhedrin 60b.</i> This is also the opinion of Onkelos, who translated: “[thou shalt have no] other gods excepting Me.”<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is evidently as follows: Since Onkelos always translated <i>elohim acheirim</i> as <i>ta’avath am’maya</i> (the deceptions of the nations) — see e.g., further, 23:13 — and here he translated, <i>ela acharan</i> (other gods), it shows that he referred to the angels of above, etc.</i><br>Know that wherever Scripture says <i>elohim acheirim</i>, the meaning is “others besides the Glorious Name.” It uses this expression with reference to accepting G-d or worshipping Him, thus saying: “Do not accept them upon yourselves as G-d, with the exception only of the Eternal.” But when Scripture speaks of making idols, it will never say <i>acheirim</i> (others) — [“other gods”] — Heaven forbid!<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">“When speaking of accepting or worshipping G-d, Scripture could say, ‘Do not accept or worship any other god besides the Eternal.’ But when Scripture warns against making an idol, how could it say [that we are] not to make ‘other gods’ when it is G-d Who has made everything and Who was not made!” (Tur.)</i> Instead it says, <i>Nor make to yourselves molten gods;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:4.</i> <i>Molten gods do not make unto thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:17.</i> They are called [gods] because they were made with the intent of serving their makers as gods, but in reference to them, Scripture says, <i>For they were no gods, but the works of men’s hands, wood and stone; therefore they have destroyed them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 37:19.</i><br>Thus in the second commandment, He admonished us firstly that we should not accept upon ourselves a master from among all gods excepting the Eternal. He then said that we should not make a graven image or any manner of likeness, [and we are not] to bow down to them or worship them in any manner whatsoever. It is for this reason that He said, <i>Thou shalt not bow down unto them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5. The intent of Ramban’s words is as follows: According to his own interpretation that this entire second commandment is directed against worshipping idols, we can understand why it says here in Verse 5, <i>Thou shalt not bow down ‘to them’</i> and it does not say ‘other gods,’ because the purport of that verse is to be understood in connection with the preceding verse: “do not make a graven image, etc., to bow down ‘unto them.’” But according to Rashi, who interpreted <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i> (Verse 3) as being a prohibition against keeping an idol, and <i>Thou shalt not make unto thee</i>, etc., (Verse 4) as being a prohibition against making idols, Verse 5 should have said, “Thou shalt not bow down ‘to other gods,’” since the subject of worshipping the idols as gods is here mentioned for the first time.</i> since it is connected with the making [of idols — mentioned in the preceding verse] — which He prohibited the people from bowing down to them. Thus all [of the first three verses in this second commandment] constitute prohibitions against worshipping idols, and their violations all entail death by the court. This verse, [i.e., <i>Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image</i>, etc. (Verse 4)], is thus not a prohibition against making idols which one does not worship oneself, [as Rashi would have it]. Further on [in Verse 20], He indeed warns against this, as it is said, <i>gods of silver, or gods of gold, ye shall not make unto thee</i>. Similarly, <i>Thou shalt not make unto thee molten gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:17.</i> <i>Ye shall not make unto thee idols</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:1.</i>
AL PANAI’ (BEFORE MY FACE). This is similar in meaning to these expressions: <i>Surely ‘al panecha’ (to Thy face) he will blaspheme Thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Job 1:11.</i> <i>Now therefore be pleased to look upon me; for surely I shall not lie ‘al p’neichem’ (to your face)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:28.</i> He thus admonishes here: “Do not make unto yourselves other gods, for they are before My face, as I look and gaze at all times and in all places at those who make them.” A thing which is done in the face of a person when he is aware thereof is called <i>al panav</i> (before his face). Thus: <i>So the present passed over ‘al panav’ (before him)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:22.</i> So also: <i>And Nadab and Abihu died… and Eleazar and Ithamar ministered in the priest’s office ‘al p’nei’ (in the presence of) Aaron their father</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:4.</i> meaning that Aaron their father saw it and was aware thereof. In the Book of Chronicles it is written: <i>And Nadab and Abihu died ‘liphnei’ (before) their father, and had no children</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 24:2. Since in the above verse (Numbers 3:4), it says that Nadab and Abihu died <i>before the Eternal</i>, Ramban therefore also quotes the verse from Chronicles, where it is stated that they died before their father. Hence the significance of the statement that he saw the remaining two sons performing the Divine Service in his presence.</i> Thus the purport of the verse here is: “Do not make other gods unto yourselves, for I am present with you always and see you in private and in public.”<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], you will understand the secret of <i>panim</i> (face) from that which we have written<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:20.</i> that Scripture warned concerning the Revelation:<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 17.</i> <i>‘Panim b’phanim’ (face to face) did the Eternal speak with you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:4.</i> And you will know the secret of the word <i>acheirim</i> (others), and then the entire verse will come [to light] in its plain meaning and purport. And so did Onkelos say it.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos translated <i>al panai</i> as <i>bar mini</i> (outside of Me). Thus the sense of the verse is as follows: “Do not worship <i>elohim acheirim</i>, since they were all created, excepting G-d, Who is eternal and has not been created by any being.” See also Note 285 above.</i> It is this which is said, <i>Ye shall not make with Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20. And as Rashi explains it: “Do not make any likeness of My ministers that serve Me.”</i> “<i>For I the Eternal thy G-d am a jealous G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> i.e., to be worshipped alone, and it is not fitting that you join others to Me. And I am <i>E-il</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban now continues to explain the two Hebrew words in the above Verse: <i>E-il kana (a jealous G-d)</i>.</i> the Mighty One,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Genesis 17:1 (Vol. I, pp. 214-215).</i> Who has the power in My hand;<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 31:29.</i> and I am, furthermore, <i>kana</i>, avenging from the one who gives My glory to another and My praise to graven images.”<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 42:8.</i><br>Now in no place in Scripture is an expression of ‘jealousy’ found in reference to the Glorious Name except in the matter of idol-worship. Thus the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] wrote in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, I, 36.</i> that in the entire Torah and in all the books of the Prophets, you will not find the term <i>burning anger</i>, wrath, or jealousy [applied to G-d] except in reference to idolatry. But of the holy ones of the Supreme One it is written: <i>And the anger of the Eternal was kindled against Moses;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 4:14.</i> <i>And the anger of the Eternal was kindled against them</i> [i.e., Aaron and Miriam] <i>and He departed!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:9.</i> And it is further written, <i>My wrath is kindled against thee</i> [i.e., Eliphaz the Temanite] <i>and against thy two friends, for ye have not spoken of Me the thing that is right, as My servant Job has</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Job 42:7.</i> However, as far as the term ‘jealousy’ is concerned, [Rambam] is correct [in maintaining that it is not applied to G-d except in reference to idolatry]. And so did the Rabbis say in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on Verse 5 here.</i> “I zealously exact punishment for idolatry, but in other matters, I am gracious and merciful.”<br>In my opinion, jealousy is mentioned only with reference to idolatry in Israel. The reason for the jealousy is that Israel is the treasured possession of the Glorious Name, which He has separated to Himself, as I have explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:4.</i> Now if His people, His servants, turn to other gods, G-d is ‘jealous’ of them even as a man is jealous of his wife when she goes to other men, and of a servant who makes another master for himself. But Scripture uses no such term of jealousy with reference to other peoples to whom He has allotted the hosts of heaven.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 4:19.</i><br>At this point, I make mention of what Scripture teaches concerning idolatry. There were three kinds of idol-worship. The first [group of idol-worshippers] began to worship the angels, who are the Separate Intelligences,<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">“For the angels are not material bodies but only forms distinguished from each other… All these forms live and realize the Creator, and their knowledge of Him is exceedingly great” (Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 2:3-8). For Rambam’s version of the development of idolatry, see his first chapter in Hilchoth Akum. See also Guide of the Perplexed I, 49, on figurative expressions applied to angels.</i> because it is known that some of them have rulership over the peoples, something like it is written, <i>the prince of</i> the kingdom of <i>Greece</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:20.</i> <i>the prince of the kingdom of Persia</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> They thought that [these angels] have power over them to do good or to do evil, and so each people began to worship the prince appointed over them, as the first [peoples] knew how to identify them. Now these are referred to in the Torah and in all the Writings as <i>other gods, the gods of the peoples</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:14.</i> for angels are called <i>elohim</i>, as it is said, <i>He is G-d of gods;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:17.</i> <i>Bow down to Him, all ye gods;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 97:7.</i> <i>For the Eternal is greater than all gods</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:11.</i> They worshipped the angels even though they admitted that supreme strength and infinite power belonged only to G-d the Most High. Thus did the Rabbis say,<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 110a.</i> [with reference to the peoples of the world], that they call G-d the Most High “G-d of gods.” Regarding this kind of idol-worship, Scripture has said, <i>He that sacrificeth ‘la’elohim’ (to the gods) shall be utterly destroyed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:19.</i> It thus mentioned them by the name with which they were known.<br>The second kind of idolatry appeared when people began worshipping the visible hosts of heaven, some worshipping the sun or the moon, and others worshipping one of the constellations. Each of the nations knew the power of the constellation according to the dominion thereof in their land,<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 38:33.</i> and they thought that by worshipping them, the constellation would be strengthened and it would help them, something like it is written, <i>or the sun, or the moon, or any of the host of heaven</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:3.</i> And it is further written, <i>And they shall spread them before the sun, and the moon, and all the host of heaven, whom they have loved, and whom they have served, and after whom they have walked, and whom they have sought, and to whom they have bowed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 8:2.</i> and as it is said in the Torah with reference to the prohibition of idolatry: <i>And lest thou lift up thine eyes unto heaven, and when thou seest the sun and the moon and the stars, even all the host of heaven, thou be drawn away and worship them and serve them, which the Eternal thy G-d hath allotted unto all the peoples under the whole heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 4:19.</i> That is to say, because G-d allotted them to all the peoples and gave each people a star or constellation, you should not let yourself be allured to worshipping them. Now these are the people who began making the many forms of graven images, <i>Asheirim and the sun-images</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 27:9.</i> They would make the forms of the constellations in the hours of their strength according to their rank, and in the opinion of the people, it bestowed power and success upon them. It appears likely to me that this [form of idolatry] began in the Generation of the Dispersion,<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Genesis 11:2 (Vol. I, pp. 154-155). In describing the beginnings of this second stage of idolatry, Rambam introduces it with this statement: “In the course of time, there arose among men false prophets who said that G-d commanded them, saying ‘Worship that particular star’” (Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Akum 1:2). Ramban here is more specific and suggests that the beginnings of this kind of idolatry took place in the age of the dispersion of the nations. This would seem to be the intent of Ramban’s words, “It appears likely to me…”</i> when G-d scattered the nations to various countries and the stars and the constellations began holding sway over them according to their divisions. The builders of the Tower had declared their intention to make themselves a name<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 11:4.</i> and not be scattered, as I have hinted in its place.<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban, Genesis 11:2 (Vol. I, pp. 154-155). In describing the beginnings of this second stage of idolatry, Rambam introduces it with this statement: “In the course of time, there arose among men false prophets who said that G-d commanded them, saying ‘Worship that particular star’” (Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Akum 1:2). Ramban here is more specific and suggests that the beginnings of this kind of idolatry took place in the age of the dispersion of the nations. This would seem to be the intent of Ramban’s words, “It appears likely to me…”</i> Now all these groups had false prophets who foretold them future events and informed them through the arts of sorcery and divination some of the things that were to come upon them. The constellations also have lords who abide in the atmosphere as the angels do in the heavens, and know the things that are to come.<br>Closely related to this kind of idolatry was the worship of human beings. When people of a country saw that a certain individual — such as Nebuchadnezzar — had great power and that his star was very much in the ascendancy, they thought that by accepting his worship upon themselves and directing their thought towards him, their star would also ascend together with his. He would also think that by their attaching their thoughts to him, his success would be augmented on account of the power of their souls directed towards him. This was the opinion of Pharaoh, who, according to the words of our Rabbis, [looked upon himself as a god],<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 9:7.</i> and of Sennacherib, concerning whose ideas Scripture says, <i>I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:14. It is to be noted though that this prophecy was said with reference to the king of Babylon (<i>ibid.</i>, Verses 4, and 22). Accordingly, it is difficult to understand why Ramban here mentions Sennacherib who was king of Assyria, and not Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon. See however, in Sefer Hage’ulah (Kithvei Haramban I, p. 274) where Ramban writes that Scripture sometimes “interchanges from the name of the king of Babylon to the king of Assyria” and he quotes various verses to prove it. In this sense it may be understood here that Ramban mentioned “Sennacherib” when his intent was really to the king of Babylon.</i> and of Hiram<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 28:2.</i> and his companions<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Such as Nimrod. See Chullin 89a.</i> who made themselves gods. They were wicked, but they were not absolute fools.<br>The third kind of idolatry appeared afterwards when people began worshipping the demons which are spirits, as I will explain with G-d’s help.<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Seder Acharei Moth</i> (Leviticus 17:6).</i> Some of them too are appointed over the peoples to be masters in their lands and to harm their beleagured ones and those who have stumbled, as is known of their activity through the art of necromancy, as well as through the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 6a. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 393.</i> It is with reference to this [third kind of idolatry] that Scripture says, <i>They sacrificed unto demons, no-gods, gods that they knew not, new gods that came up of late, which your fathers dreaded not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:17.</i> Scripture ridicules them, [i.e., the Israelites], saying they sacrifice also to the demons who are no gods at all. That is to say, they are not like the angels who are called <i>eloha</i>. Instead, they are gods that they knew not, meaning that they found in them no trace of might or power of rulership. Furthermore, they are new to them, having learned only lately to worship them from the Egyptian sorcerers, and even their wicked forefathers such as Terach and Nimrod<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 10:9. See Ramban there (Vol. I, p. 147).</i> did not dread them at all. Of this [kind of idolatry] Scripture warns, <i>And they shall no more sacrifice their sacrifices unto the demons, after whom they go astray</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:7.</i><br>Thus in this second commandment, the Torah prohibited all [kinds of] worship, <i>save unto the Eternal only</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:19.</i> It is for this reason that He first admonished, <i>Thou shalt have no other gods ‘al panai’ (before My face)</i>, which is a reference to the first kind of idolatry, namely, the worship of the angels. This is the intent of <i>al panai</i>, whose secret I have alluded to. Then He further admonished against graven images and <i>any manner of likeness of any thing that is in heaven above</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> which also alludes to mental images of spiritual phenomena, something like it is written, <i>It stood still, but I could not discern the appearance thereof; a form was before mine eyes</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Job 4:16.</i> And so have the Rabbis said:<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 24b.</i> “<i>That is in heaven</i>. This includes the sun, moon, stars, and constellations. <i>Above</i>. This includes the ministering angels.” Of them, too, [the worshippers] would make figures representing the Separate Intelligences<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">“For the angels are not material bodies but only forms distinguished from each other… All these forms live and realize the Creator, and their knowledge of Him is exceedingly great” (Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 2:3-8). For Rambam’s version of the development of idolatry, see his first chapter in Hilchoth Akum. See also Guide of the Perplexed I, 49, on figurative expressions applied to angels.</i> which are the souls of the constellations, as happened in the case of the [golden calf], as I am prepared to explain there with the help of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:1.</i>

Verse 4

ALL THAT IS IN THE WATER UNDER THE EARTH. This expression includes the demons <i>beneath the waters and the inhabitants thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Job 26:5.</i> And so the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>All that is in the water under the earth:</i> this includes the reflected images [which appear in the water].” Of all of them He said, <i>Thou shalt not bow down unto them, nor serve them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> in any manner of worship whatsoever, even if the worshipper’s intent is not to remove himself from the authority of the Holy One, blessed be He. Thus He has ordered all these services to be devoted to the Proper Name [of the Eternal], blessed be He.

Verse 5
