POKEID’ (VISITING) THE INIQUITY OF THE FATHERS UPON THE CHILDREN UNTO THE THIRD AND FOURTH GENERATION OF THEM THAT HATE ME. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that the meaning of the term <i>p’kidah</i> is similar to that of <i>z’chirah</i> (remembrance), just as in the verse, <i>And the Eternal ‘pakad’ Sarah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 21:1.</i> which is like: “and the Eternal remembered her.” The purport [of the verse here, according to Ibn Ezra], is that G-d will postpone [punishment] of the wicked person because perhaps he will repent and beget a righteous son. But if the son walks in his father’s ways, as also the third and fourth generations, their memories will be destroyed, for G-d will ‘remember’ [to visit punishment upon them for] what the parents have done, and He will no longer postpone their punishment. All the commentators have similarly interpreted [the above Scriptural expression]. But if this be so, the sins of the fathers will not be visited upon their children nor upon the third generation, but only on the fourth. It would have been proper then for Scripture to say that He will visit the iniquity of the fathers and their sons and of the third generation upon the fourth generation! Perhaps these commentators will say that the sense of the verse is that He remembers the iniquity of the fathers upon their sons, saying [to them], “You and your fathers have sinned.” He does thus with the third and fourth generations, and then takes vengeance upon them, and never again does He visit it upon them, for He destroys them all in their iniquity.<br>But their explanation is not correct. Scripture mentions G-d’s remembrance of all of them equally, and it does not specify that the vengeance is exacted [only] in the end, i.e., on the fourth generation. Besides, the term <i>p’kidah</i> in conjunction with the word <i>al</i> — [as it occurs here: <i>‘pokeid’ avon avoth ‘al’ banim</i>] — is not used in connection with remembrance, but rather signifies vengeance [or punishment]. Thus: <i>And on the day ‘pokdi upakad’ti’ (that I do punish, I will punish) them for their sin;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:34.</i> <i>In that day ‘yiphkod hashem’ (the Eternal will punish) with his sore and great and strong sword leviathan the slant serpent, and leviathan the tortuous serpent, and He will slay the dragon that is in the sea;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 27:1.</i> <i>‘yiphkod hashem’ (the Eternal will punish) the host of the high heaven on high</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 24:21.</i> All of these are expression of vengeance and punishment.<br>The correct interpretation thus appears to me to be that Scripture is stating that He visits the iniquity, which the father perpetrated, upon his children, and excises them on account of the iniquity of their father, something like it is said, <i>Prepare ye slaughter for his children for the iniquity of their fathers</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:21.</i> Similarly, He visits it upon the third generation if the sin of the two generations is not yet full, something like [it is said], <i>for the iniquity of the Amorite is not yet full</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 15:16.</i> Sometimes He visits the iniquity of all three generations upon the fourth one when their measure [of iniquity] is filled and then he excises them. But in the fifth generation, no one is punished for the iniquity of his ancestor in the first generation. Now in the Book of Deuteronomy, [where the Ten Commandments are restated], He added a <i>vav</i> [to the expression <i>‘al shileishim’ (unto the third generation)</i>, thus making it] <i>‘v’al’ shileishim v’al ribei’im l’sonai</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:9.</i> But the meaning of the <i>vav</i> [there is not the usual “and”] but “or” — [” ‘or’ unto the third generation ‘or’ unto the fourth generation of them that hate me” — as explained above].<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that children’s children are called “children.” This is why He used the briefer term.<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra tried to answer this question: Since Scripture uses the terms <i>shileishim</i> and <i>ribei’im</i> to signify the third and fourth generations, why does it not say <i>shni’im</i> for the second generation instead of using the term <i>banim</i> (children)? For this reason, Ibn Ezra interpreted <i>banim</i> as meaning “children and children’s children,” for they are both called <i>banim</i>. Hence, Scripture could not use the term <i>shni’im</i>, for that would have meant only the second generation after the sinner, who is the first generation. However, in fact the second <i>and</i> third generations also need to be included here. For this reason, Scripture used <i>banim</i>, which includes the children’s children as well, i.e., the third generation after the sinner. Accordingly, in Ibn Ezra’s opinion, <i>shileishim</i> will mean the children of the third generation, who are the fourth generation after the sinner, and <i>ribei’im</i> will mean the children of the fourth generation, who constitute the fifth generation. Ramban will differ with this entire interpretation.</i> You can understand this from the terms <i>shileishim</i> (the third generation) and <i>ribei’im</i> (the fourth generation).<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra’s intent is that when you consider the words <i>shileishim</i> and <i>ribei’im</i>, this question will occur: Why does Scripture not use the term <i>shni’im</i> instead of <i>banim?</i> You must then conclude as explained in the preceding note.</i> But this is not so. <i>Shileishim</i> means the third generation in that sin. [Hence, it includes only the father, his children, and his children’s children.] Likewise, <i>ribei’im</i> means the fourth generation in that sin, totalling four sinners. And the verse stated in connection with the thirteen attributes of G-d, <i>visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, and upon the children’s children, unto the third generation and unto the fourth generation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:7.</i> is to be explained<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew text possibly lends itself to this translation: “He — [i.e., G-d, Who is proclaiming these thirteen attributes] — is explaining that <i>al b’nei banim</i> (upon the children’s children) is the <i>shileishim</i> (the third generation) and <i>ribei’im</i> (the fourth generation).” In other words, <i>al b’nei banim</i> is in apposition to <i>al shileishim v’al ribei’im</i>.</i> as “the children’s children, <i>who are</i> the third and fourth generations.” It is for this reason that Moses, [when invoking the thirteen attributes] in the case of the spies, turned back [to this specific attribute as expressed here in the Ten Commandments] and said, <i>visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, upon the third and upon the fourth generation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:18.</i> He did not mention “children’s children,” for it is all one, [i.e., “children’s children” is the same as <i>shileishim</i>].<br>Now Scripture states [that this attribute of punishment applies only to] <i>those that hate Me</i>. That is, if the children hate G-d. If the sinner begot a righteous son, he does not bear the iniquity of the father, as [the prophet] Ezekiel has explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 18:20.</i><br>From the words of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta Sotah 4:1.</i> there appears a proof to the explanation I have presented above, [i.e., that <i>‘pokeid’ the sins of the fathers</i>, etc., is to be understood in the sense of “visiting” or “punishing”]. From here, they have derived the principle that the [Divine] measure of good is greater than the measure of punishment, for the measure of punishment is for four generations [while that of reward is for thousands]. But if it were as the first explanation has it, [namely, that of Ibn Ezra, that <i>pokeid</i> means “remembers,” thus signifying that He postpones the punishment of the sinner until the fourth generation in the hope that perhaps he will beget a righteous son], then “the measure of good” would have been greater if He postponed punishment even to the tenth generation!<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra, the phrase in question represents a measure of G-d’s mercy. He does not punish the sinner immediately but “remembers” it until the third and fourth generations because perhaps he will repent and beget a righteous son. But, asks Ramban, if that were the interpretation, “the measure of Divine good” would be increased if such “punishment” were withheld even to the tenth generation! Why then did the Rabbis in the above-mentioned text speak of the Divine measure of good being manifested in punishment only to four generations when that Divine manifestation would apply even if it were extended to the tenth generation? But according to Ramban, who asserts that this verse represents a measure of G-d’s <i>judgment</i> — for <i>pokeid</i> means “punishing,” and the verse declares that the effects of the punishment are felt up to and including the fourth generation — that question cannot be asked. If punishment were extended to the tenth generation, it would no longer represent “a measure of good.” On the contrary, it would be a harsher judgment.</i><br>It is possible that this strict measure [of punishment that is imposed on a sinner and which is felt up to the fourth generation] applies only to idolatry, for it is with regard to this prohibition that He is warning here. However, in the rest of the commandments, [the rule applies that] <i>every one shall die of his iniquity</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 31:30.</i> You will find the hidden secret of <i>visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children</i> in the Book of Ecclesiastes.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">The allusion is to the verse, <i>One generation passeth away, and another generation cometh</i> (Ecclesiastes 1:4), upon which the Sefer Habahir commented: “that hath come already.” This means that the generation that passes away had come into the sins of the father “that had come already” in a previous generation, and the sins of the father are now visited upon the son, etc. (Ma’or V’shamesh). The mystic doctrine of the transmigration of souls is thus alluded to here.</i> I have already written concerning it.<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 38:8 (Vol. I, pp. 469-470).</i>

Verse 6

AND HE SHOWETH MERCY UNTO THE THOUSANDTH GENERATION OF THEM THAT LOVE ME AND KEEP MY COMMANDMENTS. It appears from the sense of the verse that this Divine assurance is with respect to the subject-matter of the commandments that He mentioned. He is thus saying that to those that love Him, He will show mercy to their thousandth generation. These are the ones who sacrifice their lives for Him, for they are the ones who acknowledge only the Glorious Name and His G-dship and deny all strange gods, refusing to worship them even if they are in mortal danger. They are called “the lovers [of G-d],” for this is the kind of love that we have been obligated to observe even at the sacrifice of life, just as He has said, <i>And thou shalt love the Eternal thy G-d with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy might</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 6:5.</i> meaning that you should give your very life because of your love of Him, that you should not alter Him for another god, nor join Him together with a strange god. It is for this reason that [the prophet] said of Abraham, <i>the seed of Abraham my friend</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:8. See Maimonides’ “The Commandments,” Vol. I, p. 4.</i> since he risked his life in order not to worship the idols in Ur of the Chaldees.<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Genesis 11:28 (Vol. I, pp. 156-161).</i> The rest of the righteous are called <i>those that keep My commandments</i>.<br>Now many scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">So it appears from Rashi’s commentary to Sotah 31 a, and from Rambam’s introduction to the tenth chapter of Sanhedrin. See my Hebrew commentary here, p. 395.</i> have explained that “His lovers” are those who worship Him without the intention of receiving a reward, just as our Sages have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 1:3, “Be not like servants who minister to their Master with the intention of receiving a reward; but be like the servants who minister to their Master without the intention of receiving a reward.”</i> But I have found in the Mechilta that it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>Of them that love Me</i>. This refers to Abraham and those like him. <i>And those that keep My commandments</i>. This refers to the prophets and the elders. Rabbi Nathan says that the verse, <i>of them that love Me and keep My commandments</i>, refers to those who dwell in the Land of Israel and give their lives for the commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">The reference is obviously to the persecutions by the Roman emperor Hadrian (117-138 Common Era), when the Jews in the Land of Israel were forbidden the practice of Judaism, including the study of Torah. Their determination to remain in the Land of Israel and practice their faith instead of emigrating to more peaceful lands such as Babylon, was at those times constituted as a special manifestation of their love of G-d.</i> ‘Why are you being led out to be executed?’ ‘Because I have circumcised my son.’ ‘Why are you being led out to be burned?’ ‘Because I read the Torah.’ ‘Why are you being led out to be hanged?’ ‘Because I ate the unleavened bread.’ ‘Why are you being lashed with the whip?’<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">In our Mechilta: “Why are you whipped with a hundred lashes?”</i> ‘Because I took the <i>lulav</i>.’<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">“The Palm-branch.” See Leviticus 23:40.</i> And it says, <i>Those with which I was wounded in the house of my friends</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 13:6.</i> These are the wounds which have caused me to become beloved of My Father in heaven.” Thus Rabbi Nathan explained that the love [of G-d, which is referred to in the verse before us], meant the sacrifice of life for the sake of the commandments. Now the verse here certainly refers to idolatry, for it is with reference to it that we are obligated at all times forever to suffer death rather than transgress [the law].<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 74a. See Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 5:2-3.</i> But [Rabbi Nathan] broadened the matter to include all the commandments, [such as circumcision, the study of Torah, the eating of unleavened bread on Passover, the taking of the <i>lulav</i><sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">“The Palm-branch.” See Leviticus 23:40.</i> on Succoth — as mentioned above] — because in the time of religious persecutions, we are obligated to suffer death for any of the commandments<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 74a. See Rambam, Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 5:2-3.</i> [rather than transgress them], as derived from the other verse, <i>And ye shall not profane My holy Name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:32. For full discussion of this topic, see my translation of Maimonides’ “The Commandments.” Vol. II, commandment 63, pp. 61-63.</i> And it would also be incorrect to say of the first Sage [in the above Mechilta] — i.e., who said that [<i>those who love Me</i>] refers to Abraham, while [<i>those who keep My commandments</i>] refers to the prophets — that he is of the opinion that the prophets kept the commandments with the intention that they receive a reward! [Thus the explanation of “the many scholars”<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">So it appears from Rashi’s commentary to Sotah 31 a, and from Rambam’s introduction to the tenth chapter of Sanhedrin. See my Hebrew commentary here, p. 395.</i> mentioned above is refuted by the Mechilta.] However, there is a secret in this [Mechilta]: Abraham risked his life in love<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Abusaula, in his commentary on the mystic passages in Ramban, explains this as follows: “Abraham’s power revealed itself in mercy, while that of the rest of the prophets in the ameliorated Divine attribute of justice.” See Ramban, Genesis Vol. I, p. 543.</i> — something like it is written, <i>mercy to Abraham</i><sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Micah 7:20. “Know that mercy is love” (Ma’or V’shamesh).</i> — and the rest of the prophets in <i>g’vurah</i> (might).<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Abusaula, in his commentary on the mystic passages in Ramban, explains this as follows: “Abraham’s power revealed itself in mercy, while that of the rest of the prophets in the ameliorated Divine attribute of justice.” See Ramban, Genesis Vol. I, p. 543.</i> Understand this.

Verse 7

LO THISA’ (THOU SHALT NOT TAKE) THE NAME OF THE ETERNAL THY G-D IN VAIN. This verse has already been explained in the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Shebuoth 21a. Maimonides’ “The Commandments,” Vol. II, commandment 62, pp. 60-61.</i> He prohibits [here] swearing by the Glorious Name in vain, such as swearing that which is contrary to facts known to man, or swearing to [the truth of] a self-evident fact. For example: if one swears that a pillar of marble is of gold, or that it is of marble, and the pillar is right before them and they recognize it as such [that it is of marble].<br>By way of the plain meaning of Scripture, the verse also prohibits the taking of the Glorious Name in vain upon one’s lips [even without an oath], the usage of the term [<i>lo thisa</i>] being similar to these expressions: <i>‘Lo thisa’ (Thou shalt not utter) a false report;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:1.</i> <i>Nor ‘esa’ (do I take) their names upon my lips</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 16:4.</i> Speaking is called <i>thisa</i>, [which literally means “lifting”], because the speaker thereby lifts up his voice. Similarly: <i>‘masa’ (The burden) of the word of the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 9:1.</i> also, <i>In that day ‘yisa’ (shall he swear), saying: I will not be a healer</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:7.</i> which means that he will lift up his voice to say so. And in truth, this — [i.e., just taking G-d’s Name in vain even without an oath] — is also forbidden, and in the language of the Sages,<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Temurah 3b.</i> it is called “pronouncing the Name of Heaven to no purpose.” Thus our Rabbis have already said:<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, <i>Vayikra</i> 2.</i> “Whence do we know that [in dedicating a beast for a sacrifice] a man should not say, ‘Unto the Eternal this is a whole-offering,’ or ‘Unto the Eternal this is a sin-offering,’ but instead he should say, ‘This is a whole-offering unto the Eternal,’ ‘This is a sin-offering unto the Eternal’?<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">The reason for the prohibition is that if he mentions the Name of G-d first and he immediately changes his mind about bringing the beast as an offering, he will have taken the Name of Heaven for no purpose (Nedarim 10 b, Rashi).</i> Scripture therefore says, <i>an offering unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:2. Here the word “offering” is mentioned first and then the Name of G-d follows.</i> And must we not reason by using the method of <i>kal vachomer?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 208.</i> If the Torah said of him who is about to dedicate [something to Heaven], ‘Let My Name not rest on it until [he has first said] <i>korban</i> (sacrifice)’, is it not logical [that we must not pronounce the Name of Heaven to no purpose]!”<br>He has placed this commandment after the prohibition of idolatry, because just as it is proper to fear the Great and Fearful Name by not giving His Glory to another,<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 42:8.</i> so it is fitting to give glory to His Name. He who takes it in vain profanes it, similar to that which is written, <i>And ye shall not swear by My Name falsely, so that thou profane not the Name of thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:12.</i> Just as He was stringent in the case of idolatry and wrote the punishment [for transgression], i.e., that He is <i>a jealous G-d, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> so did He record here the punishment <i>that He will not hold him guiltless</i>. He used this expression instead of saying that He will visit his sin upon him, [as He did in the case of idolatry], because people who swear [in vain] do not consider it a real sin, and they think it is proper that He forgive them. Therefore He said that <i>whosoever toucheth</i> that <i>shall not go unpunished</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 6:29.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra has written appropriately on this verse.<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">The purport of Ibn Ezra’s explanation is as follows: When one swears by the Name of G-d, his intent is to imply that just as G-d is true, so is his word true. When he fails to fulfill it, it is thus tantamount to denying Him. The same reasoning applies to an oath taken in vain.</i><br>Now the language of this verse, <i>the Name of the Eternal thy G-d</i>, implies that it is as if Moses was speaking, and so also in the case of all the following commandments, whereas in the first two verses<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">“First two verses.” When the Ten Commandments are read in public, all the five verses contained in the first and second commandments are read as if they were one verse. Ramban’s language must then be understood as: “the first two commandments.”</i> G-d is speaking: <i>I; Who brought thee out; before Me; For I; Of them that love Me and keep My commandments</i>. It is for this reason that our Rabbis of blessed memory have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Makkoth 24a.</i> “We heard the two commandments — <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i> and <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i> — from the Almighty Himself,” for they are the root of everything. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra asked [concerning this tradition of the Rabbis] that Scripture says, <i>And G-d spoke all these words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> and still more clearly it is written [following the Ten Commandments], <i>These words the Eternal spoke unto all your assembly</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:19.</i> and again it is written there, <i>And He wrote them down upon two Tablets of stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 4:13.</i> meaning that as He said the Ten Commandments <i>to all your assembly</i>, so He wrote them down upon the Tablets!<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">According to Ibn Ezra, all these verses apparently stand in contradiction to that which the Rabbis have said, i.e., that we heard only the first two commandments from the Almighty Himself. Ramban proceeds to remove the difficulty.</i><br>I will explain to you the tradition of our Rabbis [that we heard the first two commandments from the Almighty Himself]. Surely all Israel heard the entire Ten Commandments from the mouth of G-d, as the literal meaning of Scripture indicates. But in the first two commandments, they heard the utterance of speech and understood their words even as Moses understood them. Therefore He spoke to them directly [in the first person], just as a master speaks to his servant, as I have mentioned. From then on, in the rest of the commandments, they heard a voice of speech but they did not understand it, and it became necessary for Moses to explain to them each and every commandment until they understood it from Moses. And so [the Rabbis] explained:<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, II, 33: “<i>Moses spoke, and G-d answered by a voice</i>. In explanation thereof, the Sages said in the Mechilta that Moses brought to them every commandment as he heard it.” I have not been able to identify the exact quotation in the Mechilta.</i> <i>Moses spoke, and G-d answered him by a voice</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:19.</i> Therefore [the rest of the Ten Commandments] were addressed by G-d to Moses so that he should tell them thus. The reason [that the first two commandments were spoken to the people directly by G-d] was so that they should all be prophets in the belief of G-d, [His existence, and His Unity], and in the prohibition of idolatry, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:9.</i> Those are the root of the whole Torah and the commandments, just as He said, <i>Assemble Me the people, and I will make them hear My words, that they may learn to fear Me all the days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:10.</i> But in the rest of the Ten Commandments, they received their explanation from the mouth of Moses after having heard <i>a voice of words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> while in all other commandments [of the whole Torah], they believed in Moses completely.

Verse 8

REMEMBER THE SABBATH DAY, TO KEEP IT HOLY. After He commanded that we believe in the Proper Name of G-d, blessed be He — i.e., that He exists, that He is the Creator, that He understands [and watches over all that happens to man], and that He is the All-powerful<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">All these principles of truth were made evident through expressing the first commandment. See Ramban above, Verse 2.</i> — and [after commanding] that we should direct both our faith in all these matters and all honor towards Him alone,<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">This was the theme of the second commandment.</i> and He further commanded that the remembrance of His Name be done in a manner of respect,<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to taking His Name in vain, as was stated in the third commandment.</i> He now commanded that we make in this matter a sign and perpetual remembrance to let it be known that He created everything. This is in the commandment of the Sabbath, which is a remembrance of the creation.<br>Now He said here, <i>‘Remember’ the Sabbath-day, to keep it holy;</i> and in the Book of Deuteronomy it is written, <i>‘Observe’ the Sabbath-day, to keep it holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:12.</i> Our Rabbis have said with respect to these verses:<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here. Also Shebuoth 20b.</i> “<i>Remember</i> and <i>Observe</i> were both spoken with one utterance.” Now the Rabbis were not so particular as to comment on the other changes of language [between the Ten Commandments written here and those in the Book of Deuteronomy. They commented only on the above-mentioned change] because their intent is to point out that <i>zachor</i> (remember) constitutes a positive commandment, i.e., that He commanded that we remember the Sabbath-day to keep it holy and that we do not forget it, [as will be explained further on]. [They considered] <i>shamor</i> (observe), on the other hand, as a negative commandment, just as they have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">Erubin 96 a, etc.</i> “Wherever Scripture says <i>take heed (‘hishamer’)</i>, or <i>lest (‘pen’)</i>, or <i>do not (‘al’)</i>, there is a negative commandment.” It warns us that we should watch it [i.e., the Sabbath] to keep it holy and that we should not profane it, [thus clearly implying both a positive commandment and a negative one with respect to the Sabbath]. It would not have been proper for Moses to change G-d’s words from a positive commandment to a negative commandment. [Therefore the Rabbis were careful to point out that both <i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i> were spoken by G-d in one utterance.] However, the change in the second commandment from <i>‘and’ any manner of likeness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> <i>to any manner of likeness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:8.</i> omitting the <i>vav</i> (and), and then adding it [to the expression <i>al shileishim (unto the third generation)</i>, which is found here in Verse 5, rendering it there in Deuteronomy], <i>v’al shileishim (‘and’ unto the third generation)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9.</i> and all such similar changes in the rest of the Ten Commandments, do not matter, for it is all one. This explanation [of why the Rabbis were particular to comment only on the change from <i>remember</i> to <i>observe</i>] will not be entertained by one who is not used to the ways of the Talmud.<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 398, that this is a veiled criticism of Ibn Ezra, who, in his commentary on Verse 1, continued to raise difficulties on this saying of the Sages and finally concluded that “reason does not bear out all these words.” To this came the retort of Ramban: “this explanation, etc.” In a Ramban manuscript, I found this remark expressed in a positive manner: “This explanation will be entertained by him who is used to the ways of the Talmud.” Thus Ramban avoids casting a direct aspersion on Ibn Ezra’s knowledge of the ways of the Talmud.</i> And the Rabbis have expressly said:<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 20b.</i> “Women are obligated by law of the Torah to proclaim the sanctity of the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">The proclaiming of the sanctity of the Sabbath is one of the six hundred thirteen commandments of the Torah. See “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 164-165.</i> because it is said, <i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i>, thus equating them so that all those who are obligated to <i>observe</i> the Sabbath are obligated also to <i>remember</i> it.<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">The general rule is: “The observance of all <i>positive</i> commandments that depend on time is incumbent on men but not on women, but the observance of all the <i>negative</i> commandments, whether they depend on time or not, is incumbent both on men and women” (Kiddushin 29 a). Now proclaiming the sanctity of the Sabbath is naturally dependent on time — i.e., the arrival of the Sabbath — and one would therefore say that women are not obligated to observe that commandment. But <i>‘shamor’ (observe) the Sabbath-day to keep it holy</i>, as was explained in the text, constitutes a negative commandment, and therefore applies to women as well. Now since the Torah equated <i>zachor</i> (remember) with <i>shamor</i> (observe), it follows that women are also obligated in the positive commandment of proclaiming the sanctity of the Sabbath.</i> And since women are obligated in the observance [of the Sabbath] — for women are obligated in the observance thereof, since the observance of all negative commandments is incumbent on women, [and <i>shamor</i> (observe) the Sabbath, as was mentioned above, constitutes a negative commandment] — they are obligated also to <i>remember</i> the Sabbath. Now women would not have been bound to remember the Sabbath — for it is a positive commandment that is dependent on time and is [therefore] not incumbent on women — were it not for this analogy [of <i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i>, i.e., that all who are obligated to observe are bound to <i>remember</i>], which does make it incumbent on them.<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus brought proof to his original point that the reason the Rabbis were particular about this change from <i>remember</i> to <i>observe</i> and not about the other changes in the Decalogues, is that here, the change represents a reclassification from a positive to a negative commandment. Hence it became necessary for them to point out that both words were spoken with one Divine utterance.</i><br>But I wonder! If <i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i> were both said by the Almighty, why were they not [both] written in the first Tablets? It is possible that in both the first and second Tablets, [only] <i>remember</i> was written, and Moses explained to Israel that <i>observe</i> was [also] said with it. This is indeed the true intent [of the saying of the Rabbis that “<i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i> were both spoken with one utterance]”. And in the Midrash of Rabbi Nechunya ben Hakanah,<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Habahir, 182. See Vol. I, p. 24, Note 42.</i> the Sages have mentioned also a great secret in this matter of <i>remember</i> and <i>observe</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 399.</i> Generally, [in the mystic lore], remembrance is at daytime and observance is at night, and this is the intent of what the Sages used to say on the Sabbath-eve at twilight [when welcoming the Sabbath]:<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 32b.</i> “Come, O Bride; Come, O Bride; Come, let us go forth to meet the Sabbath, the Queen, the Bride.”<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">“The Queen, the Bride.” In our Gemara: “the Bride, the Queen.” — These words of welcome constitute to this day the official reception of the Sabbath in the Synagogue service as the worshippers bid “the Sabbath bride” come in peace.</i> And the Sages call the blessing that is recited [over the <i>Kiddush</i>-cup] on the Sabbath-day “the great <i>Kiddush</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 106a.</i> for it is the sanctification of the Great One.<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Ma’or V’shamesh.</i> Understand this.<br>It is also true that the attribute of “remembering” is alluded to in a positive commandment and issues forth from the attribute of love to that of mercy, for he who does his master’s command is beloved of him and his master shows him mercy. But the attribute of “observing” is alluded to in a negative commandment, which goes to the attribute of justice and issues forth from that of fear, for he who guards himself from doing anything which does not please his master does so out of fear for him. It is for this reason that a positive commandment is greater than a negative commandment,<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">The question arises: Since, as Ramban writes, a positive commandment is greater than a negative one, why are all punishments for violation of the precepts specified in the Torah only for the negative commandments? This would indicate that the negative commandments are stricter than the positive ones, and indeed, the Rabbis in the Talmud do speak of the negative commandments as being stricter than the positive. Why then did Ramban write that the positive ones are greater? See my Hebrew commentary, p. 399, for lengthy discussion of this problem. In conclusion, the answer presented is as follows: Ramban did not write that a positive commandment is “stricter” than a negative one; he wrote only “greater.” Fulfillment of a Divine positive commandment represents an act of “doing good,” while observance of a negative precept is an expression of one’s “departing from evil.” Between the two — doing good and departing from evil — the former indeed represents “a greater” expression of man’s active dedication to the Divine service. Hence Ramban’s statement above. As for the stricter punishment of the negative commandments, see further in text and also Note 427.</i> just as love is greater than fear, for he who fulfills and observes the will of his master with his body and his possessions is greater than he who guards himself from doing that which is not pleasing to him. This is why the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 132 b, etc.</i> that a positive commandment overrides a negative commandment. And it is for this reason that punishment for violation of the negative commandments is great, — the court punishing the transgressor with whipping or death — whereas no punishment at all is meted out in the case of failure to fulfill the positive commandments, excepting when one is in brazen rebelliousness, such as when he says, “I shall not take the <i>lulav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">“The Palm-branch.” See Leviticus 23:40.</i> I shall not make fringes [on my four-cournered garment],<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:38.</i> I shall not make a tabernacle.”<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 23:42.</i> In these cases, the Sanhedrin would whip him until he accepts upon himself to do them, or until he dies.<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">This rule applies only if the time of the performance is still applicable, but if, for example, the festival of Tabernacles has passed, he is not to be punished for his failure to observe the commandment. See Maimonides’, “The Commandments,” Vol. II, p. 423, where it is clearly so explained. Ramban’s intent is obvious: The violation of a negative commandment entails an act on the part of the sinner, which goes in direct opposition to the King’s command. Hence the punishment is “stricter” than in the case of a violation of a positive commandment, which entails only failure to act in accordance with the King’s desire. Hence if the time for fulfillment of the positive commandment has not yet passed and he is in open defiance of the law, the court may act against him, but if the time for fulfillment has passed, no punishment is to be imposed on him.</i><br>In explanation of the word <i>zachor</i> (remember) — [<i>remember the Sabbath-day</i>] — Rashi wrote: “Take care always to remember the Sabbath-day, so that if a food of good quality happens to come your way, you should put it away for the Sabbath.” This is a Beraitha<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 209 in <i>Seder Bo</i>.</i> taught in the Mechilta<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> in the following way: “Rabbi Eleazar the son of Chananyah the son of Chizkiyah the son of Garon says: ‘<i>Remember the Sabbath-day, to keep it holy</i>, and remember it from the first day of the week, so that if a good portion happens to come your way, prepare it for the Sabbath.’” But this [Beraitha in the Mechilta] is taught in the name of a single Sage and is not the final decision of the law. In the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Beitza 16a. For the word “Gemara,” see Note 204 in <i>Seder Bo</i>.</i> we find that the Rabbis have said: “We have been taught [in the Beraitha]: They have told about Shammai the Elder that all his life, he ate in honor of the Sabbath. How so? If he found a beautiful animal to buy, he would say, ‘This one will be in honor of the Sabbath.’ On the following day, if he would find a more beautiful one, he left the second one for the Sabbath, and ate the first.<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">His eating the first one thus entailed something on which the honor of the Sabbath had rested (see Rashi in Beitza 16 a). Thus all his life he ate in honor of the Sabbath.</i> But Hillel the Elder was guided by another principle. All his deeds were for the sake of Heaven, as it is said, <i>Blessed be the Eternal, day by day He beareth our burden</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:20. Hillel was thus confident that before the Sabbath, G-d would provide him with his proper needs (Rashi, Beitza).</i> We have also been so taught [in another Beraitha]: The School of Shammai say that on the first day of the week, you should begin preparing for your Sabbath. And the School of Hillel say: <i>Blessed be the Eternal, day by day He beareth our burden</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:20. Hillel was thus confident that before the Sabbath, G-d would provide him with his proper needs (Rashi, Beitza).</i> And in another Mechilta<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai (Hoffman edition, p. 107). For the significance of the expression “<i>another</i> Mechilta,” see Vol. I, p. 603, Note 245.</i> we find: “Shammai the Elder says: ‘Remembering’ — [<i>Remember the Sabbath-day</i>] — means remember it before it comes; ‘observing’ — [<i>Observe the Sabbath-day</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:12.</i> — means observe it when it comes. It was told of Shammai the Elder that the memory of the Shabbath never left his lips. If he bought a good article he would say, ‘This is for the Sabbath;’ a new garment, he would say ‘This is for the Sabbath.’ But Hillel the Elder was guided by another principle, for he would say, ‘Let all thy deeds be done for the sake of Heaven.’” And the accepted decision is like that of the School of Hillel. [Thus it is clear that Rashi’s explanation is like that of Shammai the Elder, or of the School of Shammai, while the accepted decision of law is like that of Hillel or that of the School of Hillel.]<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 400, for Mizrachi’s defense of Rashi’s explanation.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mechilta quote further on. See Note 442.</i> that this verse commands us that we should always remember the Sabbath on every day, so that we should neither forget it nor confuse it with the other days.<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">If each of the days of the week were to have a name of its own — such as Sunday, Monday, etc. — then the Sabbath-day is confused with the other days. But if we refer to the days of the week in relation to the Sabbath — “the first day after the Sabbath,” etc. — then the Sabbath-day stands unique.</i> By always remembering the Sabbath, it will at all times remind us of the creation, and we will forever acknowledge that the universe has a Creator, and that He commanded us regarding this sign, [i.e., the Sabbath], as He has said, <i>for it is a sign between Me and you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Further 31:13.</i> this being a fundamental principle in the belief of G-d. The meaning of <i>l’kadsho</i> (to keep it holy) is that our remembrance of it should be to the end that it be holy to us, just as He said, <i>and call the Sabbath a delight, the sacred of the Eternal honorable</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 58:13.</i> The purport of this is that the resting thereon should be ours because it is a holy day, [which enables us] to turn away from our mental preoccupations and the vanities of the times and instead to give delight to our souls in the ways of G-d, and go to the Sages and to the prophets to hear the words of G-d. This is just as it is said, <i>Wherefore wilt thou go to him</i> [the prophet] <i>today? it is neither New Moon nor Sabbath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:23.</i> for such was their custom. And so did our Rabbis of blessed memory say:<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 16b.</i> “From this you learn that on the New Moon and on the Sabbath one must go [to the prophet].” This is the reason [that the Torah commanded us concerning the resting of cattle on the Sabbath], i.e., in order that we should harbor no thought of it in our hearts. And it is for this reason that the Rabbis, of blessed memory, have said<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 5a. See also Vol. I, p. 332.</i> that the Sabbath is equal in importance to all the commandments in the Torah, just as they have said with reference to idolatry,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 5a. See also Vol. I, p. 332.</i> because on the Sabbath we testify to all the fundamentals of the faith — creation, providence, and prophecy. And in the Mechilta we find:<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “Rabbi Yitzchak says: ‘You should not count [the days of the week] as others count them. Rather you should count them with reference to the Sabbath.’” The meaning of this is that other nations count the days of the week in such a manner that each is independent of the other. Thus they call each day by a separate name or by a name of the ministers [in heaven, such as Sunday, which means “sun’s day,” Monday which means “moon’s day,” etc.], or by any other names which they call them. But Israel counts all days with reference to the Sabbath: “one day after the Sabbath,” “two days after the Sabbath.” This is of the essence of the commandment which we have been obligated always to remember the Sabbath every day [of the week]. This is the literal meaning of the verse, and so did Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra interpret it.<br>And I say further that this is the intent of Shammai the Elder’s interpretation [mentioned above],<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai (Hoffman edition, p. 107). For the significance of the expression “<i>another</i> Mechilta,” see Vol. I, p. 603, Note 245.</i> who explained the command <i>remember</i> as meaning “[remember the Sabbath] before it comes.” That is to say, we should by no means forget it. [By counting the days of the week with reference to the Sabbath, forgetting it will thus be impossible.] But in the Beraitha [quoted above], they also mentioned a degree of his piety, i.e., that he would remember the Sabbath even in his eating, for all his life he ate in honor of the Sabbath. Now Hillel himself agreed to the interpretation of Shammai [that we are to count the days of the week with reference to the Sabbath], but in food-matters he followed another principle, for all of his deeds were for the sake of Heaven, and he trusted in G-d that He would provide him with a better portion for the Sabbath than that of all the other days of the week.<br>However, our Rabbis have yet another Midrash on the word <i>l’kadsho</i> (to keep it holy),<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">In the Mechilta mentioned further in the text.</i> namely, that we are to sanctify it by utterance of words. This is similar in usage to the verse, <i>And ye shall hallow the fiftieth year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:10.</i> which requires the sanctification of the court, i.e., that they say of the Jubilee year, “It is hallowed! It is hallowed!”<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 8 b, Rashi.</i> Here too He commanded that we remember the Sabbath-day by proclaiming its sanctity.<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">See Maimonides’, “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 164-165.</i> And so the Rabbis have said in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>To keep it holy</i>. Sanctify it by reciting a blessing. Based on this verse, the Rabbis have said: ‘On its entrance, proclaim the sanctity of the Sabbath over wine. But from this verse, I know only the sanctification for the day. Whence do we know that this applies also for the night? [We know it] from the words of Scripture, <i>And ye shall keep the Sabbath</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:14. Since the word “day” is not mentioned in this verse, as it is in the verse before us, <i>Remember the Sabbath-'day’ to keep it holy</i>, it indicates that the proclamation of the Sabbath is to be observed at its entrance at night. See also further in the text here for a more correct version of this Mechilta as Ramban explains it.</i> This is “the sanctification of the [Sabbath-] day” [to which the Rabbis refer].<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 20b.</i> It is incumbent upon us by law of the Torah, and is not a mere <i>asmachta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Support.” Where a law is actually of Rabbinic origin but a Scriptural text is quoted as a support, it is called an <i>asmachta</i>.</i> Thus the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 20b.</i> “Women are obligated by law of the Torah to proclaim the sanctity of the day.” Now this really refers to the sanctification recited at night, for all things requiring sanctification need to be done only once at the time of their entrance, such as the sanctification of the New Moon and the sanctification of the Jubilee year. However, the duty to recite it on the day itself is but an <i>asmachta</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Support.” Where a law is actually of Rabbinic origin but a Scriptural text is quoted as a support, it is called an <i>asmachta</i>.</i> and [the <i>kiddush</i> at daytime] contains no reference to the holiness of the day — [since only a benediction over the wine is recited] — because it is sufficient that we proclaimed the sanctity of the Sabbath once at its entrance. So also is the recital [of the sanctity of the Sabbath] over wine only an <i>asmachta</i><sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Support.” Where a law is actually of Rabbinic origin but a Scriptural text is quoted as a support, it is called an <i>asmachta</i>.</i> and is not at all a fixed part of the commandment itself.<br>And in the Gemara Pesachim,<sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 106a.</i> the Rabbis have said: “<i>Remember the Sabbath-day, to keep it holy</i>. That is, remember it over wine at its entrance. From this, I know only that it be done at daytime. Whence do we know that it must be done at night? It is from the Scriptural words, <i>the Sabbath-'day.’</i> [On the version of the Beraitha, the Sages of the Gemara asked]: ‘This Tanna<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote">A Rabbi mentioned in a Mishnah or Beraitha.</i> is seeking to find a basis for the sanctification at night, and he mentions a verse which speaks of the day! Besides, the main sanctification is at nighttime!’ Rather, you must learn [the above Beraitha] in this way: ‘<i>Remember the Sabbath-day, to keep it holy</i>. That is, remember it over wine at its entrance. From this, I know only that the Sabbath is to be sanctified at night.’ Whence do we know that it must be done at daytime? It is from the Scriptural words, <i>the Sabbath day</i>.” In a similar way we will explain the Mechilta [mentioned above to make it read as follows]: “From this, I know only that the sanctification of the Sabbath is to be done at night, which is the main <i>kiddush</i>. Whence do we know that it must be done at daytime, etc.,” this being but a mere <i>asmachta</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Support.” Where a law is actually of Rabbinic origin but a Scriptural text is quoted as a support, it is called an <i>asmachta</i>.</i> And from there you will learn that this commandment [of proclaiming the sanctity of the Sabbath] is derived from the word <i>l’kadsho</i> (to sanctify it), while the expression, <i>Remember the Sabbath-day</i>, constitutes the commandment to remember it continually every day, as we have explained. However, in the number of two hundred and forty-eight positive commandments that we have been commanded to observe, both aspects are included in the one commandment of remembering the Sabbath. Know this.

Verse 9

SIX DAYS SHALT THOU LABOR, AND DO ALL THY WORK. The term “labor” applies to work which is not for the needs of the body, such as cooking and the like, something like it is said: <i>and in all manner of labor in the field;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:14.</i> <i>when thou tillest the ground;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:12.</i> <i>and ye shall be tilled and sown</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 36:9.</i> and as I will yet explain with the help of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 23:7.</i> It is for this reason that He said: “Six days you shall work the ground <i>and do all thy work</i> which is for your physical needs and your benefit, something like, <i>bake that which you will bake</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:23.</i> But on the Sabbath, you shall not do any kind of work, <i>thou, thy son, nor thy daughter</i> — i.e., the minors.” Thus He has warned us against our minor children doing work on the Sabbath with our knowledge and consent. <i>Nor thy manservant, nor thy maidservant</i> means the servants who have undergone circumcision and immersion,<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote">And are thus <i>b’nei b’rith</i> (children of the covenant). See Mechilta here. See also above, Note 79.</i> who are obligated to observe all laws of the Sabbath just as Israelites, even as He said in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>that thy manservant and thy maidservant may rest as well as thou</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:14.</i> In all [other] commandments of the Torah, observance is incumbent upon them as it is upon women, as is explained in the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">Chagigah 4 a, etc. And see Note 415 above.</i> Now it would have been proper that He warn them directly, for they themselves are duty-bound to observe the Sabbath. Scripture, however, speaks to us because the servants are in our possession, thus telling us that their resting is incumbent upon us and that if they are not hindered from doing work, we will be punished on account of them. Besides, it is with Israel that G-d speaks in all of the Ten Commandments, [and for this reason, the command is not given directly to the servants].

Verse 10

NOR THY STRANGER THAT IS WITHIN THY GATES. In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, “the stranger of the gate” is always the <i>geir toshav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “resident alien,” so called because he was permitted to dwell within the Land of Israel. The conditions under which he becomes a <i>geir toshav</i> are described here in the text.</i> who came to dwell in “the gates of our cities” and has taken upon himself the Seven Laws of the Noachides.<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 417, Note 148, and see also in index there under “Noachides.”</i> It is he who is called “the stranger who eats the unlawfully-slaughtered animal,” of whom Scripture says, <i>thou mayest give it to the stranger that is within thy gates, that he may eat it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 14:21.</i> Therefore, the commandment [prohibiting work on the Sabbath] was not directed to him so that Scripture would be saying: “Do not do any work on it, the home-born or the stranger.” Instead, it is we who are commanded that he do no work for our benefit, just as [we are commanded about] our minors and the cattle, but this commandment is not incumbent upon him and he may do work for himself on the Sabbath. The verse which states, <i>so that the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may rest</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:12.</i> speaks of the righteous proselyte who has become Jewish and embraced our Torah, which has commanded him concerning the Sabbath and all the rest of the commandments as well, as He has said, <i>One law and one ordinance shall be both for you, and for the stranger that sojourneth with you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:16.</i> <i>both for the stranger, and for him that is born in the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:14.</i><br>However, we have found in the words of our Rabbis that they have interpreted it in the opposite manner. Thus they have said<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> that by way of the plain meaning of Scripture, <i>thy stranger that is within thy gates</i> means the righteous proselyte, and ceasing from work [on the Sabbath] is incumbent upon him as it is upon us. The verse, <i>so that the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may rest</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:12.</i> includes the uncircumcised <i>geir toshav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “resident alien,” so called because he was permitted to dwell within the Land of Israel. The conditions under which he becomes a <i>geir toshav</i> are described here in the text.</i> The Rabbis’ intent in so explaining the verses is that first, [i.e., right here in the Ten Commandments], “the stranger” warned is the proselyte who has been circumcised, who is obligated in the observance of the Sabbath as we are. The second verse — [further, 23:12] — includes the uncircumcised [<i>geir toshav</i>]. Therefore, he is likened there to the cattle, as the verse says, <i>that thine ox and thine ass may have rest, and the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may rest</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:12.</i> Thus He commanded us concerning the resting of all of them alike that they should not work for us, but they may do [work] for themselves if they so wish. Similarly, the servant and the stranger mentioned in the Ten Commandments are alike, being obligated in the observance of all laws of the Sabbath as we are, even as He has said, <i>that thy manservant and thy maidservant may rest as well as thou</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:14.</i>

Verse 11

THE ETERNAL BLESSED THE SABBATH-DAY, AND SANCTIFIED IT. The verse is stating that the Sabbath-day will be blessed and hallowed because He has commanded to bless it and glorify it by remembering it. Therefore, He commanded us to rest thereon so that the day will be sacred to us, and that we should not do any work on it. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that G-d blessed this day and sanctified it by endowing it with a greater capacity to enable the soul to receive additional wisdom than on all of the other days. I have already written concerning this matter by way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], on the verse in <i>Vayechulu</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:1. Ramban’s discussion of the mystic nature of the blessing of the Sabbath is found there on Verse 3 (Vol. I, p. 60).</i> From there, you will succeed in understanding that the expression <i>ki sheisheth yamim asa hashem</i> — [literally: “for six days the Eternal made”]<sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">Here in the verse before us, which is generally translated: “for <i>in</i> six days the Eternal made.”</i> — is not missing the letter <i>beth</i>, [which would make the verse read: “for <i>in</i> six days the Eternal made”]. Rather, the sense of the verse is that G-d made six days<sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is hinting here to what he wrote on Genesis 2:3, i.e., that the six days of creation allude to the six thousand years which are “all the days of the world.” See Vol. I, pp. 61-64. Thus the sense of the verse here is clearly, “for G-d made six days,” and not, “for <i>in</i> six days G-d made.” The six days represent the six milleniums of world-history, while the seventh millenium “will be wholly a Sabbath and will bring rest for life everlasting” (<i>ibid.</i>, p. 64).</i> <i>and on the seventh day He ceased from work and rested</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">470</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:17.</i>

Verse 12

HONOR THY FATHER. Having finished all that we are obligated towards the Creator Himself and His glory, He turns now to command us about those matters which concern created beings. He begins with the father, for in relation to his offspring, he is akin to a creator, being partner with Him in the forming of the child.<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 30 b: “There are three partners in man: the Holy One, blessed be He, his father and his mother.”</i> G-d is our first Father, and he who begets it [i.e., the child] is our last male parent. This is why He said in the Book of Deuteronomy, [<i>Honor thy father… as the Eternal thy G-d commanded thee</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:16.</i> That is, “just as I have commanded you concerning My honor, so do I command you concerning the honor of those who have joined Me in your formation.” Now Scripture has not explained [the nature of the honor we are to give our parents], for it may be derived from the honor mentioned above that we owe to our first Father, blessed be He. Thus, one is to acknowledge [his male parent] as his father and not deny him, saying of another man that he is his father. Nor should he serve him because of his estate or any other benefit he hopes to derive from him. Nor should he take his father’s name and swear “by the life of my father” in vain or falsely. There are other matters which are included within the term “honor,” for we are commanded in every aspect thereof, and they are explained in the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">“What is honoring [one’s parents? It entails] providing them with food and drink, raiment and warmth, and guiding their footsteps [when they are old and infirm]” (Kiddushin 31 b).</i> The Sages have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">474</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 30b.</i> that honoring parents has been likened to honoring G-d.<br>Now since this commandment refers to creatures on the earth, He has designated its reward to be prolongation of life on earth which He will give us. But in the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39b.</i> the purport of the verse is “<i>that thy days may be long</i> and <i>upon the Land</i>.” [It thus expresses two declarations]: He promises that our lives will be prolonged by observing this commandment — i.e., that G-d will fulfill our days in this world and they will be prolonged in the World to Come, which is unending — and that our dwelling will forever be on the good earth<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to eternal life.</i> which He will give us. And in the Book of Deuteronomy, He expressly stated it: <i>that thy day may be long, and that it may go well with thee, upon the Land which the Eternal thy G-d giveth thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:16.</i> Thus they are two promises.

Verse 13

THOU SHALT NOT MURDER. THOU SHALT NOT COMMIT ADULTERY. THOU SHALT NOT STEAL. He is stating: “Now I have commanded you to acknowledge in thought and in deed that I am the Creator of all, and to honor parents because they joined [Me] in your formation. If so, guard against destroying the work of My hands and spilling the blood of man, whom I have created to honor Me and acknowledge Me in all these matters.<sup class="footnote-marker">477</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban at end of <i>Seder Bo</i>.</i> And do not commit adultery with your fellow-man’s wife, because you will thereby destroy the principle of honoring parents, [causing the children] to deny the truth and acknowledge falsehood. They will not know their fathers and will thus give their honor to another, just as the idol-worshippers do, <i>who say to a block of wood, ‘thou art my father,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 2:27.</i> and they do not know their Father who created them out of nothing.” After that, He warned against stealing a human being,<sup class="footnote-marker">479</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> for that too brings about a similar [disintegration of values].<sup class="footnote-marker">480</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 21:15.</i><br>With respect to their stringency and penalties, the order of the commandments is as follows: after idolatry comes bloodshed, and after that adultery, and then stealing of a human being and false testimony and robbery;<sup class="footnote-marker">481</sup><i class="footnote">Since coveting also relates to action by robbery, Ramban mentions here “robbery” although the tenth commandment speaks of coveting.</i> and he who does not covet, will never harm his neighbor. Thus, He completed all obligations that a person owes towards his neighbor. After that, [in the <i>Seder</i> of <i>Mishpatim</i> which follows], He will explain the ordinances in detail, for he who has been found guilty in any suit to pay his neighbor will pay the amount he is so obligated if he does not covet or desire that which is not his.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">In his introduction to the Ten Commandments.</i> [of the commandment, <i>Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor’s house… thy neighbor’s wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant</i>, etc.], that Scripture adopted a normal course of life. First, it mentioned the neighbor’s house, for an enlightened person will first acquire a house, and then marry a woman to bring her to his house, and only afterwards will he acquire a manservant or a maidservant. But in the Book of Deuteronomy,<sup class="footnote-marker">483</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:18.</i> it mentions the wife first, because young men desire to marry first [before they acquire a house]. It may be<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote">This is Ramban’s own comment.</i> that because the coveting of a neighbor’s wife is the greatest sin of all things mentioned in that verse, [it is listed first].<br>Thus, of the Ten Commandments, there are five which refer to the glory of the Creator and five are for the welfare of man, for [the fifth commandment], <i>Honor thy father</i>, is for the glory of G-d, since it is for the glory of the Creator that He commanded that one honor one’s father who is a partner in the formation of the child. Five commandments thus remain for the needs and welfare of man.<br>In some commandments, He mentioned their recompense, and in others He did not. Thus, in the second commandment, He mentioned <i>a jealous G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> in the third, <i>for the Eternal will not hold him guiltless;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> in the fifth, <i>that thy days may be long</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> But in the others, He mentioned neither punishment [for transgression], nor reward [for fulfillment]. The reason for this is that the last five commandments deal with the welfare of man, and <i>behold, His reward is with Him, and His recompense before Him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">488</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:10. In other words, the recompense for the last five commandments is self-evident. If man observes them, his society will prosper, and if not, the whole fabric of society will collapse.</i> But in the case of idolatry, a warning of punishment is needed because of its great stringency, involving as it does the glory of the Creator.<br>It appears to me that His saying <i>a jealous G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> refers to the commandment, <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">489</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> and that His saying, <i>And He showeth mercy</i><sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> refers to <i>I am the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">491</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> for punishment comes for [transgressing] the negative commandments, and reward for [fulfillment of] the positive commandments. [He did not mention the reward immediately in the first commandment because] the acceptance of the Kingdom of G-d, [as mentioned in the first commandment], and the admonition against the worship of anything besides Him, constitute one subject. Therefore, He first finished that entire matter and then warned the idol-worshipper of punishment, and then He assured reward for he who fulfills the commandments.<br>He warned of punishment in case of a vain oath, <i>the Eternal will not hold him guiltless</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> but He mentioned no reward [for observing it]. For profaning the Sabbath, He mentioned neither excision<sup class="footnote-marker">492</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:14.</i> nor any other punishment, neither did He mention a reward for him <i>that keepeth the Sabbath from profaning it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 56:2.</i> This is because it is included in the first two commandments. He who observes the Sabbath testifies to the Creation and acknowledges his belief in the commandment, <i>I am the Eternal</i>, while he who profanes the Sabbath denies the Creation and admits the eternity of the universe, thereby denying the commandment, <i>I am the Eternal</i>. Thus, [the punishment for profaning the Sabbath] is included in: <i>a jealous G-d, visiting the iniquity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> while [the reward for he who keeps the Sabbath] is included in the verse, <i>And He showeth mercy unto the thousandth generation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> In the fifth commandment, which concerns the honor due to parents, He mentioned the reward because it is a positive commandment, [and as mentioned above, reward is for fulfillment of the positive commandments].<br>With reference to the writing on the Tablets of law, it would appear that the first five commandments were on one Tablet, for they are for the glory of the Creator, as I have mentioned, and the second five commandments were on another Tablet. Thus there were five opposite five, something like the Rabbis mentioned in the Book of Creation:<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Yetzirah 1:3. This is one of the earliest books on the Cabala. Saadia Gaon was among the first great scholars to write a commentary on it. It is written in profound symbolic language.</i> “With ten emanations,<sup class="footnote-marker">495</sup><i class="footnote">In our version of Sefer Yetzirah: “Ten Emanations”; the word “with” is not present.</i> intangible, as is the number of ten fingers, five opposite five, and the Covenant of the Unity placed directly in the middle.” From this it will be made clear to you why there were two Tablets, for up to <i>Honor thy father</i>, it corresponds to the Written Torah, and from there on it corresponds to the Oral Torah. It would appear that it is this that our Rabbis, of blessed memory, have alluded to in saying<sup class="footnote-marker">496</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 41:7.</i> that the two Tablets correspond to heaven and earth,<sup class="footnote-marker">497</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Torah was the instrument with which the world was created, the first Tablet containing our duties towards G-d thus corresponds to heaven, while the second Tablet which states our duties to man corresponds to earth (Eitz Yoseph, <i>ibid.</i>)</i> to a groom and bride,<sup class="footnote-marker">498</sup><i class="footnote">The symbol is that of the bestower and the bestowed. Heaven is the bestower and earth is the bestowed. So also is the relationship between G-d and man.</i> to the two friends [of the groom and bride], and to the two worlds [this world and the World to Come]. All these constitute one allusion, and the person learned in the mystic lore of the Cabala will understand the secret.

Verse 14



Verse 15

AND ALL THE PEOPLE PERCEIVED THE THUNDERINGS… 16. AND THEY SAID UNTO MOSES. In the opinion of the commentators,<sup class="footnote-marker">499</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra in Verse 16.</i> this happened after the Giving of the Torah. It is with reference to this that Scripture says, <i>And ye came near unto me, even all the heads of your tribes, and your elders, and ye said: Behold, the Eternal our G-d hath shown us His Glory</i>, etc. <i>If we hear the Voice of the Eternal our G-d any more, then we shall die</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">500</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:20-22.</i><br>But such is not my opinion, for it says here, <i>but let not G-d speak with us</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">501</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> and it does not say “any more.” Besides, Moses said here to the people, <i>Fear not</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">502</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> and there it is said, <i>They have well said all that they have spoken</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">503</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:25.</i> Moreover, here it is told that they feared only the thunderings, the lightnings, and the smoking mountain, and there it is said that they feared the speaking of the Divine Presence, for they said, <i>For who is there of all flesh, that hath heard the Voice of the living G-d, speaking out of the midst of the fire, as we have, and lived?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">504</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> Again, here it is said, <i>And Moses drew near unto the thick darkness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> but it does not say that “he entered into it.” [If the events narrated in this section of the Torah happened after the Revelation, it should have said that he came “into the midst of the cloud,” as it says further on in 24:18.]<br>The correct interpretation regarding this section of the Torah and the [entire] order of events pertaining to the Revelation appears to me to be as follows: <i>And all the people perceived… And they said unto Moses</i> — all this happened before the Revelation. Now at first, [in Chapter 19], Scripture mentioned in sequence all the words of G-d that were commanded to Moses regarding the setting of a boundary to Mount Sinai and the admonition given to the people.<sup class="footnote-marker">506</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:24.</i> This is followed [at the beginning of Chapter 20] by the Ten Commandments, and now Scripture refers back and mentions the words of the people to Moses, relating that from the moment they had perceived the thunderings and the lightnings, they moved backwards and stood afar off, further away from the boundary of the mountain that Moses had set for them.<br>The order of events [on the day of the Revelation] was thus as follows: In the morning, there were thunderings and lightnings and the loud voice of the horn,<sup class="footnote-marker">507</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> but the Divine Presence had not yet come down on the mountain, something like it is written, <i>And a great and strong wind rent the mountains, and broke in pieces the rocks before the Eternal; but the Eternal was not in the wind</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">508</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 19:11.</i> <i>And the people that were in the camp</i> — i.e., in their place of encampment — <i>trembled</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">507</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> But Moses encouraged them and brought them forth <i>towards G-d… and they stood at the nether part of the mount</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">509</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:17.</i> While they were standing there at the nether part of the mount in anticipation, <i>the Eternal descended upon the mount in fire and the smoke thereof ascended</i><sup class="footnote-marker">510</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> <i>unto the heart of heaven, with darkness, cloud, and thick darkness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">511</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:11.</i> The mountain itself trembled<sup class="footnote-marker">510</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> and quivered as mountains do in an earthquake called <i>zalzalah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">512</sup><i class="footnote">An Arabic word meaning earthquake. In another Ramban manuscript, the reading is <i>chalchalah</i>.</i> or even more than that. And so it is written, <i>What aileth thee… ye mountains, that ye skip like rams; ye hills, like young sheep?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">513</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 114:6. See Pesachim 118 a that this verse refers to the time of the Giving of the Torah.</i> This is not a figure of speech, just as the preceding verse — <i>The sea saw it, and fled; the Jordan turned backwards</i><sup class="footnote-marker">514</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> — is not a mere figure of speech. Meanwhile, the voice of the horn waxed louder and louder.<sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Above 19:19.</i> Then the people saw what was happening, and they moved backwards and stood further away from the boundary [that Moses had set for them].
