They all said to Moses that G-d should not speak with them at all lest they die, for <i>by reason of the vision</i>, their pains came upon them and they retained no strength,<sup class="footnote-marker">516</sup><i class="footnote">See Daniel 10:16.</i> and if they would hear the Divine utterance, they would die. Moses, however, encouraged them, and he said to them, <i>Fear not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">502</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> And they heard him, <i>and the people stood from afar off</i><sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> at their positions, for in spite of all his words, they did not want to come near the boundary [he had set for them]. <i>And Moses drew near unto the thick darkness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> but did not come into it, and then G-d uttered the Ten Commandments. Now following the Ten Commandments, Scripture did not mention here what the elders said to Moses, for it wanted to explain the commandments and the ordinances in succession. But in the Book of Deuteronomy, Moses mentioned that after the Ten Commandments [were given], all the heads of the tribes and their elders approached him and said to him, “<i>If we hear the Voice of the Eternal our G-d any more, then we shall die</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">517</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:22.</i> for we have estimated our powers [and found] that we could not stand any more the burden of the word of the Eternal G-d.” They had thought that G-d wanted to relate to them all the commandments [of the Torah], and therefore they said, <i>Go thou near, and hear all that the Eternal our G-d may say; and thou shalt speak unto us all that the Eternal our G-d may speak unto thee; and we will hear it, and do it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">518</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> And the Holy One, blessed be He, agreed to their words, and He said, <i>They have well said all that they have spoken</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">519</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> for such was His desire to proclaim to them only the Ten Commandments, and their fear appeared correct to Him.
VAYANU’U.’ In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">520</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here, and mentioned partly in Rashi.</i> the term <i>nu’a</i> here can only denote reeling to and fro, and so it says, <i>The earth ‘no’a tanu’a’ (reeleth to and fro) like a drunken man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">521</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:20.</i> If so, the verse is stating [two things]: that the people were shaken up, and that out of their fear, they retreated farther backwards and stood afar off. But in the opinion of “the masters of the plain meaning of Scripture,”<sup class="footnote-marker">522</sup><i class="footnote">The allusion is to Ibn Ezra, who interprets it so.</i> <i>vayanu’u</i> means that “‘they moved’ backwards from their place and stood from afar,” the usage of the word being similar to: <i>‘na’ (a fugitive) and a wanderer shalt thou be in the earth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">523</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:12.</i> and so also: <i>‘vay’ni’eim’ (and He made them wander) in the wilderness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">524</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 32:13.</i>

Verse 16

BUT LET NOT G-D SPEAK WITH US. The Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] noted in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">525</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, II, 33.</i> that Onkelos translated <i>but let not G-d speak with us</i> as, “Let not aught be spoken to us from before G-d.” However, he did not paraphrase in [a similar manner] in other such places, for he translated literally, <i>And G-d spoke all these words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">526</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> and so also in all places where it says, <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses</i>!<sup class="footnote-marker">527</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:10, etc.</i> Now the reason for Onkelos’ paraphrasing it here, [according to Maimonides], was that even though all Israel heard the first commandment,<sup class="footnote-marker">528</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the first two commandments, for we heard both of them from the Almighty Himself, as explained above. See also above, Note 392.</i> their capacity for comprehending it was unlike that of Moses our teacher.<sup class="footnote-marker">529</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, with reference to Moses, Onkelos translated literally, <i>And G-d spoke</i>, for Moses achieved the highest comprehension humanly possible in prophecy, and therefore he received the word of G-d directly. But where the people were concerned, since their comprehension was of a far lesser degree, Onkelos translated, “from before G-d.”</i> But if [Maimonides’ opinion is correct], why did Onkelos translate literally, <i>For I have talked with you from heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">530</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 19. Now here it refers to G-d speaking to the people, and yet Onkelos did not paraphrase it!</i> when he should have rendered it, “It was spoken to you from before Me!” Similarly in the Book of Deuteronomy, he translated literally: <i>These words the Eternal spoke unto all your assembly</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">531</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:19.</i> [and he did not paraphrase it]! So also he translated literally their words, <i>and we have heard His Voice</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">532</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> which he rendered as follows: “we have heard the voice of His word; this day we have seen that G-d speaks with man!” Likewise he translated literally, <i>The Eternal spoke with you face to face</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">533</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> Moreover, [with reference to Moses] he translated, <i>And G-d answered him by a voice</i><sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Above 19:19.</i> as “and from before G-d he was answered by a voice!” [Here Onkelos paraphrased it with regard to Moses himself, which according to Maimonides he should have translated literally!] In fact, such usage already occurs in the Torah with reference to Moses himself! Thus: <i>And he heard the Voice speaking</i><sup class="footnote-marker">534</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is <i>midabeir</i>, not <i>m’dabeir</i> (speaking), and Rashi markedly comments that it means “uttering itself” and Moses heard it of himself. It is out of reverence for G-d that this expression is used.</i> <i>unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">535</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> which Onkelos translated as “being spoken.” So also in the verse, <i>The pillar of the cloud descended, and stood at the door of the Tent, and He spoke with Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">536</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:9.</i> which Onkelos translated, “and it was spoken!”<br>But the reason for Onkelos’ translating here, [“Let not aught be spoken to us from before G-d”], is clear. In the entire Revelation, we find Israel hearing G-d’s word only <i>out of the midst of the fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">532</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> and this is what they comprehended. Similarly, <i>that I have talked with you from heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">530</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 19. Now here it refers to G-d speaking to the people, and yet Onkelos did not paraphrase it!</i> means, by way of the Truth, “from out of the midst of heaven,” and it is identical with <i>out of the midst of the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">532</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 21.</i> The purport thereof has already been explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">537</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:20.</i> Now when Onkelos saw here the expression, <i>but let not G-d speak with us</i>, [which indicates <i>direct</i> revelation], and no “partition” is mentioned, he did not deem it fit to translate literally. [That would have implied that in their comprehension of the Revelation, they were equal to Moses], and since in his language [i.e., Aramaic] there is no epithet for the word <i>Elokim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">538</sup><i class="footnote">Throughout his translation, Onkelos does not distinguish between <i>Elokim</i> and the Tetragrammaton. He translates both alike: <i>Ado-noy</i>.</i> he therefore negated here any direct communication to them, [and translated, “Let not aught <i>be spoken</i> to us <i>from before G-d</i>”].<br>Now the amazing thing in Onkelos’ wisdom is that in the Revelation on Mount Sinai, he did not mention “the Glory of G-d,” or “the word of G-d,” but instead translated: “Behold, I will reveal Myself to you;”<sup class="footnote-marker">539</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:9. The verse reads: <i>Behold, I come unto thee</i>.</i> “G-d will reveal Himself in the sight of all the people upon Mount Sinai;”<sup class="footnote-marker">540</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11. the verse reads: <i>the Eternal will come down</i>.</i> “because He revealed Himself upon it;”<sup class="footnote-marker">541</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18. The verse reads: <i>because the Eternal descended upon it</i>.</i> “And G-d revealed Himself upon Mount Sinai.”<sup class="footnote-marker">542</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20. The verse reads: <i>And the Eternal came down</i>.</i> He did not translate, “and the Glory of G-d revealed itself,” as he translated the expression, <i>the mountain of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">543</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:1.</i> at the beginning [of this book] as “the mountain upon which the Glory of G-d revealed itself.” Likewise, Onkelos did so regarding this descent [upon Mount Sinai]; wherever the Proper Name of G-d [i.e., the Tetragrammaton] is mentioned, [he did not translate “the Glory of G-d”]. But when Scripture mentioned <i>Elokim</i>, such as <i>towards ‘ha’Elokim,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">544</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:17.</i> he translated “towards the word of G-d.” Similarly, he translated <i>‘ha’Elokim’ is come</i><sup class="footnote-marker">545</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> as “the Glory of G-d has revealed itself to you,” and he did not render it “G-d has revealed Himself to you.” Likewise, [he translated <i>where ‘ha’Elokim’ was</i><sup class="footnote-marker">546</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> as] “where the Glory of G-d was.” And so also he translated [<i>‘v’ha’Elokim’ answered him by a voice</i><sup class="footnote-marker">547</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:19.</i> as] “and from before G-d, he was answered with a voice.” All this is clear and lucid to him who comprehends our words explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">548</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20. Also in Vol. I, pp. 550-552.</i> Similarly, I have seen in carefully-edited texts of Onkelos that he translated literally the verse, <i>And Moses went up into ‘har’ha’Elokim’ (the mount of G-d)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">549</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:13.</i> Since it was after the Giving of the Torah, [he translated even the name <i>Elokim</i> literally, and he did not render it, “and Moses went up into the mountain upon which the Glory of G-d revealed itself”], and so it is written, <i>And they set forward from the mount of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">550</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:33.</i>

Verse 17

FOR G-D IS COME IN ORDER TO ‘NASOTH’ YOU. “I.e., to make you ‘great’ in the world, [to ensure] that you obtain a name amongst the nations [because of the fact] that He in His Glory revealed Himself to you. <i>Nasoth</i> is a term for ‘exalting’ and ‘greatness,’ just as in the verses: <i>Lift up a ‘neis’ (an ensign);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">551</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 62:10.</i> <i>‘k’neis’ (as an ensign) on a hill</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">552</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 30:17.</i> which is so called because it is high.” Thus Rashi’s language. But this is not correct.<sup class="footnote-marker">553</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi connects <i>nasoth</i> with <i>neis</i> (ensign, banner). Ramban objects to this because in his opinion, the root of the word <i>nasoth</i> is <i>nasoh</i> (try, accustom).</i> Instead, it is possible that Moses is saying that “it is in order to get you ‘accustomed’ to have faith in Him that G-d is come. Since He has shown you the Revelation of the Divine Presence, your faith in Him has entered your hearts to cleave to Him, and your souls will never be separated from it forever. <i>And that His fear may be before you</i> when you see that He alone is G-d in heaven and upon the earth, you will have great fear of Him.” It may be that Moses is saying that “the fear of <i>this great fire</i><sup class="footnote-marker">554</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:22.</i> will be before you, and you will not sin because of your fear of it.” And the word <i>nasoth</i> is similar in expression to the verses: <i>And he</i> [David] <i>assayed to go, but could not, for he had ‘nisah’ (tried) it. And David said unto Saul: I cannot go with these; for I have not ‘nisithi’ (tried) them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">555</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 17:39.</i> something like “accustomed.”<br>The Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has said in the Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">556</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, III, 24. The Hebrew text here follows Al Charizi’s translation, and not that of Ibn Tibbon.</i> that Moses said to the people, “<i>Fear not</i>, because the purpose of that which you have seen is that when the Eternal G-d, in order to demonstrate your faithfulness to Him, will test you by sending you a false prophet who will aim to reverse that which you have heard, your steps will never slide from the way of the truth, for you have seen the truth with your own eyes.” But if so, the sense of the verse, [according to Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon], is that “in order to be able to prove you <i>in the future</i>, G-d came now so that you should remain faithful to Him in all trials.”<br>In my opinion, the real “trial” is now, [and not as Rambam has it that “He now came in order to be able to prove you in the future”]. Moses is saying: “Now G-d wanted to try you whether you will keep His commandments,<sup class="footnote-marker">557</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 8:2.</i> since He has now removed all doubt from your hearts. From now on, He will see <i>whether ye do love Him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">558</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 13:4.</i> and whether you want Him and His commandments.” So also does every expression of <i>nisayon</i> mean “test,” such as: <i>I cannot go with these; for I have not ‘nisithi’ them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">555</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 17:39.</i> which means “I have never tried to walk with them.”<br>It is possible that this “trial” is for the good [of the one who is being tried],<sup class="footnote-marker">559</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 275.</i> for the master will sometimes try his servant with hard work in order to know whether he will endure it out of his love for him. Sometimes he will do him good in order to know whether he will requite him with additional service and honor for the good he has done him. This is similar to what the Sages have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">560</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 31:2.</i> “Happy is the person who stands through his trials, for there is no man whom the Holy One, blessed be He, does not try. He tries the rich to see if his hand will be open for the poor; He tries the poor if he can bear suffering, etc.” This is why Scripture says here: “G-d has been good to you in showing you His Glory, which <i>He hath not dealt with any nation</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">561</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 147:20.</i> in order to prove you whether you will requite Him according to the good He has done to you <i>to be unto Him a people of inheritance</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">562</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:20.</i> similar to what He said, <i>Do ye thus requite the Eternal?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">563</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:6.</i> And it is said. “<i>You only have I known of all the families of the earth; therefore I will visit upon you all your iniquities</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">564</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 3:2.</i> for the nations are not obligated to me as are you, whom I have known face to face.”

Verse 18



Verse 19

YE YOURSELVES HAVE SEEN THAT I HAVE TALKED WITH YOU FROM HEAVEN. He commanded that Moses tell them: “Since you yourselves have seen that I have talked with you from heaven and that I am Master in heaven and upon the earth, do not combine <i>gods of silver or gods of gold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">565</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> with Me, for you have no need of another aid with Me.” The purport of the verse is: <i>Ye shall not make with Me gods of silver</i>, and <i>ye shall not make unto you gods of gold</i>. In my opinion, the explanation of the verse is as follows: “Do not make gods of silver or gods of gold to be to you for gods with Him; <i>and ye shall not make them</i> altogether.” Thus He warned against believing in them, and again warned against merely making them, similar to the verse, <i>Neither shall ye rear you up a graven image, or a pillar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">566</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:1. There too He first admonished against believing in the idols — <i>Ye shall make you no idols</i>, i.e., to believe in them — and then He warned against the mere making of them.</i> By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the meaning of the word <i>iti (with Me)</i> is like the Expression <i>al panai</i> (before My face),<sup class="footnote-marker">567</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3.</i> and I have already alluded to its explanation.<sup class="footnote-marker">567</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 3.</i><br>Rashi wrote: “<i>That I have talked with you from heaven</i>. But another verse states, <i>And the Eternal came down upon Sinai!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">568</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:20.</i> There comes a third verse to harmonize them: <i>Out of heaven He made thee to hear His Voice, that He might instruct thee; and upon earth He made thee to see His great fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">569</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> His Glory was in heaven, and His might was [manifest] upon the earth.” Thus Rashi’s language. But it is not precise.<sup class="footnote-marker">570</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent, as is evident from the text which follows, is to this effect: The harmonizing of the verses is correct, for so it is stated in the Mechilta, but that which Rashi added: “His Glory was in heaven, etc.,” is not precise, as will be explained that the Glory was upon Mount Sinai.</i> The harmonizing of the verses is indeed a Midrash of the Sages,<sup class="footnote-marker">571</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> and it is true that G-d was in heaven, and His Glory was upon Mount Sinai,<sup class="footnote-marker">572</sup><i class="footnote">This is unlike Rashi, who wrote that “His Glory was in heaven.”</i> for G-d was in the fire, and it is written, <i>Thou camest down also upon Mount Sinai, and spokest with them from heaven</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">573</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 9:13. Thus, it is stated that He was in heaven and His Glory was upon Mount Sinai.</i> All the verses in their various expressions are thus clear to all who know [the mystic teachings of the Cabala]. I have already explained it all above.<sup class="footnote-marker">568</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:20.</i> And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that he who has a discerning heart will understand the meaning thereof in the section of <i>Ki Thisa</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">574</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:21. In harmonizing the above-mentioned conflicting verses, Ibn Ezra also suggests that His Glory came down upon Mount Sinai and the Voice was heard from heaven. This is identical with Ramban’s explanation, and Ramban praises him for it.</i> <i>The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">575</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 10:12.</i>

Verse 20



Verse 21

AN ALTAR OF EARTH THOU SHALT MAKE UNTO ME. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that He is saying: “<i>Ye shall not make with Me gods of silver, or gods of gold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">565</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> to receive power from heavenly creatures through them, that they be intermediaries between Me and you, for <i>in every place where I cause My Name to be mentioned I — I in</i> My Glory — <i>will come unto thee and bless thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">576</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> You have no need at all for an intermediary.” And according to the opinion of the Rabbis concerning [the verses here, i.e., that they speak of] the altars that were made in the Tabernacle and in the Sanctuary,<sup class="footnote-marker">571</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> He mentioned the commandment of the altars of earth and of stones<sup class="footnote-marker">577</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> in order to say that they also make the altars for G-d alone and that there they shall sacrifice the burnt-offerings and the peace-offerings, and not to the demons in the open field.<sup class="footnote-marker">578</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 17:5-7.</i> In every place where they will mention His Name, He will come upon them in His Glory to make His Divine Presence dwell among them and to bless them.

Verse 22

AND IF THOU MAKE ME AN ALTAR OF STONE. The meaning of the word <i>v’im</i> (and if) in an obligatory commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">579</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is obligatory upon us to build an altar of stone in the Sanctuary, the question arises: Why does the Torah here use the word <i>v’im</i> (and if)? Ramban proceeds to answer this question.</i> is: If the time comes that you will be worthy to inherit the Land and to build Me an altar of stone, beware that <i>thou shalt not build it of hewn stones</i>, for you may think to make it so to enhance the beauty of the structure. In his commentaries,<sup class="footnote-marker">580</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:4.</i> Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s opinion is that [the verse here refers] to the altar of the covenant [mentioned] in the section of <i>V’eileh Hamishpatim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">581</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i> The sense of the expression, <i>‘and if’ thou make Me an altar of stone</i> is thus as follows: “Make Me now an altar of earth, and if you will merit it, then you shall make Me an altar of stone for the altar of the covenant.” See Ibn Ezra here.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the verses are in methodical arrangement: “<i>Ye yourselves have seen that from heaven I have talked with you</i> with My Great Name, <i>and ye shall not make</i> before My face <i>gods of silver, or of gold</i>. But I permit you to make an altar to Me alone and to sacrifice thereon burnt-offerings, and also peace-offerings, <i>in every place where I cause My Name to be mentioned</i> for <i>I will come unto thee and bless thee — with blessings of heaven above, blessings of the deep that coucheth beneath</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">582</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:25.</i> The word <i>azkir</i> (I will cause it to be mentioned) is associated with the expression: <i>He hath been mindful of us, He will bless</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">583</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 115:12.</i>
FOR IF THOU LIFTETH UP ‘CHARB’CHA’<sup class="footnote-marker">584</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “thy sword.” The significance of it is explained further on in the text.</i> (THY IRON TOOL) UPON IT THOU HAST PROFANED IT. This is to prohibit the touching of the stones of the altar with an iron tool, just as He said, <i>Thou shalt build the altar of the Eternal thy G-d of unhewn stones;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">585</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 27:6.</i> <i>thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">586</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> He mentioned iron here by the term <i>cherev</i> (sword), because all iron tools that have sharp edges are called <i>cherev</i>. Thus it is said of a sword, <i>And Ehud made him ‘cherev’ (a sword) which had two edges;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">587</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 3:16.</i> and of a blade it is said, <i>Take thee a sharp ‘cherev’ (sword)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">588</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 5:1.</i> Of hatchet and hammers with which a building is demolished it is said, <i>And he shall break down thy towers ‘b’charbothav’ (with his axes)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">589</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:9.</i> Similarly, an iron tool with which stones are cut is called <i>cherev</i>.<br>According to our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">592</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> the reason for the commandment [against building an altar of stones which have been touched by iron] is the glorification of the altar: [It is not right] that that which shortens life [i.e., iron] is to be lifted up against that which prolongs life. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that this is in order that the chips of the stones should not remain in the dunghills, while part of them [i.e., the stones] is built into G-d’s altar, or that the chips should not be taken to make an altar for the idols, since their worshippers might do so, hoping that perhaps this will bring them success. And the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] wrote in Moreh Nebuchim<sup class="footnote-marker">593</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed, III, 45.</i> that this prohibition is an extraordinary precaution against making stones into certain shapes, thus being hewn stones, for such was the custom of the heathens [to build their altars with hewn stones].<sup class="footnote-marker">594</sup><i class="footnote">Thus by prohibiting the building of an altar with stones which have been touched by iron, the Torah gave us an extraordinary precaution to guard against idolatry.</i><br>But I say that the reason for the commandment is that a sword is made out of iron and is the destroyer of the world. In fact, this is why it is called <i>cherev</i> (sword) [which is of the same root as <i>churban</i> (destruction)]. And since Esau whom G-d hated<sup class="footnote-marker">595</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 1:3.</i> is the inheritor of the sword — for to him it was said, <i>And by thy sword shalt thou live</i><sup class="footnote-marker">596</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 27:40.</i> — and the sword is his power in heaven and upon the earth — for with [the power of] Mars and the stars [which influence] bloodshed, the sword succeeds, and with them Esau’s might is shown — therefore it must not be brought into the House of G-d. It is this reason which Scripture mentions expressly: “You should not build [the altar] of hewn stones, for in lifting up any iron to make them, you have lifted up your murderous sword, and increased victims; and thus you have profaned it.” It was for this reason that there was no iron in the Tabernacle, for even its pins, which would have been better if made of iron, were made of copper.<sup class="footnote-marker">597</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:19.</i> Similarly, in the Sanctuary<sup class="footnote-marker">598</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “The Permanent House,” a synonym for the Sanctuary in Jerusalem, which cannot be built in any other location. It stands in contrast to the Tabernacle, which could be moved from place to place.</i> there were no vessels of iron except the ritual slaughtering-knives, for slaughtering [of the sacrifice] was not an act of “worship” [requiring a priest].<sup class="footnote-marker">599</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 42a.</i><br>Scripture prohibited only the building of an altar with hewn stones if touched by iron, for so it is clearly stated, <i>when thou lifteth up thy sword upon it thou has profaned it</i>, and still more clearly, <i>thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">586</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> But if he comes to chisel them with silver tools or the <i>shamir</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">600</sup><i class="footnote">A worm that pierced stones with its touch.</i> which our Rabbis have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">601</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 48b.</i> it is permissible, even though the stones are not whole. This law will refute the reasoning of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.<sup class="footnote-marker">602</sup><i class="footnote">If, as Ibn Ezra suggested, the reason for the commandment is that the chips of the stones should not be on a dunghill while the stones be in the altar of G-d, why then is it permissible if the chiselling is done with a silver tool? The same question applies to Rambam’s explanation that the commandment is a precautionary measure against idolatry.</i> The reason advanced by the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] is also incorrect on account of this law.<br>Now [when building the Sanctuary], Solomon added a stricture in the commandment, i.e., that <i>no tool of iron was heard in the House while it was in building</i><sup class="footnote-marker">603</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 6:7.</i> even though it was permissible, [the prohibition applying only to the altar]. Thus we were taught in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">604</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the verse here.</i> “<i>Thou shalt not build it of hewn stones</i>. You are not allowed to build the altar of hewn stones, but you may build the Sanctuary and the Holy of Holies of hewn stones. And how do I explain the verse, <i>And there was neither hammer nor axe nor any tool of iron heard in the House, while it was in building?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">603</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 6:7.</i> They were not heard ‘in the House,’ but outside of the House they were heard.” What happened was thus as follows: They would remove the stones from their mountains with iron tools and chisel them there with iron, just as they also cut with iron the trees and the cypresses<sup class="footnote-marker">605</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> which were in the House. And so it is written, <i>And they quarried great stones, costly stones, to lay the foundation of the House with hewn stone</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">606</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> When they brought them to the House to build the walls, they did not fix them with iron, nor did they lift up any iron tool upon them as is the custom of builders. And that which Scripture says, <i>It was built of whole stones from the quarry</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">603</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 6:7.</i> does not mean that they were whole and complete; they were whole only insomuch as they had no notch deep enough for the nail to halt over on passing upon the edge,<sup class="footnote-marker">607</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 18a.</i> but they were smooth and even. The meaning of the word <i>masa</i><sup class="footnote-marker">608</sup><i class="footnote"><i>It was built of whole stones ‘masa’</i> (I Kings 6:7) is generally translated “at the quarry.” Ramban interprets <i>masa</i> to mean “great,” and the sense of the verse is: “it was built of whole large stones.”</i> is “great”; for when they moved them from the mountain, they did not divide the rocks into many stones as is the custom of the builders, and they did not fix them there, nor did they set them into the building with hammers or axes as any other building is built. Solomon did not want it to be built [with any iron tool], or that the sound of iron be even heard in the whole Mount of the House. All these strictures were for the purpose of removing iron from it. This is according to the opinion of Rabbi Yirmiyah in Tractate Sotah.<sup class="footnote-marker">609</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 48b. In our Gemara: Rabbi Nechemyah.</i> But according to Rabbi Yehudah, the hewn stones were for Solomon’s own house, not for the Sanctuary. According to his opinion, the verse stating, <i>And they quarried great stones, costly stones, to lay the foundation of the house with hewn stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">606</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> means that they also quarried hewn stones which were for his own house. So also it appears from the plain meaning of Scripture, that he built the court with hewn stone, as it is written, <i>And he built the inner court with three rows of hewn stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">610</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 6:36.</i> and he placed himself under restriction [to build with unhewn stone] only in the Sanctuary and the Holy of Holies. All this was for the sake of removing iron from the Sanctuary. And regarding <i>the iron without weight</i> which David prepared,<sup class="footnote-marker">611</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 22:14.</i> that was to make instruments of it [with which] to cut the trees and to quarry the stones.

Verse 23

NEITHER SHALT THOU GO UP BY STEPS UNTO MINE ALTAR. Because He began the commandment of the altar, He therefore completed it and did not postpone it until He would command about the subject of the sacrifices in <i>Torath Kohanim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">590</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “Law of the Priests.” Generally, it is another name for the Book of Leviticus.</i> This is proof to the words of the Sages,<sup class="footnote-marker">591</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned above in Verse 21, that the altars referred to here are those of the Tabernacle and the Sanctuary. Now since these altars were ascended by a ramp connecting them with the ground, this verse, which states that the altar should not be ascended by steps, fits in with the general subject. But if it is as Ibn Ezra wrote, (mentioned here in the text above, Verse 22), that the altar of stone referred to here was the altar of the covenant made at Mount Sinai the present verse does not fit in here because that altar had no ramp.</i> which are not really in need of defense.<br>The reason for [the prohibition against ascending the altar with] steps is that the fear of the altar and its enhancement is for the glory of G-d. Each of G-d’s commandments has many reasons, there being many benefits in each for body and soul.<br>Mishpatim

Chapter 21



Verse 1

AND THESE ARE THE ORDINANCES WHICH THOU SHALT SET BEFORE THEM. The reason [why this whole section dealing with <i>mishpatim</i> — civil laws — is placed here, rather than being placed after the <i>chukim</i> — statutes — as is the order in the commandments given at Marah],<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:25: <i>There He made for them ‘chock’ (a statute) ‘umishpat’ (and an ordinance)</i>. The “statutes” are the precepts for which the reasons are generally unknown. See Vol. I, p. 331.</i> is that G-d wanted to explain to them first the civil laws. Thus we find that the first of the Ten Commandments dealt with the obligation of knowing of the existence of G-d, and the second one with the prohibition against idolatry, after which [following the giving of the Ten Commandments] He again instructed Moses, saying, <i>Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel: Ye yourselves have seen that I have talked with you from heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:19.</i> meaning that you, [Moses] should warn them again to take to heart that which they have seen, so that they will be careful to keep these precepts which I have commanded them. For <i>Ye yourselves have seen</i> corresponds to the commandment, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> <i>Ye shall not make with Me — gods of silver</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> — corresponds with <i>Thou shalt have no other gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> thereby completing the subject of idolatry; likewise, <i>And these are the ordinances</i> corresponds to <i>Thou shalt not covet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> for if a man does not know the laws of house and field or other possessions, he might think that they belong to him and thus covet them and take them for himself. This is why He said, <i>thou shalt set before them</i> just ordinances, which they should establish amongst themselves, so that they will not covet that which does not legally belong to them. And thus did the Rabbis say in Midrash Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 30:15.</i> “The whole Torah depends on justice; that is why the Holy One, blessed be He, gave the civil laws directly after the Ten Commandments.” Similarly G-d explains in this section of <i>These are the ordinances</i> additional laws about idolatry,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:19.</i> the honor of parents,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 15 and 17.</i> murder,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 12-14.</i> and adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:15-16.</i> — which are all mentioned in the Ten Commandments.<br>The Rabbis have explained:<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma <i>Mishpatim</i>, 6.</i> “<i>Before them</i>, but not before the Canaanites.” This interpretation is based on the observation that it should have said, “which <i>tasim lahem</i>” (“thou shalt set <i>for them</i>”) just as He said, <i>There ‘sam lo’ (He set for them) a statute and an ordinance;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:25.</i> thus since He said, <i>which thou shalt set ‘liphneihem’ (before them)</i>, we interpret this to mean that they should be the judges, for it is with reference to a judge that this term [<i>liphnei</i> (before)] appears in Scripture: <i>And both the men, between whom the controversy is, shall stand before the Eternal, ‘liphnei’ (before) the priests and the judges;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 19:17.</i> <i>Until he stand ‘liphnei’ (before) the congregation for judgment;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:12.</i> <i>‘liphnei’ (before) all who know law and judgment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:13.</i> The Rabbis further explained: “<i>Before them</i>, but not before laymen.” They interpreted [the verse in this way] because with reference to the ordinances it is written: <i>Then his master shall bring him unto ‘ha’elohim;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 6.</i> <i>the cause of both parties shall come before ‘ha’elohim;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 22:8.</i> <i>and it is also written, and he shall give ‘biphlilim’ (as the judges determine)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i> — these terms referring to judges who are experts in the law, and who had received ordination<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The process of investiture with judicial rights and functions. Ordination was conferred by three Sages, only one of whom himself had to be duly ordained. Ordination was valid only if both the ordainers and the ordained were in the Land of Israel. Once received in the Land of Israel, however, the authority of ordination became effective outside the Land as well.</i> [in an unbroken chain from the time of those who had been duly ordained] by Moses our Teacher. This is why He said here that these ordinances are to be set <i>before them</i>, meaning before the <i>elohim</i> [expert, ordained judges] that He will mention further on, but not before Canaanites, and not before one who is not a judge by the standard of the Torah, such as a layman in this respect. It is forbidden to appear before such a person to act as a judge, just as it is forbidden to bring it before the Canaanites, even if he knows that this layman knows the correct law and will render him a proper decision. Even so it is forbidden for the litigant to set him up as a judge and complain before him so that he orders the other party to come to court before him, and the layman himself is also forbidden to act as their judge. Now even though the Sages have mentioned these two groups [the layman and the Canaanite] together, there is a difference between them, in that if the two litigants are willing to come before an Israelite who is a layman, and accept him upon themselves, it is permissible for them to do so, and they must abide by his decision, but to come before the Canaanites to act as judges between them, is forbidden under all circumstances, even if the Canaanite laws are in that particular case the same as our laws.

Verse 2

IF THOU BUY A HEBREW SERVANT. G-d began the first ordinance with the subject of a Hebrew servant, because the liberation of the servant in the seventh year contains a rememberance of the departure from Egypt which is mentioned in the first commandment, just as He said on it, <i>And thou shalt remember that thou wast a bondman in the land of Egypt, and the Eternal thy G-d redeemed thee; therefore I command thee this thing today</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:15.</i> It also contains a remembrance of the creation, just as the Sabbath does, for the seventh year signals to a servant a complete rest from the work of his master, just as the seventh day of the week does. There is in addition a ‘seventh’ amongst the years, which is the jubilee, for seven is the chosen of the days [to be the Sabbath], and of the years [to be the Sabbatical year], and of the [seven] Sabbaticals [to be the jubilee]; and they all point to one subject, namely, the secret of the days of the world — from <i>bereshith (in the beginning)</i> till <i>vayechulu (and they were finished)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:1. See Ramban Vol. I, pp. 61-64.</i> Therefore this commandment deserved to be mentioned first, because of its extreme importance, alluding as it does to great things in the process of creation.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s reticent and challenging language is illuminated in an essay by I. Weinstock (B’maglei Haniglah V’hanistar, pp. 151-241) where he traces the development of this Cabalistic doctrine: The universe is subject to cycles of seven thousand years; after each six thousand years of growth and activity the seventh thousand is one of “rest” — destruction. This process repeats itself seven times — representing a total of forty-nine thousand years, the fiftieth thousand being the jubilee when all existence returns to its beginnings. This phenomenon applies to the planet on which we live as well as to the worlds above us. One can thus get a glimpse into the meaning of Ramban’s words before us, that this commandment “alludes to great things in the process of creation.”</i> This is why the prophet Jeremiah was very stringent about it and said, <i>Thus saith the Eternal, the G-d of Israel: I made a covenant with your fathers;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 34:13.</i> <i>At the end of the seven years ye shall let go every one his manservant, and every one his maidservant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 14 and 10 (Ramban combined here parts of these verses).</i> And on account of its violation, G-d decreed the exile,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 17-22.</i> just as the Torah decreed exile for the Sabbatical rest of the land which was not observed,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:34-35.</i> as I will yet write,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:2.</i> with the help of the Rock.<br>When He finished stating the ordinance of this [first] commandment as it applies to Hebrew servants, He began the ordinance of the commandment, <i>Thou shalt not murder</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:13.</i> since it is the worst [sin] and then [He stated the ordinances of the commandments] to honor one’s parents, and of <i>Thou shalt not steal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:13.</i> and then He went back to the ordinance of one who smites his fellow-man but did not kill him,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verses 18-19.</i> and then to the murder of a bondman, which is worse than the killing of an offspring,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">See further Verse 22 — that for killing an unborn child a fine is paid, while in the case of the bondman, if he did not survive for twenty-four hours after he was struck by the master, the master is liable to death (Verses 20-21).</i> and after that to [injury to] the limbs of Israelites and bondmen,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 24-27.</i> and then to cases of death inflicted by cattle which cause injury.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 28-32.</i> All the sections are thus arranged in logical sequence and in proper order.

Verse 3

THEN HIS WIFE SHALL GO OUT WITH HIM. Rashi commented: “But who brought her in, that Scripture need say that she shall go out with him? But [by saying this], Scripture tells us that he who acquires a Hebrew servant is obliged to provide for the food of his wife and children.” This is a Midrash of the Sages.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the Verse here.</i> Now [even though the children are not mentioned in this verse, but only his wife,] the Rabbis have included the children together with the wife in this duty of the master, on the basis of what is written further on, <i>Then he shall go out from thee, he and his children with him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:41.</i><br>I am not clear on this law as to whether the earnings of the woman and children belong to the master during the time he is supporting them. It appears to me that the master takes the place of the husband [in this respect]. For the Torah had compassion on the wife and children, whose lives are hanging in suspense,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 28:66.</i> and who expect [to be supported from] the husband’s earnings, since now that he is sold as a servant, they are in danger of being lost in their misery. Therefore the Torah commanded the master who is now entitled to the servant’s labor, to act towards them as he [the servant] would. If so, the master only has to assume the responsibilities of the husband, [and no more]; thus he is entitled to their labor as is the husband, and in return he must feed and support them. This is the meaning of the expression, <i>then his wife shall go out with him</i>, since the servant’s wife was together with him as a handmaid to his master, for the labor of both of them belongs to him, in return for which he is obliged to give them food. Thus the only difference between husband and wife is that the wife has a right to go away as she pleases, [and is not bound to work for her husband’s master if she does not want to be supported by him, whilst the husband, who is the servant, is bound to the master]. Similarly, the master’s obligation to support the children is limited to the time that the father is responsible for them, namely when they are minors, or as long as is customary to feed them, as Rashi explained in Tractate Kiddushin.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 22a. See my Hebrew commentary p. 413.</i> All this is out of G-d’s compassion for them [the wife and children], and for the servant as well so that he should not die in his anguish, in the knowledge that whilst he is toiling in a strange house, his children and wife are neglected. Now even though he is not obliged by law of the Torah to support them, as has been explained in the Talmud, Tractate Kethuboth,<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 49 a-b.</i> but since it is the normal way of life for a man to support his wife and small children, G-d in His mercies commanded the buyer [of the servant] to act to them as a merciful father. The meaning of the Sages in speaking of <i>banav</i> [literally: “his sons”] is both sons and daughters.<br>I have seen written in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the Verse here.</i> “I might think that the master is obliged to support the betrothed [of the servant] and the childless widow of his brother who is waiting for him to marry or reject her? Scripture therefore says, <i>his wife</i>, thus excluding the brother’s childless widow who is waiting for him, since she is not yet his wife. <i>With him</i>, this excludes the betrothed who, [even though she is his wife], is not yet <i>with him</i>.” This Mechilta is a proof to the law which I have stated, for since it is not customary for the betrothed and the childless brother’s widow to be supported by the man [in this case the servant], therefore the Torah did not impose their support upon the master either. And even if the brother-in-law or the bridegroom became liable by law at a certain time known in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">According to a first [i.e., an older] Mishnah, if after such time as the law allows for the preparation of the wedding, the bridegroom postponed it, he is liable to support her, and she may eat from his goods, so that if she is an Israelite’s daughter and betrothed to a priest, she may eat <i>terumah</i> (the heave-offering) as if she was already his wife. A later Mishnah though, ruled that a woman may not eat heave-offering until she has entered the bride-chamber (Kethuboth 57 b).</i> to support them, that obligation was in the nature of other debts they may have, and therefore the master did not become liable to support them.<br>Again I have found in another Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon:<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">In Hoffman’s edition, p. 120. — See Vol. I, p. 603, Note 245, for explanation of the term “another.”</i> “<i>If he be married then his wife shall go out with him</i>. Just as the master is obliged to feed the servant, so he is obliged to feed his wife and children. Still I might say: if the servant had a wife and children before he was bought, then his master is obliged to feed them, because he bought him on that condition, but if he had a wife and children only after he was bought I might think that his master is not obliged to feed them. Scripture therefore says, <i>if he be married</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “if he be the husband of a <i>wife</i>, then his <i>wife</i> shall go out with him.” The word “wife” is thus mentioned twice, once to indicate etc. (see text).</i> etc. There are thus two wives mentioned here, one referring to a wife that he had before his master bought him, and the other referring to a wife he had after he was bought. I might think that even if he had just a betrothed wife, or a childless brother’s widow who is waiting for him, whom the servant himself is not obliged to feed, that nonetheless his master is obliged to support them, and proof for that argument I might find in the fact that the husband himself is not obliged [by law of the Torah, as explained above] to feed his own wife and children, and yet, the master of the servant is obliged to feed the wife and children of his servant; Scripture therefore says, <i>then his wife shall go out with him</i> — that wife who is <i>with him</i>, the master is obliged to feed, but he is not bound to feed a wife who is not <i>with him</i>. I might think that even if the servant’s wife was one with whom it is not correct for him to continue living — such as a widow married to a High Priest, or a divorcee or profaned woman married to a common priest<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 21:7;14.</i> — [that the master is bound to feed her]; Scripture therefore says, <i>then his wife shall go out with him</i> — one that is fit to live <i>with him</i>, but not this one etc. I might think that even if he married without the master’s knowledge [the master is obliged to feed her]; Scripture therefore says, <i>if ‘he’ be married</i> — just as ‘he’ was acquired with the master’s knowledge, so his wife [whom the master must support] means one taken with the master’s knowledge. I might think that the earnings of his sons and daughters belong to the master, and it is logical that it be so: for if we see in the case of a Canaanite bondman, whose master is not bound to feed him, that nonetheless the earnings of his sons and daughters belong to the master, then surely it is logical that in the case of a Hebrew servant, whose master is obliged to feed him, that the earnings of his sons and daughters should belong to his master! Scripture therefore says: <i>he (if ‘he’ be married)</i> — it is he whose earnings belong to his master, but not those of his sons and daughters. <i>Then his wife shall go out with him</i> — do not separate him from his wife; do not separate him from his children.” Thus far the language of this Beraitha.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 209.</i><br>Yet I continue to say<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">In spite of the fact that this Beraitha apparently contradicts what Ramban said above — namely, that during the time of the Hebrew servant’s servitude the earnings of his wife and minor children belong to his master, since he is obliged to feed them, whereas here the Beraitha seems to be saying the opposite — “Yet I continue to say” writes Ramban, “as I have written above etc.”</i> as I have written above, that if the servant’s wife and children want to be supported by the master, that he may take their earnings, and this Beraitha quoted above intends only to tell us that they are not his by absolute right, as is the law of the Canaanite bondman, or as is the law of the Hebrew servant himself, [who must of necessity work for their master], but they [the wife and children of the Hebrew servant] can say to him: “We will not be fed by you, and we will not work for you.” What is new in this Beraitha is that if the servant married without the consent of his master, he is not bound to feed the wife or her children, for since it is within the power of his master to give him a Canaanite bondmaid, he is not obliged to feed this Israelite woman. The Rabbis further interpreted the word <i>imo</i> (with him) to teach us that you are not to separate him from his wife and children, which means to say that the master cannot tell him: “Be together with the handmaid I gave you and sleep with her at night, and not with the Israelite wife,” but the servant has the right to choose for himself.

Verse 4

IF HIS MASTER GIVE HIM A WIFE. “Scripture is speaking of a Canaanite woman. Or perhaps this is not so; but Scripture here speaks only of an Israelite woman?! Scripture therefore says, <i>the wife and her children shall be her master’s</i>. Consequently, it must be speaking of a Canaanite woman.” This is the language of the Beraitha<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 209.</i> taught in the Mechilta.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta on the Verse here.</i> Now Rashi wrote [in explanation of this Mechilta]: “For a Hebrew maidservant also goes free at the end of six years [just as a Hebrew manservant does], or even before the end of six years if she shows signs of puberty, for it is said, <i>If thy brother, a Hebrew man, or a Hebrew woman, be sold unto thee, he shall serve thee six years</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:12. “This teaches you that a Hebrew maidservant also goes free after six years’ service” (Rashi). Consequently the verse here which states <i>the wife [and her children] shall be her master’s</i> can only be speaking of a Canaanite woman.</i><br>But this is not quite correct. For if we say [as the Beraitha above attempted to,] that the verse here speaks of an Israelite woman, it could no longer refer to the case of a father selling his minor daughter, about whom the law is given that when she shows signs of puberty she goes free, for how could the master give her as a wife to his Hebrew servant, since he has no power to hand her over to any other man [except to designate her to be his own wife, or that of his son — as is explained further in Verses 8-9]!<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Accordingly, the Beraitha above that attempted to argue that Scripture here speaks of an Israelite woman [given by the master to his Hebrew servant], must refer only to a Hebrew woman <i>of age</i> who sold herself as a maidservant. So how then could Rashi support his argument [that if she were an Israelite woman, she would go free “if she shows signs of puberty],” when the Beraitha must of necessity be referring not to a minor but to a woman of age? (Mizrachi).</i> Similarly, the proof that Rashi mentioned, namely that she also goes free at the end of six years, is only so in accordance with his own words which he wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2, Rashi.</i> that a person who sells himself [on account of his destitution] is sold for a maximum of six years; but in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 14b.</i> these are the words of a single Sage [Rabbi Eliezer], but the accepted opinion is that one who sells himself can be sold for six years or more. Now if so, the case of a woman who goes free at the end of six years can only be when her father sold her [as a minor, but in that case the master has no right to give her as a wife to his Hebrew servant, but only to designate her as his own wife or that of his son]!<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">So both proofs of Rashi as to why Scripture cannot be speaking here of an Israelite woman, [1. that a Hebrew maidservant also goes free at the end of six years; 2. that even before the end of six years, she goes free if she shows signs of puberty], have no application here for reasons explained above.</i><br>But that which the Rabbis have said [in the Beraitha above, on the basis of the verse, <i>the wife and her children shall be the master’s</i>]: “Consequently, Scripture must be speaking of a Canaanite woman” — the meaning thereof is as follows: Since He stated, <i>the wife and her children shall be the master’s</i> [it must be speaking only of a Canaanite woman], for the children of a Canaanite bondmaid are the master’s since her child has the same status as she does, but in the case of an Israelite woman — even if she were of age [in which case her master could give her to his Hebrew servant as a wife], and even if we were to say that a woman may sell herself as a maidservant<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">A woman really cannot sell herself; as the Mechilta puts it: “<i>And if a man sell</i> (Verse 7) — a man can sell himself, but a woman cannot sell herself.” But Ramban is writing only on the assumption that the Beraitha introduced this as a hypothesis finally to be disproved. See my Hebrew commentary pp. 515-516.</i> — her children are the father’s [not the master’s].

Verse 5



Verse 6

THEN HIS MASTER SHALL BRING HIM UNTO ‘HA’ELOHIM’ — “to the court. The servant must take counsel with those who sold him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This section speaks here of one who was sold by the court for a theft which he had committed and was not able to pay for (further, 22:2). On refusing to go free at the end of his six years of service, the servant is to take counsel with his vendors [the court] “and they will advise him to go free, for when he is free he can serve G-d in more ways than he could as a servant etc.” (Zeh Yenachmeinu — commentary on the Mechilta).</i> [Thus is the language of Rashi.] And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the judges are called <i>elohim</i> because they uphold the laws of G-d on earth.<br>In my opinion Scripture uses these expressions: <i>Then his master shall bring him unto ‘ha’elohim;’ the cause of both parties shall come before ‘ha’elohim,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:8.</i> in order to indicate that G-d will be with the judges in giving their judgment. It is He Who declares who is just, and it is He Who declares who is wicked. It is with reference to this that Scripture says, <i>he whom ‘Elokim’ (G-d) shall condemn</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:8.</i> And so did Moses say, <i>for the judgment is G-d’s;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:17.</i> so also did Jehoshaphat say, <i>for ye judge not for man, but for the Eternal, and He is with you in giving judgment</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles, 19:6.</i> Similarly Scripture says, <i>G-d standeth in the congregation of G-d; in the midst of ‘elohim’ (the judges) He judgeth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 82:1.</i> that is to say, in the midst of a congregation of judges He judges, for it is G-d Who is the Judge. And so also it says, <i>Then both men, between whom the controversy is, shall stand before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 19:17.</i> And this is the purport of the verse, <i>For I will not justify the wicked</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:7.</i> according to the correct interpretation. In Eileh Shemoth Rabbah I have seen it said:<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 30:20.</i> “But when the judge sits and renders judgment in truth, the Holy One, blessed be He, leaves, as it were, the supreme heavens and causes His Presence to dwell next to him, for it is said, <i>When the Eternal raised them up judges, then the Eternal was with the judge</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 2:18.</i>
AND HE SHALL SERVE HIM ‘L’OLAM’ (FOREVER). Our Rabbis interpreted<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> this to mean until the jubilee year. And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that “the meaning of <i>olam</i> in the Sacred Language is <i>‘time.’ It hath been already, ‘l’olamim’ which were before us</i> means ‘the times’ [or ‘the ages’] <i>which were before us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 1:10.</i> <i>And there he may abide ‘ad olam’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 1:22.</i> [cannot mean ‘forever,’ for Samuel did not stay all his life in Shiloh; it must therefore mean ‘until a certain time,’ i.e., until he comes of age]. This is why the Rabbis have said, <i>and he shall serve him l’olam</i> means up to the time of the jubilee year, for of all appointed seasons in Israel the jubilee year is the most remote, and the going out to freedom is as if the world was made anew for him. The sense of the verse is then, that he should return to his status in his first time, when he was free.” The student learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand that <i>l’olam</i> is to be taken in its usual sense [i.e., forever], for he who works until the jubilee year has worked <i>all the days of old</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 63:9. See also above Note 23.</i> In the words of the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> “Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The epithet for Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi, the redactor of the Mishnah, or as he is often known <i>Rabbeinu Hakadosh</i>, “Our holy teacher,” or simply “Rabbi.”</i> says: Come and see that <i>olam</i> cannot mean more than fifty years, for it is said <i>and he shall serve him ‘l’olam,’</i> which means until the jubilee year.” Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra forgot that which he wrote with understanding in another place.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary to Leviticus 25:40-41, Ibn Ezra wrote on the verses, <i>He shall serve with thee unto the year of jubilee. Then shall he go out from thee…</i>: “This is what the Rabbis have received by tradition concerning the verse, <i>and he shall serve him ‘l’olam</i>,” meaning that he is to serve him until the jubilee year.” Thus Ibn Ezra did understand the verses there and found in them Scriptural proof that <i>olam</i> means fifty years, whilst here he wrote that it means “time.” Apparently, “he forgot” — as Ramban puts it — “what he wrote with understanding elsewhere.”</i>

Verse 7

SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT AS THE MENSERVANTS DO. This means that the Hebrew maidservant does not go out free “in consequence of the loss of a tooth or an eye, as Canaanite slaves do.”<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">See further, Verses 26-27.</i> Thus is Rashi’s language, and our Rabbis interpreted it likewise.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> Indeed it is so, for a Hebrew servant is not called <i>eved</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew servant may be called <i>eved ivri</i> [as in Verse 2 here: <i>if thou buy an ‘eved ivri’</i> — a Hebrew servant] but never just <i>eved</i>, which term by itself signifies a Canaanite bondman. Here in Verse 7 where it just says <i>ha’avadim</i> (menservants) it must therefore refer to the Canaanite bondmen. For a similar statement of Ramban see also further Verse 20.</i> without any further qualification.<br>But I wonder: why does Scripture find it necessary altogether to tell us this [that a Hebrew maidservant does not go out free because of the loss of a tooth or eye, as Canaanite bondmen do]?<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">For what reason might I have thought that she does go out free, so that Scripture should find it necessary to tell us that such is not the case?</i> Perhaps it is to tell us that we should not argue by applying the method of <i>kal vachomer</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Bo</i> Note 208. — The <i>kal vachomer</i> in this case would be as follows: A Canaanite bondwoman who does not go out free at the end of six years or in the jubilee year, does go out free because of the loss of any of the chief external organs. It is therefore only logical that a Hebrew maidservant, who does go out free at the end of six years or in the jubilee, should surely go out free because of the loss of any chief external organs.</i> from a Canaanite women, that a Hebrew maidservant goes out free because of the loss of a tooth or eye. This law is stated expressly in the case of a Hebrew woman, but such is also the law for a Hebrew man, who has been compared to her [thus he too does not go out free because of the loss of any of the chief external organs]. The author of the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth,’<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Shimon Kairo, who flourished in the second half of the eighth century — when the Gaonic period was at its height. Considered a most authoritative work on Rabbinic law, the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth’ was a pioneer in the field of <i>Taryag</i> (613) Commandments, for in a preface to this work the author was the first scholar who attempted to define each separate commandment (see my foreword to “The Commandments,” Vol. I pp. viii — ix).</i> wrote, however, that [the verse is not needed to exclude this <i>kal vachomer</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Bo</i> Note 208. — The <i>kal vachomer</i> in this case would be as follows: A Canaanite bondwoman who does not go out free at the end of six years or in the jubilee year, does go out free because of the loss of any of the chief external organs. It is therefore only logical that a Hebrew maidservant, who does go out free at the end of six years or in the jubilee, should surely go out free because of the loss of any chief external organs.</i> for even if Scripture had not excluded it, we could not have argued that a Hebrew woman should go out free in consequence of the loss of a tooth or eye], because the going forth to freedom by slaves on account of the loss of a tooth or eye is a penalty [to the master], and you cannot derive a law by logical argument from penalties. The author of the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth’ thus considered this verse a negative commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">As opposed to a mere “negation,” where the verse just negates a certain law from being applicable, without constituting a prohibition. In his Book of the Commandments, Maimonides dedicated the eighth principle to the clarification of this distinction between a negation and a prohibition, and without mentioning the name of the author of the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth,’ differs with him on the interpretation of this verse, which in his opinion merely states that there is no obligation on the part of the master to let her go free where he causes her the loss of one of her organs. [See in my translation, “The Commandments,” Vol. II pp. 390-393.] In his notes to Maimonides’ Book of Commandments, Ramban came to the defense of the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth.’</i> wherein G-d warns the master that if he wants to send her out free because of the loss of a tooth or eye, that he transgresses a prohibition; but instead he is to pay her monetary compensation for the tooth or eye, and she shall stay with him up to the time [of six years, or before if she produces signs of puberty], to be designated as the master’s wife [or his son’s]. For it would be a great injustice if, after causing her the loss of a tooth in his anger and blemishing her thereby, he would then send her out of his house, when she had hoped to become his wife. Moreover, many times the monetary compensation for the damage done to the chief external organs, is more than the earnings for her labor if her days as a handmaid have nearly terminated. Therefore Scripture was strict upon the master and made a clear prohibition, so that he should not rob her of the monetary compensation due to her for the loss of any of her chief organs, even if he should want to let her go free on account of them. It may be that sending her to freedom is itself forbidden before the fixed time, for Scripture has obliged the master to support her and that she stay with him, in case she finds favor in his eyes and becomes his wife; just as He warned him with a prohibition that [after he marries her and takes another wife] <i>her food, her raiment, and her conjugal rights shall he not diminish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> In accordance with this opinion [the author of the ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth’] counted the verse, <i>She shall not go out as the menservants do</i> among the three hundred and sixty-five negative commandments.

Verse 8

L’AM NOCHRI’ HE SHALL HAVE NO POWER TO SELL HER. “Neither her master nor her father has the right to sell her to another [Hebrew man].<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi thus interprets <i>l’am nochri</i> [literally: “unto a foreign people”] as signifying “unto a strange man,” i.e., to another Israelite. Thus the verse is stating that neither the father nor the master has a right to resell her. Ramban will question this interpretation.</i> <i>Seeing he hath dealt deceitfully with her</i> — if he [i.e. the master] intends to act deceitfully towards her and not to fulfill the commandment of designating her as his wife [or his son’s]. So also did her father act deceitfully towards her, by selling her to this master.” Thus far Rashi’s language. And if so, <i>l’am nochri</i> would be like <i>l’ish nochri</i> (to a strange man), but we find in all Scripture no parallel to such a usage [that <i>am</i> (people) should be understood in the sense of “man”]. Perhaps the letter <i>lamed</i> in the word <i>l’am</i> draws along with it a similar letter in the next word, thus making it: <i>‘l’am l’nochri’ he shall have no power to sell her</i>, and the explanation thereof would be similar to the verse, <i>Thou gavest him to be food ‘l’am l’tziyim’ (to the folk inhabiting the wilderness)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 74:14.</i> where the second word <i>l’tziyim</i> explains: who is <i>the folk?</i> — the men who inhabit the wilderness; so here too He says, <i>he shall have no power to sell her ‘l’am’</i>, and He explains: who is <i>l’am? — l’nochri</i>, that is to say, to any stranger from the whole people [i.e., to another Israelite]. The term <i>nochri</i> here will then be similar in usage to the expressions: <i>and thy labors in the house of a ‘nochri’ (stranger)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 5:10.</i> which means in the house of another man; <i>even from the ‘nochriyah’ (the strange woman) that maketh smooth her words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:16.</i> meaning the woman who is not his wife. All this I have written in order to uphold the words of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Eleazar and Rabbi Shimon — in Kiddushin 18a.</i> who say that a man is not permitted to sell his daughter twice into the status of a handmaid, thus holding to the explanation: since he has once dealt deceitfully with her [by selling her to such a status of a handmaid], he has no more the right to sell her.<br>But I have seen in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> “<i>‘L’am nochri’ he shall have no power to sell her</i>, — this is a warning to the court that he [i.e., the father] should not sell her to an alien [i.e., a non-Israelite].” It would thus appear from their language that this verse is not meant as an admonition against the father reselling her to this Israelite master or to another one, but is a prohibition against her being sold altogether [even the first time] to a non-Israelite, so that a man may not sell his minor daughter to an idolator as a handmaid. [It was necessary for this to be stated] because in the case of a Hebrew servant He said, <i>and he sell himself unto the stranger who is a settler with thee, or to the offshoot of a stranger’s family</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:47.</i> therefore it had to say that this should not be done to a woman. The reason for it is obvious.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">“That she not be exposed to the dangers of immorality.” (Bachya).</i> This surely is the plain meaning of Scripture, that after the father — the vendor — redeemed her from her first master, he cannot sell her to an idolator, and the same law applies to the original sale. Scripture, however, [had to state this prohibition in the case of a re-sale], because sometimes a man may very much want to redeem his daughter from a master who did not take her as his wife, and will want to sell her to an idolator for a year or two with the intention of then taking her out from him; therefore Scripture warned him against doing this. Or it may be that this expression [i.e., <i>‘l’am nochri’ he shall have no power to sell her</i>] refers back to the beginning of this subject: <i>And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> — <i>he shall have no power to sell her to a foreign man</i>. If so, then the Rabbis’ interpretation in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Eleazar and Rabbi Shimon — in Kiddushin 18a.</i> that a man may not resell his daughter into the status of a handmaid, [even to an Israelite], is derived [not from <i>‘l’am nochri’ he shall have no power to sell her</i>, but] from the [apparently] superfluous expression: <i>seeing he hath dealt deceitfully with her</i>. For to a non-Israelite he never has power to sell her; so why did G-d say: <i>seeing he hath dealt deceitfully with her</i>, [since he cannot sell her even once to a foreign man], and the meaning of that expression is that since he acted once deceitfully with her by selling her into a status of a handmaid, he cannot do so another time? Therefore the Rabbis interpreted the verse thus: “<i>to a foreign people he shall have no power to sell her</i> [altogether], and <i>when he hath dealt deceitfully with her</i> [he also has no power to sell her];” that is to say, he shall have no power to sell her if he dealt deceitfully with her, for after he sold her once [to an Israelite], he cannot sell her again. There are many instances where the Rabbis interpreted the verses in such a manner. [Thus we find: <i>Unto the stranger that is within thy gates thou shalt give it that he may eat it, or thou mayest sell it unto a foreigner</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 14:21.</i> — which Rabbi Meir interpreted]:<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 21b.</i> “Read the verse thus: unto the stranger that is within thy gates thou shalt give it that he may eat it, or thou mayest sell it;
