thou shalt give it that he may eat it or thou mayest sell it unto a foreigner.” Similarly they interpreted here<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 4a.</i> <i>then shall she go out for nothing, without money</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> which, on account of the redundant language, [“for nothing,” “without money”] they made the basis for two additional ways of the Hebrew maidservant regaining her freedom: “<i>she shall go out for nothing</i>, and <i>she shall go out without money;</i>” thus establishing that she goes out to freedom when she produces signs of puberty, or signs of fuller development if she had no signs of puberty — this being that maturity of the barren woman, [who is incapable of conception], as is stated in the beginning of Tractate Kiddushin.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 4a.</i><br>The plain meaning of Scripture in this section is as follows: <i>If a man sell his</i> minor <i>daughter to be a maidservant, she shall not go out as</i> these <i>menservants</i>, [i.e., the <i>Hebrew</i> menservants] mentioned [above in Verses 2-6,] who go out to freedom in the seventh year and in the jubilee year: for the master<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tur who quotes Ramban: “the father.” That is to say, if the maiden pleased the master and he wishes to marry her, the father cannot take her out from his house.</i> can never send her away from his house if the maiden pleases him <i>and she obtains kindness of him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">See Esther 2:9.</i> but he is to take her for a wife as is his will. <i>But if she pleaseth not her master</i>, who has not espoused her to be his wife — for he who buys an Israelite’s daughter does so with the intention of taking her as his wife, thus she is under ordinary conditions designated for him; but now if her master does not desire her, <i>then shall</i> the father mentioned <i>redeem her</i>, for as soon as the master says: “I do not want to marry her,” it is forbidden for the father to leave her any longer under his authority, nor may he sell her to a foreign people in case he comes to deal deceitfully with her, for it is deceit for a man to sell his daughter except to someone who can marry her. Or the meaning thereof may be that anyone who sells his daughter [even to an Israelite], deals deceitfully with her.

Verse 9

AND IF ‘YI’ODENAH’ (HE ESPOUSE HER) UNTO HIS SON, HE SHALL DEAL WITH HER AFTER THE MANNER OF DAUGHTERS. In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is possible that G-d is saying that if the buyer <i>yi’odenah</i> for his son, which means that he espoused her to him — for the term <i>yi’ud</i> is an expression of appointing, such as: <i>he tarried longer than the set time which ‘y’ado’ (he had appointed him)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 20:5.</i> — <i>then he shall do unto her after the manner</i> that a man does <i>for</i> his own <i>daughters</i> — he is to give her of his own <i>according to the dowry of virgins</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:16.</i> He thus commanded this as He did in the law of outfitting the emancipated servant,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:13-14.</i> and it is all an expression of His goodness, magnified be He! And in accordance with the interpretation of our Rabbis, which is the truth, the meaning of the verse is: <i>after the manner of daughters</i> whom parents marry off, <i>so shall</i> the son [of the master] <i>deal with her</i>. And then He explains [what is “the manner of daughters”] that <i>if he take him another wife, her food, her raiment, and her conjugal rights</i> — that is, of this one [the former maidservant] — <i>he shall not diminish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> It is obvious that if he did not marry another woman he must not diminish her rights, but Scripture speaks of that which is usual.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., if he does marry another woman he is more likely to diminish the rights of this one; hence Scripture speaks of the case <i>‘if’ he take him another wife</i>. But this is by no means to be understood that it was “the usual” thing to take another wife.</i><br>Now Rashi explained: “<i>sh’eirah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> means food; <i>k’suthah</i> is, as the literal sense of the word, raiment; <i>onatha</i> is the marital duty.” And so did Onkelos render <i>sh’eirah: zivanah</i> (food). But in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 47b. — For the meaning of the term Gemara see in <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 204.</i> the Rabbis said with reference to the Sage who held this opinion [that <i>sh’eirah</i> means food]: “And this Tanna<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Yithro</i>, Note 451.</i> holds that the alimentation of one’s wife is a law of the Torah. For we have been taught: <i>sh’eirah</i> — this means her food, and so it says, <i>He caused ‘sh’eir’ (flesh) to rain upon them as the dust</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:27.</i> etc.” And from the subject under discussion in that Gemara it is understood that this is the opinion of a single Sage, whilst the accepted law is that the alimentation of one’s wife is a Rabbinical enactment. And even according to the plain meaning of Scripture, why should it mention food under the term <i>sh’eir</i> which means “flesh;” it should rather have mentioned <i>lachmah</i> (her bread), for man lives by bread<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 8:3.</i> and his obligation towards her is [mainly] in that sustenance. Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra thought to correct this, and so he explained <i>sh’eirah</i> as meaning food which builds up her <i>sh’eir</i>, namely her flesh. But there is no sense in Scripture saying that the “husband diminish not her flesh!”<br>Therefore I say that the meaning of <i>sh’eir</i> everywhere is flesh close and near to one’s own, the root thereof being derived from the expression <i>sh’eir b’saro</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:6. Generally translated: “that is near of kin to him.” According to Ramban the literal meaning would be: “the flesh close and near to his flesh.”</i> that is his close flesh outside that of the flesh of his own body. Thus relatives are called <i>sh’eir: to any sh’eir b’saro’ (that is near of kin to him);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:6. Generally translated: “that is near of kin to him.” According to Ramban the literal meaning would be: “the flesh close and near to his flesh.”</i> <i>they are ‘sha’arah’ (near kinswomen)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 17.</i> this being associated with the expressions: <i>surely thou art my bone and my flesh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 29:14.</i> <i>of whom the flesh is half consumed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:12. “The flesh” here refers to Miriam — Aaron’s and Moses’ sister.</i> Similarly, <i>And I will cut off from Babylon a name, ‘ush’ar’ offshoot and offspring</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:22.</i> means a child related to him. Likewise, <i>when thy flesh ‘ush’eirecha’ are consumed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 5:11.</i> which means “yourself and your children” who are the flesh closest to you. Thus meat is called <i>sh’eir — He caused ‘sh’eir’ to rain upon them as the dust</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 78:27.</i> — because meat when eaten is absorbed by the eater and becomes part of his flesh. It is possible that this is the meaning of the expression, <i>when thy flesh ‘ush’eirecha’ are consumed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 5:11.</i> meaning: when the original flesh of your body, and the nutriment of flesh which came from the food, will be consumed and will no longer be part of your flesh. Thus a woman in relation to her husband is called <i>sh’eir</i> — just as the Rabbis interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 22b.</i> “<i>except for ‘lish’eiro,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 21:2.</i> <i>sh’eir</i> means his wife;” — the usage of the term being derived from the idea that G-d stated, <i>and he shall cleave unto his wife, and they shall be one flesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:24.</i> Thus <i>sh’eira</i> here means “the nearness of her flesh;” <i>k’suthah</i> is “the cover of her bed,” just as it is said, <i>for that is his only ‘k’suthoh’ (covering)… wherein shall he sleep?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:26.</i> and <i>onathah</i> is “her time,” that he come to her at times of love. And even if we say as some commentators do, that the meaning of <i>sh’eir</i> is like “his flesh,” and the expression, <i>to any ‘sh’eir’ b’saro’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:6. Generally translated: “that is near of kin to him.” According to Ramban the literal meaning would be: “the flesh close and near to his flesh.”</i> is like “to any flesh of his flesh,” just as it says, <i>for he is our brother, our flesh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:27.</i> — in that case we would still explain <i>‘sh’eirah'… he shall not diminish</i> as meaning that he shall not diminish from her her flesh; that is, the flesh due to her, namely, the flesh of her husband who with her is one flesh. Thus the meaning of the verse is, that G-d says that if the master takes another wife, he shall not diminish from this one the nearness of her flesh, the cover of her bed, and her time of love, for such is <i>the manner of daughters</i>. And the intention is that the other woman should not be sitting <i>upon a stately bed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 23:41.</i> <i>and</i> there <i>they shall be one flesh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 2:24.</i> whilst this one is to him merely like a concubine, with whom he lives only by chance, and upon the ground, just like one comes to a harlot. It is for this reason that Scripture has forbidden him to act in this way. And so did the Sages say:<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 48a.</i> “<i>sh’eirah</i> means the nearness of flesh, that he should not behave to her as is the custom among the Persians, who perform their marital rights in their clothes.” This is a correct interpretation, for such is the style of Scripture always to mention sexual intercourse in clean and brief language. Therefore it mentions these duties by means of allusion: <i>sh’eirah k’sutha v’onatha</i>, referring to the three things which are usual when a man comes together with his wife. Thus the verse is properly explained in accordance with the accepted law, whilst alimentation of one’s wife and provision of her raiment are duties put upon the husband by ordinance of the Rabbis.

Verse 10



Verse 11

AND IF THESE THREE — designating her to himself as his wife, or to his son, or allowing her to be redeemed — HE DO NOT UNTO HER, then SHALL SHE GO OUT FOR NOTHING, WITHOUT MONEY, as do the menservants mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., at the end of six years, or the jubilee year. It is thus in contrast to Verse 7 above: <i>And if a man sell his daughter to be a maidservant, she shall not go out as the menservants do</i>. But if the master do not these three things to her [as explained], then she shall go out as the menservants do. See Ramban above at the end of Verse 8 [“The plain meaning of Scripture in this section etc.”]. To this he now adds that if the master fails to do any of the three ways to ameliorate her condition, then she shall go out free for nothing, as menservants do.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND HE THAT SMITETH HIS FATHER, OR HIS MOTHER, SHALL SURELY BE PUT TO DEATH. Our Sages have already taught<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 84b.</i> that his death is by strangulation. This is why He placed next to it, <i>And he that stealeth a man, and selleth him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> for he too is punished by the same death. He separated it from the later verse, <i>And he that curseth his father or his mother</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> because his death is by stoning, as it is said concerning him, <i>he hath cursed his father or his mother; his blood shall be upon him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 20:9.</i> and whenever such an expression [<i>his blood be upon him</i>] is used about someone, his death is by stoning, this being derived from that which is written, <i>They shall stone them with stones; their blood shall be upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> The reason why He was more severe as to the manner of death of the one who curses his mother or father than as to the manner of death of one who smites them,<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In the order of severity stoning is considered the most stringent of the four deaths that the court had power to inflict, and strangulation the least severe. Ramban’s question is thus pertinent: why the most severe punishment for the curser, and the least severe one for one who smites?</i> is because the sin of cursing is more common, for when the fool gets angry <i>he frets himself and curses by his king</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 8:21.</i> and father and mother the whole day, and a crime that is frequently committed needs a greater punishment [than one rarely committed]. Or it may be that cursing involves a greater sin, because he uses the Name of G-d,<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Shebuoth 36a. Also in the Mechilta here: “One who curses his father or his mother is not liable to the death penalty unless he curses them by using the Divine Name.” Needless to say cursing is strongly forbidden by itself, even without using the Divine Name.</i> and therefore he has to be punished for his sin against his father and mother, and also for taking G-d’s Name in transgression and sin. Now the Gaon Rav Saadia<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned here in Ibn Ezra, Verse 16. — On Rav Saadia, see in <i>Seder Va’eira</i>, Note 229.</i> said, that the reason why He placed the matter of stealing a human being between that of smiting one’s parents and cursing them, is because most people are kidnapped when they are young, and they grow up in a strange place unaware of who their parents are, and thus they may come to smite them or to curse them [not knowing that they are their parents]; therefore it is fitting that the thief too be punished by death as they are, since he is responsible for the punishment that is visited upon the child [who smites or curses either of his parents, and for that reason the verse dealing with the thief’s punishment is mentioned between those dealing with smiting one’s parents and cursing them].

Verse 16

AND HE THAT STEALETH A MAN, AND SELLETH HIM, AND HE BE FOUND IN HIS HAND — “previously, before the sale.” This is Rashi’s language. But I have not understood it.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban argues that since Rashi made his comment upon the phrase: <i>and he be found in his hand</i>, it would appear that the fact that the witnesses saw him in his possession constitutes their proof that the holder stole him. On this, Ramban asked: could you possibly think that the thief be subject to death without the witnesses having seen the actual theft and the sale? Their having seen him in the thief’s possession is in fact no proof at all that he had stolen him (Nimukei Shmuel).</i> If Rashi means that witnesses must have seen him [the stolen person] in the thief’s possession before he had sold him — could it even enter your mind that the thief be subject to the death penalty without witnesses having seen him stealing and also seeing him selling! It would therefore have been sufficient if Scripture were to say: “and he that stealeth a man and selleth him”. Further, his being found in the thief’s possession is no real proof that he stole him! Rather, this verse is the source for that which we have been taught in a Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 85b.</i> “He that steals a person is not liable to the punishment unless he brings him into his own possession,” and in a Beraitha the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 85b.</i> “If he stole him but did not sell him, or if he sold him but he is still in his [the thief’s], possession, he is free [from the death penalty].” The meaning of this is to teach us that the law applying to the thief of a human being is [in one respect] similar to that of thieves of other, i.e., monetary, matters; namely, that if a thief killed or sold [an ox or a sheep] within the domain of the owner, he is free [from paying five oxen for an ox and four sheeps for a sheep],<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 37.</i> but if he lifted them up [thereby acquiring possession of them], or removed them from the domain of the owner, he is liable to pay. Similarly, this thief of a human being must first have brought the stolen person into his own domain [in order to be liable to death]. Likewise if he lifted the lad upon his shoulder, and sold him to another person, he is liable to the death penalty, because this too is called <i>if he be found in his hand</i>, since it is not logical that a man’s ground should have a greater power of taking possession of a thing for the owner, than his own hand has. In a similar way, that which the Rabbis said [in the Beraitha mentioned above]: “or if he sold him but he is still in his [the thief’s] possession etc.,” means that the buyer did not remove him at all from the thief’s domain, even though he paid him the money, and since he did not remove him from there, the thief is free [from the death penalty]. Now I do not know whether this is to say that [in order to make the thief of a human being liable to the death penalty] the buyer must perform a formal act of acquisition, as is the law in other transactions, that the buyer does not take ownership of the article until he draws it from the domain of the seller into a <i>simta</i>, [an alley adjoining an open place] or until he lifts it [even within the domain of the seller] — or it may be that it is a special Scriptural decree in the case of the sale of a stolen human being, that even if the sale has been finalized between them, and the buyer has taken ownership from the seller by lifting him or by drawing him along in ground which belongs to both of them, [in which case usually the act of drawing the purchased article is a valid act of acquisition even if not done in a <i>simta</i>], that the thief is nonetheless free from the death penalty until the stolen person goes out from his domain into the domain of the buyer. And so indeed it would appear to be [as the latter exposition].<br>Now Rashi in his commentaries there in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 85b.</i> explained [the phrase of the Beraitha]: “if he sold him but he is still in his possession” as meaning “if he is still <i>in the stolen person’s</i> domain,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Not as we have explained it heretofore, according to Ramban, that the reference is to <i>the thief’s domain</i>.</i> in which case the thief is free from punishment because there has been no real theft at all.” But if so, nothing new has been established here which is unlike the ordinary law of theft in monetary matters!<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">But according to Ramban, as explained above, there is a new law established here: even if the thief brought the stolen person to his domain, and the buyer came there and the sale was completely finalized, [by the buyer lifting him, or drawing him into ground which belongs to both], the thief is nevertheless free from the death penalty as long as the buyer did not remove him from the seller’s domain. In the case of theft of an ox or sheep under such circumstances, the thief would be liable to pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.</i><br>However, it may be, the words of the verse [to be interpreted properly, must be transposed as follows]: “and he that stealeth a man, and he be found in his hand, and he selleth him, he shall surely be put to death.” But it is still possible that the verse may be explained properly in the order it is written in. Thus: <i>And he that stealeth a man, and selleth him, and he be found in the hand</i> of the buyer [<i>he</i> — the thief — <i>shall surely be put to death</i>]; for if he stole a human being and brought him to his house, and then he brought the buyer there and sold him without the buyer taking him out from there, the thief is not liable, because the sale has not been completed between them, or even if the sale has been completed, he is still free of the death penalty, as I have written above.

Verse 17



Verse 18

WITH A STONE OR ‘B’EGROF’ (WITH HIS FIST). Judging from certain expressions of the Rabbis, <i>egrof</i> is the hand closed tightly, with the fingers gathered into the palm for the purpose of striking someone with it. Thus they speak of <i>ba’alei egrofin</i> [literally: “men of fists,” or men of power];<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 76b.</i> “<i>egrofo</i> (the fist) of Ben Abtiach.”<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Keilim 17:12. A giant who lived in the time of the Second Sanctuary.</i> Similarly <i>‘b’egrof’ of wickedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 58:4.</i> means the hand of wickedness that strikes. Scripture thus mentioned two kinds of hitting — the hard one, with a stone, and the lighter one, with the fist, which in most cases does not cause death — in order to declare that in both cases an estimate [of the power of the stone or the fist with which he struck him] is needed, and the assailant is meanwhile imprisoned. If the assailed person dies, such as where he struck him a mortal blow, <i>he is a murderer; he shall surely be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:16.</i> but if he does not die, the assailant has to pay him for the loss of his labor and for the cost of the healing.<br>In the Mechilta [we find the following text]:<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> “Rabbi Nathan says: He has likened the stone to the fist and the fist to the stone. Just as the stone can cause death, so also the blow of the fist must be such that it is capable of causing death. And just as the fist is something that can be identified [and measured for the power of its blow], so also the stone must be such as can be identified. But if the stone with which he struck him became mixed up with other stones, the assailant is free.” This means if the stone became mixed up with other stones, they [e.i., the judges] estimate the lightest one and if it is incapable of causing death, they free the assailant.<br>Other scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra and R’dak (in Sefer Hashorashim, root <i>goraf</i>).</i> have said that the word <i>egrof</i> means “a clod of earth,” the term being derived from the expression: <i>the grains shrivel under ‘megr’fotheihem’ (their clods of earth)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 1:17.</i> and the letter <i>alef</i> [in the word <i>egrof</i> is redundant], as is the <i>alef</i> in the word <i>ezro’a</i> [“arm,” where the word is really <i>zro’a</i>]. And this is the opinion of Onkelos who translated <i>b’egrof — b’churmeiza</i> (a piece of white stone or glazed tile). He mentioned these things also in order to tell us that the assailant who hits him with a clod of earth is also liable to be put to death, if he struck him on a sensitive spot where it is capable of causing death. This is to distinguish the law of the sword from the stone and <i>egrof</i>, for no estimate [of a sword or weapon] needs to be taken [since even a minute piece of metal — such as a needle — can also cause death], as the Sages have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 76b.</i>

Verse 19

IF HE RISE AGAIN, AND WALKS ABROAD ‘AL MISH’ANTO’ — “in his former healthy state and vigor.” This is Rashi’s language. And Rabbi ibn Ezra said that the reason why this word [which means literally: “support”] is used, is to tell us that he must not be dependant upon others for the ability to walk, like an invalid, but must walk by himself;<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Thus according to Rashi <i>mish’anto</i> is “his physical strength;” according to Ibn Ezra, it is “his leaning” or “support.” Ramban will proceed to explain it in its literal sense — “on his staff.” Almost all translations follow Ramban’s interpretation.</i> only <i>then shall he that smote him be quit</i> from prison.<br>In my opinion, <i>mish’anto</i> is to be understood in its literal sense, [a staff], just as in the verses: <i>every man with ‘mish’anto’ (his staff) in his hand for old age;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Zechariah 8:4.</i> <i>‘mish’eneth’ (the staff) of this bruised reed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 18:21.</i> Scripture is thus stating that if the injured person’s health improves sufficiently to enable him to go out walking as he wishes <i>in the streets and in the broad ways</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 3:2.</i> with his staff, like those healed from some prolonged disabling injury, <i>then shall he that smote him be quit;</i> and it further teaches us that even if the injured man is careless later about his health and dies after that in his weakness, the assailant is free from the death penalty. Scripture says <i>and he walketh abroad</i> because it speaks of the customary way of life, for injured men who were laid up in bed do not go out walking again until their wounds have healed and they are out of danger, this being the sense of the phrase, <i>and he walketh abroad</i>, because if he just gets up and walks in his house on his staff, and then dies, the assailant is not free [from the death penalty].<br>In the words of the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> “<i>If he rise again and walketh</i>. I might think this means within the house; Scripture therefore says, <i>abroad</i>. But from the word <i>abroad</i> I might think that even if he was wasting away [the assailant is still free from punishment]; Scripture therefore says, <i>if he rise again</i>.” This explanation too is very correct, that Scripture should be saying that if the injured man gets up completely from his bed and goes steadily outside — without having to go back to his bed when returning from outside, as is the way of those who continue to waste away — even though he is weak and has to lean upon a staff, the assailant shall be let off. In general all this is to be interpreted as being figurative, language expressing people’s practical conduct, and the basic rule is that he must have been assessed as being capable of recovery. This is why Onkelos translated <i>al mish’anto: al boryeih</i> (in his healthy state).
Scripture states, <i>only he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed</i>, but it does not say, “he shall pay for the loss of his time and his medical care.” in order to tell us that he must pay the money for the doctors to heal him, and the injured person cannot demand that he should give him the compensation and he will do other things with it. Instead, the assailant must heal him under all circumstances.

Verse 20

IF A MAN SMITE HIS BONDMAN. Our Sages have already perforce derived from the expression, <i>for he is his money</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> that this verse speaks of a Canaanite bondman, and the plain meaning of Scripture is indeed as they say, for his countryman, a Hebrew man or woman, is not called plain <i>eved</i> or <i>amah</i> without any further qualifications.<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">See also Ramban above Verse 7, and Note 67.</i> Scripture states <i>‘basheivet’</i> [with a <i>patach</i> under the <i>beth</i>, which indicates the definite article, thus meaning] “with the rod”: [<i>And if a man smite his bondman, or his bondwoman, with the rod</i>], because it is the custom of a ruler or master to keep in his hand a rod, and G-d therefore warned him that even if it be <i>a rod of correction</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 22:15.</i> and not a wooden cane, he should be careful with it and should not use it to hit even a Ganaanite bondman <i>with a persecution that none restrained</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 14:6.</i> This is the purport of the expression, <i>and he die under his hand</i>, meaning that he kept striking him until he died. It was not necessary for Scripture to state the punishment which he is liable to, but it just stated that he is not to go free merely because the bondman is his money, but <i>he shall surely be punished</i>, as is the punishment of anyone who strikes another person so that he dies, where Scripture has said, <i>he shall surely be put to death</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 12.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture the intention of: <i>Notwithstanding, if a day or two ‘ya’amod’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> [generally translated “he continues”], is that the bondman literally gets up “and stands” on his feet. This is why it was necessary for Scripture to say <i>a day or two</i>, the meaning thereof being that if on that day or on the following day the bondman will stand up on his feet, <i>he</i> [i.e., the master] <i>shall not be punished</i>. And the verse is to be understood as if it said: “notwithstanding, [if he stands up] <i>‘bayom’</i> or <i>‘bayomayim’</i> (<i>in</i> a day or <i>in</i> two) or <i>‘l’yom’</i> or <i>‘l’yomayim’</i> (<i>to</i> a day or <i>to</i> two).<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">The verse has it: <i>yom o yomayim</i> [literally: “a day or two”]. This fits in with the translation of <i>ya’amod</i> as “he continues,” thus: <i>if he continues</i> [living] <i>a day or two</i>. Ramban who interprets <i>ya’amod</i> in its literal sense — “he stands up” — therefore concludes that the sense of the verse is: “notwithstanding, if <i>he stands up in</i> a day or <i>in</i> two etc.” The opinion of the Rabbis mentioned further on will explain sufficiently why the Torah did write here <i>yom o yomayim</i>.</i> There are many such cases [where the prefix <i>beth</i> or <i>lamed</i> is missing as it is assumed in the meaning of the word]. Thus, at first He had said, <i>and he die under his hand</i>, which might be taken to have meant that the bondman died immediately at the time he struck him; therefore He referred back and explained that if on the day he struck him he stood up on his feet, or even if he could not stand at all on that day, but did so on the next day, the master is free from punishment. But if he did not stand up at all, the master is liable to punishment, even though the bondman only died on the second day, for that too is considered as if he died <i>under his hand</i>. It did not mention a case where he stood up on the third day, for if the bondman lived three days, the master is free from the death penalty, since this is no longer considered a case of <i>he die under his hand</i>.<br>In the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> Scripture mentioned <i>yom o yomayim</i> [“a day or two,” and not <i>bayom o bayomayim</i>, “in a day or in two”], in order to teach us that [for the master to go free] the bondman must have survived twenty-four hours, and the meaning of the expression used is: “<i>a</i> complete <i>day</i> [consisting, as it does, of twenty-four hours]; <i>or two days</i>, neither of which consists of a complete day, [but instead the period of twenty-four hours is made up of the parts of two separate days].” Had it said just “a day,” the bondman would have had to continue living for a night first and then the following day, as is the “day” of the Torah mentioned at the creation<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And there was evening and there was morning, one day</i> (Genesis 1:5).</i> and in connection with the Sabbaths and festivals; [but now that it said, <i>a day or two</i> it means any period of twenty-four hours, as explained above]. The word <i>ya’amod</i> [in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis] then means that “he continues to live.” Similarly, <i>that they may ‘ya’amdu’ many days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 32:14.</i> means “continue to exist.” And this is the correct and true interpretation of the verse.

Verse 21



Verse 22

AND IF MEN STRIVE TOGETHER, AND HURT A WOMAN WITH CHILD, SO THAT HER FRUIT DEPART, AND YET NO HARM FOLLOW, HE SHALL BE SURELY FINED, ‘KA’ASHER’ THE WOMAN’S HUSBAND SHALL LAY UPON HIM. “This means: ‘when’<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi is thus explaining the letter <i>kaf</i> in the word <i>ka’asher</i> not in the sense of “as,” indicating degree or extent (“according as”), but in the sense of “when” — when the woman’s husband takes him to court.</i> the husband will summon him before the court in order that they put a fine on him for it.” Thus far Rashi’s language. And it is correct [to interpret here the letter <i>kaf</i> in the word <i>ka’asher</i> as meaning “when”, and not “as”]. A similar case is the expression, <i>‘ka’asher’ (when) it shall be well with thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 40:14.</i> and there are many other such cases. And the intention of the verse is that the assailant has to pay compensation for the miscarriage when the husband takes him to court, not when the woman does so, as the compensation is not hers. Onkelos, however, translated: “according to the amount [that the woman’s husband] shall lay upon him.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the verse as follows: <i>according as the woman’s husband shall lay upon him</i>, or<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word <i>v’nathan</i>, which is generally translated <i>“and he shall pay”</i> — <i>as the judges determine</i>, Ibn Ezra interprets to mean “<i>or</i> he shall pay,” and the purport thereof is as explained in the text.</i> <i>he shall pay as the judges determine</i>, as if to say that the assailant should come to agreement with the husband on a fixed sum, or he should pay compensation as the court will assess him. This is not correct, for what reason is there to mention this?<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">For surely if the parties voluntarily agree on a sum there is no necessity for them to go to court, and if they fail to agree on a sum it is self-understood that the court will have to assess the fine.</i><br>In my opinion, since the damage done is one that is not discernible in the unborn children themselves — for who could know their fortune — therefore Scripture said, that although he cannot be made to pay a precise monetary compensation, he should nonetheless be fined as a sort of penalty in the form of a sum of money<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary p. 424 for further elucidation of this phrase of Ramban “a sort of penalty.”</i> which others [i.e., the judges] shall impose upon him. A similar usage [of the term <i>onesh</i> — punishment] is also found in these verses: <i>and he put the land to ‘onesh’ (a fine);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 23:33.</i> <i>they drink the wine of them that have been ‘anushim’ (fined)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 2:8.</i> Scripture is thus stating that the punishment be entirely <i>as the woman’s husband shall lay upon him</i>, because he desires his children and they are important to him, but he [i.e., the husband] should fix the sum through the judges, in order that he should not impose upon him an exorbitant sum. In the words of the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i>, “<i>According as the woman’s husband shall lay upon him</i>. I might think this to mean, whatever he pleases; Scripture therefore says, <i>and he shall pay as the ‘pelilim’ determine</i>, and <i>pelilim</i> always means judges.”

Verse 23



Verse 24

EYE ‘TACHATH’ (FOR) EYE. It is known in the tradition of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> that this means monetary compensation. Such usage [of the term <i>tachath</i> to indicate] monetary compensation is found in the verse: <i>And he that smiteth a beast mortally shall pay for it; life ‘tachath’ life</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:18.</i> [in which case <i>tachath</i> surely indicates monetary compensation]. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that Scripture uses such a term to indicate that he really is deserving of such a punishment, [that his eye be taken from him], if he does not give his ransom. For Scripture has forbidden us to take <i>ransom for the life of a murderer, that is guilty of death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:31.</i> but we may take ransom from a wicked person who cut off any of the limbs of another person. Therefore we are never to cut off that limb from him, but rather he is to pay monetary compensation, and if he has no money to pay, it lies as a debt on him until he acquires the means to pay, and then he is redeemed.<br>Proof for what the Sages have said [that <i>eye ‘tachath’ eye</i> means he pays him the value of his eye], is in what He has said above [with reference to one who injures another person], <i>only he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 19.</i> But if we were to do to the assailant exactly as he has done to the injured man, why does he have to pay after that? He himself is in need of amends for the loss of his own time and costs of his own healing! And it would not be valid to argue that the assailant is to give the injured man [the difference in cost between a slow recovery and] a fast recovery,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Thus, if the assailant had a fast recovery and the injured man a slower recovery, the assailant is to pay him the difference of expenses incurred in the loss of time and costs of healing. In that case, one could still argue that <i>eye ‘tachath’ eye</i> really means that the eye of the assailant be removed, and Verse 19 that deals with his obligation to pay for the loss of time and cost of healing of the injured, applies to that difference as explained above. — This argument is actually mentioned in the Talmud (Baba Kamma 84a.). But, argues Ramban, it is not the plain meaning of Scripture, for the simple meaning of Verse 19 is that it speaks of the assailant having to pay for the <i>whole</i> loss of time and costs of healing. Therefore it constitutes a proof that <i>eye ‘tachath’ eye</i> means monetary compensation, as explained above.</i> since this is not the plain meaning of Scripture. Rather, Scripture speaks of all people, and even if his recovery [i.e., the assailant’s] were to be fast, we would have long taken our punishment of him, in doing to him exactly as he did!<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">And why should he be burdened with the additional cost representing the difference in the recoveries [as explained above], after we have already taken our punishment of him by doing to him as he had done to others? Thus it is obvious that Verse 19 speaks of all men alike, and <i>eye ‘tachath’ eye</i> cannot be meant literally, but means the monetary value of the eye.</i><br>If we explain the verses according to the literal interpretation of Scripture, there is no escape from this question,<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., an apparent difficulty in the verses [if we interpret them in their plain meaning]: that in one verse it says <i>eye for an eye</i>, and in the other it speaks of the assailant’s duty to pay for <i>the loss of his time and costs of healing</i>, and the question appears why he should pay this additional payment when we have already punished him. There is no escape from this question except by saying that etc. [see text]. Ramban will finally allude to why he mentions all this: it is to show what sophistry we have to display if we seek to follow only the plain meaning of Scripture! We thus have no recourse but to Tradition.</i> unless they<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “those who pursue the plain meaning of Scripture” (the <i>rodfei ha’pshat</i>). See Vol. I, p. 154.</i> will say that if someone maims his neighbor so that he deprives him permanently of some bodily member, such as an eye, hand, or foot, or causes a burn which leaves a permanent mark, then we are to do likewise to the assailant’s body, this being the case of the verse which says, <i>As he hath caused a blemish in a man, so shall it be done to him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:20.</i> and in that case there is no monetary compensation paid for loss of time and cost of healing. But if he hits him with a stone or with his fist on his clothes, and he is laid up in bed but then is completely healed without any crippling effect remaining upon his body, in that case He said, <i>only he shall pay for the loss of his time, and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 19.</i> All the injuries specified in the verse, <i>burning for burning, wound for wound, stripe for stripe</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> are included, according to the plain meaning of Scripture, in this preceding general principle, for a wound and stripe may be completely healed. And as for that which Scripture states there, <i>And if a man cause a blemish in his neighbor, as he hath done so shall it be done to him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:19.</i> it too was meant to include all injuries, but He did not mention there at length the cases of wounding, striping, and burning [as He did here]. He used the term <i>mum</i> (blemish), for every wound causes at least a temporary blemish. Thus even if it is of the kind which heals, it is still called “a blemish,” just as we say: “a passing blemish,”<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Bechoroth 37b.</i> and the Torah calls <i>scabbed, or scurvy, or hath his stones crushed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 21:20.</i> “a blemish” although they are temporary and can be healed,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 425.</i> and it is further written, <i>youths in whom there was no blemish</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 1:3. The intention there is obviously that these youths who were to serve in the king’s palace were free even of any passing blemish.</i> The general principle everywhere is that the Tradition is always true.<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 157.</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND ITS OWNER SHALL BE PUT TO DEATH. Our Rabbis have received by Tradition<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> that this death means by the hand of Heaven. Similar cases are these verses: <i>and the common man that draweth nigh shall be put to death;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7. Punishment for a non-priest who performs the Divine service in the Sanctuary is death by the hand of Heaven (Sanhedrin 83 a).</i> <i>and they die therein, if they profane it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:9. This is with reference to an unclean priest who ate clean heave-offering [which is forbidden to him as long as he remains in his state of uncleanness], and the punishment is death by the hand of Heaven (Sanhedrin 83 a).</i><br>I have noticed that where the Torah speaks of those liable to be put to death by the court, it does not mention just <i>yumoth</i> (he shall be put to death), but always says, <i>moth yumoth</i> (he shall surely be put to death). Do not object to this rule from the verse, <i>and he that killeth a man ‘yumoth’ (shall be put to death)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:21. In this case his punishment is death by the court, and yet it says only <i>yumoth</i>!</i> or from the verse about the Sabbath,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Of the Sabbath it is said, <i>Whosoever doeth any work therein ‘yumoth’ (shall be put to death)</i> (further 35:2), and his punishment is death by the court!</i> or a prophet who misleads,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And that prophet… ‘yumoth’ (shall be put to death)</i> (Deuteronomy 13:6), and there too his punishment is by the court (Sanhedrin 84 a).</i> for in each of these cases He has already clearly explained elsewhere about them [that they are liable to death by the court, by using the phrase: <i>moth yumoth</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">In the case of smiting a man — see above Verse 12; for the Sabbath, see further, 31:14. For a prophet who misleads, see Deuteronomy 13:10: <i>ki harog tahargenu (for thou shall surely kill him)</i>.</i><br>Now I do not know the reason for Onkelos’ rendering <i>yumoth</i> as <i>yithk’teil</i> [“he shall be killed”, which indicates that his death is to be by the court, instead of by the hand of Heaven]. Perhaps his intention is to state that the owner, [who had been previously warned that his ox had gored three times, but still did not guard it, so that it went out and killed a man or woman], deserves to be put to death, but is instead made liable to the payment of a ransom. Or perhaps Onkelos means to explain that that which Scripture states, <i>and its owner also shall be put to death</i> means that the owner will perish in a similar manner to that by which the gored person was killed, for <i>his day shall come to die, or he shall go down into battle, and be swept away;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:10.</i> <i>the Eternal will not hold him guiltless</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:7.</i> Thus Onkelos wanted to teach us that the owner of the ox is liable, according to the view of Heaven, to die by the hand of a killer, and not by a natural death, something like it is said, <i>and I will kill you with the sword</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 22:23.</i> In the verse, <i>and the common man that draweth nigh shall be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:7. Punishment for a non-priest who performs the Divine service in the Sanctuary is death by the hand of Heaven (Sanhedrin 83 a).</i> Onkelos also translated <i>yumoth as yithk’teil</i> [“he shall be killed,” indicating that his death is to be by the court], because he agrees with the opinion of Rabbi Akiba who said that a non-priest who performed the Divine service in the Sanctuary is put to death by strangulation.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 84a. The Sages, however, are of the opinion that his death is by the hand of Heaven.</i>

Verse 30

IF THERE BE LAID ON HIM A RANSOM, THEN HE SHALL GIVE FOR THE REDEMPTION OF HIS LIFE WHATSOEVER IS LAID UPON HIM. Since the redemption is a form of atonement<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">“An atonement for the owner whose ox killed a man” (Rashi Makkoth 2 b).</i> as are the offerings, and if the owner does not desire it we cannot force him to come before the court to impose the ransom on him, and even if the court ordered him to pay it, we cannot seize his goods as security, therefore He said: “if.”

Verse 31

O’ (OR) HE HAVE GORED A SON, OR HAVE GORED A DAUGHTER ACCORDING TO THIS JUDGMENT SHALL IT BE DONE UNTO HIM. Scripture uses the word <i>o (‘or’ he have gored a son)</i>, because it adds to a phrase mentioned above, the meaning of the whole phrase thus being: “<i>and he hath put to death a man or a woman</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 29.</i> <i>or he have gored a son, or have gored a daughter</i>, one ordinance shall be for them.” Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi in Leviticus 4:23, and R’dak in Sefer Hashorashim, root <i>o.</i></i> say that the word <i>o</i> comes in the place of <i>im</i> (if). Similarly: <i>‘o’ (if) it be the carcass of an unclean beast;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 5:2.</i> <i>‘o’ (if) I had dealt falsely against mine own life;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 18:13.</i> <i>‘o’ (if) it be known that the ox was wont to gore</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 36.</i> There are many such cases, in the opinion of these scholars.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi in Leviticus 4:23, and R’dak in Sefer Hashorashim, root <i>o.</i></i> But all these proofs are false witnesses; you will understand them all in their context.<br>According to our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 44a.</i> Scripture had to detail the ordinance [in the case of an ox goring] minors, because it found it necessary to say above, <i>And if an ox gore a man or a woman</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> — in order to teach us that in all laws of the Torah concerning damages G-d has treated woman equally to man — thus I might have thought that one is only liable in the case of a grown man or woman; therefore Scripture says, <i>or he have gored a son</i>, to make him liable for the death of minors as for that of adults. The same method was followed by Scripture in the verse, <i>And he that smiteth any man mortally shall surely be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:17.</i> as Rashi explained there.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">“Because it is said, <i>He that smiteth a man, so that he dieth, shall surely be put to death</i> (above Verse 12), I know only about a man. How do I know that the same applies to a woman and to a minor? Scripture therefore says, <i>kol nefesh adam (and he that smiteth ‘any man’</i>) — [literally: ‘the soul of any human being’]” (Rashi, Leviticus 24:17).</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, [the ordinance concerning an ox goring minors is stated] because an ox that kills a grown-up person is extremely vicious, <i>as a bear robbed of her cubs</i><sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 17:8.</i> in the wilderness, thus <i>if warning hath been given to its owner, and he hath not kept it in</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 29.</i> he has committed a grave transgression, and deserves to be liable to death or to pay a ransom [for the redemption of his life]; but an ox that kills minors is not so vicious, for most oxen are not afraid of them, and one might therefore think that their owners are not liable [to the same punishment], therefore Scripture states that <i>according to this judgment shall it be done unto him</i>.

Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34

AND THE DEAD BEAST SHALL BELONG TO HIM — “to the one who suffered the damage. We make an estimation of the value of the carcass and he takes it in part payment and the one who caused the damage, [the owner of the pit], pays him in addition as much as makes up the value of his damage.” This is Rashi’s language. But he did not explain the law sufficiently. For there is no need for Scripture to tell us concerning this carcass that the one who suffered the damage must take it in part payment, when he brings it before the court to collect his damage; for even if the one who caused the damage had other carcasses that were carrion, or flesh that was <i>treifah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Any animal suffering from a serious organic disease, whose meat is forbidden even if ritually slaughtered.</i> in his possession, he can give it to him in part payment, it being already established<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 7a.</i> that restitution for damages need not be in money, but may “include anything of value, even bran.” Rather, the meaning of the verse is to state that the carcass belongs to the one who suffered the damage and is considered his property; therefore if its value decreased after the damage was caused, or it was stolen, the one who caused the damage, [the owner of the pit], pays only the loss in value caused by the death of the animal. Thus if the ox that was killed was worth when alive one hundred <i>zuzim</i>, and upon its death became worth fifty, the one who caused the damage is liable to pay only fifty <i>zuzim</i>, and the other attends to his carcass [removing it from the pit], and keeps it for himself.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">He may use its hide for leather, and its flesh to feed the animals, or he may sell it for such uses.</i> This law applies to all damages, and it is what the Sages call: “the loss in the carcass’ value,” and is explained in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34a. [See in my translation of Hameniach, Shulsinger Bros., New York, 5729, p. 65.]</i>

Verse 35



Verse 36

OR IF IT BE KNOWN THAT THE OX WAS WONT TO GORE IN TIME PAST, AND ITS OWNER HATH NOT KEPT IT IN, HE SHALL SURELY PAY AN OX FOR AN OX. It is known that if a <i>Tam</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>Tam</i> is an animal which has not injured, or killed [an animal] more than three times and whose owner has not been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damages a <i>Tam</i> does, its owner pays only half the loss. The <i>Tam</i> is distinguished from a <i>Muad</i>, an animal which has killed or injured at least four times, and whose owner has been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damage it does, the owner must pay in full.</i> too is properly guarded by its owner, but through an accident it so happened that it went out and caused damage, the owner is certainly not liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">But if so, the question arises why the Torah mentions the guarding of the animal only in the case of the <i>Muad</i>, (see Note above) since the same law applies to a Tam as well. Ramban proceeds to remove this difficulty.</i> Thus the reason why He states only with reference to a <i>Muad</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>Tam</i> is an animal which has not injured, or killed [an animal] more than three times and whose owner has not been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damages a <i>Tam</i> does, its owner pays only half the loss. The <i>Tam</i> is distinguished from a <i>Muad</i>, an animal which has killed or injured at least four times, and whose owner has been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damage it does, the owner must pay in full.</i> <i>and its owner hath not kept it in</i>, [when the same principle would apply to a <i>Tam</i> as well] is, according to that Sage in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 45b. See in my Hebrew commentary p. 426, that the reference is to Rabbi Meir.</i> who says that a <i>Muad</i> needs better guarding than a <i>Tam</i>, as follows: Scripture states that <i>if the ox was wont to gore</i> and warning had been given to its owner, <i>and he hath not kept it in</i> and guarded it better in view of its dangerous nature, so that it went out and caused damage, the owner must pay the full damage. According to the opinion of that Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov (<i>ibid.</i>).</i> who holds that the degree of guarding necessary for both <i>Tam</i> and <i>Muad</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>Tam</i> is an animal which has not injured, or killed [an animal] more than three times and whose owner has not been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damages a <i>Tam</i> does, its owner pays only half the loss. The <i>Tam</i> is distinguished from a <i>Muad</i>, an animal which has killed or injured at least four times, and whose owner has been warned that it is dangerous and must be guarded. For whatever damage it does, the owner must pay in full.</i> is alike, the meaning of the verse is as follows: If it be known to the owner <i>that the ox was wont to gore</i> and now too [i.e., at the fourth time] <i>he hath not kept it in</i>, he is liable to pay the full damage on account of his grave negligence.
AND THE DEAD BEAST SHALL BELONG TO HIM — “to the one who suffered the damage, and the one who caused the damage adds to it until he completes the amount, so that the one who was damaged will have been paid for his entire loss.” This is Rashi’s language, and is in accordance with the teaching of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10b.</i> And if so, it is proper that we explain the verse as follows: <i>he shall surely pay ox for ox</i> “with” <i>the dead beast</i> which <i>shall, belong to him</i>. Similarly, <i>and Joseph was in Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:5.</i> means: “with” Joseph who was in Egypt [they were seventy souls]. Likewise, <i>I cannot endure iniquity ‘va’atzarah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:13.</i> [literally: “and the solemn assembly”] means <i>with the solemn assembly</i>, similar to that which He said, <i>I hate robbery ‘b’olah’ — “with” a burnt-offering</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 61:8.</i><br>According to the simple meaning of Scripture it is possible to explain the expression, <i>and the dead shall belong to him</i> — to the one who caused the damage, the verse thus stating: <i>he shall surely pay ox for ox</i>, but he may keep the carcass, so that in making monetary compensation he can turn it over to the one who suffered the damage as part payment. Thus according to both interpretations the law is alike — the owner of the dead animal attends to the carcass, and its value is determined as at the time of its death,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">If its value decreases after the time of its death, he must bear that loss alone (Baba Kamma 34 b).</i> to be taken by him as part payment, according to the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">If its value decreases after the time of its death, he must bear that loss alone (Baba Kamma 34 b).</i>

Chapter 22



Verse 1



Verse 2

IF THE SUN HAS RISEN UPON HIM.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">The verses read: 1. <i>If a thief be found breaking in, and be smitten so that he dieth ‘ein lo damim’ (there shall be no guilt of blood incurred for him)</i>. 2. <i>If the sun be risen upon him ‘damim lo’ (there shall be guilt of blood incurred for him). He shall make restitution; if he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft</i>.</i> “This is nothing but a metaphorical expression, [for did the sun rise upon him alone? Does it not rise upon the whole world? It means etc.]<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew text shortens here Rashi’s interpretation, since Ramban’s intention here is not to comment on Rashi’s own explanation, but upon Rashi’s understanding of Onkelos.</i> But Onkelos who rendered the phrase <i>if the sun has risen upon him</i> as: ‘if the eye of the witnesses fell upon him’ chose a different way of interpreting the verse, which is as follows: if the witnesses found the thief before the householder came, and when the householder came to resist the thief, they warned him not to kill the thief, then <i>damim lo</i>, he is liable if he killed him, for since there were witnesses watching him, the thief had no thought of taking human life, and he would not have killed the householder.” Thus is Rashi’s language.<br>But I wonder! When He said above [in Verse 1], <i>there shall be no guilt of blood incurred for him</i>, thereby acquitting the householder for the murder of the thief, it must surely be speaking of a case where the witnesses warned him not to kill him, for no murderer is ever liable to death without prior warning. And if you say then that in stating: <i>there shall be no guilt of blood incurred for him</i>, Heaven permitted the thief’s blood to be shed, that is to say, it is permissible to kill him — that is not true!<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., such an interpretation cannot be the true meaning of <i>this</i> particular verse. For while the law itself is true [that the owner is permitted to kill him], but here the verse speaks of a case where he has already killed him! So how can you say that the intent of the verse is to give him permission to kill him, when he has already killed him! Moreover, since <i>damim lo</i> [in Verse 2] declares the householder culpable both by the court and at the hand of Heaven, then <i>ein lo damim</i> [in the preceeding verse, stating the opposite case], must as a counterpart free him from both, and the way Rashi interpreted Onkelos <i>ein lo damim</i> frees him only from punishment at the hand of Heaven! In other words, Verse 2 must be a case where there were witnesses, as is indicated by the phrase <i>if the sun be risen upon him</i>, as Rashi understands Onkelos. In contrast Verse 1 speaks of a case where there were <i>no</i> witnesses, and hence it cannot refer at all to freeing him from the death by the court, for the court can never act anyway without witnesses; but instead it refers only to freeing him from death by the hand of Heaven. But in that case, the <i>ein lo damim</i> [of Verse 1] and <i>damim lo</i> [of Verse 2] are <i>not</i> in exact contrast: <i>ein lo damim</i> frees him only from punishment by Heaven, and <i>damim lo</i> holds him guilty in both! (Mizrachi). Rather etc.</i> Rather, the first verse acquits the householder under all circumstances from the hand of Heaven, [where he had no prior warning], and from the court if he had prior warning, and the second verse [dealing as it does with another set of circumstances], holds him guilty by the law of both. Perhaps the Rabbi’s intention [i.e., Rashi’s intention in interpreting Onkelos’ translation], was to say that if the witnesses found the thief before the householder came, and recognized him, and the thief knew of their presence, then the thief no longer could have intended to take human life, since he saw that the witnesses recognized him and knew that if he would kill, the witnesses would come to court and have him put to death. And this is the reason for the expression, <i>if the sun has risen upon him</i>, for at night, seeing that the witnesses did not recognize him, he would kill the householder and escape.<br>In my opinion Onkelos intended to say that if the thief has left the break-through, and the householder comes to court to say that he has witnesses that he was found breaking through, <i>damim lo</i> [literally: “he has blood”] as other living people do, and it is not permissible to kill him, and if the householder did kill him, he is to be put to death; but the thief is to pay if he took anything from there. Scripture uses the expression, <i>if the sun be risen upon him</i> because it speaks of the usual manner, for those who break into homes generally do so at night when no one recognizes them, and the one who kills them there is free and may do so with impunity. But if the thief stayed there until the sun had risen upon him, and then left in a stealthy manner and ran for his life, then if the householder comes to bring a charge against him with the help of witnesses, he [i.e., the thief] is not liable to death, neither by the hands of the court nor by the householder. If this is so, then — according to the opinion of the Sage who says<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">The opinion is that of Rav (Sanhedrin 72 a).</i> that a thief who broke into a house and took some of its vessels and went out, is free from paying for them, because he acquired them with “blood”<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Had he been found by the householder while still in the house and he were killed by him, the householder would be free from punishment.</i> — we must say that the second half of the verse which states, <i>he shall make restitution; if he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft</i>, refers back to a previous verse [i.e., Verse 37 in the preceeding chapter]: <i>if a man steal an ox</i> etc. A similar case is the verse, <i>And also unto thy bondwoman thou shalt do likewise</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:17. This is to be connected with Verse 14 there, which states that the master must present gifts to a manservant who goes out free, and here it states that the same must also be done to a maidservant. But it does not refer to the first half of that verse [17] which speaks of the piercing of the ear of a manservant, since that law does not apply to a woman.</i><br>The plain meaning of the verse is known to be as follows: If a thief dug through into a home at dark, and was found there at night, he may be killed; but if the sun shone upon the thief and someone saw him and recognized him, he may not be killed, but he must pay for what he stole and took from there at daytime. The meaning of the term <i>hashemesh</i> (the sun) is “in the sight of those who saw him.” Similarly, <i>in the sight of this sun</i><sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 12:11.</i> means “openly.” The reason for this law is as we have mentioned, that one who comes at night will kill the householder, [and therefore the householder may kill him], whilst one who comes at daytime will flee from him [once he is recognized].

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

IF A MAN DELIVER UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR MONEY OR VESSELS TO KEEP. This section [Verses 6-8] speaks of an unpaid guardian, therefore He has freed him from payment in case the money or vessels are lost or stolen, as is the Tradition of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 94b.</i> Scripture mentioned it without specifying what the case is because those who guard money or vessels generally do so without reward. The second section [Verses 9-12] speaking of a paid guardian mentions <i>an ass, or an ox, or a sheep, or any beast</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> because it is the customary way to give over cattle into the hands of shepherds who pasture them for payment.
AND IT BE STOLEN OUT OF THE MAN’S HOUSE. Rashi explained it as meaning that it was <i>stolen out of the man’s house</i> “according to his statement,” meaning that this is what the unpaid guardian claims.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">It cannot mean that it was <i>admittedly</i> stolen, for then how could Scripture say in the next verse that if the thief was not found, the guardian must swear, since it is admitted that it was stolen from him? Hence the verse must mean that he claims it was stolen.</i> Scholars have brought parallel cases in Scripture [as proof to Rashi’s explanation]. Thus: <i>If there arise in the midst of thee a prophet;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:2. The case there speaks of a false prophet. The term “prophet” must therefore be understood as “one who claims to be a prophet.”</i> <i>Hananiah the son of Azzur the prophet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 28:1. [The reasoning is as in the previous Note.]</i> for he is not referred to by that epithet [“prophet”] as a true description, but only because he claimed to be so. But there is no need for this. For Scripture is stating that if it was really stolen out of the man’s house and <i>the thief be found, he shall pay double;</i> and <i>if the thief be not found</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> they shall come to court and the guardian shall swear concerning the stolen article <i>whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> and <i>he whom the court condemns</i> as the thief of this article <i>shall pay double</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> as the court will not convict anyone and make him pay double unless he stole it, since the law of twofold restitution applies only to a thief, as He said above, <i>If the theft be found in his hand alive… he shall pay double</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i>

Verse 7

WHETHER HE HAVE NOT PUT HIS HAND UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR’S GOODS. In the opinion of Rashi this means that the guardian is to come before the judges to swear that he has not put his hand to his fellow-man’s goods [i.e., that he is not guilty of embezzlement]. The correct interpretation is that he is to come before the judges to swear that it was stolen and thus substantiate his claim, but he can only swear thus if he did not <i>put his hand</i> to make use of <i>his neighbor’s</i> goods, for he who puts to his own use what had been left in his keeping is answerable for it as if he were a robber, and is liable to make restitution even if it was lost through an unavoidable accident.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 41a.</i>

Verse 8

WHEREOF ONE SAITH: ‘THIS IS IT.’ Rashi comments: “according to the literal sense it means: that which the witness will say ‘<i>this is it</i> — this is that article about which you have taken an oath [that it was stolen from you] but see, it is in your possession!’ And our Rabbis have explained that the phrase <i>this is it</i> teaches us that an oath cannot be imposed [by the court on a defendant] unless he admits part of the claim, saying ‘I owe you so and so much, but the rest was stolen from me.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">But if he denied the claim altogether, he is free from having to take an oath of the Torah. The Rabbis, however, instituted a consuetude oath in such cases (Shebuoth 40 b).</i><br>But this principle of partial admission which the Rabbi [Rashi] has written here, is in accordance with the opinion of certain individual Rabbis [in the Talmud],<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Chiya bar Aba in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, and Rami bar Chama (Baba Kamma 106-107 a).</i> but is not the accepted decision of the law, for guardians [to incur liability to an oath] need not partially deny and partially admit the claim,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, while the principle of partial admission applies to claims of debts, in the case of claims in guardianship, the accepted decision of the law is that the guardians need not partially admit the claim in order to be liable an oath of the Torah. The above interpretation of Rashi agrees therefore only with the opinion of certain individual Rabbis, but is not the accepted opinion.</i> but even if they claim that the whole article was stolen, they still have to take the oath of the guardians, [unlike debts, which, if the debtor denies completely, do not require an oath of the Torah]. Moreover, it has been explained in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 107a.</i> with convincing proofs, that when he denies the very fact that he ever became a guardian, such as where he says “you have never given me the object to keep,” in that case if he denied it totally, he is free from taking an oath, and if he admitted it partially he is obliged to take an oath, this being the opinion of all Rabbis in the Talmud,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is here making an important distinction [in accordance with the teaching of the masters of the Tosafoth — see my Hebrew commentary, p. 430]: If the guardian sets up the kind of defense which can apply to cases of guardianship, such as where he says “an unavoidable accident happened to it” [such a defense has no place naturally where one is sued for a plain debt], then there is no distinction between total and partial admission — he is liable to an oath in either case. But where he puts up the kind of defense which can apply also to a debt, such as where he says, “You have never given me the object to keep” [which can apply to a debt as well: “You have never lent me”], then the law of partial admission applies to a guardian as well as to a debtor: if he denies it totally he is free of an oath, and if he admits it partially he is subject to an oath. — A re-reading of Ramban’s words [“Moreover, etc.”] will yield this thought clearly.</i> even though the Rabbi [Rashi] has not written so in his commentaries to the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 107a.</i> If so, we may say that the phrase [<i>this is it</i> — from which we derive the principle of partial admission, as explained above], speaks according to the interpretation of the Sages of a case where the guardian’s defense is: “He never gave me anything to keep,” in which case if he denied it totally he is free of an oath, and if he partially admitted it and partially denied it, he is liable to take an oath.<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Such as where the claimant said, “I gave you two vessels to keep,” and he replies, “You gave me one to keep, but the other you never gave to me.” Had the defendant claimed so on both vessels, he would be free of an oath of the Torah. However, if his defense had been that an unavoidable accident happened, even if he claimed so on both of them, he would have had to swear [see preceding Note].</i> Thus the verses are to be explained as follows: <i>If the thief be not found, then the master of the house shall come near unto the judges</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> — <i>for every</i> claim <i>of trespass</i> which he may claim against him, such as: “You were negligent in your guarding it,” or where the guardian says: “<i>this is it</i>, — this is what you have deposited with me, and you did not deposit any more with me” — then the one with whom the article was deposited <i>that the judges will condemn</i>, [upon testimony given before them that he embezzled it], <i>shall pay double unto his neighbor</i>. Thus, both [the debtor and the guardian] pay, but double restitution is only where the guardian claims falsely that it was stolen, and the rule concerning the plea of partial admission applies to all claims, even to loans, robbery and other matters. In all these laws the verses of Scripture are few and the rules many. But there is no need to explain them here, except in order to interpret the verses.

Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

IF IT BE TORN IN PIECES — “by a wild beast. ‘Y’VIEIHU EID’ — let him bring witnesses that it has been torn in pieces by accident, and then he will be free from paying.” This is the language of Rashi.<br>But one may wonder. Why did Scripture mention specifically here [in the case of the animal being torn to pieces by a wild beast], the necessity of having witnesses, since in this [very same section of the law of the paid guardian] it has already said above, [in the cases where the animal dies, or is hurt, or captured], <i>The oath of the Eternal shall be between them both</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> [i.e., between the owner of the animal and the guardian], and the law in all cases is alike: if there are witnesses that the animal died, or was hurt, or captured, he is free from paying and so also if it was torn in pieces by a wild beast, and if there are no witnesses he must take an oath in all cases, and if he does so, he does not pay? Perhaps Scripture speaks of the customary manner, for when an animal dies in <i>his master’s crib</i><sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 1:3.</i> or it goes up to the top of a crag and is hurt, <i>there is</i> usually <i>no man seeing it;</i> so also if it was captured by armed bandits who came upon it and took it from the flock and went away [there are usually no witnesses].
