But when a lion or bear attacks, <i>a multitude of shepherds is called forth against it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:4.</i> and therefore Scripture says that he should bring the shepherds to court, and [upon their testimony] he will be freed from the liability of payment.<br>Or we may explain that Scripture intends to establish the law enunciated by Isi ben Yehudah,<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 83a.</i> who says, “<i>No-one seeing it</i> — he is free [from payment but he must swear]; but if there are witnesses who could testify in this matter, let him bring the witnesses and only then will he be free.” And the explanation thereof is as follows: If the accident happened [to the animal entrusted to his guardianship] in a place where people are present the whole day, we do not rely upon his oath but instead he must bring witnesses, and where an animal is torn in pieces by a wild beast, it is generally the case [that other people are present besides the guardian], and therefore Scripture required him to bring witnesses.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: <i>y’vieihu eid</i> — “let him bring part of the torn animal as witness, <i>two legs, or a piece of an ear</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 3:12.</i> in proof of his statement.” And I have seen it explained thus in the Mechilta of Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai:<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">In Hoffman’s edition of that Mechilta, p. 147. — See Vol. 1. p. 603, Note 245.</i> “Aba Shaul said, he should bring the carcass, as it is said, <i>Thus saith the Eternal, as the shepherd rescueth out of the mouth of the lion, two legs</i> etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 3:12.</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND IF A MAN ‘Y’FATEH’ — “speaks to her emotions [until she submits to him]. And so did Onkelos render it <i>arei y’shadeil</i>, the term <i>shidul</i> in Aramaic being like <i>pitui</i> [persuasion, seduction], in the Sacred Language. ‘MAHOR YIMHARENAH’ (HE SHALL SURELY PAY A DOWRY FOR HER) TO BE HIS WIFE — he shall assign her a marriage portion as is the manner of a man to his wife by writing her a <i>kethubah</i> (marriage contract), and he shall marry her.” Thus far is Rashi’s language.<br>But this is not correct, for the term <i>pitui</i> [does not mean “speaking to her feelings,” as Rashi put it], but winning over another person’s will by falsehood. A similar usage of the term is found in these verses: <i>‘yifteh l’vavchem’ (your heart will be deceived);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:16.</i> <i>‘vayift’ (and he seduced) my heart secretly;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Job 31:27.</i> <i>if my heart ‘niftah’ (have been enticed) unto a woman</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9.</i> This is why people whose minds are not adroit in discriminating matters, and whose hearts can be easily bent by a few words at the beginning of a discussion, are called <i>p’ta’im</i> (simple-minded ones), just as it is said, <i>‘peti’ (the simple-minded) believeth every word</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 14:15.</i> and he who seduces a virgin in order to have sexual relations with her, bends her will to his desire by words of falsehood, and is therefore called <i>m’fateh</i> (seducer).<br>Onkelos, however, divided the term <i>pitui</i> into two meanings. Thus here he translated it: <i>y’shadeil</i>, which is an expression for cunning and effort that a person exercises towards another in order to do with him as he pleases, regardless of whether this effort is by means of words or deeds. Thus Onkelos translated: <i>‘vayei’aveik’ a man with him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 32:25. See Vol. 1, pp. 404-405 where Ramban discusses in brief the same theme as here.</i> — <i>v’ishtadeil</i> (and a man ‘wrestled craftily’ with him). And Yonathan ben Uziel<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. 1, p. 127 Note 152.</i> translated: <i>‘v’shovavticho’ (and I will turn thee about), and put hooks into thy jaws</i><sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 38:4.</i> — <i>‘v’ishtadlinoch.’</i> And in the Targum of the Scroll of Ruth we find: <i>Where hast thou gleaned to-day? ‘v’anah asit’ (and where wroughtest thou)?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 2:19. It is of interest to note that Ramban refers to “the Targum of the Scroll of Esther” instead of ascribing it as he had done in the preceding reference to the Targum on the Book of Ezekiel. This indicates that Ramban held them to be of different authorship. Such indeed is the prevailing opinion in modern scholarship (see P. Churgin, Targum Kethuvim, pp. 140-151).</i> — <i>‘u’lan ishtadalt l’me’bad’ (and where have you ‘endeavored’ to work)?</i> — <i>And she said: The man’s name with whom ‘asithi’ (I wrought) to-day is Boaz</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 2:19. It is of interest to note that Ramban refers to “the Targum of the Scroll of Esther” instead of ascribing it as he had done in the preceding reference to the Targum on the Book of Ezekiel. This indicates that Ramban held them to be of different authorship. Such indeed is the prevailing opinion in modern scholarship (see P. Churgin, Targum Kethuvim, pp. 140-151).</i> is translated in the Targum: <i>‘d’ishtadalith imei’</i> (with whom I ‘endeavored’). For all effort involving skill, with which a person attempts to achieve something, is called <i>hishtadluth</i> (endeavoring). Thus the Rabbis have said in the Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 2:5.</i> “And where there are no men, <i>hishtadeil</i> (strive) to be a man.” And in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 58a.</i> we find: “A man should always <i>yishtadeil</i> (strive) to go out to welcome kings of Israel.” And in Scripture it is written: <i>and he</i> [i.e., the king] <i>‘mishtadar’ (labored) to rescue him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 6:15.</i> — employing every skill [to save Daniel].<br>In my opinion, associated with this term [<i>hishtadluth</i> — striving] is the expression, <i>rebellion ‘v’eshtadur’ (and sedition) have been made therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 4:19.</i> meaning, rebellion and “much striving.” For even in the Sacred Language these letters [the <i>lamed</i> and the <i>reish</i> of <i>y’shadeil, y’shadeir</i>] interchange. Thus we find: <i>mazaloth</i> (constellations)<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 23:5.</i> and <i>mazaroth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Job 38:32.</i> <i>niml’tzu</i> (sweet),<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 119:103.</i> and <i>nimr’tzu</i> (forcible);<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Job 6:25.</i> <i>‘mifl’sei’ (the balancing of) the clouds</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 37:16.</i> and <i>‘mifr’sei’ (the spreadings of) the clouds</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:29.</i> Similarly in Aramaic: <i>va’alu</i> (and behold),<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 7:8.</i> and <i>va’aru</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7.</i> <i>Sharshereth</i> (chain)<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:14.</i> is termed by the Sages <i>shalsheleth</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Mikvaoth 10:5.</i> There are Mishnaic texts where it is written, “<i>hishtadeir</i> [instead of <i>hishtadeil</i> — both terms meaning ‘strive’] to be a man.”<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Aboth 2:5.</i> It is for this reason that Onkelos renders <i>ki y’fateh — arei y’shadeil</i> (he will endeavor); he will attempt by devious means to invest the virgin with a sense of trust in him, by many ruses, until she submits to him. And since seduction may be achieved in many ways — sometimes with words, sometimes with money, sometimes by falsehood to mislead her, and sometimes even by truth, as when he really wishes to marry her — therefore Onkelos did not use a precise term for it, but rendered it as an expression of “endeavor.” However, in the verse, <i>lest your heart be ‘yifteh,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 11:16.</i> he used the other meaning and translated it: <i>‘dilma yit’ei,’</i> for there it means, “perhaps you will be misled.”<br>And that which the Rabbi [Rashi] explained: “‘<i>Mahor yimharenah’ (he shall surely pay a dowry for her) to be his wife</i> — he shall assign her a marriage portion as is the manner of a man to his wife, by writing her a <i>kethubah</i> (marriage contract)” — this is not correct, for if the seducer marries her, he pays no penalty,<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16, and Kethuboth 39a.</i> and if he divorces her after the marriage, there is no monetary obligation upon him by law of the Torah, since a <i>kethubah</i> is a matter of Rabbinic ordinance. Rather, <i>mohar</i> means gifts — the gifts which a man sends to his betrothed, <i>jewels of silver and jewels of gold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:53.</i> and clothes for the wedding ceremony and marriage, these being called <i>sivlonoth</i> in the language of the Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 50a.</i> Thus they said: “<i>Mohari</i> go back [upon the death of the wife].”<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 145a. This applies to a case where the marriage was not consumated (Even Ha’ezer 50, 4).</i> And Onkelos rendered the verse, <i>And Shechem said… Multiply upon me greatly ‘mohar’ and gift</i><sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 34:12.</i> — “multiply upon me greatly <i>moharin</i> [in the plural] and gifts,” and Shechem would not have vowed to write Dinah many <i>kethuboth</i>. Instead, <i>mohar</i> means gifts, as I have explained. It is possible that the word is derived from the expression <i>‘m’heirah chushah’ (hasten, stay not)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:38.</i> because the <i>mohar</i> is the first thing which hastens the wedding, as the groom hurries and sends these presents ahead of him in eager haste and then he comes to his father-in-law’s house to make the wedding or the feast, just as the Sages have spoken of “parties of <i>sivlonoth</i>” (when presents are presented to the betrothed).<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 49a.</i> The meaning of <i>‘mahor yimharenah’ to be his wife</i> is then, that the seducer should send her presents and necessities for the wedding in order to become his wife. There is thus a hint here that both the seducer and the seduced can prevent the marriage, since Scripture uses such language rather than saying expressly that he should take her to him as his wife; for there is no commandment upon him to marry her unless he so desires, and if he does not want her to begin with, he is to pay fifty shekels of silver.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:29. As explained further on in Ramban, this fine [stated in the case of a violator] applies also to a seducer — if he or she refuses marriage.</i> After that Scripture states<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> that if the father <i>refuses to give her unto him, he shall pay</i> him <i>money according to the ‘mohar’</i> which men give <i>to virgins</i> whom they marry. The reason for this fine is that the seducer has spoiled her reputation in the eyes of young men, thus the father will have to give her many presents and they will not give her any dowry, therefore it is right that the seducer should pay it. Our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here in the verse, and Kethuboth 10a.</i> that the amount of this <i>mohar</i> was determined by Scripture in the case of the violator to be fifty shekels of silver,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:29.</i> the law of the violator and of the seducer being alike in this respect. Scripture, however, did differentiate between them in that in the case of the violator it says, <i>and she shall be his wife… he may not put her away all his days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:29.</i> the reason [for this distinction between the violator, who must marry the maiden whom he has raped, and is forbidden to divorce her ever, and the seducer, who does not have to marry the seduced girl, but may instead pay the penalty mentioned in the Torah], is that usually it is <i>handsome young men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 23:6.</i> who seduce virgins, and the beautiful daughters of prominent families, [in the hope of marrying them]. But since it is not proper that he should gain from his sin, [i.e., that the girl should have to marry the seducer], therefore He explained that he cannot marry her against their will [hers and that of her father], but instead must pay them. Also, because she too sinned in this matter, He did not impose it on him to have to marry her against his will, but instead it is enough if he pays the penalty [of the fifty shekels of silver], and if he marries her with her consent and that of her father, she has the same status in relation to him as all women, having no claim to a <i>kethubah</i> from him by law of the Torah [but only by Rabbinic ordinance]. Similarly, it is usually the sons of prominent families who rape the daughters of those less-known families who have no power against them. Therefore He said in the case of the violator, <i>and she shall be his wife</i><sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:29.</i> — against his will. And in the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 39b.</i> there too [in the case of the violator] the maiden and her father can withhold consent, as it would not be correct that he should marry her against her will, and thus do her two evils. Sometimes she may be of a more honorable family than he, and it is inconceivable that she should be further disgraced by his sinful act. The fair law is thus that the decision as to the marriage of the raped maiden be left to her discretion and that of her father, and not to the violator; instead, [if she desires it] he must marry her against his will,<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">“Even if she be lame, even if she be blind, and even if she is afflicted with boils” (<i>ibid.</i>, 39 a).</i> in order that violent men should not take liberties with the daughters of Israel.<br>Now this law of seduction only applies to a <i>na’arah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>na’arah</i> is a maiden between the age of twelve years and a day and twelve and a half. After that she counts as a <i>bogereth</i> — past her maidenhood. The period of <i>yalduth</i> (childhood) is from three years and a day to twelve years and a day.</i> as does the law of violation [which applies only to a girl between the ages of twelve years and a day, and twelve and a half], for there Scripture expressly stated, <i>if a man find a ‘n’arah’ that is a virgin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:28.</i> but here He did not mention <i>na’arah</i>. The reason for this is that the term <i>na’arah</i> mentioned there [in the case of a violator], is used in order to exclude the <i>bogereth</i> [a woman who has passed the stage of maidenhood], who is considered an adult woman, whereas a girl who is a minor [between the ages of three years and a day and twelve years and a day], is also included under the terms of the law of violation. But here [in the case of seduction], it was not necessary to exclude a <i>bogereth</i>, for it is self-understood that one who seduces a <i>bogereth</i> pays nothing, as he did it with her mature consent. Besides, a father has no rights at all in his daughter after the days of her maidenhood, as it is written, <i>‘bin’ureihah’ (in her maidenhood) in her father’s house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 30:17.</i> and here He said, <i>If her father utterly refuse to give her unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16 here.</i> thus indicating that he [the father] can give her to him as a wife, seeing that he has the authority to take her betrothal-money, and this applies only when she is a minor or a <i>na’arah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>na’arah</i> is a maiden between the age of twelve years and a day and twelve and a half. After that she counts as a <i>bogereth</i> — past her maidenhood. The period of <i>yalduth</i> (childhood) is from three years and a day to twelve years and a day.</i> just as the Rabbis interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Kiddushin 3b.</i> “All benefits which accrue during maidenhood belong to her father.”<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">There was no need for Scripture here to write <i>na’arah</i> to exclude a <i>bogereth</i> from the law of seduction, since the verse <i>if her father utterly refuse</i> etc. could not possibly speak of a <i>bogereth</i>. Hence it is self-understood that the section deals here with a <i>na’arah</i>, and there was no need to mention it. But in the case of violation etc.</i> But in the case of a violation it was necessary to write <i>na’arah</i>, in order to exclude a <i>bogereth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>na’arah</i> is a maiden between the age of twelve years and a day and twelve and a half. After that she counts as a <i>bogereth</i> — past her maidenhood. The period of <i>yalduth</i> (childhood) is from three years and a day to twelve years and a day.</i> from that law, because we might have thought that if she were a <i>bogereth</i> he should pay the fifty shekels of silver to her, [instead of to her father; it was therefore necessary to state] that it is a Scriptural decree [that if she is a <i>bogereth</i> he is free from that penalty], the reason being that since she is in full control of herself, she should guard herself against such a mishap.<br>Now Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained <i>mohar</i> as being an expression of “binding” [that he should bind her to him as a wife], similar in usage to the verse, <i>Let the idols of them be multiplied ‘acheir maharu’ (who bind themselves to another god)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 16:4. It is generally translated: “that make suit unto another.” According to Ibn Ezra: “that bind (or connect) themselves with another god.” Ramban’s own interpretation of that verse follows later in the text.</i> But this is not correct; instead, the meaning of <i>mohar</i> is as I have explained it on the basis of the words of our Rabbis, of blessed memory. And in my opinion <i>acheir maharu</i><sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 16:4. It is generally translated: “that make suit unto another.” According to Ibn Ezra: “that bind (or connect) themselves with another god.” Ramban’s own interpretation of that verse follows later in the text.</i> means, “those who are ‘hasty’ in thought, [from the root <i>maheir</i> — fast] and follow another god precipitately, without consideration and without knowledge.” In the writings of the grammarians<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak in Sefer Hashorashim, root <i>acheir</i>.</i> [<i>acheir maharu</i> is explained as meaning]: “those who give <i>mohar</i> (gifts) to another god,” meaning that they bring him sacrifice and offering.

Verse 16



Verse 17

THOU SHALT NOT SUFFER A SORCERESS TO LIVE. In connection with all those who are guilty of death, He has said above: <i>moth yumoth (he shall be surely put to death)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Above 21:15-17.</i> meaning he is liable to death, and it is a positive commandment upon us to slay him, based upon the verse which says, <i>And thou shalt put away the evil from the midst of thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 17:7. Ramban is here intimating that this verse is the basis for the <i>one</i> commandment of the execution of all four modes of death penalties. Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon (Rambam) counted them as <i>four</i> separate commandments. See my translation, “The Commandments,” Vol. I, p. 240.</i> or it may be that this obligation on us is derived from the very expression <i>yumoth</i> (he shall be put to death) which He used in these cases.<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">This opinion corresponds closely to that of the author of ‘Hilchoth Gedoloth’ which Rambam in his Sefer Hamitzvoth criticised, and Ramban in his notes to that work defended. See “The Commandments,” Vol. II, p. 420.</i> But here, however, He did not say, “a sorceress shall be put to death,” but in this case He warned us in a stricter manner by means of a negative commandment, that we should not suffer her to live.<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, pp. 285-286.</i> The reason for this is that the sorceress is <i>defiled of name and full of tumult</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 22:5.</i> and fools are mislead by her, therefore He was more stringent and admonished us with a prohibition. We find a similar severity in relation to all those who cause snares for many people, such as that which He said in the case of the misleader after idols, <i>neither shalt thou spare, nor shalt thou conceal him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:9.</i> and in the case of a murderer He said, <i>And ye shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer, that is guilty of death</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:31.</i>

Verse 18



Verse 19

HE THAT SACRIFICETH ‘LO’ELOHIM YOCHARAM’ (SHALL BE UTTERLY DESTROYED). “<i>Lo’elohim</i> means to the idols, for since the word is voweled with a <i>patach</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>patach</i> and <i>kamatz</i> are in this sense alike, as both indicate the definite article — “<i>those</i> gods which in another place you have been forbidden to worship.” The word <i>lo’elohim</i> is voweled with a <i>kamatz</i>.</i> it means <i>those</i> gods which in another place you have been warned not to worship.” This is Rashi’s language. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that in accordance with the plain meaning of Scripture, this command is not directed to Israel, as they had already been warned in the second of the Ten Commandments against the worship of idols. Instead it was said to “the stranger” mentioned in the following verse, that he may live in our land only on condition that he should not sacrifice to his gods as he was wont to do. — But <i>he</i> [i.e., Ibn Ezra] <i>openeth his mouth in vanity</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Job 35:16. Here in the sense of “worthless” or “unsubstantial.”</i> For in the Ten Commandments He warned against idolatry by a prohibition, and here He explained the punishment and the law that we are to apply to he who transgresses that commandment, just as He did in the case of <i>Thou shalt not murder; Thou shalt not commit adultery</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:13.</i> for <i>these are the ordinances</i> which He set <i>before them</i> [with respect to these commandments].<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above 21:12 (towards the end) for further explanation.</i> Thus He is hereby declaring that one who sacrifices to idols is guilty of death, for the term <i>yocharam</i> means death by the court. Similarly we find, <i>All ‘cheirem’ that may be ‘yocharam’ of men may not be ransomed; he shall surely be put to death</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 27:29. See Ramban there for full explanation. But here he merely brings proof from this verse that the word <i>yocharam</i> signifies death by the court.</i> He uses the term <i>yocharam</i> [of the root <i>cheirem</i> — unlawful, anathema], because he who sacrifices to that which is anathema, deserves destruction, similar to that which is said in the verse, <i>And thou shalt not bring an abomination into thy house, and be ‘cheirem’ (accursed) like unto it; thou shalt utterly detest it, and thou shalt utterly abhor it; for it is an accursed thing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:26.</i><br>It is possible that the verse includes the slaughterer and the animal slaughtered, to tell us that they both go to <i>cheirem</i> (destruction), thus hinting that it is forbidden to derive any benefit from that which has been offered to the idols. It mentioned sacrificing, but the same law applies to bowing down before the idol, and to all other acts of worship performed in the Sanctuary,<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Such as offering incense and libation. Since these acts are performed in the worship of G-d, they come under the terms of this law, so that he who performs them in the worship of the idols is liable to death by the court.</i> but other acts of worship — such as sweeping it, or besprinkling it, or putting his arms around it, or kissing it — are not punishable by death, provided that the idol is not usually worshipped in that manner, but if it is the customary way of worshipping it, he is liable to death under all circumstances, even if excreting to Baal Peor.<br>The correct interpretation of the term <i>lo’elohim</i> with the <i>lamed</i> voweled with a <i>patach</i>, [or a <i>kamatz</i> as in this instance], is that it refers to the angels of above who are called <i>elohim</i> in many places of Scripture, as it is written: <i>There is none like unto Thee among ‘elohim,’ O Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 86:8.</i> <i>He is G-d of ‘elohim’ and Lord of lords;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:17.</i> <i>Bow down to him, all ye ‘elohim.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 97:7.</i> They are also called <i>eilim</i> (the mighty ones),<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:11.</i> as I have already mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:11.</i> And He said here, <i>save unto the Eternal only</i>, because those who sacrifice to His angels think that thereby they do His will, and that the angels will be the intermediaries to obtain His favor for them, and that it is as if they sacrifice to G-d and His ministers; therefore He said [that sacrifices must not be brought] <i>save unto the Eternal only</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">See also Ramban above, 20:3.</i> Inherent in this interpretation is also a profound secret, from which one can understand the concept of offerings, and the student learned in the secrets of the Cabala can understand it from that which we have written elsewhere.<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Seder Shemoth</i> 5:3. and <i>Seder Yithro</i> 18:13.</i> Onkelos hinted at it here.<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos rendered the verse thus: “save unto the <i>name of the</i> Eternal only.” With this translation Onkelos indicated that the intention of the sacrifice is to the proper Name of G-d (Abusaulah, and Ma’or V’shamesh).</i> We shall yet allude to it in <i>Torath Kohanim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:9. — For the term <i>Torath Kohanim</i> see <i>Seder Yithro</i> Note 590.</i> with the help of G-d, may His Name forever be blessed to all eternity.

Verse 20

AND A STRANGER SHALT THOU NOT WRONG, NEITHER SHALT THOU OPPRESS HIM; FOR YE WERE STRANGERS IN THE LAND OF EGYPT. There is no reason why all strangers [from countries outside the land of Egypt] should be included here because of our having been strangers in the land of Egypt! And there is no reason why they be assured for ever against being wronged or oppressed because we were once strangers there! Now Rashi explained that this is a reason for the prohibition against annoying a stranger. G-d warned against vexing him with words, for “if you vex him he can also vex you, by saying to you, “You also descend from strangers.’ Do not reproach your fellow man with a fault which is also in you.” Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained the verses: “Remember <i>that ye were strangers</i> as he is now.” But there is in all these comments no real reason for the law.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that He is saying: “Do not wrong a stranger or oppress him, thinking as you might that none can deliver him out of your hand; for you know that you were strangers in the land of Egypt <i>and I saw the oppression wherewith the Egyptians oppressed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Above 3:9.</i> you, and I avenged your cause on them, because <i>I behold the tears of such who are oppressed and have no comforter, and on the side of their oppressors there is power</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 4:1.</i> and I deliver each one <i>from him that is too strong for him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 35:10.</i> Likewise <i>you shall not afflict the widow and the fatherless child</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> for I will hear their cry,<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> for all these people do not rely upon themselves but trust in Me.” And in another verse He added this reason: <i>for ye know the soul of a stranger, seeing ye were strangers in the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:9.</i> That is to say, you know that every stranger feels depressed, and is always sighing and crying, and his eyes are always directed towards G-d, therefore He will have mercy upon him even as He showed mercy to you, just as it is written, <i>and the children of Israel sighed by reason of the bondage, and they cried, and their cry came up unto G-d by reason of the bondage</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:23.</i> meaning that He had mercy on them not because of their merits, but only an account of the bondage [and likewise He has mercy on all who are oppressed].

Verse 21

ANY WIDOW — even a rich one of quite considerable wealth — YE SHALL NOT AFFLICT, for her tears are frequent and her soul is depressed. He states, <i>If thou afflict ‘otho’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> [“him” in the singular], meaning any one [who is a widow or a fatherless child]. Therefore it is written after that, <i>and your wives shall be widows</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> in punishment for your causing the cry of the widow, <i>and your children fatherless</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> in punishment for the cry of the orphan.<br>This punishment [<i>And My wrath shall glow, and I will kill you with the sword</i> etc.]<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> is not counted by our Rabbis amongst those brought upon people who are liable to death by the hand of Heaven, as listed in the Beraitha,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>Seder Bo</i> Note 209.</i> “These are the people who are liable to death by the hand of Heaven” taught in Tractate Sanhedrin.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 83a.</i> The reason for this is that the death mentioned here is unlike the usual death of people by the hand of Heaven, of whom it is said, <i>and they die therein, if they profane it;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:9.</i> <i>and ye die not</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:32.</i> But here the punishment is that they will die by the enemy’s sword, <i>or he shall go down into battle, and be swept away</i><sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:10.</i> without anyone knowing it, and their wives will thus have to remain forever widows, and their children always be fatherless.

Verse 22

IF THOU AFFLICT HIM IN ANY WISE. “This is an elliptical verse; it threatens, but does not explain the punishment needed to complete the sense of the verse. It is like the verse, <i>therefore, whosoever slayeth Cain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:15.</i> which does not explain what the punishment is. Here too, <i>if thou afflict him in any wise</i>, is an expression of determination to inflict punishment, as if to say: ‘In the end you will get your deserts. Why? For <i>if he cry unto Me</i> I will hear him, and I will avenge him.’” This is Rashi’s language. But it is not correct [to interpret a verse on the basis of such a long omission, in order to complete the sense]. The witness he brings [i.e., the verse about Cain] also does not testify to that [kind of long omission]. But it is possible that the word <i>ki</i> [generally translated “for”], here means “if,” for this is one of the usages of the word <i>ki</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Rosh Hashanah 3a. The verse here reads: <i>ki im tza’ok yitzak</i>, and is generally translated: “<i>for</i> if he cry.” But with the word <i>ki</i> understood as “if”, the verse would read: “if if he cry,” as explained further on in the text.</i> and the verse thus states: “if if he cry at all unto Me, I will surely hear his cry,” the repetition of the word “if” being used in order to show the gravity and importance of the matter, similar in usage to these phrases; <i>hamiblie ein k’varim</i> [generally translated: “Was it because there were no graves…?” — but literally: “was it because there were ‘no no’ graves…?”];<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 14:11.</i> <i>harak ach b’Mosheh</i> [generally translated: “hath the Eternal indeed spoken only with Moses”, but literally: “‘only only’ with Moses].”<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:2.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that He is stating: “<i>If thou afflict him in any wise, if he will</i> only just <i>cry at all unto Me I will</i> at once <i>hear his cry:</i> he does not need anything else at all, for I will save him and avenge his cause from you. And the reason for this is that you oppress him because [you think] he has no one to help him against you, but behold he has more help than anyone else. For other people will try to find saviors to save them, and helpers to avenge their cause, and perhaps <i>they cannot profit nor deliver</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:21.</i> while this one will be saved by the Eternal merely through his crying out, and He will take vengeance from you, for <i>The Eternal is a jealous and avenging G-d</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Nachum 1:2.</i> There are many verses to a similar effect. Thus, that which He said, <i>Rob not the weak, because he is weak, neither crush the poor in the gate; for the Eternal will plead their cause</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 22:22-23.</i> means: “rob not the poor merely because he is poor and has no helpers, nor crush the poor in your gates, for the Eternal will plead on their behalf.” Similarly He said, <i>And enter not into the fields of the fatherless, for their Redeemer is strong;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:10-11.</i> <i>the Eternal of hosts is His Name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 50:34: <i>Their Redeemer is strong, the Eternal of hosts is His Name</i>.</i> for they have a Redeemer Who is stronger and closer to them than all people have. Here also He said, that just by his cry, the fatherless will be saved. Likewise: <i>For as the rain cometh down and the snow from heaven, and returneth not thither, except it water the earth, and make it bring forth and bud, and give seed to the sower and bread to the eater; so shall My word be that goeth forth out of My mouth; it shall not return unto Me void, except it accomplish that which I please</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 55:10-11.</i> In both phrases [<i>except it water — except it accomplish</i>] He is stating that they<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the rain and the snow.</i> will do nothing else other than to water the earth immediately, and so also will <i>My word</i> do that which I please. Thus the meaning of the word <i>ki</i> [<i>ki im hirvah — ki im asah</i>: except it water — except it accomplish] has the sense of “but.” And so also: <i>‘ki im’ (but) I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:30.</i>

Verse 23



Verse 24

THOU SHALT NOT BE TO HIM AS AN EXACTOR — that is, a creditor. He is saying that the lender should not behave to the borrower like a creditor who is a sort of lord over the borrower, as it is written, <i>and the borrower is a servant to the lender</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 22:7.</i> but instead you should behave to him exactly as if he had never borrowed from you; neither shall you lay upon him interest, whether <i>interest of money, interest of victuals</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 23:20.</i> Rather, the loan to him should be an act of goodness; you should not take from him any mark of honor because of it, nor are you to derive any monetary benefit from it.

Verse 25



Verse 26

AND I WILL HEAR FOR I AM GRACIOUS — showing favor and accepting everyone’s supplication even though he is unworthy, the word <i>chanun</i> (gracious) being derived from the word <i>chinam</i> (for nothing). And the meaning of the verse is that you should not think: “I will not take the righteous man’s garment as a pledge, but the garment of a man who is not righteous I will take as a pledge and not return to him, for G-d will not hear his cry.” Therefore He said, <i>for I am gracious</i> and I hear the cry of all who beseech Me.

Verse 27

THOU SHALL NOT CURSE ‘ELOHIM.’ Onkelos translated it as referring to a judge, that one is not to curse him if he should hold him guilty in a lawsuit. <i>Lo takeil</i> [Onkelos’ rendition of the Hebrew <i>lo t’kaleil</i> — thou shalt not curse], is the Aramaic expression for “cursing.” Thus: “<i>Meikal l’hu</i> (they curse him): <i>May the Eternal cut off to the man that doeth this, him that calleth and him that answereth</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 2:12. — Yerushalmi Shabbath III, 7.</i> There are many similar expressions, in the language of the Talmud Yerushalmi.
NOR CURSE A ‘NASI’ OF THY PEOPLE — <i>nasi</i> means the one who is “lifted up” above his people, namely, the king. He thus mentioned that one is not to curse him in case he declares him guilty in a trial before him.<br>In the opinion of our Rabbis in the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 66a.</i> <i>Thou shalt not curse ‘Elokim,’</i> constitutes an admonition against blaspheming the Name of G-d, even by one of the substituted names [such as: Gracious and Merciful etc.].<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">See Mishneh Torah, Mada, Hilchoth Yesodei Hatorah 6:5.</i> Thus He warned against cursing the King on high, blessed be He, and also the monarch that reigns on earth. The Rabbis have also said in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 66a.</i> that included in the term <i>Elokim</i>, is <i>the Glorious Name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58. — I.e., the Tetragrammaton.</i> as well as the judge who sits <i>in the seat of G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 28:2.</i> on earth. But it has not been explained whether the term <i>nasi</i> includes the head of the Great Sanhedrin,<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">The Great Sanhedrin consisted of seventy-one judges, and sat in the court of the Sanctuary. A small Sanhedrin of twenty-three judges was to be found in every city.</i> who is called <i>nasi</i> in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 19b.</i> Harav Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon said<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">In his Book of the Commandments, Negative Commandment 316 (See Vol. II of my translation, p. 290).</i> that he is included under the term of this prohibition. And so it also appears to me, on the basis of a question that Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi, the redactor of the Mishnah, was Chief of the Sanhedrin of his generation. — The question he asked concerning himself was whether he had, in the eyes of the Law, the status of a <i>nasi</i> so that [in the time of the Sanctuary] the law of a special sin-offering for the prince (see Leviticus 4:22-26) applied to him as well, since he was the <i>nasi</i> of the Sanhedrin, or perhaps because he had his counterpart in the Diaspora — the Exilarch — his authority was no longer unique as that of a king, and therefore his sin-offering is to be like that of any individual Israelite. It is thus obvious that the office of the Chief of the Sanhedrin as such is included under the term <i>nasi</i>.</i> asked about himself:<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Horayoth 11b.</i> “A person in my status, am I to bring a <i>sa’ir</i><sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">A male goat. See Leviticus 4:23. The individual Israelite brings a female goat as a sin-offering (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 28).</i> etc.?” If so, He is stating: “Do not curse any ruler of the people, who holds a position of supreme authority over all Israel, whether that position be in the secular sphere of government or in the rule of Torah,” for the head of the Sanhedrin is the highest position in the authority of the Torah.

Verse 28

M’LEIATHCHA V’DIM’ACHA’ (OF THE FULNESS OF THY HARVEST, AND OUT OF THE OUTFLOW OF THY PRESSES) THOU SHALT NOT DELAY TO OFFER. We find the word <i>m’leiah</i> with reference to seed, thus: <i>lest there be forfeited ‘ham’leiah’ (the fulness) of the seed which thou hast sown</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:9.</i> and again: <i>‘v’kamleiah’ (and as the fulness) of the winepress</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:27.</i> meaning wine and oil, just as it is said, <i>and the vats shall overflow with wine and oil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:24.</i><br>It appears to me in connection with these terms, that fruits of the field and vineyard are called <i>t’vuah</i> [of the root <i>bo</i> — come in] because the farmers “bring” the whole crop in together to the homes. It is also called <i>asif</i> (the ingathering): <i>‘osef’ (the ingathering) shall not come;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 32:10.</i> <i>and the feast of ‘ha’asif’ (the ingathering)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 23:16.</i> This is why produce is called <i>m’leiah</i> (fulness), because a gathering-together into one place of a mass of material or people is called <i>milui</i> (fulness): <i>though there be called forth against him ‘m’lo’ (a multitude of) shepherds;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 31:4.</i> <i>even they are ‘malei’ (in full) cry after you;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 12:6.</i> <i>together against me ‘yitmalo’un’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Job 16:10.</i> — they gather themselves and come. Similarly, <i>and his seed shall become ‘m’lo’ nations</i><sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 48:19.</i> — means an assembly and multitude of nations.<br>It is further possible that produce is called <i>m’leiah</i> (full) as a substitute term for a blessing — that <i>the granaries shall be full of corn, and the vats shall overflow with wine and oil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:24.</i> and the reaper fills his hands, and the binder of sheaves his bosom,<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 129:7.</i> and gathers grapes in the vintage. For when <i>their portion is cursed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">Job 24:18.</i> Scripture says, <i>Let them be as the grass upon the housetops, which withereth afore it springeth up; wherewith the reaper filleth not his hand, nor he that bindeth sheaves, his bosom</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 129:6-7.</i> but when their portion is blessed, it is called <i>m’leiah</i> (full). And in that case <i>dim’acha</i> [literally: “your tear”] is an allusion to wine and oil, a usage borrowed from <i>dim’ath ha’ayin</i> (tear of the eye), because the drops from the grape and olive resemble the tear of the eye. Or it may be that all moisture that falls in globules — even drops of water — are called <i>dim’ah</i> (tear), such as: <i>and mine eyes shall run down ‘dim’ah’ (with tear)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 13:17.</i> and it is not a term used only for tears. And the intention of the verse is, that when you gather in the crops of the field, and <i>the granaries will be full of corn</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:24.</i> and you press the grapes and olives to extract their juice, <i>and the vats shall overflow with wine and oil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:24.</i> you should not delay them in your possession, but right at the beginning you are to give your tithings to Me, just as He said, <i>The first fruits of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil… shalt thou give him</i> — [i.e., the priest].<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 18:4.</i><br>In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> of blessed memory, <i>thou shalt not delay</i> means that: “you are not to set aside last what should be first, [and set aside first what should be last].” Now here He did not explain [the correct order of the gifts], for here He mentions the commandments in a general way, and afterwards He explained them in detail. The Rabbis arranged the order of the gifts as follows: first-fruits, the heave-offering, the First Tithe, and the Second Tithe.<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">The first-fruits are brought to the Sanctuary and then given to the priest. The heave-offering is given to the priest, the First Tithe to the Levite, and the Second Tithe is eaten by the owner in Jerusalem. See “The Commandments,” Vol. II, pp. 145-146, for full discussion of this commandment.</i> This order they established on the basis of the following interpretation with reference to these gifts, just as we have been taught:<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Terumoth 3:7.</i> “How do we know that first-fruits come before the heave-offering, being that this one is called by Scripture <i>terumah</i> (heave-offering) and <i>reshith</i> (the first), and the other is also called <i>terumah</i> and <i>reshith?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 12:6 speaks of first-fruits as <i>terumath yedchem</i> (the heave-offering of your hand); they are called <i>reshith</i> in this Scriptural section (further 23:19). The heave-offering is called <i>terumah</i> in Numbers 18:8, and is called <i>reshith</i> in Deuteronomy 18:4.</i> First-fruits have priority because they are the first [to grow] of all produce. The heave-offering comes before the First Tithe, because it is called <i>reshith</i> (the first),<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 12:6 speaks of first-fruits as <i>terumath yedchem</i> (the heave-offering of your hand); they are called <i>reshith</i> in this Scriptural section (further 23:19). The heave-offering is called <i>terumah</i> in Numbers 18:8, and is called <i>reshith</i> in Deuteronomy 18:4.</i> and the First Tithe comes before the Second Tithe because it contains in it <i>reshith</i>” [since the Levite who receives the First Tithe must give a tenth of it as <i>terumah</i> to the priest].<br>Onkelos translated <i>m’leiathcha v’dim’acha:</i> “<i>bikurach</i> (your first fruit), <i>v’dim’ach</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos thus left the Hebrew word <i>v’dim’acha</i> untranslated. As explained further it is a term denoting the priest’s share of the produce — in other words, the <i>terumah</i> [or the heave-offering]. According to Onkelos the verse thus refers to the first-fruits and the heave-offering.</i> And Rashi explained: “<i>M’leiathcha</i> — this means the duty which falls upon you when your crop becomes fully ripened, and it refers to the first-fruits. <i>V’dim’acha</i> means the heave-offering. But I do not know what the term <i>dim’a</i> means.” It is similarly stated in the Mechilta:<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> “<i>M’leiathcha</i> means the first-fruits which are taken from the full crop, and <i>dim’acha</i> means the heave-offering.” Perhaps in the same way that according to the Rabbis the first-fruits are called in this verse <i>m’leiah</i> (fulness), because they are taken from the full crop, so the heave-offering is called <i>dim’ah</i> [literally: “tear” or “outflow,” as explained above], because it is set aside from wine and oil, [as liquids], not from the fruit. Scripture mentioned only these two kinds of produce, [wine and oil], in order to hint at the law that the heave-offering only has to be set aside from them when in the form of wine and oil, there being no obligation upon the owner to anticipate and set it aside when they are still grapes and olives.<br>Thus He only mentioned these commandments here by way of allusion, as if to say, “Be careful to keep these commandments about which I will command you further,” in a similar manner to that which He said above, <i>and I will appoint thee a place whither he may flee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:13.</i> This was in order to write down these commandments in <i>the book of the covenant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:7.</i> which He mentions in a subsequent section, and Scripture explains them all again in another place, [each one in detail].

Verse 29



Verse 30

AND YE SHALL BE HOLY MEN UNTO ME. The reason for the expression in this verse is that until now He mentioned only the ordinances and admonished them about repulsive matters,<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">Such as those described above in Verses 17-21.</i> but now when He is about to begin the law of forbidden food, He prefaced it by saying, <i>And ye shall be holy men unto Me</i>. For in order to preserve his physical life man should [be able to] eat anything which serves that purpose, and the prohibitions concerning certain foods are only a means of guarding the purity of the soul, in order that one should eat clean things which do not give rise to harshness and coarseness in the soul. Therefore He said, <i>And ye shall be holy men unto Me</i>, that is to say: “I want you to be holy men so that you will become suitable for Me, to cleave to Me, for I am Holy; therefore do not defile your souls by eating abominable things.” And similarly He said, <i>Ye shall not make yourselves detestable with any swarming thing that swarmeth, neither shall ye make yourselves unclean with them, that ye should be defiled thereby. For I am the Eternal your G-d; sanctify yourselves therefore, and be ye holy; for I am Holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 11:43-44.</i> Swarming things thus make the soul detestable, but the <i>treifah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 189.</i> is not detestable, however abstention from eating it adds holiness.

Chapter 23
