Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

BUT THE SEVENTH YEAR ‘TISHM’TENAH U’N'TASHTAH’ (THOU SHALT LET IT REST AND LIE FALLOW). “<i>Tishm’tenah</i> — by not tilling it. <i>U’n'tashtah</i> by not eating of its produce after ‘the time of removal.’<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 25:6-7. The produce of the Sabbatical year which grows of its own accord may be eaten by humans and animals in the house, as long as the wild beasts are able to eat of that produce in the field. But when it is no longer found by the wild beasts in the field, the food has to be “removed” from the house and made available to all alike.</i> Another interpretation: <i>Tishm’tenah</i> — from real work, such as plowing and sowing; <i>u’n'tashtah</i> — from hoeing or manuring it.” This is Rashi’s language. But it is not correct, for according to the law of the Torah we have only been warned against plowing and sowing in the seventh year, but hoeing and manuring, and even weeding, hoeing under the vines, and cutting away thorns, and all other forms of agricultural work, are not forbidden by law of the Torah. This is the conclusion that the Rabbis came to [after a discussion of this matter] at the beginning of Tractate Moed Katan in the Chapter <i>Mashkin</i>:<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “We may water” [an irrigated field…]. — Moed Katan 2 b-3a.</i> that the Merciful One forbade only plowing and sowing in the seventh year, but did not prohibit secondary kinds of work [such as hoeing, manuring, etc.], which are all forbidden only by Rabbinic ordinance, and the verse mentioned [there in the Talmud] in connection with these secondary kinds of work is a mere support in the Scriptural text.<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Yithro</i> Note 449.</i> Similarly, the law of “removal”<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 25:6-7. The produce of the Sabbatical year which grows of its own accord may be eaten by humans and animals in the house, as long as the wild beasts are able to eat of that produce in the field. But when it is no longer found by the wild beasts in the field, the food has to be “removed” from the house and made available to all alike.</i> is not derived from this verse [as Rashi explained here].<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “<i>Tishm’tenah</i> means: every creditor <i>‘shamot’ (shall release)</i> that which he hath lent unto his neighbor.<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 15:2.</i> — <i>U’n'tashtah</i> means that you should not sow your field.” But it is not a correct comment. Instead, [the true explanation is that] Scripture first said, <i>six years thou shalt sow</i> and gather in the increase thereof,<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> <i>but the seventh year ‘tishm’tenah’</i> — you should not sow your land; <i>u’n'tashtah</i> — you should not gather in its increase, but instead you are to leave it so that the poor of your people and the beasts of the field may eat the fruits of the tree and the produce of the vineyard. In a similar sense is the verse, <i>‘v’nitash’ the seventh year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 10:32.</i> [which thus means: “and we will not gather in the increase of the field in the seventh year”].

Verse 12

L’MA’AN’ (THAT) THINE OX AND THINE ASS MAY HAVE REST. Because the word <i>l’ma’an</i> is like <i>ba’avur</i> (“in order that”), we must explain<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intention is as follows: It cannot be said that the command here is directed to the owner himself, that he should rest on the Sabbath, since it says clearly <i>‘in order that’ thine ox… may have rest;</i> neither can it be referring to a case where the owner works together with the animal, for if that were so, why does the Torah not mention that the reason is that he himself should have rest? Hence Ramban explains the verse in the following way: “<i>Six days thou shalt do thy work</i> in such a manner as if it were all completed by the Sabbath-day, so that the animal can have rest by itself on that day.”</i> that the verse is stating: “Six days you shall do all your work in the house and in the field, in order that the ox and the ass may have rest on the seventh day. <i>And the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may be refreshed</i> — in order that they all be witnesses to the Creation.” The verse here is then similar in meaning to: <i>Bake that which ye will bake</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:23. In other words, bake on the sixth day double in order that you should not have to bake on the Sabbath. Here likewise a similar thought is expressed: do all your work in six days so that the animal can have rest on the seventh day.</i> Similarly He said, <i>Six days shalt thou labor, and do all thy work</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:9.</i> as I have explained there.

Verse 13

AND IN ALL THINGS THAT I HAVE SAID UNTO YOU TAKE YE HEED. Rashi explained: “This verse is intended to bring every positive commandment also under the term of a prohibition,<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">So that if one fails to fulfill a positive commandment [as e.g. taking the <i>Lulav</i> on the festival of Succoth] he has also violated thereby a negative commandment as expressed in the verse before us.</i> for wherever the term <i>shmirah</i> (taking heed) or <i>shvithah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">“Or <i>shvithah</i>” is not found in our Rashi. And correctly so, for the term <i>shvithah</i> can indicate a <i>positive</i> commandment, such as: <i>and on the seventh day ‘tishboth’</i> (thou shalt rest) — Verse 12.</i> is used in the Torah, it signifies an admonition in the place of an express prohibition.”<br>Now according to his explanation, Rashi will have to say that this verse is a <i>lav sh’bichlaluth</i> [a negative admonition expressed in general terms, so that violation of any or all of the prohibitions included under it does not render one liable to punishment].<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">This term is applied to a verse which covers many different prohibitions, none of which is specifically indicated, and therefore the court does not administer punishment for violation thereof. — See “The Commandments,” Vol. II, p. 11, Note 1, for full explanation of this term.</i> For if that were not so, the court would have to administer whipping to anyone who fails to fulfill any of the positive commandments of the Torah; but in such a prohibition which includes many matters without mentioning specifically any particular transgression, everyone would agree that no whipping is incurred on account of its breach. But [if so, there is the following difficulty with Rashi’s explanation]: the Rabbis have already said<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Erubin 96a. The opinion is that of Rabbi Ilai.</i> that the term <i>hishamer</i> (take heed) used in connection with a positive commandment, carries the force of an additional <i>positive</i> commandment; in that case, He has added here [not a <i>negative</i> commandment as Rashi has it], but a mere positive one [since the statement, <i>and in all things that I have said unto you ‘tishameru’ (take ye heed)</i>, refers to the <i>positive</i> commandments mentioned in the preceding Verses 10-12]! In the Mechilta the Sages differed as to the explanation of this verse and interpreted it in many ways.<br>In accordance with the plain meaning of Scripture, the explanation of the verse is: “<i>and in all things that I have said unto you</i> concerning other gods <i>take ye heed</i>,” for the verse is to be connected with its continuation, [which states: <i>and make no mention of the name of other gods, neither let it be heard out of thy mouth</i>]. Thus He is stating: Of all the many admonitions that I have said to you concerning other gods, take great heed; do not worship them, nor bow down to them, condemn to death anyone who sacrifices to them, and make no graven image, nor any manner of likeness. Moreover, take heed not to mention the name of their gods, such as <i>Chemosh the god of Moab, and Milkom the god of the children of Ammon</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 11:33.</i> and Ashima the god of Hamath.<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 17:30.</i> <i>Neither let there be heard out of thy mouth</i> their name, even without the epithet of deity, such as merely mentioning Milkom or Ashima; instead you are to mention them in a manner of condemnation: “the abhorrent thing of Moab,” “the abomination of the children of Ammon.” Or, the expression <i>lo yishama (neither let there be heard)</i>, means: let it not be heard from its worshipper through your dealings with him, similarly to that which our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 63b.</i> that one should not make a business—partnership with an idolator, for it might lead to him swearing by his deity.<br>It is possible that <i>lo tazkiru (make no mention)</i> is transitive, meaning: do not mention the name of other gods to their worshippers, such as saying, “By your god! deal kindly with me.” <i>Neither let there be heard out of thy mouth</i> the mention of his name at all. It is this which is said in the Book of Joshua, <i>Neither make mention of the name of their gods, nor cause to swear by them, nor serve them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 23:7.</i> He added prohibitions in that verse, in order to explain that the admonition here covers not mentioning or causing anyone whomsoever to swear by the foreign gods.

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND THE FEAST OF HARVEST, THE FIRST-FRUITS OF THY LABORS, AND THE FEAST OF INGATHERING AT THE END OF THE YEAR. I do not know why Scripture mentions the names of the festivals with the definite article since He has not yet commanded about or mentioned them at all till now, and it ought to have said first: “and you shall keep a feast of harvest, the first-fruits of your labors,” just as He said in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>And thou shalt keep a festival of weeks unto the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:9.</i> But perhaps because He had already said, <i>Three times thou shalt keep a feast unto Me in the year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14 here.</i> and further explained, <i>The feast of unleavened bread shalt thou keep… in the mouth of Aviv</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15. — <i>Aviv</i> [literally: “maturity”] means the month when the grain becomes full in its ripe state (Rashi). It is the month of spring.</i> meaning that you are to make sure that the Passover festival is observed at the beginning of the month of Aviv, He referred back [to these verses] and said, “And as for the other festival, make sure that it be <i>the feast of harvest, the first-fruits of thy labors</i>, and as for the third one, make sure that it be <i>the feast of ingathering, at the end of the year</i>. Now all these festivals are thus named with reference to man’s activities in the field, in order that he give thanks for them to G-d who guards <i>the ordinances of heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 33:25.</i> and brings forth bread out of the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 104:14.</i> to satisfy <i>the longing soul, and the hungry soul He hath filled with good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 107:9.</i> This is Scripture’s intention in using here the expression: <i>el pnei Ha’adon Hashem (three times in the year shall all thy males appear — ‘before the Master, the Eternal’)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17 here.</i> for He is the Master who provides the needs of His servants, and when they take their part from before Him, they come to Him to see what He commands them to do. Thus the expression <i>el pnei</i> is like <i>‘liphnei’</i> (“before”) — <i>before the Master</i>. But by way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], the word <i>pnei</i> is derived from the term <i>panim</i> [literally: “face”], and I have already alluded to the explanation of <i>panim</i> in the Ten Commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:3.</i> This is why He said <i>Ha’adon Hashem (the Master, the Eternal)</i>, just as He said the second time, <i>the Master, the Eternal, the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:23. — Ramban’s intention is to suggest that <i>el pnei Ha’adon</i> here is not in the grammatical form of construct with the word <i>Hashem;</i> this is evident from the same expression which occurs a second time [in 34:23] where it is written <i>Hashem Elokei Yisrael</i>, thus indicating that here too the word <i>Hashem</i> is not in construct with <i>Ha’adon</i> (Abusaula).</i> Similarly: <i>Behold, the ark of the covenant of the Master of all the earth;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 3:11.</i> <i>Tremble, thou earth, ‘miliphnei’ (at the presence) of the Master</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 114:7. The allusion is here to the word <i>‘miliphnei’</i> which is suggestive of <i>panim</i>, as mentioned above (Abusaula).</i>

Verse 17



Verse 18

THOU SHALT NOT OFFER THE BLOOD OF MY SACRIFICE WITH LEAVENED BREAD. “You shall not slaughter the Passover-offering on the fourteenth day of Nisan before you have removed the leavened bread [from your possession].” This is Rashi’s language.<br>Do not interpret the meaning of this statement of Rashi to refer to the removal of unleavened bread, [and that the verse tells us] that this must take place before the time of slaughtering the Passover-offering, just as is mentioned in the first chapter of Tractate Pesachim:<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the question that was asked in the Gemara Pesachim [4 b-5 a]: how do we know that unleavened bread is forbidden by law of the Torah after six hours on the fourteenth day of Nisan? To this Rava answered that we derive it from the verse, <i>Thou shalt not slaughter…</i> (further 34:25), which means: “do not slaughter the Paschal-lamb while the leavened bread is still there.” And since the time for the slaughtering of the Paschal-lamb begins after the sixth hour, we therefore deduce that unleavened bread is forbidden from that time on. When the Gemara further asked: “Perhaps the Torah meant a separate time for each individual, [so that if he slaughtered it on the ninth hour of the day, he would not be in violation of the law against keeping unleavened bread till such time]? To this the answer is given: “The Merciful One has declared a time for the slaughtering of the Passover-offering [for all alike, and He did not distinguish between one person and another]. — Ramban is now writing that Rashi’s explanation was <i>not</i> prompted by this text of the Gemara, for reasons explained further on.</i> “The Merciful One has declared a time for the slaughtering of the Passover-offering for all alike” — for this interpretation is not the real point of the verse in accordance with the final decision of the law mentioned there. For there is no <i>prohibition</i><sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s point is that the duty of removing from one’s possession unleavened bread on the fourteenth day of Nisan, is a matter of a <i>positive</i> commandment, thus one who failed to remove it from his possession after the sixth hour of that day, has thereby violated a <i>positive</i> commandment. But there is no <i>negative</i> commandment to cover this matter. Hence the verse before us which is a <i>negative</i> commandment cannot be establishing the time for the removal of unleavened bread, since that is covered only by a positive commandment. This is the intention of Ramban’s words.</i> according to the law of the Torah requiring the removal of unleavened bread on the day before Passover, not even is there a prohibition against eating it [but the violation of a <i>positive</i> commandment].<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Here too Ramban’s opinion is that there is no <i>negative</i> commandment of the Torah covering it, but one who eats it violates thereby a <i>positive</i> commandment, since he had failed to destroy the unleavened bread beforehand. See, however, “the Commandments,” Vol. II, p. 196, where Rambam differs on this point and counts a specific negative commandment, wherein we are forbidden to eat unleavened bread after the middle of the fourteenth of Nisan.</i> But the subject of the verse as established according to the final decision of the law, is an admonition against slaughtering the Passover-offering <i>with leavened bread</i>, meaning that none of the company who have been counted to eat of this Passover-offering, may have leavened bread remaining in their possession at the time it is slaughtered. And so Rashi explained it in the section of <i>Ki Thisa</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:25. “This is an admonition addressed to him who slaughters the offering, as well as to him who sprinkles its blood [on the altar], or to one of the company [that joined together to eat the Paschal-lamb]” (Rashi).</i> Now the verse should have read, “Thou shalt not slaughter with unleavened bread My sacrifice” [omitting the word: <i>dam</i> — blood], for the blood is not “slaughtered.” But in the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here on the Verse.</i> this comes to include the sprinkling, so that the priest who sprinkles the blood of the offering is also forbidden to have leavened bread in his possession. The verse thus states: “Do not slaughter the Passover-offering with unleavened bread, and neither [sprinkle] the blood of My sacrifice,” That is, and neither let the blood of My sacrifice be with unleavened bread. It is an elliptical verse.

Verse 19



Verse 20

BEHOLD, I SEND AN ANGEL BEFORE THEE. “Here they were informed that they would sin [by worshipping the golden calf] and that the Divine Glory would be saying to them, <i>For I will not go up in the midst of thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:3.</i> <br>FOR MY NAME IS IN HIM. This is connected with the beginning of this verse: <i>Take heed of him</i>, for My Name is associated with him. Our Rabbis explained<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 38b.</i> that the angel referred to is Mattatron<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 12:12 [beginning: <i>I will execute judgments</i>].</i> whose name in numerical value is equal to that of his Master, for the sum of the letter-numbers of the name Mattatron is equal to that of <i>Sha-dai</i> (Almighty).”<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">The number of each is three hundred and fourteen.</i> All this is the language of Rashi. In Eileh Shemoth Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 32:7.</i> I have likewise seen that one of the Sages interprets the verse in this way, referring to the worshipping of the calf.<br>But one must ask that [we find that] this decree of <i>I send an angel before thee</i> did not actually take place, for the Holy One, blessed be He, had said to Moses, <i>And I will send an angel before thee… for I will not go up in the midst of thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:2-3.</i> but Moses pleaded for mercy on this and said, <i>If Thy presence go not, carry us not up hence. For wherein now shall it be known that I have found grace in Thy sight, I and Thy people? is it not in that Thou goest with us?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 15-16.</i> And the Holy One, blessed be He, consented to him and told him, <i>I will do also this thing that thou hast spoken</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 17.</i> Thus also did the Rabbis interpret it:<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 38b.</i> “Even as a guide we refused to accept him, as it is written, <i>If Thy presence go not, carry us not up hence</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 15-16.</i><br>The answer according to this opinion of the Rabbis is that this decree was not fulfilled in the days of Moses, and it is with reference to this that Moses said, <i>So that we are distinguished, I and Thy people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> and G-d answered him, <i>For thou hast found grace in My sight, and I know thee by name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 17.</i> and He further said, <i>And all the people among which thou art shall see the work of the Eternal</i> [that I am about to do];<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 34:10.</i> however, after the death of Moses our Teacher He did send with them the angel. It is with reference to this that Scripture states: <i>And it came to pass, when Joshua was by Jericho, that he lifted up his eyes and looked, and, behold, there stood a man over against him with his sword drawn in his hand, and Joshua went unto him, and said unto him: ‘Art thou for us, or for our adversaries? ‘And he said: ‘Nay, but I am captain of the host of the Eternal; I am now come.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 5:13-14.</i> And there you will see that Joshua asked him, <i>What saith my lord unto his servant?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> Now the angel did not command Joshua anything in connection with his appearance to him, but merely told him, <i>Put off thy shoe from off thy foot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> nor did he explain why he came. But the vision was for the purpose of informing Joshua that from now on there would be an angel sent before them to go out in the host in battle. It is with reference to this that he said, <i>I am now come</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 5:13-14.</i> And so did the Sages say in the Tanchuma:<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma <i>Mishpatim</i>, 18.</i> “The angel said to Joshua: ‘I am he who came in the days of Moses your master, and he pushed me away and did not want me to go with him.’” The Rabbis have also said expressly:<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 32:4.</i> “The promise that Israel would not be turned over to ‘a captain’ all the days of Moses now became void; thus as soon as Moses died ‘the captain’ returned to his position, for Joshua saw him, as it is said, <i>And it came to pass, when Joshua was by Jericho… And he said, ‘Nay, but I am captain of the host of the Eternal; I am now come.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 5:13-14.</i> This is why it is said, <i>Behold, I send an angel before thee</i>.”<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], this angel they were promised here is <i>the redeeming angel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 48:16. See Ricanti (<i>ibid.</i>, 31:13) where he quotes this text of Ramban, and explains that the reference is to the <i>Shechinah</i> (the Divine Glory). See in the text Note 419.</i> in whom is the Great Name, <i>for in Y-a-h the Eternal is an everlasting Rock</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:4.</i> This is [what He meant when] He said, <i>I am the G-d of Beth-el</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 31:13.</i> for it is the custom of the King to dwell in His Palace. He is called <i>mal’ach</i> (angel) because the whole conduct of this world is by that attribute. And our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 38b.</i> that this is Mattatron, a name which signifies “the guide of the road” — I have already explained this in <i>Seder Bo</i><sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 12:12 [beginning: <i>I will execute judgments</i>].</i> — and this is the sense of the phrase here, [<i>Behold, I send an angel before thee,</i>] <i>to keep thee in the way. — And to bring thee into the place which I have prepared</i>, referring to the Sanctuary, as it is written, <i>the Sanctuary, O Eternal, which Thy hands have established</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:17.</i> The meaning of the expression: <i>which I have prepared</i>, is “for Myself, to be My holy and beautiful house,”<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 64:10.</i> for there the Throne is perfect. I will yet mention<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 24:1 (towards the end).</i> the Rabbis’ meaning in saying that Mattatron’s name [in the sum of letter-numbers] is even as the Name of his Master. His voice is thus the voice of the living G-d, and it is mandatory upon us to hearken to His voice by the mouth of the prophets. Or the meaning may be that “they should not mutilate the shoots” of faith<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 155.</i> and thus come to abandon the Oral Torah, just as the Rabbis have interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">P’sichta Eichah Rabbathi, 2.</i> “<i>And they have spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 5:24.</i> — this refers to the Oral Torah.” Thus the explanation of the expression, <i>and hearken unto his voice</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> is “to My words.” Similarly He said, <i>But if thou shalt indeed hearken unto his voice, and do all that I speak</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> Onkelos hinted at this, for he translated [<i>‘ki sh’mi b’kirbo’ — for My Name is in him</i>]: “for in My Name is his word,” as he speaks with it. He said, <i>Then I will be an enemy unto thine enemies</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> for even with the attribute of mercy I will be an enemy to them; <i>and an adversary unto thine adversaries</i> — through him, [the angel], through the attribute of justice. Hence He explained, <i>For Mine angel shall go before thee, and bring thee in unto the Amorite</i> etc. <i>and the Canaanite</i> etc. <i>and I will cut him off</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> when he will bring you to them, that we may know that it is He [through the attribute of justice] that will cut them off. He mentioned them in the singular [“and I will cut <i>him</i> off], for He will cut them all off as if they were one man. Now when this angel dwelled in the midst of Israel, the Holy One, blessed be He, would not have said, <i>For I will not go up in the midst of thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:3.</i> — [for He said] <i>for My Name is in him</i>, so He was in the midst of Israel! But when they sinned by worshipping the golden calf He wanted to remove His Divine Glory<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">See above Note 406.</i> from their midst, and that one of His angels should go before them as His messenger, and Moses pleaded for mercy, and He again caused His Divine Glory to dwell amongst them as before. There I will explain the verses, with the help of G-d.<br>The Rabbis have also hinted to this in Midrash Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 32:8.</i> in that section. Thus they said: “<i>Behold, I send an angel</i>. The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses: ‘The one who guarded the fathers will guard the children.’ And thus you find with Abraham, that when he blessed Isaac he said, <i>He will send His angel before thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:7. The words were actually addressed by Abraham to Eliezer — but the goal of Eliezer’s mission was for Isaac’s blessing.</i> In the case of Jacob we find [that he blessed Joseph’s sons by saying], <i>The angel who hath redeemed me</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 48:16.</i> He said to them: ‘He redeemed me from the hand of Esau; He redeemed me from the hand of Laban; He fed me and sustained me in the years of famine.’ Said the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses: ‘Now too, the one who guarded the fathers will guard the children,’ as it is said, <i>Behold, I send an angel before thee</i>.” Again the Rabbis have said there clearly:<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 32:4.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel: ‘Be heedful of the messenger, for he does not go back on his mission; he is the attribute of justice, <i>be not rebellious against him</i>, etc.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i><br>In any case, according to all authorities the Midrash I have mentioned is true, that as long as Moses lived the angel who was <i>captain of the host</i><sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> did not go with them, for Moses filled his place, similarly to that which is said, <i>And it came to pass, when Moses held up his hand, that Israel prevailed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:11.</i> And in the days of Joshua it was necessary that the angel <i>captain of the host of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> come to him to fight their battles, this being Gabriel who fights for them, and this was why Joshua saw him <i>with his sword drawn in his hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 5:13.</i> because he came <i>to execute vengeance upon the nations, and chastisements upon the peoples</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 149:7.</i>

Verse 21

<i>For he will not pardon your transgression; for My Name is in him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> He is saying: “<i>Be not rebellious against him, for he will not pardon your transgression</i> if you rebel against his word, for he who rebels against him, rebels against the Great Name which is in him, and he deserves to be cut off by the attribute of justice.” It is possible that the expression <i>My Name is in Him</i>, is connected to the above verses: hearken to his voice, for My Name is in him, and his voice is the voice of the Supreme One.

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

THOU SHALT NOT BOW DOWN TO THEIR GODS, NOR SERVE THEM. The Torah has warned against idolatry in many places, and even though there are excessive verses on this subject, the redundancy is not a matter to be concerned about, for because the matter is so stringent — since he who acknowledges the divine nature of the idols, thereby denies the whole Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre <i>R’ei</i>, 54.</i> — therefore the Torah warns against it again and again, like one who says to his servant: “remember continually and do not forget the great principle which I have commanded you, since everything depends on it.” It is possible that in the Ten Commandments He warned against making an idol and worshipping it, and now He warned that if they find a ready-made idol which is worshipped by the nations in the land, that they should not worship it at all, but they should uproot it from the land.
NOR DO AFTER THEIR DEEDS. This may possibly be an admonition against adopting the “ways of the Amorites” [i.e., superstitious practices] which the Sages have enumerated,<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 67a. See “The Commandments,” Vol. II, pp. 28-29.</i> just as He warned against them in another place, saying, <i>Neither shall ye walk in their statutes</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 18:3.</i> on which the Rabbis commented:<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>ibid</i>.</i> “These statutes refer to the ‘ways of the Amorites’ which the Sages have enumerated.” A more all acceptable interpretation is that He is warning here against worshipping an idol in the particular manner in which it is ordinarily worshipped, even if it is a disgraceful act [such as excreting to Baal Peor], just as the Rabbis have interpreted<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 61b.</i> the verse, <i>Take heed… that thou enquire not after their gods, saying: ‘How used these nations to serve their gods? Even so will I do likewise.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 12:30.</i> Thus the meaning of the verse here is as follows: He said, [in the Ten Commandments 20:5], <i>Thou shalt not bow down to their gods, nor serve them</i>, “serving” usually being an act of honor that a servant does to his master, and then He said, additionally that even if that act is not one of honor but is disgusting, such as in connection with Baal Peor which one worships by excreting before it, or throwing a stone at Merkulis,<sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Mercury, the Roman divinity, who was worshipped by throwing stones to his statue.</i> nonetheless if that is the customary manner of worshipping them, you may not do such acts at all. Similarly the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 64a.</i> “Even if he intends to worship Peor in this ignominious way, and even if he intends to throw a stone to Merkulis in a contemptible manner [he is still liable].”

Verse 25

AND YE SHALL SERVE THE ETERNAL YOUR G-D, AND HE WILL BLESS THY BREAD, AND THY WATER. The intention of this verse is as follows. Most idolators acknowledge and know that the revered G-d is <i>G-d of gods, and Lord of lords</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:17.</i> and they do not intend to worship the idols themselves, but they think that because of these acts of worship they will have success in their endeavors. Thus when they worship the sun it is because they have found it to have a beneficial power over their crops, and they find the moon to have influence over fountains and all deep waters, and similarly [they attribute powers] to all the hosts of heaven. They are even more inclined to think that they will be greatly benefitted by worshipping the angels, since they are invested with dignity through ministering before the Great G-d. Therefore this verse states that only through the worship of the Holy One, blessed be He, can you have success and protection, and the uprooting of idolatry<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">As commanded in Verse 24.</i> will not cause damage; on the contrary, it will add goodness and blessing to you, for the Holy One, blessed be He, will bless your “bread,” this being a term which includes all manner of food, and will bless your “water,” which is a generic term for all liquids that people drink. The blessing referred to means increase, so that you will have an exceeding abundance of them.
AND I WILL TAKE SICKNESS AWAY FROM THE MIDST OF THEE. That is to say, through them [the bread and water that I will bless], I will free you from disease, for when your food and drink are good and healthy, they do not cause sicknesses but, on the contrary, heal you. And He states<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> furthermore that there will not be amongst you a woman that miscarries, <i>a miscarrying womb</i><sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 9:14.</i> nor one barren of the womb <i>and with dry breasts</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">Hosea 9:14.</i> for when food and drink and the air are blessed, human bodies become healthy and the organs of reproduction are able to function properly. The verse<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> singles out women because they are liable to miscarriage, and sterility too is more common amongst them than amongst men. It is possible that [male sterility] is included in the expression, <i>and I will take sickness away from the midst of thee</i>, for barrenness is a sickness in bodies. He addresses Himself without specifications to men, and afterwards He mentioned the women, as He said, <i>there shall not be male or female barren among you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:14.</i> The meaning of the expression <i>in thy land</i>, [<i>None shall miscarry, nor be barren, in thy land</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> is to include also the animals, just as He said there, <i>or amongst your cattle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:14.</i> <i>The number of thy days I will fulfill</i><sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 26.</i> means that one will not die prematurely in battle, nor through an epidemic caused by a change in the atmosphere, but only at a ripe age, whatever happens to be the normal span of life during that particular generation, such as seventy or eighty years as in the generation of King David.<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 90:10.</i> I have already mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote">Above at the beginning of <i>Seder Va’eira</i>, and on Genesis 17:1 (Vol. I, p. 215).</i> that these are all miracles, G-d showing <i>wonders in the heavens and in the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 3:3.</i> for the sake of those who do His will. And then He said that just as He will do on their behalf <i>a sign for good</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 86:17.</i> so will He do to their enemies for bad; He will give them <i>a trembling heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:65. — Ramban derives this from the phrase written here: <i>I will send My terror before thee</i> (Verse 27).</i> <i>and in the chambers terror</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:25. — Ramban derives this from the expression here: <i>And I will cause discomfort to all the people to whom thou shalt come</i>.</i> Moreover, He will send the <i>tzir’ah</i> amongst them,<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> this being a certain kind of hornet of the family of the bee. The Sages mention it continually:<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">Machshirin 6:4.</i> “Bees’ honey, hornets’ honey.” The meaning of the verse is that He will send this plague through the atmosphere of their land, like the locust that He had sent in Egypt: <i>the canker-worm, and the caterpillar, and the palmer-worm, His great army</i><sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 2:25.</i> which came in the days of Joel. The meaning of the expression, <i>and she</i> [the hornet] <i>will drive out the Hivite</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> is that this will be the cause of their being driven out of the land, for since the hornets <i>will cover the face of the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:5.</i> and darken it, they will not be able to go into battle. Moreover, it will eat up all their produce in the field, similar to that which is said in the imprecations, <i>Thou shalt carry much seed out into the field, and shalt gather little in; for the locust shall consume it</i>, etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:38.</i> <i>All thy trees and the fruit of thy land shall the locust possess</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 42.</i> Similarly He said here that He will do such things to our enemies.<br>Scripture mentioned here <i>the Hivite, the Canaanite, and the Hittite</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28.</i> [and not the other four nations as well], because it adopted here a shortened form, and the intention is to all those mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23. See Ramban above, 3:8 as to why the Girgashite [the seventh one] is omitted.</i> The correct interpretation appears to me to be that the majority of these three nations [mentioned here] did not go out to battle and thus avoided being killed by the sword, because they remained strongly enclosed in their fortified places. It is against them that He sent only this form of death [through the hornet], in a similar manner to that which is said of Egypt, <i>And thy houses shall be filled, and the houses of all thy servants, and the houses of all the Egyptians</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 10:6.</i> It is this which He said in the Book of Deuteronomy: <i>Moreover the Eternal thy G-d will send the hornet amongst them, until they that are left, and they that hide themselves, perish from before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:20.</i> and it is this hornet that crossed the Jordon with Joshua.<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s statement that the hornets did <i>not</i> cross the Jordan but merely “placed themselves on the east bank of the Jordan and from there injected the poison against them” applies to the hornet of the days of Moses. The one in the days of Joshua did cross the Jordan. This distinction is made in Sotah 36a.</i> So did the Rabbis conclude in Tractate Sotah,<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s statement that the hornets did <i>not</i> cross the Jordan but merely “placed themselves on the east bank of the Jordan and from there injected the poison against them” applies to the hornet of the days of Moses. The one in the days of Joshua did cross the Jordan. This distinction is made in Sotah 36a.</i> saying that the hornet injected a poison into them which caused their death, and indeed there is nowadays also in the hornet a poisonous substance which harms or even kills the victim. And it is written in the Book of Joshua: <i>And ye went over the Jordan, and came unto Jericho; and the men of Jericho fought against you, the Amorite, and the Perizzite, and the Canaanite, and the Hittite, and the Girgashite, the Hivite and the Jebusite; and I delivered them into your hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:11.</i> and it is further written there, <i>And I sent the hornet before you, which drove them out from before you, even the two kings of the Amorites; not with thy sword, nor with thy bow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> The phrase <i>which drove them out</i><sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> refers to <i>those that are left</i><sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 7:20.</i> amongst them, for after I delivered into your hand all the nations mentioned, <i>I sent the hornet</i> to drive out <i>those that are left and they that hide themselves</i>. He mentioned <i>the two kings of the Amorites</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> meaning Sichon and Og whom He had referred to earlier. All this you have done <i>not with thy sword, nor with thy bow</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i><br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the <i>tzir’ah</i> refers to a disease in the body, the word being of the root <i>tzara’ath</i> (leprosy). But there is no need for this interpretation.<br><i>And ye shall serve the Eternal your G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> means that service [by offering or prayer] is to be devoted to the Proper Name [i.e., the Tetragrammaton]. The verse stating <i>and He will bless… and I will take</i>, [thus changing from the third-person pronoun to the first-person pronoun], is similar to the verse <i>and thou wilt keep all His statutes… for I am the Eternal that healeth thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:26. In that case too the pronouns change.</i> I have already explained it, and the person learned [in the mystic lore of the Cabala] will understand the verse here from what I have written there.

Verse 32

THOU SHALT MAKE NO COVENANT WITH THEM, NOR WITH THEIR GODS. He warned here against making a covenant <i>with them</i> [the seven nations] to save them and keep them alive; <i>nor with their gods</i>, this being a warning against making a covenant with the nations to leave them their idols, but instead we are to destroy them and break their pillars in pieces.<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> It is possible that the verse is stating that we are not to make a covenant with them and their gods together, but we are to destroy them and break their idols in pieces, and the intention is to state that as long as they worship their gods we are not to make any covenant with them, but if they accepted upon themselves not to worship the idols, we may leave them unharmed.

Verse 33

KI’ (FOR) THOU WILT SERVE THEIR GODS, ‘KI’ (FOR) THEY WILL BE A SNARE UNTO THEE. “Both words <i>ki</i> here have the meaning of <i>asher</i> (that),<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi’s interpretation of the verse is thus as follows: “The idolators shall not dwell in your land lest they make you sin against Me ‘that’ you serve their gods ‘that’ it be a snare against you.” Ramban will explain the word <i>ki</i> as meaning “for,” as explained further on. — The J.P.S. translation using the words “for” follows thus Ramban’s interpretation.</i> and we find this in many places. This is the meaning of the [Aramaic word] <i>ie</i> which is one of the four usages of the word <i>ki</i> as we find in many places,<sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">See Rosh Hashanah 3 a, Rashi, and Gittin 90a.</i> and this [Aramaic word <i>ie</i> is the Hebrew] <i>im</i> which in many verses has the meaning of <i>asher</i> (that), etc.” Thus far is Rashi’s language. But it is not so.<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote">For according to Rashi the first <i>ki</i> would mean “when that,” and the second <i>ki</i> would mean only “that” — thus: “lest they make you sin against Me <i>when that</i> you serve their gods <i>that</i> will be a snare against you” (Mizrachi). The two identical Hebrew words thus have different meanings in the same verse.</i> Instead, the meaning of the verse is: “They shall not dwell in thy land for they will be a snare unto thee lest they make thee sin against Me, for you will serve their gods.” Similarly He said, <i>Take heed to thyself, lest thou make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land whither thou goest, lest they be a snare in the midst of thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:12.</i> The meaning of this verse is that their dwelling in your land will be a snare unto you and a source of stumbling, lest they make you sin against Me through their evil ways and their corrupt doings, for you will serve their gods when they will persuade and beguile you to do so.

Chapter 24



Verse 1

AND UNTO MOSES HE SAID: ‘COME UP UNTO THE ETERNAL etc.’ “This section was told to Moses before the giving of the Ten Commandments, on the fourth day of Sivan.” This is Rashi’s language. “<i>And the Eternal said unto Moses: ‘Come up to Me into the mountain, and be there’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12 (further in this section).</i> — this was said to Moses after the Giving of the Torah.” These too are Rashi’s words. But if so, the sections of the Torah are not in chronological order, nor even in their ordinary sense! Moreover, it is written here, <i>And Moses came and told the people all the words of the Eternal, and all the ordinances</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> which are these ordinances written above, concerning which He said, <i>And these are the ordinances which thou shalt set before them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:1.</i> For it is not correct to interpret the expression: <i>and all the ordinances</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> to mean [as Rashi wrote], the ordinances which “the sons of Noah”<sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 417, Notes 147-8.</i> were commanded, or the laws which were given to the Israelites in Marah<sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 15:25.</i> which they had already heard and knew, and besides, the word <i>vayesapeir (and he told)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> always indicates new things which one tells!<br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra has already grasped this subject correctly, in explaining the verses to be in their proper order, when he commented:<sup class="footnote-marker">470</sup><i class="footnote">On the preceding Verse (23:33).</i> “Up to here is the Book of the Covenant.” On the basis of this statement it can be seen that all the sections of the Torah are in methodical arrangement. For after the Giving of the Torah immediately on the same day G-d said to Moses, <i>Thus shall you tell the children of Israel: Ye yourselves have seen that I have talked with you from heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:19.</i> and He began to warn them again against idolatry, by saying, <i>Ye shall not make with Me</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> and He continued to command him, <i>Now these are the ordinances which thou shalt set before them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:1.</i> and all the commandments following that, and finally He finished with the admonition against the worship of idols which they find in the Land, and against making a covenant with their worshippers. He then said to Moses, “After you have commanded them this, <i>come up unto the Eternal, thou and Aaron</i>.” The section mentions that Moses did according to the command of G-d, and came to the camp <i>and told the people all the words of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> as He had commanded him, <i>Thus shall you tell the children of Israel: Ye yourselves have seen</i> etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:19.</i> <i>and all the ordinances</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> as He had commanded him, <i>Now these are the ordinances which thou shalt set before them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:1.</i> The people received everything with joy and said, <i>All that the Eternal hath spoken will we do</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">Above 19:8. See though my Hebrew commentary, p. 447, where it is pointed out that since this verse relates to an event <i>before</i> the Revelation and Ramban is now discussing the events <i>after</i> the Revelation, we must perforce understand his use of that verse, in a stylistic manner, namely, that the people joyfully accepted upon themselves the duty of observing all of G-d’s commandments.</i> meaning that all these things which G-d has told you we will do, for we believe in your words; just as he narrated in the Book of Deuteronomy [that the people said to him], <i>and thou shalt speak unto us all that the Eternal our G-d may speak unto thee; and we will hear it, and do it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">474</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:24.</i> and then Moses wrote them down. Thus on that day he wrote down in a book all that he had been commanded — the statutes, the ordinances, and the laws — and he <i>rose up early in the morning</i><sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> of the following day to make a covenant with them concerning all this. He built the altar and offered the sacrifices,<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4.</i> and put half of the blood upon the altar of G-d, and half of it he put in basins<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> [in order to sprinkle upon the people],<sup class="footnote-marker">477</sup><i class="footnote">As explained further in Ramban, (also in Rashi). For the reason of exact division into two equal parts see further in the text of Ramban and also in Note 479.</i> and he took the book which he had written the day before and read it in their hearing,<sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> and they accepted upon themselves to make the covenant with Him, saying. <i>All that the Eternal hath spoken will we do, and hearken</i><sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> to you and to whatever you will command in His Name. Then he sprinkled upon them half of the blood [which he had put in the basins], for this is the sign of a covenant, when two things<sup class="footnote-marker">479</sup><i class="footnote">By putting half of the blood upon the altar of G-d and the other half upon the people, Moses indicated that “the two [parties to the covenant] come into equal parts.” See Deuteronomy 26:17-18, and also Vayikra Rabbah 6:5, where the equal division of the blood is explained as signifying that G-d swore to Israel never to exchange it for another nation, and Israel swore eternal fidelity to G-d.</i> come in equal parts. Now after he finished what he did with them, he had to fulfill the word of G-d which He told him, <i>Come up… thou and Aaron</i>, etc. and it is with reference to this that it is said, <i>Then went up Moses, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">480</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> He completed that which he had been commanded,<sup class="footnote-marker">481</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., <i>And Moses alone shall come near unto the Eternal</i> (Verse 2).</i> by coming near alone unto the Eternal. It is with reference to this that it is said, <i>And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> Thus the act of the covenant took place on the day after the Giving of the Torah, and on that day was the ascent, when Moses went up into the mountain and he stayed from then on for forty days. It is with reference to this that Scripture explains, <i>and on the seventh day He called unto Moses out of the midst of the cloud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">483</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> [i.e., <i>the seventh day</i> of the month Sivan, which was the day after the Giving of the Torah], and it is said, <i>And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> All this is correctly and clearly explained.<br>Now I have seen in the Mechilta<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta above, 19:10.</i> That the Rabbis differed on this matter. Some say<sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael.</i> that the making of the covenant took place before the Giving of the Torah — on the fifth day of Sivan — and Moses said to them: “Now you are bound, held and tied; tomorrow come and accept upon yourselves all the commandments.” But Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Yehudah says: “All these acts were done on one and the same day,” that is to say all these acts were performed on the same day, namely the day after the Torah was given — all that Moses told the people and the writing of the Book of the Covenant — all as we have explained. And to this one [i.e., Rabbi Yosei the son of Rabbi Yehudah] we listen, since he has spoken according to the accepted opinion.<sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">See Peah 4:1 for origin of this expression [“to this one we listen etc.”].</i>
<i>And unto Moses He said</i>. The reason for this kind of expression [when it should have said, as elsewhere, <i>And the Eternal spoke unto Moses</i>], is that up till now the commandments and the ordinances were addressed to the children of Israel, therefore Scripture said here that this particular commandment was given to Moses, that he alone should do it; thus He commanded him: “After you have set before them the commandments and the ordinances, and have made with them the covenant, come up to Me.” This was why Moses fulfilled the first command [i.e., of telling the people the section beginning with <i>Ye yourselves have seen</i> — above 20:19 — up to <i>for they will be a snare unto thee</i> — 23:33], on the sixth day of Sivan, [following the Revelation which took place on that morning], and on the seventh he rose up early in the morning and made with them the covenant, and after that he went up into the mountain, he and those that were asked to come,<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel (Verse 1).</i> as they were commanded.<sup class="footnote-marker">488</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., just as at the time of the Giving of the Torah Moses had a place designated for himself, Aaron a place designated for himself, and the people a place designated for themselves (see Ramban above 19:19), so here too Moses approached closer than Aaron, etc.</i>
<i>Come up to the Eternal</i>. In line with the simple meaning of Scripture, the reason for this expression [when it should have said: “Come up unto Me”], is because it is the Scriptural style to mention the proper name instead of the pronoun, such as: <i>And Lemech said… Ye wives of Lemech;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">489</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 4:23. It should have said: “My wives.”</i> <i>and the Eternal sent Jerubaal and Bedan and Jephthah and Samuel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:11. Since Samuel was the speaker, he should have said: “and myself.”</i> A similar case is the verse, <i>and cause Thy face to shine upon Thy Sanctuary that is desolate, for the Eternal’s sake</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">491</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 9:17. It should have said: “for Thy sake.”</i> In the Talmud,<sup class="footnote-marker">492</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 38b.</i> however, we find that they<sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">“They” — the Rabbis, asked. To understand, however, the following references in Ramban it is necessary to know that the question was addressed by a <i>min</i> [a Jewish infidel], to Rav Idie for sectarian purposes. The answer here quoted was given by Rav Idie.</i> asked, “It should have said, ‘come up to Me,’” and therefore they said, “this refers to Mattatron, whose name is even as the Name of his Master.”<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 23:20.</i> That is to say, “<i>And unto Moses He</i> — the Divine Name mentioned at the beginning of this subject, namely, <i>And the Eternal said unto Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">495</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:19.</i> — said, come up to Mattatron, for My Name is in him.” The meaning is thus: “Come up to the place of the Glory where the great angel is,” and the intention was that Moses should come <i>into the midst of the cloud</i><sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> where the Glory of G-d was, but he should not come right up to the Proper Divine Name, <i>for man shall not see Me, and live</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">496</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:20.</i> The intention of our Rabbis is thus not at all as Rashi had written above.<sup class="footnote-marker">497</sup><i class="footnote">23:20. — Ramban refers to what Rashi wrote there, that the verse mentioned further on [after the sin with the golden calf], <i>and I will send an angel before thee</i> (33:2) has reference to Mattatron. That is not correct, for Moses did not consent that the angel mentioned there should go with them (Abusaula). See also Ramban above 23:20 for a full discussion.</i> In Tractate Sanhedrin also the Rabbi [Rashi] turned the subject around.<sup class="footnote-marker">498</sup><i class="footnote">In Sanhedrin 38 b, Rashi commented: “This is Mattatron. It was he who said <i>Come up unto the Eternal</i>.” Ramban’s opinion, as explained above, is that the Eternal said, “Come up to Mattatron.”</i> Now I have already mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">499</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:20, and in <i>Seder Bo</i> 12:12.</i> the Rabbis’ intention concerning this name [Mattatron], and all their words are true. In that homily, however, [related in Tractate Sanhedrin, concerning the infidel’s question to Rav Idie],<sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">“They” — the Rabbis, asked. To understand, however, the following references in Ramban it is necessary to know that the question was addressed by a <i>min</i> [a Jewish infidel], to Rav Idie for sectarian purposes. The answer here quoted was given by Rav Idie.</i> the Sages spoke in an abstract manner, since Rav Idie did not want, Heaven forbid, to reveal to that infidel who asked him the question, the matter of the great Mattatron and its secret! Instead, he mentioned to him that the verse speaks of the angel who is “the guide of the road” of the world below; and hence he told him, that “even as a guide we refused to accept him, for it is written [that Moses said], <i>If ‘panecha’</i> — [literally: ‘Thy face’ or ‘Thy presence’] <i>go not up, carry us not up hence</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">500</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:15.</i> for we accepted no messenger, only the Revered G-d. I have already explained<sup class="footnote-marker">501</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:3.</i> clearly the secret of <i>panim</i> (face) and the whole subject to those learned in the secret lore of the Cabala, in the section of the Giving of the Torah.

Verse 2

AND MOSES ALONE SHALL COME NEAR UNTO THE ETERNAL. In the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra this too is a case where a proper name is used instead of a pronoun, for after the expression, <i>Come up unto the Eternal</i>, it should have said, “and you alone shall come near,” but such is the Scriptural style, as I have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">502</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> Similarly: <i>And the Eternal caused to rain upon Sodom and upon Gomorrah brimstone and fire from the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">503</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:24.</i> which means “from Him;” <i>And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">504</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 10:29.</i> which means “his father-in-law.” Also: <i>And the Eternal sent Jerubaal, and Bedan, and Jephthah, and Samuel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 12:11. Since Samuel was the speaker, he should have said: “and myself.”</i> and similarly: <i>Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel, and all the heads of the tribes… unto King Solomon</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:1. The meaning is: he gathered them “to himself.”</i><br>The correct interpretation here appears to me to be that this commandment was addressed also to Aaron, and he too heard the Voice of G-d saying to Moses, <i>Come up unto the Eternal, thou, and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel; and worship ye afar off</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">506</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> And if so, it was necessary that the name of the one who was to draw near [i.e., Moses] be expressly mentioned, for it was he alone who was to come near [and not Aaron]. And even if [we were to explain that when G-d said, <i>Come up unto the Eternal</i> etc.] He spoke to Moses directly [and Aaron did not hear it], it would still be necessary to explain that “you Moses alone shall come near unto the Eternal,” and the mere pronoun “thou” would not have sufficed.<sup class="footnote-marker">507</sup><i class="footnote">For since Aaron’s name was after all mentioned in the command [in Verse 1], it was already necessary that Moses’ name be designated in Verse 2, so that he would know that it was he who was to come near, otherwise it would have included Aaron as well. Therefore etc.</i> Therefore He said, <i>And Moses alone shall come near; but they shall not come near</i>. This is the reason for the word <i>l’vado</i> (alone), to exclude Aaron who had been included previously with Moses as far as the commandment [to “come up”].

Verse 3

AND MOSES CAME AND TOLD THE PEOPLE ALL THE WORDS OF THE ETERNAL. At the time that this whole commandment mentioned here was given, Moses was at the place where <i>he drew near unto the thick darkness where G-d was</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">508</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:18.</i> and now he came to that “far off” place where the people had been at the time of the Revelation,<sup class="footnote-marker">508</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:18.</i> and told them all that he had been commanded [i.e., beginning with <i>Ye yourselves have seen</i> — above 20:19 — up to the end of all the commandments and ordinances, 23:33], and they listened to his voice. Scripture does not say here: “and he came down from the mountain,” for they were all then <i>at the lower part of the mountain</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">509</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:17.</i> and not at the top where the Glory of G-d was; [the difference] was only that Moses was near the place of <i>the thick darkness</i>, whilst the people <i>stood from afar</i> at the time of the giving of the commandments, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">510</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:19, and 20:15.</i> When Moses left his place and began coming towards the people, all the heads of their tribes and their elders came up to the place where <i>the priests that come near to the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">511</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:22.</i> stood, and said to him, <i>Now therefore why should we die? for this great fire will consume us;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">512</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:22.</i> <i>Go thou near, and hear</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">513</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> for they thought that the Revered G-d Himself would tell them all the commandments of the Torah just as He had told them the Ten Commandments. Then Moses came together with the heads of the tribes and the elders to the place where the people were standing and told all of them all the words of G-d, and they said, “<i>We will do</i> all that He has commanded us in the Ten Commandments, and <i>we will hearken</i><sup class="footnote-marker">514</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> to your voice in everything that you have commanded, or will command in His Name, exalted be He.” When Moses went back afterwards to the edge of the mountain with the elders, as G-d had commanded him,<sup class="footnote-marker">506</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> then G-d said to him again, <i>Come up to Me into the mountain, and be there</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> It was at that time that He informed him, <i>I have heard the voice of the words of the people, which they have spoken unto thee; they have well said all that they have spoken</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">516</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:25.</i> and He commanded him: <i>Go say to them: Return ye to your tents. But as for thee, stand thou here by Me, and I will speak unto thee all the commandment, and the statutes, and the ordinances, which thou shalt teach them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">517</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 27-28.</i> It is with reference to this that He said here, <i>And I will give thee the Tablets of stone, and the law and the commandment</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">518</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12. See Vol. I, p. 7 for Ramban’s interpretation of each term mentioned.</i> meaning, that to you alone I will give the law and the commandments which you will teach them, and they will keep them as they have undertaken to do.

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND HE SENT ‘NA’AREI’ (THE YOUNG MEN OF) THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. These were the firstborns, as Onkelos rendered it, for it was they who used to offer the burnt-offerings and the peace-offerings. But I do not know why Scripture designates the firstborns by the term <i>na’arei</i> (the young men)? Perhaps it is because Scripture mentioned the elders who are <i>the nobles of the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">519</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 11.</i> therefore it called the firstborns <i>ne’arim</i> (young men), for in relation to the elders they were young. It thus indicates that Moses sent them to offer the sacrifices not because of their status in wisdom, for they were not yet advanced in age, but only an account of the birthright, through which they were set aside to offer sacrifices.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, <i>the young men of the children of Israel</i> were the youth of Israel who had not tasted of sin,<sup class="footnote-marker">520</sup><i class="footnote">Erubin 21b.</i> and had never come near a woman, for they were the most select and holy of the people, in a similar manner to that which the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">521</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 43b.</i> “The young men of Israel who have not tasted of sin<sup class="footnote-marker">522</sup><i class="footnote">“Who have not tasted of sin” is not found in our Gemara, but it is present in manuscripts of the Talmud and other early works (see Dikdukei Sofrim, <i>ibid.</i>, Note 6).</i> are destined to give forth a fragrance like the Lebanon etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">523</sup><i class="footnote">“As it said, <i>His branches shall spread, and his beauty shall be as the olive-tree, and his fragrance as Lebanon (Hosea 14:7)</i>” (<i>ibid</i>). The word Lebanon [of the root <i>lavan</i> — white] is an allusion here to the Sanctuary which “whitens” [atones for] the sins of Israel. The thought suggested then is that these young men who have not tasted of sin are as beneficial to Israel as the Sanctuary (Maharsha).</i>
OXEN UNTO THE ETERNAL. The reason they brought oxen is that as long as Israel was in the wilderness they feared the attribute of justice, this being indeed the source of their mistake at the incident of the golden calf — as I will mention there.<sup class="footnote-marker">524</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 32:1.</i> And so they now offered burnt-offerings and sacrificed peace-offerings all of oxen, for a similar reason to that of the bullock brought by the anointed priest [for a sin-offering],<sup class="footnote-marker">525</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 4:3.</i> and the bullock which the court brings for an erroneous decision [which contradicts in part what the Torah enjoins],<sup class="footnote-marker">526</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> and the bullock for idolatry,<sup class="footnote-marker">527</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 15:24.</i> as well as the Red Heifer.<sup class="footnote-marker">528</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:2. See Ramban there: “Its redness alludes to the attribute of justice, etc.”</i>

Verse 6

AND MOSES TOOK HALF OF THE BLOOD AND HE PLACED IT ‘BA’AGANOTH.’ These are vessels made unlike the shape of the regular basins of the altar. Hence Scripture states that half of the blood of the sacrifices which Moses intended to sprinkle on the people, he put into these vessels, and the other half he sprinkled upon the altar from the regular basins in which he had received the blood, as is the customary way with all offerings. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said that <i>ba’aganoth</i> served for both halves, [and thus the word signifies the regular basins of the altar]. Such is also the opinion of Onkelos, who translated <i>ba’aganoth</i> as <i>b’mizr’kaya</i> [a term referring to the regular basins].

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AND THEY SAW THE G-D OF ISRAEL. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained: “They saw Him in a prophetic vision, this being similar to the verse: <i>I saw the Eternal standing beside the altar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">529</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 9:1.</i> — <i>And there was under His feet the like of a paved work of sapphire stone</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">530</sup><i class="footnote">Continuing Verse 10 before us.</i> This is identical with what the prophet Ezekiel saw: <i>as the appearance of a sapphire stone was the likeness of a throne</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">531</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:26.</i> — <i>And the like of the very heaven for clearness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">530</sup><i class="footnote">Continuing Verse 10 before us.</i> means that they saw under the paved work of sapphire stone the likeness of the very heaven for clearness, which is identical with <i>the firmament, like the color of the terrible ice, stretched forth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">532</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 22.</i> over the heads of the living creatures [that Ezekiel saw]. Now here it is written, <i>And they saw the G-d of Israel</i>, and there it is written, <i>This is the living creature that I saw under the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">533</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:20.</i> [In saying that he saw the living creature <i>under the G-d of Israel</i>, the prophet Ezekiel] used a shortened expression, for the living creature was under the firmament which was under the throne, and all this was under the Glorious Name.” [Thus far is Ibn Ezra’s language.]<br>In line with the simple meaning of Scripture the expression <i>the G-d of Israel</i> is used here to indicate that the merit of their father Israel [Jacob] was with them, and it was through his merit that they beheld this vision. And by the way of the Truth, [the mystic doctrine of the Cabala], it is because Scripture mentioned at the Giving of the Torah, <i>and G-d spoke</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">534</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:3.</i> this being identical with the verse, <i>Behold, the Eternal our G-d hath shown us His glory and His greatness, and we have heard His voice out of the midst of the fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">535</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21.</i> therefore Scripture explained here that they saw <i>the G-d of Israel</i>. It does not say as it does in all other places, <i>the Eternal, the G-d of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">536</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 5:1, etc.</i> but mentioned this [<i>the G-d of Israel</i>] in order to say that the seventy elders perceived in this vision more than the rest of the people who saw upon the earth <i>His great fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">537</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> because the people saw through a partition of <i>cloud and thick darkness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">538</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 5:19.</i> Onkelos hinted at this, for he translated here, “and they <i>saw</i> the Glory of the G-d of Israel,” but did not render it, “and the Glory of G-d <i>revealed</i> itself to them,” as is his way of translating in other places.<sup class="footnote-marker">539</sup><i class="footnote">E.g., in Numbers 16:19, where it states, <i>And the Glory of the Eternal appeared unto all the congregation</i>, Onkelos translated: “and the Glory of the Eternal <i>revealed</i> itself…” Here, however, he wrote “and they saw,” in order to indicate that they achieved a greater insight in this vision than the rest of the people.</i>

Verse 11

AND TO ‘ATZILEI’ (THE NOBLES OF) THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. These are Nadab, and Abihu, and the elders mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">540</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> They are called <i>atzilim</i> [of the root <i>atzal</i>, to emanate] because the spirit of G-d emanated upon them. Similarly, <i>I have called thee ‘mei’atzilehah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">541</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:9.</i> — from those upon whom His spirit has emanated, or the great people upon whom honor has descended from royalty.
The meaning of the expression <i>He laid not His hand</i>, is that since He had said, <i>But let not the priests and the people break through to come up unto the Eternal, lest He break forth upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">542</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:24.</i> therefore He let it be known here that they had been careful to observe that command and that He did not break forth upon them, and that the nobles of the children of Israel were worthy of that which they saw in this vision; thus the meaning of the verse is that <i>they beheld G-d</i> but they did not break through <i>to come up unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">542</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:24.</i>
<i>And they did eat and drink</i>. This means that they ate there the peace-offerings at the lower part of the mountain before G-d previous to their returning to their tents, for peace-offerings have to be eaten within an enclosure; in Jerusalem they were eaten within the wall of the city,<sup class="footnote-marker">543</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 112b.</i> in Shiloh<sup class="footnote-marker">544</sup><i class="footnote">The Tabernacle stood in Shiloh, in the territory of the tribe of Ephraim, for three hundred and sixty-nine years.
