After Shiloh was destroyed by the Philistines, the Tabernacle stood in Nob and then in Gibeon — a period of fifty-seven years — and then finally the Sanctuary was built by King Solomon in Jerusalem.</i> they could be eaten within sight of Shiloh,<sup class="footnote-marker">543</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 112b.</i> and here they were eaten before the altar at the lower part of the mountain, and not in the camp. 
The meaning of the expression <i>and they drank</i>, is that they made it an occasion for rejoicing and festival, for such is one’s duty to rejoice at the receiving of the Torah, just as He commanded when they finished writing all the words of the Torah upon the stones, <i>And thou shalt sacrifice peace-offerings, and shalt eat there; and thou shalt rejoice before the Eternal thy G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">545</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 27:7.</i> And with reference to Solomon it is written, <i>Wisdom and knowledge is granted unto thee etc.</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">546</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 1:12.</i> and immediately after that, <i>he came to Jerusalem… and made a feast for all his servants</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">547</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 3:15.</i> “Said Rabbi Eleazar:<sup class="footnote-marker">548</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 1:9.</i> From here you learn that we make a feast at the finishing of the Torah.” With reference to David, Solomon’s father, it is likewise said that when the people gave of their free-will towards the building of the Sanctuary, <i>And they offered sacrifices unto the Eternal, and offered burnt-offerings unto the Eternal etc., and they did eat and drink before the Eternal on that day with great gladness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">549</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:21-22.</i> Similarly, here too on the day of the “wedding” of the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">550</sup><i class="footnote">Taanith 26b.</i> they did likewise.

Verse 12

AND THE ETERNAL SAID UNTO MOSES: ‘COME UP TO ME INTO THE MOUNTAIN.’ This is the same command which He had said to him on the preceeding day [i.e., on the sixth of Sivan], <i>Come up unto the Eternal;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">551</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> <i>and Moses alone shall come near unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">552</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> and now on the seventh day of Sivan He said additionally to him, <i>and be there, and I will give thee the Tablets of stone</i> etc., for Moses was to stay on the mountain until He would give him <i>the Tablets of stone, and the law and the commandment</i>. The expression <i>which I have written</i> refers back to <i>the Tablets of stone; that thou mayest teach them</i> relates to <i>the law and the commandment</i>. Thus the meaning of the verse is: “and I will give thee the Tablets of stone which I have written, and the law and the commandment that thou mayest teach them.” This is identical with what He said in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>And I will speak unto thee all the commandment, and the statutes, and the ordinances, which thou shalt teach them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">553</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:28.</i><br>Rashi wrote: “<i>Which I have written</i> in the Tablets of stone.<sup class="footnote-marker">554</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is not found in our Rashi.</i> <i>That thou mayest teach them</i>, for all the six hundred and thirteen commandments are implicit in the Ten Commandments.”<sup class="footnote-marker">555</sup><i class="footnote">Our Rashi adds: “And Rabbeinu Saadia Gaon listed in his ‘Azharoth’ [Exhortations — liturgical poems treating of the Divine Commandments] the commandments which may be associated with each of the Ten Commandments.” — See further in my Foreword to “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. VIII-X.</i> And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented: “<i>The law</i>, this refers to the first and second commandments; <i>and the commandment</i> refers to the other eight mentioned.” It is a comment of no value, since the verse in Deuteronomy mentioned above, <i>And I will speak unto thee</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">553</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:28.</i> testifies that He is speaking about all the commandments. In accordance with the opinion of our Rabbis it is possible that the expression <i>which I have written</i> is a hint that the whole Torah was written before Him before the creation of the world, as I have mentioned at the beginning of the Book of Genesis.<sup class="footnote-marker">556</sup><i class="footnote">Vol. I, pp. 8, 14-15.</i>

Verse 13

AND MOSES ROSE UP, AND JOSHUA HIS MINISTER. “I do not know in what capacity Joshua was serving here. But it appears to me that the disciple was accompanying the master as far as the place where the limits of the mountain were marked out, for beyond them Joshua was not permitted to go, and from there <i>Moses went up</i> alone <i>into the mountain of G-d</i>, while Joshua pitched his tent there for the whole of the forty days. Thus we find that when Moses came down from the mountain it is written, <i>And Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">557</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:17.</i> from which we learn that Joshua was not with them in the camp” [at the time of the making of the golden calf]. Thus far is Rashi’s language.<br>In my opinion, Joshua was one of the seventy elders [who were asked to ascend the mountain], for there was nobody more worthy amongst the seventy elders of Israel to approach G-d than he, and when Moses separated from them [to ascend higher], Joshua accompanied his master up to the border [beyond which he was not permitted to go]. Now do not object to my explanation on this point from what the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">558</sup><i class="footnote">Tanchuma <i>Beha’alothcha</i>, 16. Rashi in Verse 10 here brings part of the Midrash with reference to Nadab and Abihu.</i> concerning the punishment of these elders at Taberah,<sup class="footnote-marker">559</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:3. The place was called Taberah (which means “burning”) <i>because the Eternal burnt among them</i> — that is, among the most distinguished and prominent ones among them, namely the elders (see Rashi <i>ibid.</i>, Verse 1). Now the reason why the elders were singled out for punishment at that time is stated by the Rabbis as follows: Since at the time of the Giving of the Torah they gazed more intently than they were permitted to, behaving as if they were eating and drinking (see here Verse 11), they were liable to death. But since G-d did not wish to disturb the joy caused by the Giving of the Torah, He waited with their punishment till Taberah. — Now on the basis of this Midrash you might think that Joshua, too, was like the elders and unworthy of seeing Divine visions. But, concludes Ramban, this was not the case with Joshua.</i> for they said so concerning all of them except Joshua, for he was indeed worthy to see visions of G-d and to receive prophecy.

Verse 14

AND UNTO THE ELDERS HE SAID: ‘TARRY YE HERE FOR US.’ The meaning of this is that when Moses parted from them with his minister, he commanded them that they should tarry there. It does not mean that they were to stay there day and night until their return, for he said, <i>and behold, Aaron and Hur are with you; whosoever hath a cause, let him come near unto them</i>, and it is in the camp that parties to a dispute would be found, since that was where the seat of justice was, and he had already told everybody, <i>Return ye to your tents</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">560</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:27.</i> But the meaning of <i>tarry ye here</i> is that they should stay at that place, and should not break through to come up to them, even to the place where Joshua was, until he [Moses] would come back to them.<br>In my opinion it is possible that the explanation of the verse is as follows: “Sit<sup class="footnote-marker">561</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus takes the Hebrew word <i>sh’vu</i> [translated as “tarry”] in its literal meaning: “sit” — sit in court in our place and act as a substitute for us.</i> in our place and serve as a substitute for us in the camp; <i>Aaron and Hur are with you</i>, and <i>whosoever hath a cause</i> — one of those hard causes that they would bring to me<sup class="footnote-marker">562</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 1:17.</i> — <i>let him come near unto them</i> in my place.” He said <i>unto them</i> as a special recognition to Aaron and Hur, for they were to come before all the elders and they would all be assembled at one place, just as he said <i>Aaron and Hur are with you</i>. Thus Moses commanded that the elders together with Aaron and Hur should sit as a court, just as he himself did, over the officers of thousands and hundreds, until he returns, since he knew that he would tarry in the mountain. He said: <i>for us</i> [<i>tarry ye here ‘for us’</i>] as a mark of honor to his disciple, just as he said to Joshua, <i>Choose us out men</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">563</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:9.</i> This is a correct interpretation. But Rashi wrote: “<i>And unto the elders he said</i> — when he left the camp, <i>Tarry ye here for us</i> — stay you with the rest of the people so as to be ready to judge each man’s dispute.” But this is impossible, for they were not at that moment in the camp, and what sense would there be for him to tell them so when they were in the camp and had already been appointed as judges!<br>Terumah

Chapter 25



Verse 1

Now that G-d had told Israel <i>face to face</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:4.</i> the Ten Commandments, and had further commanded them through Moses some of the precepts which are like general principles to the [individual] commandments of the Torah — in the same way that our Rabbis were accustomed to deal with strangers who come to be converted to the Jewish faith<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 47 a: “We inform him of some of the light commandments and of some of the weightiest …” The convert to Judaism is thus not taught the whole Torah prior to his conversion but only some of the essentials thereof, which is followed by his total commitment to observe whatever the Torah will command. Ramban’s language clearly indicates that the procedure of the Rabbis with converts followed the pattern of events at Sinai.</i> — and now that the Israelites accepted upon themselves to do all that He would command them through Moses and He made a covenant with them concerning all this, from now on they are His people and He is their G-d<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 26:12.</i> This is in accordance with the condition He made with them at the beginning: <i>Now, therefore, if ye will indeed hearken unto My voice, and keep My covenant, then ye shall be Mine own treasure</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:5.</i> and He said further: <i>and ye shall be unto Me a kingdom of priests, and a holy nation</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> They are now holy, in that they are worthy that there be amongst them a Sanctuary through which He makes His Divine Glory dwell among them. Therefore He first commanded concerning the Tabernacle, so that He have amongst them a house dedicated to His name, from where He would speak with Moses and command the children of Israel. Thus the main purpose of the Tabernacle was to contain a place in which the Divine Glory rests, this being the ark, just as He said, <i>And there will I meet with thee, and I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i> Therefore He first gave the commandment about the ark and the ark-cover, for they are first in importance. Next to the ark He gave the commandment about the table and the candelabrum, which are vessels just like the ark, and because they indicate the purpose for which the Tabernacle was made. Moses, however, preceded to mention in the section of <i>Vayakheil: the Tabernacle, its Tent, and its covering</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 35:11. And then in the following verse mentioned: <i>the ark…</i></i> and in that order Bezalel made them [first the Tabernacle and then the ark],<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:8-38. 37:1-9.</i> because from the practical end it is proper to build the house first [and then make its vessels].<br>The secret of the Tabernacle is that the Glory which abode upon Mount Sinai [openly] should abide upon it in a concealed manner. For just as it is said there, <i>And the glory of the Eternal abode upon Mount Sinai</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:16.</i> and it is further written, <i>Behold, the Eternal our G-d hath shown us His glory and His greatness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21.</i> so it is written of the Tabernacle, <i>and the glory of the Eternal filled the Tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:34.</i> Twice is this verse, <i>and the glory of the Eternal filled the Tabernacle</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:34.</i> mentioned in connection with the Tabernacle,<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, and in Verse 35.</i> to correspond with <i>His glory and His greatness</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:21.</i> Thus Israel always had with them in the Tabernacle the Glory which appeared to them on Mount Sinai. And when Moses went into the Tabernacle, he would hear the Divine utterance being spoken to him in the same way as on Mount Sinai. Thus just as it is said at the Giving of the Torah: <i>Out of heaven He made thee to hear His voice, that He might instruct thee; and upon earth He made thee to see His great fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> so it is written of the Tabernacle, <i>and he heard the voice speaking unto him from above the ark-cover…from between the two cherubim; and He spoke unto him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> The expression “speaking unto him” is mentioned here twice in order to indicate that which the Rabbis have said in the Tradition<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Bamidmar Rabbah 14:22.</i> that the Voice would come from heaven to Moses from upon the ark-cover, and from there He spoke with him; for every Divine utterance with Moses came from heaven during daytime,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Vayikra Rabbah 1:3: “But to the prophets of Israel the Holy One, blessed be He, revealed Himself at daytime.”</i> and was heard <i>from between the two cherubim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> similar to what is said, <i>and thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 4:36.</i> It is for this reason that the two cherubim were made of gold.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18. — In order to resemble “the fire” that was on Mount Sinai. (Tziyoni).</i> And Scripture so states: <i>where I will meet with you, to speak there unto thee;<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:42.</i> and it shall be sanctified by My glory</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 43.</i> for there [in the Tabernacle] will be the appointed place for the Divine utterance, <i>and it will be sanctified by My glory</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 43.</i><br>Now he who looks carefully at the verses mentioned at the Giving of the Torah, and understands what we have written about them,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 20:16, 24:10, and further here, Verse 21.</i> will perceive the secret of the Tabernacle and the Sanctuary [built later by King Solomon]. He will also be able to understand it from what Solomon in his wisdom said in his prayer in the Sanctuary: <i>O Eternal, the G-d of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:23.</i> just as is said at Mount Sinai: <i>And they saw the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:10.</i> Solomon however added the Name <i>the Eternal</i> because of a matter which we have alluded to above;<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:10.</i> for <i>the G-d of Israel sitteth upon the cherubim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 19:15.</i> just as is said: <i>And the glory of the G-d of Israel was over them above. This is the living creature that I saw, under the G-d of Israel by the river Chebar; and I knew that they were cherubim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 10:19-20.</i> and David said, <i>and gold for the pattern of the chariot, even the cherubim, that spread out their wings, and covered the ark of the covenant of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:18.</i> Solomon also always mentions that the Sanctuary is to be <i>for the name of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:19.</i> or <i>for Thy name</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:44.</i> and at each and every section of the prayer he says, <i>then hear Thou in heaven</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32 etc.</i> — with the attribute of mercy. And it is further written: <i>If Thy people go out to battle against their enemy… and they pray unto the Eternal toward the city which Thou hast chosen, and toward the house which I have built for Thy name, then hear Thou in heaven</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 44-45.</i> and in explanation Solomon said: <i>But will G-d in very truth dwell with man on the earth? Behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot contain Thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 6:18.</i> And it is written concerning the ark, <i>And David arose… to bring up from thence the ark of G-d, whereupon is called the Name, even the Name of the Eternal of hosts that sitteth upon the cherubim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 6:2.</i> and in the Book of Chronicles it is written: <i>to bring up from thence the ark of G-d, the Eternal, Who sitteth upon the cherubim, whereon is called the Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 13:6.</i> — for it is G-d Who sitteth upon the cherubim.

Verse 2



Verse 3

V’ZOTH’ (AND THIS) IS THE OFFERING. By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], this is like the expression, <i>And the Eternal gave Solomon wisdom</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 5:26. — See my Hebrew commentary p. 454 that in the word <i>zoth</i> Cabalists saw an allusion to the Divine Glory.</i> It is also written: <i>‘v’zoth’ (and this) is it that their father spoke unto them and blessed them;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 49:28.</i> <i>‘v’zoth’ (and this) is the blessing;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:1.</i> <i>the Eternal’s doing is ‘zoth’ (this)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 118:23. — Bereshith Rabbah 100:12.</i> The Rabbis have already alluded to this in Bereshith Rabbah on the basis of the verse, <i>I understand from the elders</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 118:23. — Bereshith Rabbah 100:12.</i> The discerning student will understand.<br>And in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 49:2.</i> the Rabbis have said: “<i>And this is the offering which ye shall take of them</i> — this refers to the congregation of Israel, which is the heave-offering, as it is said, <i>Israel is the Eternal’s hallowed portion, His first-fruits of the increase</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 2:3.</i> And it is also said there:<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 33:1.</i> “The Holy One, blessed be He, said to Israel: I have sold you My Torah; and I, as it were, was sold with it, for it is said, <i>‘v’yikchu li terumah’</i>” [which the Midrash takes to mean: “and they shall acquire Me as an offering”]. For the offering shall be Mine, and I am with it, similar to: <i>My beloved is mine, and I am his</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 2:16.</i> Similarly, He said, <i>according to all that I show thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 9.</i> for it is I who show [the pattern of the Tabernacle, and the pattern of all its vessels]. The statement, <i>it hath been shown to thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 27:8.</i> also alludes to the word “I”; similarly, <i>which is being shown to thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 40.</i> And so did David say, <i>All this [do I give thee] in writing, as the Eternal hath made me wise by His hand upon me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:19.</i> for the hand of G-d was upon David [to show him the pattern of the Sanctuary and of all its works].

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

SPICES FOR ANOINTING OIL AND FOR INCENSE OF ‘HASAMIM’ (AROMATICS). Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">I have not been able to identify these scholars.</i> say that this is an elliptical verse,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">These scholars are of the opinion that <i>b’samim</i> (spices) and <i>hasamim</i> (aromatics) are two different terms. And since it says further on that for the incense <i>take unto thee ‘samim’ (aromatics)</i> (30:34), the word <i>b’samim</i> cannot refer also to the incense mentioned here. Hence they complete the sentence thus: “spices for anointing oil, <i>and aromatics</i> for incense and aromatics.”</i> the sense being: “spices for anointing oil and aromatics for incense of aromatics.” And other scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Ibn Ezra in the name of “contemporary scholars.” I found this in Chizkuni.</i> say that the verse is to be understood as if it were inverted: “and for incense of aromatics they shall bring aromatics.” Scripture mentions them with the definite article [<i>hasamim</i>], in order to indicate that it is referring to those aromatics that are good as incense, for there also [i.e., further in the section of the Torah dealing with the incense — 30:34] He did not explain [fully the compound forming the incense].<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Hence He referred to them here by the definite article — <i>hasamim</i> — the aromatics that are known. See Ramban further 30:34 for full discussion of this subject.</i> And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the verse is to be taken in its simple sense, that spices be taken for both — for the anointing oil and for the incense, for included in the compound of the incense were these spices: spikenard and saffron and cinnamon, according to the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> It was not necessary for Scripture to mention “spices and aromatics for the incense,” because it said <i>the incense of aromatics</i>, just as it did not say “oil for the anointing oil.” This is the correct interpretation.<br>All these opinions are necessary because according to the view of the linguists [<i>samim</i> and <i>b’samim</i> connote two different things]: <i>samim</i> are curative herbs which are not edible, such as frankincense and galbanum,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 30:34.</i> while <i>b’samim</i> are those that are edible, and are called <i>mis’adim</i> (props)<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This was a Medieval medicinal term for spices which were given to the sick to restore their vigor. See Hebrew dictionaries, under the term <i>mis’ad</i>.</i> because they have a strengthening power by their fragrant odor.<br>However, in the opinion of Rashi <i>samim</i> is identical with <i>b’samim</i>. And such is the meaning of our Rabbis in the Midrash<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 1:61.</i> in saying: “Eleven <i>samonin</i> (ingredients) were told to Moses on Mount Sinai” [which form the incense, and among them were spikenard and saffron and cinnamon which are <i>b’samim</i>, thus proving that they are all called by the term <i>samim</i>]. Onkelos also translates in both cases <i>busmin</i> [“<i>busmaya</i> for the anointing oil, and for incense of <i>busmaya</i>”]. This is correct in the understanding of this verse. But because Scripture changed the terms [calling one <i>b’samim</i> and the other <i>samim</i>] we might possibly say that the most important of aromatics and spices are called <i>b’samim</i>, a term which signifies the choicest and most famous of the spices, just as He said, <i>‘b’samim rosh’ (the chief spices)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 30:23.</i> <i>‘b’rosh kol bosem’ (with chief of all spieces)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 27:22.</i> We are also correct in saying that the words <i>b’samim</i> and <i>bosem</i> are composite words: <i>bo sem, bo samim</i> (“in it is spice,” “in it are spices”). Proof to the words of the Rabbis [that the term <i>b’samim</i> includes also <i>samim</i>] is the verse, <i>Take thou unto thee ‘b’samim rosh’ (the chief spices) of flowing myrrh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 30:23.</i> and myrrh, is counted among the <i>samim</i> since it is a curative, not an edible herb. Scripture further says, <i>Spikenard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincense</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:14.</i> and the verse there continues: <i>myrrh and aloes, with all the chief ‘b’samim’ (spices)</i>. And with reference to all of these Scripture says, <i>Awake, O north wind; and come, thou south; blow upon my garden, that ‘b’samov’ (the spices thereof) may flow out</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16. Thus it is clear that the term <i>b’samim</i> (spices) includes also <i>samim</i> (aromatics), since it speaks of all of them as <i>b’samim</i> and lists amongst them myrrh, which is one of the <i>samim</i>.</i> A further proof [to the opinion of the Rabbis that <i>b’samim</i> includes also <i>samim</i>] is the verse, <i>and the princes brought… the ‘bosem’ and the oil for the light and for the annointing oil and the incense of aromatics</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:28.</i> but it does not mention that they brought <i>samim</i>, from which we may conclude that they are all included in the <i>bosem</i>.

Verse 7

AVNEI SHOHAM’ (ONYX STONES) ‘V’AVNEI MILU’IM’ (AND STONES FOR SETTING). “Because they used to make a setting for the stone in gold — a kind of indentation — and they placed the stone there to fill the indentation, they are called <i>avnei milu’im</i> (stones for filling-in), and the place of the indentation is called <i>mishbetzet</i> (setting). FOR THE EPHOD AND THE BREASTPLATE. The onyx stones were for the <i>ephod</i>, and the stones for setting were for the breastplate.” This is Rashi’s language. Similarly Rashi explained: “<i>They shall be inclosed in gold in their settings</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:20.</i> — surrounded by gold settings of such a depth that each setting shall be filled by the thickness of the stone. This is the meaning of the word <i>milu’otham</i> (their filling),<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:20.</i> and this is the meaning of every expression of <i>milui</i> (filling) mentioned in this connection.”<br>But it does not appear to me to be at all correct to say that Scripture calls them already now <i>avnei milu’im</i>, because in some time as yet in the future He was to command that the indentations made for them were to be filled with these stones! Moreover, the onyx stones were also <i>enclosed in settings of gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11 — in the case of the ephod.</i> and yet He did not call them <i>milu’im</i>. Again, our Rabbis have already said in the Gemara:<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 48b.</i> “These stones<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The onyx stones for the ephod, and the stones for setting in the breastplate. Ramban will later suggest that the reference perhaps is only to the stones for setting in the breastplate. See further, Note 76.</i> are not incised with a chisel,<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">For the purpose of writing the names of the tribes upon the stones (further, 28:12, and 21).</i> for it is said <i>b’milu’otham</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:20.</i> (in their filling).” Now if the explanation <i>b’milu’otham</i> would be, [as Rashi has it], that they fill the indentations with the stones, there would have been no proof at all from this verse that they should not incise the names [of the tribes] on them with a chisel. Besides, the manner of the setting of the stones which the Rabbi [Rashi] mentioned, namely that it was made in a kind of indentation, is not correct. Instead, it is as Onkelos rendered it: [<i>meshubatzim zahav</i> — inclosed in gold] <i>meramtzan didhav</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:20.</i> which means that they made at the bottom a gold setting according to the measure of the stone, and from it they projected a fork-like shape of three prongs which would hold the stone. [The word <i>meramtzan</i> mentioned by Onkelos] is similar to the expressions of the Sages: “and they take it out <i>beramtza</i> (with a pointed tool) made of iron;”<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Niddah 62a.</i> “as when he bored a hole in it <i>beramtza</i> (with a pick) made of iron.”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 103a.</i> This is how they also do it today when they set precious stones in rings, in order that they be seen from all angles and that their beauty and splendor should not be hidden in the indentations. You may know that this is so, for the two gold chains inserted in the two rings of the breastplate were attached to the <i>mishb’tzoth</i> on the shoulder-pieces of the <i>ephod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:24-25.</i> Now if <i>mishb’tzoth</i> were [as Rashi said] frames for the setting of the stone, how would they attach to them the chains? And even [if there were there other <i>mishb’tzoth</i> not for the setting of the stone but for the purpose of inserting the chains] how would the indentations serve that purpose [as they were not perforated for the chains to go through]? Rather, the <i>mishb’tzoth</i> are the fork-like prongs as we have said and the holes for the chains were made in them. Associated with the word <i>mishb’tzoth</i> is, in my opinion, [Saul’s expression, <i>Slay me</i>] <i>for ‘hashabatz’ hath taken hold of me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 1:9.</i> these being the men who hold spear-like weapons with mounted forks on top to catch those that flee the battle-field, just as it is said, <i>and lo, the chariots and the horsemen pressed hard upon him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i><br>And the meaning of <i>musaboth mishb’tzoth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:11.</i> is that he should fix the gold prongs “around it.” And in the opinion of Onkelos who translated [<i>musaboth</i> as] <i>meshak’on</i> [literally: “depressed,” “sunk”], the stones were sunk into the frames from which came forth prongs surrounding them above and holding them in place.<br>But the sense of the word <i>milu’im</i> is that the stones be whole as they were created, and that they should not be hewn stones which were cut from a large quarry, or from which anything has been chipped off. It is also known in the natural sciences that the complete powers of precious stones and the particular qualities that distinguish them, exist only when in their natural state, as when smooth stones are taken from the river. This is why Onkelos translated [<i>avnei milu’im — avnei</i>] <i>ashlamutha</i> (stones of perfection). But the term <i>milui</i> (filling of) vessels or an indentation [Onkelos] translates literally, — thus: <i><b>'va’t'malei'</b> (and she filled) her pitcher</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:16.</i> Onkelos translated: <i><b>u’mleiah</b></i> (and she filled), and similarly in all other cases — but here he translated the term <i>milui</i> to mean <i>shleimuth</i> (perfection). Similarly, he translated the verse, <i>‘milei’ (He filled) them with wisdom of heart</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:35.</i> — <i>ashleim</i> (“He perfected” them with wisdom of heart), as wisdom is not something that you can fill a vessel with, but instead it denotes perfection, that they [i.e. Bezalel and Oholiab — who did the workmanship of the Tabernacle] were perfect in wisdom. This is the intent of the verse, <i>and in cutting of stones <b>'l’maloth'</b></i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:5.</i> — that they knew how to engrave like the engravings of a signet upon stones in their [natural] perfect state.<br>Now in the case of the stones of the ephod it is said, however, <i>with the work of an engraver in stone, like the engravings of a signet, shalt thou engrave the two stones, according to the names of the children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11 — in the case of the ephod.</i> [but it does not say here <i>b’milu’otham</i> — “in their perfect state”], because they made an incision in them when writing the names [of the tribes upon them] as stone engravers do, and thus the stones were no longer in their [natural] perfect state. But in the case of the stones for the breastplate it is written, <i>‘umileitha’ in it ‘miluath’ of stone</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:17.</i> and again it is written of them, <i>they shall be ‘b’milu’otham;’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> <i>and the stones</i> [of the breastplate] <i>were according to the names of the children of Israel, twelve, according to their names</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39:14.</i> — not the work of engravers [who make incisions upon the stones]. Therefore Moses our teacher could find no way [of inscribing the names of the tribes of Israel upon the twelve stones in the breastplate] except by means of the <i>shamir</i> [a worm that cuts stones with its glance] which our Rabbis mentioned, just as they have said in Tractate Sotah:<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 48b.</i> “These stones<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">I.e. the stones of the breastplate. See above Note 61.</i> are not written upon with ink, for it is said, <i>like the engravings of a signet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:21. “And this means carving” (Rashi, <i>ibid.</i>, Sotah). — The verse is mentioned in connection with the stones of the breastplate.</i> and they are not incised with a chisel, for it is said <i>b’milu’otham</i> (in their perfect state).<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20. — Also in connection with the stones of the breastplate.</i> But instead [Moses] brought the <i>shamir</i> and showed it the stones and they split of their own accord.” Now the word <i>b’milu’otham</i> is said only in connection with the stones of the breastplate. Do not be troubled by what is mentioned in the Agadah (homily, tradition) that the Rabbis said to Solomon:<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Gittin 68a. In preparing to build the Sanctuary, Solomon asked the Rabbis: “How shall I accomplish the cutting of the stones without using iron tools?” They replied: “There is the <i>shamir</i> etc.”</i> “There is the <i>shamir</i> with which Moses cut the precious stones of the <i>ephod</i>.” [From this you might argue that the stones of the <i>ephod</i> also had to be <i>b’milu’otham</i> — in their perfect natural state — which would be contrary to what we have said above, that this applied only to the stones of the breastplate! Do not be troubled by this statement,] for the breastplate is called ephod by the Rabbis by way of metaphor, because the breastplate is attached thereto. It is also written, <i>Bring hither the ephod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 23:9.</i> and it was of the breastplate that they asked [for guidance].<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 28:30.</i> Thus the explanation of the verse before us is as follows: “<i>onyx stones</i> three — two for the ephod<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:9.</i> and one for the breastplate;<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> and <i>stones of ‘milu’im’</i> for the breastplate.” And in case the opinion of our Rabbis was that the stones of the ephod also had to be in their full natural state [as the stones of the breastplate], then both <i>the onyx stones and the stones of ‘milu’im’</i> were for both, <i>for the ephod and for the breastplate</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, if that be the opinion of the Rabbis that the stones of the ephod also had to be <i>b’milu’otham</i> (in their full natural state), then they derived it from this verse as explained in the text. For — the ephod and the breastplate — had both the onyx stones and the stones of <i>milu’im</i>. Of the ephod it is clearly written that it had two onyx stones (further, 28:9), and according to the Rabbis these were also <i>b’milu’otham</i> (in their full natural state). In the case of the breastplate <i>b’milu’otham</i> is clearly mentioned (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 20) and so is the onyx stone (<i>ibid.</i>). Thus the verse before us, <i>stones of onyx and stones of ‘milu’im’</i> means that both were <i>for the ephod and for the breastplate</i>.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9

AND SO SHALL YE MAKE IT — [also] “in future generations. If one of the vessels is lost, or when you make<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">“Make.” In our Rashi: “make Me.”</i> the vessels of the Sanctuary of Jerusalem,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is <i>beith olamim</i> — “the Eternal House.” See in <i>Seder Yithro</i> Note 598.</i> such as the tables,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 4:8: <i>And he made ten tables</i>.</i> the candelabrums,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7: <i>And he made the ten candelabrums</i>.</i> the lavers,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6: <i>And he made ten lavers</i>.</i> and the bases<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 7:27-39: <i>And he made the ten bases…</i></i> which Solomon made — after the pattern of these you shall make them. If, however, this [part of the verse] were not connected with the preceding part [which reads: <i>According to all that I show thee, the pattern of the <b>Tabernacle</b>, and the pattern of all the vessels</i>], Scripture should not have written: <i>‘and’ so shall ye make it</i>, but: “so shall ye make it,” and then it would be speaking of the making of the Tent of Meeting<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">And not of the Sanctuary of Jerusalem and its vessels. But now that Scripture says <i>‘and’ so shall ye make it</i>, the expression is not set apart from the preceding part of the verse but is connected with it, thus: “and” so shall you make the pattern of all the furniture of the Sanctuary.</i> and its vessels.” Thus is Rashi’s language. But I do not know if this is true, that Solomon was bound to make the vessels of the Sanctuary of Jerusalem<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew is <i>beith olamim</i> — “the Eternal House.” See in <i>Seder Yithro</i> Note 598.</i> after the pattern of these vessels [of the Tabernacle]. The altar of brass which Solomon made was twenty cubits long and twenty wide!<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 4:1. The altar of the Tabernacle was five cubits long and five cubits broad (further, 27:1).</i> And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “<i>And so shall ye make</i> — the vessels,<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The expression <i>and so shall ye make it</i> thus refers only to <i>the pattern of all the furniture</i> (mentioned right above), but does not refer to <i>the pattern of the Tabernacle</i> since the term “making” was already stated with reference to it, namely, <i>and let them ‘make’ Me a Sanctuary</i>.</i> for at the beginning He said, <i>And let them make Me a Sanctuary</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture there is no need for all this. Rather, the duplication [<i>and so shall ye make it</i>] has the purpose of expressing emphasis and eagerness. Thus He said: “<i>And let them make Me a Sanctuary</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i> — a house and vessels — as a Royal Sanctuary and seat of Majesty, <i>that I may dwell in the midst of them</i> in the house and on the Throne of Glory which they will make for Me there. <i>According to all that I show thee the pattern of this Tabernacle</i> of which I have said that I will dwell in the midst of them, <i>and the pattern of all the vessels thereof</i>. He repeated, <i>and so shall ye</i> all <i>make it</i> with eagerness and diligence. This is similar to the repetition found in the verse, <i>and the children of Israel did according to all that the Eternal commanded Moses, so did they</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:32.</i> Here, because the verse speaks of a command, it says, <i>and so ‘shall’ ye make it</i>, [whereas in the other verse the repeat states <i>so ‘did’ they</i>, because it speaks of a deed accomplished].

Verse 10

AND THEY SHALL MAKE AN ARK. The plural [<i>and ‘they’ shall make</i>] refers back to <i>the children of Israel</i> mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> But afterwards Scripture states: <i>And thou shalt overlay it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> <i>And thou shalt cast for it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> — all in the singular, as Moses is the leader of all Israel. It is possible that [in using the plural — <i>and they shall make</i>] He is indicating His wish that all Israel should share in the making of the ark because it is <i>the holiest dwelling-place of the Most High</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 46:5.</i> and that they should all merit thereby [a knowledge of] the Torah. Thus the Rabbis have said in Midrash Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 33:3.</i> “Why is it that with reference to all the vessels it says, <i>and thou shalt make</i>, and in the case of the ark it says, <i>and they shall make?</i> Said Rabbi Yehudah the son of Rabbi Shalom: The Holy One, blessed be He, said, Let all the people come and engage themselves in the making of the ark, so that they should all merit [a knowledge of] the Torah.” The “engaging themselves” of which the Rabbi speaks means that they should each offer one golden vessel [for the making of the ark, in addition to their general offering for the building of the Tabernacle], or that they should help Bezalel in some small way, or that they should have intent [of heart in the making thereof].<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Thus even the desire to help Bezalel in the making of the ark was already accounted as an act of helping in the making thereof (Kli Chemdah). It may also hint that a mere genuine craving for Torah is praiseworthy before the Creator.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12

AND THOU SHALT CAST FOUR RINGS OF GOLD FOR IT, AND PUT THEM IN THE FOUR ‘PA’AMOTHAV’ (CORNERS THEREOF). “The word <i>pa’amothav</i> is to be understood as the Targum rendered it: ‘corners thereof.’ It was on the upper corners near to the cover of the ark that the rings were placed. <i>And two rings shall be on the one side of it, and two rings on the other side of it</i>. These are the very four rings which are mentioned at the beginning of the verse, but here Scripture explains that two of these rings were placed on one side [and the other two on the other side].” Thus did Rashi explain, and he explained it well. But I do not know why Rashi wrote that “on the upper corners near to the cover” the rings were placed. For in that case, the weight [of the ark and the tables of law hanging down from the staves] would be very much heavier. Moreover, the respectful way is that the ark be lifted up, resting high upon the shoulders of the priests<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In Numbers 7:9 it is clearly stated that it is the Levites the sons of Kohath who carried the ark, not the priests. See, however, “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 43-44, that in reality the fulfillment of this commandment, bearing the ark upon the shoulders, devolves upon the priests, but in the wilderness the duty was laid upon the Levites because of the limited number of priests then available. This is Rambam’s position. For Ramban’s opinion see my Note there, p. 44.</i> [when carrying it].<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “I have searched in all Scripture and I have not found the term <i>pa’am</i> to mean ‘corner’ but only ‘foot.’ Thus: <i>How beautiful are p’amayich’ (thy feet);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:2. The J.P.S. translation “steps” follows Ramban’s interpretation, explained further on.</i> <i>the feet of the poor, ‘pa’amei’ (the feet of) the needy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 26:6. In J.P.S. translation: “steps,” as Ramban explains it.</i> Therefore I felt bound to explain that the ark had feet to it [upon which it rested].” And so Ibn Ezra explained the meaning of the verse to be that there were altogether eight rings, the four bottom ones<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary p. 459, that our Ibn Ezra texts have here a different version, and that it is <i>only</i> according to that different version that Ramban’s questions on Ibn Ezra can be understood. Principally Ramban differs with three points that Ibn Ezra made: 1. That there were eight rings to the ark; 2. that the staves for carrying the ark were inserted in the <i>upper</i> rings; 3. that the ark had feet. — It is on this second point that the texts differ. It must then be remembered that Ramban is directing his criticism on Ibn Ezra holding that it was the <i>upper</i> rings that were for carriage. Ramban’s opinion is that the lower rings were for the insertion of the staves with which the ark was carried. Ramban will also differ with Ibn Ezra on the other two points.</i> being those through which the staves were inserted to carry the ark with, whilst the four upper rings were purely for ornamental purposes. His words are, however, not at all correct. For if, as he said, <i>pa’am</i> means foot, then Scripture is commanding that the rings should be in the lower corners upon which the ark rests, and these bottom corners are called “feet” because the Sacred Language adapts all forms according to the image of man. Thus it calls the upper part of any object <i>rosh</i> (head), and the bottom part <i>regel</i> (foot). [Accordingly there is no need to say as did Ibn Ezra that the ark had feet to it upon which it rested, since Scripture calls the bottom corners “feet.”] And this is indeed true, that the rings for the purpose of carriage were at the bottom corners, and the ark was thus lifted up above the staves, as I have explained above.<br>But in my opinion <i>pa’am</i> does not mean “foot” but is a term meaning “step.” <i>How beautiful are ‘p’amayich’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 7:2. The J.P.S. translation “steps” follows Ramban’s interpretation, explained further on.</i> — your steps. This usage is similar to the phrase in the Talmud:<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 18a.</i> “How beautiful are the steps of this maiden.” Similarly: <i>why tarry ‘pa’amei’ (the steps of) his chariots?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 5:28. Translated: <i>why tarry ‘the wheels’ of his chariots?</i></i> The word <i>pa’amothav</i> here is Scripture’s reference to the steps of the priests<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">In Numbers 7:9 it is clearly stated that it is the Levites the sons of Kohath who carried the ark, not the priests. See, however, “The Commandments,” Vol. I, pp. 43-44, that in reality the fulfillment of this commandment, bearing the ark upon the shoulders, devolves upon the priests, but in the wilderness the duty was laid upon the Levites because of the limited number of priests then available. This is Rambam’s position. For Ramban’s opinion see my Note there, p. 44.</i> that carry the ark, thus hinting at two things: that the rings be in the corners right at the bottom, near the seat of the ark, and that the whole length of the ark should interpose between the two rings. For, assuming that the length of the ark was placed in an east-west position, then there were two rings on its north side, one at the eastern head and one at the western, and likewise two rings on the south side of the ark [similarly placed], and the steps of the priests moved between the rings with their faces towards one another. In the Mishnah of the Tabernacle<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">This is the Beraitha on the work of the Tabernacle. (Otzar Midrashim, Eisenstein, p. 301; Ish Shalom’s scientific edition, Breslau 1915.) For the name Beraitha see in <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 209. — In the Holy of Holies the length of the ark was in a north-south position i.e., to the width of the holy place while the width of the ark was in an east-west position i.e., to the length of the holy place (Mishneh Torah, Hilchoth Beth Habchirah 3:13). When carrying the ark they carried it face to face, with their backs turned outward, and their faces set towards the ark (<i>ibid.</i> Hilchoth Klei Hamikdash 2:13). A reference to this point is found here in the text of Ramban.</i> we have learned: “There were four gold rings affixed in the ark, two to the north thereof and two to the south, and in them the staves were inserted and were never moved therefrom etc.”

Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND IN THE ARK THOU SHALT PUT THE TESTIMONY THAT I SHALL GIVE THEE. “I do not know why this is repeated, for it has already been stated [in Verse 16], <i>And thou shalt put into the ark the Testimony which I shall give thee?</i> One may answer that it intends to teach us that while the ark was still by itself, without its cover, he should first place the Testimony into it and then place the cover on it [for the first time]. Thus we find also when Moses set up the Tabernacle that Scripture says, <i>And he put the Testimony into the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:20.</i> and after that it says,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:20.</i> <i>and he put the cover of the ark above</i>.” This is Rashi’s language.<br>But if this be a command [as Rashi has it], the sense thereof would rather seem to be that after he puts the cover on the ark as G-d had commanded, [he should then remove the cover and] put the Testimony into the ark, for the term “ark” applies also when there is a cover on it. Moreover, one can also ask why did Scripture repeat the phrase <i>from between the two cherubim which are upon the ark of the Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> when it is known already from the preceding verses that the cherubim are upon the ark of Testimony? And what need is there to explain this again, seeing that He has already stated, <i>from above the ark-cover, from between the two cherubim?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> But the explanation thereof is as follows: Because He had commanded that <i>the cherubim shall spread out their wings on high</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> but had not said why they should be made altogether, and what function they should serve in the Tabernacle, and why they should be in that form, therefore He now said, <i>and thou shalt put the ark-cover</i> with the cherubim, for they are all one, <i>above upon the ark</i>, because <i>in the ark thou shalt put the Testimony that I shall give thee</i>, so that there be for Me a Throne of Glory, for there will I meet with thee and I will cause My Glory to dwell upon them, <i>and I will speak with thee from above the ark-cover, from between the two cherubim</i> because it is <i>upon the ark of the testimony</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 22.</i> It is thus identical with the Divine Chariot which the prophet Ezekiel saw, of which he said, <i>This is the living creature that I saw under the G-d of Israel by the river Chebar; and I knew that they were cherubim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 10:20.</i> This is why He is called <i>He Who sitteth upon the cherubim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 4:4.</i> for they spread out their wings on high in order to teach us that they are the Chariot who carry the Glory, just as it is said, <i>and gold for the pattern of the chariot, even the cherubim, that spread out their wings, and covered the ark of the covenant of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:18.</i> as I have mentioned.<br>In the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Chagigah 13b.</i> the cherubim had the forms of a human being, the word being of the Aramaic language which calls a lad <i>ravya</i>. In that case the letter <i>kaf</i> in the word <i>k’rubim</i> (cherubim) is not part of the root of the word, but merely serves in a comparative function [meaning “as lads”], the name indicating their substance. If you will further contemplate as to why their faces were turned one to another,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> and why they were <i>of beaten work</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> you will be able to know that it was proper for them that they be <i>spreading out their wings on high</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i> for they are the throne of the Supreme One, sheltering the Testimony which is <i>the writing of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:16.</i> <i>This is the meaning of the expression, the pattern of the chariot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:18.</i> for the cherubim which Ezekiel saw carrying the Glory are the pattern of the cherubim [on high], these being the Glory and the <i>tipheret</i> (beauty); and the cherubim which were in the Tabernacle and in the Sanctuary were of a likeness to them, <i>for one higher than the high watcheth, and there are higher than they</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 5:7.</i> And this is the meaning of <i>and I knew</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 10:20.</i> [and not “and I saw”], for Ezekiel saw one and knew the other [on high]. This is why he said “they” [<i>and I knew that ‘they’ were cherubim</i>]. The student learned in the mysteries of the Cabala will understand.

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24

A CROWN OF GOLD ROUND ABOUT. “This is a symbol of the crown of royalty, for the table represents wealth and prominence, just as the Rabbis say<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Yebamoth 24 b: “He who becomes a proselyte for the sake of ‘the royal table.’”</i> ‘the royal table.’” This is Rashi’s language. And this explanation is indeed the truth, for in this lies the secret of the table [in the Tabernacle]. For since the time that the world came into existence, G-d’s blessing did not create something from nothing; instead, the world follows its natural course, for it is written, <i>and G-d saw every thing that He had made, and behold, it was very good</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:31.</i> But when <i>the root of the matter</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Job 19:28.</i> already exists, the blessing descends upon it and increases it, just as Elisha said, <i>tell me; what hast thou in the house?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:2.</i> and then the blessing came upon the pot of oil that she already had, and she filled all the vessels from it.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6.</i> And in the case of Elijah it is said, <i>The jar of meal was not spent, neither did the cruse of oil fail</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 17:16.</i> And so also was the case with the showbread on the table; upon it rested the blessing, and from it came abundance to all Israel. That is why the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 39a.</i> “Every priest who received even only as much as the size of a bean [of the showbread] ate it and was satisfied.”

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

AND THOU SHALT MAKE ‘KE’AROTHAV VEKAPOTHAV UKSOTHAV UMENAKIYOTHAV.’ Rashi explained: “<i>Ke’arothav</i> are the forms [the moulds that were made to fit the shape of the bread]; <i>vekapothav</i> are spoons in which the incense was put;<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 24:7.</i> <i>uksothav</i> are rods in the shape of halves of hollow canes [which were put between one loaf and another so that they would not become mouldy]; <i>umenakiyothav</i> are the trestles which were notched in [five places] to support the canes.” These vessels [that Rashi referred to] are indeed mentioned in the Gemara.<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 97a.</i> And the Rabbi further said: “The word <i>mechilathei</i> [which Onkelos used for the Hebrew <i>menakiyothav</i>] means ‘bearers,’ similar to the expressions: <i>and I weary myself ‘kalkeil’ (to bear it);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 20:9.</i> <i>I am weary ‘hachil’ (bearing it)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:11. The beginning of the verse reads: <i>Therefore I am full of the fury of the Eternal</i>.</i> Now the Sages of Israel have differed on this. For some say that <i>ksothav</i> are the trestles, and <i>menakiyothav</i> are the hollow canes. But Onkelos who translated <i>menakiyothav</i> by [the Aramaic] <i>mechilathei</i> was of the same opinion as he who says that <i>menakiyoth</i> are the trestles [supporting pillars attached to the table].” These are Rashi’s words. But I do not find them to be correct, for the word <i>mechilathei</i> [of Onkelos] in the Aramaic language is but a term meaning measures, such as ephahs and the like. Thus Onkelos rendered, <i>eiphath tzedek</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:36.</i> — <i>mechilon dikshot</i> (a true measure); <i>Thou shalt not have in thy house ‘eiphah v’eiphah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:14.</i> — thou shalt not have <i>mechilta umechilta (diverse measures)</i>. In a similar sense it is found whenever mentioned in the Talmud and in the Sages’ words: <i>kayal meikal</i> (he was measuring);<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 53 b: <i>ka kayol</i>.</i> <i>bimchilta d’kayil inish ba mitkil</i> (with the measure that one measures others, with that he is measured).<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Targum Yerushalmi Genesis 38:26.</i> Similarly, <i>I am weary ‘hachil’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:11. The beginning of the verse reads: <i>Therefore I am full of the fury of the Eternal</i>.</i> means “I am weary of being a holding measure” [of G-d’s fury], and it is associated with these expressions: <i>alpayim bath yachil (it held two thousand baths);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 7:26.</i> <i>v’chol bashalish aphar ha’aretz (and He comprehended the dust of the earth in a measure);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:12.</i> <i>too little ‘meihachil’ (to receive) the burnt offering</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:64.</i> Similarly, <i>I am weary ‘hachil’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 6:11. The beginning of the verse reads: <i>Therefore I am full of the fury of the Eternal</i>.</i> is in my opinion not an expression of “bearing” but is instead a form of that very same meaning of “holding,” thus saying, “I am weary of holding” [G-d’s fury], similar in usage to these expressions: <i>the land is not able ‘l’hachil’ (to hold) all his words;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Amos 7:10.</i> <i>the spirit of a man ‘y’chalkeil’ his infirmity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 18:14.</i> meaning that he will be able to hold the pain within himself and not become weary [and broken in spirit] because of it. <i>Behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens cannot ‘y’chalkelucha’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:27.</i> — they cannot hold and contain the greatness of Your exaltedness, for there is no limit and measure to You — <i>how much less this house that I have built!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 8:27.</i> <i><b>'Y’chalkeil'</b> his words rightfully</i><sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 112:5.</i> means that he is not <i>a fool</i> who <i>spendeth all his spirit</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 29:11.</i> but holds his words within himself when necessary, and uses them as necessary. <i><b>'Vay’chalkeil Yoseiph'</b></i><sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 47:12.</i> means that Joseph gave them as much food as they could hold; he gave neither too much nor too little, but <i>bread according to the want of their little ones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban on Genesis 41:48 (Vol. I, p. 507) that Joseph had gathered all food essential to life “even figs, fresh and dried, etc.” Now of this kind of food he gave his family abundantly, but bread he gave them <i>according to the want of their little ones</i> (Genesis 47:12).</i> And such is the explanation of all [other similar expressions].<br>But Onkelos’ opinion [who translated <i>umenakiyothav — umechilathei</i>] is not clear. Perhaps <i>menakiyothav</i> is in the opinion of Onkelos a term for measures, since they had [in the Tabernacle and later in the Sanctuary] a measure holding two tenth parts [of an ephah] flour, with which to measure one cake,<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:5.</i> and they did not measure it twice with the one tenth measure of the meal-offering. We must then say that Onkelos differs from the Mishnah which teaches:<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 87a.</i> “There were two dry-measures in the Sanctuary: the tenth, and the half-tenth” [of an ephah], and in his opinion there were three dry-measures: the tenth, the half-tenth, and the two tenths.<br>The correct interpretation of Onkelos’ opinion appears to me to be that <i>mechila</i> is the form (mould) made for the dough, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 94a.</i> “There were in the Tabernacle three moulds [for the showbread]: he placed it in a mould whilst it was still dough; when baked in the oven it was put in another mould, and when he took it out he placed it in a [third] frame so that it should not spoil.”<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The first and third moulds were made of gold; the one for the oven was an iron mould.</i> This [third] frame which was used so that it should not spoil did not have to be shaped to the form of the bread and its size; instead, it was made like a sort of dish to support the sides of the bread, this being the <i>ke’arothav</i> mentioned in the verse. But the first mould for the dough was shaped to the form of the bread and its size, namely, ten [handbreadths] long and five wide, and its horns<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Small pieces of dough were put on the four corners of each of the breads (Menachoth 96 a).</i> seven fingerbreadths [high]. Into this mould the dough was put, measured and shaped to fit its form, and for this reason it was called <i>mechila</i> because it was made to “the measure.” The term <i>menakiyoth</i> then [according to Onkelos] is a name just like ephah and <i>s’ah</i> [a third of the ephah measure is a <i>s’ah</i>], similar, to <i>ke’arothav</i> and <i>ksothav</i> and other nouns which are not descriptive. Perhaps those just measures which are called <i>a just ephah, and a just hin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:36.</i> and termed <i>menakiyoth</i> [of the root <i>naki</i> — clean] because they are clean of any falsehood, and thus they clear their owners of any cheating and sin. And <i>ksavoth</i> is a general term covering the canes [which were put between one loaf and another] and the trestles [notched in five places upon which the canes separating the loaves rested]. Perhaps because of their notches they were so called [<i>ksavoth</i>], with the letter <i>tzade</i> [<i>ktzavoth</i> — sides, corners] being used instead of the letter <i>sin</i> [<i>ksavoth</i>], this word [<i>ksavoth</i>] being similar to [the word <i>ktzavoth</i> found in the following verse]: <i>so that they that dwell in ‘ktzavoth’ (the uttermost parts) stand in awe of Thy signs</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 65:9.</i> by interchanging the letter <i>tzade</i> with the <i>sin</i>, just like in the word <i>s’chok</i> [“laughter,” which is the word <i>tzchok</i>].<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “There is an error in Chronicles,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:17. The verse there reads: <i>‘v’hamizlagoth’ (and the forks), ‘v’hamizrakoth’ (and the basins), ‘v’haksavoth’ (and the jars), of pure gold; ‘v’lichphorei’ (and the bowls of) gold by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl); ‘v’lichphorei’ (and for the bowls of) silver by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl)</i>. — Ibn Ezra’s comment is to the effect that there are new vessels here mentioned for the table in the Sanctuary that are not found here in the Torah in connection with the table in the Tabernacle. — Ramban will point out mat Ibn Ezra erred in thinking that this Verse 17 refers back to the tables of showbread mentioned above in Verse 16, since it really refers back to Verse 13, as explained in the text.</i> for in speaking of the vessels of the table in place of <i>ke’aroth</i> [mentioned here] it writes <i>mizrakoth</i> (basins); in place of <i>kapoth</i> [mentioned here] it writes <i>kiporim</i> (bowls); <i>ksavoth</i> is mentioned there as here; and in the place of <i>menakiyoth</i> it speaks of <i>mizlagoth</i> (forks). And all these were made of gold for the purpose of the table [and yet we do not find the <i>mizrakoth, kiporim</i>, and <i>mizlagoth</i> mentioned here in connection with the table in the Tabernacle]! Perhaps these were other vessels which David commanded to be placed on the tables<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 4:8.</i> which his son Solomon would make, but the table in the Tent of Meeting did not have these vessels.” The error, however, is in Rabbi Abraham’s words, [not in the Book of Chronicles], for that which Scripture states, <i>and the forks, and the basins, and the jars of pure gold; and for the golden bowls by weight for every bowl</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:17. The verse there reads: <i>‘v’hamizlagoth’ (and the forks), ‘v’hamizrakoth’ (and the basins), ‘v’haksavoth’ (and the jars), of pure gold; ‘v’lichphorei’ (and the bowls of) gold by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl); ‘v’lichphorei’ (and for the bowls of) silver by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl)</i>. — Ibn Ezra’s comment is to the effect that there are new vessels here mentioned for the table in the Sanctuary that are not found here in the Torah in connection with the table in the Tabernacle. — Ramban will point out mat Ibn Ezra erred in thinking that this Verse 17 refers back to the tables of showbread mentioned above in Verse 16, since it really refers back to Verse 13, as explained in the text.</i> is not connected only with <i>the tables of showbread</i><sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:16.</i> [mentioned in the preceding verse], but it reverts back to that which Scripture stated [several verses above], <i>and for all the work of the service of the house of the Eternal, and for all the vessels of service in the house of the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> And then it continues, <i>of gold, for all vessels of every kind of service</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> and then it mentioned, <i>and the forks, and the basins</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:17. The verse there reads: <i>‘v’hamizlagoth’ (and the forks), ‘v’hamizrakoth’ (and the basins), ‘v’haksavoth’ (and the jars), of pure gold; ‘v’lichphorei’ (and the bowls of) gold by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl); ‘v’lichphorei’ (and for the bowls of) silver by weight ‘lichphor uchphor’ (for every bowl)</i>. — Ibn Ezra’s comment is to the effect that there are new vessels here mentioned for the table in the Sanctuary that are not found here in the Torah in connection with the table in the Tabernacle. — Ramban will point out mat Ibn Ezra erred in thinking that this Verse 17 refers back to the tables of showbread mentioned above in Verse 16, since it really refers back to Verse 13, as explained in the text.</i> which are vessels of the altar, <i>and the jars</i> for the table, and <i>the bowls</i> for the altar. And finally it stated, <i>and for the altar of incense refined gold by weight</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> concluding: <i>All this [do I give thee] in writing, as the Eternal hath made me wise by His hand upon me, even all the works of this pattern</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> Thus David [in speaking to his son Solomon] included all needs of the Sanctuary.

Verse 30

LECHEM PANIM’ (SHOWBREAD). “It is called <i>lechem panim</i> [which literally means ‘bread of faces’] because it had ‘faces’ [surfaces] looking in both directions towards the sides of the House [Tabernacle or Sanctuary]. The loaf was set lengthwise across the breadth of the table with its sides standing up exactly in a line with the edge of the table.” This is the language of Rashi. This conforms with the language of the Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 96a.</i> “Ben Zoma says: <i>lechem panim</i> — [it is so called] because it is to have surfaces” [looking in both directions]. But all this is in accordance with the opinion of the Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Chanina (<i>ibid.</i>, 94 b).</i> who says: “How did they make the showbread? Like a case broken open.”<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">“With its cover and two of its opposite sides removed, thus leaving the bread the two sides [facing each other] and the bottom underneath” (Rashi <i>ibid.</i>). The figure thus is: .</i> But according to the Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yochanan (<i>ibid</i>).</i> who says that it was shaped “like a rocking boat,”<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">The sides of which narrowed downwards until there was but a fingerbreadth at the bottom and it had no covering on top (Rashi <i>ibid.</i>). The figure is: V.</i> then it could not have been [called <i>lechem panim</i> because of the parallel surfaces looking in both directions, as it had none]! And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that it is called <i>lechem panim</i> because it is <i>before Me always</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>panim</i> meaning “face” is thus explained by <i>l’phanai tamid (before Me always):</i> it is <i>lechem panim</i> literally: “bread of the face” because it is <i>before Me always</i>.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], when you will understand the word <i>l’phanai</i> (before Me)<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “to My face.”</i> you will understand its name [i.e., why it is called “the bread of <i>panim</i>”] and its secret, for because of that [the table] was placed on the north side [of the Tabernacle],<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 26:35.</i> seeing that <i>the blessing of the Eternal maketh rich</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 10:22.</i> similar to what is said, <i>in every place where I cause My name to be mentioned I will come unto thee and bless thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:24.</i> I have already alluded to this.<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:3. — So explained in Bachya.</i><br>Where shall be found the wisdom embodied in the candelabrum, its cups and knops and flowers, seeing that it is so <i>hidden from the eyes of all living!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">See Job 28:20-21.</i> But as to the reason for its being of beaten work, with the six branches coming out of the seventh, and upon them <i>the lamp of G-d</i><sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 3:3.</i> <i>and all</i> [six lamps] <i>to give light over against it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 37.</i> — all this you can understand from our words that we have written in another place.<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">I have not been able to identify that “other place.” The basic concept though is explained by Abusaula that it is an allusion to the lower six emanations all being <i>one beaten work</i> (Verse 36), symbolizing a perfect Unity, with <i>the lamp of G-d</i>, alluding to the Supreme One, above them.</i> This is the intent of the saying of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 29a.</i> that Moses found difficulty with the candelabrum.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning, that he found it perplexing to understand the secret of its cups and knops and flowers, for it is extremely hidden from the eyes of all living (Abusaula).</i>

Verse 31
