Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39

OF A TALENT OF PURE GOLD SHALL HE MAKE IT WITH ALL THESE VESSELS. This means “that its weight together with all its vessels shall be exactly one talent, neither less nor more.” This is Rashi’s language. And such indeed is the simple meaning of Scripture. But if that be so, there is here a point which is greatly to be wondered about, namely that Scripture should not specify at all how much of the talent of gold should go into the candelabrum itself! For in that case half of the talent or even more could then go into the making of the tongs and the snuffdishes<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 38.</i> which are vessels separate from the candelabrum, while the candelabrum itself could be made of less than half the talent, or perhaps the candelabrum would be made of the entire talent less one <i>maneh</i> [a sacred talent consisted of one hundred and twenty <i>manoth</i>] and all these vessels would be made of the one <i>maneh</i>! Moreover, what reason is there that the total weight of the candelabrum with its many separate vessels should be given as one talent, and why was it not explained how many tongs and snuffdishes should be made from it?<br>But the opinion of our Rabbis is not as the Rabbi [Rashi] stated it, for thus did the Sages teach in Tractate Menachoth:<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Menachoth 88b.</i> “The candelabrum and its seven lamps<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 37. — These were a kind of small receptacle into which the oil and the wicks were put (Rashi).</i> came from the talent, but not its tongs and snuffdishes. And if you ask how will I then explain, [<i>Of a talent of pure gold shall he make it</i>,] <i>with all these vessels?</i> Then I reply that this includes the lamps. These are the words of Rabbi Yehudah. Rabbi Nechemyah says: the candelabrum [alone] came from the talent but not its lamps, tongs, and snuffdishes. And if you ask how will I then explain the expression, <i>with all these vessels?</i> I answer that it teaches that they all be made of gold [aside of the talent mentioned].” There in Tractate Menachoth the Rabbis have further said, that according to Rabbi Yehudah [who says that the lamps came from the talent], the lamps were also of beaten work together with the candelabrum; yet Scripture calls them <i>these ‘vessels,’</i> because they are receptacles for the oil, known by a name of their own, since in all other candelabrums they are separate from them [although here they were hammered out of the same talent of gold from which the whole candelabrum was made]. And according to Rabbi Nechemyah [who says that the lamps did not come from the talent, the Rabbis] have said there that the lamps were not of beaten work together with the candelabrum. Thus according to Rabbi Yehudah included in the weight of the talent — with that which was of beaten work with it — is only the candelabrum itself but none of the separate vessels thereof. And according to Rabbi Nechemyah the Rabbis have said there: “And if you ask how will I then explain the expression, <i>with all these vessels</i>? I answer, it teaches that they all be made of gold, this being necessary to be stated because of the mouth of the lamps.”<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">One might think that the mouth of the lamps where the wicks burn and become blackened should not be made of pure gold, since the Torah cares for the wealth of Israel; therefore Scripture let it be known that even the mouth of the lamps be made of pure gold (Rashi, Menachoth 88 b).</i><br>According to the simple meaning of Scripture the verse states: “<i>Of a talent of pure gold shall he make it; all these vessels</i> he shall [also] make of pure gold,” since He did not explain at first that the lamps<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">That the tongs and snuffdishes are to be made of pure gold is clearly stated in Verse 38. However, concerning the lamps He did not mention at all (in Verse 37) that they be made of pure gold. Hence the reverting to them in Verse 39 before us.</i> should be of gold. Similarly, Scripture relates at the time of the making of the candelabrum, <i>And he made the lamps thereof, seven, and the tongs thereof, and the snuffdishes thereof, of pure gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:23.</i> the expression <i>of pure gold</i> referring only to the tongs and the snuffdishes [but not to the lamps], and therefore He explained it further and said, <i>Of a talent of pure gold he made it, and all the vessels thereof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> the meaning being that all its vessels he [i.e., Bezalel] made of pure gold, not that he made them out of the talent of gold. Included in the expression <i>all the vessels thereof</i> are the oil vessels, for he made with the candelabrum many vessels besides those mentioned, just as it is said during the journeyings, <i>And they shall cover the candelabrum of the light, and its lamps, and its tongs, and its snuffdishes, and all the oil vessels thereof, wherewith they minister unto it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 4:9.</i> And the verse which states, <i>unto the base thereof, and unto the flowers thereof, it was beaten work</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:4.</i> likewise indicates according to its plain sense that only the candelabrum itself was of beaten work but not its lamps. All this is in accordance with the line of teaching of the Gemara.<br>But in the Beraitha of the work of the Tabernacle<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">See above, Note 108.</i> it is taught in another way. “The candelabrum which Moses made in the wilderness was made of gold. It had to be made by a process of beating, and had to have cups, knops, and flowers, for it is said, <i>And thou shalt make a candelabrum of pure gold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 31.</i> I might have thought that [the cups etc.] may be made separately and then soldered on to the candelabrum; Scripture therefore states, <i>they shall be of one piece with it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 36.</i> How do we know that this includes lamps, so that they must also be made of one piece with it? Scripture therefore says, [<i>Of a talent of pure gold</i>] <i>he shall make</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 39 before us.</i> I might think this also includes its cups, knops, and flowers? Scripture therefore says, <i>it</i> [<i>he shall make ‘it’</i>]. Now how do you know that you are to include its lamps and exclude its cups, knops and flowers? Since Scripture has here used a term of amplification and followed it by a term of limitation,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">A literal translation of the text here reads: “After it included its lamps Scripture limited.” I have followed on this point Ish Shalom’s text (see Note 108). The thought conveyed would seem to be identical in both versions.</i> I reason as follows: I include its lamps because they have to be made with the candelabrum, and I exclude its cups, knops and flowers because they do not always have to be made with it.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">The intent, as explained further on, is as follows: even if the candelabrum is made of any other metal beside gold it must also contain the branches. But cups, knops, and flowers are to be made only if the candelabrum is made out of gold. — When the Hasmonean kings recaptured the Temple from the hands of the Greeks the candelabrum was first made of iron, then of silver and finally when the people could afford it, they made it of gold (Menachoth 28 b). Now when it was made of iron or silver it did not need cups, knops etc.</i> And how do I know that I am to include its <i>malkocheha</i><sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Up to this point we have followed all standard commentators — Rashi, Onkelos, etc. as well as all translations — that <i>melkochayim</i> are “tongs.” But from this point on it is clear [and Ramban will so clarify it further] that <i>melkochayim</i> are a sort of cover-like part for each of the lamps so that no impurities fall into the lamp while it is burning. Ramban’s comment that “in the same way they make today in candelabrums for kings” is obviously a reference to what he had personally seen in the royal palace of the Kingdom of Aragon which as the recognized leader of the Jews he often visited.</i> and <i>machtotheha?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The same change applies to <i>machtoth</i> which we have translated till now as “snuffdishes.” But it is clear that Ramban interprets it now as meaning that underneath each lamp there was a small receptacle for the sparks to fall into.</i> Scripture therefore says, [<i>of beaten work</i>] <i>shall it be done</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 31.</i> I might think I am also to include the <i>tzvatim</i> (tongs) and the snuffers; Scripture therefore says, [<i>Of a talent of pure gold he shall make</i>] <i>it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 39 before us.</i> And how do you know that you are to include the <i>malkocheha</i> and <i>machtotheha</i> and exclude the tongs and the snuffers? Since Scripture has here used a term of amplification and followed it by a term of limitation, I reason as follows: I include the <i>malkocheha</i> and <i>machtotheha</i> because they are used with the candelabrum, and I exclude the tongs and the snuffers because they are not used with it. Rabbi Yehoshua the son of Korcha says: <i>It</i> [i.e., the candelabrum] is made of the talent, but not its vessels, for it is said, <i>Of a talent of pure gold he shall make ‘it.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 39 before us.</i> And if you ask how will I then explain the expression, <i>and all its vessels</i>? Then I reply that it means that they should be made of pure gold [but not of the talent].” Thus far is the text of the Beraitha.<br>It appears from that which the Rabbis, of blessed memory, have said, that the lamps, the <i>melkochayim</i>, and the <i>machtoth</i> were all made of beaten work together with the candelabrum; since the <i>melkochayim</i> were not tongs [as we understood the word till now]<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">And as Rashi and Onkelos interpreted <i>melkochayim</i> to mean “tongs.”</i> but they were rather golden lids which were made on the rim of the lamps for opening and closing, and would cover them so that nothing fell into the oil, in the same way that they make today in candelabrums for kings. This usage [of the word <i>melkochayim</i>] is associated with the expression, <i>and my tongue cleaveth ‘malkochay’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 22:16.</i> — the palate and bottom parts of the mouth being called <i>melkochayim</i> [of the root <i>loko’ach</i> — “taking”] because they “take in” the tongue between them.<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The above-mentioned verse from the Psalms would then mean: “and my tongue cleaveth to the roof and bottom of my mouth.”</i> The <i>machtoth</i> are receptacles under each lamp to catch the sparks of fire which might fall from them. The <i>melkochayim</i> and the <i>machtoth</i> were all of one beaten work with the candelabrum and were made out of the talent of gold. But the tongs and the snuffers, which were not used in the candelabrum itself but were instead vessels separate from it and not attached thereto, did not come from the talent at all. Similarly this Beraitha excluded its cups, knops and flowers, so that if he wanted to make them not of beaten work together with the candelabrum he was so permitted, the reason according to the Beraitha being “because they are not made with it,” that is to say, they do not invalidate the candelabrum. For if he made it of any other metal besides gold, it did not come with cups, knops and flowers, but the [six] branches [with the central shaft] always invalidated the candelabrum if lacking therefrom.<br>According to this Beraitha then, the Scriptural expression, <i>and all the vessels thereof</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> means that Bezalel made of gold all vessels needed for the proper use of the candelabrum and appropriate to it — these being the tongs and the snuffers that are necessary in the use of all candelabrums. Similarly, <i>All the instruments of the Tabernacle in all the service thereof</i><sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:19.</i> means all instruments needed for [erecting] the Tabernacle. These He did not explain but mentioned only that they were to be made of brass. But the verse before us which states, <i>Of a talent of pure gold shall he make it, with all these vessels</i>, refers to those vessels mentioned [in the preceding verse, namely, <i>malkocheha</i> and <i>machtotheha</i>], and they were all of beaten work with it. It is possible that the statement which Scripture uses at the construction, namely, <i>and all the vessels thereof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> alludes to these vessels [the <i>malkocheha</i> and <i>machtotheha</i>] mentioned there in the preceding verse, so that they were all to be made with the candelabrum of beaten work, as is the plain meaning of Scripture. But <i>the vessels of oil</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 4:9.</i> were not mentioned at the construction just as they were not mentioned at the command [for making the candelabrum], but they made them on their<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., Bezalel and Oholiab.</i> own accord. Perhaps Bezalel did not make them but certain individuals made them and dedicated them to the public.<br>In summary, the candelabrum itself came from the talent, but nothing outside of it came therefrom, according to the words of all authorities.

Verse 17

TWO TENONS SHALL THERE BE IN EACH BOARD. Rashi wrote: “He cut out the lower part of the board in the middle to a height of one cubit, and he left one quarter of its width on the one side and one quarter of it on the other side. These [pieces on each side] are the <i>yadoth</i> (the tenons). The part cut out between the tenons was one half of the breadth of the board, and these tenons they fixed into the sockets which were hollowed out. The sockets were one cubit in height, forty of them fitting closely one to the other. The tenons of the boards which were fixed into the sockets were cut away on three sides, the width of the portions cut away being equal to the thickness of the rim of the sockets, so that when the boards [were fitted into the sockets, the wood of the board] would cover the entire top of the socket. For if this were not so [if the same thickness were not cut away from the tenons], there would have been a space between one board and the other equal to the thickness of the rims of the two sockets which would have separated them. This is what is meant when it is said, <i>And they shall be coupled together beneath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> meaning, that they should cut away the sides of the tenons so that the boards should fit closely one to the other.” So I found the language of the Rabbi.<br>But I wonder! If the part cut away in the middle was half of the breadth of the board [as Rashi has it] — measuring four and a half handbreadths<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">The whole breadth of the board was a cubit and a half (Verse 16) which are nine handbreadths, and a half thereof is four and a half.</i> — it follows that the thickness of the rim of each socket must be the same as a fourth of the breadth of the board, which is two handbreadths and a thumb, in order that the thickness [of the rims] of the two sockets should cover the part cut away in the middle, which is half of the breadth of the board, and thus there would be no space between one socket and the other. But if so, if you cut away the boards<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">“The boards.” In Mizrachi quoting Ramban: “the tenons.” This is correct. The Hebrew text before us also means the same, except that the term “boards” is here used in a general sense.</i> on three sides in that way, there would be nothing left [for the tenons], since the rims of the sockets were alike on all sides! Moreover, the Rabbi [Rashi] brought proof further on in Verse 20, stating: “Thus it is taught in the Mishnah of ‘The structure of the Tabernacle:' The order of arranging the boards for making the Tabernacle was as follows: He made the sockets hollow and cut away from<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">The text in Rashi states <i>v’choreitz</i> (and he cuts away) — “and he cuts away a quarter on one side and a quarter on the other side.” Ramban will then ask: if in addition to these two quarters which he cuts away at the sides he also cuts away in the middle half of the width of the board — then there is nothing left for the tenons! Mizrachi answers that Rashi’s understanding of the Beraitha was that the expression “a quarter on one side etc.” does not refer to the cutting away but to what is “left” at the sides of the board as tenons. The translation would then be: “and he cuts the board at the bottom, [leaving] a quarter on one side and a quarter on the other.” To understand the text of Ramban though requires the first translation as above.</i> the board at the bottom a quarter of its width on one side and a quarter on the other, and the cut-away portion in the middle totalled one half of its width. Thus they made for each board two tenons like two rungs of a ladder, and these they fixed into the two sockets.” But if one takes this Beraitha too in its ordinary sense, it would result in something exceedingly astonishing. For if he cuts away from the board a quarter on each side, and in the middle he cuts away half of the breadth of the board, then the whole bottom part [to the height of a cubit] is cut away, and nothing is left of it at all [to serve as a tenon]! In my opinion, however, this Beraitha did not specify the size of the amount cut away, since the Torah also gave no measurements for the thickness of the rims of the sockets. Therefore what the Rabbis [in this Beraitha] said is that he cut away a quarter of the total amount of the board on one side in order to cover one rim of the socket, and another quarter he cut away on the other side; and in the middle of the board he cut away <i>half</i> of the total amount cut away from the whole board, in order to cover the rims of the two sockets.<br>But according to all opinions it still needs to be clarified further, because the Tabernacle at the bottom to the height of a cubit was not wide ten cubits,<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">That is to say, Scripture states that the height of each board was to be <i>ten</i> cubits (Verse 16). But because of the cutting away at the bottom to the height of a cubit for the tenons, its size was reduced to <i>nine</i> cubits high, as it lay on top of the sockets!</i> since the thickness of the two sockets, one on each side, reduced its size! Perhaps there is no objection to that. And in the words of Rashi we read: “He cut away from the thickness of the tenons inside, out of the board which was a cubit thick, according to the thickness of the rims of the sockets”. This is correct, but it is not mentioned in the Beraitha.
MESHULAVOTH ISHAH EL ACHOTHAH’ (SET IN ORDER ONE TO ANOTHER). “<i>Meshulavoth</i> means made like <i>shlivoth</i> (rungs of) a ladder. <i>One to another</i>, this means that they should correspond exactly one to the other, and should be separated from each other, and so planed at their ends that they may be inserted into the hollow of the sockets, just like a rung enters the holes of a ladder’s uprights; further, that the portions cut away [from the boards] in their fronts and backs should be alike, one identical to the other, in order that there should not be two tenons, one of which extends towards the front and the other towards the back in relation to the thickness of the board which was one cubit.” This is Rashi’s language.<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">It should be noted that the version of Rashi here in Ramban is somewhat different in the order of the phrases from the standard editions of Rashi.</i><br>Thus according to Rashi the word <i>meshulavoth</i> refers back to the tenons, that they be planed at their ends so that they enter the hollow of the sockets, and <i>ishah el achothah (one to the other)</i> refers only to the boards, that they be fitted close together. But the Hebrew word <i>krashim</i> (boards) is masculine, and therefore it should have rather said <i>ish el achiv</i> [“one to the other” — in the masculine form]!<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">And not <i>ishah el achothah</i> — which is in the feminine form.</i> Perhaps [Rashi] will interpret <i>ishah el achothah</i> as meaning that the <i>shlivoth</i> [literally: “the rungs” but here referring to the <i>yadoth</i>, the tenons — a feminine form] correspond exactly one with the other, and the thickness of wood cut away from each of the tenons be exactly alike, for in that way the boards will fit closely together. Now the tenons were not planed in a sloping fashion, for the hollow of the sockets was alike in each of them; they were cut only on their sides in order that the boards fit closely one to another.<br>But in the Beraitha on the work of the Tabernacle I found the following text: “Two <i>sanin</i> (‘pegs’) [as explained further] projected from the boards, two from each of them, fitting into corresponding holes, for it is said, <i>meshulavoth ishah el achothah</i>. These are the words of Rabbi Nechemyah. For Rabbi Nechemyah says: It should not have said <i>meshulavoth</i>; what does Scripture teach us then by using that word? It is to teach us that he make them like the rungs of an Egyptian ladder.” Now the meaning of the word <i>sanin</i> is similar to the device they make in chests to tighten and hold the boards together, a sort of wooden peg, somewhat like that which we have been taught in the Mishnah of Keilim:<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Keilim 10:6.</i> “If [two boards] were fastened together with <i>sanin</i> (pegs) or joints they need not be plastered in the middle.”<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Since the pegs or joints hold the boards together tightly they need not be plastered in the middle to afford protection from corpse uncleanness.</i> In the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 117a.</i> they likewise speak of “reeds and <i>sanin</i>.” Accordingly it would appear that Scripture is telling us that he is to make a projection on the side of the board, like a sort of “male shafts,”<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Succah 12b.</i> and on the opposite side of the board next to it he is to make a corresponding cavity into which the arrow-head is set. The same he is to do on the other board, thus dovetailing each board twice [one on each side]. <i>Meshulavoth ishah el achothah</i> is thus a reference to these <i>shlivoth</i> (pegs) themselves [and not to the tenons as Rashi has it], and is here properly in the feminine form [<i>ishah el achothah</i>, because of the word <i>shlivah</i> which is feminine]. And so did the Sages make mention of this term in the feminine: “The <i>shlivah</i> (rundle) slipped from under him;”<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Makkoth 7b.</i> “In a ladder it depends on the material of <i>shlivothav</i> (its steps).”<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 60a. And if the steps are of metal the whole ladder is susceptible to uncleanness.</i> And even though we find the plural of this word in the masculine form — <i>between ‘hashlabim’ (the stays)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 7:28.</i> — it is like <i>nashim</i> (women) and <i>pilagshim</i> (concubines) whose plural form is in the masculine.
KEIDMAH MIZRACHAH’ (ON THE EAST SIDE EASTWARD).<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:13. — At this point Ramban begins to explain the significance of the Hebrew terms for “east, west etc.,” which are mentioned in connection with the arrangement of the boards. The word <i>kedem</i> (east) is not found in connection with the boards, as the Tabernacle on that side had only a curtain. Hence Ramban chose a verse from the following chapter which mentions <i>kedem</i>, and then he will revert to the theme of the boards, and explain the terms <i>negbah, teimanah</i> (the south side, southward) mentioned here in the following Verse 18.</i> The reason for this expression is that the Sacred Language calls the east <i>kedem</i>, just as it is said, <i>And ye shall measure without the city for the side of ‘keidmah’ (east) two thousand cubits</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 35:5.</i> and calls the west <i>achor</i> (back), just as it is said, <i>Behold, I go ‘kedem’ (forward), but He is not there, v’achor (and backward), but I cannot perceive Him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Job 23:8.</i> Similarly: <i>As far as ‘ha’achron’ (the hinder) sea</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 34:2.</i> which means the western sea. Both [<i>kedem</i> and <i>achor</i>] are borrowed terms, as the Sacred Language adopts these substitute forms from the standpoint of a person who turns to the light of the sun [thus calling the east <i>panim</i>, “face,” because his face is turned eastward to the rising sun, and the west <i>achor</i>, “back,” because his back is then to the west]. Similarly it says, <i>and they went l’achor (backward) and not ‘l’panim’ (forward)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 7:24. According to Ramban the sense of the verse is: they went away from the light [the word of G-d] and did not go towards it.</i> And the south is called <i>negev</i> (dry, parched) because the land is dried up on account of the heat. At times Scripture mentions the borrowed term and then explains it by name. Thus it says <i>keidmah</i>, a term which is borrowed, and explains it by saying <i>mizrachah</i> (eastward),<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 27:13. — At this point Ramban begins to explain the significance of the Hebrew terms for “east, west etc.,” which are mentioned in connection with the arrangement of the boards. The word <i>kedem</i> (east) is not found in connection with the boards, as the Tabernacle on that side had only a curtain. Hence Ramban chose a verse from the following chapter which mentions <i>kedem</i>, and then he will revert to the theme of the boards, and explain the terms <i>negbah, teimanah</i> (the south side, southward) mentioned here in the following Verse 18.</i> which is the name itself. Similarly, it says <i>negbah</i>, which is the borrowed name, and explains it by its proper name — <i>teimanah</i> (southward).<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18 (here in Chapter 26 before us). See above Note 211.</i> And the west is called by the substitute name <i>yam</i> [which also means “sea”] because the language adopted it from the standpoint of the people living in the Land of Israel to whom the Great Sea is on the west. The north on the other hand has no by-name, and is so called <i>tzaphon</i> [which means “hidden”] because the sun never appears on that side. The south is called <i>darom</i>, just as it is said, <i>The wind goeth toward ‘darom’ (the south), and turneth about into the north</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 1:6.</i> It is really a double word [<i>dor rum</i> — “it abides in the height,” a reference to the sun that always reaches its greatest height on that side], with one letter <i>reish</i> missing because of the combination of two similar letters: <i>dor rum</i>, which means that the sun [always] moves at its highest point on that side. The south is also called <i>yamin</i> [which means “right”] and the north is called <i>smol</i> [meaning “left”] with reference to a man who turns eastward [to face the light of the rising sun, in which case his right hand is to the south, and his left to the north], as I have mentioned.<br>The secret of these names is known from the mystic speculations on the Chariot on high [i.e. the vision of Ezekiel of the Divine Chariot]. Likewise, [the secret of] the name for the west which is <i>yam</i> (sea) is known from that which the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 25a.</i> “The Divine Glory is in the west,” for the <i>yam</i> alludes to “the wisdom of Solomon,” just as the Rabbis have said in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The exact source is unknown to me. See, however, in my Hebrew commentary p. 468, Note 52 for a similar thought in Yerushalmi Shekalim VI, 1.</i> “<i>Yam</i> always signifies Torah, as it is said, <i>and broader than ‘yam’ (the sea)</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Job 11:9.</i> I intend to mention this in the section of <i>V’zoth Habrachah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:1.</i> on the verse, <i>possess thou ‘yam’ (the sea) and the south</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> if my Creator will bless me to reach there.

Verse 24

AND THEY SHALL BE COUPLED TOGETHER ABOVE THE HEAD OF IT UNTO THE ONE RING. According to Rashi’s interpretation this verse goes back to explain that all the boards should be coupled together beneath, where the boards were cut away on their sides, and they all should be <i>coupled together about the head of it</i>, meaning “of each board.” Or it may be that <i>rosho (the head of it)</i> refers to the top of the Tabernacle. Similarly, [according to Rashi] the expression <i>unto the one ring</i> means of each of the boards. Likewise he explained, <i>thus shall it be for them both</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">In the second half of Verse 24 (before us).</i> for the two end boards [for the board at the end of the north side and for the adjacent board in the western wall].<br>But if this is so, I do not know why Scripture does not explicitly tell us about these rings, saying “and you shall make twenty gold rings” [instead of saying, <i>unto the one ring</i>, which means of each board], seeing that it mentions the cut which he is to make in all the boards.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> Moreover, how could Scripture say <i>unto the one ring</i> with the definite article [when it has not mentioned it previously]? Perhaps because it is the customary manner with all houses made of boards to attach them at the top with one ring, Scripture shortened the explanation and said <i>the ring</i> — meaning the one which is known to him and customary. Similarly it said of the bars, <i>and thou shalt make their rings of gold for places for the bolts</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29.</i> which means the customary [rings] being known to them. A similar case is the expression, <i>their hooks shall be of gold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 37.</i><br>I have found in the Beraitha on the work of the Tabernacle [the following text]: “He cut away the board at the top, a fingerbreadth on one side and a fingerbreadth on the other side, and he placed them [i.e., the two adjacent boards] inside one gold ring in order that they should not move apart from each other, for it is said, <i>And they shall be coupled together beneath, and they shall be coupled together above the head of it unto the one ring</i>. Now it need not have said, <i>unto the one ring;</i> and what does it teach us by saying it? It is to teach us that this is the place where the bolts were inserted.” Accordingly, the verse stating: <i>and they shall be coupled together above the head of it</i>, refers to the head of the board where it was cut away until the place of the upper ring of the bolts, for the incision in the board was to extend as far as the place of the ring. Now Scripture was not particular [concerning these upper parts of the boards] how they should be attached, whether with rings of silver or gold, fixed ones or moveable, or with connecting rods. But the Beraitha states that Moses made rings for that purpose. However, in line with the plain meaning of Scripture this verse refers only to the endboards.

Verse 33

AND THOU SHALT BRING IN THITHER WITHIN THE VEIL THE ARK OF THE TESTIMONY. He did not now command Moses to do it in this particular order, to hang up the veil under the clasps and only afterwards to bring in the ark inside the veil, for the commandment now does not refer to the erection of the Tabernacle but to the making thereof. Similarly, <i>And thou shalt put the ark-cover upon the ark of the Testimony in the most holy place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 34.</i> does not mean that he is to put the ark-cover upon the ark of the Testimony when the ark has already been brought into the Holy of Holies [screened by the veil].<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">On the contrary, at the charge for the erection of the Tabernacle it is said, <i>And thou shalt put therein the ark of the Testimony</i> (further 40:3), <i>and</i> then <i>thou shalt screan the ark with the veil (ibid.)</i>. It is so explained in the Tur based upon Ramban’s words further on.</i> But the purport of the verse is to command Moses to hang up the veil under the clasps in order that the ark be there within the veil, and the veil will thus divide <i>between the holy place and the most holy</i>. Similarly He says, <i>And thou shalt put the ark-cover upon the ark of the Testimony in the most holy place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 34.</i> in order to inform us that the ark-cover with its cherubim on the ark should all be there in the Holy of Holies mentioned, which means within the veil. But when He came to command the erection of the Tabernacle He said, <i>And thou shalt put therein the ark of the Testimony, and</i> afterwards, <i>thou shalt screen the ark with the veil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 40:3.</i> Similarly, at the actual construction it is said, <i>and he put the ark-cover above the ark. And he brought the ark into the Tabernacle, and</i> afterwards, <i>he set up the veil of the screen</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20-21.</i><br>Tetzaveh

Verse 20

Scripture states here, <i>and thou shalt command</i> [and does not say, “command the children of Israel”], because He always said with reference to the Tabernacle <i>and thou shalt make</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:11, etc.</i> which means by your command [i.e., “you Moses command them to do it”]. Therefore He said here “and you yourself command them that they bring to you the oil for the light.” [It says <i>that they bring</i> and not “that they make”] because they had no way of making the oil in the wilderness; [therefore they were told] to bring it if they had it in reserve. Actually it were the princes that brought it.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:27-28.</i> 
The meaning of the word <i>eilecha</i> (unto thee) — [<i>that they bring ‘unto thee’ pure olive oil</i>] is that they were to bring it to Moses and he would see if it was pure and beaten properly. A similar intent is present in the verse, <i>Command the children of Israel, that they bring unto thee</i> [<i>pure olive oil beaten for the light</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:2.</i> 
The meaning of the expression <i>of the children of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 21.</i> is that they bring you the oil from the children of Israel, from whoever has it in his possession, just as He said, <i>of every man whose heart maketh him willing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:2.</i> Similarly He said, <i>And bring thou near unto thee Aaron thy brother, and his sons with him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:1.</i> meaning that you yourself are to call them and give them the tidings of this distinction. <i>And thou shalt make</i> them <i>holy garments</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> means by commanding the wise men who wrought the work as was done with <i>all the work of this pattern</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 28:19.</i> Likewise, <i>And thou shalt speak unto all that are wise-hearted</i><sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:3.</i> means that Moses himself is to speak to them, for he will recognize their qualifications and know which is the work that ought to be given over to each of them. Now because He said, <i>And bring thou near;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:1.</i> <i>And thou shalt make</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 2.</i> it was necessary that He explain, <i>And thou shalt speak unto all that are wise-hearted</i> [<i>…that they make Aaron’s garments</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 28:3.</i> for it was by the command of Moses that they were to make the garments,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">For one might have thought that since Verse 1 [<i>And bring thou near unto thee…</i>] means that Moses himself is to speak to Aaron and his sons, as explained above, Verse 2 following [<i>And thou shalt make holy garments for Aaron…</i>] also means that Moses himself is to make them; hence it was necessary to explain in Verse 3 [<i>And thou shalt speak unto all that are wise-hearted… that they make Aaron’s garments</i>], meaning that they are to be made in the same way as the rest of the work.</i> as was the case with the rest of the work of which it is said, <i>See, I have called by name Bezalel etc</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 31:2.</i>
TO CAUSE A LAMP TO BURN ‘TAMID’ (CONTINUALLY). “Doing something each and every night is called <i>tamid</i> (continually), just as you say, <i>olath tamid (a continual burnt-offering)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 28:6.</i> and yet it was brought only from day to day. Similarly in the case of the meal-offering made on the griddle [brought every day by the High Priest] it is said <i>tamid</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 6:13.</i> and yet it was brought only <i>half of it in the morning, and half thereof in the evening</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 6:13.</i> However, the word <i>tamid</i> used in connection with the showbread<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:30.</i> signifies [the whole period without interruption] from Sabbath to Sabbath.” Thus is Rashi’s language.<br>But the Midrash [interpretation] of our Rabbis is not so. Instead they taught in the Sifre as follows:<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre, beginning of <i>Seder Beha’alothcha</i>.— For meaning of “Sifre” see <i>Seder Yithro</i>, Note 52.</i> “<i>The seven lamps shall give light</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 8:2.</i> I might think that they are to burn always; Scripture therefore says, <i>from evening to morning</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:3, and Verse 2 here.</i> I might then think that they are to burn from evening to morning and then he is to extinguish them; Scripture therefore says, <i>the seven lamps shall give light</i>. — How is this to be understood? <i>The seven lamps shall give light from evening to morning. Before the Eternal continually</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:3, and Verse 2 here.</i> — this refers to the <i>neir ma’aravi</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “the western light.” It is this light which is considered as being <i>before the Eternal</i>, and therefore is to burn <i>continually</i>, for it is to that particular light that the expression <i>before the Eternal continually</i>, applies. See further Note 23 as to which of the seven lamps in the candelabrum the term <i>neir hama’aravi</i> has reference to.</i> which is to burn perpetually, since the candelabrum was lit from it in the evening.” In the Torath Kohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>Emor</i> 13:7. — Torath Kohanim is another name for the Sifra, which is the Halachic Midrash of the Tannaim on the Book of Leviticus.</i> the Rabbis have likewise said: “<i>To cause a lamp to burn continually</i> — this means that ‘the western light’ should burn perpetually.” They have further taught there: “If [the priest who came into the Sanctuary in the morning to trim the candelabrum] found that it had gone out, he cleaned it out and kindled it from [the fire upon] the altar of the whole-offering.” Thus it is clear that even at daytime he kindled the <i>neir ma’aravi</i>, for that lamp always burnt regularly [and not as Rashi has it that the candelabrum was lit only in the evening]. And in Tractate Tamid<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Tamid 3:9.</i> we have been taught as follows: “[The priest] who was privileged to clean out the candelabrum [during the morning service] entered [the Sanctuary], and if he found the two easternmost lamps burning, he cleaned out the rest [leaving them to be lit during the evening service], but the two easternmost lamps he left burning as they were. If he found that [the two easternmost lamps] had gone out, he cleaned them out and kindled them from those that were still burning, and then cleaned out the rest” [leaving them to be kindled during the evening service].<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">This text again shows that there were lamps burning in the candelabrum the whole day. — In case the priest found that all the lights had gone out it has already been mentioned above in Ramban’s text quoting the Torath Kohanim that the <i>neir ma’aravi</i> was then kindled from the fire upon the altar of the burnt-offering which stood outside in the Sanctuary Court.</i> Now this anonymous Mishnah conforms to the opinion of Rabbi<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi. See in <i>Seder Mishpatim</i> Note 64.</i> who says that the lamps of the candelabrum were placed in an east-west direction, and the <i>neir ma’aravi</i> (the western light) in his opinion is the second light from the east side.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">For since the candelabrum was standing with its six branches extending in an east-west direction, the first [the easternmost] light could not be considered as being <i>before the Eternal</i>, since that expression implies that there is one light still further away from the Holy of Holies [where the Divine Glory abided]. Hence the first lamp of which it might be said that it is <i>before the Eternal</i> is the second from the east, and since we must not pass over an occasion for performing a religious act, the second light from the east becomes affixed as being <i>before the Eternal</i>, and that is the <i>neir ma’aravi</i> (the western light). — There is, however, another opinion [mentioned further on in the text] that the candelabrum was placed in a south-north direction, and the term <i>neir ma’aravi</i> was given to the middle lamp, because the three lamps on each side turned towards the center one. — Menachoth 98b. See also Shabbath 22 b, Rashi.</i> It is called <i>ma’aravi</i> (western) because it is to the west of the first, and since he has to kindle the western light to fulfill therewith the Divine command <i>before the Eternal continually</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:3, and Verse 2 here.</i> he must kindle also the easternmost lamp, for the second lamp cannot be called “western” until there be an “eastern” next to it.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Hence if the ministering priest found that the two easternmost lamps had gone out, he trimmed them and kindled them both. For although the command regarding the perpetual lamp [burning day and night] applied essentially to the second — the western — light, yet since it could not be called “western” unless there was an “eastern” in front of it, the priest lit both.</i> But according to the opinion of the Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rabbi Eleazar the son of Rabbi Shimon (Menachoth 98 b).</i> who says that the candelabrum was placed in a north-south direction, the <i>neir ma’aravi</i> was the middle one — on the central shaft of the candelabrum — and that light alone he kindled in the morning [for since none of the lamps were “outside” of it towards the east it was not necessary that another lamp be lighted].<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Thus there appears an important difference as to the number of lights that burned a whole day in the candelabrum. According to Rabbi who holds that the candelabrum was placed in an east-west direction, the two easternmost lamps burned a whole day [for reasons explained in Note 24]. But according to Rabbi Eleazar the son of Rabbi Shimon who says that the candelabrum was placed in a north-south direction, only the middle lamp burned a whole day.</i> Thus the principle is clear that the expression <i>before the Eternal continually</i> applies to “the western light,” which burns regularly day and night.

Chapter 28



Verse 1

AND THOU BRING THOU NEAR AARON THY BROTHER, AND HIS SONS WITH HIM … THAT THEY MINISTER UNTO ME IN THE PRIEST’S OFFICE, EVEN AARON, NADAB AND ABIHU, ELEAZAR AND ITHAMAR, AARON’S SONS. The reason for mentioning <i>Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar</i> [when it mentioned already “and his sons”] is that Moses should not think that by anointing the father to minister as priest, his sons would automatically become priests; instead he had to initiate them personally into the priesthood. Thus Phinehas [the son of Eleazar] and others already born were excluded [from the priesthood], for only these four sons who were anointed with Aaron, and their children born to them henceforth, were appointed as priests.

Verse 2

AND THOU SHALT MAKE HOLY GARMENTS FOR AARON THY BROTHER FOR SPLENDOR AND BEAUTY — this means that he be distinguished and glorified with garments of distinction and beauty, just as Scripture says, <i>as a bridegroom putteth on a priestly diadem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:10.</i> For these garments [of the High Priest] correspond in their forms to garments of royalty, which monarchs wore at the time when the Torah was given. Thus we find with reference to the tunic, <i>and he made him a tunic of ‘pasim’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:3.</i> — meaning, a cloth woven of variegated colors, this being <i>the tunic of chequer work</i> [mentioned here], just as [Ibn Ezra] explained, which clothed him <i>as a son of ancient kings</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 19:11.</i> The same applies to the robe and the tunic, as it is written, <i>Now she</i> [Tamar] <i>had a garment of many colors upon her; for with such robes were the king’s daughters that were virgins apparelled</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 13:18.</i> which means that a garment of many colors was seen clearly upon her, for such was the custom that the virgin daughters of the king wore robes with which they wrapped themselves; thus the coat of many colors was upon her as an upper garment. It is for this reason that it says there, <i>and she rent her garment of many colors that was on her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19.</i> The mitre [mentioned here] is to this day known among kings and distinguished lords. Therefore Scripture says with reference to the fall of the kingdom [of Judah], <i>The mitre shall be removed, and the crown taken off</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 21:31.</i> Similarly it is written, <i>and a royal diadem</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 62:3.</i> Scripture also calls them <i>the ornamented high caps</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:28.</i> and it is further written, <i>They shall have linen ornamented</i> [caps] <i>upon their heads</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 44:18.</i> which are for the beauty and glory of those that are adorned with them. The ephod and the breastplate are also royal garments, just as it is written, <i>and thou shalt have a chain of gold about thy neck</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 5:16.</i> The plate [around the forehead, which the High Priest wore], is like a king’s crown. Thus it is written, <i>‘yatzitz nizro’ (his crown will shine)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 132:18. — Ramban thus associates the word <i>tzitz</i> (plate) with the expression <i>yatzitz nizro</i> (his crown will shine), thus suggesting that the <i>tzitz</i> of the High Priest is a sort of royal crown.</i> Furthermore, [the High Priest’s garments] are made of <i>gold, blue-purple, and red-purple</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 5.</i> [which are all symbolic of royalty]. Thus it is written, <i>All glorious is the king’s daughter within the palace; her raiment is of chequer work inwrought with gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 45:14.</i> and it is further written, <i>thou shalt be clothed with purple, and have a chain of gold about thy neck</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 5:16.</i> As for the blue-purple, even to this day <i>no man will lift up his hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 41:44.</i> to wear it except a king of nations,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 14:9.</i> and it is written, <i>And Mordecai went forth from the presence of the king in royal apparel of blue and white, and with a great crown of gold, and with a ‘tachrich’ (robe) of fine linen and purple</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 8:15.</i> — the <i>tachrich</i> being a robe in which the wearer wraps himself.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala,] majesty is to <i>kavod</i> (glory) and to <i>tiphereth</i> (splendor),<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Cabalistic terms for certain Emanations.</i> the verse thus stating that they should make <i>holy garments for Aaron</i> to minister in them to the Glory of G-d Who dwells in their midst, and to the Splendor of their strength, as it is written, <i>For Thou art the Glory of their strength</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:18.</i> and it is further stated, <i>Our holy and our beautiful house, where our fathers praised Thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 64:10.</i> meaning [“the house of] our Holy One” which is the Glory, and “of our Splendor” which is the Splendor of Israel. And it is further stated, <i>Strength and beauty are in His Sanctuary</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 96:6.</i> and similarly, <i>To beautify the place of My Sanctuary, and I will make the place of My feet glorious</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:13.</i> — meaning, that the place of the Sanctuary will be glorified by the Splendor, and the place of His feet, which is the place of the Sanctuary, will be honored by the presence of the Glory of G-d. <i>And in Israel will He glorify Himself</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 44:23.</i> also means that in Israel He will show and designate His Splendor. Likewise He says further with respect to the garments of all of Aaron’s sons, that they are <i>for splendor and for beauty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 40.</i> Of the sacrifices He also says, <i>they will come up with ‘ratzon’ (‘will’ — acceptance) on Mine altar, and I will glorify My glorious house</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 60:7.</i> Thus the altar is His Will and the house of His Glory is the Splendor.<br>The [priestly] garments had to be made with the intention to be used for that purpose. It is possible that in making them, intent of heart [for what they symbolize] was also needed on the part of their makers. It is for this reason that He said, <i>And thou shalt speak unto all that are wise-hearted, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> — who will understand what they will do. And the Rabbis have already said [of Alexander the Great, that when asked by his generals why he descended from his chariot to bow before the High Priest Simon the Just, he answered]:<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 69a. The story told there is that when Alexander the Great conquered the Land of Israel the Samaritans petitioned him to destroy the Temple in Jerusalem. Thereupon a procession of notables went out from Jerusalem headed by Simon the Just, the High Priest, who was attired in the high priestly garments. They walked a whole night with torches in their hand until dawn. In the morning as soon as Alexander saw Simon the Just, he descended from his chariot and bowed down to him. When the Samaritans said to him, “Such a great king as thou art dost thou bow thyself to that Jew?” He replied, “His image etc.”</i> “His image glistened before me whenever I had a victory.”

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5

AND THEY SHALL TAKE THE GOLD. Now up to this point all the commands were directed to Moses himself: <i>and thou shalt make,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> thou shalt make</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:1.</i> but now He commanded that He should speak <i>unto all that are wise-hearted</i> that they make the garments. It is for this reason that He said, <i>and they shall take the gold and the blue-purple</i>, meaning that they are to receive the free-will gifts directly from the public, and make with them the garments. The purport thereof is to state that the gifts should not be weighed out to them, nor be counted, for they are trustworthy people, similarly to that which is said, <i>Moreover they reckoned not with the men, into whose hand they delivered the money to give to them that did the work; for they dealt faithfully</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 12:16.</i> And just as this is said with reference to the garments, the same applied to the whole work of the Tabernacle. Only on the first day [of its construction] is it written, <i>and they received of Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 36:3.</i> and even then they took everything from him without an accounting. But on the other days the people brought the gifts directly to those who did the work. Therefore it is written, <i>And they spoke unto Moses, saying: The people bring much more than enough</i><sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> — for it was to them that the people brought the free-will gifts, not that they gave them to Moses for him to weigh it out to them. However, after the workers had collected everything, they did count and weigh it out, and told it to Moses, as it is written, <i>and the gold of the offering was twenty and nine talents</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 38:24.</i>

Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28

AND THE BREASTPLATE SHALL NOT BE ‘YIZACH’ (LOOSENED) FROM THE EPHOD. “<i>Yizach</i> is an expression of ‘breaking away’. It is an Arabic expression, as Dunash ben Labrat explained.”<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">A pupil of Saadia Gaon, he was grammarian, exegete and poet. He wrote a criticism of Menachem ben Saruk’s Machbereth (see Vol. I, p. 156, Note 347), whose contemporary he was. He was born in Baghdad and ultimately settled in Cordova where, like Menachem, he was a protege of Hasdai ibn Shaprut. He flourished in the middle of the tenth century.</i> This is Rashi’s language.<br>It appears likely to me, however, that <i>yizach</i> is like <i>yisach</i> (break away), which is associated with the expressions: <i>The Eternal ‘yisach’ (will pluck up) the house of the proud;<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 15:25.</i> and the faithless ‘yis’chu’ (shall be plucked up) out of it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:22.</i> — referring to breaking and plucking, and the letter <i>samech</i> (in <i>yisach</i>), is interchanged with the letter <i>zayin</i> (of <i>yizach</i>), just as in the verses: <i>let the saints ‘ya’alzu’ (exult) in glory;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 149:5. — Here <i>ya’alzu</i> is with a <i>zayin</i>.</i> <i>‘nithalsa’ (let us solace ourselves) with loves;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 7:18. — Here the same root appears with a <i>samech</i>.</i> <i>‘v’nitatztem’ (and ye shall break down) their altars;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 12:3.</i> <i>‘nathsu’ (they break up) my path</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Job 30:13. In this case the <i>tzade</i> interchanges with the <i>samech</i> of the above verse. See in this connection Vol. I, p. 485.</i> Similarly, <i>and they shall keep the watch of the house ‘masach’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 11:6.</i> — from being torn away; he. [Jehoiada the priest] thus warned the guard that not one of them should leave his position and thus cause the watch to be broken. Perhaps the following verse can also be explained on this basis: <i>‘ulmeizach’ wherewith he is girded continually</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 109:19.</i> which means “for separation and breaking,” the verse stating that the wicked shall always be girded with the curse until they will be destroyed and broken up by it, just as others gird themselves with a girdle. <i>There is no ‘meizach’ any more</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 23:10.</i> — there is no more separation, the prophet [Isaiah] telling the people of Tyre: “overflow with the people of your land as the Nile to the land of Tarshish your trafficker; there will be no more separation and scattering for you — for not one will be separated from you there [in the hope of returning to his city], since he will not return to Tyre, because it will have been destroyed completely.” The term <i>horeis</i> applies to one who separates himself from the station of his colleagues, just as in the expression, <i>let them not ‘yehersu’ (break through) towards the Eternal to see</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:21. The beginning of the quote here comes from Verse 24 there.</i> and it is written, <i>and from thy station ‘yehersecha’ (shalt thou be pulled down)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 22:19.</i> Similarly: <i>He looseth ‘meziach aphikim’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:21.</i> — He abates the destruction of the <i>aphikim</i>, which are flooding rivers that inundate mountains and valleys. The term <i>meizach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 23:10.</i> is in the same form as <i>meitzach</i> (forehead), both of them having the letter <i>nun</i> missing,<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">As Ramban will explain, <i>meitzach</i> (forehead) is of the root <i>nitzuach</i> (victory), since the strength of the head is in the forehead. Likewise the word <i>meizah</i> is of the root <i>nosach</i> or <i>nozach</i> which means pull or tear away.</i> <i>as [meitzach</i>] is of the root <i>nitzuach</i> (enduring, victory), for the strength of the head is in the forehead.

Verse 29



Verse 30

AND THOU SHALT PUT IN THE BREASTPLATE OF JUDGMENT THE URIM AND THE THUMMIM. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra thought to display wisdom in the matter of the Urim and the Thummim, by saying that they were made by a craftsman from gold and silver, and he continued his discussion of them in this vein, for he thought that they were akin to the forms which the astrologers make in order to know the thoughts of the one who comes to ask of them [about the future]. But what [Ibn Ezra] said is of no import. Rather, the Urim and the Thummim are as Rashi has written: “This was an inscription of the Proper Name of G-d which was placed between the folds of the breastplate.” It was for this reason that the breastplate had to be double<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> [i.e., made of a material that was folded in order to form a sort of bag, into which the Urim and the Thummim — the sacred Names of G-d, as explained further on, — were placed by Moses]. The proof for this is that in the work of the craftsmen the Urim and the Thummim are not mentioned at all, neither in the command nor in the [description of the] making thereof. Now concerning the garments He details: <i>And he made the ephod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:2.</i> <i>and he made the breastplate</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> but it does not say, “and he made the Urim and the Thummim.” And if it were the work of a skilled engraver He would have dealt with it in greater length than with all [the garments]. Even if perhaps He desired to shorten the discussion about them on account of their profundity, He would at least have said here, “and thou shalt make the Urim and the Thumim as it has been shown to you in the mount; of pure gold — or purified silver — you shall make them.” moreover, you will notice that He did not use the definite article in connection with any of the vessels [of the Tabernacle] which had not been previously mentioned. Instead, He said, <i>and they shall make an ark;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:10.</i> <i>and thou shalt make a table;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> <i>and thou shalt make a candelabrum,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31</i> and thus too in connection with all of them. In the case of the Tabernacle, however, He said, <i>And thou shalt make ‘the’ Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:1.</i> because He had already mentioned it [in saying], <i>And let them make Me a Sanctuary</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:8.</i> Now with reference to the Urim and the Thummim He said, <i>And thou shalt put in the breastplate of judgment ‘the’ Urim and ‘the’ Thummim</i>. He did not command him as to the making of them, and yet Scripture mentions them with the definite article! Moreover, Scripture mentions them with reference to Moses only, saying by way of command, <i>and thou shalt put in the breastplate of judgment…;</i> similarly, at the time of making them it says, <i>and in the breastplate he put the Urim and the Thummim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:8.</i> since they were not the work of craftsmen. Neither craftsmen nor the congregation of Israel had any part whatsoever in their making or in their donation, for they were a secret transmitted by the Almighty to Moses, and he wrote them in holiness. They<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">In Ricanti [quoting the language of Ramban]: “Or they were…”</i> were thus of heavenly origin, and therefore they are referred to without any specification and with the definite article, in a similar usage to that which we have in the verse, <i>and He placed at the east of the garden of Eden the cherubim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 3:24. Here too Scripture uses the definite article [<i>‘the’ cherubim</i>] and yet nowhere previously do we read concerning them (Bachya).</i> Now Moses took the inscription of the Urim and the Thummim, and placed them in the breastplate of judgment after he had clothed Aaron with the ephod and the breastplate, as it is said, <i>And he put the ephod upon him, and he girded him with the skilfully-woven band of the ephod… And he placed the breastplate upon him; and in the breastplate he put the Urim and the Thummim</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:7-8.</i> For only after [Aaron was already clothed with the ephod and the breastplate] did Moses place the Urim and the Thummim between the folds of the breastplate.<br>Thus the Urim and the Thummim were the holy Names of G-d, and it was by virtue of the power residing in these Names that the letters inscribed upon the stones of the breastplate would light up before the eyes of the priest who inquired of their judgment.<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 27:21.</i> For example, when they inquired, <i>Who shall go up for us first against the Canaanites, to fight against them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 1:1. — Scripture continues [in Verse 2]: <i>And the</i> Eternal said: <i>‘Yehudah ya’aleh’ (Judah shall go up)</i>.</i> the priest fixed his thoughts on those Divine Names which were the Urim [literally: “lights”], and the letters forming the name <i>Yehudah</i> lighted up before his eyes, and [for the word <i>ya’aleh</i> — “he shall go up”] the letter <i>yod</i> lighted up from the word <i>Levi</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The twelve stones in the breastplate bore the names of the twelve tribes of Israel. Since there was no letter <i>tzade</i> amongst these names, the patriarchs’ names [<i>Avraham, Yitzchak</i> and <i>Yaakov</i>] were also inscribed upon the stones. Finally to include the letter <i>tet</i> the words <i>shivtei Y-ah</i> (“the tribes of G-d”) were also written upon them (Yoma 73 b). The answer given to the priest who inquired of the Urim and Thummim was through the gleaming forth of the letters written upon the stones. Thus when the tribes asked, <i>Who shall go up for us first against the Canaanites?</i> the name <i>Yehudah</i> gleamed forth, and as for the word <i>ya’aleh</i>, the <i>yod</i> of <i>Levi</i> lighted up etc.</i> the <i>ayin</i> from <i>Shimon</i>, the <i>lamed</i> from <i>Levi</i>, and the <i>hei</i> from <i>Avraham</i> which was also written there, according to the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 73b. See Note above.</i> or perhaps the <i>hei</i> from <i>Yehudah</i> lighted up a second time. Now when the letters lighted up before the eyes of the priest, he did not yet know their arrangement [that is, how these letters were to be grouped together into words], for from the letters forming the words <i>Yehudah ya’aleh</i> (Judah shall go up), it is possible to form the words: <i>hoy heid alehah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">“The echo of woe upon it.”</i> or <i>hie al Yehudah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">“Lamentation upon Judah.”</i> and very many other words. But then there were other sacred Divine Names [in the fold of the breastplate] called Thummim [literally: “perfection”], through whose power the priest’s heart was made perfect to understand the meaning of the letters which lighted up before his eyes. Thus, when he fixed his thoughts on the Divine Names in the Urim, and the letters lighted up, he would then immediately turn and fix his thoughts on the Divine Names in the Thummim, whilst the letters [of the Urim] were still lit up before him, and then it came to his mind that they combine to form the words <i>Yehudah ya’aleh</i> (Judah shall go up). This knowledge [of how to combine the letters that lit up in the breastplate into words], is one level of the degrees of <i>Ruach Hakodesh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “The Holy Spirit.” See Moreh Nebuchim II, 45, beginning: “second degree of prophecy.”</i> It is lower than prophecy, and higher than the <i>Bath Kol</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “echo” or “reverberating sound.” It is here used in the sense of a Divine Voice which on certain occasions was heard coming forth from the Holy of Holies (Sotah 33 a).</i> which served [Israel] in the Second Sanctuary after prophecy had ceased, and after the Urim and Thummim had ceased, just as our Rabbis have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 21b.</i> It is possible that after Moses placed the sacred Names of the Urim and Thummim in the breastplate, they became known to the great Sages of Israel, having been transmitted to them from Moses together with the secrets of the Torah. Hence we find that David possessed an ephod<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 23:6.</i>, which was similar to the ephod of Moses, and together with it was a breastplate similar to the holy breastplate [in the Tabernacle]. It appears, however, that [instead of being made of gold, blue-purple etc.] it was made of linen, just as it says of Samuel that he was <i>a child, girden with a linen ephod</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 2:18.</i> and of Nob, the city of priests, it is said, <i>fourscore and five persons that did wear a linen ephod</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid</i>, 22:18.</i> They would clothe a priest who was of <i>the sons of the prophets</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:1. A term denoting the disciples of the prophets, or those who sought the prophetic gift.</i> and inquire of him [regarding certain events] and at times they were answered, just as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra thought on this point. However, as far as that which he [Ibn Ezra] said, that if [Rashi] had seen the responsum of Rabbeinu Hai,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The last of the Gaonim. He was a son of Rabbeinu Sherira Gaon (see Vol. I, p. 97, Note 477). — Rabbeinu Hai Gaon wrote in a responsum that by invoking the Proper Name of G-d, or the names of the angels, one could not predict future events. Using this responsum as a basis, Ibn Ezra commented that if Rashi had seen this responsum he would not have written that the Urim and Thummim were inscriptions of the Proper Name of G-d etc. [as quoted above]. — To this comment of Ibn Ezra, Ramban answers caustically: “We have already seen this responsum of Rabbeinu Hai and have pondered its meaning, and we do know that it was Ibn Ezra’s understanding that did not grasp it.”</i> he would not have explained as he did, [that the Urim and Thummim were inscriptions of the Proper Name of G-d] — now we have already seen that responsum and have considered it, and we know [for a certainty] that it was Rabbi Abraham whose opinion [shows that he] did not grasp it.

Verse 31

ME’IL’ (ROBE). Rashi commented:<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">On Verse 4 above.</i> “This was a kind of shirt, and so also was the <i>k’thoneth</i>, except that the <i>k’thoneth</i> was worn next to the body and the <i>me’il</i> is a term for the upper [outer] shirt.” But this is not so, for the <i>me’il</i> is a garment in which one wraps oneself, just as Scripture says, <i>and he</i> [Samuel] <i>is covered with a ‘me’il’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 28:14.</i> and it is further written, <i>‘y’atoni’ (He hath covered me) with ‘me’il’ (the robe) of righteousness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:10.</i> and the term <i>atiyah</i> (enwrapping) does not apply to a shirt, but to a garment with which one covers oneself, as it is said, <i>‘oteh’ (Who coverest Thyself) with light as with a garment</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 104:2.</i> it being associated with the term <i>atoph</i> (enveloping onself). And so we find: <i>and his upper lip ‘ya’teh’ (he shall cover up</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 13:45.</i> [which Onkelos renders] <i>yitatoph</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that <i>atiyah</i> and <i>atoph</i> are identical terms.</i> This is identical with the word <i>kardunin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">In our Rashi: <i>kardutin</i>.</i> from the Targum of Jonathan ben Uziel which the Rabbi [Rashi] mentioned [as his translation of the word <i>me’il</i>], for this <i>kardunin</i> is used for enwrapping oneself, something akin to the form of the ephod with which [the High Priest] envelops the half of his body that is towards his feet. But if a <i>me’il</i> was a kind of shirt [as Rashi said], then <i>me’il</i> and <i>kardunin</i> would not be alike at all. Another proof is the verse, <i>and he seized the skirt of ‘me’ilo’ (his robe), and it rent</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 15:27.</i> Thus the <i>me’il</i> has skirts and is not a kind of shirt. Rather, the <i>me’il</i> is a garment which enwraps the whole body from the neck downwards to the feet of the person, and has no sleeves at all. Now in other <i>me’ilim</i> there is a piece of garment for the neck, covering the whole of it, and sewed on [with a needle], this garment being called <i>pi me’il</i> (the hole of the robe), but with reference to this <i>me’il</i> Scripture commanded that it be woven together with the robe.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> The <i>me’il</i> is entirely slit frontwise till the bottom, and he put his head through the hole on top; thus the neck [of the priest] is enwrapped with the hole of the <i>me’il</i>, and in front of him are the two skirts with which he covers or uncovers himself at will — something like [our] cloak which has no head-tire. Now since the seam divides the front part of the <i>me’il</i> and separates it all the way downwards, therefore the term <i>atiyah</i> (enwrapping) is always used in connection with it [as explained above].<br>Nor do I know either<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “in addition to that which I did not understand in Rashi’s definition of the <i>me’il</i> [as explained above], I also do not know why etc.”</i> why the Rabbi [Rashi] made the bells independent objects, stating that there was one bell between every two pomegranates.<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi, Verse 33.</i> For if so, the pomegranates served no purpose. And if they were made just for ornament, why were they made like hollow pomegranates? Let him rather make them like golden apples! Moreover, Scripture should have explained with what the bells should be hung, and whether rings should be made on which to hang the bells. Instead, [we must say that] the bells were inside the pomegranates themselves, for the pomegranates were hollow and made in the shape of small pomegranates that have not yet burst open,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 88b.</i> and the bells were hidden inside but visible through them. Now Scripture has not specified their number. But our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 88b.</i> that there were seventy-two bells and within them there were seventy-two clappers; he hung thirty-six on one side and thirty-six on the other side, as is found in Tractate Zebachim, in the chapter The Altar Sanctifies.<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 88b.</i> From here also you may learn that the <i>me’il</i> was not a sort of shirt or <i>kthoneth</i> [as Rashi wrote], but instead it had skirts [front and back, and therefore the Rabbis speak of “one side” and “the other side” of the <i>me’il</i>].<br>Similarly Rashi wrote<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">On Verse 4 above.</i> that “the <i>mitznepheth</i> (mitre) is a kind of domed helmet, for in another place<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 40.</i> the verse calls it <i>migba’oth</i>, which we translate in the Targum <i>kov’in</i> (helmets).” This also is not correct, for the Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The source is not known. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 476.</i> that the <i>mitznepheth</i> was sixteen cubits long. Thus it was a sort of turban with which the head is wrapped, as he wound it around and around his head, fold upon fold. Moreover, the <i>mitznepheth</i> of the High Priest is nowhere called <i>migba’oth</i> [as Rashi said]. It is only with reference to the ordinary priests that Scripture calls the head-dress <i>migba’oth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:28. [<i>And they made… the ‘mitznepheth’ (mitre) of fine linen, and the ornamented ‘migba’oth’ (head-tires) of fine linen</i>. — Thus Scripture distinguishes between the two garments, since the <i>mitznepheth</i> was made for Aaron and the <i>migba’oth</i> for Aaron’s sons.
