So how did Rashi write of the <i>mitznepheth</i> that in another place Scripture calls it <i>migba’oth?</i></i> and these too were a sort of turban,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent is as follows: Even if we were to say that Rashi intended to state that the head-dress for the High Priest here called <i>mitznepheth</i> is for the common priest elsewhere called <i>migba’at</i>, that too, continues Ramban, would not be correct; since the head-dress for the common priest is also called <i>mitznepheth</i>, as explained in the text (Gur Aryeh). Thus according to Ramban the head-dress for the common priest is called both <i>mitznepheth</i> and <i>migba’at</i>, while that of the High Priest is called only <i>mitznepheth</i>.</i> except that they were set upon<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">The difference between the two attires is thus clear. The head-dress of the High Priest — i.e., the <i>mitznepheth</i> — was wound <i>around</i> his head in several folds like a turban, and the one for the common priest was also wound in folds (hence its name <i>mitznepheth</i>) but set <i>upon</i> his head and came up like a conical helmet [hence its other name — <i>migba’at</i>]. See also Ramban further on Verse 37, and 29:7.</i> the head and the folds came up like a sort of [conical] helmet which is the <i>kovei’a</i>, as Onkelos rendered it. For <i>migba’at</i> is like <i>mikba’at</i>, as I have said in <i>Seder Mikeitz</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 41:47 (Vol. I, pp. 505-506).</i> as the letter <i>gimmel</i> serves here as <i>kuph</i>, excepting that the <i>migba’at</i> was also wound like a <i>mitznepheth</i>. It is for this reason that the Sages always mention in Torath Kohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>Tzav</i>, 2:1. — For the term Torath Kohanim see above Note 19.</i> the <i>mitznepheth</i> both in relation to the High Priest and the common priest. And in Tractate Yoma<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 71b.</i> we have been taught [in a Mishnah]: “A High Priest ministers [the Divine Service] in eight garments, and a common priest in four — in tunic, breeches, <i>mitznepheth</i> (mitre), and belt. To these the High Priest adds the breastplate, the ephod, the upper garment, and the frontplate.”<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is clear that the term <i>mitznepheth</i> applies to the head-dress of both the High Priest and the common priest. As to why the head-dress of the common priest is also called <i>migba’at</i>, see Note 115 above.</i>

Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35

THAT HE DIE NOT. “From this negative statement you infer the positive: if these garments are upon him, he will not incur death, but if he enters [the Sanctuary] lacking one of these garments he is liable to death [by the hand of Heaven].” This is Rashi’s language. But it does not appear to me to be correct, for if so He should have written this verse after having mentioned all eight garments [of the High Priest], and why did He mention it after three garments — the breastplate, the ephod, and the robe — before mentioning the frontplate, the upper garment, the mitre, the belt and the breeches! Furthermore, [the verse reads here,] <i>and when he cometh out</i> [of the Sanctuary], <i>that he die not</i>. But the act of going out [from the Sanctuary] is no function for which he should incur death if lacking the [proper number of] garments!<br>Similarly Rashi commented on the verse: “<i>And they shall be upon Aaron and upon his sons</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> — <i>they</i> means all these garments; <i>upon Aaron and upon his sons</i>, those which are proper to him, and those specified for them. [<i>That they bear not iniquity</i>,] <i>and die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> — thus you learn that he who ministers [the Divine Service] lacking any of these garments incurs death [by the hand of Heaven].” And so indeed it appears from the simple meaning of Scripture. But according to the conclusion reached on these subjects in the discussions in the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">For meaning of the term Gemara see in <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 204. The particular texts here referred to are mentioned further on.</i> it would appear that this does not conform to the opinion of our Rabbis, for to them this commandment applies to all alike, to Aaron and his sons, but it refers only to the breeches, and the punishment [of death by the hand of Heaven for lacking them] likewise applies [only] to them [i.e. the breeches]. For He had commanded that they be made, [as it is said,] <i>And thou shalt make them linen breeches</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 42.</i> and then He commanded concerning their being worn [by the priests, saying,] <i>And they shall be upon Aaron, and upon his sons</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> As to the rest of the garments, He had already given the command above concerning the making of them and wearing them, [as it is said,] <i>And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and upon his sons with him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 41.</i> If so, this command <i>[And they shall be upon Aaron, and upon his sons</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> refers wholly to the breeches, and the punishment likewise refers [only] to them.<br>We learn this from what the Rabbis have said in Tractates Sanhedrin<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 83b.</i> and The Slaughtering of Sacrifices:<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 17b.</i> “Whence do we know that a priest who ministered [the Divine Service] lacking the [proper number of] garments is liable to death [by the hand of Heaven]? Said Rabbi Abohu in the name of Rabbi Yochanan, and they arrived in the chain of tradition up to ‘in the name of Rabbi Eleazar the son of Rabbi Shimon:' <i>And thou shalt gird them with belts, Aaron and his sons, and bind head-tires on them; and they shall have the priesthood by a perpetual statute</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:9.</i> the interpretation of which is: ‘So long as they wear their [appointed] garments, they are invested with their priesthood; when they do not wear their garments, they are not invested with their priesthood, and they become laymen, and it has been said that a layman who ministers [in the Sanctuary] incurs the penalty of death [by the hand of Heaven].” Now if this verse [<i>that they bear not iniquity, and die</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> were held by the Rabbis to apply to all the garments [of the priests], as the Rabbi [Rashi] said, they could have found in it an expressly stated punishment for one who ministers lacking all the garments, [and why did they need to base it upon an inference from another verse]! Rather, this verse refers only to the breeches, and the other verse to the rest of the garments, where the breeches are not mentioned at all. Proof to what the Rabbis have said [that this verse, <i>And they shall be upon Aaron, and upon his sons… that they bear not iniquity, and die</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i> refers only to the breeches], is that further on when the order of putting on the garments is mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 5-9.</i> the breeches are not referred to at all, for having declared here the punishment if they are lacking [when ministering in the Sanctuary], there was no more need to mention them again further on, as it is understood already that he would wear them.<br>And that which He said above [i.e., in Verse 35 before us], <i>and the sound thereof shall be heard when he goeth in unto the holy place before the Eternal, and when he goeth out, that he die not</i>, is [not as Rashi has it that from here we learn that if he enters the Sanctuary lacking one of these garments he incurs death at the hand of Heaven, but is] in my opinion an explanation for the commandment of the bells [upon the robe], since there was no need to wear them, nor are they customary amongst dignitaries. Therefore He said that He commanded that they be made in order that the sound thereof be heard in the Sanctuary, that the priest enter before his Master as if with permission. For he who comes into the king’s palace suddenly, incurs the penalty of death according to the court ceremonial, just as we find in the case of Ahasuerus.<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 4:11. <i>All the king’s servants… do know, that whosoever… shall come unto the king… who is not called, there is one law for him, that he be put to death</i>.</i> It thus alludes to what the Rabbis have said in Yerushalmi Tractate Yoma:<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Yoma I,5. — On Jerusalem Talmud see in <i>Seder Bo</i>, Note 204.</i> “<i>And there shall be no man in the Tent of Meeting when he goeth in to make atonement in the holy place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:17.</i> — even those [heavenly beings] of whom it is written, <i>As for the likeness of their faces they had the face of a man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:10.</i> they too are not to be then in the Tent of Meeting.” Therefore He commanded that [the ministering High Priest] make a sound be heard, as if crying out, ‘<i>Cause everyone to go out from before me</i>,’<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 45:1.</i> so that he can come to minister before the King alone. Similarly, when going out from the Sanctuary his sound is heard in order to leave with permission, and that the matter be known so that the King’s ministers can go out before Him. In the Chapters of the Palaces<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Pirkei Heichaloth, 31. — This is an Agadic Midrash on “The Seven Palaces of Heaven.” See Wertheimer’s ed. of Batei Midrashoth Vol. I, p. 67.</i> this subject is known. Thus the reason [for the bells upon the robe of the High Priest] is that he should not be encountered by the angels of G-d. He gave this warning concerning the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Since the common priests also entered the Sanctuary in the regular daily service, the question arises why were these bells not necessary upon their garments so that their sound be heard when they come into the Sanctuary? Ramban’s answer is that this was on account of the high position of the High Priest. “For the greater the person the more are the powers of strict judgment stirred up against him” (Bi’ur Ha’lvush to Ricanti who quotes the language of Ramban).</i> on account of his high position. This is Scripture’s intent in saying, <i>when he goeth in unto the holy place before the Eternal</i>, for it is the High Priest who passes<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Another reading: “ministers.”</i> before Him so that He cause His Divine Glory to rest upon his service, <i>for he is the messenger of the Eternal of hosts</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 2:7.</i> even though the common priests also enter the Sanctuary to burn the incense and to kindle [the lamps].<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">Yet the High Priest is more distinguished; hence the bells were necessary upon his garments and not upon those of the common priests, as explained above (see Note 134).</i><br>Now I have seen in the Midrash Shemoth Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 38:10.</i> with reference to the stones upon the breastplate: “For what reason were the stones? It was in order that the Holy One, blessed be He, observe them in the garments of the priest when he enters on the Day of Atonement,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">When the High Priest on the Day of Atonement entered the Holy of Holies he did not wear the eight garments [amongst which was the breastplate], but instead, he wore the four linen garments [as prescribed in Leviticus 16:4]. The meaning of the Midrash must perforce be as follows: The merit of the High Priest wearing the breastplate all the year round when ministering in the Sanctuary, stood by him when he entered the Holy of Holies on the Day of Atonement, although at that moment he did not wear it.</i> and He be gracious to the tribes [whose names were inscribed upon the stones in the breastplate]. Rabbi Yehoshua in the name of Rabbi Levi says: This may be compared to a king’s son, whose tutor came before the king to speak in his defense, but was afraid of those standing there lest they strike him. What did the king do? He dressed him in his purple cloak in order that they see it and be afraid of him. In the same way Aaron entered at all times<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Reference here is to the four times that the High Priest entered the Holy of Holies during the special service for the Day of Atonement (Peirush Maharzav on Midrash Rabbah).</i> the Holy of Holies, and were it not for the many merits that entered with him and helped him, he could not have entered. Why? Because of the ministering angels who were there. What did the Holy One, blessed be He, do? He gave him a likeness of His sacred garment, as it is said, <i>And He put on righteousness as a coat of mail</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 59:17.</i> Thus far is the language of this Agadah. Now even though the High Priest did not enter into the innermost part of the Sanctuary [i.e., the Holy of Holies] with these garments, yet on the Day of Atonement he needed these [garments] even in the Tent of Meeting, for it is written, <i>And there shall be no man in the Tent of Meeting</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:17. Therefore when the High Priest came into the Sanctuary during the service preceding his entrance into the Holy of Holies, he also had to wear these garments as his protection against those powers assailing him because of his high position.</i>

Verse 36



Verse 37

AND THOU SHALT PUT IT ON A BLUE-PURPLE STRING. “But in another place in Scripture it states, <i>And they put upon it a string of blue-purple</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:31.</i> [which indicates that the frontplate was beneath the string, not upon it as is here commanded]! Moreover, here it is written, <i>and it shall be upon the mitre</i>, and further on it says, <i>And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 38.</i> In the Tractate on the Slaughtering of Sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 19 a-b.</i> we have been taught: ‘The High Priest’s hair was visible between the frontplate and the mitre, whereon he placed the phylacteries.’ From this we learn that the mitre was above on the crown of the head [and was not so large that it covered the entire head right down to the forehead], and the frontplate was beneath it [with a space between them], and the strings were in holes and hung from the frontplate at its two ends and in its middle — six in these three places:<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">For, as the center of each string rested at the bottom point of the hole, the three strings became six.</i> one string on top [of the frontplate], one outside and one inside [between the frontplate and the forehead]. He tied the ends of the three strings behind the neck, and thus it came to be that the length of the frontplate and the strings at its ends encompassed his whole skull. The middle string which was on top was tied together to the ends of the two strings [at the extremities of the frontplate], and passed over above the breadth of the head. Thus it came to be that [the frontplate with the strings] formed a kind of helmet. Now it is with reference to the middle string that Scripture states, <i>and it shall be upon the mitre</i>, for he placed the frontplate [together with the strings tied in the above manner] upon his head [as a kind of helmet, passing it over the mitre], and tightened it through the middle string so that it would not fall. Thus the frontplate hung in front of his forehead. All these verses are thus reconciled: the string was on the frontplate, and the frontplate upon the string, and the string on the mitre above.” All this is Rashi’s language.<br>But I wonder concerning Rashi’s words, for Scripture commands the making of only one blue-purple string, and he makes six! Moreover, Rashi combined the verses which tell of the command to make [the frontplate] with those which tell of the making thereof,<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The verse mentioned by Rashi [<i>And they put upon it a string of blue-purple</i>] is found further (39:31) in connection with the actual making thereof. So how can the string mentioned in that verse be added to the one that is stated in the verse commanding the making of the frontplate?</i> increasing the strings with the number of verses! One could count in such manner in the case of the ark, the table, and the candelabrum [two of each, since they are mentioned once in the command to make, and again in the narrative when they were actually made]! Furthermore, if Scripture commanded that they put the frontplate on a blue-purple string, how did they [do the opposite and] put a blue-purple string on it? Where were they commanded to do so? And why did they need the strings in the middle, since the frontplate was tied behind the neck, as are all frontplates which are worn by men and women?<br>Indeed, the matter is not as the Rabbi [Rashi] said. For there was only one string there; the plate reached from ear to ear and was pierced at its two ends and the blue-purple string was put through the two holes, the plate being thus tied behind the neck. Thus he wound the <i>mitznepheth</i> (mitre) around the head, not at all upon the forehead, but on the head where the hair grows. And according to the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 19a.</i> that he also left [uncovered] part of the hair of his head towards his face for the phylacteries, he wound [the <i>mitznepheth</i>] high above on the crown of the head, opposite the middle of the brain, covering the whole head at the back. Thus the <i>mitznepheth</i> lay above on the slope of the head opposite the brain, and the frontplate rested opposite his forehead from ear to ear, there being nothing intervening between his forehead and the frontplate. Thus the <i>mitznepheth</i> lay on the back of his head from ear to ear, opposite the whole neck, and the string which was tied to the frontplate was upon the <i>mitznepheth</i>. It is with reference to this that Scripture says, <i>And thou shalt put it on a blue-purple string</i>, meaning that he should put the string through the holes of the frontplate; <i>and</i> the string <i>shall be upon the mitre</i> behind his ears opposite the neck; <i>towards the front of the mitre it shall be</i> — that is, the frontplate, which shall be upon the forehead opposite the front part of the mitre. This is Scripture’s intent in stating, <i>And thou shalt set the mitre upon his head</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:6.</i> that is to say, above on the crown of the head, unlike the <i>migba’oth</i> of which it is said, <i>and thou shalt bind head-tires upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9.</i> binding the head like one whose head hurts and he binds it for the purpose of strengthening the head. It further states, <i>and thou shalt put the holy crown upon the mitre</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:6.</i> for it was upon the mitre that [the frontplate] was tied at the back. This is so stated: <i>And they put upon it a string of blue-purple, to fasten it upon the mitre above</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:31.</i> for there upon [the mitre] the string [of the frontplate] was tied. Similarly, <i>and upon the mitre, in front, did he set the golden plate</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:9.</i> means that he tied upon the front of the mitre the golden frontplate. Thus the term “placing” in all the verses refers to putting [the string of the frontplate] upon the mitre, for it was there that it was tied; the frontplate itself, however, was on the forehead opposite the mitre. There is then no difference between the expression <i>And they put upon it a string of blue-purple</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:31.</i> and [in the verse before us] <i>and thou shalt put it on a blue-purple string</i> [unlike Rashi who distinguished between them], for in both cases it is as if it said, “and thou shalt place it <i>with</i> a blue-purple string,” “and thou shalt put a blue-purple string,” similar in usage to the expression, <i>and thou shalt put them ‘on’ one basket</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:3.</i> which means “in” the basket. Likewise, <i>escape ‘on’ thy life</i><sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:17.</i> [which means “with your life,” as long as your life is in you, or “escape for your life”]. Or it may be that the word <i>al</i> (‘on’ — <i>on a blue-purple string</i>) here serves as <i>el</i> (to), thus stating: “and you shall put it <i>to</i> a blue-purple string,” “and they put a blue-purple string <i>to</i> it,” for the string was put [to the frontplate, and the frontplate was put] to it, for it rested on it for support. In essence, the meaning of the verses is only that they should place a string in the holes of the frontplate, and in that way it also came about that the frontplate was upon the string and the string upon the frontplate. Similarly, <i>And they shall bind the breastplate by the rings thereof to the rings of the ephod with a string of blue-purple</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 28.</i> from which Rashi brought a proof<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">In Rashi’s exposition of the frontplate he had explained (as mentioned above) that there were three double strings attached to it. To answer the question why Scripture speaks only of “a thread of blue-purple” in the singular, Rashi wrote (further 39:31). “Do not be puzzled because it does not say ‘<i>threads</i> of blue-purple,’ for we find the same thing in the case of the breastplate and the ephod, of which it is said, <i>And they shall bind the breastplate by the rings thereof with a string of blue-purple</i> (above, Verse 28), and you must admit that there could not have been less than two strings, for at the two ends of the breastplate were the two rings of the breastplate, and on the two shoulder pieces of the ephod were two rings opposite them. Now according to the way the breastplate was tied on, there were four threads, and under any circumstance it could not have been less than two [and yet Scripture speaks only of ‘<i>a string’ of blue-purple</i>]!” — To this proof of Rashi, Ramban answers that reference is only to one string, as explained in the text.</i> [that there were three double strings in the frontplate], also refers to only one string, which they put through the rings of the breastplate and the rings of the ephod opposite them; so also on the other side there was one string, for these were two [separate] places, and in each place they tied [the breastplate by the rings thereof] with one string [of blue-purple to the rings of the ephod].

Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41

AND THOU SHALT PUT THEM UPON AARON THY BROTHER AND UPON HIS SONS WITH HIM — “those which are mentioned in connection with them.” This is Rashi’s language. The meaning of <i>with him</i> is that they were all clothed with the priestly garments and anointed on the same day.
AND THOU SHALT ANOINT THEM ‘UMILEITHA ETH YADAM’ [literally: “and fill their hands”]. “Every expression of ‘filling the hand’ denotes installation, when one enters for the first time into an office which one is to hold from that day onwards.” This is Rashi’s language. But I have not understood his words. How does the expression of “filling the hand” come to mean “installation?” And as to that which the Rabbi said that “in the [old] French language — when a person is appointed to be in charge of any matter, the ruler puts into his hand a leather glove which they call <i>gant</i>, and by means of that glove gives him the right to that matter, and it is this which is called ‘filling the hand,’” — I do not know whether the Rabbi’s intent is to state that because of that glove the installation is called “filling the hand,” and to this he brought proof from a custom [in France]! Know that this custom they derived from the Torah, as to them this form of taking possession is [what is meant by] the acquisition by exchange mentioned in connection with Boaz, for so they translated: [<i>Now this was the custom in former time in Israel concerning redeeming and concerning exchanging…</i>] <i>a man drew off ‘na’alo’ (his shoe)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 4:7.</i> — “a man drew off his <i>gant</i>,” and they say<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">Our accepted law is that acquisition by exchange is accomplished with something that originally belongs to the buyer. Hence it was Boaz [the buyer] who “drew off his shoe” and gave it to the near kinsman. But “they say” differently, that it was the near kinsman [the seller] that gave it to Boaz. Hence they derived the custom that it is the prince [who is in the position of the bestower or seller] who pulls off his <i>gant</i> and gives it to the recipient.</i> that it was the near kinsman that gave it to Boaz. This custom of theirs is mentioned in the books of their scholars. Thus we have engaged in vain talk!<br>The correct interpretation of <i>milui yadayim</i> in the Torah is that it is an expression of perfection, similar in usage to these verses: <i>‘ki malu yamai’ (for my days are completed);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 29:21.</i> <i>‘ubimloth’ hayamim ha’eileh’ (and when these days were fulfilled);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 1:5.</i> <i>until the days ‘m’loth’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:33.</i> — be fulfilled. Similarly, <i>‘b’keseph malei’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 23:9.</i> means “for the full price.” And the reason for this expression is that one might say of a stranger [i.e., a non-priest] who cannot perform the offering for his cleansing, or of any person who is not empowered to perform some royal service, that his hand misses that function; and when he becomes empowered to do it, his hand has thereby been perfected and made fit for all kinds of work and service. Thus, <i>‘milu yedchem hayom’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:29.</i> [generally translated: <i>consecrate yourselves today</i>] means that: “now your hands are full with the whole service of G-d, <i>for even every man upon his son, and upon his brother</i><sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:29.</i> have you served Him [that day].” Or it may be that Moses was hinting to the sons of Levi that by virtue of this merit they would be chosen to perform the Divine Service in the Tabernacle, as it is said, <i>At that time the Eternal separated the tribe of Levi</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:8.</i> Similarly King David said to Israel on the occasion of the donations for the House [of G-d], <i>Because I have set my affection on the house of my G-d, seeing that I have a treasure of mine own of gold and silver, I give it into the house of my G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:3.</i> and then he continued saying, <i>Who then offereth willingly ‘l’maloth yado’ this day unto the Eternal?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> — meaning “to perfect his hand [this day unto the Eternal],” for by doanting towards the building of the House [of G-d] their hands become full with all the sacrifices and all manner of services, for Israel’s worship of G-d is only a complete one in the Sanctuary. Similarly, <i>the ram of ‘milu’im’</i> mentioned in this section<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 29:22.</i> is so called because the filling of the priests’ duties was accomplished through this offering, for the sin-offering and the burnt-offering<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> were to effect atonement, and this ram was to fill the priest’s hand with [the right to] sacrifice. I have also found that in Targum Yerushalmi <i>the ram of ‘milu’im’</i> is translated: <i>d’ashlamutha</i>, (of perfection);<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">This translation I found in Targum Yonathan ben Uziel to Leviticus 8:22.</i> similarly also in all expressions of <i>milui yadayim</i> it translated “perfection.” Onkelos, however, [in translating <i>umileitha eth yadam</i> — ‘and you will bring their sacrifices’<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">On the seven days of installation it was Moses who acted in the role of the priest and performed the rites of the sacrifices. Hence Onkelos’ translation: “and you [i.e., Moses] will bring their sacrifices,” as during these seven days of installation you will be the priest to offer their sacrifices.</i>] followed the sense of the subject and was not pedantic as to the literal language, as is his custom in many places. Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Found in R’dak’s Sefer Hashorashim, root <i>male</i>.</i> explain <i>umileitha eth yadam</i> as meaning that he will fill their hands [with the gifts] from the sacrifices. Similarly: <i>whosoever would, he</i> [Jeroboam] <i>‘yemalei eth yado’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 13:33.</i> means that he could fill his hands at will from the sacrifices. But the correct interpretation [of the term <i>milui yadayim</i>] is as I have explained. And the meaning of the expression, <i>whosoever would, ‘yemalei eth yado’ that he might be one of the priests of the high places</i><sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 13:33.</i> is that he would bring for himself an offering of installation <i>as he devised of his own heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 12:33.</i> in order to initiate himself into his office, and thereby he became one of the priests of the high places, for they acted in a manner similar to the ways of the Torah.<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">See Leviticus 6:13. This is also applied to the ordinary priest who brought a meal-offering when he officiated for the first time. Ramban’s intent is thus that in the days of Jeroboam when the king installed a new group of priests in the kingdom of Israel to officiate at the sacrifices on the <i>Bamoth</i> (high places) he adopted the ways of the Torah as explained, in order to give the appearance of his remaining loyal to the commandments of the Torah.</i>

Chapter 29



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

AND THOU SHALT BRING THEM IN THE BASKET. This is connected with the following verse [… <i>unto the door of the Tent of Meeting</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4. Ramban is thus taking the phrase, <i>unto the door of the Tent of Meeting</i> from Verse 4 and transposing it to Verse 3, thus meaning: “and thou shalt bring them in the basket — unto the door of the Tent of Meeting.” Under “the more correct interpretation” Ramban will explain that the phrase rightfully belongs in Verse 4, teaching that the washing of Aaron and his sons must be done in the Sanctuary Court.</i> Scripture thus stating that he [Moses] shall bring the bread in the basket, the bullock, the rams, and Aaron and his sons, to the door of the Tent of Meeting. <i>And thou shalt wash them with water</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4. Ramban is thus taking the phrase, <i>unto the door of the Tent of Meeting</i> from Verse 4 and transposing it to Verse 3, thus meaning: “and thou shalt bring them in the basket — unto the door of the Tent of Meeting.” Under “the more correct interpretation” Ramban will explain that the phrase rightfully belongs in Verse 4, teaching that the washing of Aaron and his sons must be done in the Sanctuary Court.</i> — that is, Aaron and his sons. A more correct interpretation is that the expression <i>and thou shalt bring them in the basket</i> leaves the matter unspecified, for without further explanation it is known that he should bring them to the place where He commands the priests to come [it being sufficient if they come before the door of the court of the Tabernacle]. And the second verse speaks only of Aaron and his sons, and therefore He says [<i>thou shalt bring unto the door of the Tent of Meeting</i>] <i>and thou shalt wash them with water</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 4. Ramban is thus taking the phrase, <i>unto the door of the Tent of Meeting</i> from Verse 4 and transposing it to Verse 3, thus meaning: “and thou shalt bring them in the basket — unto the door of the Tent of Meeting.” Under “the more correct interpretation” Ramban will explain that the phrase rightfully belongs in Verse 4, teaching that the washing of Aaron and his sons must be done in the Sanctuary Court.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

THEN SHALT THOU TAKE THE ANOINTING OIL, AND POUR IT UPON HIS HEAD. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that this was before the setting of the mitre upon his head [mentioned in the preceding verse], for it is upon the head itself that Moses was to pour the oil. But this does not appear to me to be correct. For at the actual installation also, Scripture says, <i>And he set the mitre upon his head</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:9.</i> and afterwards it says, <i>And Moses took the anointing oil, and anointed the Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10.</i> and subsequently it states, <i>And he poured of the anointing oil upon Aaron’s head</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12.</i> But the correct interpretation is that he wound [the <i>mitznepheth</i>] around and around the head, but left the middle of the head uncovered, and it was on that place that he poured the oil. But if the anointing was upon the entire head as Rashi said,<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi here in Verse 7: “This anointing was in the form of an X. He put a drop of oil on his head and another drop between his eyebrows and joined them with his finger.” In that case he could not have put the drop of oil on top of the head, for the mitre would then intervene between it and the drop of oil between his eyebrows. Ramban concludes that according to this comment of Rashi we must say, that the pouring of the oil etc.</i> then [we must say] that the pouring of the oil was upon the place where the phylacteries lay, which was left uncovered, and from there he joined [the oil with his finger to the drop between his eyebrows] in the form of an X.

Verse 8



Verse 9

AND THOU SHALT GIRD THEM WITH BELTS. This alludes to Aaron and his sons, and then Scripture reverts and explains, <i>Aaron and his sons</i>. This is similar to the expressions: <i>let him bring it, the Eternal’s offering;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:5. The word <i>it</i> alludes already to <i>the Eternal’s offering</i>, but then Scripture itself reverts and explains it. The same principle applies in the next example.</i> <i>the kingdom which will not serve him, Nebuchadnezzar</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 27:8.</i> Such are the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra. But if so, [the following phrase in the verse before us,] <i>and thou shalt bind ‘migba’oth’ on them</i> refers only to some of them [mentioned before, namely, Aaron’s sons], for Aaron’s head-dress was not of the <i>migba’oth</i>, and besides, the <i>mitznepheth</i> is already on his head [as mentioned in Verse 6]. It is possible that the explanation of the verse is: “and thou shalt gird them with belts, <i>and</i> Aaron and his sons.” The verse is thus stating that he should gird Aaron’s sons mentioned with belts, and Aaron himself should be girded with his sons. For since the belt was alike for all of them [for Aaron and his sons], it was not mentioned above among the particular garments of Aaron; therefore it now became necessary to say that he should gird Aaron too with a belt like his sons. The breeches were not mentioned here as it was not necessary, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:35. “For having declared there [above] the punishment for lacking them there was no more need to revert and mention them [here], as it is understood already that he would wear them.”</i> And the reason why the breeches were singled out from the rest of the garments [by not being mentioned here] is that it was Moses who clothed them with all the garments, as G-d commanded, <i>and thou shalt clothe them.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> But the breeches which were <i>to cover the flesh of their nakedness</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:42.</i> they themselves put on in privacy. Therefore He did not mention them here among the garments — <i>and thou shalt take the garments, and clothe Aaron…</i><sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> and therefore He separated them [from the other garments] in command and in punishment, as I have mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:35. “For having declared there [above] the punishment for lacking them there was no more need to revert and mention them [here], as it is understood already that he would wear them.”</i>

Verse 10

AND THOU SHALT BRING THE BULLOCK BEFORE THE TENT OF MEETING; AND AARON AND HIS SONS SHALL LAY THEIR HANDS UPON THE HEAD OF THE BULLOCK. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented, that the meaning of it is that when you will bring the bullock before the Tent of Meeting, Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands upon it, for [the bringing of the bullock] has already been mentioned above.<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> The correct interpretation appears to me to be as I have explained,<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> that above He commanded to bring them but did not explain “to the Tent of Meeting,” but only that he bring them; the purport being that he bring them to the place of the priests so that they be ready [for sacrifice], thus it would be sufficient that they be before the door of the court of the Tabernacle. But now He required that they be brought before the Tent of Meeting, to the door of the Tent, as He will explain in connection with the slaughtering thereof,<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> for it is there that the laying of hands will take place.

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

AND THOU SHALT TAKE ALL THE FAT THAT COVERETH THE INWARDS. “This is the membrane upon the maw which is called <i>tele</i> [in old French].” This is Rashi’s language. In my opinion, the expression <i>the fat that covereth the inwards</i> is indeed a reference to the membrane [upon the maw]. But when it says [as it does here], <i>‘all’ the fat that covereth the inwards</i>, it alludes to two kinds of fat which are there: to the fat of that membrane, and to the heavy fat which is upon the inwards, as it is said in <i>Seder Vayikra: the fat that covereth the inwards, and the fat that is upon the inwards</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 3:3.</i> Thus it is clear that there are two kinds of fat upon the inwards — at times Scripture mentions them both, and at other times it includes them as one under the term “all” [as it says here]. Thus by saying here, <i>all the fat that covereth the inwards</i>, He already included the fat that is upon the inwards. Similarly in the actual fulfillment of this command He says, <i>And he took all the fat that was upon the inwards, and the lobe of the liver</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 8:16.</i> thus including [the two kinds of fat upon the inwards] in the phrase, <i>‘all’ the fat that was upon the inwards</i>. But further in this section He says, <i>And thou shalt take of the ram the fat, and the fat tail, and the fat that covereth the inwards</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 22.</i> Here the first “fat” mentioned without explanation, means the fat upon the inwards.

Verse 14

THOU SHALT BURN WITH FIRE WITHOUT THE CAMP; IT IS A SIN-OFFERING. “We do not find any outside<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">An <i>inner</i> sin-offering was one the blood of which was sprinkled within the Sanctuary — upon the veil in front of the Holy of Holies and the golden altar; that kind of a sin-offering was burnt completely outside the camp (Leviticus 6:23). Such a sacrifice, for example, was the sin-offering of the High Priest (<i>ibid.</i>, 4:3-12). An <i>outside</i> sin-offering was one the blood of which was sprinkled upon the outer altar that stood in the court of the Tabernacle [or Sanctuary]. Of such a sin-offering only certain fats were burnt on the altar, and the meat eaten by the priests. Since the sin-offering mentioned here was an <i>outside</i> sacrifice, and yet it was to the burnt wholly outside of the camp, it must have been a temporary, special legislation.</i> sin-offering that was to be burnt except this.” Thus is Rashi’s language. It was a temporary, special legislation, according to the words of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">See Rashi to Leviticus 9:11.</i> The reason for this is, that everything being foreseen by Him, this sin-offering was to effect forgiveness for the making of the golden calf, and it was the sacrifice of the anointed priest;<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to Aaron’s role in that affair (see further 32:35) (Ricanti).</i> and there [in the Book of Leviticus] He was to command that the blood of the sin-offering [of the High Priest] be brought within [the Tent of Meeting and sprinkled in front of] the veil,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 4:6.</i> [and the sacrifice be burnt outside the camp<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 12. Hence He commanded here — in advance — that that sin-offering was to be burnt.</i>]. At present, however, He did not wish to mention that [the blood be brought] within the Tent, for there [in the Book of Leviticus] He says in discernment, [that he sprinkle the blood] <i>in front of the holy veil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 4:6.</i> and at this point [the Tabernacle] had not yet been sanctified, and the Divine Glory did not yet dwell upon it, that it be called “the holy veil.” Thus the outside sin-offering [mentioned here] was like the inner one [of the anointed priest]. The laying of hands was [also] by Aaron’s sons, [although if it was deemed to be Aaron’s sin-offering the laying of hands should have been done only by Aaron], because <i>He was angry with Aaron to have destroyed him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:20.</i> which means the extermination of his children, therefore they too needed atonement by this sin-offering. The reason for burning [such a sin-offering outside the camp] is the same as the reason for burning the Red Heifer there,<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 19:3, 5.</i> and the secret thereof is known from [the text concerning] the goat sent to Azazel.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:10. See Ramban there on Verse 8.</i>

Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26

OF THE RAM OF CONSECRATION WHICH IS AARON’S. He did not mention here Aaron’s sons, although the ram was for the consecration of all of them. The reason for this is that Scripture commanded [in the first part of the verse before us], <i>And thou</i> [i.e., Moses] <i>shalt take the breast</i> of the wave-offering <i>of the ram of consecration</i> because it is <i>Aaron’s</i>, since the breast of the offering is by right not Aaron’s, for it does not belong to the owner of the animal [but to the priest,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 7:31.</i> and since on this occasion Aaron and his sons were the owners of the ram of consecration, and Moses the officiating priest, the breast in this instance belonged to Moses]. Now having stated the reason why it does not belong of right to Aaron, there was no need any more to declare that it does not belong to his sons, for they follow him in their rights [and where it does not belong to him, it likewise does not belong to them]. Further, however, He does say, <i>And thou shalt sanctify the breast of the wave-offering… of the ram of consecration, even of that which is Aaron’s, and of that which is his sons’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 27.</i> for the intent is to state: “just as he [Moses] takes of the offering which belongs to them all, the breast and the shoulder,<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">“And the shoulder,” is merely an expression, for it is clearly stated in Verse 22 that the shoulder was also burnt on the altar, and Rashi also so states it clearly.</i> so shall they — the father and the sons [High Priest and common priests] — take of the future [peace-] offerings which they [the children of Israel] will offer up.”

Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

L’MOSHCHAH BAHEM’ (TO BE ANOINTED IN THEM). “<i>L’moshchah</i> means to be raised to dignity by means of them, for the term <i>m’shichah</i> (anointing) is sometimes used in the sense of ‘authority,’ just as in these expressions: <i>unto thee have I given them ‘l’moshchah’ (as a distinction);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:8.</i> <i>touch not ‘bimshichai’ (My noble ones)</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:15.</i> This is Rashi’s language. Perhaps it is so. For because authority in Israel belonged to those who were anointed — the king and the High Priest — they used the term [“anointing”] metaphorically for all kinds of authority. Similarly, when it says, <i>thou shalt anoint Hazael to be king over Aram… and Elisha the son of Shaphat of Abel-meholah shalt thou anoint to be prophet in thy stead</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 19:15-16.</i> [the term “anoint” is used metaphorically — “appoint” or “designate”]. Here, however, the correct interpretation of <i>l’moshchah bahem</i> is to anoint with the garments the High Priests above their sons, and to consecrate them to offer the sacrifices. Likewise, <i>unto thee have I given them ‘l’moshchah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:8.</i> means that I have given them [i.e., the priestly gifts] because I have anointed you <i>to minister unto Me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> Similarly, <i>touch not ‘bimshichai’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 105:15.</i> means that he who touches them touches the anointed ones of G-d [i.e., the kings] who are destined to come from them, as He said, <i>and kings shall come out from thy loins;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 35:11.</i> <i>kings of peoples shall be of her</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 17:16.</i><br>It is even possible that we say that the expression <i>thou shalt anoint Hazael to be king over Aram</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 19:15-16.</i> means that he [i.e., Elijah] is to send him oil to be anointed as king, in order to inform him that this was the command of G-d; and Elisha [his disciple] did so in accordance with the charge of his master when he told Hazael that he will rule as king.<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 8:13.</i> Now even though it is not written there, [he yet actually anointed him as king], and [so did Elijah] anoint Elisha as a prophet [in accordance with G-d’s command to him]. Perhaps they<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">The prophets who lived in the time of Cyrus.</i> also did so to Cyrus [king of Persia] whom they anointed like the kings of Israel, in order that he would know that it was a prophet in Israel who prophesied that he would reign, and [generations before his birth] he even called forth his name, for [the glory of] G-d. Therefore [Isaiah] said, <i>to His anointed, to Cyrus</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 45:1.</i> upon which our Rabbis have commented:<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Megillah 12a.</i> “And was Cyrus the anointed one? etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">“Rather, the Holy One, blessed be He, said to the Messiah: “I complain to you about Cyrus. I said he will build My house and gather My exiles, but he said, <i>Whosoever there is among you of all His people… let him go up</i>.” (Ezra 1:3) — From this text it would appear that the Rabbis understood the verse to mean that Cyrus was really anointed [for otherwise there would have been no place at all for their question], except that he later became impaired in character.</i> Thus all these verses speak of real anointing. However, the verse stating, <i>The spirit of the Eternal G-d is upon me; because the Eternal ‘mashach’ me to bring good tidings unto the humble</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 61:1.</i> is by way of metaphor, comparing the holy spirit which came to rest upon the prophet with precious oil, similar to that which is said, <i>A good name is better than precious oil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 7:1.</i>

Verse 30



Verse 31

AND THOU SHALT SEETHE ITS FLESH IN A HOLY PLACE. We do not know whether this was a temporary, special legislation that the flesh of [the ram of] consecration be seethed only by a priest, [who in this case was Moses] or — as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra has it — that the expression <i>and thou shalt seethe</i> means by commanding [another person to do it], it being similar in usage to these verses: <i>and thy rod wherewith thou smotest the river;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:5. Since it was Aaron who smote the river (<i>ibid.</i>, 7:19), the verse must mean: “<i>thy rod wherewith thou smotest the river</i> — by commanding Aaron.”</i> <i>and Solomon built the house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 6:14.</i> [by commanding the builders to build it].<br>The seething had to be done <i>in a holy place</i>, since they<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the seven rams of consecration, one brought on each of the seven days of consecration.</i> were like the peace-offerings of the congregation which were to be eaten within the hangings of the court, the same day and evening until midnight.<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 54b.</i>

Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36

AND EVERY DAY SHALT THOU OFFER THE BULLOCK OF SIN-OFFERING ‘AL HAKIPURIM’ — “for atonement, to atone for the altar for anything strange [i.e., unholy] and abominable [that may happen to be brought upon it]. And in the Midrash of Torath Kohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>Tzav</i>, Milu’im 1:15.</i> it says: ‘atonement for the altar was necessary in case a person had donated for work in connection with the construction of the Tabernacle and [the sacrifices brought upon] the altar something he had acquired by robbery’” [or other unlawful means]. This is the language of Rashi. The correct interpretation of <i>al hakipurim</i> is, however, [that he is to bring the bullock of sin-offering] in addition to the two rams<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">One was a burnt-offering (Verses 16-18) and the other — the ram of consecration — was a peace-offering, as explained by Ramban above in Verse 31.</i> which were an atonement for Aaron and his sons, as He said here, <i>And they shall eat those things wherewith atonement was made</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33.</i> and surely the [bullock] sin-offering was for the purpose of atonement. And it is further written, <i>As hath been done this day, so the Eternal hath commanded to do, to make atonement for you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:34. This verse shows that all three sacrifices [the bullock sin-offering, the ram burnt-offering, and the ram peace-offering] brought on each of the seven days of consecration were for the purpose of making atonement. Thus it is seen that there was atonement in all the three sacrifices.</i> Such are the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra.

Verse 37



Verse 38



Verse 39



Verse 40



Verse 41



Verse 42



Verse 43



Verse 44



Verse 45



Verse 46

L’SHOCHNI B’THOCHAM’<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Literally: “to dwell among them.”</i> — “on condition that I dwell in the midst of them.” This is Rashi’s language. But the usage of the letter <i>lamed</i> [<i>l’shochni</i>] for a condition of this kind is not found [elsewhere in Scripture]! It is possible that He is stating: “and they shall know ‘when’ I dwell among them that I am the Eternal their G-d that brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, for they will [then] know My Glory and believe that I brought them forth from the land of Egypt.” It is similar in usage to the verses: <i>And David had great success ‘l’chol drachav’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 18:14. Literally: “<i>to</i> all his ways.”</i> [which is like <i>b’chol drachav</i> — “<i>in</i> all his ways”]; <i>that thou hast</i> chosen <i>‘l’ben Yishai’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:30. Literally: “<i>to</i> the son of Jesse.”</i> [which means <i>b’ben Yishai</i> — “the son of Jesse”]; <i>because ye rebelled against My word ‘l’mei Meribah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 20:24. Literally: “<i>to</i> the waters of Meribah.”</i> [which means <i>b’mei Meribah</i> — “in (or ‘at’) the waters of Meribah”], and similar cases.<br>But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained [the verse to mean that] the purpose of My bringing them forth from the land of Egypt was only that I might dwell in their midst, and that this was the fulfilment of [the promise to Moses], <i>you shall serve G-d upon this mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:12.</i> He explained it well, and if it is so, there is in this matter a great secret. For in the plain sense of things it would appear that [the dwelling of] the Divine Glory in Israel was to fulfill a want below, but it is not so. It fulfilled a want above, being rather similar in thought to that which Scripture states, <i>Israel, in whom I will be glorified</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 49:3.</i> And Joshua said, [<i>For when the Canaanites… hear of it… and cut off our name from the earth</i>,] <i>and what wilt Thou do for Thy Great Name?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 7:9.</i> There are many verses which express this thought: <i>He hath desired it</i> [i.e., Zion] <i>for His habitation;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 132:13.</i> <i>Here I dwell; for I have desired it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> And it is further written, <i>and I will remember the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 26:42. “That is to say, the land is remembered in mercy. <i>And I will remember</i> is of the root <i>The Eternal hath been mindful of us</i>” (Psalms 115:12) (Ricanti).</i>

Chapter 30



Verse 1

AND THOU SHALT MAKE AN ALTAR TO BURN INCENSE UPON. Now the altar of incense being one of the articles in the inner part of the Sanctuary, it should have been mentioned with the table and the candelabrum together with which it was placed, as indeed they are mentioned at the actual construction in the section of <i>Vayakheil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:25 — next to the making of the candelabrum.</i> But the reason for mentioning it here after the Tabernacle and all its vessels and the sacrifices [for the seven days of consecration], is because of what He said at the completion of them all, <i>and the Tent shall be sanctified by My Glory;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:43.</i> <i>and I will dwell among the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 45.</i> Therefore He now said that they will yet be obliged to make an altar for the burning of incense — to burn it for the glory of G-d. This was a secret which was transmitted to Moses our Teacher,<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 89a.</i> that the incense checks the plague.<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 17:11-13.</i> For the incense is of the attribute of justice, as it is said, <i>they shall put incense ‘b’apecha’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:10. It is generally translated: “before Thee,” but Ramban suggests that <i>b’apecha</i> is of the root <i>aph</i> (anger).</i> which is of the root <i>v’charah api (My wrath shall wax hot)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:23.</i> It is for this reason that He said of strange incense, <i>and before all the people I will be glorified</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 10:3.</i> meaning that they will know My glory, <i>for He will not pardon your transgression</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:21.</i> For this reason too He said here [of the altar of incense], <i>And thou shalt put it before the veil that is by the ark of the Testimony, before the ark-cover that is over the Testimony, where I will meet with thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> For why is it necessary to speak at length of all these matters, and why did He not say briefly, “and thou shalt put it before the ark of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting,” as He said in the section of <i>Vayakheil?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">It is found in the section of <i>Pekudei</i> (further, 40:5).</i> But the extended form of the verse here indicates the purport [of the altar of incense].

Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7

AND AARON SHALL BURN THEREON INCENSE. This commandment [of burning the incense] did not devolve upon the High Priest alone, but was also incumbent upon the common priests, as is the law of the lighting of the lamps mentioned right beside it, [<i>every morning, when he dresseth the lamps</i>], although of that too it says, <i>And when Aaron lighteth the lamps</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> and yet it does not apply to the High Priest alone, as He said above, <i>Aaron and his sons shall set in order</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 27:21.</i> Therefore I do not know why He mentioned Aaron in both of them, and did not say “the priest” [which would signify any — even a common-priest]. Perhaps it is because of Scripture’s statement further, <i>And Aaron shall make atonement upon the horns of it once in the year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 10.</i> which was done by Aaron only, [because the reference there is to the Service on the Day of Atonement which could be performed only by the High Priest — therefore He also mentioned the name of Aaron in the verse before us and in the following verse]. Or it may be that He hinted that it was to be Aaron who [at the first time] was to begin the burning of the incense and the lighting of the lamps. Similarly at the end of <i>Seder Emor el hakohanim</i> He said, <i>Aaron shall set in order</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:3.</i> and He did not mention his sons, because it was Aaron who performed it first. The phrase <i>a statute forever</i> mentioned there,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 24:3.</i> refers to the commandment [of kindling the lamps, and does not mean that it is <i>a statute forever</i> that only the High Priest do it].

Verse 8



Verse 9

YE SHALL NOT BRING UP ‘KTORETH ZARAH’ (STRANGE INCENSE) THEREON — “any incense brought as a freewill offering; for all [offerings of incense] are ‘strange’ to [this altar] except this one [prescribed here].” This is Rashi’s language. But Onkelos rendered <i>ktoreth zarah: ktoreth busmin nuchra’in</i> (“the burning of aromatics which are of strange components,”) and he did not translate it <i>nuchritha</i> “strange incense” [as Rashi interpreted it]. By this translation Onkelos wanted to explain that the sense of the verse is that he should not offer an incense of any other components except those prescribed as He commanded.<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">This is identical with Ibn Ezra’s interpretation of the verse. Ramban, however, called attention to Onkelos’ text because it required an explanation as mentioned.</i> Similarly, if one were to add to the prescribed composition any other components one would transgress this negative commandment.<br>Ki Thisa

Verse 10



Verse 11



Verse 12

The Holy One, blessed be He, commanded Moses that when he takes a census of the children of Israel, they should each give a soul’s ransom — half a shekel; and He further told him, <i>And thou shalt take the atonement-money</i><sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> mentioned, <i>and shalt give it for the service of the Tent of Meeting</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> From this Moses would understand that he was to count them now. And so indeed he did, as Scripture says, <i>And the silver of them that were numbered of the congregation was a hundred talents</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 38:25.</i> It was thus not necessary to state at length, “and now you should take their census and give the silver for the service of the Tent of Meeting,” for it is self-understood that he should count them now. The reason that He generalized the commandment — saying “when you will take their census you should do it in the prescribed way” — is in order to include in this general principle any time when a census was decided upon.<br>It appears to me that now [at this census, Moses] did not have to come to the people’s tents and count them, as he did in the census spoken of in the Book of Numbers,<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In connection with that census the Midrash says specifically that when the enumeration of the Levites was taken “Moses went and stationed himself at the entrance of each tent etc.” (Tanchuma <i>Bamidbar</i>, 16). Ramban is here suggesting that the same was done with the other tribes as well.</i> but he did it as our Rabbis have said through the [half] shekels they brought for the sacrifices; for he commanded them that all who know themselves to be <i>from twenty years old and upward</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> should give that sum, and they brought him the ransom as a voluntary offering together with all the other voluntary offerings every morning.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 36:3.</i> That is why He said only, <i>And thou shalt take the atonement-money</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> that is to say, “Behold, I have commanded you that when you count them they shall give their ransom, and now they will voluntarily give it and you should appoint it <i>for the service of the Tent of Meeting</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> This is the reason why it was not necessary now that Aaron and the princes [of the tribes] be present with Moses [at the taking of the half-shekels, as was required in the census spoken of in the Book of Numbers<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:3-4.</i>]. Do not object on account of the verse, <i>This they shall give, every one that passeth among them that are numbered</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> [from which you might think that here too, Moses actually counted the people], for the meaning thereof is “those that are eligible to pass.”<br>Now because it has not been explained here whether this is a commandment binding for all time or only for that particular period of when Moses was in the wilderness, David erred and counted the people without shekels, and on account of this a plague broke out amongst them.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 24:1-15.</i> He confessed about this [sin], as it is said, <i>And David said unto G-d, I have sinned greatly, in that I have done this thing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 21:8.</i><br>Our Rabbis have derived<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shekalim I, 1.</i> from the many expressions [of “offering”] mentioned here,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Half a shekel for an offering to the Eternal</i> (Verse 13); <i>he shall give the offering of the Eternal</i> (Verse 14); <i>when they give the offering of the Eternal</i> (Verse 15).</i> [an indication] that there were three [separate] offerings.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">One was for the making of the sockets of the Tabernacle (further 38:26-27). The second was after the erection of the Tabernacle and the money was used for purchasing the public sacrifices. Both of these offerings were compulsory, each person giving a half-shekel. The third was voluntary and was used for the building of the Tabernacle. See also further on in the text.</i> And so it appears from what Scripture says, [<i>And the king called for Jehoiada the chief, and said unto him:</i>] <i>‘Why hast thou not required of the Levites to bring in out of Judah and out of Jerusalem the tax of Moses the servant of the Eternal, and of the congregation of Israel, for the Tent of Testimony?’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 24:6.</i> From this it would appear that the tax of Moses was enjoined for all time — and that it was to be brought for the repair of the Temple even though no census was to be taken. Likewise the offering for [buying the public] sacrifices [was enjoined for all time] as the Sages have said, and it is so written [of Ezra and Nehemiah]: <i>Also we made ordinances for us to charge ourselves yearly with the third part of a shekel for the service of the house of our G-d; for the showbread, and for the continual meal-offering and for the continual burnt-offering, of the Sabbaths, of the New Moons, for the appointed reasons, and for the holy things, and for the sin-offerings to make atonement for Israel, and for all the work of the house of our G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 10:33-34.</i> Here it is clearly stated that they used to bring shekels every year for the sacrifices and for the Temple repair. Scripture states that the levy was <i>the third part of a shekel</i> [whereas here it is stated that it is to be half a shekel]; this was because in the days of Ezra they added to the value of a shekel, so that the third of a shekel was then ten gerahs [the equivalent of a half a shekel in the days of Moses].<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><i>The shekel is twenty gerahs</i> (Verse 13). In the days of Ezra a shekel was worth thirty gerahs; hence a third was ten gerahs.</i><br>In Tractate Shekalim we are taught:<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Shekalim 2:4.</i> “When Israel came up from [the Babylonian] exile they used to pay the [half-] shekel in <i>darics</i> [a Persian silver coin, each one giving one <i>daric</i>, as will be explained further]. Then they changed, and paid it in <i>s’laim</i> [each one giving one <i>sela</i>]. Again they changed and paid the shekel in <i>tibin</i> [each one giving one <i>tiba</i>], and they finally sought to pay it in <i>denars</i> [but these were not accepted of them].” The meaning of this Mishnah is as follows: When Israel came up from the exile and large funds were needed for the Temple repair, they paid the shekel in <i>darics</i>, which were larger than the <i>s’laim</i>, each one giving one <i>daric</i>. Then they changed and began paying in whole <i>s’laim</i> [each one giving one <i>sela</i> — since there was a decrease in the needs of the Temple repair]. Again they changed it to <i>tibin</i> — in the Yerushalmi<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi <i>ibid.</i></i> it is explained that a <i>tiba</i> is half a <i>sela</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>sela</i> was the exact equivalent of the shekel that was in the days of Moses. Hence a <i>tiba</i> which is half a <i>sela</i> is the same as the half-shekel which the Torah commanded to be given by each Israelite.</i> When they sought to pay it in <i>denars</i> [each one giving one <i>denar</i>]<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">There are four <i>denars</i> to a shekel [or <i>sela</i>]. Hence to give one <i>denar</i> only would be half of a half-shekel, and as will be explained further on that less than a half-shekel cannot be given.</i> they did not accept it of them, for although the public can increase the levy to more than half a <i>sela</i>, provided only that everyone pays alike, as we have been taught in the Mishnah of Tractate Shekalim,<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Shekalim 2:4.</i> yet no one is permitted to decrease it and give less than half of a <i>sela</i>, be it one person or many people, for “the ransom of a soul” is not less than that [i.e. a half-<i>sela</i>], as it is written, <i>This they shall give</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> In the Yerushalmi<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi <i>ibid.</i></i> the Rabbis have said with reference to what is written [that in the days of Ezra and Nehemiah they ordained that each one is to give] <i>the third part of a shekel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Nehemiah 10:33-34.</i> “from here you learn that a person is responsible for shekels three times a year.<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Yerushalmi the meaning of the verse (Nehemiah 10:33) is thus as follows: “<i>we made ordinances for us to charge ourselves</i> each <i>third part</i> of the year with <i>the shekel</i> mentioned in the Torah.” For by law of the Torah they were enjoined to give it only once; but because the needs for the Temple repair were so great [as explained above], they took it voluntarily upon themselves to donate it three times a year. Since three <i>s’laim</i> [or shekels of the Torah] make one <i>daric</i>, it is now clear why the Mishnah quoted above states that when Israel came up from the exile they paid the shekel in <i>darics</i>, and as Ramban clearly states, “each one giving a <i>daric</i>” which was equivalent to three shekels of the Torah.</i> From here you also learn that we must not impose on the public more than three times a year” [for the Temple treasury].<br>Now Rashi wrote: “there are three offerings hinted at here<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Half a shekel for an offering to the Eternal</i> (Verse 13); <i>he shall give the offering of the Eternal</i> (Verse 14); <i>when they give the offering of the Eternal</i> (Verse 15).</i> — one was for the making of the sockets, for Moses counted them when they began to contribute towards the building of the Tabernacle after the Day of Atonement in the first year [of the exodus], — each one giving half of a shekel, and the total amounting to a hundred talents, as it is said, <i>And the silver of them that were numbered was a hundred talents</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 38:25.</i> The second [offering] was also levied through a census, for he counted them after the Tabernacle was erected, this being the census referred to in the Book of Numbers: <i>on the first day of the second month in the second year</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:1.</i> each one giving a half-shekel for purchasing the public sacrifices. And if you ask: How is it possible that on both of these occasions the number of Israelites was exactly the same — 603,550?<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 38:26. Numbers 1:46.</i> Were these two censuses not taken in two [different] years;<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">The first census was taken in the month of Tishri [after the Day of Atonement in the <i>first</i> year of the exodus]. The second census — on the first day of Iyar — was seven months later. But since we calculated the beginning of a new year [in the count after the exodus] with Nisan, the second census was therefore in the <i>second</i> year. Thus the two censuses were in two years!</i> thus it is impossible that there were no people aged nineteen at the time of the first census, [who accordingly were not counted], who became twenty years old [by the time the second census was taken, and thus must have added to the total]! The reply to this question is as follows: As far as the years of people’s ages are concerned, the two censuses were taken in one year, but counting from the exodus from Egypt, they were held in two years. For when we count from the exodus from Egypt, we calculate from Nisan, but when we count the years of man’s ages we count according to the era of the creation of the world, which begins with Tishri. In that way, the two censuses were in one year: the first census was in Tishri after the Day of Atonement, when the Holy One, blessed be He, became reconciled to Israel and they were commanded about the construction of the Tabernacle, and the second census took place [in the same year] on the first day of Iyar.” All these are the Rabbi’s words.<br>But I wonder! How is it possible that the number of deaths amongst such a great assemblage of people in a period of half a year did not run to the hundreds and thousands! For according to the words of the Rabbi [Rashi], they remained for about seven months [from about the middle of Tishri to the beginning of Iyar] without one fatality, and yet it is written, <i>But there were certain men, who were unclean by the dead body of a man</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 9:6. This happened in Nisan in the second year after the exodus. Thus it is clear that before the month of Iyar when the second census took place, there was at least one death in the camp.</i> I have also another difficulty: The years of men’s ages are not counted according to the era of the creation of the world which begins with Tishri, but are counted in astronomical years beginning with the day of one’s birth. It is for this reason that it says with reference to the people counted, that they are to be <i>from twenty years old and upward</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:3.</i> meaning that they are to be a full twenty years old. Similarly, all countings of the Torah with respect to people’s ages are calculated in astronomical years, just as the Rabbis have said in Tractate Arakhin:<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Arakhin 18b.</i> “The ‘year’ mentioned in connection with the hallowed offerings,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Such as <i>a he-lamb of the first year</i> (Leviticus 12:6).</i> and dwelling-houses in a walled city,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">If sold, these houses can be redeemed within the space of a full year (Leviticus 25:30).</i> the two ‘years’ mentioned in connection with a field which is the owner’s by inheritance [which, if sold, he may not redeem until after two years],<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:15, and Arakhin 29b.</i> the six ‘years’ mentioned in connection with a Hebrew servant,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:2.</i> a son and daughter [explained further on], are all reckoned in astronomical years. Whence do we know this of the hallowed offerings? Scripture says, <i>keves ben shnatho</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Such as <i>a he-lamb of the first year</i> (Leviticus 12:6).</i> [literally: “a lamb of his year”] — his year, and not the year counted according to the era of the creation of the world etc.” Then [the Gemara] explains there: “In connection with what law does this principle affect ‘the son and daughter’ [mentioned above] ?
