Said Rav Gidal, It is in connection with Valuations.”<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">If a person vows to give to the Sanctuary his “Valuation,” the sum is fixed by the Torah on the basis of years for a male and for a female (Leviticus 27:1-7). These years then are not counted according to the era of the creation of the world, but are calculated astronomically.</i> And the reason for this is because [in the case of Valuations] it says, <i>and upward</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 27:7: <i>And if it be from sixty years old and upward…</i></i> and in all censuses of the wilderness it is also written <i>and upward</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:3: <i>from twenty years old and upward</i>. Similarly, <i>ibid.</i>, 26:2.</i> The calculation of years in the census taken in the wilderness was thus alike in every respect to the calculation in the Valuations, as the Rabbis have said in [Tractate] Baba Bathra:<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Bathra 121b.</i> “The analogy is established on the basis of the identical phrase <i>and upward</i> [which is stated in the censuses taken in the wilderness, and its precise meaning is] derived from that mentioned in the law of Valuations.” And if so, all people born between Tishri and Iyar completed an astronomical year in the interim, thus between the two censuses there was bound to be a great number of people added to the total! But it would be more correct if we were to say that it so happened that the Israelites at the time of the first census [in Tishri] were 603,550 people, and in the following seven months many of them died, as is natural, and those who were twenty years old completed their twentieth year between Tishri and Iyar, and it so happened<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">By way of miracle (L’vush Ha’orah).</i> that their number corresponded exactly to that of those who died.<br>In my opinion, however, these identical numbers [of the two censuses] present no difficulty at all. For in the first census the tribe of Levi was counted together with the other tribes, since they had not yet been selected and were therefore not separated from the people, but at the second census Moses was told, <i>Only thou shalt not number the tribe of Levi, and neither take the sum of them among the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:49.</i> Now the number of those whose twentieth year was completed between the two censuses was close to twenty thousand<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In the separate count that was taken of the Levites they numbered twenty-two thousand (<i>ibid.</i>, 3:39). But since they were numbered from the age of a month upward, Ramban rightly assumes that the Levites who were twenty years old and upward were “approximate to twenty thousand.” Their numbers [not included in the figures of the second census], were made up by those Israelites who completed their twentieth year between the two censuses.</i> [thus making up for the tribe of Levi which was not counted in the second general census]. This is clearly established [that the tribe of Levi was counted in the first census]. For since Scripture found it necessary to say at the second census, <i>Only thou shalt not number the tribe of Levi, and neither take the sum of them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:49.</i> it is proof that until then they were counted with the other tribes of Israel; and only now was the tribe of Levi selected and numbered by itself, in order to become “the legion of the King.”<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:49, Rashi.</i> Now when Israel left Egypt they were <i>‘about’ six hundred thousand ‘g’varim’ (men) on foot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:37.</i> — not “six hundred thousand;” of these there died a number of people corresponding to the number of young men whose twentieth year was completed [in the next six months between the exodus, which was in the middle of Nisan, and the first census which was taken in the middle of Tishri, when the number was 603,550]. Perhaps the term <i>g’varim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:37.</i> does not denote men of twenty years of age, but all those who had reached puberty — including all those from thirteen years old upwards — and that term [<i>g’varim</i>] is only used in order to exclude women and children, as it says, <i>beside little ones</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:37.</i><br>It also appears to me that of the three offerings here alluded to, the one designed for purchasing the public sacrifices is not the one taken through a census and mentioned in the Book of Numbers, as the Rabbi [Rashi] said, for there it is said, <i>Only thou shalt not count the tribe of Levi</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:49.</i> and all the Sages agree that the Levites too were liable to give the shekels for the sacrifices; and in accordance with the words of the Sages, even the priests had to give it,<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Shekalim 1:4.</i> and such is the established law as is explained in Tractate Shekalim.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Shekalim 1:4.</i> Moreover, the duty of giving the [half-] shekel for the sacrifices was not dependent upon a man being twenty years old or more, [as is mentioned in the case of the second census], but as soon as he could produce two [bottom] hairs he became liable to give the shekel. It is so clearly stated there [in Tractate Shekalim].<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 1:3. See also my Hebrew commentary p. 491.</i> Rather, Scripture commanded that they bring for the work of the Tabernacle an offering of a half-shekel, <i>every one that passeth among them that are numbered, from twenty years old and upward</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> and it hinted: <i>The rich shall not give more, and the poor shall not give less, than the half-shekel… to make atonement for your soul</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> for all who need atonement — that is, all who have reached the stage of being obligated to observe the commandments [which is at thirteen years and a day, corresponding to the period of puberty], shall being one half-shekel for the sacrifices [in addition to the half-shekel given for the work of the Tabernacle].

Verse 13

HALF OF A SHEKEL AFTER THE SHEKEL OF HOLINESS. Moses our Teacher instituted a silver coin in Israel, for he was a great king.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 33:5. See also Ramban above, 15:25.</i> He called it “shekel” [literally: “weight”] because that whole coin was a perfect weight, it had nothing defective in it and the silver contained no dross. And since the standard shekel of Valuations<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">If a person vows to give to the Sanctuary his “Valuation,” the sum is fixed by the Torah on the basis of years for a male and for a female (Leviticus 27:1-7). These years then are not counted according to the era of the creation of the world, but are calculated astronomically.</i> and the redemption of the firstborn,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:16.</i> which are holy matters, were given in that coin, as also all shekels mentioned in connection with the Tabernacle, and all moneys the amount of which is exactly specified in the Torah,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Such as thirty shekels if an ox kills a slave (above, 21:32), etc.</i> therefore Scripture calls it <i>the shekel of holiness</i>.<br>I hold that this is the same reason why our Rabbis call the language of the Torah “the Sacred Language,”<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah, 32a.</i> because the words of the Torah, and the prophecies, and all words of holiness<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">A reference to the third section of the Bible which contains the Writings.</i> were all expressed in that language. It is thus the language in which the Holy One, blessed be He, spoke with His prophets, and with His congregation [when He said], — <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:2.</i> and <i>Thou shalt have no other gods before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3, and Makkoth 23b.</i> and the other communications of the Torah and prophecy — and in that tongue He is called by His sacred names: <i>E-il, Elokim, Tze-baoth, Sha-dai, Ya-h</i>, and the Great Proper Name [i.e., the Tetragrammaton]. In that tongue He created His world,<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 18:4.</i> and called the names <i>shamayim</i> (heavens),<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 1:8.</i> <i>eretz</i> (earth)<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10.</i> and all that is in them, His angels and all His hosts — <i>He called them all by name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 40:26.</i> The names of Michael and Gabriel are in this Sacred Language.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Michael [<i>mi kamocha E-il</i>] signifies “who is like unto Thee, O G-d.” Gabriel [<i>gabri E-il</i>] means “my strength is from G-d.”</i> In that language He called the names of <i>the holy ones that are in the earth:</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 16:3.</i> Abraham,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 17:5: <i>but thy name shall be Abraham, for the father of a multitude of nations have I made thee</i>.</i> Isaac,<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 19: <i>and thou shalt call his name Isaac</i> [of the Hebrew root meaning “to laugh”].</i> Jacob,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:26: <i>and He called his name Jacob</i> [“one that takes by the heel”], the word <i>vayikra</i> (and He called) referring to G-d (Rashi quoting the Midrash).</i> Solomon,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 12:25: <i>And he called his name Jedidiah, for the Eternal’s sake</i>.</i> and others.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 13:2: <i>Josiah will be his name</i>.</i><br>Now the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has written in the Moreh Nebuchim:<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Guide of the Perplexed III, 8. Ramban is following the text of Al Charizi’s translation [and not that of Ibn Tibbon].</i> “Do not think that our language is called the Sacred Language just as a matter of our pride, or it be an error on our part, but it is perfectly justified; for this holy language has no special names for the organs of generation in male or female, nor for semen, nor for urination or excretion, excepting in indirect language. Be not misled by the word <i>sheigal</i> [to take it to mean the act of intercourse; this is not the case,] but it rather denotes a female ready for intercourse. It says <i>yishgalenah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:30. In Tibbon’s translation there is here a completely different text.</i> in accordance with what has been written on it, and it means that ‘he will take the woman as a concubine.’”<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">I have found this interpretation in Jonah ibn Ganach’s Sefer Hashorashim (under the root: <i>shin, gimmel, lamed</i>): “The most appropriate of the interpretations on it is that it is used in reference to a concubine.”</i> Now there is no need for this reason [why Hebrew is called the Sacred Language], for it is clear that the Hebrew language is most holy, as I have explained. And the reason [Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon] mentioned is in my opinion not correct. The mere fact that [the masters of the Masorah] have circumscribed the word <i>yishgalenah</i> [to be read as] <i>yishk’venah</i> (he will lie with her), shows that the word <i>mishgal</i> is the term for sexual intercourse itself. Similarly the fact that they circumscribed the expression, <i>to eat ‘et choreihem’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 18:27.</i> [to be read <i>eth tzo’atam</i> — “their dung”] shows that <i>choreihem</i> is an indecent term. And if the reason were indeed as the Rabbi [Moshe ben Maimon] has said, they should have called [the Hebrew language not “the Holy Language” but] “the modest langauge,” similarly to that which we have been taught [in a Mishnah]:<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 68b.</i> “until he grows a beard — the lower one and not the upper one [is meant], except that the Sages spoke in modest language.” The Rabbis have further said:<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 86:6.</i> “<i>Save the bread which he did eat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 39:6.</i> — this is a refined expression [for it refers to his wife],” and so also in many places.<br>Now Scripture explained that <i>the shekel is twenty gerahs</i>, of silver. Onkelos translated gerahs as <i>mo’ah</i>, for the gerah was, in his opinion, a name for a coin which in Aramaic is called <i>mo’ah</i>. And so did Yonathan ben Uziel translate <i>la’agorath keseph</i> (a piece of silver):<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:36.</i> <i>l’mo’ah d’chsaph</i> (for a <i>mo’ah</i> of silver). So also did Onkelos translate <i>after the shekel of holiness</i> as <i>sil’o</i>, for such is the name of the [shekel] coin in Aramaic, and its measure is also known in the Talmud.<br>Rashi wrote:<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Seder Mishpatim</i> 21:32.</i> “A shekel weighs four gold coins, making half an ounce according to the correct weight of Cologne.” Now when the Rabbi [Rashi] found it clearly written in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Metzia 34 b; Shebuoth 43a.</i> that a [silver] <i>sela</i> [which is equivalent to the shekel] is four [silver] <i>denars</i>, he deduced [that a gold shekel is also equivalent to four gold <i>denars</i>], for the weight of the silver <i>denars</i> is as the weight of the gold <i>denars</i>. Thus he wrote in his commentary to the Gemara of Baba Kamma:<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Baba Kamma 36b.</i> “A [silver] <i>denar</i> weighs as much as a gold [<i>denar</i>], and in Constantinople they even call the gold coin <i>denar</i>.” All this is correct. But as to the Rabbi’s estimation, that in terms of the gold coins found in his generation and in our generation the shekel is equivalent to half an ounce, as he mentioned — that is not so, for the kings of the peoples have lessened [the weight of] the gold coins. We find it already mentioned in the words of the author of Hilchoth Gedoloth<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Mishpatim</i> Note 70.</i> and the first Gaonim,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Following the close of the Talmud [in the year 500 of the Common Era] the recognized spiritual heads of Jewry were the heads of the Sura and Pumbeditha academies in Babylon. The recipients and interpreters of the traditions of the Rabbis of the Talmud, the Gaonim were active for over a period of five hundred years — during the height of the Moslem empires.</i> that the <i>denar</i> mentioned throughout the Talmud is the <i>denar shashdang</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">A small coin (Kohut, Aruch Hashalem).</i> and it is so written in Tractate Kiddushin in the Halachoth (Laws) of our Rabbi [Rabbi Yitzchak Alfasi] who said that “[the <i>zuz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>zuz</i> is the same as a <i>denar</i> (<i>ibid.</i>, <i>zuz</i>).</i> <i>shashdang</i>] is the gold <i>denar</i> of the Arabs.” Now according to these estimations found in the words [of the Hilchoth Gedoloth and the Halachoth of Alfasi], the <i>denars</i> of the Talmud were larger than the gold coins current in our times by almost a third, and the shekel weighed three fourths of an ounce according to the weight of that country [and not as Rashi wrote that the shekel weighed four gold coins, making <i>half</i> an ounce etc.], and that is “the ounce” that the Rabbi [Rashi], of blessed memory, mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">At this point see the Addendum which Ramban added to the end of his commentary after he arrived at Acco and found some ancient Hebrew coins which when he weighed them he found that the result corroberated Rashi’s explanation.</i><br>Know that the shekels [mentioned in] the Torah are these <i>s’laim</i> [mentioned in the Talmud], each <i>sela</i> being four <i>denars</i>. But the shekel mentioned in the words of the Sages — such as that which we have been taught in a Mishnah:<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Shebuoth 43a.</i> [“if a man lent his fellow money on a pledge, and the pledge was lost, and the borrower said,] ‘You have lent me a shekel on it and it was worth a <i>sela</i> [and therefore you owe me two <i>denars</i>],’ or [the lender said,] ‘I lent you a <i>sela</i> on it and it was worth a shekel [and therefore you still owe me two <i>denars</i>]’” — [this shekel] is two <i>denars</i>, half of a <i>sela</i>. The reason for this [change in the meaning of the term shekel — the shekel of the Torah being four <i>denars</i> whilst the shekel of the Sages is two <i>denars</i>], is that the people called the half-<i>s’laim</i> [which were each two <i>denars</i>] “shekels,” since they used them every year to pay the [half-] shekel to the Sanctuary. And so it was adopted by the Sages in the style of the Mishnah. Therefore a man would say to his friend, “You have lent me a shekel,” that is, the “shekel” which Israelites give to the Sanctuary.<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the shekel of the Torah is really four <i>denars</i>, but since the Torah enjoined the giving of a half-shekel, that half-shekel came to be called “shekel,” as that was the coin the people gave yearly to the Sanctuary, and hence the Sages adopted the usage of that term — so that when people say “shekel” they really mean a coin worth two <i>denars</i>.</i> It is possible that in the time of the Second Sanctuary they actually made a silver coin of two denars, so that it should be available to be given to the Temple treasurer, and they would not have to give an allowance [for exchanging the full shekel of the Torah into two half-shekels]. That coin they called “shekel,” and the shekel of Moses which is the shekel of the Torah they called <i>sela</i>, as Onkelos translated it. Some scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">I have not identified them.</i> say that the reason [they called the shekel of Moses <i>sela</i>] is because of what the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Bechoroth 5a.</i> “The maneh<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The maneh is a weight equal to the sixtieth part of a talent.</i> of the Sanctuary was double [as much as the common maneh],” and so also were all the coins. But this is not correct, for the [thirty] shekels that the owner of an ox who killed a slave must pay<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:32.</i> and the [fifty] shekels that the violator<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 22:29.</i> and seducer<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:16. See Ramban here.</i> must pay, were not connected with the Sanctuary.

Verse 14



Verse 15

THE RICH SHALL NOT GIVE MORE, AND THE POOR SHALL NOT GIVE LESS. The meaning of this is that they should all bring the specified amount of money in equality. It would appear from this verse that if the poor man gave as his shekel-dues less than the half-shekel [prescribed by the Torah], he transgresses this negative commandment, since this verse constitutes a prohibition. For even if we were to say that the phrase <i>the rich shall not give more</i> constitutes a mere negation,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Mishpatim</i>, Note 71.</i> meaning that it is enough for him to give the half-shekel, we could not so interpret <i>and the poor shall not give less</i>. If so, they must both be prohibitions: thus if the individual rich man gave more, or the poor man gave less, he transgressed this negative commandment. Perhaps the reason why the Temple — officers used to take up the shekel-dues in baskets [out of the shekel-chamber], with the intention also to cover the shekels lost and those still to be collected,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Kethuboth 108a. When the shekels were collected they were put in a chamber. Three times in the year the officers of the Temple would take up three basketfuls out of the chamber for the purpose of purchasing the public sacrifices. And in order to cover every Jew, even those living in the remote parts of the Diaspora, [whose shekel contribution has not arrived yet], or to cover anyone whose shekel was lost, the officers in taking up the shekels would do it also on behalf of those people whose shekels were lost and those whose shekels were yet to arrive. Ramban on the basis of the verse before us suggests an additional reason for this procedure.</i> was to rectify this matter, for if the poor gave less, the balance was destined to be collected from him, but as for the rich who gave more, the Temple-officers would not “take up” his surplus, for they would not take possession of these surpluses [on anyone’s behalf]. However, I have noticed that neither the author of the Hilchoth Gedoloth nor all other scholars who counted the commandments [including the Rambam in his Sefer Hamitzvoth], have mentioned this as one of the negative commandments.

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19

AND AARON AND HIS SONS SHALL WASH THEIR HANDS AND THEIR FEET THEREAT. This washing was out of reverence for Him Who is on high, for whoever approaches the King’s table to serve, or to touch <i>the portion of the king’s food, and of the wine which he drinks</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 1:5.</i> washes his hands, because “hands are busy”<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Succah 26b.</i> [touching unclean things automatically]. In addition He prescribed here the washing of feet because the priests performed the Service barefooted, and there are some people who have impurities and dirt on their feet.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], these parts of the body had to be washed because the extremities of the person’s body are his hands and feet, for when the hands are upraised they are higher than the rest of the body, and the feet are the lowest point. They allude in the human form to the Ten Emanations, with the whole body between them, just as the Rabbis have said in Sefer Yetzirah:<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Sefer Yetzirah (Book of Creation), 6:4.</i> “He made a covenant with him [i.e., Abraham] between the ten fingers of his hands and the ten fingers of his feet, with the protrusive part of the tongue and with the protrusive part of the nakedness.” Therefore the ministers of the One on High were commanded to wash their hands and feet, this washing being for the sake of holiness, as Onkelos translated here, <i>l’rochtzah</i> (to wash): <i>l’kidush</i> (to sanctify).<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">But in all other places (such as Genesis 18:4) Onkelos renders the term <i>rochtzah</i> (washing) literally.</i> It is on the basis of the idea of this commandment that our Rabbis have instituted the washing of hands before prayer,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 60b.</i> in order that one should direct one’s thoughts to this matter, just as in the uplifting of hands by the priests when blessing the people.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">When reciting the Benediction for the washing of hands one must lift up the hands. This is comparable to the raising of the hands of the priests in order to bring down the blessings from on High; so also the washer raises his hands for that purpose.</i><br>It is the washing which is the essence of the commandment, but He commanded [the making of] the laver only in order that the water should be ready in it. Thus the absence of the laver does not invalidate the washing, neither is there any duty [to do the washing specifically from the laver]; thus on the Day of Atonement the High Priest washed his hands and feet from a golden jug<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 43b.</i> which they made in his honor. However, what we do learn from the laver [that the Torah mentions], is that the washing [of the hands and feet by the priests] must be performed from a vessel.

Verse 20



Verse 21



Verse 22



Verse 23

MOR DROR’ (FLOWING MYRRH) FIVE HUNDRED SHEKELS. The commentators<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Ibn Ezra quoting Rabbeinu Saadia Gaon.</i> — including Harav Rabbi Moshe [ben Maimon]<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Mishneh Torah, <i>Hilchoth Klei Hamikdash</i>, 1:3: “<i>Mor</i> is the blood gathered up [in the abdomen] of a certain animal in the land of India known to all, which is used in perfumery.”</i> — have agreed that <i>mor</i> is that perfume which is called musk [an animal perfume].<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">See Jastrow: <i>muskin</i> and <i>mor</i>.</i> But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra objected to this interpretation, since [musk] is not a spice [as are <i>the sweet cinnamon</i> and <i>the sweet calamus</i> mentioned here in the same verse], even though it has a pleasing odor. Perhaps this is why Scripture separated it from the spices.” And then [Ibn Ezra] asked: “But is it not written, <i>I have gathered ‘mori’ (my myrrh)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:1.</i> which shows that <i>mor</i> is something gathered [like spices], while those who bring musk say that it is a substance gathered in a glandular sac under the skin of the neck of the deer?<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, this proves that <i>mor</i> is not musk as Saadia Gaon said, for the verse speaks of <i>mor</i> being gathered while musk is not “gathered.”</i> Moreover, the verse states, <i>and my hands dropped with myrrh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:5.</i> [and musk does not drop]. But perhaps it does do so, due to its moistness.” [Thus far are Ibn Ezra’s words].<br>It is possible that we say that Scripture states <i>I have gathered ‘mori’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:1.</i> because <i>mor</i> is the blood gathered up in the abdomen of an animal of the hind species known in the land of India; when it walks between the shrubs on very hot days it scratches against the sac and the blood comes out in thickened mass, which is then gathered from the reed-grass. It states <i>and my hands dropped ‘mor,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:5.</i> because Scripture imagines its odor to be such that one’s hands drop globules of water because of it.<br>Others<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to Rabbi Abraham ben David [Rabad] who commented on Rambam’s language (see Note 96): “My opinion does not accept this, that there should enter into sacred things the blood of any animal in the world, and all the more the blood of an unclean animal.”</i> have argued: how could there be included in the incense<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Among the eleven components of the incense was <i>‘mor’</i> (myrrh, cassia, spikenard etc.) (Kerithoth 6 a).</i> and the sacred oil the blood of an unclean animal? This too is no question, for that moisture gathered up in the animal because of its abundant blood, which drops from [the animal] whilst still alive, is not susceptible to uncleanness, nor is it repulsive.<br>The word <i>dror</i> they<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">R’dak, in his Book of Roots, under the root of <i>dror</i>.</i> have explained to be of the expression, <i>and ye shall proclaim ‘dror’ (liberty)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:10.</i> here meaning that it should be free from any imitation or adulteration. Perhaps we might say that Scripture requires it to be gathered when free, meaning that it should be taken from that deer whilst it is free, wandering between the beds of spices and enjoying itself at will, because once it is captured and held in the possession of man, it produces but little <i>mor</i> (musk) and it does not have such a pleasant odor. This is clear.<br>Yet despite all this [that we have written to justify the opinion of Rabbeinu Saadia Gaon and Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon, that <i>mor</i> mentioned here is musk], it appears to me from the words of our Rabbis that <i>mor</i> is not musk, for they have said in Midrash Chazita:<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 4:29. See Vol. I, p. 292, Note 73, for explanation of the name “Chazita.”</i> “<i>Mor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:14.</i> means <i>inmirinon</i>” [an unguent scented with Arabian myrtle], while musk is so called even in the language of the Sages, just as it is said in Tractate Berachoth:<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 43a.</i> [“Over all spices put on coals one recites the Benediction: ‘Blessed… Who createst diverse kinds of spices’], except over musk, because it is derived from an animal.” In the Yerushalmi there<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Berachoth VI, 6.</i> they likewise say, [with respect to this Benediction]: “excepting <i>muskin</i>,” and the author of the Aruch<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbi Nathan ben Yechiel of Rome [flourished in the middle of the eleventh century] was a contemporary of Rashi. His work the “Aruch” is not only a complete dictionary of Talmudic and Midrashic language but is also a veritable storehouse of explanations of Rabbinic texts. It is thus both a dictionary and commentary. It has had a lasting influence on Jewish learning. — The particular reference here is to the Aruch, under the term: <i>mushk</i>.</i> wrote that it is also so called in Greek. In Midrash Chazita it furthermore says:<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 1:58.</i> “<i>My beloved is unto me a bag of ‘hamor’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 1:13.</i> — this refers to Abraham. Just as the <i>mor</i> is the chief of all kinds of spices,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban will further on explain that the intent thereof is, that in the verse before us where the spices [for the making of the Oil of Anointment] are listed, the myrrh heads the list, or it may mean that for aromatic purposes it is the best of all spices.</i> so was Abraham the chief of all righteous people. Just as this <i>mor</i> exudes only through the fire, so Abraham’s deeds were not known until he was thrown in the fiery furnace.<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 160.</i> And just as with this <i>mor</i> [we see that] whoever gathers it with his hands develops bad sores, so did Abraham cause himself to be distressed and afflicted with suffering” [for the sake of his love of G-d.] Now the musk exudes its odor [spontaneously], without being put upon the flame! Moreover, we have been taught [in a Mishnah]:<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Mikvaoth 9:5.</i> “These interpose in vessels:<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">When immersing an unclean vessel in an Immersion-pool to be cleansed, for the immersion to be valid there must be nothing interposing between the body’s surface and the water of the pool.</i> pitch and <i>mor</i> etc. on a packsaddle. Rabban<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rabban” [instead of “Rabbi”] signifies that he was the <i>Nasi</i> (Prince) of the Sanhedrin.</i> Shimon ben Gamaliel says: [They interpose only] if they are as big as an Italian <i>issar</i> [a Roman coin].” And it further teaches there:<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Mikvaoth 9:7.</i> “This is the general principle: Anything about which a person is particular, interposes [and invalidates the immersion]; anything about which he is not particular that does not interpose.” Now musk is not something which sticks [to a vessel or to a garment] so that it should interpose [and invalidate the immersion, and so, if <i>mor</i> is musk, why does the Mishnah state that it does interpose]! And even if perhaps they fix it in such a way that it does attach to vessels, a person is not particular about it, so that it should interpose even on a packsaddle! Moreover, the verse <i>‘mor va’aholoth k’tzioth’ are all thy garments</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 45:9.</i> [Yonathan ben Uziel] translated: <i>‘mura,’ aloe-wood and cassia</i>. [Thus it is clear that <i>mor</i> is not musk, for <i>mura</i> is myrrh.]<br>It is likely that <i>mor</i> is so called in Arabic as there are diverse kinds of it — <i>mur achmar ve’abitz</i>. It is used for incense, and when burned produces a sweet odor. Thus all languages — Hebrew, Aramaic, and also Arabic — are alike in the usage of this term. And in the language of the Agadah [quoted above]<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">See the text from the Midrash Chazita, at Note 105.</i> — be it Persian or Greek<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">In Kohut’s Aruch Hashalem [and in Jastrow’s Dictionary] <i>inmirinon</i> is explained as a word of Greek origin.</i> — it is a similar expression: <i>inmirinon</i>. In Latin as well it is called <i>myrrha</i>. The consensus of the languages on this term would thus indicate that [the <i>mor</i> of the Torah] is indeed that substance [called myrrh or its equivalent in the above-mentioned languages — and not the musk mentioned by Saadia Gaon], and it is counted among the spices.<br>And as to that which the Rabbis said above,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">See the text from Midrash Chazita mentioned above at Note 110.</i> that “the <i>mor</i> is the chief of all kinds of spices,” they mean that [in the verse before us where the spices are listed] the Torah mentioned it first, or it may mean that for aromatic purposes it is the best of all spices. Possibly amongst its diverse kinds there may be a still more aromatic one, and that is called <i>dror</i>, and the one who gathers it [as the Midrash quoted above said], develops bad sores on his hands, because it is bitter as wormwood. And the Rabbis have taught in the Sifra:<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, <i>Vayikra Chova</i> 22:7.</i> “Things which cannot be recognized, such as a mixture of water into wine, or of gum in myrrh,” for this is how they falsify the myrrh, by putting into it a certain gum which resembles it, called <i>tzemeg</i> in Arabic. This is why He said <i>mor dror</i>, meaning that it be clear of any of these usual adulterations. It is possible that the term <i>dror</i> always indicates “clean” (or “pure”). Similarly, <i>and ye shall proclaim ‘dror’ throughout the land unto all the inhabitants thereof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 25:10.</i> means that all people of the land be “clean” from servitude, and from all subjection attaching to their persons or lands, similar to the expression, <i>and the owner of the ox shall be quit</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 21:18.</i> And as to that which Scripture says, <i>And my hands dropped with ‘mor’, and my fingers with flowing ‘mor,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:5.</i> it is possible that the meaning is as follows: “and my hands dropped with <i>oil</i> of myrrh,” for it is customary to apply it also to the hands in order to make them gentle and soft, as it is written, <i>six months with oil of myrrh</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 2:12.</i> which our Rabbis have explained to be: “the oil of olives that have not reached a third of their growth, because that makes the hair fall out and improves the complexion.” And the purport thereof is that that oil was prepared with myrrh and therefore it was so called [“oil of myrrh”]. This then is the meaning of <i>‘natphu’ (dropped with) ‘mor’</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 5:5.</i> [the dropping being not from the myrrh but from the oil put in it]. I hold this to be the <i>inmirinon</i> mentioned in the Midrash [quoted above,<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 4:29. See Vol. I, p. 292, Note 73, for explanation of the name “Chazita.”</i> namely that it is identical with <i>the oil of myrrh</i> mentioned in the Scroll of Esther], for similarly the Rabbis in the Yerushalmi<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Demai I, 3.</i> call “oil of <i>v’rad</i>” (roses): <i>vardinun</i> [and in the same way they called “the oil of <i>mor</i>” — <i>inmirinon</i>]. Such is the customary usage for names of oils in the various languages of the nations. [Finally,] it is also possible that they extract oil from the myrrh, as is done with gum mastic and other kinds of gums. Thus it is correct to call it “myrrh,” and “oil of myrrh.”
V’KINMON BESEM’ (AND OF CINNAMON SPICE) HALF SO MUCH. “Since cinnamon is the bark of a tree [and it is of two kinds], one which has a good taste and fragrance, whilst the other is just like [any other] wood, therefore Scripture had to say: <i>kinmon besem</i> — of the good kind.” This is Rashi’s language. And Harav Rabbi Moshe [ben Maimon] said<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In his commentary to the Mishnah, at the beginning of Tractate Kerithoth. See, however, in my Hebrew commentary p. 497, Note 8, that this definition that Ramban quotes in the name of Rambam on <i>kinmon besem</i>, is in our texts of Rambam’s commentary found on a different name altogether. The term mentioned here is in Arabic since Rambam wrote his commentary to the Mishnah in Arabic. See also following note.</i> that it is “<i>kesher salichah</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">In Joseph Kapach’s new Hebrew translation of Rambam’s commentary in Arabic, he comments on this term that it is “Cinnamonum Zeylanicum” (Kerithoth, p. 229, Note 49).</i> Other scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned by Ibn Ezra [in his short commentary on Exodus] in the name of Rabbeinu Saadia Gaon.</i> hold that it is that precious tree called <i>itib</i>. But none of these interpretations is correct, for the Rabbis have said in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 65:13.</i> and in Midrash Chazita:<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 4:29. See Vol. I, p. 277.</i> “<i>‘kinmon’</i> grew in the Land of Israel, and goat and deer ate of it.” Thus it is like the grass of the field from which the sheep pasture. In my opinion <i>kinmon besem</i> is the aromatic grass called in Arabic <i>adbar</i>, and in Latin <i>ascinant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">See Dictionary under “ascidium.”</i> which is an important spice, called in the vernacular, <i>saika domika</i>, and where it grows it is used as fodder for camels. Our Rabbi [Yitzchak Alfasi] wrote in [his Halachoth on Tractate] Pesachim,<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">In the Chapter <i>Arbei Pesachim</i>.</i> [in connection with the spices put into <i>charoseth</i> in memory of the straw from which the Israelites in Egypt made the bricks]: “such as <i>kinmon</i> and <i>sanbal</i>, which are similar to straw.”<br><i>Kidah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned in Verse 24.</i> is known from the Aramaic language, [as Onkelos rendered it] <i>k’tziah</i> (cassia). It is also so in Arabic.

Verse 24



Verse 25

AND THOU SHALT MAKE IT A HOLY ANOINTING OIL, A PERFUME COMPOUNDED AFTER THE ART OF THE PERFUMER. In line with the simple meaning of Scripture, the preparation of the Oil of Anointment was in accordance with the view of Rabbi Yehudah, who said<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 5a.</i> that they first soaked the spices in water in order that they would not absorb the oil which was poured upon them Now this soaking [of which Rabbi Yehuda speaks] was not mere soaking in water alone. Rather, they put ground spices in a vessel full of water and then they poured upon them <i>a hin of olive oil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> Then they placed this vessel upon another vessel full of water, and put it over a low flame with embers, and boiled it until the water [in the upper vessel] evaporated, and they retained the oil which was upon it. Such indeed is the way that perfumers make all aromatic oils. This is why Scripture shortened the explanation and commanded merely that they make this oil <i>a perfume compounded after the art of the perfumer</i>, without explaining the process by which it is to be made, for the way of the perfumers was known among them. And so I found in Tractate Shekalim of the Yerushalmi:<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Shekalim VI, 1.</i> “Rabbi Yehudah says: They boiled [the spices] in water and put the oil on top of it; as soon as [the oil] retained the odor [of the spices] they would take off the oil, just as druggists do, for it is said, <i>And thou shalt make it a holy anointing oil, a perfume compounded after the art of the perfumer</i>.”

Verse 26



Verse 27



Verse 28



Verse 29

Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

OR WHOSOEVER PUTTETH ANY OF IT UPON A ZAR'… — “When it is not required [for anointing a person] into the [high-] priesthood or kingship.” This is Rashi’s language. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra retorted that <i>zar</i> in this connection means anyone who is not of the seed of Aaron and his sons mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">For since He mentioned first (in Verse 30): <i>And thou shalt anoint Aaron and his sons</i>, it follows that the expression, <i>or whosoever putteth any of it upon a ‘zar’</i> means that anyone who is not of the seed of Aaron is a <i>zar</i> (a stranger). So why did Rashi say that the oil may also be used for the anointing of a king?</i> just like the verse, <i>and the ‘zar’ that draweth nigh shall be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 1:51. “<i>Shall be put to death</i> — by the hand of Heaven” (Rashi).</i> which means any stranger not included in those mentioned. Similarly: <i>There shall no ‘zar’ eat of the holy thing</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:10.</i> [which means anyone not of the seed of Aaron]; <i>to the end that no ‘zar’ that is not of the seed of Aaron, draw near…</i><sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 17:5.</i> It is for this reason that [Ibn Ezra] thought that the anointing of Solomon<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 1:39.</i> which was done by Zadok [the priest] taking <i>the horn of oil out of the Tent</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 1:39.</i> — which refers to the Oil of Anointment [which Moses prepared] — was a special, temporary decree by authority of prophecy [permitting the oil to be used upon one who was not of the seed of Aaron]. But this is not the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">For according to the Talmud (Kerithoth 5 b) every High Priest who would be appointed was to be anointed with this oil, as were also some of the kings. Generally an heir to the throne of Israel did not have to be anointed, though in order to avoid disputes over the royal succession [as was the case with Solomon] anointing was resorted to. See further on this topic “The Commandments,” Vol. I, p. 45.</i><br>And I say that [the opinion of our Rabbis is borne out by the language of the verse]. For Scripture states, <i>This shall be a holy anointing oil unto Me throughout your generations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31.</i> and it would have been correct if it were to say instead, “This shall be a holy anointing oil for Aaron and his sons throughout their generations,” just as He said in the case of the garments, <i>And the holy garments of Aaron shall be for his sons after him;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:29.</i> or that He say, “And thou shalt anoint Aaron and his sons, and sanctify them, that they may minister unto Me, and it shall be a statute forever to them throughout their generations.” But now that He mentioned only them, [<i>And Aaron and his sons thou shalt anoint</i>] and then continued by saying that it should not be put upon any <i>zar</i>, it could mean that [the prohibition extends] to all people [even High Priests after Aaron] except those mentioned specifically [i.e., Aaron and his sons] ! Similarly He said, <i>Upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> [which might be taken to mean upon anyone’s flesh — even that of the High Priests after Aaron], and yet Scripture explicitly states, <i>And the anointed priest that shall be in his</i> [Aaron’s] <i>stead, from among his sons!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 6:15. This shows that it is impossible to say that the High Priests after Aaron should not be anointed with this oil. And if so, the question appears why did Scripture use here language which might indicate the opposite, as explained above? But such is the explanation etc.</i> But such is the explanation: He commanded that at the moment Aaron and his sons should be anointed with this oil, and then He continued, <i>This shall be a holy anointing oil unto Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31.</i> — to anoint with it My holy anointed ones whom I will choose — <i>throughout your generations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31.</i> and it shall not be put upon a <i>zar</i> (stranger) whom I have not designated unto Me. It is for this reason that kings and High Priests were anointed with this oil, for both of them are “the anointed ones of G-d.” Thus it is written, <i>I have found David My servant; with My holy oil have I anointed him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 89:21.</i> — meaning, with the oil which is <i>the holy anointing oil unto Me</i>. And the meaning of the verse, <i>Upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> is as an admonition to all men [even to Aaron and his sons after they have been anointed with it], since He did not say, “upon the flesh of a <i>zar</i> shall it not be poured.” Thus the purport thereof is that he [Moses] is to pour of the oil upon Aaron’s head in order to anoint him, and then he is to anoint also his sons, but he is not to pour this oil upon any man, even upon the anointed priests, merely as people apply good oils to their bodies in order to scent themselves with hands soaked in oil, after bathing, something like it is said, <i>Wash thyself and anoint thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Ruth 3:3.</i> <i>Then I washed thee with water… and I anointed thee with oil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 16:9.</i> This is the plain meaning of the verse and its intention. And so did our Rabbis say:<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 7a.</i> “How do we know that if the High Priest took some of the oil of anointment which was upon his head and put it upon his stomach, that he is liable [to punishment]? Scripture therefore says, <i>Upon the flesh of man shall it not be poured</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i>

Verse 34

TAKE UNTO THEE ‘SAMIM’ (AROMATICS), STACTE, AND ONYCHA, AND GALBANUM; ‘SAMIM’ (AROMATICS) WITH PURE FRANKINCENSE. Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra commented that by way of the plain meaning of Scripture the interpretation of the verse is: “take unto you the aromatics which are stacte, onycha and galbanum; these spices [you are to take], and pure frankincense with them.” But it is not correct that Scripture should just repeat the word <i>samim</i> [in such a short verse], for it is not the normal way of Scripture to repeat words unless there is some lengthy interpolation<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 4:9.</i> or in order to indicate that it is a continuing thing.<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 15:6.</i> The truth is as our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6b.</i> that the second word <i>samim</i> refers to other aromatics.<br>Now Rashi wrote: “<i>‘Samim’</i> — the least number of aromatics implied by the plural form of this word is two. <i>Stacte, and onycha, and galbanum</i>, make together five. <i>‘Samim’</i> adds a similar number to those already prescribed, thus making ten. <i>With frankincense</i>, makes eleven [altogether].”<br>But one wonders! Why did Scripture not mention them explicitly? Perhaps Scripture is saying: “<i>Take unto thee aromatics, stacte, and onycha, and galbanum</i>, many <i>aromatics with pure frankincense</i>,” thus insisting only on these four spices, for they were the ones that caused <i>the cloud of</i> the smoke of <i>the incense</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 16:13.</i> to ascend; but He commanded that they add to them many other aromatic spices in order that the pillars of smoke [of the incense] should be fragrant. This is why He did not explain [in the case of the incense] the weight of each component [as He did in the case of the Oil of Anointment], nor how much of it should be burnt [daily], since He insisted only that these four [spices mentioned] should be alike [in weight], and that he should add to them other good spices for the burning. The reason for this is that just as He had said with reference to the Oil of Anointment that they make it in accordance with the art of the perfumer, and did not specify how it was to be made but relied upon it [that they knew how to make it], so He said in respect of this incense that he take an equal weight of these four [mentioned] aromatics, and add to them other aromatics and make out of all the components one incense, done <i>after the art of the perfumer</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> [which implies by] using spices known to blend well with these [four] and by preparing them through the process by which they are usually prepared. It is of this incense that he had to put before the Testimony,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 36.</i> so that its pillar of smoke should go up, as was the custom to put spices on coals before kings. In the same way He shortened the account of how to make the incense, and did not mention it when He referred to all the other spices. In a similar vein the Rabbis have said in the Gemara:<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6b.</i> “Resh Lakish said: What is the meaning of the word <i>k’toreth?</i> It is something which circles and rises.”<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The word <i>k’toreth</i> (incense) is thus of the root <i>kateir</i> (surrounding, circling), because the smoke of the burning incense circles and rises.</i> Thus the Torah only commanded in connection with the incense to use those spices the smoke of which circles and rises, in a way similar to the art of the perfumers. Perhaps it was explained to Moses on Sinai by word of mouth which spices are best for that purpose, as well as the whole process of making the incense, for the process of making the Oil of Anointment was likewise explained to him in this manner, even though Scripture made it dependent upon the art of the perfumers. Or it may be that He insisted only on those [four spices] expressly mentioned in the verse, commanding that he perfume them with other spices after the art of the perfumers. And so the Rabbis have said in Midrash Chazit:<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Shir Hashirim Rabbah 3:7.</i> “The Sages investigated and found no more fitting components for the incense than those eleven spices.”<br>It is also possible that <i>samim</i> (aromatics) and <i>b’samim</i> (spices) denote the same thing, as I have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">Above 25:6.</i> and these three components<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., <i>Nataph ushcheileth v’chel’bnah’</i> These are generally translated as being various kinds of fragrant spices: “stacte, and onycha, and galbanum.” But Ramban will now question the two terms [stacte and galbanum].</i> which He specified are not spices, for <i>‘nataph’ and ‘chel’bnah’</i> are saps, and <i>shcheileth</i> is the onycha which comes from the ocean.<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">Onycha… supposed to be the operculum of a marine gastropod (Dictionary).</i> And Scripture states: “Take unto you the mentioned <i>samim</i> [i.e., all components mentioned above<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verses 23-24.</i> in the preparation of the Oil of Anointment — namely, the flowing myrrh, the cinnamon, the calamus, and the cassia — as all these <i>b’samim</i> also went into the incense, as will be explained], and the <i>nataph</i>, and <i>shcheileth</i> and the <i>chel’bnah</i>, and other <i>samim</i> [in addition, as will be explained], with pure frankincense, and make of them a perfumed incense, after the art of the perfumer.” For the <i>samim</i> mentioned above in connection with the Oil [of Anointment] — flowing myrrh, cinnamon, and cassia — also went into the incense. And the <i>knei bosem</i> [mentioned among the components of the oil]<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23. Generally translated “sweet calamus.”</i> is in my opinion the <i>kiluphah</i> mentioned by the Sages,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> called <i>dratzini</i> in Arabic, and so also in the language of the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 65a. In connection with what is taught in the Mishnah there that a woman may go out on the Sabbath with “anything that she puts in her mouth” [to have a good breath], the Gemara explained, “such as <i>dartzuna</i>,” which Rashi explained as “cinnamon.”</i> which is a cane [of sweet spices] resembling reeds. And the <i>samim</i> which He commanded to add [to all those mentioned above] are: spikenard and saffron and the costus, in accordance with that which the Sages have taught.<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> Perhaps Scripture only insisted on these nine<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">“Nine.” The reading should be “eight” (as explained above): the four components mentioned in the making of the Oil of Anointment [myrrh, cinnamon, <i>kanah</i> — the cane of sweet spice — and cassia], and the four expressly stated in the making of the incense [<i>nataph, shcheileth, chel’bnah</i>, and frankincense]. With the three components [spikenard, saffron, and costus] added by the second word <i>samim</i> they form the eleven components of the incense.</i> which He mentioned, but was not particular as to [the nature of] those included by means of the repetition of the word <i>samim</i>, except inasmuch as they are to be sweet, so that they may make a perfumed incense. Thus He shortened the account of the making thereof, as well as of the weights of the other components [except for the four mentioned in the making of the oil, where the weights are prescribed],<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verses 23-24.</i> because He commanded that they make it <i>after the art of the perfumer</i>.<br>It appears to me that the Sages chose three spices [spikenard, saffron, and costus] because they are mentioned in the Song of Songs: <i>Spikenard and saffron… and ‘oholoth,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:14.</i> which is the costus. Its name is in the plural from [<i>oholoth</i>] because there are two kinds of it, the sweet and the bitter. Now Scripture mentioned there, <i>calamus and cinnamon… frankincense</i>, and <i>myrrh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:14.</i> together with these three [spikenard, saffron, and costus], and then said, <i>with ‘all’ the chief spices</i>, so as to include cassia. Thus you have there all<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., eight components: spikenard, saffron, costus, calamus, cinnamon, frankincense, myrrh, and cassia. Three more will follow. Thus Ramban found the eleven components of the incense mentioned in the Song of Songs.</i> the components of the incense. Now before that Scripture mentioned there: <i>‘k’pharim im n’radim’ (henna with spikenard plants)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:13.</i> This is to include <i>nataph ushcheileth v’chel’bnah</i> [mentioned here in the verse] which are saps, for <i>k’pharim</i> is of the root <i>‘v’chapharta othah’ (and thou shalt pitch it)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 6:14.</i> it being an adhesive sap. And the Targum Yerushalmi rendered: <i>myrrh and ‘oholoth’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Song of Songs 4:14.</i> — [pure myrrh and] <i>aksi lalu’an</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">“A tree of bitter aloe wood.” Ramban will further on explain that <i>aksi</i> means tree. See also Jastrow under the term <i>aksiloliyon</i>.</i> which is that precious tree called in Latin <i>linga lubin</i> as <i>aksi</i> means “tree” in Aramaic, and <i>lalu’an</i> is the name of the tree. In Greek it is actually so called: <i>aksiluin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">See Jastrow (<i>ibid.</i>) for the Greek term.</i> and so it is called in Arabic — <i>al urtib</i>. But Onkelos rendered: <i>‘ka’aholim’ planted of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 24:6.</i> — <i>k’busmaya</i> (as spices), without specifying a particular name [for <i>oholim</i>, as did the Targum Yerushalmi mentioned above].
NATAPH’ — is <i>tzori</i> (balsam). Now in Rashi’s commentary it is written: “The balm itself is called <i>triga</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">In our Rashi: <i>theriaque</i>. — To this term Ramban will object, since a theriac is an electuary [a medical compound] composed of many ingredients.</i> but because it is merely the sap which ‘drips’ from the wood of the balsam it is called <i>nataph</i> (dripping).” But I do not know whether this is the scribe’s mistake, or the one who so told Rashi misinformed him. For theriac [the <i>triga</i> mentioned by Rashi] is not one ingredient but is a compound of many ingredients, containing leaven and honey, the flesh of forbidden animals and reptiles, for the powder of dried scorpions and the flesh of the viper go into it, this being the reason why it is so called [theriac], for “poison” in Greek is called <i>theriac</i>. So also in the language of the Talmud:<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 109b.</i> “<i>Torkai</i> (stung by) a serpent.” Similarly this compound is mentioned in the language [of the Rabbis]:<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">Nedarim 41b.</i> “as theriac is good for the whole body.” And Heaven forbid that there should be in the incense the flesh of forbidden animals and reptiles, leaven and honey, for it is written, <i>for ye shall make no leaven, nor any honey, smoke as an offering made by fire unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 2:11.</i> Rather, the <i>tzori</i> is the oily sap which drips from the balsam tree, called in the language of the Sages <i>k’taph</i>. It is this which we have been taught:<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> “Rabban<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The title “Rabban” [instead of “Rabbi”] signifies that he was the <i>Nasi</i> (Prince) of the Sanhedrin.</i> Shimon ben Gamaliel says: The <i>tzori</i> [required for the incense] was the sap which exuded from the <i>k’taph</i> (balsam) tree.” Perhaps it is called <i>k’taph</i> (plucking off) because they break off its branches on days in the hot season, and the balm runs down from the place where it is broken. In the Gemara of Chapter <i>Bameh Madlikin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">“With what may they light” [the Sabbath lamp]? — Shabbath 26a.</i> it is stated: “Rabbi Shimon ben Eleazar says: We do not light [the Sabbath lamp] with <i>tzori</i>, and so did Rabbi Shimon ben Eleazar<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">In Ramban manuscripts: “Rabban Shimon ben Gamaliel.” So also in some manuscripts of the Talmud (see Dikdukei Sofrim, Shabbath, p. 48 Note 1).</i> say: The <i>tzori</i> [required for the incense] was the sap exuding from the balsam tree.” And there in the Gemara<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25b.</i> the Sages explained the reason [why that balm is not used for the Sabbath lamp], because its fragrance spreads and he may come to use it as food [and taking off oil from a burning lamp is considered the same as extinguishing it]. Thus it is clear that the <i>tzori</i> mentioned [for the incense] is that good oil mentioned [in the above Gemara].<br>And I wonder! For Onkelos translated: <i>‘n’choth’ (spicery) ‘u’tzri’ (and balm) and labdanum</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:25.</i> — <i>sh’aph u’ktaph</i>. Similarly he rendered: <i>a little ‘tzori’ (balm)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 43:11.</i> — <i>k’taph</i>. But <i>nataph</i> [here in this verse] he translated <i>n’tupha</i>, and did not translate it as he did in the case of the word <i>tzori!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">For since Onkelos translated (in Genesis 37:25) the Hebrew <i>tzori</i> as the Aramaic <i>k’taph</i>, he should have translated likewise here the Hebrew <i>nataph</i>, for as said above <i>nataph</i> is <i>tzori</i>, and so why did he translate it as <i>k’topha</i>?</i> And Yonathan [ben Uziel] translated everywhere <i>tzori</i> as <i>sh’aph</i>, which is a term for an anointing oil in the language of the Talmud, such as in their saying:<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Chullin 111b.</i> “[for him whose eyes hurt] they make <i>shipha</i> (an ointment of various components) in a vessel,” the word <i>shipha</i> being short of the letter <i>ayin</i>, which would make it <i>she’ipha</i>. A similar example is:<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">Beitzah 16a.</i> “<i>D’sha’yeiph</i> (he anoints) him with the same kind he gave him” to eat. Here too, the word <i>d’sha’yeiph</i> is like <i>d’sha’iph</i> [with the letter <i>ayin</i>].<br>It appears from their opinions<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">From Onkelos who translated (in Genesis 37:25) <i>tzori</i> as <i>k’taph</i>, and from Yonathan who translated it as <i>sh’aph</i>.</i> that both the balsam tree and its fruit are called <i>tzori</i> in the Sacred Language, just like <i>t’einah</i> (fig), <i>rimon</i> (pomegranate), <i>ethrog</i>, and many other names like them. The term <i>n’choth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 37:25.</i> is thus, according to them, [Onkelos and Yonathan], a generic name for all notable and fragrant oils. That is why Scripture states, <i>and he</i> [Hezekiah] <i>showed them all the house ‘n’chothoh’</i> (of his treasure),<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:13.</i> because the treasure-house where the precious oil is stored is called by that name, seeing that it is the choicest of all treasure, and there in fact it is also written, <i>and the precious oil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 20:13.</i> Therefore Onkelos said in the case of the present that Jacob sent to Joseph, that they brought him <i>sh’aph</i> [which is the Aramaic translation for the Hebrew <i>n’chot</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 43:11.</i> which is the term for that notable oil. And they further brought [in the present for Joseph] from the branches of the <i>tzori</i>-tree called <i>k’taph</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">This explains Onkelos’ translation in Genesis 43:11.</i> In other places where Scripture mentions <i>tzori</i> alone, speaking of it as a beneficial medicine — such as in the verse, <i>Is there no ‘tzori’ in Gilead?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 8:22.</i> — Yonathan translates it as referring to the oil called <i>sh’aph</i>. Onkelos translated [here] <i>nataph</i> as <i>netupha</i>, which is an oil called by that name because it “drips” from the broken branches. There is no justification here to translate <i>nataph</i> as <i>sh’aph</i>, for the incense did not contain any ointment.<br>Now I have seen that Harav Rabbi Moshe [ben Maimon]<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Mishneh Torah, <i>Hilchoth Klei Hamikdash</i> 2:4.</i> included in the incense the bark of a tree called in Arabic <i>od balsan</i>. From this it would appear that he was of the opinion that Rabban Shimon ben Gamaliel who said:<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> “The <i>tzori</i> [required for the incense] was the sap which exuded from the <i>k’taph</i>-tree” thereby intended to differ with the Sages [who counted the <i>tzori</i> among the eleven components of the incense], and to say instead that <i>tzori</i> was not one of the ingredients of the incense, since <i>tzori</i> is nothing but a sap, and it was not the sap [of the <i>k’taph</i>] that was put into the incense, but the [bark of the] <i>k’taph</i> itself.

Verse 35

MEMULACH’ (SEASONED WITH SALT), PURE AND HOLY. This means that it be seasoned with salt of Sodom, just as the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">Kerithoth 6a.</i> “Of salt of Sodom, the fourth part of a <i>kab</i>.” Onkelos translated [<i>memulach</i> as] <i>m’areiv</i> (mixed together). By this he intended to say that <i>memulach</i> means “rubbed out” — that the ingredients should all be so well-ground and mixed so thoroughly together, that their identity is “rubbed out” and none of the [individual] ingredients can be recognized. This is of the expression: <i>For the heavens ‘nimlochu’ (shall vanish away) like smoke</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:6.</i> Similarly: <i>‘u’vloyei m’lachim’</i> (and worn rags);<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 38:11.</i> <i>A fruitful land ‘limleichah’ (into a salt waste)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 107:34.</i> These are all expressions of destruction and annihilation.<br>And Rashi explained that the term <i>memluach</i> means that it be thoroughly mixed together in the grinding of the ingredients one with another. To this interpretation Rashi brought proof from the verse similar in meaning: <i>‘malachayich’ (thy mariners) and thy pilots</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 27:27.</i> who are so called “because they turn over the water with the oars when they propel the ship, like a person who stirs up beaten eggs with a spoon in order to mix them thoroughly.”<br>In my opinion mariners are called <i>malachim</i> [of the root <i>melach</i> — salt] because they know the “taste” of the sea, as if they could feel if it is “salty” or “sweet;” that is to say, they know when it will be sweet and pleasant for those travelling by sea, and when it will be bad and bitter for them. It is not those who hold the oars [propelling the ship] who are called <i>malachim</i> [as Rashi said], for it is written on Tyre, <i>The inhabitants of Sidon and Arvad were thy ‘shotim’ (rowers);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> <i>The elders of Gebal and the wise men thereof were in thee thy calkers; all the ships of the sea ‘u’malacheyhem’ (and their mariners) were in thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 9.</i> For it is the older captains who know the sea that are called <i>malachim</i>. And it is further written, <i>And all that handle the oar, ‘malachim’ (the mariners), and all the pilots of the sea, shall come down from their ships, they shall stand upon the land</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 29.</i> Thus three categories are mentioned: those that handle the oar, the mariners, and the pilots [which proves that <i>malachim</i> — the mariners — are not those that handle the oar].<br>Similarly, <i>a fruitful land ‘limleichah’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 107:34.</i> means “to a salt land,” for in a salt land nothing will grow, just as is written of Sodom, <i>The whole land thereof is brimstone, and salt, and a burning, that it is not sown, nor beareth</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 29:22.</i> and it is further written, <i>and he sowed it with salt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">Judges 9:45.</i> It is possible that the letter <i>lamed</i> is redundant in the verse, <i>for the heavens ‘nimlochu’ like smoke</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:6.</i> the intent thereof being as in the word <i>nimchu</i> (erased), which would make it similar to these cases: <i>ba’l'umim;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 44:15. The structure of the word is <i>ba’umim</i> (among the nations).</i> <i>wholly ‘shalanan’ (at ease) and quiet</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Job 21:23. The structure of the word is <i>shanon</i> (ease).</i>

Verse 36

AND THOU SHALT PUT OF IT BEFORE THE TESTIMONY IN THE TENT OF MEETING, WHERE I WILL MEET WITH THEE. We may possibly explain that Scripture mentions here all the [various] regulations concerning the burning of the incense. It thus states that he should burn of it <i>before the Testimony</i> in the Holy of Holies, which refers to the incense burnt on the Day of Atonement, and that he should also burn of it <i>in the Tent of Meeting</i>, [referring to that burnt] every day. The phrase, <i>where I will meet with thee</i> refers back to [<i>before</i>] <i>the Testimony</i> [from where He spoke to Moses]. It is possible that He refers to the putting of the incense on the inner altar which is set <i>before the</i> ark of the <i>Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">In this way the phrase <i>before the Testimony</i> does not allude to the incense burnt on the Day of Atonement in the Holy of Holies, as explained above, but is instead to be understood as follows: “<i>and thou shalt put of it</i> [daily] on the inner altar which is set in the Tent of Meeting <i>before the Testimony</i> in the Holy of Holies.”</i> as He says in the section of <i>Vayakheil</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">It is in the section of <i>Pekudei</i> (40:5): <i>And thou shalt set the golden altar for incense before the ark of Testimony</i>.</i>

Chapter 31



Verse 1



Verse 2

SEE, I HAVE CALLED BY NAME BEZALEL THE SON OF URI, THE SON OF HUR. G-d said to Moses, <i>See, I have called by name</i>, and Moses said to Israel, <i>See, the Eternal hath called by name</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">And the question appears: Why was that special designation called for? The answer is that it was needed because etc.</i> The reason for this is because Israel in Egypt had been crushed under the work <i>in mortar and in brick</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 1:14.</i> and had acquired no knowledge of how to work with silver and gold, and the cutting of precious stones, and had never seen them at all. It was thus a wonder that there was to be found amongst them such a great wise-hearted man who knew how to work with silver and gold, and in cutting of stones [for setting] and in carving of wood, a craftsman, an embroiderer, and a weaver.<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">See further, 35:35.</i> For even amongst those who study before the experts, you cannot find one who is proficient in all these crafts. And even those who know them and are used to doing them, if their hands are continually engaged in [work with] lime and mud, lose the ability to do with them such artistic and delicate work. Moreover, he [i.e. Bezalel] was a great Sage <i>in wisdom, and in understanding, and in knowledge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> to understand the secret of the Tabernacle and all its vessels, why they were commanded and to what they hinted. Therefore G-d said to Moses that when he sees this wonder he should know that <i>I filled him with the spirit of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> to know all these things in order that he would make the Tabernacle. For it was His Will to make the Tabernacle in the wilderness, and He created him for His glory,<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 43:7. And in Chapter <i>Kinyan Torah:</i> “Whatsoever the Holy One, blessed be He, created in His world He created it but for His glory.” Bezalel thus was born for that sacred purpose, as the thought continues to be unfolded by Ramban.</i> for it is <i>He that called the generations from the beginning</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 41:4. — See Vol. I, p. 59, Note 240, for important note on this topic.</i> it being similar in meaning to the verse, <i>Before I formed thee in the belly I knew thee, and before thou camest forth out of the womb I sanctified thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 1:5.</i> The same type of expression we find in the verse, <i>See that the Eternal hath given you the Sabbath; therefore He giveth you on the sixth day the bread of two days</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:29. Here too the sense of the verse is: “See the wonder…”</i><br>Our Rabbis have on this topic a Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 40:2.</i> “G-d showed Moses the book of the first man and told him: ‘Each person I have given a role from that moment on, and Bezalel too I have given a role already then, as it is said, <i>See, I have called by name Bezalel</i>.” This is similar to what I have explained. The Rabbis have also said:<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 55a.</i> “Bezalel knew how to combine the letters with which heaven and earth were created.” The purport of this saying is that the Tabernacle alludes to these matters [heaven and earth], and he knew and understood its secret.

Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AND THE GARMENTS OF ‘HA’SROD.’<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi explains it as “the garments of net-work” [with which the sacred vessels were covered during the journeyings]. Ramban will differ with this interpretation.</i> I do not know why He did not command the making of these garments at the beginning, as He did concerning all the [rest of the] work of the Tabernacle and the garments of Aaron and his sons, for it would have been proper that He say to Moses, “and thou shalt make cloth of blue-purple to cover with it the ark,<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 4:6.</i> and a red-purple cloth to cover with it the altar,<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 13.</i> and a cloth of scarlet to cover with it the table,” and now when charging Moses about those who were to make these things, He should have included these garments with the rest of the work. Perhaps there was no insistence on how they were to be made, and they could have made these garments of <i>srod</i> of one kind alone, but they made them of blue-purple, red-purple and scarlet. They did not want to make them of linen, as that is not distinguished, as are those other colors. After they made them, G-d willed that the blue-purple cloth be for the ark, the red-purple for the altar, and the scarlet for the table. Therefore, it was sufficient to command them in brief [here] when He gave the command about those who were to do all the work, for these <i>garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> were to be made according to their understanding.<br>Now it is not befitting that a garment made to cover [the sacred vessels] should have many holes in it, as Rashi has said.
