Rather, the word <i>ha’srod</i> is of the term <i>sarid</i> (a lone survivor), because all these garments were of one kind,<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">I.e. wool, excepting that they were colored differently: blue-purple, red-purple, and scarlet.</i> as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra said.<br>All this I have written in accordance with the line of thought of Rashi. <i>Yet all this availeth me nothing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 5:13.</i> For what meaning is there in the Holy One, blessed be He, saying to Moses that they should make “garments of <i>kela</i>,”<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The Hebrew word <i>kla’im</i> (hangings) (above 27:9) Onkelos translates <i>s’radin</i>. Similarly he translates the Hebrew word <i>michbar</i> (grate) (<i>ibid.</i>, Verse 4) as <i>s’rada</i>. On the basis of these translations of Onkelos, Rashi suggests here that the word <i>ha’srod</i> is an Aramaic term, which means “garments of net-work,” because they were made with many holes. — It is with reference to this basis for Rashi’s explanation that Ramban says, “garments of <i>kela</i>.”</i> or “garments of <i>s’ridah</i>,” without explaining to him how many of them there should be, two or a hundred, how long and wide they should be, and why they should be made altogether, since the matter cannot be understood at all from this communication [stated here]? Moreover, why are they mentioned always before the garments of Aaron?<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">In the verse before us: <i>And the garments of ‘ha’srod,’ and the holy garments for Aaron</i> etc. — Likewise further, 35:19, and 39:41.</i> Besides, what is the meaning of the phrase, <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’, for ministering in the holy place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 35:19.</i> for this seems to refer to the sacrificial rites in the holy place, just as He says, <i>or when they come near to the altar to minister</i><sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:20.</i> in the holy place. Similarly, <i>even he who cometh into the Tent of Meeting to minister in the holy place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:30.</i> does not refer to outer work, or the carrying of the holy vessels. Furthermore, it is written, <i>and they will make all that I commanded thee: the Tent of Meeting</i> etc., <i>and the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> etc., <i>and the incense of sweet spices; according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 6-11.</i> But He had not commanded him before about <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> at all!<br>What appears from the words of our Rabbis is that <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> are the actual garments of the priesthood. This is mentioned in Tractate Yoma.<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 72 a-b. “What is the meaning of the verse, <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’ for ministering in the holy place</i> (further 35:19)? If not for the garments of the priesthood [which are worn during the service which brings atonement to Israel], there would not have been left a survivor [a <i>sarid</i>] of Israel’s enemies.” The final expression is a euphemism. But the whole quotation shows that <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> refer to the actual garments of the priests.</i> If that is so, it is correct that we translate <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> as “the garments of uniqueness,” that is to say, the garments which when worn designate the outstanding one of the people, <i>the highest among his brethren</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 21:10.</i> Similarly, <i>‘u’basridim’ whom the Eternal shall call</i><sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">Joel 3:5.</i> means the remnants of those who have survived, [the word being] of the root, <i>escape ‘v’sarid’ (and remain)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 44:14.</i> [<i>The garments of ‘ha’srod’</i>] thus allude to the garments of Aaron, which are so called [‘unique’] because only one of the generation may wear them — Aaron in his lifetime, and after him <i>the priest that is highest… upon whose head the anointing oil is poured, and that is consecrated to put on the garments</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 21:10.</i> And Scripture always mentions Aaron’s garments in a way of honor, as it says: <i>for splendor and for beauty;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:2.</i> <i>holy garments;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> <i>the golden plate, the holy crown</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:9.</i> It is for this reason that they are called <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> — garments of royalty. This is the meaning of the verse, <i>And the garments of ‘ha’srod’</i> (the High Priest) <i>to minister in the holy place, and the holy garments for Aaron the priest</i>, Scripture thus reverting [in the second half of the verse] to explain [that the garments of <i>ha’srod</i> are for Aaron]. Similarly it is mentioned in the section beginning, <i>And they brought the Tabernacle unto Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:33. In Verse 41 there it is stated: <i>the garments of ‘ha’srod'… the holy garments for Aaron the priest</i>.</i> And the reason why in this section of <i>See, I have called by name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> it says, <i>And the garments of ‘ha’srod,’ ‘and’ the holy garments for Aaron the priest</i> [when the second half of the verse should have been without the connective <i>vav</i> which signifies “and,” since, as explained, it is in apposition to the first<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">See also Note 232; further in 39:41 the connective “and” is not used by Scripture. The question then appears why is it mentioned here.</i>], is to indicate that these garments are superior in two qualities: they are garments of <i>ha’srod</i> [the High Priesthood], and they are garments of holiness. This is in order to tell us that only the outstanding one among the people should wear them, [and only] when he comes in to minister in the holy place. And seeing that He did not mention here the phrase, <i>to minister in the holy place</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:30.</i> He added in explanation that they are garments of <i>s’rod</i> and garments of holiness. Besides, there are many cases in Scripture where a redundant <i>vav</i> occurs. And the reason why Scripture states, <i>And of the blue-purple, and red-purple, and scarlet, they made garments of ‘srod,’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:1. And if, as explained above, <i>srod</i> is a term referring to the garments of the High Priest, why then does the verse not mention the linen, of which the garments of Aaron were also made? This is because etc.</i> is because it comes to explain <i>These are the accounts of the Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 38:21.</i> giving an accounting — because of their importance — of the gold, silver and brass, how much of them the Israelites brought and what they did with them; therefore it then said afterwards that <i>of the blue-purple, and the red-purple, and scarlet</i> which were brought to them they made <i>the garments of ‘srod’</i> (the High Priest), neither more nor less. Thus it did not mention the linen because it is not as costly a matter [as the rest]. Perhaps they brought so much [of the linen] that it was left over [and therefore Scripture did not mention it]. Then Scripture there refers back and explains [what they did with the blue-purple, the red-purple, etc.] and says, <i>and they made the holy garments for Aaron, as the Eternal commanded Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:1. And if, as explained above, <i>srod</i> is a term referring to the garments of the High Priest, why then does the verse not mention the linen, of which the garments of Aaron were also made? This is because etc.</i> <i>And he made the ephod of gold</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39:2.</i> and then finished the [whole] subject.

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13

ACH’ (BUT) YE SHALL KEEP MY SABBATHS. “Even though you may be anxious<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">Our Rashi adds: “and alert.”</i> to do the work promptly, do not set aside the Sabbath on its account. All [Scriptural expressions containing] the words <i>ach</i> (but) or <i>rak</i> (only), intimate limiting qualifications; [in this case] it is to exclude the Sabbath from [the days on which] the work of the Tabernacle may be done.” This is Rashi’s language. But I have not been able to explain it. For according to the method used by our Rabbis to interpret the words <i>ach</i> (but) and <i>rak</i> (only), it should limit the scope of Sabbath-observance [and permit the work of the Tabernacle on the Sabbath], for the limiting qualifications [of <i>ach</i> and <i>rak</i>] everywhere apply to the subject of the commandment itself [and since the verse here speaks of Sabbath-observance, the word <i>ach</i> should be restricting its application]. Thus if we are to interpret [and apply] the limiting nature of the word <i>ach</i> to the subject of the work of the Tabernacle, it should follow that it is allowed to be done on the Sabbath! Rather, the limiting nature of the word <i>ach</i> here applies to circumcision [on the eighth day of the child], or to the saving of human life, and similar instances, [to tell us] that they set aside the Sabbath. And so the Rabbis said in Tractate Yoma:<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Yoma VIII, 5.</i> “And whence do we know that even in a doubt whether life is in danger, the Sabbath may be set aside? Rabbi Abohu said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: <i>‘Ach’ ye shall keep My Sabbaths</i> — [the word <i>ach</i>] has a limiting qualification.” And the reason why the work of the Tabernacle does not override the Sabbath [is not on account of the word <i>ach</i>, but] because He warned [about keeping the Sabbath] here [right next to the subject of the making of the Tabernacle, thus indicating that the Sabbath is not to be set aside on account of it]. And in line with the plain meaning of Scripture the verse states as follows: “You shall do the work of the Tent of Meeting, but My Sabbaths you shall keep forever.” And in the Torath Kohanim<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>Kedoshim</i> Section 3, 7:7.</i> [the Rabbis have said as follows]: “I might think that the building of the Sanctuary overrides the Sabbath? Scripture therefore says, <i>Ye shall keep My Sabbaths, and reverence My Sanctuary: I am the Eternal</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 19:30. This teaches that “all of you are obligated to keep My honor” (Yebamoth 6 a), and as the Meiri explains it: “you and the Sanctuary are obligated to keep My honor.” Thus the building of the Sanctuary does not override the Sabbath.</i><br>Now the reason for the word <i>Shabtothai</i> [in the plural] is because the Sabbaths of the year are many. By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], He commanded here [the keeping of the “Sabbaths”] by <i>zachor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote"><i>‘Remember’ the Sabbath-day</i> (above 20:8).</i> and <i>shamor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><i>‘Observe’ the Sabbath-day</i> (Deuteronomy 5:12).</i> as I have hinted with reference to their secret,<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:8.</i> this being the reason for the plural — <i>My Sabbaths</i>. Of the two of them [<i>zachor</i> and <i>shamor</i>] He says, <i>for it is a sign</i> [when He should have said “for <i>they</i> are a sign,” this is in order to indicate] that “it” [the Sabbath] is the sign <i>between Me and you… that ye may know</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary here, p. 505, for the mystic interpretation thereof.</i> He states, <i>Ye shall keep the Sabbath</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> and declares that those that profane it are liable to extinction,<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> for <i>the spirit returneth unto G-d who gave it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">Ecclesiastes 12:7.</i> but the soul of that one [who profanes the Sabbath] will be cut off from there.<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">“It is measure for measure. On the Sabbath everything is in perfect Unity. But he who desecrates the Sabbath shows that he does not believe in that Unity, and therefore he deserves to be cut off from it” (Ma’or V’shamesh).</i> He states concerning the seventh day that it is <i>a Sabbath of solemn rest holy to G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 15.</i> because it is the foundation of the world; of the Sabbath He also says that it is <i>a perpetual covenant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 16.</i> and then He states again that <i>it is a sign between Me and the children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> meaning that the Sabbath is the sign on the seventh day, and the purport thereof is that the [seventh] day itself is a sign, and [its sanctification as] the Sabbath is the sign forever.<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">The allusions are Cabalistic. According to Ricanti [here] reference is to the thoughts mentioned above in <i>Seder Mishpatim</i>, Note 23.</i> This is also the purport of the expression, <i>He ceased from work and rested</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 17.</i> this being an allusion to “the extra [Sabbath] soul” which comes from The Foundation of the world, <i>in Whose hand is the soul of every living thing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Job 12:10.</i> Thus the chapter is explained. I have already hinted at its meaning in [my commentary to] the Ten Commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:8.</i> The student learned [in the Cabala] will understand.

Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18

AND HE GAVE UNTO MOSES. This is connected with the end-part of the verse, where the word “G-d” is mentioned, thus meaning: “and G-d gave unto Moses.” Just as Scripture mentioned concerning G-d’s communicating with Moses, <i>And G-d spoke all these words</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:1.</i> and with reference to the work of the Tablets of Law and the writing thereon it says, <i>And the Tablets were the work of G-d, and the writing was the writing of G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 32:16.</i> so also it says concerning the giving, <i>and</i> G-d <i>gave to Moses</i>.

Chapter 32



Verse 1

MAKE US A GOD WHO ‘YEILCHU’ (SHALL GO — in the plural) BEFORE US. “They wished to have many gods. FOR THIS MOSES, THE MAN THAT BROUGHT US UP OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT, and used to show us the way we were to go, WE KNOW NOT WHAT IT BECOME OF HIM. Now we need many gods which shall go before us.” This is Rashi’s language.<br>But his language does not fit [the verse, since Scripture indicates only that they wanted a leader in place of Moses, but not gods]. Rather, this verse is the key to understand the incident of the golden calf, and the thought of those who made it. For it is known that the Israelites did not think that Moses was a god, and that he did for them the signs and wonders through his own power. So what sense is there in their saying, “since Moses is gone from us, we will make ourselves gods?” Moreover, they clearly said, <i>make us, ‘elohim’ who shall go before us</i> — and not a deity who should give them life in this world or in the World to Come. Instead, they wanted another Moses, saying: “Moses, the man who showed us the way <i>from Egypt until now</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 14:19.</i> being in charge of the journeyings <i>at the commandment of the Eternal by the hand of Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:23.</i> he is now lost to us; let us make ourselves another Moses who will show us the way at the commandment of the Eternal by his hand.” This is the reason for their mentioning, <i>Moses, the man that brought us up</i>, rather than saying “the G-d who brought them up,” for they needed <i>a man of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 33:1.</i> You can also understand this matter from Aaron’s answer to Moses our Teacher, when he asked him, <i>What did this people do unto thee, that thou hast brought a great sin upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 21.</i> to which Aaron replied, <i>And they said unto me: Make us a god</i> etc. <i>And I said unto them: Whosoever hath any gold, let him break it off; so they gave it to me; and I cast it into the fire</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 23-24.</i> Now Aaron was apologizing to Moses and saying to him, <i>Let not the anger of my lord wax hot</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 22.</i> and yet here he was speaking as if adding <i>rebellion unto his sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Job 34:37.</i> saying that they asked of him an idol and he made it for them with his hands! So why should Moses’ anger not burn against him! What greater sin than this is there?<br>But the matter is as I have stated, that they did not want the calf to be for them in place of a god <i>who killeth and maketh alive</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 2:6.</i> whom they would take upon themselves to serve as a deity; instead, they wanted to have someone in place of Moses to show them the way. And this was the apology of Aaron. He argued that “they merely told me that I should make them <i>elohim</i> who would go before them in your place, my lord, because they did not know what had happened to you and whether you would return or not. Therefore they needed someone who would show them the way as long as you were not with them, and if perchance you would return they would leave him and follow you as before.” And so indeed it happened, for as soon as the people saw Moses, they immediately left the calf and rejected it, and they allowed him to burn it and scatter its powder upon the water,<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 20.</i> and no one quarrelled with him at all. Similarly you will note that he did not rebuke the people nor say anything to them, and yet when he came into the camp <i>and he saw the calf and the dancing</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> they immediately fled from before him; and he took the calf and burnt it [and scattered its powder upon the water] and made them drink of it, and yet they did not protest at all. But if the calf were to them in place of a god, it is surely not normal that a person should let his king and god be burnt in fire. Lo, if one burn their abominations before their eyes, would they not stone him?<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 8:22.</i> Now it was Aaron who brought forth this shape, for they did not tell him what he should make, whether <i>a bullock, or a sheep, or a goat</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 22:27.</i> or other forms. It is this which is the intention of the saying of the Sages who said,<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 63a.</i> “The verse teaches us that they wished to have many gods,” For they did not know what to choose and which one would be best for them.<br>Now Aaron’s intention was as follows. Because Israel was in a wilderness, a desolate wasteland, and destruction and everlasting desolation come from the north, as it is written, <i>Out of the north the evil shall break forth upon all the inhabitants of the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 1:14.</i> the reference being not merely to the king of Babylon, as can be seen clearly from Scripture,<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15: <i>For, lo, I will call all the families of the kingdoms of the north</i> etc.</i> but rather [the intent of the verse is to state] that the attribute of justice comes to the world from the left,<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">As one faces the east, his left hand is to the north.</i> to requite upon all the inhabitants of the land according to their evil; and since in the account of the Divine Chariot it is said, <i>and the four of them had the face of an ox on the left side</i><sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:10.</i> — therefore Aaron thought that the destroyer [the ox, which was to the left, i.e. the north] points to the place of destruction where its great power is centered, and when worshipping G-d through there <i>the spirit will be poured from on high</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 32:15.</i> just as it was put upon Moses. It is for this reason that Aaron said, <i>Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> meaning that the services and the sacrifices would be to the Proper Name of G-d in order to obtain His favor upon the power [symbolized by] this image,<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., “the ox” which is on the left side of the Divine Chariot, and denotes the attribute of justice. See my Hebrew commentary, p. 507.</i> for, it being before them, they would direct their thoughts towards the purport thereof [and thus would be able to mitigate the destructive forces of the wilderness].<br>It is our Rabbis who have taught us this interpretation, and it is they who have revealed the secret thereof. Thus they have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban is quoting here a composite of Midrashim in Shemoth Rabbah — 3:2, 42:5, 43:8.</i> “<i>‘Ra’oh ra’ithi’ (I have surely seen) the affliction of My people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Exodus 3:7.</i> Said the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses: ‘Moses, you see them in one appearance, and I see them in two appearances.<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the double expression: <i>Ra’oh ra’ithi</i>, translated “I have surely seen.”</i> You see them coming to Sinai and accepting My Torah, and I see them contemplating Me and how I came forth in My ‘travelling coach’ to give them the Torah, as it is said, <i>The chariots of G-d are myriads, even thousands upon thousands</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 68:18. This whole psalm is interpreted in Midrash Tehilim with reference to the Revelation on Sinai.</i> and they will unhitch one of My <i>tatromulin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">This is a Greek word [as Ramban will explain further on] which denotes “four mules.” Here it is used in reference to the four <i>chayoth</i> (living creatures) in the Divine Chariot as described by Ezekiel (Chapter 1), which, as stated in Psalms quoted above, were also seen at the Revelation on Sinai. The sense here is thus that “they will unhitch one of the four <i>chayoth</i> (creatures) in My Chariot, and worship it.”</i> of which it is written, <i>and the face of an ox on the left side</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:10.</i> and bring Me to anger with it.” <i>Tatromulin</i> means “four mules,” for <i>tetra</i> in Greek means “four,” just as the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">Nazir 8b.</i> [“If a person vowed, ‘I will be a <i>Nazir</i>] <i>tetragon</i>,’ he becomes [a <i>Nazir</i> for a period of] four times;” <i>mulin</i> means “mules,” just as in the expression, “The <i>mula’oth</i> (mules) of Rabbi’s house<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 52a.</i> [used to go out with their bits on the Sabbath].” The word <i>tatromulin</i> is thus used as a symbol of the four <i>chayoth</i> (living creatures) who carried the Divine Chariot.<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:5.</i> And in Vayikra Rabbah [10:3] [we find the Midrash stating] that Aaron said, “Since I am building the altar, I will build it to the Name of the Holy One, blessed be He, as it is said, <i>and Aaron made a proclamation, and said, ‘Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Eternal.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> It is not written here, ‘Tomorrow shall be a feast to the calf,’ but <i>to the Eternal</i>.”<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that <i>elohim</i> in this case [<i>Arise, make us ‘elohim’</i>] means that Aaron should make them “something visible and corporeal on which the glory would rest. And if you will pay attention to the first journey,<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 14:19. <i>And the angel of G-d, who went before the camp of Israel</i> etc. (Bachya).</i> you will understand this.” But this does not appear to me to be correct, since the calf was not made according to the manner of those proficient in the art of the constellations, so that the glory or some spiritual influence should dwell upon it; rather, the figure was made so that when the people would worship it they would direct their thoughts to the purport thereof [as explained above]. Now I have already explained<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 13:21.</i> the secret of the first journey, and far it be from Aaron that he should want to be likened to him. Instead, his desire was merely to take of [the <i>tatromulin</i>, as explained above] so that their journeys [in the wilderness] should be on the side of that attribute. The student learned [in the mysteries of the Cabala] will understand.

Verse 2

PULL OFF THE GOLDEN RINGS. He selected gold and not silver, because gold indicates the attribute of justice, its appearance being <i>as the appearance of fire</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:27.</i> just as the Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 45a. The Biblical expression (gold of <i>parvaim</i>) is found in II Chronicles 3:6.</i> “gold of <i>parvayim</i>, gold which is like the blood of bullocks.” It is for this reason that the House where the sacrifices were brought was made wholly of gold, as also the altar of incense<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:3.</i> and the cherubim,<sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:18.</i> and the Rabbis have interpreted [the verses to mean]<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta <i>ibid.</i>, 20:23.</i> that “if they made them of silver [and not of gold] they are like gods of silver and gods of gold.” Even the form for the calf they made of gold rather than of silver.

Verse 3



Verse 4

AND THEY SAID, THESE ARE THY GODS, O ISRAEL, WHICH BROUGHT THEE UP OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT. This verse also will teach you [that they had no intention of worshipping it as an idol], for there is no fool in the world who would think that this gold which was in their ears<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> is that which brought them up out of the land of Egypt. Rather, they said that the power of that figure brought them up out of there. Thus you will find that in no place does it say of the calf, “which brought us ‘out’ of Egypt,” for they acknowledged Him Who said, <i>I am the Eternal thy G-d, who brought thee ‘out’ of the land of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:2.</i> and that it was by His Great Name that He delivered them from there. Instead, they said in many places <i>who brought thee ‘up,’</i> for they took it to be in place of <i>the great hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:31.</i> — <i>that dried up the sea, the waters of the great deep; that made the depths of the sea a way for the redeemed to pass over</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 51:10.</i> It is with this intention that Scripture says, <i>Thus they exchanged their Glory for the likeness of an ox that eateth grass</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 106:20.</i> and there it is said, <i>They forgot G-d Who had delivered them, Who had done great things in Egypt; wondrous works in the land of Ham, terrible things by the Red Sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 21-22.</i> They forgot His word which He commanded them. Thus they transgressed the prohibition, <i>Thou shalt have no other gods before Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:3.</i> as I have hinted there, and you will understand this.

Verse 5

AND AARON SAW. The meaning of this verse is that Aaron saw them set on evil, intent upon making the calf, and he arose and built an altar and proclaimed, <i>Tomorrow shall be a feast to the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> so that they should bring offerings to the Proper Name of G-d upon the altar which he built to His Name, and that they should not build <i>altars to the shameful thing</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 11:13.</i> and that their intent in the offerings should be [to none] <i>save unto the Eternal only</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i><br>It is possible that Aaron said, <i>Tomorrow</i> [<i>shall be a feast</i>], in order to delay them, thinking that perhaps Moses would come in the meantime and they would abandon the calf. But they rose up early in the morning <i>and offered burnt-offerings, and brought peace-offerings</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> Now Scripture does not say “and they offered burnt-offerings to it, and brought peace-offerings to it.” The reason for that is that there were some people amongst them who intended them to be for the Name of the Holy One, blessed be He, as Aaron had said, but some of them became corrupted and sacrificed them to the calf. It is with reference to this latter group that the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, <i>they have worshipped it, and have sacrificed unto it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> for it is they who were the sinners. And even if it was perhaps Aaron who performed the sacrifical rites, Scripture used an indefinite expression — saying, <i>they offered burnt-offerings and brought peace-offerings</i><sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> — in order to suggest that Aaron’s intention was directed towards the Name of the Eternal, whilst they set their mind towards the calf which they had made, and thus the owners [of the sacrifices] invalidated them.

Verse 6

AND THE PEOPLE SAT DOWN TO EAT AND TO DRINK. This means that they all sat down together to eat and drink inordinately, as they would do at feasts and on festivals, and afterwards <i>they rose up to make merry</i> with their idols and indulge in revelry. Scripture tells us this on account of what Moses [later] said, <i>the noise of them that sing do I hear</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> for Moses found them acting riotously in front of him <i>and his heart was lifted up in the ways of the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 17:6.</i> to take it from before them and to burn it in their presence [and scatter its powder upon the water] and make them drink of it.<br>Now Scripture first completed the account of everything they had done with the calf, and afterwards told of what the Holy One, blessed be He, said to Moses, <i>Go, get thee down</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> This communication, however, was given to Moses early that morning, when they worshipped the calf and sacrificed to it. When Moses came down from the mountain they had <i>sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to make merry</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> and he found them in revelry. This also is proof to what I have explained [that at first their intent was not to worship idols], since it was not said to Moses, <i>Go, get thee down, for thy people have dealt corruptly</i><sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> on the day that Aaron made the [golden] calf and the altar, [for had they been made for the purpose of idolatry, Moses] would have come down immediately. Instead, it was only when the people sacrificed to it and worshipped it that He told Moses to go down.

Verse 7

FOR THY PEOPLE HAVE DEALT CORRUPTLY. G-d said to Moses that <i>they have committed two evils</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 2:13.</i> One is that <i>thy people have dealt corruptly</i>. The meaning of the term <i>hashchathah</i> (corruption) is destruction of a structure, similar to that which is said, <i>every man with his weapon of ‘mashchetho’ (destruction) in his hand;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 9:1.</i> <i>behold, I am against thee, ‘hamashchith’ (O destroying) mountain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 51:25.</i> — Babylon — which destroyed every wall and tower [of the fortified cities]. And the meaning of “the destruction” here is that which our Rabbis have called<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">Chagigah 14b. See Vol. I, p. 155. — The “mutilating of the shoots” consists of separating any of the Ten Emanations and worshipping it independently (see Ha’emunah Vehabitachon, Chapter 3, in my Kithvei Haramban, Vol. II, p. 362).</i> “mutilating the shoots,” [of faith, by seeking to undermine the principle of the Unity]. Secondly, <i>they have made them a molten calf, and have worshipped it, and have sacrificed unto it</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 8.</i> Now as regards the first transgression it was known only to G-d, for it is <i>He Who knoweth the secrets of the heart</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 44:22.</i> but the second one, [the open disregard of the Law] was by the sinners amongst them, as I have explained, [in bringing sacrifices to the golden calf; and that was a matter known to all]. Now most of the people shared in the sin of the incident of the calf, for so it is written, <i>And all the people pulled off the golden pendants</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> And were it not for this [participation of theirs in the incident], the anger [of G-d] would not have been directed against them to destroy them all. For even though the numbers of those who were killed for this sin<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 28: <i>there fell of the people that day about three thousand</i>.</i> and those smitten by G-d<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> were few [in comparison to the total number of the people, this was because] most of them shared in the sin only in their evil thought [and not in action], as I have explained.
THAT THOU [i.e., Moses] BROUGHTEST UP OUT OF THE LAND OF EGYPT. This is to be understood in the light of the verse, <i>And Moses led Israel onward from the Red Sea</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:22.</i> Or it may be that G-d wanted to tell it to Moses in the same way as the people had said it — <i>for as for this Moses, the man that brought us up out of the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1.</i> Similarly, in the Book of Deuteronomy, He said, <i>thy people that thou hast brought forth out of Egypt</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:12.</i> meaning that through you [Moses] they have gone out of Egypt, as they say. But in his prayer Moses said, <i>that Thou hast brought forth out of the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11 here.</i> meaning that You alone are the One Who took them out of Egypt, for Yours is the might and the power; for it was with great power that <i>Thy right hand, O Eternal is glorious in power</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:6.</i> and with a mighty hand <i>Thy right hand, O Eternal dasheth in pieces the enemy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:6.</i> Similarly it is said, <i>by Thy great power and by Thy outstretched arm</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:29.</i> as I have hinted at<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 15:6.</i> in connection with the secret of the attribute of the Arm.

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

NOW THEREFORE LET ME ALONE, THAT MY WRATH MAY WAX HOT AGAINST THEM. The meaning of this cannot be “<i>let Me alone</i> and I will become angry,” for if His anger had not been aroused yet, why should it wax hot as soon as Moses leaves Him alone? But in line with the plain meaning of Scripture the meaning thereof is: “leave Me, <i>and I will consume them</i> in My burning anger,” similar in thought to the expression, <i>let Me alone, and I will destroy them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the verse means: “My mercy will subside, and My attribute of justice will wax hot against them <i>and I will consume them</i> with it, for with Me [i.e. when the attribute of mercy is before Me], it<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the attribute of justice has then no power. — So it is clearly explained in Abusaula’s commentary on the mystic passages in Ramban. See Vol. I, Preface, xii, Note 21.</i> has no power over them.” This is the meaning of the expression, <i>And Moses besought the face of the Eternal his G-d</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11. The word <i>pnei</i> (“face of”) alludes to the attribute of justice (Bachya).</i> being similar in usage to the expression, <i>the face of the Lord Eternal G-d, the G-d of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:23.</i> And so Moses mentioned [in his prayer] in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>O G-d Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:26.</i> — first the name of G-d with <i>Aleph Dalet</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ado-noy</i> which alludes to the attribute of justice.</i> followed by the name of <i>Yod Hei</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton which alludes to the attribute of mercy.</i> It is possible that the word <i>vay’chal</i> (and he besought) is of the root <i>t’chilah</i> (beginning).<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">“Since Moses prayed that the attribute of justice be withheld from the people, Scripture therefore uses the word <i>vay’chal</i> [of the root <i>t’chilah</i>, meaning “beginning” or “first”], because [in the order of the attributes as they are arranged from lowest to highest, the one of justice] is nearest to us” (Ricanti). See also Bachya, in my edition, Vol. II, p. 332.</i> Understand it and you will know.

Verse 11

ETERNAL, WHY DOTH THY WRATH WAX HOT AGAINST THY PEOPLE? Now when Moses prayed about this great sin, it would have been fitting that he do so by way of confession and supplication, similar to what he said later on, <i>Oh, this people have sinned a great sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 31.</i> and just as Ezra prayed and confessed<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 10:1.</i> <i>because of the faithlessness of them of the captivity</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:4.</i> and there is no reason why he should say, <i>why doth the Eternal</i> etc.? Our Rabbis, prompted by this [difficulty], have in various homiletic ways<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">See Shemoth Rabbah 43:7-10.</i> tried to mention several reasons for Moses’ minimizing the sin before Him.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], Moses is saying: “Why do You give permission to the attribute of justice to hold sway over Your people, for You have taken them out of the land of Egypt for the sake of Your Name with the attribute of mercy ruling over them, and with the attribute of justice upon their enemies.”<br>Now this prayer — <i>Why doth the Eternal… Wherefore should the Egyptians speak</i><sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 11-12.</i> — appears really to be the very same prayer he mentioned in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>And I prayed unto G-d and I said: O Eternal G-d, destroy not Thy people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:26.</i> for the purport of the prayer is alike in both cases, the difference being only that here Scripture mentioned the prayer before it told us that he came down from the mountain, and there Moses mentioned it after it tells us that he came down from the mountain. But Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra’s opinion is that Moses did not pray for Israel as long as the idol was among them;<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">Hence the prayer recorded in Verses 11-13 was really not recited by Moses until after his descent from the mount and his cleansing the camp of the idolatrous worship, mentioned in Verses 15-29. — Ramban will differ with this interpretation of Ibn Ezra.</i> but only when G-d told him, <i>Let me alone, that I may destroy them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> and he realized that the fate [of the people] was dependent upon him, did he go down the mountain and destroy the calf, and then he returned to pray for forty days, there being no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah. But I do not agree with this opinion. For the prayer he recited upon his return to the mountain [after he had cleansed the camp of the idol] is the one which he mentions, <i>Oh, this people have sinned a great sin</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 31.</i> And if it is all one prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., if the prayer mentioned in Verses 11-13, and the one in Verses 31-32, were both said at the same time, as Ibn Ezra would have it, namely during the forty days after he returned to the mountain, then why etc.</i> which Moses said during the forty days after he returned to the mountain, why does Scripture divide it, mentioning here [in Verses 11-13] part of it, and after he had come down, mentioning the other part [in Verses 31-32]? Rather, these are two separate prayers. Therefore it appears that when G-d told him <i>Let Me alone, that My wrath may wax hot against them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10 here.</i> Moses immediately <i>besought the face of the Eternal</i> and did not delay at all, for he was afraid lest the wrath go out from G-d and the plague would begin<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">See Numbers 17:11.</i> and consume them in a moment,<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 10.</i> therefore at once he said, <i>Eternal, why doth Thy wrath wax hot against Thy people?</i> Similarly I found it in Eileh Shemoth Rabbah:<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 42:1.</i> “Said Moses: ‘If I leave Israel [to their fate] and go down the mountain, they will never have a restoration again. Instead I will not move from here until I seek mercy for them.’ Immediately Moses began pleading on their behalf etc.” Thus he prayed for them and G-d <i>repented of the evil which He said</i><sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> to kill them and destroy them. That does not mean that He was [completely] reconciled with them, but at least He said, “I have repented, I will not destroy them.” And now that Moses had time, he went down the mountain and burnt the calf, and punished its worshippers, and afterwards he said to the people, <i>I will go up unto the Eternal, perhaps I shall make atonement for your sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i> so that He should entirely forgive you. However, in the Book of Deuteronomy Moses narrated the account in another order, stating that after G-d had told him, <i>Let Me alone, that I may destroy them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:14.</i> he said, <i>So I turned and came down</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 15.</i> The reason [for this change in the account of the narrative] is that Moses was listing to them there all their transgressions, and the pains he took for them. Thus he told them of the golden calf they had made in Horeb,<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> on account of which he had to break the Tablets of the Law and to pray for them forty days and forty nights, and also for Aaron,<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> and how he was put to the trouble of burning the calf. Then he continued to tell what they had done <i>at Taberah, and at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 22.</i> <i>And when the Eternal sent</i> them <i>from Kadesh-barnea;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> and after he finished, <i>Ye have been rebellious against the Eternal from the day that I knew you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 24.</i> he went back to the matter of his prayers which he had mentioned, and set down in order the two prayers, saying, <i>So I fell down before the Eternal the forty days and forty nights that I fell down; because the Eternal had said He would destroy you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> — until I prayed, <i>destroy not Thy people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 26.</i> It was not necessary for him to mention the second prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">I.e., the prayer mentioned here in Verses 31-32: <i>Oh, this people have sinned a great sin</i>, etc.</i> because he had already said there that he prayed for them forty days, and even here it does not mention [all the prayers he recited], for who can write down the many supplications and entreaties that he prayed for them during the forty days. And if you will understand what I have explained, then you will really comprehend that there were [here] two prayers, for at first he <i>besought the face of the Eternal his G-d</i>, and at the end [i.e., after he came down the mountain and burnt the golden calf etc. and then returned to the mountain], he <i>fell down before the Eternal for forty days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> as it is explained in the section, <i>and Moses returned unto the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31 here.</i><br>Now in the Book of Deuteronomy he mentioned, <i>Moreover the Eternal was very angry with Aaron… and I prayed for Aaron also at the same time</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:20.</i> This he did not mention here at all for the sake of Aaron’s honor, for Moses did not want to mention in Aaron’s lifetime that he had been dependent upon his prayer, in order that he should not feel ashamed.<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">Of the grief he had caused (Abusaula).</i> But there [in the Book of Deuteronomy] after Aaron’s death, he informed us of the truth. This is the correct order in these Scriptural sections.

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16

AND THE TABLETS WERE THE WORK OF G-D. It would have been proper for Scripture to mention everything connected with the work of the Tablets of the Law in the verse, <i>And He gave unto Moses</i> [<i>… the two Tablets of the Testimony</i>],<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:18.</i> as He said [there], <i>written with the finger of G-d</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:18.</i> It is, however, mentioned here in order to tell of their high distinction [that they were <i>the work of G-d</i>], thus stating that despite all this Moses did not hesitate to break them, because he was angered upon seeing that evil sight and he could not restrain himself from breaking them. Or the matter may be as our Rabbis have mentioned,<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 46:1.</i> that the writing vanished from the Tablets as he approached the border [of the camp] where the calf was, the place of defilement and transgression.

Verse 17



Verse 18

THE NOISE OF THEM THAT SING DO I HEAR.<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tur it is correctly marked as a new paragraph. In all Hebrew editions of Ramban, however, it is connected with the above. As the subject is clearly independent of the preceding matter, I have followed here the order of the Tur for the sake of clarity.</i> The meaning of this is not that Moses knew the matter to be so, for in that case he would have said, “It is the noise of them that sing” [instead of saying, “do I hear”]. Rather, its meaning is that since Moses was the father of wisdom,<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">Sifre <i>Devarim</i> 1. See also in Vol. I, pp. 9-10.</i> and recognized the musical character of all sounds, he said that it was a noise of singing which was being heard by him. The Rabbis have likewise said in an Agadah<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Koheleth Rabbah 9:11.</i> that Moses told Joshua, “Is it possible that one who is destined to be the leader of Israel cannot distinguish between the different kinds of sounds?” Now Moses in his great humility did not tell Joshua the cause of the noise, as he did not want to speak of the disgrace of Israel, and so instead he told him that it was a noise of merriment.

Verse 19



Verse 20

AND HE STREWED IT UPON THE WATER, AND MADE THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DRINK IT. After grinding the golden calf to a fine powder, he scattered it on the surface of the stream which came down from the mountain, and made the people drink of those waters. It is possible that gold burnt in fire does not melt, but instead when placed therein is charred and can be ground to powder, as Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">“There is a certain substance which, if put with gold into the fire, will cause the gold to become charred to dust and never return to its former properties” (Ibn Ezra).</i> This powder was <i>light upon the face of the waters</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Job 24:18.</i> and therefore it floated, and he made them drink of it. Or it may be that he scattered it upon the stream in small quantities, and then drew the water and made them drink it before the gold powder sank in the stream. Or perhaps it was a miraculous event. Thus he wanted to disgrace their deeds by grinding their god to powder and bringing it into their bellies to issue as excrement, something like it is said, <i>Thou shalt put them</i> [i.e., the graven images] <i>far away as one unclean; thou shalt say unto it: ‘get thee hence.’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 30:22.</i> In the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 44a.</i> he also intended to put them to the test in the same way that faithless wives were tried,<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 5:16-22.</i> [so that those guilty of having worshipped the golden calf] would have their bellies swell and their thighs fall away.<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> This is the truth.

Verse 21

WHAT DID THIS PEOPLE UNTO THEE, THAT THOU HAST BROUGHT SO GREAT A SIN UPON THEM? “How many pains did you endure, and how much suffering did they inflict on you, before you brought this sin upon them?” This is Rashi’s language. But it does not appear to me to be correct. For this transgression [of idolatry] is of the kind for which one must sacrifice one’s life and submit to death rather than transgress it [and from Rashi’s words it would appear that if Aaron had suffered much it was permissible for him to make it]. Perhaps Moses told him so in order to magnify his guilt.<br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be that this is like the verse, <i>What have I done? what is mine iniquity? and what is my sin before thy father, that he seeketh my life?</i><sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 20:1.</i> Moses is thus saying: “What hatred did you have for this people, that you have [almost] brought about their destruction and annihilation?” Moses told him this because Aaron had served them in the function of one who reproves<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">This is a reference to what the Rabbis have said that Aaron served as prophet while Israel was yet in Egypt. See commentaries to I Samuel 2:27.</i> and atones for them, and he should have had compassion and mercy on them [and should have made them desist from their course of conduct]; thus the meaning is: “You conducted yourself towards them as an enemy who desires to see their calamity, when they had neither sinned nor transgressed against you.” Now the proper order would have been for Moses to blame him firstly for the sin which he himself had done, and then to charge him for the sin which he brought upon the people, saying: “how did you do this great sin against G-d, causing also many people to trespass, and bringing a great sin upon them?” Moses, however, in his humility showed respect towards his elder brother, and only mentioned to him the stumbling of the people. It is possible that Moses’ <i>heart was steadfast, trusting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 112:7.</i> in the righteousness of his brother [and he assumed] that his intention was not a bad one, [and therefore he did not reprove him for his own conduct]; but for the people’s guilt he did blame him, for he should have reproved them, and thus they stumbled because of him, — and Aaron replied that they deceived him with their words.

Verse 22

THOU KNOWEST THE PEOPLE, THAT THEY ARE SET ON EVIL. Aaron is saying: “They proceeded along the path of evil. They told me to make them a guide in the place of my lord until he returns to me, for perhaps he will return, and then they gave me the gold <i>and I cast it into the fire</i><sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> and behold there came out this calf for them, for they had an evil intention as to the gold, [and wanted] to worship it and sacrifice to it.” But because Aaron did not want to speak at length about their corruption, he spoke briefly and said, <i>and there came out this calf</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> meaning, “there came out for them this evil matter that my lord sees.”

Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

AND MOSES SAW THAT THE PEOPLE WERE ‘PHARUA’ (BROKEN LOOSE). The meaning of this is that although Aaron defended himself and said that he was not at fault with them, yet Moses knew in his heart that the people were broken loose — <i>For they are a nation void of counsel, and there is no understanding in them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:28.</i> It is similar to the expression, <i>‘vatiphr’u’ (and ye have set at nought) all my counsel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 1:25.</i> and similar also to the verse, <i>for ‘hiphria’ (he had cast away restraint) in Judah, and acted treacherously against the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 28:19.</i> [Thus the verse is stating that Moses saw] that Aaron had let the people loose, and left them without any counsel and instruction, so that they became like sheep scattered upon the mountains<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">See I Kings 22:17.</i> without counsellor and guide. Scripture stated this [especially] because they had thought that the calf would be their guide, but in fact they appeared as if they had no counsel, not knowing <i>the way wherein they must walk, and the deeds they must do</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 18:20.</i> for some of them intended it for the good, according to their way of thinking, and others intended it for real evil [i.e., outright idolatry], and thus each one went his own way.
L’SHIMTZAH B’KAMEIHEM’ (FOR A DERISION AMONG THEIR ENEMIES). This means that even those who had no evil design [in the affair of the golden calf] will be slandered throughout the generations by the evil report of their enemies, who will say that the whole people were bereft of counsel and instruction; some [of the nations] will say it for a purely evil purpose, and others will merely say it <i>in the lips of the talkers, and the evil report of the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 36:3.</i> Moses said this with reference to Aaron, meaning that he sinned towards all [i.e., even towards those who did not really intend to sin in the matter of the golden calf]. This is in accordance with the opinion of Onkelos who translated <i>l’shimtzah b’kameihem</i> — “to give them a bad name in their generations.” However, since Onkelos rendered it “in their generations,”<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">In other words, Onkelos’ translation of <i>l’shimtzah</i> as meaning “for an evil report” is in agreement with the above interpretation. However, that which Onkelos said “in their generations” shows that his intent is that even throughout the generations <i>in Israel</i> this affair will become a source of evil, as is explained further on.</i> it would seem that his intention was to explain that the calf which they made will become a cause of evil talk throughout the generations of Israel, for they will say: “It was not in vain that our fathers made the calf and worshipped it, for they knew that it was this which brought them up out of the land of Egypt, and they found worshipping it to be to their benefit, so we will do likewise, it being better for us to serve it;” as indeed happened in the case of Jeroboam who said, <i>Ye have gone up long enough to Jerusalem; behold thy gods, O Israel, which brought thee up out of the land of Egypt</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">I Kings 12:28.</i> Moses thus saw how the incident of the calf would remain a cause for sin throughout the generations.
Now <i>shimtzah</i> according to Onkelos means “evil report,” it being a common term in the language of our Rabbis, such as “a <i>shemetz</i> (a blemish of) descent.”<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">Pesachim 3b.</i> Perhaps according to their<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Onkelos’ and that of the Rabbis, as mentioned above.</i> opinion, that which Scripture states, <i>and mine ear received a ‘shemetz’ thereof</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Job 4:12.</i> also means that his [i.e., Eliphaz the Temanite’s] ear received knowledge of man’s blemish and imperfection, saying, <i>Behold, He putteth no trust in His servants, and His angels He chargeth with folly; how much less them that dwell in houses of clay, whose foundation is in dust</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 18-19.</i> Similarly, <i>and what ‘shemetz davar’ is heard of Him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:14.</i> means that of all His ways there is nothing deserving of reproach or censure, but only praise and adoration.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture <i>shemetz</i> means “little.” Thus [<i>and mine ear received a ‘shemetz’ thereof</i><sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Job 4:12.</i> means] that his ear received but a whisper thereof. <i>And what ‘shemetz davar’ is heard of Him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:14.</i> means that whatever is heard and said about G-d’s strength and His powers, is but a minute amount in relation to the greatness of His deeds. Similarly, <i>l’shimtzah b’kameihem</i> means that Aaron had uncovered the people, thus enabling their enemies to diminish them, for this great sin would lessen them in the eyes of their enemies, or reduce their merits when coming to battle with the enemy, something like that which is said, <i>and I shall diminish them, that they shall no more rule over the nations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 29:15.</i> or as it is said, <i>O Eternal, correct me, but in measure; not in Thine anger, lest Thou diminish me</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 10:24.</i>

Verse 26

AND MOSES STOOD IN THE GATE OF THE CAMP. This is connected with what is said in the preceding verse, thus stating that when Moses saw that the people would be a source of derision and disgrace amongst their enemies, and would thereby profane the Name of G-d, he stood in the gate of the camp and called out loudly, <i>Whoso is on the Eternal’s side, let him come unto me;</i> and they killed publicly all those who worshipped the calf, so that the matter be heard about amongst their enemies, and G-d’s Name would thus be sanctified, in place of the profanation that they had caused.

Verse 27

THUS SAITH THE ETERNAL, THE G-D OF ISRAEL. The reason for this expression<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote"><i>‘Elokei’ (the G-d of) Israel</i> — the Divine Name which denotes the attribute of justice.</i> is that since the worshippers of the calf had intended to sacrifice to the G-d of Israel, therefore the attribute of justice extracted punishment from them, because they “mutilated the shoots” [of faith],<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">See Note 308 above.</i> and besides, <i>for the judgment is G-d’s</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 1:17.</i> It is for this reason that he [Moses], said of the Levites, <i>for the G-d of Israel hath separated you from the congregation of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:9.</i> for the Service is to the G-d of Israel, and to His Name they were separated by virtue of this meritorious deed.
PUT YE EVERY MAN HIS SWORD UPON HIS THIGH. Since there were many worshippers of the calf, and they could not have all been brought to the court, therefore Moses commanded all the sons of Levi to put on their swords, in a similar way to that which our Rabbis have said,<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote">Sanhedrin 45b.</i> that if you cannot administer to the guilty the specific kind of death mentioned for his case, you may execute him by any means that you can. Now this procedure was a decision only for an emergency, in order to sanctify G-d’s Name, since those who worshipped [the calf] had not been forewarned [of the death penalty], for who had warned them beforehand? The sons of Levi, however, recognized those whom they killed as the worshippers of the calf. And in the opinion of the Sage who says<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 66b. The Gemara there brings this opinion in the name of one of two Amoraim, Rav and Levi. Hence Ramban writes anonymously: “in the opinion of the Sage who says…”</i> that if there were witnesses [to the act of idolatry] and forewarning of the penalty, the offender’s death was by hand of man, as Rashi wrote,<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20 here.</i> then we shall interpret the meaning of the verse to be that Moses commanded the sons of Levi to put on their swords and take hold of the offenders by force and bring them to court before Moses or before the Sanhedrin. Those who were found to have worshipped the calf in the presence of witnesses and with forewarning, were then put to death by stoning, as is the punishment of those who worship idols, or perhaps their death was by the sword, as is the punishment of a whole city gone astray.<sup class="footnote-marker">390</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:13-16.</i> Thus all the sons of Levi remained loyal to G-d, and it was they who had warned the people not to worship the calf or sacrifice to it, seeing that Aaron had only commanded to hold a feast to the Eternal alone, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">391</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 5.</i><br>The correct interpretation<sup class="footnote-marker">392</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban now goes back to his original thesis, that this whole procedure was a decision under emergency.</i> is in accordance with the opinion of the Sage who says:<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 66b. The Gemara there brings this opinion in the name of one of two Amoraim, Rav and Levi. Hence Ramban writes anonymously: “in the opinion of the Sage who says…”</i> “Those who slaughtered or burnt the sacrificial portions [to the calf] were punished by the sword;<sup class="footnote-marker">393</sup><i class="footnote">Even though such an offense makes the offender liable to stoning according to Torah-law, but since the law of the four kinds of death had not been declared yet, the offenders were treated under the law of “the sons of Noah” to whom its form of punishment is applicable (Rashi Yoma 66 b).</i> those who embraced and kissed it, were punished with death [by the hand of Heaven]; those who merely rejoiced in their heart, were afflicted with dropsy,” as is stated in Tractate Yoma.<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 66b. The Gemara there brings this opinion in the name of one of two Amoraim, Rav and Levi. Hence Ramban writes anonymously: “in the opinion of the Sage who says…”</i> Thus it was all a decision under circumstances of emergency, because embracing or kissing an idol does not make one liable to death [by the hand of Heaven] in all future generations.
AND SLAY EVERY MAN HIS BROTHER. This means that they were not to spare nor conceal<sup class="footnote-marker">394</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 13:9.</i> brother, friend, or relative. And the meaning of the expression, <i>Thus saith the Eternal, the G-d of Israel:</i> [<i>Put ye every man his sword…</i>] is not [as Rashi has it, a command] based upon the verse, <i>He that sacrificeth unto the gods shall be utterly destroyed</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">395</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:19.</i> since these worshippers of the calf were not strictly liable to death [as has been explained above], but it was a command said to Moses by the Almighty which was not written in the Torah; for when <i>the Glorious Name</i><sup class="footnote-marker">396</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 28:58.</i> <i>repented of the evil</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">397</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 14.</i> He commanded Moses, “Since you do not want Me to destroy them, you should slay its worshippers by the sword,” similar to that which is said, <i>Take all of the chiefs of the people, and hang them up unto the Eternal in face of the sun, that the fierce anger of the Eternal may turn away from Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">398</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 25:4.</i> This commandment is thus similar to the one in connection with the manna, where it is said, <i>This is the thing which the Eternal hath commanded: Let an omerful of it be kept</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">399</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:32. There too the original command given to Moses is not written in the Torah.</i> I have already mentioned<sup class="footnote-marker">400</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:2, and 11:1.</i> similar instances.

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32

YET NOW, IF THOU WILT FORGIVE THEIR SIN. Rashi comments: “If You forgive their sins — well and good, and I do not say to you ‘Blot me out.’ <i>But if not, blot me out</i>. This is thus an abbreviated verse. There are many cases similar to it. <i>Out of Thy book</i> — this means out of the whole Torah; so that people should not say about me that I was not worthy [successful] to seek mercy for them.” But if so, what was the answer that the Holy One, blessed be He, gave to Moses — <i>Whosoever hath sinned against Me, him will I blot out of My book</i><sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33.</i> — since there was no one else to be blotted out of His book [i.e. the Torah, since they are not mentioned therein to begin with]? Perhaps [Rashi] will interpret it thus: “I shall only blot out [from My Torah] those who have sinned against Me, and you have not sinned against Me.” But this is not correct.<br>Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote that the expression <i>out of Thy book which Thou hast written</i> is like, <i>The judgment was set, and the books were opened</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">402</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 7:10.</i> “the books” in Ibn Ezra’s opinion being the dispositions of the heavenly bodies upon which the fate of the lower creatures depends. And G-d answered, <i>Whosoever had sinned against Me, him will I blot out from My book</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">401</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33.</i> which means: “I will not blot you out, but I will blot out from among the people those sinners who have sinned against Me in their thoughts, and were not killed by the sons of Levi.” It is with reference to this that it is said, <i>And the Eternal smote the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">403</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> — This interpretation [of Ibn Ezra] does not appear to me to be correct, for besides those killed by the sword of the sons of Levi and those who died in the plague, most of the people had sinned against Him, as I have written.<sup class="footnote-marker">404</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 7.</i><br>In my opinion [the interpretation of the verse is as follows]: Moses said, “<i>Yet now, if Thou wilt forgive their sin</i> in Thine mercies [— well and good]; <i>but if not, blot me out</i> in their place <i>from the book</i> of life, and I will share their punishment,” it being similar to what Scripture says, <i>But he was wounded because of our transgressions, he was crushed because of our iniquities; the chastisement of our welfare was upon him, and with his stripes we were healed</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">405</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 53:5.</i> And the Holy One, blessed be He, answered Moses: “I will erase from My book [of life] whosoever sinned, but not you, for you have not sinned.”

Verse 33



Verse 34

AND NOW GO, LEAD THE PEOPLE. [G-d is saying here:] “Since I have repented from destroying them, lead them <i>unto the place of which I have spoken unto thee</i> — to the place of the Amorite, the Canaanite, etc.” However, He did not want to mention this expressly, for this was said in a manner of anger, as if to say: “What I have said to you, I shall do in your honor, but I will not forgive them their sin, for <i>in the day when I visit, I will visit their sin upon them</i> — I will visit it upon them even after they come to the Land.” This was an allusion to the time of the exile, or to what our Rabbis have said<sup class="footnote-marker">406</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 43:3.</i> that “No punishment [ever comes upon Israel] in which there is not a small part for the sin of the golden calf.”

Verse 35

AND THE ETERNAL SMOTE THE PEOPLE. Scripture does not state how many died in this plague, as it stated the number of those that fell by the hand of the sons of Levi,<sup class="footnote-marker">407</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 28: <i>and there fell of the people that day about three thousand men</i>.</i> and as it mentioned in the case of the plague <i>about the matter of Korah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">408</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 17:14: <i>Now they that died by the plague were fourteen thousand and seven hundred</i>.</i> and in connection with the Baal of Peor,<sup class="footnote-marker">409</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 25:9: <i>And those that died by the plague were twenty and four thousand</i>.</i> the reason perhaps being that those here did not all die in one plague, but they were smitten and died prematurely, something like it said, <i>but the Eternal shall smite him, or his day shall come to die</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">410</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 26:10.</i> Perhaps Scripture did not bother to number them, for similarly it did not number those that died in the plague at Taberah,<sup class="footnote-marker">411</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 11:3.</i> and at Kibroth-hattaavah, where it says, <i>and the Eternal smote the people with a very great plague</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">412</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 33.</i> Those that fell, however, through the sons of Levi He counted in their honor, thus saying that they slew many of the people but yet they did not fear them, for they trusted in the Eternal.
BECAUSE THEY MADE THE CALF. This means that they were not amongst those who worshipped it or sacrificed to it,<sup class="footnote-marker">413</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 8.</i> but they were the men who “made” it, that is to say, they were the ones who gathered around Aaron and brought him the gold. Now since Scripture states that they were punished <i>for making the calf</i>, not for worshipping it, and in reality they did not make it, it explains further, <i>which Aaron made</i>, meaning that Aaron made it at their command.<br>But Onkelos translated [the expression, <i>because they ‘made’ the calf</i>], “because they ‘worshipped’ the calf which Aaron made.” By this Onkelos intended to explain that the ones who died in the plague were those who embraced and kissed it, and were pleased with the calf. Now [although the same term <i>asah</i> (“did”) is mentioned in both cases, <i>because they ‘made’ the calf, which Aaron ‘made’</i>], Onkelos did not feel obliged to translate both alike [but instead he translated: “because they ‘worshipped’ the calf, which Aaron ‘made’ “]. A similar case [of Onkelos’ rendition] is the verse, <i>and whatsoever they ‘did’ there, he was the ‘doer’ of it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">414</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 39:22.</i> which he translated: “and whatsoever they did there ‘was done’ by his command.”<sup class="footnote-marker">415</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Onkelos translated the same form of the verb once in the active tense and once in the passive.</i><br>This plague occurred after Moses had punished the worshippers and prayed for Israel, saying, <i>and if not, blot me, I pray Thee, out of Thy book</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">416</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> For because Moses had shown his readiness to give his life for them, the Holy One, blessed be He, had mercy upon them, and told him to bring them up to the Land, and that He would send an angel before them;<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:2.</i> but since He wanted to take away from them part of the great sin, in order that they should be worthy [to go up to the Land], He sent upon them this plague. Or it may be that He had decreed this plague upon them [before Moses’ prayer] and the plague had already begun, and after that He said again to Moses, <i>Go up hence, thou and the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 1.</i> meaning, that the plague will not blot out their sin from before Me so that I should again dwell in their midst.
