He mentioned though, <i>unto the land of which I swore unto Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 1.</i> and further said, <i>and I will drive out the Canaanite</i>, etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">417</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:2.</i> for on account of the plague which He brought or decreed upon them, part of their sin was blotted out, and He was partially appeased to them, in remembering the merit of the patriarchs, and [promising] that He would fulfill to them the oath He had taken to bring them <i>unto a good land, a land flowing with milk and honey</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">419</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:8.</i> Thus He hinted to Moses that the earth [i.e., the land of Canaan] would not become corrupt<sup class="footnote-marker">420</sup><i class="footnote">See Genesis 6:11.</i> nor would it be <i>defiled under the inhabitants thereof</i><sup class="footnote-marker">421</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 24:5.</i> on account of their sin, and that He would drive out all the six nations whose land they were originally promised.<sup class="footnote-marker">422</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 3:8.</i> And He also said by way of pacification, <i>for I will not go up in the midst of thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:3.</i> this being to your benefit, <i>lest I consume thee in the way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">423</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 33:3.</i> because of your stiff-neckedness.<br>Thus there were here two punishments for Israel: firstly, that He would not cause His Divine Glory to dwell amongst them, and secondly, that He would send an angel before Moses until the nations would be driven out; but He did not promise them after they would inherit the Land even an angel to help them, for this is why He mentioned <i>in the way</i> [<i>lest I consume thee ‘in the way’</i>]. It is with reference to all this that Scripture says, <i>And when the people heard these evil tidings, they mourned; and no man put on him his ornaments</i><sup class="footnote-marker">424</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> — just as mourners. But G-d is merciful, abounding in compassion, and when He saw that they mourned, He said again by way of mercy, <i>Say unto the children of Israel</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> for up till now He had used the terms, <i>thy people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">426</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:7.</i> and <i>the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">418</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 1.</i> but now He mentioned them by their beloved name, and He commanded Moses to tell them that it was to their benefit that He would not go up in their midst, in order that He should not consume them in one moment. However, they have done well in repenting and mourning for their sin. So should they always do, <i>and I will know what to do unto</i> them.<sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> That is to say, I will visit their sin in accordance with My knowledge of their mourning and repenting their sin, since it is I Who tries the heart and searches the kidneys.<sup class="footnote-marker">427</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 17:10.</i><br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic teachings of the Cabala], the expression, <i>that I may know what to do unto thee</i><sup class="footnote-marker">425</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> means that He will do unto them in the knowledge of mercy, similar to what is said, <i>and if not, I will know</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">428</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 18:21.</i> as I have already explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">429</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20. Vol. I, p. 245.</i>

Chapter 33



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3



Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL STRIPPED THEMSELVES OF THEIR ORNAMENTS. The meaning of this is that when they heard this declaration, they stripped and divested themselves of all their ornaments, even more so than they had done before. Now Onkelos who translated the word <i>edi</i> (ornament) as “the equipment of armor,” was in agreement with the opinion of the Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">430</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai.</i> in Bereshith Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">431</sup><i class="footnote">I have not found it in Bereshith Rabbah, but in Shemoth Rabbah 45:1.</i> who said “He tied them with belts.” That is to say, at the time of the Giving of the Torah the Holy One, blessed be He, girded them with weapons of armor to save them from all mishaps and the angel of death, just as the Rabbis have interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">432</sup><i class="footnote">Erubin 54a.</i> “<i>‘charuth’ (graven) upon the Tablets</i><sup class="footnote-marker">433</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:16.</i> — <i>‘cheiruth’</i> (freedom) from the angel of death” [was given to the Israelites together with the Tablets of the Law], these [weapons of armor] being the Names of the Holy One, blessed be He.<sup class="footnote-marker">434</sup><i class="footnote">And as long as they were in possession of that knowledge they were above the power of the angel of death. Now, however, that they were divested of this knowledge they became subject to the decree of death as all human beings are (Bachya, Vol. II, p. 340, in my edition).</i> Thus Israel now accepted upon themselves death from their own free will as a form of punishment for the incident of the calf. This was indeed an expression of great repentance and regret for their sin.

Verse 7

NOW MOSES TOOK THE TENT AND WOULD PITCH IT WITHOUT THE CAMP. Rashi wrote: “This was practiced by Moses from the Day of Atonement until the Tabernacle was set up [five and a half months later — on the first day of Nisan], but not afterwards. For on the seventeenth day of Tammuz the Tablets of the Law were broken, on the eighteenth he burnt the calf and brought the sinners to judgment, and on the nineteenth he ascended the mountain and stayed there for forty days. On the first of Ellul it was said to him, <i>and come up in the morning</i><sup class="footnote-marker">435</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:2.</i> to receive the second Tablets. There he spent another forty days [which terminated on the tenth day of Tishri]. On the tenth of Tishri the Holy One, blessed be He, became reconciled with Israel, and He handed over to Moses the second Tablets, whereupon Moses came down the mountain and began to command them concerning the work of the Tabernacle. This occupied them till the first of Nisan, and from that time on, since the Tabernacle was set up, G-d only communicated with him from there.” This also is the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, that all this [narrated here in Verses 7-11] took place after Moses brought down the second Tablets [the account of which is narrated further on in 34:1-10], there being no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah.<br>But it does not appear to me to be correct, for what reason is there to mention this [practice of Moses] here in the middle of the section? The words of our Rabbis in all Midrashim are also to the effect that Moses did this on account of their sin with the calf. Thus they explained<sup class="footnote-marker">436</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 45:3.</i> [that Moses said], “One who is excommunicated from the master, is also excommunicated from the disciple,” and as Rashi mentioned [that G-d said to Moses], “I am angry and you are angry; if so, who will bring them near to Me?” Now if the removal of the Tent was after the Day of Atonement [as Rashi and Ibn Ezra have it], the Holy One, blessed be He, as well as Moses, was already in [complete] reconciliation with them! Rather, it appears that on the day that he came down from the mountain — on the seventeenth of Tamuz — he burnt the calf and punished the worshippers.<sup class="footnote-marker">437</sup><i class="footnote">And not, as Rashi has it, that the burning of the calf and the punishing of the sinners took place on the eighteenth of Tammuz.</i> On the next day, [i.e., on the eighteenth of Tammuz] he told them that he would go up to G-d to seek atonement for them,<sup class="footnote-marker">438</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:30.</i> and so he went up to the mountain where the Glory was. This is the sense of the verse, <i>And Moses returned unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> and prayed briefly: <i>Oh, this people have sinned a great sin</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">439</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> and G-d answered him, <i>Whosoever hath sinned against Me</i>, etc.;<sup class="footnote-marker">440</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 33.</i> <i>And now go, lead the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">441</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> and the plague began.<sup class="footnote-marker">442</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 35.</i> Then He commanded him, <i>Depart, go up hence, thou and the people</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">443</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1 here.</i> and Moses told this to Israel, <i>and they mourned, and stripped themselves of the ornaments</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">444</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 4-6.</i> Then Moses realized that the matter was a very long one, and did not know what the end thereof would be, therefore he took the tent and pitched it outside the camp so that the Divine Glory would communicate with him from there, for it was no longer dwelling in the midst of the people, and if the tent were to be in the midst of the camp, He would not communicate with him from there. Scripture continues, <i>and it came to pass, that every one that sought the Eternal…</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">445</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 7 here.</i> meaning that everyone who sought the Eternal used to go out to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">446</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban interprets the Hebrew <i>yeitzei</i> (the imperfect — “was going out”) as <i>yotzei</i> (a participle — taking of the nature of both a verb and an adjective — “used to go out”). Rashi explained it likewise.</i> Then Scripture [in Verse 8-11] completed the narrative of all that happened whilst the tent was there until the Tabernacle was set up, which was, according to the opinion of our Sages, from the Day of Atonement until the first day of Nisan.<sup class="footnote-marker">447</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban further, 40:2.</i><br>I have seen in Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer [the following text]:<sup class="footnote-marker">448</sup><i class="footnote">Chapters of Rabbi Eliezer, Chapter 46.</i> “Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha says: “[After the Revelation] Moses spent forty days on the mountain, studying the Written Law at daytime, and the Oral Law at night. After the forty days he took the Tablets and came back to the camp. On the seventeenth of Tammuz he broke the Tablets and killed the sinners of Israel, and then stayed in the camp forty days until he burnt the calf and ground it like dust of the earth. Thus he eliminated idolatry from Israel, and established each tribe in its place. On the first of Ellul the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, <i>come up unto Me into the mount</i><sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:1.</i> [to be given the second Tablets]. Then the ram’s horn was sounded throughout the camp, announcing to the people that Moses was going up the mountain, so that [they might not be alarmed by his absence] and not be misled anymore after idols. [On that day] the Holy One, blessed be He, was exalted by the sound of that ram’s horn, as it is said, <i>G-d is gone up amidst shouting, the Eternal amidst the sound of the horn</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">450</sup><i class="footnote">Psalm 47:6. “For by the sound of this horn Israel vowed eternally never again to be deceived by the idols” (R’dal; see my Hebrew commentary, p. 518).</i> And thus likewise the Sages ordained that we blow the horn every year on the first day of Ellul.”<sup class="footnote-marker">451</sup><i class="footnote">The Shofar is now sounded in the synagogue every morning during the whole month of Ellul, except on the Sabbaths and on the day before the New Year.</i> Thus far are the words of this Agadah. And if this is so, then the whole section from: <i>Moses took the tent</i>, applied to the time from the eighteenth of Tammuz till the end of the forty days [i.e., up to the first of Ellul], and from the Day of Atonement till the first of Nisan [when the Tabernacle was set up]. But this exposition does not fit in well with what Scripture says, <i>And I fell down before the Eternal, as at the first, forty days and forty nights; I did neither eat bread</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">452</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:18.</i> and it is further written there, <i>So I fell down before the Eternal the forty days and forty nights that I fell down; because the Eternal had said He would destroy you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">453</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> and it is impossible that all this refers to the last forty days [i.e., between the first of Ellul and the Day of Atonement], since He told him, <i>Hew thee two Tablets of stone… and come up unto Me into the mount</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">449</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:1.</i> thus these last forty days were already those of G-d’s good-will, after He had already nullified the decree that <i>He would destroy you!</i><sup class="footnote-marker">454</sup><i class="footnote">From all this it is thus obvious that there was an intervening period of forty days [i.e. from the eighteenth of Tammuz to the twenty-ninth of Ab] when Moses was on the mountain interceeding for Israel. So how could the Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer hold that there were only two ascents of forty-day periods of Moses? — In his commentary to that Midrash, Rabbi David Luria answers Ramban’s question by suggesting that the phrase <i>He would destroy you</i> does not refer to the beginning of that verse, <i>so I fell down before the Eternal</i>, but reverts to the very beginning of the incident of the calf, when G-d had said He would destroy them. The verse itself can still apply then to the final forty days, which culminated on the Day of Atonement.</i>

Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10



Verse 11

AND HIS MINISTER JOSHUA, ‘BIN’ (THE SON OF) NUN, ‘NA’AR’ (A LAD). Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra wrote: “Joshua lived a hundred and ten years,<sup class="footnote-marker">455</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 24:29.</i> and the Sages say<sup class="footnote-marker">456</sup><i class="footnote">Arakhin 13a.</i> that it took him seven years to conquer the Land [of Israel] and seven years to apportion it amongst the tribes. If so, he was now fifty-six years old,<sup class="footnote-marker">457</sup><i class="footnote">The forty years of the wilderness plus the fourteen years in the Land of Israel, make a total of fifty-four years. Subtract these from a hundred and ten, and you are left with fifty-six. Yet Scripture calls him <i>na’ar</i> (lad)!</i> and how does Scripture call him <i>na’ar</i> (lad)? We must therefore say that this is the meaning thereof: <i>and his minister Joshua the son of Nun</i> rendered him such service as can be given only by a youthful attendant.”<br>In my opinion it is the way of the Sacred Language to call any attendant [regardless of age] <i>na’ar</i>, for the person of high office is called <i>ish</i> (man),<sup class="footnote-marker">458</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban Genesis 9:20, Vol. I, p. 141.</i> and [with respect to him] his attendant is called <i>na’ar</i>. Thus: <i>Gehazi ‘na’aro’ (his attendant);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">459</sup><i class="footnote">II Kings 4:12.</i> <i>Let ‘ha’ne’arim’ (the attendants), I pray thee, arise and play before us</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">460</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 2:14.</i> Similarly, <i>and ten ‘ne’arim’ (attendants) that bore Joab’s armor</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">461</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 18:15.</i> and Joab [David’s commander-in-chief] would surely only turn over his armor to valiant men who stood near him! And it is also written, <i>And Joshua said unto the two ‘men’ that had spied out the land</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">462</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 6:22.</i> and yet it is written there, <i>and ‘ha’ne’arim’ the spies went in</i> etc!<sup class="footnote-marker">463</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> [Thus we must say that the] term [<i>ha’ne’arim</i>] is used because they were servants of the congregation, acting for them as spies. There are many similar instances. So also, <i>the ‘na’arei’ of the king that ministered unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">464</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 2:2.</i> [the second half of the phrase being in apposition,] explaining that they were the servants who attended the king personally, and not the attendants of the court. And if so, our verse is stating: <i>and his minister Joshua the son of Nun</i> was always in attendance, and never departed out of the tent.
The reason for the form <i>‘bin’ Nun</i> [instead of <i>‘ben’ Nun</i>] is that the vowel <i>chirik</i> comes sometimes in place of the <i>segal</i> [which would have made it “ben Nun”]. Similar cases are: <i>The words of Agur ‘bin’ (the son of) Jakeh;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">465</sup><i class="footnote">Proverbs 30:1. Normally it should have been <i>ben</i>.</i> <i>‘she’bin lailah hayah’ (which came up in a night) ‘u’bin lailah avad’ (and perished in a night);</i><sup class="footnote-marker">466</sup><i class="footnote">Jonah 4:10. Here too the words should have been: <i>she’ben, u’ben</i>.</i> <i>‘im bin hakoth harasha’ (if the wicked man deserve to be beaten)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">467</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:2. Here likewise the sense of the verse is: “<i>ben hakoth</i> — a person deserving to be beaten, because he hit his friend.” So clearly explained in Ibn Ezra <i>ibid.</i></i><br>Yet despite all this I wonder! Why [of all the times that Joshua the son of Nun is cited in the Scriptures] is the name of this righteous man not once mentioned properly [i.e., <i>‘ben’</i> Nun]? Therefore I think that they used to call him in this way as a mark of honor, since he was the greatest of the disciples of Moses our teacher, and so they called him <i>binun</i>, meaning “the understanding one,” since there was <i>none so discreet and wise</i> as he.<sup class="footnote-marker">468</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 41:39.</i> Or it may be that the meaning of it is: “Joshua, whom understanding begot;” they thus used the term <i>nun</i> as in the expression, <i>may his name ‘yinon’ (be continued) as long as the sun</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">469</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 72:17.</i>

Verse 12

AND MOSES SAID UNTO THE ETERNAL: ‘SEE, THOU SAYEST UNTO ME: BRING UP THIS PEOPLE.’ This happened on Mount Sinai, when Moses went up there on the nineteenth of Tammuz. It was not necessary though for Scripture to say, “and Moses went up to G-d, and he said to him, ‘See, Thou sayest unto me, etc.,’” for it is known that as long as the Glory dwelled upon Mount Sinai, all communications [to Moses] took place there. Similarly Moses said, <i>and now I will go up unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">470</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:30.</i> and it is also said, <i>And Moses returned unto the Eternal</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">471</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31.</i> meaning that he returned <i>to the place where he had stood before the Eternal</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">472</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 19:27.</i>
AND THOU HAST NOT LET ME KNOW WHOM THOU WILT SEND WITH ME. “And that which You said to me, <i>Behold, I send an angel before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:20.</i> — that is not ‘letting me know,’ for I am not satisfied with it.” This is Rashi’s language. But it is not correct to fit this thought into the language of the verse. Besides, why should Moses have said this only now [that he was not satisfied with the angel], and when the matter was communicated to him he remained quiet? Did Moses think to gain because of the incident of the calf? Instead, the purport thereof is as follows: The Holy One, blessed be He, had told Moses here, <i>and I will send an angel before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">474</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2 (in this chapter).</i> and Moses told Him, <i>Thou has not let me know</i> who is that angel <i>whom Thou wilt send with me</i>, and whether it is that first angel in whom is Thy Name.<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:21.</i> This is the sense of the expression, <i>Yet Thou hast said: I know thee by Name</i>, meaning that You have known me and exalted me by [the knowledge of] Your Name. And so also did Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explain the verse here. In his opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">476</sup><i class="footnote">So explained by Ibn Ezra above 23:20 (towards the end).</i> the angel he [i.e., Moses] wanted was Michael. With his good sense [Ibn Ezra] understood the verses to imply that the first angel was pleasing to Moses and to Israel. He could not, however, know the truth, since he neither heard it [from others] nor did he prophesy it [on his own].<sup class="footnote-marker">477</sup><i class="footnote">This is a veiled criticism of Ibn Ezra who neither received the mystic traditions of the Cabala from others, nor studied them by himself. As Ramban will explain in the following verse, this whole subject can be understood only through “the way of Truth.”</i>

Verse 13



Verse 14

PANAI’ (MY PRESENCE) SHALL GO. In the opinion of all commentators this means, “I myself will go.” And they brought a parallel expression to this from the verse, <i>‘upanecha’ (and thine own person) shalt go to battle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">478</sup><i class="footnote">II Samuel 17:11.</i> 

Verse 15

AND HE [Moses] SAID UNTO HIM: IF ‘PANECHA’ (THY PRESENCE) GO NOT WITH ME, CARRY US NOT UP HENCE. The meaning thereof according to Rashi is as follows: “This is what I desired, for if it be by an angel, rather do not carry us up from here.” But G-d forbid! that Moses should say, <i>If Thy presence go not</i>, after he had already been promised, <i>My presence shall go!</i><br>And Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra explained that G-d said to Moses: “I Myself will go, and only you will I give rest, for only with you will I go [but I will not dwell in the midst of the people].” But Moses replied: “If Your presence does not go with the whole nation, <i>carry us not up hence</i>.” This is why Moses used the plural, “carry us up.” But this interpretation too, does not fit the verses properly. For Moses said at first, <i>Thou hast not let me know whom Thou wilt send with me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">479</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> — in the singular. Now even at the time of G-d’s good-will, before the sin [with the golden calf occurred], He also said, <i>Behold, I send an angel before thee, to keep thee by the way, and to bring thee into the place which I have prepared</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">473</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:20.</i> [and yet this promise too is expressed in the singular — to Moses]! And if you will say that the singular there [<i>before ‘thee’, to keep ‘thee’</i> etc.] refers to Israel [as one unit], then here also it could be explained to refer to all Israel! Besides, if it is so [as Ibn Ezra interpreted], that Moses requested of G-d that He inform him who is the angel He would send with him, then we see that Moses was satisfied with the angel, concerning whom it is said, <i>for My Name is in him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:21.</i> and G-d answered him with a double, and redoubled, beneficence, over and above that which he had asked for — that He Himself would go!<br>But this section of Scripture cannot possibly be grasped by one who has not heard the secrets of the Torah. The following is its meaning by way of the Truth. Moses said, and <i>Thou hast not let me know</i> who is the angel <i>Thou wilt send with me</i>, and he requested that He fulfill two things He had said to him: firstly, that <i>I know thee by Name</i>, meaning [G-d said to Moses] that “I will be known to you by My [Great] Name, for your sake” [and this was now Moses’ request, that he be not divested of this highest degree of prophecy on account of the incident of the calf]. It is possible that the phrase, <i>yet Thou hast said</i>, [<i>I know thee by Name</i>], is based upon what He had said to Moses [with reference to the patriarchs], <i>but by My Name the Eternal I made Me not known to them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">480</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:3. But to Moses He did reveal Himself by His Great Name, as explained there.</i> as I have explained [there]. And secondly Moses had been told: <i>and thou hast also found grace in My sight</i>, meaning that he will find grace, which is the cleaving of knowledge.<sup class="footnote-marker">481</sup><i class="footnote">That G-d always be with them in the wilderness <i>face to face</i> (Abusaula).</i> And Moses continued, <i>Now therefore, I pray Thee, if I have found grace in Thy sight</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">482</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> in the attribute of justice, <i>show me now</i> the paths of the ways<sup class="footnote-marker">483</sup><i class="footnote">“The paths of goodness with which You conduct Your world, and by which You are known” (Bachya).</i> even as Thou art known by Thy Name, <i>that I may know Thee</i> to declare Thy Unity, <i>to the end that I may find</i> the great <i>grace; and consider that this nation is Thy people</i> — Thou art their Father, and they are Thy children. It is this that Onkelos intended in translating the verse thus: “make me then know the path of Thy goodness to the end that I may know Thy mercy.” Then the Holy One, blessed be He, answered him, <i>My presence shall go — the messenger of the covenant, whom ye delight in</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">484</sup><i class="footnote">Malachi 3:1.</i> for in him My presence will be seen, since it is with reference to him that it is said, <i>in an acceptable time have I answered thee;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">485</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 49:8.</i> <i>for My Name is in him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">475</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:21.</i> <i>‘Vahanichothi lach’ (and I will give thee rest)</i> through him, that he should not conduct himself towards you with the stringent attribute of justice but with the measure which is inclusive of the attribute of mercy, the usage [of the word <i>vahanichothi</i>] being associated with the expression, <i>Therefore it shall be ‘b’haniyach’ (when) the Eternal thy G-d (hath given thee rest) from all thine enemies</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">486</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 25:19.</i> This is similar to that which is said, <i>Thus shall Mine anger spend itself, ‘vahanichothi’ (and I will satisfy) My fury upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">487</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 5:13.</i> Then Moses answered, <i>If Thy presence</i> — Thou Thyself and in Thy Glory — <i>go not, carry us not up hence</i>, for Thou art to be with us <i>face to face</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">488</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:4.</i> for such were the conditions [as mentioned] in the section of <i>Va’eira</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">489</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 6:6-8.</i> Likewise Moses mentioned above, <i>with great power and with a mighty hand</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">490</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 32:11.</i> and so now too he asked that He bring them to the Land <i>with great power and with a mighty hand</i>, just as He took them out with them from Egypt.

Verse 16

V’NIPHLINU’ (SO THAT WE BE DISTINGUISHED) I AND THY PEOPLE. This means that our portion be that which is unique, something which is not to be found amongst <i>all the people that are upon the face of the earth</i>.

Verse 17

I WILL DO THIS THING ALSO THAT THOU HAST SPOKEN. Perhaps this manifestation of G-d’s good-will was at the end of the second [period of] forty days, in accordance with the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">491</sup><i class="footnote">See above in Verse 7 where Ramban quotes the Pirkei d’Rabbi Eliezer, that Moses went up to the mountain for forty days only twice, the second time culminating on the Day of Atonement. This is Ramban’s intent in writing here “at the end of the <i>second</i> forty days according to the opinion of our Rabbis.” Rashi, quoted there, holds that there were three such periods.</i> when the Holy One, blessed be He, became completely appeased with him, and He said to him, <i>Hew thee two Tablets of stone like unto the first</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">492</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 34:1.</i>

Verse 18

AND HE [Moses] SAID: ‘SHOW ME, I PRAY THEE, THY GLORY.’ Moses desired that he should actually see in clear sight the Glory of G-d. It is possible that <i>Thy Glory</i> here means the Great Glory — the clear vision.<sup class="footnote-marker">493</sup><i class="footnote">See Vol. I, p. 229.</i> And G-d answered him, <i>I will make</i> the measure of <i>all My goodness pass before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i> that you will comprehend and understand all My goodness more than all men, but the vision of the Presence that you have asked for, you will not be able to see.

Verse 19

AND I WILL PROCLAIM THE NAME OF THE ETERNAL BEFORE THEE. I will proclaim before you the Great Name, for you will not be able to see Him. AND I WILL BE GRACIOUS [through it] TO WHOM I WILL BE GRACIOUS, AND WILL SHOW MERCY [through it] TO WHOM I WILL SHOW MERCY. This means that by this proclamation you will know the attributes of graciousness and mercy, by which people are shown grace and mercy through My name and through My goodness. It is with reference to this [knowledge received by Moses] that G-d said of him, <i>he is trusted in all My house</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">495</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 12:7.</i> for a man’s goodness is in his house.

Verse 20

FOR MAN SHALL NOT SEE ME AND LIVE. This does not mean that man could see Him, but must immediately die; it means that before he could grasp the sight, his soul would depart from him, for even of the vision of the angels it is said, <i>by reason of the vision my pains are come upon me</i>, [<i>and I retained no strength</i>].<sup class="footnote-marker">496</sup><i class="footnote">Daniel 10:16.</i>

Verse 21

BEHOLD, THERE IS A PLACE BY ME — on this mountain, where My Glory resides. 
AND THOU SHALT STAND UPON THE ROCK — which was upon the mountain, as it is said, <i>Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">497</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 17:6.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

BUT MY FACE SHALL NOT BE SEEN — meaning the clear countenance, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">498</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 18.</i> It is possible that the word <i>achorai (My back — and thou shalt see ‘My back’)</i> is of similar usage as in the verse, <i>Thou hast hemmed me in behind and before</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">499</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 139:5.</i> in accordance with the opinion of our Rabbis.<sup class="footnote-marker">500</sup><i class="footnote">Based on this verse in Psalms the Rabbis have said (Berachoth 61 a) that Adam was originally created with two faces (see Vol. I, p. 76). Ramban’s application here of this saying of the Sages is Cabalistic.</i>

Chapter 34



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

AND NO MAN SHALL COME UP WITH THEE. None of the elders of Israel at all should go up with you, as they had done at the first Tablets of the Law.<sup class="footnote-marker">501</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:9.</i> 
NEITHER LET ANY MAN BE SEEN THROUGHOUT ALL THE MOUNT — even at the foot of the mountain, where Israel had stood at first [during the Revelation]. 
NEITHER LET THE FLOCKS NOR HERDS FEED BEFORE THAT MOUNT — in front of it. For at [the giving of] the first Tablets they had been warned only, <i>no hand shall touch it</i> [i.e., the mountain] … <i>whether it be beast or man</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">502</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 19:13.</i> and now they were still under that admonition, for the Glory was always on the mountain until the last Tablets of the Law were given. However, at the giving of these Tablets He was now more stringent than at the first Revelation [in requiring that none of the elders accompany Moses]. The reason for all this was that at the first Tablets the Revelation was for all Israel, whereas this one was only for Moses, because of his merit and his prayer, and the Glory revealed on the mountain for [the giving of] the last Tablets would be greater than that of the first ones.

Verse 4



Verse 5

AND HE STOOD WITH HIM THERE. That is, the Eternal stood — something like it is said, <i>And the Eternal came, and stood</i><sup class="footnote-marker">503</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 3:10.</i> — with Moses, meaning, that Moses entered into the cloud as he had done at first.<sup class="footnote-marker">504</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:18: <i>And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud</i>.</i>

Verse 6

AND THE ETERNAL PASSED BY BEFORE HIM. This means that He fulfilled His promise to Moses, <i>I will make all My goodness pass before thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">494</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 19.</i>
AND HE PROCLAIMED: ‘HASHEM HASHEM E-IL’ (THE ETERNAL, THE ETERNAL, G-D). These three words are sacred Names of G-d which the Sages call <i>midoth</i> (attributes), being that they constitute the attribute of the Lord of repentance, the attribute of His mercies and that of His goodness.<sup class="footnote-marker">505</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary, p. 522, for some elucidation of these Cabalistic terms. — It is noteworthy that Ramban here follows a long line of authorities who count <i>Eternal, Eternal</i> as separate attributes. See, however, Guide of the Perplexed, Vol. I, p. 193, Note 5, in Friedlander’s translation.</i> The Proper Name of G-d [i.e. the Tetragrammaton], however does not lend itself to any plural form.<sup class="footnote-marker">506</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban’s intent here is to stress the perfect Unity, regardless of the various attributes. This is why he stresses that the Proper Name of G-d [and as stated here: <i>Hashem, Hashem…</i>] does not lend itself to any plural form, in spite of the fact that the various attributes are here cited (Abusaula).</i> And the attributes which are perceived in human terms are ten: <i>merciful and gracious</i>, etc. Thus on one side they are all attributes, and on the other, there are the three which denote the Names of His essence, whereas the Ten are attributes. Now the attributes also represent Names of G-d, for <i>merciful and gracious, long-suffering</i> etc. are all with reference to the essence of G-d the Most High. Therefore it does not say “the G-d Who has mercy, grace, and is long-suffering,” for [that would have meant that these are His ways with the lower creatures; instead it says, <i>merciful and gracious, long-suffering</i>, indicating] that these actions emanate from G-d’s attributes, [which are His essence].<sup class="footnote-marker">507</sup><i class="footnote">Abusaula.</i>
<i>And abounding in goodness and truth; keeping mercy upon the thousandth generation</i> — these three denote the attribute of mercy, since He increases the goodness over His strength and might and the truth in His mercies. <i>And ‘notzeir’ (keeping) mercy unto the thousandth generation</i>, for <i>He hath remembered His mercy and His faithfulness toward the house of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">508</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 98:3.</i> Or it may be that the word <i>notzeir</i> means “sprouting,” of the root, <i>‘v’neitzer’ (and a twig) shall grow forth out of his roots</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">509</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 11:1.</i> And in His goodness He is <i>‘nosei’ (forgiving) iniquity and transgression and sin</i>. This is of the expression, <i>I have made, and I ‘esa’ (will bear)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">510</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 46:4.</i><br>The two phrases, <i>and that will by no means clear the guilty</i>, and <i>visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children</i>, are an explanation to the one of <i>forgiving iniquity</i> [mentioned before]. It is called an “attribute”<sup class="footnote-marker">511</sup><i class="footnote">Thus it is now clear that Ramban counts the thirteen attributes as follows: 1. The Eternal. 2. The Eternal. 3. G-d. 4. Merciful. 5. Gracious 6. Long-suffering. 7.-8. Abounding in goodness and truth. 9. Keeping mercy unto the thousandth generation. 10.-11.-12. Forgiving iniquity, transgression and sin. 13. That will by no means clear the guilty, visiting the iniquity etc. — See Tosafoth Rosh Hashanah 17 b that such is also the opinion of Rabbeinu Tam. Ibn Ezra likewise follows generally this interpretation.</i> because He clears the sinner by this visitation. And because this act of forgiving is not equal for iniquity, transgression and sin, but instead in each category has its own form of clearing the sinner, it is called in each case “one attribute.”<sup class="footnote-marker">512</sup><i class="footnote">“And the expressions, <i>and that will by no means clear the guilty; visiting the iniquity of the fathers</i> etc., also constitute an independent attribute, for the ‘clearing’ done in this form of forgiving is by visitation, it being another way of forgiveness of sin, that He will not forgive it outright, but visit it upon the generations etc.” (Abusaula).</i>
Now Moses bowed his head to G-d Who passed by before him, and prayed that G-d should always go in their midst and forgive their iniquity and their sin<sup class="footnote-marker">513</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> in whatever they might do, and that He cause them to inherit the Land. Moses, however, did not ask that G-d forgive “our transgressions,” since it is not possible that G-d forgive transgressions, which are sins of a rebellious nature; in those cases He is only to bear them [through visitation] and not to destroy them. It will not be concealed from you why these two Names [<i>If now I have found grace in Thy sight, O Lord, let the Lord, I pray Thee, go in the midst of us…</i><sup class="footnote-marker">513</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i>] are written with <i>Aleph Daleth</i> [instead of in the letters of the Tetragrammaton];<sup class="footnote-marker">514</sup><i class="footnote">As Moses now prayed for the perfect Unity to go in the midst of Israel. At such time it is as if all is in the <i>Aleph Daleth</i>. Thus the first Name is in place of the Tegragrammaton, and Moses prayed that the Lord [written in <i>Aleph Daleth</i>] go in our midst in the absolute perfection of the Unity of the two Names (Abusaula).</i> it is for this reason that G-d said, <i>Behold, I make a covenant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i> until [<i>all people shall see…</i>] <i>the work of the Eternal that it is tremendous</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">515</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 10.</i>

Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9

FOR IT IS A STIFFNECKED PEOPLE. This is to be understood in its literal sense. G-d is to go in their midst because they are a stiffnecked people, for now that the Holy One, blessed be He, became reconciled with them, His Presence amongst those who are stiffnecked would be better than that of the angel. For He will want to increase their blessings more, since they are His people and His inheritance.<sup class="footnote-marker">516</sup><i class="footnote">See Deuteronomy 9:29 and 32:9.</i> And just as at the time of anger it was better for them that He send before them an angel, because they are a stiffnecked people, just as He said, <i>lest I consume thee in the way</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">517</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 33:3.</i> so at the time of good-will it is better for them that the Divine Glory go with them, because they are a stiffnecked people, and He would more readily show grace and mercy upon His servants. And G-d answered him that He would do so, that He would make the covenant and do marvels because of it, just as Moses had asked for, <i>so that we are distinguished, I and Thy people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">518</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> He said, <i>before all thy people I will do marvels… and all the people amongst which thou art shall see</i>, because all these great and tremendous things He would do with Moses and for his sake, and the people would merely be in the covenant. It is not possible, however, to explain that G-d was promising that He would now do with Israel wonders <i>such as have not been wrought</i> before and <i>in all the earth, nor in any nation</i>, for [we do not find] that after this [statement] there were any wonders done for them, greater than those which had been wrought for them at the beginning in Egypt and at the sea; on the contrary, at first there were wrought and done for them greater things. Rather, the purport thereof hints at the dwelling of the Divine Glory amongst them, and at G-d being with Moses, <i>for splendor and for beauty</i><sup class="footnote-marker">519</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 28:2.</i> in hidden and wondrous matters, as he said, <i>‘v’niphlinu’ (so that we are distinguished)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">518</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 16.</i> [which is of the root <i>peleh</i> — wonder], and as I have explained. May the Holy One, blessed be He, show us wonders in His Torah.

Verse 10



Verse 11

OBSERVE THOU THAT WHICH I AM COMMANDING THEE THIS DAY. Of all the commandments mentioned previously He did not say <i>I am commanding thee</i>. Therefore we must explain the meaning of His words as follows: “Observe the commandments which I command you today, and do not treat them as you have treated those which I commanded you at first, when you violated everything by worshipping the idols.” Now He promised here to drive out from before them the peoples [of the Land], and He warned them against their idols and against making a covenant with them, just as He had done in the section of <i>Behold, I send an angel before thee</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">520</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 23:20.</i> thus going over the first conditions again. However, He added here, <i>Thou shalt make thee no molten gods</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">521</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> meaning that they should not do as they had done with the calf, even if their thoughts are directed to Heaven, to make themselves a guide. He restated here the subject of the three festivals,<sup class="footnote-marker">522</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> that they <i>appear before the Eternal G-d, the G-d of Israel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">522</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> as He had mentioned it there.<sup class="footnote-marker">523</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:17.</i> The reason [for the restatement] is known, since it comes after the admonition against idolatry. I have already explained it at the end of [<i>Seder</i>] <i>Vayishma Yithro</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">524</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 20:21.</i>

Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15

AND THOU EAT OF THEIR SACRIFICE. “You might think that there is no punishment for eating thereof, but I will account it to you as if you agreed to its idolatrous worship.” This is Rashi’s language.<sup class="footnote-marker">525</sup><i class="footnote">In our text of Rashi the text concludes: “Because through this [partaking of his meals] you will come to take of his daughters to your sons” (as mentioned in the following Verse 16). Rashi thus connects Verse 15 with the following verse, as if to say that the danger of partaking of his meals (mentioned in Verse 15) is that it will lead to the taking of his daughters to your sons (mentioned in Verse 16). Ramban will differ with this interpretation, and hold that Verse 15 constitutes an independent prohibition.</i> But I say in accordance with the opinion of our Rabbis that this constitutes an admonition against eating of the sacrifices to idols, which they said<sup class="footnote-marker">526</sup><i class="footnote">Abodah Zarah 29b.</i> is forbidden by law of the Torah, and we find no verse concerning it except this one. And the following is the meaning of the verse: “<i>Lest thou make a covenant with the inhabitants of the land, and they go astray after their gods</i>, for they will always be sacrificing to them, <i>and</i> lest <i>they call thee and thou eat of their sacrifice</i>, which he will sacrifice to his gods in his going astray after them, <i>and</i> lest <i>thou take of their daughters unto thy sons</i>.” Thus they are all admonitions following the first prohibition, concerning which He said, <i>lest thou make a covenant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">527</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 15 before us.</i>

Verse 16



Verse 17



Verse 18



Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

IN PLOWING TIME AND IN HARVEST THOU SHALT REST. In line with the plain meaning of Scripture He mentioned plowing and harvesting [as works forbidden on the Sabbath] because they are the mainstay of man’s life. He mentioned the Sabbath between the holidays, putting it next to the feast of unleavened bread and the sanctification of the firstborn,<sup class="footnote-marker">528</sup><i class="footnote">Verses 19-20.</i> because they are all a reminder of the act of Creation, for in the exodus from Egypt itself there is a sign and wonder referring to the Creation, as I have explained in the Ten Commandments.<sup class="footnote-marker">529</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:2.</i> Besides, Scripture states that in the Sabbath likewise there is a reminder of the exodus from Egypt, as it says in the second Ten Commandments, <i>And thou shalt remember that thou wast a servant in the land of Egypt, and the Eternal thy G-d brought thee out thence [by a mighty hand and by an outstretched arm]; therefore the Eternal thy G-d commanded thee to keep the Sabbath-day</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">530</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 5:15.</i> There I will explain it, with the help of G-d, blessed and exalted be He.

Verse 22



Verse 23



Verse 24



Verse 25

NEITHER SHALL THE SACRIFICE OF THE FEAST OF THE PASSOVER BE LEFT UNTO THE MORNING. In line with the plain meaning of Scripture this admonition applies to the whole [Passover-] offering, [the sacrificial portions burnt on the altar, and the flesh eaten by the Passover celebrants]: that one should not leave over of the flesh unto the morning, for that which remains of it until the morning shall be burnt with fire,<sup class="footnote-marker">531</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 12:10.</i> and also the fat of it should be burnt on the altar only until the morning. Onkelos, however, translated the verse as applying [only] to the fat which had to be taken up to be burnt on the altar,<sup class="footnote-marker">532</sup><i class="footnote">Thus Onkelos translated: “There shall not remain [overnight] away from the altar till the morning the fat of the sacrifice of the feast of the Passover.”</i> for this “feast” [mentioned there] is explained there, <i>neither shall the fat of My feast remain all night until the morning</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">533</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:18.</i> since all these commandments [mentioned here] are based upon those cited there.<br>Now Rashi wrote: “<i>Neither shall [the sacrifice of the feast of the Passover] be left unto the morning</i>. This is to be understood as the Targum renders it [namely, that it refers to the fat, as explained above]. An offering left overnight is not invalidated if it was placed on top of the altar [during the night, even though it was not burnt at night; and it may be burnt on the altar the following day], neither is it invalidated until the dawn of morning [i.e., if at that time it is not on top of the altar, it is deemed to have been ‘left-over’]. <i>The sacrifice of the feast of the Passover</i>. This refers to the sacrificial portions. From here you derive the law concerning the burning of all fats and limbs of sacrifices [which were burnt on the altar].” In the section of <i>Tzav</i><sup class="footnote-marker">534</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 6:2.</i> I will explain this with the help of G-d. And with regard to what Rashi wrote about an offering left overnight if it was placed on top of the altar [during the night it is not invalidated] — there is a difference of opinion on this matter in the Gemara,<sup class="footnote-marker">535</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 87a.</i> and in the opinion of Raba it does become invalidated even if on top of the altar; thus if limbs of a sacrifice were left there [on top of the altar] overnight, and then by accident they were taken down [from the altar to the pavement], they may no longer be taken up. On the other hand, if they were not taken down, then even those limbs that had been left over on the pavement of the Court for many days, and by accident were taken up, do not need to come down [and are burnt upon the altar], as is found in the Chapter “The Altar.”<sup class="footnote-marker">535</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 87a.</i>

Verse 26

THE CHOICEST FIRST-FRUITS OF THY LAND THOU SHALT BRING INTO THE HOUSE OF THE ETERNAL THY G-D. Because He mentioned that they should bring <i>the first-ripe fruits of all that is in their land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">536</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 18:13. — Ramban’s intention of course is to the verse here before us, but as a matter of style he uses similar language referring to that commandment found elsewhere in Scripture. This can be observed in countless instances.</i> to the house of G-d, He placed next to it, <i>Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk</i>. For at the time of bringing the first-fruits of the earth they would also take along all firstlings of cattle, goats and sheep, and at that season the goats have grown up and begin giving milk. Thus they would often bring up the mother with its firstborn whilst it was still a suckling, in order that it should not die. Now those who came to celebrate the festival would enjoy eating the firstlings amongst all tasty foods, together with the priests. That is why He mentioned the prohibition [against seething the kid in its mother’s milk] together with the precept of the first-fruits. In the Book of Deuteronomy, however, He mentioned this commandment together with the laws of prohibited foods,<sup class="footnote-marker">537</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 14:21.</i> after He cited the laws of unclean cattle, fish, and unclean fowl, and carrion, for that is the fitting place to mention it, since it is a prohibition concerning eating, and not merely a prohibition against seething it alone, as those wanting in faith and devoid of knowledge think.<sup class="footnote-marker">538</sup><i class="footnote">Reference is to the Karaites. See Ibn Ezra who writes in a vein similar to that of Ramban. — See also Vol. I, p. 22, where Ramban uses a similar reproof to those who scoff at the words of our Rabbis.</i>

Verse 27

WRITE THOU THESE WORDS. G-d commanded Moses that he write <i>a book of covenant</i> and read it <i>in the hearing of the people</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">539</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:7.</i> and they should accept it upon themselves by saying, <i>we will do and we will obey</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">539</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:7.</i> as they had done at first; for He wanted that the whole procedure with the first Tablets should now be repeated with the second Tablets. There is no doubt that Moses actually did repeat it; however, Scripture did not want to prolong the account by saying, “and Moses did so,” as I have shown you in many places.<sup class="footnote-marker">540</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:2, etc.</i><br>The correct interpretation appears to me to be, that since Israel had sinned and violated the [first] covenant, the Holy One, blessed be He, had to renew the covenant with them, so that He should not nullify His covenant with them, and so He told Moses to write the conditions [of the renewed covenant]. This is the sense of the verse, <i>for after the tenor of these words I have made a covenant with thee and with Israel</i>. The meaning of <i>with thee</i> is that for your sake I have done it with them, and it will not be necessary for them to bring themselves <i>into the bond of this covenant</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">541</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 20:37.</i> However, G-d, blessed be He, had to make with them a covenant on the forgiveness that He extended to them [for their sin with the calf], and so [Moses] wrote the forgiveness, and the conditions [of the new covenant].

Verse 28

AND HE WAS THERE WITH THE ETERNAL FORTY DAYS AND FORTY NIGHTS… AND HE WROTE UPON THE TABLETS THE WORDS OF THE COVENANT, THE TEN WORDS. The verse is stating that Moses was on top of the mountain for forty days and forty nights, and he wrote there upon the Tablets. And in the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">542</sup><i class="footnote">Shemoth Rabbah 47:12.</i> the meaning of the verse is that Moses was there with G-d for forty days and forty nights,<sup class="footnote-marker">543</sup><i class="footnote">From the first of Ellul to the tenth of Tishri, which is the Day of Atonement.</i> during which time He wrote on the Tablets the words of this second covenant. But he had stayed there for another forty days<sup class="footnote-marker">544</sup><i class="footnote">From the nineteenth of Tammuz to the twenty-ninth of Ab.</i> prior to these to pray for all his requests, as is narrated in the section beginning, <i>See, Thou sayest unto me: Bring up this people;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">545</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 33:12.</i> and with reference to these days it is said in the Book of Deuteronomy, <i>So I fell down before the Eternal the forty days and forty nights that I fell down; because the Eternal had said He would destroy you</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">546</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 9:25.</i> Here, however, Scripture did not explain how many days were the duration of this period of supplication and prayer, for it is known that it was from the time he went up to the mountain until he came down to hew the second Tablets.<sup class="footnote-marker">547</sup><i class="footnote">This was on the first day of Ellul (see Ramban above, 33:7). Having hewn the Tablets, he went up to the mountain and stayed until the tenth of Tishri. From this we learn that the forty-day period of prayer preceded it, which brings it to the days between the nineteenth of Tammuz and the twenty-ninth of Ab.</i> But it said that the matter of the second Tablets was like that of the first in every respect — the writing of G-d, and the number of days he stood before G-d, so that he should not think that he had already learned the Torah during the first time, and that therefore it would not be necessary for him to stay there many days.
<i>‘Va’yichtov’ upon the Tablets</i> — this means that G-d wrote, and does not refer back to Moses [mentioned in the preceding phrase, <i>he did neither eat bread, nor drink water</i>], for so He said, <i>and I will write upon the Tablets</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">548</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> Similarly, in the Book of Deuteronomy it says, <i>and I hewed two Tablets of stone like unto the first, and went up into the mount, having the two Tablets in my hand. And He wrote on the Tablets, according to the first writing</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">549</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 10:3-4.</i> And since it says <i>according to the first writing</i>, we know that they were written with the finger of G-d.<sup class="footnote-marker">550</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:18.</i> Thus the meaning of the expression, <i>and I will write</i><sup class="footnote-marker">548</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 1.</i> means “with the finger,” and you know [already] the meaning of “finger” from that of “the hand.”<sup class="footnote-marker">551</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 14:31. See Ramban there.</i>

Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31

VA’YEDABEIR MOSHEH’ (AND MOSES SPOKE) TO THEM. “This whole section denotes a [continuing] present action [thus making the sense of the verbs: ‘and Moses used to speak…’ ‘and they used to come near…’]. 32. AND AFTERWARDS ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL CAME NIGH. After Moses had taught the elders, he would again teach the section or the specific law to the Israelites.” All this is Rashi’s language. But it is not so [that this section describes a continuing occurrence — whenever Moses spoke to Israel]. Rather, Scripture is stating that when all Israel went forth to meet him [upon his descent from the mountain with the second Tablets], they saw the beams of glory streaming from his face, <i>and they were afraid to come nigh him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">552</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 30.</i> and stepped backwards. Perhaps they thought that the Glory of G-d was there, or that the angels of Him on high were with him, and they feared <i>lest the Eternal break forth upon them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">553</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 19:22.</i> Then <i>Moses called unto them; and Aaron and all the princes</i>, who walked before them <i>returned unto him</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">554</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 31.</i> and Moses spoke to them <i>words of peace</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">555</sup><i class="footnote">Esther 9:30.</i> and told them the tidings of the forgiveness of their sin and of the Tablets he brought down. <i>And afterwards</i> when all the children of Israel saw that he was speaking with the princes of the congregation, they all came near to him, and then he commanded them <i>all that the Eternal had spoken with him in Mount Sinai</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">556</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 32.</i> these being the second Ten Commandments that He gave him, and all that was said to him from the beginning of, <i>Observe thou that which I am commanding thee this day</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">557</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 11.</i> to the end of the section; for he told them that G-d had commanded him to make a covenant with them <i>after the tenor of these words</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">558</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 27.</i> Scripture, however, shortened the account and narrated the matter in general terms. Then Scripture says that <i>when Moses had done speaking with them</i> the whole subject mentioned, <i>he put a veil upon his face</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">559</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 33.</i> for he understood that upon his return [from the mountain] <i>the skin of his face sent forth beams</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">560</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 29.</i> or perhaps they told it to him. Finally, after having told the account of the events of that day, Scripture states, <i>But when Moses went in before the Eternal</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">561</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 34.</i> It is this part of Scripture that represents the continuing action, meaning that so did Moses conduct himself with them all the days.<sup class="footnote-marker">562</sup><i class="footnote">But not, as Rashi put it, that this <i>whole</i> section (from Verses 31 to 35) represents a frequentative action. According to Ramban this applies only to Verses 34-35.</i><br>Vayakheil

Chapter 35



Verse 1

AND MOSES ASSEMBLED ALL THE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The expression <i>all the congregation of the children of Israel</i> includes the men and women, for all donated to the work of the Tabernacle. Thus Moses, after having commanded Aaron, and the rulers and <i>all the children of Israel</i> — the men — <i>all that the Eternal had spoken with him in Mount Sinai</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 34:32.</i> following the breaking of the Tablets, and after he had put the veil on his face<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 33.</i> [as all this is narrated in the preceding section], again commanded that the people be assembled, whereupon the whole congregation gathered to him — men, women, and children.<br>It is possible that this occurred on the day following his descent from the mountain, and he told all of them the subject of the Tabernacle which he had been previously commanded, before<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban follows [here as elsewhere] the natural sequence of Scripture which tells of the command to build the Tabernacle [in Chapters 25-30] before the people’s sin with the calf [in Chapter 32]. The actual building thereof was delayed until after Moses’ intercession and the complete reconciliation of G-d with Israel. Rashi, however, following the principle that there is no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah, clearly writes: “The incident of the golden calf happened a considerable time before the command regarding the building of the Tabernacle was given” (Rashi above, 31-18). See my Hebrew commentary, p. 526, for further elucidation of this point.</i> the breaking of the Tablets. For since the Holy One, blessed be He, became reconciled with them and gave Moses the second Tablets, and also made a new covenant that G-d would go in their midst,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">See Ramban above, 34:9.</i> He thereby returned to His previous relationship with them, and to the love of their “wedding,”<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">See Jeremiah 2:2.</i> and it was obvious that His Presence would be in their midst just as He had commanded him at first, even as He said, <i>And let them make Me a Sanctuary, that I may dwell amongst them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:8.</i> Therefore Moses now commanded them all that he had been told at first.
THESE ARE THE THINGS WHICH THE ETERNAL HATH COMMANDED, THAT YE SHOULD DO THEM. 2. SIX DAYS SHALL WORK BE DONE. The expression, <i>these are the things which the Eternal hath commanded</i> refers to the construction of the Tabernacle,<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">And not as Ibn Ezra explains [in his short commentary on the Book of Exodus], that <i>these are the words</i> refers to the law of the Sabbath, it being mentioned in the plural “words” because the Sabbath is as important as all the other commandments. But according to Ramban, the reference is to the building of the Tabernacle, and the plural is used because the allusion is also to all its vessels, etc.</i> all its vessels and all its various works. He preceded [the explanation of the construction of the Tabernacle] with the law of the Sabbath, meaning to say that the work of <i>these things</i> should be done during the six days, but not on the seventh day which is <i>holy to G-d</i>. It is from here that we learn the principle that the work of the Tabernacle does not set aside the Sabbath, and not from the interpretation of the word <i>ach (but — ‘but’ you shall keep My Sabbaths)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:13.</i> as I have explained in the section of <i>Ki Thisa</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:13.</i>

Verse 2



Verse 3

YE SHALL KINDLE NO FIRE THROUGHOUT YOUR HABITATIONS UPON THE SABBATH DAY. The meaning of this verse is clearly to prohibit also on the Sabbath doing any work necessary for the preparation of food, since He said, <i>whosoever doeth work therein shall be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 2.</i> and He further explained that they <i>should</i> also <i>not kindle fire</i>, in order to bake bread and boil meat, for fire is needed in the preparation of all food. This had to be stated because He did not say here: “whosoever doeth ‘any manner’ of work,” just as He said in the Ten Commandments, <i>thou shalt not do any manner of work</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:10.</i> but instead He merely said “work” without specifying any type. Therefore we might have excluded from the general statement [<i>whosoever doeth work</i> …] all activity necessary for the preparation of food, for we find it said about the feast of unleavened bread, <i>thou shalt not do work therein</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 16:8.</i> and yet the preparation of food is not included [in the scope of its prohibition]. It is for this reason that here He mentioned expressly that the preparation of food is also forbidden on the Sabbath.<br>I have found a similar text in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Mechilta here.</i> “Rabbi Nathan says: <i>Ye shall kindle no fire throughout your habitations upon the Sabbath-day</i>. Why is this said? Because it is stated, <i>And Moses assembled all the congregation of the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 1. — Reference here in the Mechilta is of course to Verse 2: <i>whosoever doeth work therein</i>…, and as Ramban explained above. The insertion of the word “etc.” at the end of the verse mentioned in the text of Ramban, would clarify the matter completely. It is present in texts of the Mechilta.</i> I might think that one should be allowed to light a candle, to put away food to be kept warm, and to make a fire on the Sabbath. Therefore Scripture says, <i>Ye shall kindle no fire throughout your habitations upon the Sabbath-day</i>.” This corresponds closely to that which we have said, that these works [mentioned in the Mechilta], since they are of direct benefit to the body, were not included in the first prohibition. Thus Rabbi Nathan wanted to say that the purpose of the verse here is not to prohibit baking, cooking, and the rest of the activities involved in the preparation of food, for these have already been prohibited to them by the verse, <i>Bake that</i> [on the sixth day of the week] <i>which ye will bake</i> [i.e., which ye intend to bake on the Sabbath], <i>and seethe that which ye will seethe</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 16:23.</i> But yet I might think that all activities which benefit man in such a way that the benefit is only to the body — such as lighting a candle, making fire, or washing one’s whole body in hot water — should be allowed, for these are part of the delight of the Sabbath.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See Isaiah 58:13.</i> Therefore it says, <i>Ye shall kindle no fire</i> — to prohibit all [mentioned activities even if done for these purposes].<br>Our Rabbis in the Talmud<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Shabbath 70a.</i> have yet another Midrash on this verse, because it does not say: “whosoever doeth any manner of work therein shall be put to death,” or: “whosoever kindles fire throughout your habitations shall be put to death.” Therefore they said that the kindling of fire was singled out in order to make it punishable in a less stringent manner, [namely by stripe], since it is a mere negative command, [whereas violation of the Sabbath by doing any of the other kinds of work is punishable by death]. But another Sage<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This is Rabbi Nathan.</i> holds that it was singled out in order to separate it, since it was included in the prohibition, <i>thou shalt not do any manner of work</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:10. It was thus singled out to indicate a general principle: just as in the case of kindling, which is specifically mentioned although it is included in the prohibition, <i>thou shalt not do any manner of work in it</i>, one becomes liable to punishment for transgressing it alone, so also in the case of all the other thirty-nine categories of forbidden work on the Sabbath, one becomes liable upon transgressing each one of them by itself. For otherwise we might have thought that only if one has done all thirty-nine main classes of “work” he is liable to punishment; therefore kindling of fire was singled out in order to teach that the punishment applies even if he has done but one kind of “work” (Rashi, Yebamoth 6 b). For it is one of the thirteen rules of interpretation of the Torah: “If anything is included in a general proposition and is then made the subject of a special statement, that which is predicated of it is not to be understood as limited to itself alone, but is to be applied to the whole of the general proposition.” Similarly we might have thought that if one has done all thirty-nine main classes of “work” on the Sabbath through error he is liable to bring but one sin-offering, therefore kindling of fire was singled out to teach that he is liable to bring such an offering for each of the main classes of “work” he has done.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5

Y’VI’EHA’ (LET HIM BRING IT), THE ETERNAL’S OFFERING. This is like “<i>yavi</i> (let him bring) the Eternal’s offering.” But Scripture mentions a pronoun and then returns to explain it. Similarly: <i>And she opened and saw him, the child;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:6</i> <i>when he went in, the man;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 10:3. It should have said: <i>b’vo ha’ish</i> — when the man went in.</i> <i>the nation and the kingdom which will not serve him, Nebuchadnezzar;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah 27:8.</i> <i>which I do give to them, the children of Israel</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Joshua 1:2.</i> There are many similar instances.<br>By way of the Truth, [the mystic lore of the Cabala], the phrase here is like “let him bring it ‘with’ the Eternal’s offering,” meaning that he is to bring the higher offering as alluded to in the secret of <i>and they take for Me an offering</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:2.</i> I have already explained it.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 3.</i> Our Rabbis have a Midrash<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Sotah 12b.</i> on the verse, <i>and she opened and saw him, the child</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 2:6</i> that she saw with him the Divine Glory.<br>Now it was necessary for Moses to tell the whole congregation all the work which G-d had commanded him, in order to let them know that they had to bring large donations, for <i>the work is great</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">I Chronicles 29:1.</i> That is why he told them, <i>The Tabernacle, its tent, and its covering</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> mentioning all in a general way. The reason for the definite article in <i>‘eth hamishkan’ (the Tabernacle)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 11.</i> <i>‘eth ha’aron’ (the ark)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 12.</i> <i>‘eth hashulchan’ (the table)</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 13.</i> and all those mentioned with the definite article, is as if to say: “the Tabernacle and the vessels which we will explain to the wise men doing the work in their details and measurements,” but speaking now to the whole congregation, he told them only their names in general.

Verse 7
