Verse 19



Verse 20



Verse 21

AND THEY CAME, EVERY ONE WHOSE HEART STIRRED HIM UP. This is said with reference to the wise men who did the work, for we do not find the use of this phrase, “the stirring up of the heart,” in connection with those who merely brought the donations; Scripture rather mentions “generosity of heart” with reference to them. Now the reason for using such a phrase, <i>whose heart stirred him up</i>, is because they undertook to do the work, although there was no one amongst them who had learned these crafts from an instructor, or had trained his hands at all to do them. Rather, a person who felt in his nature that he knew how to do such skills, <i>his heart was lifted up in the ways of the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">II Chronicles 17:6.</i> to come before Moses and say to him, “I will do all that my lord speaks.” I have already mentioned this in another section.<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:2.</i> Thus Scripture is stating that there came before Moses <i>every one whose heart stirred him up</i> to undertake the work, <i>and every one whom his spirit made willing</i> brought the offering. Then Moses said to all of them that <i>G-d had called by name Bezalel</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 30.</i> <i>and Oholiab</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> Afterwards Moses called them <i>and every wise-hearted man</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:2.</i> to come before him, and he gave them the whole donation [brought by the people so that they could proceed to do the work].

Verse 22

AND THE MEN CAME ‘AL HANASHIM’ (WITH THE WOMEN). The meaning of this expression is that because donations of ornaments were more common amongst women, and they all had these jewels [cited in the verse: <i>nose-rings, and ear-rings, and signet-rings, and golden beads, all jewels of gold</i>], therefore they immediately pulled off their ear-rings and signet-rings and were the first to come to Moses, and [afterwards] they brought with them those men with whom they found ornaments. For the phrase <i>al hanashim</i> indicates that they were there first, while the men joined them later. Similar usage of the word <i>al</i> is found in these verses: <i>Aram is confederate ‘al’ Ephraim</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 7:2.</i> for that war [against Judah] was mainly led by Ephraim [i.e., the kingdom of Israel]; <i>and he did not put them ‘al’ (unto) Laban’s flock;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 30:40.</i> <i>‘v’alav’ (and next unto him) shall be the tribe of Manasseh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 2:20.</i> There are other similar instances. Thus Scripture is stating that all — men and women — came with <i>nose-rings, and ear-rings, and signet-rings, and golden beads</i>, and with <i>all jewels of gold</i>, such as bracelets and ear-rings, as all of the people found some jewelry to bring. It further states that some of them <i>brought an offering of gold</i>, in some broken form or as coin.
<i>And every man, with whom was found blue-purple and red-purple</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 23.</i> The reason for this expression is that these items were found only amongst a few of the people. Then Scripture states again, <i>and every man, with whom was found acacia-wood</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> because the people who had this kind of wood were still fewer in number. It states, <i>Every one that did set apart an offering of silver and brass</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 24.</i> because most people had silver and brass in coins or vessels. Scripture, however, did not mention this above together with <i>all jewels of gold</i>, because it mentioned there the women, and they did not have silver and brass ornaments but gold ones, just as Aaron said, <i>Pull off the golden rings, which are in the ears of your wives</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 32:2.</i>
<i>And every man that ‘heinif tenufath’ (brought an offering of) gold</i>. This is so phrased because the number of these people was not as great as those who brought silver and brass. Thus the amount of gold brought was not as much as that of silver and brass. It is for this reason that the gold donation is called <i>tenufah</i> (waving), whilst that of silver and brass is called <i>terumah</i> (offering),<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Thus in Verse 24: Every one that <i>‘meirim terumath’ (set apart an offering of) silver and brass</i>…</i> for one who brings gold waves it with his hand to show the importance of the donation, or it may be that those who take it from him wave the gold to show up the donor in a praiseworthy light for having brought such a donation. However, in the section of <i>Eileh Pekudei</i> Scripture calls the donations of both gold and brass <i>tenufah</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 38:24: <i>And the gold of ‘hatenufah’</i>… And in Verse 29: <i>And the brass of ‘hatenufah’</i>…</i> because there it does not mention at all <i>terumah</i> (free-will offering,) but only <i>the silver of them that were numbered</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25. And since everyone had to give the half-shekel in order to be counted, it is not called <i>terumah</i> which indicates a free-will offering. See Ramban above at beginning of <i>Seder Ki Thisa</i>.</i> It is possible that brass also was called <i>tenufah</i> because it was more important to them than silver, since they did not have much of it. Or it may have been very important on its own merit, similar to that which is said, <i>and two vessels of fine bright brass, precious as gold</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Ezra 8:27.</i>

Chapter 36



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

AND THEY TOOK FROM BEFORE MOSES ALL THE OFFERING. In one day they brought all this donation to the Tent of Meeting where Moses was,<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">See above, 33:7.</i> and the wise men took it from Moses on that very same day and on the following day, early in the morning. On the second day, too, the people still continued to bring the donation to Moses’ tent and he commanded them to bring it to the craftsmen, until they told him that <i>the people bring much more;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> thus there was <i>sufficient [for all the work to make it], and too much</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 7.</i> The surplus, however, was not a sufficiently important amount to warrant Moses’ telling in the section of <i>Eileh Pekudei</i> what they did with it. Perhaps it remained in the tent to repair the breaches of the Tabernacle, or to make with it vessels used in the Tabernacle service, as they used to do with the surpluses in the Sanctuary.<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Shekalim 4:4.</i> Scripture mentions, <i>the people bring much more than enough</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 5.</i> in order to praise the people who brought with such generosity, and to glorify the wise men for their honesty. The one who was in charge principally over them [namely Moses], also comes in for praise for having <i>caused it to be proclaimed throughout the camp</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 6.</i> that the people should stop bringing, telling us that he had no desire for their silver and gold, as do other rulers over peoples, in a similar way to that which it says, <i>I have not taken one ass from them</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 16:15.</i>

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6

LET NEITHER MAN NOR WOMAN MAKE ANY MORE ‘MLACHAH’ (WORK). Money [and possessions] are called <i>mlachah</i>. Similarly: <i>whether he have not put his hand ‘bimlecheth’ (the goods of) his neighbor;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 22:7.</i> <i>according to the pace of ‘hamlachah’ (the cattle) that are before me;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 33:14.</i> <i>‘v’chol hamlachah’ (but everything) that was of no account and feeble, that they destroyed utterly</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">I Samuel 15:9.</i> Thus the meaning of this verse is that they should not bring anything more for the sacred work. Scripture, however, states, <i>Let them not make any more ‘mlachah’</i> [using the verb “to make”] in order to include therein the women, that they should no longer spin the goats’ hair.<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:26.</i> Thus even the act of bringing is here referred to as “making,” and [it was now Moses’ wish] to restrain them altogether [from bringing more donations, and from making any work in their homes, as explained].

Verse 7



Verse 8

AND EVERY WISE-HEARTED MAN AMONG THEM THAT WROUGHT THE WORK, MADE THE TABERNACLE OF TEN CURTAINS. The Torah has repeated the [description of the] work of the Tabernacle five times.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">1. When commanding to make it — designating each part specifically [in the section of <i>Terumah</i> — Chapters 25-27, and in parts of <i>Tetzaveh</i>]. 2. In a general way [in the section of <i>Ki Thisa</i> — 31:6-11]. 3. At the time of the actual making thereof — in a general way [at the beginning of this section — 35:10-19]. 4. Specifically at the time of construction. For even though this is not mentioned expressly, yet Moses surely told them details, such as that the curtains should be of such and such a length, etc., as will be explained by Ramban further on. 5. The specific account of how each part was made [beginning with our verse here].</i> It mentions the whole of it at the time of the command in detail, and in general terms. First it says, “and you shall make it thus,” “and you shall make it thus,” and then it mentioned all things in a general way, <i>and they will make all that I have commanded thee: the Tent of Meeting, and the ark of the Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:6-7. — This is the second time it is mentioned (see above, Note 55).</i> until <i>according to all that I have commanded thee shall they do</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> The reason [why the command is repeated in a general way], is that G-d commanded Moses that he should tell Bezalel and Oholiab and all the wise men about the work in general terms, and only afterwards should they begin to do it, for they would not be suited for the sacred work until they had heard the scope of the whole undertaking and understood it all, and only then could they accept it upon themselves, when they know how to finish it. At the time of its actual construction he described it to them first in the general way as mentioned here, saying, <i>let every wise-hearted man among you come, and make all that the Eternal hath commanded: the Tabernacle, its tent</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 35:10-11. This is the third time (see Note 55).</i> The statement of the details is, however, missing here; for surely Moses had to say to the wise men who did the work: “make the Tabernacle of ten curtains, each curtain of such-and-such a length and such-and-such a width,” and so on with the whole work. This procedure [of Moses’ telling the workers the exact details of the measurements] Scripture does not mention, for it is understood that he told them everything in order, since they made each part exactly as prescribed. And the reason why Scripture does not mention it is that it was not necessary for Moses to go with them into the smallest details as they are mentioned at the command and the construction; instead, he told it to them briefly, as if to say that they should make the Tabernacle of ten curtains, five opposite five, and they themselves understood that they had to make loops corresponding to clasps of gold in order to couple the curtains together. Similarly with the rest of the work, he hinted to them the matter in brief, and they understood everything. It is for this reason that Scripture does not dwell at length on this detail [of Moses’ instruction to the workers], since its hints [at the same time] at their wisdom, understanding, and good sense. After this Scripture describes again the whole work in a specific way as at first, stating, <i>And every wise-hearted man among them that wrought the work made the Tabernacle; and he made curtains of goats’ hair;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 14.</i> <i>and he made the boards</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i><br>Now it would have been sufficient in this whole subject for Scripture to have said, “and Moses told the whole congregation of the children of Israel all the work which G-d had commanded him,” and then say, “and the children of Israel did <i>according to all that the Eternal had commanded Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 39:42.</i> <i>so did they. And Moses saw all the work, and behold they had done it, as the Eternal had commanded, even so had they done it. And Moses blessed them</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 43.</i> Scripture, however, wanted to state that Moses mentioned to the whole congregation of the children of Israel and the wise men who were there all the work in general, for he intended thereby to stir the people to donate sufficiently for the large work, and in order also that the wise men should hear [the entire scope of the work] and would know if they could undertake to do everything as he had been commanded. Then Scripture mentions in detail the whole work in order to tell us that all the wise men worked on the Tabernacle. It is with reference to this that Scripture states here, <i>And every wise-hearted man among them that wrought the work made the Tabernacle of ten curtains</i>. The verses stating, <i>and he made curtains of goats’ hair</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 14.</i> <i>and he made the boards</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 20.</i> mean: “and every wise-hearted man made the curtains of goats’ hair,” [not Bezalel alone].<br>In the case of the ark, however, Scripture mentions specifically, <i>and Bezalel made the ark</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 37:1.</i> in order to say that the greatest craftsman amongst them made the ark alone. The reason for this is because he was filled <i>with the spirit of G-d, in wisdom, and understanding, and in knowledge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 31:3.</i> so that he could contemplate its meaning and make it with the proper intention. For in the actual making of the ark there was no great craftsmanship entailed, there being amongst the other work things which required greater skill than that of the ark. [Hence we must conclude that Bezalel was required to make the ark on account of its great significance.]<br>Then Scripture again states without elaboration, <i>and he made the table</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 37:10.</i> <i>and he made the candelabrum</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 17.</i> In the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra,<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 37:1.</i> this alludes to Bezalel who made all the sacred vessels. But this is not my opinion, for in the case of the court of the Tabernacle it likewise says, <i>and he made the court</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 38:9. And it would not be reasonable to say that Bezalel alone made the court.</i> Rather, this refers back to every <i>wise-hearted man</i> as mentioned in the making of the Tabernacle.<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Mentioned here in the verse before us (36:8), and as explained above.</i><br>After Scripture completed the account of the construction of the Tabernacle in general and particular terms, it mentions their bringing it to Moses in a general way, stating, <i>And they brought the Tabernacle unto Moses, the Tent, and all its vessels</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Further, 39:33.</i> in order to tell of their wisdom, in that they brought everything in order and no one brought his work to Moses until the whole work had been completed, as Scripture says, <i>Thus was finished all the work of the Tabernacle of the Tent of Meeting</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 32.</i> After it was finished they all gathered and showed it to Moses in order, saying at first: “Our Rabbi, here is the Tent and there are its vessels,” and afterwards they said, “Here is the ark and here are its staves,” and so on with everything.<br>Now [in this whole section of <i>Vayakheil</i>] Scripture does not state that the Tabernacle and its vessels were made “as the Eternal commanded Moses.” But in the next section of <i>Eileh Pekudei</i>, with reference to the garments of priesthood, it mentions such a statement at each item. The reason for this is that the whole work of the Tabernacle is included in the verse mentioned at the end, <i>And Bezalel the son of Uri… made all that the Eternal commanded Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 38:22.</i> Perhaps it is because of the change of the order, as our Rabbis have mentioned.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 55a. Moses told Bezalel to make “the ark, vessels and the Tabernacle.” But Bezalel said to him, “It is the way of the world first to build a house and then to place in it its various utensils. Perhaps G-d told you to make the Tabernacle, and then the ark and vessels.” Moses consented, and Bezalel made them in this order.</i><br>In general, then, all this repetition in the account of the Tabernacle is a sign of love and distinction, showing that G-d desires the work, and He mentions it in His Torah many times in order to increase the reward of those who engage themselves in its study. This is similar to what the Rabbis have said in the Midrash:<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Bereshith Rabbah 60:11.</i> “The ordinary conversation of the servants of the patriarchs’ homes is more pleasing to the Holy One, blessed be He, than even the Torah-discourses of their children, for the section about Eliezer [as he recounts his journey],<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Genesis 24:34-48.</i> comprises two or three columns in the Torah, [whereas many important principles of the Torah are derived from only slight references in the text].”

Verse 29

AND HE MADE THE HOLY ANOINTING OIL, AND THE PURE INCENSE OF SWEET SPICES. Scripture did not explain these as it did with the others, for according to the way it writes about the others it should have said, “and he took the chief spices, of flowing myrrh etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:23.</i> and he made them into the holy anointing oil; and he took sweet spices, stacte, and onycha etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> and he made them into an incense compounded after the art of the perfumers.” But the reason [for Scripture not saying so] is because He did not state the whole process of the making of the oil of anointment when He gave the command for them, as I have explained there.<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> In the making of the incense likewise it does not mention all the spices, but relied on them [the craftsmen who made the Tabernacle] by saying that it should be made <i>after the art of the perfumer</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 35.</i> and therefore when they made it Scripture only mentioned that they made it according to the way of the perfumers. This is the sense of the expression, <i>holy… pure, after the art of the perfumer</i>.

Chapter 38



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8

OF THE MIRRORS ‘HATZOVOTH’ (OF THE SERVING WOMEN). “The women of Israel possessed mirrors of brass which they used to look into when they adorned themselves, and even these they did not withhold [from donating to the Tabernacle]. But Moses was reluctant to accept them because they were made to arouse sensual desires. Said the Holy One, blessed be He, to Moses: ‘These are dearer to Me than all [other donations], for by means of them the women raised many hosts in Egypt, etc. For this reason the laver was made from these mirrors, because it was used in order to bring peace between husband and wife; for it was out of this laver that they took the water which they give to drink to a woman who was warned by her husband not to meet a certain man privately and who had nevertheless associated with him.”<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 5:17-24.</i> This is Rashi’s language.<br>The meaning of this Midrash is that in the whole work of the Tabernacle they accepted ornaments from women, as it is written, <i>And they came, both men and women… and brought nose-rings, and ear-rings, and signet-rings ‘v’chumaz’</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:22.</i> — the <i>chumaz</i>, according to its Midrashic interpretation, being even more undesirable.<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In Shabbath 64, the <i>chumaz</i> is explained as an ornament worn by women on their pudendum.</i> There, however, all the donations became mixed together, whereas here they were to make one specific vessel purely from ornaments [i.e., the mirrors] which were made to arouse sensual desire. Therefore Moses did not consent at first [to accept them] until he was told to do so by the Almighty.<br>But I do not know how to explain according to this Midrash the phrase — <i>that did service at the door of the Tent of Meeting</i> — [since the Tent of Meeting had not yet been put up]. Perhaps it can be said that the women brought this donation to Moses’ tent, which he called the Tent of Meeting,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 33:7.</i> and he himself received it from them by word of G-d, since the tent of the Tabernacle had not yet been made. Onkelos’ translation, “women that came to pray at the door of the Tent of Meeting,” accords approximately to the words of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, who said that these women worshipped G-d, and turned away from the desires of this world and gave their mirrors as a donation, coming each day to the door of the Tent of Meeting to pray and to hear instruction about the commandments.<br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is also possible to say that Moses <i>made the laver and its base for the mirrors</i> of the women who came in a great crowd,<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Ramban thus interprets the word <i>tzavu</i> as being from the root <i>tzava</i> (a host). <i>Of the mirrors ‘hatzovoth’</i> would thus mean “of the mirrors of the hosts of women” who assembled at the door of the Tent of Meeting.</i> <i>and assembled at the door of the Tent of Meeting</i> in order to give their mirrors in the generosity of their hearts. Now the brass of the mirrors was <i>burnished brass</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 1:7.</i> resplendent and very beautiful. It is for this reason that he set aside this brass from the beginning for the making of this vessel. Upon seeing this [that Moses accepted it from them], the women gathered and came in many hosts, all of them wanting to give their mirrors for the making of the whole laver and its base. It is also correct to explain that they had in mind right at the start to offer them for the laver because of its use in connection with the suspected adulteress [as explained above], and they accepted the law [of the suspected adulteress] upon themselves with joy, and offered to give all their mirrors.<br>Pekudei

Verse 21

THESE ARE THE ACCOUNTS OF THE TABERNACLE, THE TABERNACLE OF THE TESTIMONY. Scripture uses this expression because the term “Tabernacle” means the curtains of fine-twined linen, which are so called both when the command was given<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And thou shalt make the Tabernacle of ten curtains</i> (above, 26:1).</i> and at the construction of the Tabernacle,<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><i>And every wise-hearted man… made the Tabernacle of ten curtains</i> (<i>ibid.</i>, 36:8). See also Ramban further on, 39:33.</i> while “the Tabernacle of the Testimony” includes the entire building, which is the Tabernacle made to house the Tablets of the Testimony.<br>In the opinion of many scholars<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi and Ibn Ezra.</i> the phrase <i>these are the accounts of the Tabernacle</i> refers back to all the things mentioned above, the verse stating that the Tabernacle and its vessels, namely, the house and the court and all that was made for them, constituted the service entrusted to the Levites at the command of Moses <i>by the hand of Ithamar</i> [whose duty it was to hand over to each family the service that devolved upon it]. But the holy vessels — the ark, the table, the candelabrum, and the altars — are not included in the term “Tabernacle,” for they were in the hands of Eleazar.<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:32. The verse refers to the time of the journeying through the wilderness.</i> But this is not my opinion, for why should Scripture mention the entrusting of those things given to Ithamar, and not mention that of Eleazar, which was the more honored one? Rather, <i>these are the accounts of</i> hints at those things that Scripture mentions in the section further on, thus stating that <i>the silver of them that were numbered of the congregation was a hundred talents</i> etc.,<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 25.</i> — from which were made the sockets, the hooks for the pillars, the overlaying of their capitals and their fillets.<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 27-28.</i> And <i>the brass of the wave-offering</i>, which was seventy talents, from which were made the brazen altar and its grating and all its vessels, and the sockets of the court and the pins<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 29-31.</i> — all these Moses gave over by number and weight through the hand of Ithamar. Now the section does not say what was done with the gold, for that was partly in the charge of Ithamar, namely, that used for covering the boards and the bars, and part of it was in the charge of Eleazar — the ark and the cover, the candelabrum, the table, and the golden altar. Now since one cannot know exactly how much gold went into the covering of each of these vessels, Scripture did not say that Moses gave it over to them by number and weight. It is for this reason that Scripture did not mention here the entrusting of the things given to Eleazar, for its intention here is only to speak of the work of the Tabernacle, not of that involved in the journeyings. Do not object [to this explanation] because Scripture mentions here <i>the brazen altar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 30.</i> which was in the charge of Eleazar,<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:31-32.</i> for Scripture had to state that they made it out of the brass of the wave-offering, therefore it was not particular to exclude this one item from the general list of objects of which it said that they were <i>by the hand of Ithamar</i>, this being the way of Scripture in many places.<br>Scripture does not mention in this section the laver and its base [which were also made of brass, and were under the charge of Ithamar], because it was not made according to a specified weight; instead, he put into it all the mirrors that the women brought together<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">see Ramban above, 38:8, towards the end.</i> and thus Moses did not know its weight. It is possible that these were not under the charge of Ithamar [and therefore they are not mentioned], but they come into the category of that which Scripture says [of the children of Kohath, whose work was under the charge of Eleazar], <i>and their charge was the ark, and the table, and the candelabrum, and the altars, and the vessels of the Sanctuary wherewith the priests minister</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 3:31.</i> for through the laver and its base the priests were enabled to minister at the altar. Thus they do not come into the listing given in this section.

Verse 22

AND BEZALEL THE SON OF URI, THE SON OF HUR, OF THE TRIBE OF JUDAH, MADE ALL THAT THE ETERNAL COMMANDED MOSES. The meaning of this is that everything was done through his direction, for he acted as instructor to all the wise men, and they all did heir work in his presence and showed him all that they had done, just as it is said, <i>And He hath put in his heart that he may teach</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 35:34.</i> But all the wise-hearted men also did the work, as it is said, <i>and every wise-hearted man among them that wrought the work made the Tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 36:8.</i> In the opinion of our Rabbis,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Yerushalmi Peah I, 1; and quoted here by Rashi.</i> this verse is intended to praise Bezalel, and to say that even these things that his master Moses did not tell him, he understood through his own mind in exactly the same way that they had been told to Moses on Sinai.<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">See in <i>Seder Vayakheil</i> Note 72. Moses agreed that originally G-d had told him to do it as Bezalel said it should be done.</i> Thus the intention of Scripture is not to state that Bezalel did all the work, but that in all which was done through him, he fulfilled <i>all that the Eternal commanded Moses</i>. It is for this reason that Scripture does not state in connection with anything that was done until now: “as G-d spoke to Moses,” for this would have implied: “as Moses said by the word of G-d,” and he [i.e., Bezalel] changed their order from that which Moses had told him. Therefore Scripture stated everything in general terms, and said that Bezalel did everything as G-d had said, as I have written above.<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 36:8 (towards the end).</i>

Verse 24



Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

THE SOCKETS OF THE SANCTUARY, AND THE SOCKETS OF THE VEIL. Scripture calls the Tabernacle “the Sanctuary,” and mentioned the veil separately, because it divided <i>between the holy place and the most holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:33.</i> Thus it is as if it said, “the sockets of the holy place and the sockets of the most holy.”

Chapter 39



Verse 1



Verse 2



Verse 3

AND THEY BEAT THE GOLD INTO THIN PLATES. In all the sacred work that was done, Scripture did not add an explanation as to the method of execution except for here. It should rather have said: “and they made the ephod of gold, and blue-purple etc., the work of a skilful workman; they made shoulder-pieces for it etc.,” for such is the way it describes all of them. It is possible that Scripture relates here [how it was made] because of the original thought that they had to put into making the gold threads, for they were greatly astonished [to be told] that the gold should be spun and twined as is done with wool or linen, for no-one ever heard of doing such a thing until that day.

Verse 23



Verse 24

AND THEY MADE UPON THE SKIRTS OF THE ROBE POMEGRANATES OF BLUE-PURPLE AND RED-PURPLE, AND SCARLET, AND TWINED LINEN. This means<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Since the pomegranates were not made upon the robe, but instead were made separately and then attached to the robe, Ramban found difficulty in the language of the verse, <i>And they made upon the skirts of the robe pomegranates</i>. Hence his interpretation: “This means, etc.”</i> that they made the pomegranates in order to put them around the bottom of the skirts of the robe, and they made bells of pure gold,<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 25.</i> and then they put the bells inside the pomegranates before they put them on the robe. Thus the bells were within the pomegranates whilst they were still detached, and they put the pomegranates on the skirts of the robe round about while the bells were within them [i.e., the pomegranates]. This is why Scripture mentions the phrase <i>within the pomegranates</i> twice,<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.: and they put the bells within the pomegranates upon the skirts of the robe round about, within the pomegranates</i>. — The repetition of the phrase is in order to indicate etc.</i> in order to indicate that the bells were within the pomegranates from the beginning, and also when they hung them upon the skirts of the robe round about. This too is proof to what we have explained in <i>Seder V’atah Tetzaveh</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:31. Ramban there discusses Rashi’s opinion that the bells were hung separately on the skirts of the robe alongside the pomegranates. On this point he differs and holds that the bells were within the pomegranates. The proof to his opinion Ramban finds in the repetition of the phrase: <i>within the pomegranates</i>, which indicates that they were so to begin with and also when attached to the robe. But according to Rashi the repetition is redundant. — It should be noted that the J. P. S. translation of <i>b’thoch harimonim</i>: “between the pomegranates” [instead of “within the pomegranates”], follows Rashi’s interpretations.</i>

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

AND THEY MADE THE TUNICS OF FINE LINEN OF WOVEN WORK FOR AARON, AND FOR HIS SONS. It appears from here that the tunics were identical for father [Aaron] and sons. For even though in the case of the tunic made for Aaron it says, <i>And thou shalt make the tunic of chequer-work from fine linen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:39.</i> and in speaking of those made for his sons it just says, <i>thou shalt make tunics</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 40.</i> [without specifying that they should be of chequer-work], the intention is: “<i>thou shalt make tunics</i> similar to the one mentioned.” And thus it is written, <i>a breastplate, and an ephod, and a robe, and a tunic of chequer-work, a mitre, and a belt; and they shall make holy garments for Aaron thy brother, and his sons, that they may minister unto Me</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 4.</i> for the expression <i>for Aaron… and his sons</i> refers back to the tunic of chequer-work, the mitre and the belt, which were alike for all of them. Similarly, that which Scripture says here, <i>and the mitre of fine linen, and the beautiful head-tires</i>, refers to those of both Aaron and his sons, since the <i>mitznepheth</i> (mitre) and the <i>migba’ath</i> (the head-tire) were made in the same way, except that Aaron wound it [around his head, fold upon fold], and his sons set them upon their heads tightly, as I have explained.<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 31 (towards the end) and Verse 37.</i>

Verse 28

PA’AREI HAMIGBA’OTH.’ The term (the beautiful head-tires) means that these head-dresses rose upon the head like turbans, similar to the expressions, <i>‘hap’eirim’ (the head-tires) and the armlets</i>;<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Isaiah 3:20.</i> <i>‘pa’arei’ (tires of) linen they shall have upon their heads</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 44:18.</i><br>Scripture explained with reference to the belt [in the following verse], that they made it <i>of fine-twined linen, and blue-purple, and red-purple, and scarlet</i>. This, however, was not explained at the command, except for that which it said briefly about the belt, <i>that thou shalt make it the work of the weaver in colors</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:39.</i> from which it is known that it was to be woven of these four kinds, as it said with reference to the screen, <i>And thou shalt make a screen for the door of the Tent, of blue-purple, and red-purple, and scarlet, and fine-twined linen, the work of the weaver in colors</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:36.</i> This belt referred to was also for both Aaron and his sons, in accordance with the opinion of the Sage who says<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Yoma 12a. The opinion is that of Rabbi Dosa (<i>ibid.</i>, b).</i> that the belt of the High Priest was made in the same way as that of the common priest. In the opinion, however, of the Sage who says<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The opinion is that of Rabbi Yehudah Hanasi.</i> that the High Priest’s belt was not the same as that of the common priest, [for that of the common priest was merely of plain linen, whilst the High Priest’s was of the above-mentioned four kinds — blue-purple, red-purple, scarlet, and twined linen], Scripture explained with reference to the belt of Aaron that it should be <i>the work of the weaver in colors</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 28:39.</i> but it was not even necessary to mention that the one for his sons should be made of linen, just as it said, <i>And for Aaron’s sons thou shalt make tunics, and thou shalt make for them belts, and head-tires shalt thou make for them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 40.</i> [and it is self-understood] that all of them should be made of linen just like the tunics.

Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33

AND THEY BROUGHT THE TABERNACLE UNTO MOSES, THE TENT, AND ALL ITS VESSELS. The translation of this verse is as if it were written with the connective <i>vav</i> [which indicates “and”], thus making the sense of the verse: “and they brought the Tabernacle unto Moses, ‘and’ the tent and all its vessels,” for it was the curtains of fine-twined linen that are called “Tabernacle,” as it is said, <i>And thou shalt make the Tabernacle with ten curtains of fine-twined linen</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:1.</i> and then it continues, <i>and thou shalt couple the curtains… that the Tabernacle may be one whole</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 6.</i> The “tent,” however, means the curtains of goats’ hair, as Scripture says with reference to them, <i>And thou shalt make curtains of goats’ hair for a tent over the Tabernacle;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 7.</i> <i>and thou shalt couple the tent together, that it may be one</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 11.</i> Similarly, <i>the Tabernacle, its tent, and its covering</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 35:11.</i> means “and its tent.” So also here the meaning of the verse is, “and they brought the Tabernacle unto Moses, and the tent, and all its vessels,” as Scripture mentions here [in this section] the names of all its parts. At times the whole house is called “the Tent of Meeting,” as He said, <i>and they shall make all that I have commanded thee: the Tent of Meeting, and the ark of the Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 31:6-7.</i> for “the Tent of Meeting” is the house in its totality, where He would meet with Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 30:6.</i> Similarly, <i>all the vessels of the service of the Tabernacle of the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 40.</i> [refers to the building as a whole].

Verse 34



Verse 35



Verse 36



Verse 37

THE LAMPS THEREOF, EVEN THE LAMPS TO BE SET IN ORDER. It is possible that there are candelabrums with lamps on them purely for decorative purposes, or that they should give additional light if more is required. But this was not the case with the candelabrum of the Sanctuary, for it only had seven lamps. Therefore He explained, <i>even the lamps to be set in order</i>, for they were always set in order at dusk.

Verse 40

Verse 42

ACCORDING TO ALL THAT THE ETERNAL COMMANDED MOSES, SO THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID ALL ‘HA’AVODAH’ (THE WORK) — all the work of the Tabernacle. Scripture calls it <i>avodah</i> [a term which means also “the Service” to G-d], in order to indicate that they did it for the service of the Glorious Name, it being similar to that which is said, <i>‘v’avad’tem’ (and ye shall serve) the Eternal your G-d;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 23:25.</i> <i>and Him ‘ta’avodu’ (shall ye serve)</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 13:5.</i> It is possible that the phrase <i>all the ‘avodah’</i> refers here also to all the vessels, similar to the expression, “all the vessels of the <i>‘avodah’</i> (service) of the Tabernacle.”<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The source is unknown to me.</i> Thus Scripture first mentioned the vessels, in order to say that even in making the vessels they were careful to do them exactly as they were commanded, and afterwards it states, <i>And Moses saw all the work</i>…<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 43.</i>

Chapter 40



Verse 1



Verse 2

ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE FIRST MONTH SHALT THOU SET UP THE TABERNACLE OF THE TENT OF MEETING. In the opinion of our Rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, beginning of <i>Seder Shemini</i>.</i> who say that this was on the eighth day of the installation [of the priests into their sacred office],<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">On the first seven days of the installation the Tabernacle was put up and taken apart each day. But on the eighth day it was put up and no longer dismantled until they moved away from the encampment at Mount Sinai. Accordingly, since in the opinion of the Rabbis the first day of Nisan was the eighth day of the installation, the expression <i>thou shalt set up the Tabernacle</i> must mean “set it up permanently etc.,”</i> the meaning of the verse is: “you are to put up the Tabernacle and it should remain so; do not dismantle it and do not put it up again, for when the camps will move, the Levites will dismantle it and put it up.” It was not necessary that G-d should command Moses now about the putting up of the Tabernacle during the first seven days, since He had told him at the start, <i>And thou shalt set up the Tabernacle according to the fashion thereof which hath been shown thee in the mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:30.</i> Now since He explained to him here that <i>On the first day of the first month</i> the setting up of the Tabernacle would be of a permanent nature, Moses thus understood that during [each of] the seven days of installation it would be necessary for him to put it up and to dismantle it. Perhaps this was done in order to train the Levites how to do it, for they would see how he did it and would do likewise. Or it may be that this was done in order to crown the eighth day with this special crown [that the Tabernacle was for the first time not dismantled on that day].<br>It would appear according to the opinion of the Rabbis that on the first seven days Moses put up the Tabernacle each morning, and it remained standing all day and all the following night, and at each dawn he would dismantle it and put it up again immediately, for Scripture says, <i>And at the door of the Tent of Meeting shall ye abide day and night for seven days</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:35.</i> and there could be no “door” to the Tent of Meeting except at the time when it was erected.<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Thus since Scripture states that during the first seven days of the installation Aaron and his sons had to sit <i>at the door of the Tent of Meeting</i>, we must therefore conclude that the Tabernacle was dismantled at dawn and put up again immediately.</i> The Sages have already interpreted:<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra <i>Vayikra, parshata</i> 4.</i> “<i>he shall bring it to the door of the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:3.</i> — at the time when it is open, and not when [the Tent of Meeting] is taken to pieces.” Similarly, the Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 55b.</i> “Peace-offerings which have been slaughtered before the doors of the Sanctuary were opened are invalid, because it is said, <i>and he shall slaughter it at the door of the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 3:2.</i> — at the time it is open, and not when it is locked.” Similarly, “at the Tabernacle, [peace-offerings which were slaughtered] before the Levites put up the Tabernacle, or after the Levites had dismantled it, were invalid.”<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Zebachim 55b.</i> Moreover, [during the first seven days of installation, Moses] used to sacrifice the Daily Offering of the evening and kindle the lamps at night. And in Vayikra Rabbah<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">I have not found this quotation in Vayikra Rabbah, but in Tanchuma <i>Pekudei</i>, 11.</i> I have seen [the following text]: “Moses used to put up the Tabernacle and dismantle it twice every day. Rabbi Chanina the Great says: three times every day, for [the phrase ‘putting up’ of the Tabernacle] is mentioned three times: <i>thou shalt put up;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 2 before us.</i> <i>the Tabernacle was put up;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 17.</i> <i>and Moses put up the Tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i> Once it was put up for the Daily Offering of the morning, and once for the special offerings of the installation, and once for the Daily Offering of the evening.” It is possible that all this was done for the sake of practice, so that they would know the procedure for putting it up, and which order to follow, but they never left it in a dismantled state at all [during the seven days of installation].<br>And that which Scripture states here, <i>And the cloud covered the Tent of Meeting, and the Glory of the Eternal filled the Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> in the opinion of the Rabbis it refers to the eighth day, for Scripture says, <i>So Moses finished the work</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 33.</i> and when he had completed this erection on the first of Nisan, the cloud covered the Tabernacle. Now Rashi has already mentioned the interpretation of the Rabbis: “<i>And they came out and blessed the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 9:23.</i> During all the seven days of installation when Moses was putting up the Tabernacle, and officiating therein, and dismantling it,<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Our Rashi adds: “every day.”</i> the Divine Glory did not rest upon it, and the Israelites felt ashamed, and they said to Moses: ‘Our master! All the trouble which we have taken was only so that the Divine Glory would dwell amongst us, and that we would know that the sin of the calf has been atoned for!’ Then Moses said to them: ‘My brother Aaron is more worthy and meritorious than I am, and it is through his offerings and service that the Divine Glory will rest upon us.’”<br>And in the <i>Parshath Hamiluim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, beginning of <i>Seder Shemini</i>.</i> (the Chapter of the Installation) we find written: “I might think that the Tabernacle was put up on the first of the month of Nisan, and that the Divine Glory did not rest thereon until the eighth day of the month. Scripture therefore says, <i>And on the day that the Tabernacle was put up, the cloud covered the Tabernacle, even the Tent of Meeting</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 9:15.</i> This teaches us that on the day the Tabernacle was put up, the Divine Glory rested thereon through the service of Aaron.” Thus the Rabbis are clearly saying that the cloud covering the Tabernacle was on the eighth day of the installation, which was on the first day of Nisan.<br>If this is so, then this whole chapter, in the opinion of the Rabbis, took place on the eighth day of the installation. This is indeed so, because Scripture describes the sequence of events as follows: G-d commanded Moses that the final putting up of the Tabernacle should be <i>on the first day of the first month</i>, and then it states that Moses did so and finished the whole work<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 33.</i> [of the seven days of installation], and then [on the eighth day] <i>the cloud covered the tent</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 34.</i> and so it was always [henceforth whenever they journeyed and put up the Tabernacle at their new place of encampment]. Then Scripture goes back to the beginning of the communication which came to Moses from the Tent, saying, <i>And He called unto Moses</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:1.</i> All this is now in proper order.<br>A kind of proof to what the Rabbis have said, [that during the seven days of installation the Tabernacle was dismantled every day], is what Scripture says, <i>And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the Tabernacle</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:1.</i> Now if he did not dismantle it, what sense is there to the expression, <i>the day that he ‘made an end’ of setting up the Tabernacle</i>, since he began and finished all the work in one day? In that case it should rather have said: “and it came to pass on the day that Moses set up the Tabernacle.” Moreover, it says there [with reference to the eighth day], <i>This is the thing which the Eternal commanded that ye should do;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 9:6.</i> <i>and the Glory of the Eternal appeared unto all the people</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 23.</i> The implication of these verses is that the cloud had not yet covered the Tent of Meeting, and the Glory of the Eternal did not yet fill the Tabernacle.<br>However it may be, from the first day of the installation G-d communicated to Moses from the Tabernacle all the sections from the beginning of the Book of Leviticus until <i>And it came to pass on the eighth day</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:1.</i> But the cloud did not cover the Tabernacle, and the people therefore thought that the communication from there to Moses was directly from heaven, just as it was in the land of Egypt. But in the Midrash Chazit<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">I have not found it in Shir Hashirim Rabbah ( Midrash Chazit ), but in Koheleth Rabbah 1:31.</i> I have found the following text: “<i>And it came to pass on the eighth day</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 9:1.</i> This really should have been the beginning of the Book of Leviticus. Why then was it written here? Because there is no strict chronological order in the narrative of the Torah.” Now if this is so, then the chapter beginning <i>And He called unto Moses… out of the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:1.</i> happened after <i>and the Glory of the Eternal appeared unto all the people. And there came forth fire from before the Eternal, and consumed upon the altar;</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 9:23-24.</i> and the communication addressed to Aaron, <i>drink no wine or strong drink</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 10:9.</i> took place on the following day, for it is impossible that G-d should speak to Aaron from the Tent of Meeting before He had spoken to Moses.<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">But if we say, as Ramban does, that G-d already spoke to Moses from the Tent of Meeting on the first day of the installation, then the communication to Aaron, <i>drink no wine nor strong drink</i>, took place on the eighth day of the installation.</i> But I do not know whether this Midrash represents the unanimous opinion of all the Sages, or whether they are the words of a single Sage, for they are mentioned there in the Midrash with reference to Rabbi Yishmael.
THOU SHALT SET UP THE TABERNACLE OF THE TENT OF MEETING. G-d did not explain to Moses in this command the order of putting it up, as it is clearly set forth in the actual construction: <i>and he laid its sockets, and set up the boards thereof</i> etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 18.</i> The reason for His not explaining it here is because He had already shown it to him visually, as He said, <i>And thou shalt put up the Tabernacle according to the fashion thereof which hath been shown thee in the mountain</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:30.</i> Similarly, He shortened the account here, saying, <i>And thou shalt put therein the ark of the Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 3.</i> and did not mention <i>and in the ark thou shalt put the Testimony</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:21.</i> for since He used the phrase: <i>the ark of the Testimony</i>, Moses would understand this, since the ark is only termed “the ark of the Testimony” when the Tablets of the Testimony are in it, and they were already commanded at the beginning, <i>And thou shalt put the ark-cover above upon the ark; and in the ark thou shalt put the Testimony that I shall give thee</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 25:21.</i> It was necessary here to mention it only in order to tell him the order of priority, namely that the putting of the ark with the Tablets [into the Tabernacle] should precede the setting up of all other vessels. Similarly He shortened the account of the table and the candelabrum, since He had already commanded him in what place of the Tabernacle they were to be set up.<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 26:35.</i> He also shortened the subject of the dressing of Aaron and his sons, saying merely, <i>And thou shalt put upon Aaron the holy garments</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 13.</i> and with reference to Aaron’s sons He said, <i>and thou shalt put tunics upon them</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 14.</i> for He had already told and commanded Moses in detail about the order of putting on their garments.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:5-9.</i> Here the intention was only to fix the time of the dressing in its correct order, namely, after the whole Tabernacle had been set up. Of the priestly garments He mentioned only the tunics, because it is with them that the dressing began.

Verse 3

AND THOU SHALT SCREEN ‘AL’ THE ARK. The word <i>al</i> (upon) is in place of the word <i>el</i> (to), for the word <i>v’sakotha</i> (and thou shalt screen) is derived from the term <i>masach</i> (curtain, screen).<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Thus the sense of the verse is not: “and thou shalt screen ‘upon’ the ark,” but: “thou shalt screen the ark.” By putting up the veil in front of the ark, the ark will be screened.</i> Similarly, <i>and he set up the veil of the screen, and screened ‘al’ the ark of the Testimony</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 21.</i> [carries the same interpretation as the verse before us].

Verse 4



Verse 5



Verse 6



Verse 7



Verse 8



Verse 9



Verse 10

AND THE ALTAR SHALL BE MOST HOLY. Since they would also sacrifice on it the most holy offerings, Scripture describes the altar as “most holy,” even though it stood in the court of the Tabernacle. Of the Tabernacle, however, Scripture says, <i>and it shall be holy</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 9.</i> because the term “most holy” is used usually only with reference to the place where the ark rests, just as it is said, <i>and the veil shall divide unto you between the holy place and the most holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 26:33.</i> It is possible that He said of the altar “most holy,” because it sanctifies other things, just as He said, <i>whatsoever toucheth the altar shall be holy</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 29:37. See also Ramban above in <i>Seder Ki Thisa</i> 34:25, towards the end, for the specific explanation of how the altar sanctifies whatever touches it.</i>

Verse 11



Verse 12



Verse 13



Verse 14



Verse 15



Verse 16



Verse 17

AND IT CAME TO PASS IN THE FIRST MONTH… ON THE FIRST DAY OF THE MONTH. In the opinion of our Rabbis [who hold, as mentioned above,<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> that the eighth day of the installation was on the first of Nisan], Scripture stated that the Tabernacle was first put up on a permanent basis on the first day of the first month, as He had commanded.<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> It states, <i>And Moses put up the Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 18.</i> in order to tell us what he did when putting it up from the first day that he began to do so, which was on the twenty-third day of Adar. Scripture does not mention here the anointing of the Tabernacle and its vessels, nor the anointing of Aaron and his sons and the offerings of the installation, since Moses did not do these until he had finished putting up the Tabernacle [on each of the seven days of the installation],<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">See my Hebrew commentary p. 538, where I have shown that this is perforce the meaning of Ramban.</i> and was commanded thereon a second time, <i>Take Aaron and his sons</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:2.</i> as is explained in the section of <i>Tzav</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 8:2.</i> Now the Tabernacle and its vessels were only sanctified for the Divine Service through their anointing, just as it is said, <i>and thou shalt anoint the Tabernacle, and all that is therein, and shalt hallow it, and all the vessels thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 9.</i> Therefore the meaning of the verses, <i>And he set a row of bread upon it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 23.</i> <i>And he lighted the lamps</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 25.</i> must be that he did so at the time that was appropriate for them, that is, after they were anointed [on each of the seven days of the installation], and the sense of the verses is that such was their ultimate purpose [i.e., he put the table in the Tent of Meeting so that he would later on be able to set a row of bread upon it; he put the candelabrum so that he would be able to light the lamps]. And that which Scripture states above, <i>And thou shalt bring in the table, and set in order the bread that is upon it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> also means that he is to set the bread upon it after the anointing of the table. The same meaning applies to the verse, <i>And thou shalt set the golden altar for incense</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> Similarly, <i>and he offered upon it the burnt-offering and the meal-offering</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 29.</i> means at its proper time, for the court around the Tabernacle had not yet been put up,<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">For that is only mentioned further, in Verse 33.</i> and no sacrifices can be brought without the hangings of the court, for that would be considered slaughtering outside [the Tabernacle].<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A matter strongly forbidden in Leviticus 17:1-9.</i> But all these mean that they were done at their proper time.<br><i>And he took and put the Testimony into the ark</i>.

Verse 19



Verse 20

The meaning of this is that he took the Tablets from the wooden ark in Moses’ tent which they were in, and brought them to the Tabernacle.<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 20.</i>

Verse 22



Verse 23

Verse 25



Verse 26



Verse 27

AND HE BURNT THEREON INCENSE OF SWEET SPICES. All the seven days of the installation Moses burnt the incense on the golden altar, and even though he was not specifically told to do so when he was commanded,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">In Verse 5: <i>And thou shalt set the golden altar for incense</i>…</i> he did so nonetheless, for he understood that he was to do so from all the other acts of service, since G-d had commanded him here that he should set the bread<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> and kindle the lamps.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4.</i> Similarly, <i>and he offered upon it the burnt-offering and the meal-offering</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Further, Verse 29.</i> means that Moses was the one who offered them, for thus he was commanded, <i>Now this is that which thou shalt offer upon the altar</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 29:38.</i> meaning that he was to begin to do this when performing the Service during the days of the installation, for all commands there [about the burnt- and the meal-offering]<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verses 39-41.</i> refer to Moses’ service. Afterward, it says, <i>It shall be a continual burnt-offering throughout your generations</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 42.</i> meaning that the priests shall do throughout the generations as Moses now did. Therefore in the section of <i>Pinchas</i> it says about this Daily Offering, <i>It is a continual burnt-offering, which was offered in Mount Sinai</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 28:6.</i> meaning that Moses began doing it there. Thus Moses our Teacher was the first priest in all these acts of service, therefore he also burnt the incense. Perhaps this is included in the words, <i>and thou shalt put the golden altar for incense</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 5.</i> meaning that he should immediately burn the incense on it. And that which is said at the time of the command, <i>And thou shalt put it before the veil… and Aaron shall burn thereon the incense of sweet spices</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:6-7.</i> refers to the proper time, from the day that Aaron begins his service and forever afterwards, [and does not exclude Moses’ service during the seven days], for so He said, <i>And when Aaron lighteth the lamps at dusk</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 8.</i> and he only lit them from that day on, for here Moses was clearly commanded: <i>and thou shalt light the lamps thereof</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 4. Accordingly, the verse here in this chapter must refer to the seven days of the installation when Moses acted as the priest, and the verses above (30:6-8) refer to the time when Aaron would take charge of the service.</i><br>Now in Rashi’s commentary I have seen this text:<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">It is not found in our texts of Rashi.</i> “<i>And he — Aaron — burnt thereon incense (of sweet spices)</i> morning and evening, as it is said, <i>every morning, when he dresseth the lamps, he shall burn it. And when Aaron lighteth the lamps at dusk</i> etc.”<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 30:7-8.</i> But I do not know if this is the scribe’s mistake.<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">For, as explained above, the verse here speaks of Moses doing the service, and not Aaron, since the account here is of what happened during the seven days of the installation.</i>

Verse 28



Verse 29



Verse 30



Verse 31



Verse 32



Verse 33



Verse 34

AND THE CLOUD COVERED THE TENT OF MEETING etc. Scripture is stating that the cloud covered the Tabernacle from all sides, with the result that the building was covered and hidden in it. 
AND THE GLORY OF THE ETERNAL FILLED THE TABERNACLE, this means that it was filled completely with the Glory, for the Glory rested within the cloud inside the Tabernacle, just as it is said with reference to Mount Sinai, <i>unto the thick darkness where G-d was</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 20:21.</i> It states further on that <i>Moses was not able to come into the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> — even to the door, because the cloud covered it, and he was not permitted to come into the cloud. Moreover, <i>the Glory of the Eternal filled the Tabernacle</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> so how could he enter it? The reason for this was so that Moses should not go in without permission, but instead G-d would call him and then he was to come into the midst of the cloud, just as He had done at Mount Sinai, as it is said, <i>and He called unto Moses on the seventh day out of the midst of the cloud</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Above, 24:16.</i> and then it says, <i>And Moses entered into the midst of the cloud</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, Verse 18.</i><br>In line with the plain meaning of Scripture, it is because it is said, <i>and the Eternal spoke unto him out of the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:1.</i> that Moses did not enter the Tabernacle, but G-d called him from the Tent of Meeting and he stood at its door and He spoke to him. But our Rabbis have said:<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">Sifra, Introduction, 8.</i> “One verse states, <i>And Moses was not able to enter into the Tent of Meeting</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Verse 35.</i> and another verse states, <i>and when Moses went into the Tent of Meeting</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> [thus the two verses appear to be contradictory]! The matter is decided by the passage, <i>because the cloud abode thereon</i>.”<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Here in Verse 35. “From this you learn that as long as the cloud was there, Moses was not able to enter; when the cloud withdrew, Moses entered and He spoke with him” (Sifra <i>ibid.</i>).</i> For in the opinion of the Rabbis, the phrase <i>and when Moses went into the Tent of Meeting</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> means that he went inside of his own accord without being called. Or it may be that because Scripture states there, <i>and he heard the Voice speaking unto him from above the ark-cover</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">Numbers 7:89.</i> therefore it appeared to the Rabbis that Moses stood within the Tent before the ark-cover. Now as long as the Glory of G-d filled the Tabernacle, Moses did not enter it. Therefore they say that he only would enter after the cloud withdrew, meaning after it withdrew from covering the whole Tent, and the Glory no longer filled the Tabernacle. That was only on the eighth day of the installation when the Glory descended there,<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 9:23-24.</i> and as for the call that came to Moses, of which it is said, <i>And he called unto Moses</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Leviticus 1:1.</i> that happened, in the opinion of the Rabbis, before [the eighth day, namely, on the first day of the installation], as I have explained above.<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Above, Verse 2.</i> It is possible that the verse before us which repeats, <i>and the Glory of the Eternal filled the Tabernacle</i> [when it had already stated, <i>and the cloud covered the Tent of Meeting</i>], alludes to the Glory that dwells within it.
Thus is completed the Book of Redemption,<br>In which <i>the Eternal, the G-d of Israel, hath entered</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">Ezekiel 44:2. In the Book of Exodus Israel first appears as a people. Hence Ramban uses this expression: <i>The Eternal the G-d of Israel hath entered</i>.</i>
<i>Even for the children of Israel, a people near unto Him</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Psalms 148:14.</i>
He saved him from the hand of him that hated him,<br>And redeemed him from the hand of his enemy.<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">See <i>ibid.</i>, 106:10.</i>
And blessed be G-d<br><i>Who delighted in the peace of His servant</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ibid.</i>, 35:27.</i>
Who has helped him to come thus far,<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The reference may be personal: “Blessed be G-d Who has helped me to reach so far in my commentary on the Torah.” Or again, it may be that these concluding verses Ramban wrote when already in the Land of Israel. In that case the words assume a literal meaning: “Who has helped him to come thus far,” which is, as he continues, the place where his youth is renewed in his old age. See in “Hamayon,” Tammuz, 5728, pp. 32-6, where I defended this explanation at length.</i>
Who renews his youth<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">See Psalms 103:5.</i> in his old age,
Who satisfies his hunger with His Torah,
<i>And He made him to suck honey</i><sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Deuteronomy 32:13.</i> and the fat thereof.
For he set his whole heart [to seek G-d],<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">See II Chronicles 30:19.</i>
And to His Name he offers blessings morning and evening.
Blessed be He of Whose bounty we have partaken,<br>And through Whose goodness we live.<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">Berachoth 50a.</i>
